text: with the name "Phaeton" on it, it was a pimped-out Town Car stretch limo!

author: player4
text: Yesterday 2004 Volkswagen Phaeton, and yes these things aint sellin they wasted sooo much money building the Phaeton factory for a slow selling vehicle in Europe sales are very low and they are even lower in the US. Also saw a 2005 Ford Focuz ZX5.

author: andys120
text:
Weird! How'd the Phaeton name get attached to these steel roofed cars.

I have seen a couple, one at a dealer, the other in a restaurant parking lot.

OTOH it looks like the Toureg is a big hit for VW. I see them every day now.

author: lemko
text: ...was also used on 1957-58 Mercury hardtops and convertibles. The word "phaeton" has become as corrupted as "roadster" these days - as in those pimpy "roadster" fake convertible roofs on sedans. I recall Ford built cars called "pillared hardtops" in the '70s - a contradiction.

author: andre1969
text:
actually, all of the Big Three offered "pillared hardtops". GM offered a slim-pillar Electra and Ninetey-Eight 4-door in the mid-late 60's. It had frameless windows, but still had a slim B-pillar.

The '73-77 GM intermediates were referred to as "Colonade Hardtops", which was basically just a car with a B-pillar, and frameless windows, even with the 4-doors.

With Ford, they offered "pillared hardtops" in full-sized models in '73-78. The earlier, c1969-72 style had them as well, I believe. And the '72-76 and '77-79 midsized Ford sedans and wagons had frameless windows, but a B-pillar.

I think the only Chryslers that were referred to as "pillared hardtops" were the 1979-81 R-body Newport, New Yorker/5th Ave, St. Regis, and '80-81 Gran Fury. They even had a different code to denote "pillared hardtop" in the VIN code. "41" denoted a 4-door sedan, and "43" denoted a 4-door hardtop. They came up with "42" for the R-body, which denotes "pillared hardtop".

The '95-99 Neon also had frameless windows, and I guess you could call it a pillared hardtop. I don't know how to decode modern Mopar VIN #'s though, so I dunno if they actually used a different classification for it or not.

author: andre1969
text: I know I also saw a '56 Mercury 4-door hardtop with a "Phaeton" badge at a car show once. So evidently they used it more than just 2 years.

author: ateixeira
text:
I see plenty of '05 Focii already. They're all over the place. Perhaps the quickest 2005 model launch out there.

Saw 2 convertible bugs yesterday. The nice weather seems to draw them out.

-juice

author: andre1969
text: 2005 Focuses. I've also seen a few Tauruses that look just a bit different up front than what I'm used to. The grille, instead of being so oval, is squared off a bit on the sides. Is that an '05? And I've seen a few '05 Altimas...I like the look of them.

author: a_l_hubcaps
text:
Andre-

Those Tauruses are '04s (well, they could be '05s too, I think they recently switched over).

Today I saw an '04 Diamante, with that odd new front-end treatment. It makes a little more sense in reality than in the press photos, but not much more.

Also I saw a Scion xB Release Series (orange paint, custom grille). That certainly catches the eye. It was almost the same color as my brother's '77 Celica.

-Andrew L

author: ateixeira

It's neat, also, how they manage without a B-pillar. Much cleaner than the BMW 6's design.

Top down and looking good.

For the money, this is easily a better buy than the base Celica. This car should be a big sales hit for Scion.

author: fintail
text: I saw 4 300s today, all the "lower" models with no chrome wheels, and a Magnum

author: ghulet
text: ...was likely a midrange model, and had a BRA on the front. I thought these ugly things died with the '80s. Yes, they protect from bugs and road rash, but the bra also indelibly stains the paint by trapping dirt and moisture underneath, at least eventually (I know, I peeled the bra off my old '86 SAAB after it had been on for probably ten years and it was a big mess). It's scary that bras are even offered for a brand new model like the 300.

author: andys120
text: those bras have pretty much been supplanted by the 3-M film that's nearly invisibly yet offers good protection against stone chips.

author: andre1969
text:
from the all-Mopar nationals at Carlisle PA, and can now say that I've seen more Dodge Magnums than you can shake a stick at. Rode in one too, on a test drive event.

They also had a pre-production model of the Dodge Dakota, in crew cab form, and the new Jeep Grand Cherokee. Both of them look really nice in person. I was really impressed with the way the Dakota's bed was put together. It makes the Colorado look like crap in comparison! The Colorado's bed is pieced together with several different sections that look like they were finished off with roofing tar out of a tube, and then painted over. In contrast, damn if I could see the seams in the Dakota's bed!

The Dak did look a little sloppy around the headlights and taillights though. Hopefully that was just because of it being a pre-production model!

They also had the Charger concept there. Damn they NEED to build that thing!!!

author: wale_bate1
text:
Which Charger concept? The one from '99-'00, or a new one?

This AM: 645Ci - black/black/black. Came up on its six and from about 100-50 yds back, I thought it was a slammed Eclipse GT! When I got closer, the bustle became more pronounced (flat light this morning), and I recognized it for what it was.

So, from straight on at the back it's not great. From the side is OK; still kind of Sebring-ish to me. Looking in the rearview, I like the front from head-on. Very aggressive and business-like; tough. The rest of the car just doesn't match up.

Still, if someone gave me one...

author: andre1969
text: well, it looked like the same Charger concept that's been floating around for awhile now. Kind of a burgundy/maroon color, low slung, and from the rear slightly evokes memories of the '68-70 model. Very sexy...ME WANT!!

author: wale_bate1
text:
Yeah, that's the '99-'00!

They should've built it. It's a knockout, and unless you knew it was a sedan, you wouldn't know it was a sedan. Genius.

text:
I think I'd rather just have a Mazda 3 if it came down to the choice between that and coughing up another $10k for the Volvo!

Realistically, an S40 vs 3 comparison, take a base S40 at an MSRP of $23,260, vs the 3s with the ABS/Airbag package at $17,935. So it is only about a $5,300 difference at sticker.

The Volvo also did better in crash testing.

author: andyman73
text:
2 GTs...........I don't want to hear it!!! Lucky Cow!

I just spent the past few days at the Delaware shore with some close family friends. They are hosting a 16yr old German exchange student. Anyways, several weeks ago, before he came to U.S. of A., he went on a weekend trip with 2 of his buddies. One of which is 18, legal driving age in Europe. 18 yr old's father had more money than brains and let the 3 teens take his last year made V-8 M5. Now, here's the point of this whole story. They were doing about 120 on Autobahn and they hear this ferocious wailing, coming up fast, on their 6. They moved over and an Enzo went screaming by at least 30 to 40 mph faster than their foot draggin' 120mph. I guess when you live in the land of the Autobahn, you are much more likely to see true exotics.

text:
Maybe if you write to the Ford Company and bet them if the Lions (NFL team they OWN) win the Super Bowl they should give you 1. LoL

I still like my Idea that Ford should put 100 vehicle (for their 100 anniversary) on Ford Field (Home of the Lions), have a raffle with 100 prizes. The 100 people who win would be flow to Detroit and have to stand in the 2 end zones. Then a whistle is blow and every one runs to their car of choice... but the first person to touch the car gets THAT car (but only 1 car per person) and right on the 50 Yd line have 1 GT(40). That would deffinatly top Oprah's show and I would love to see the scrapping to get to the GT(40). Oh yeah if your pushed into a car (or bump into one) that car is your car.

Odie

P.S. - and yes I AM A LIONS FAN

text:
I took a quick drive, and it seemed nice. I'm not really an SUV person (current family car is a minivan), but this one didn't seem particularly "trucky", but still seemed less car-like than a minivan, if that makes sense.

It was comfortable, nice seats, good control layout, etc. The CVT is a bit different, but not enough to really matter. It was more of a novelty, and I robably spent too much time watching the tach while accelerating, but I'm sure once you get used to it, you wouldn't even notice (especially with the radio cranked up!).

It was pretty roomy, but even though it is almost as long as an Ody or SIenna, much less room inside.

The back seat was actually sorta comfy for an adult. I at least had enough head and leg room.

author: a_l_hubcaps
text:
I took a walk down the Springfield PA "auto mile" today. A few comments:

Hyundai Tucson: The interior looked a little disappointing. Obviously I didn't sit in it, but through the windows it looked cheap compared to my mom's Forester and the Mitsu Outlander we test drove recently. The steering wheel and door panels particularly caught my eye as rather cheesy. The exterior styling is nice though -- distinctive without appearing to have been styled by Martians, as is the case with the Santa Fe.

Mercury Montego: The dealer had one of these, in dark red. It was an AWD model with a sticker of almost $29K. It looked pretty nice; the interior was well done and there was nothing ugly or cheap-looking anywhere. I can't help but jump on the "bland" bandwagon, though. I mean, even a Camry has certain stylistic elements (the unique taillight shape, the "hockey stick" indentation in the door bottoms) that set it apart. If you removed the grille and emblems from the Montego, it would look extremely generic.

Ford Focus: I think the '05 restyle was a major improvement. The elimination of the bizarro dashboard couldn't have come too soon. They should have changed the steering wheel, too, though. It is very weird-looking. Also, the sticker prices on the cars on the lot seemed rather high. Many approached $20K. Maybe Ford needs a cheaper car in this market. Speaking of which...

Chevy Aveo: Just a quick note on the new wheel covers for '05: *RETCH*! The '04 ones looked fine. I don't know why they messed with them. Also, if they're going to offer optional alloys on this car, they ought to come up with a design that doesn't look exactly like a wheel cover. I have been collecting hubcaps for 17 years, and I had to get down on my knees and tap on the wheel to determine that it was aluminum and not a cover. I do like the Aveo though. It seems like a nice car for the price.

-Andrew L

author: andre1969
text:
it's a wagon masquerading as one! 1551 mm translates to about 61", which is a far cry from most "real" minivans, which are pushing 70" or taller. Think of it as more a replacement for those old tall Civic wagons, or maybe the continuation of the first-gen Odyssey/Oasis, which was really more wagon than minivan.

I like it, though. The proportioning is lower and wider than the typical minivan, and the ratio of headlight-to-grille-width is just about perfect, IMO. Nice "floating" effect with the horizontal grille bars inset in the trapezoid, and it's nice to see some chrome (plastic or otherwise) tastefully done on a vehicle!

It takes a long time to wean people off what they are used to, no matter how effective the technology is. The CVT is a bit different at first, only because you are expecting one sensation and get another.

author: scscars
text:
I also saw a new STS this weekend. It was being shown at a shopping mall north of Chicago. The fit and finish is better than the Seville, but I must admit, I've never driven the last version of the Seville. The interior is a step up from Devilles. The wood is real this time. According to the sales person, wood accents are eucalyptus--light or dark. This particular car, dark gray with gray leather interior, had dark eucalyptus dash and console trim. While this car bears a resemblance to the CTS, it is longer, wider, and has more street presence. For $50,000, it better have some street presence.

Also saw a new Mercury Montego yesterday, and got a good look at the inside and outside of it. Yes, its a rebadged Five Hundred, however, the interior seems lots more upscale. This one was black with gray leather and beige(?) cloth upholstery. Rear seat room looks bigger than Sable, but not huge. The overall interior design makes more sense than Sable or Taurus and it reminds me of an Audi A6.

Unfortunately, a Montego won't perform like an A6. This particular Montego was saddled with a Duratec 3.0L cranking out 203 HP. If Ford were really remotely serious about competing with Passats, V6 Accords, Camrys, Altimas and the like, they would have taken the 220 HP 3.0L from the Mazda6 and made it available in the Montego and Five Hundred.

author: andre1969
text: that no matter how hard they try, some of the new Malibus will end up in rental fleets. It could just be that the rental company wanted them, and ordered them. Also, isn't that a good way for the new model to get more exposure? Just as long as they're not dumping every blessed one they produce into rental fleets!

author: fintail
text: I saw a black SSR on the road today. First one I've seen being driven and not hogging up space on a lot full of cars that barely sell (relative to the amounts that the dealers take in) anyway.

author: a_l_hubcaps
text:
I don't think it was ever the case that the Malibu was not going to be sold to fleets at all. They are just trying to keep the percentage down. In fact, if you look at the GM ordering guides, there is a special fleet-only package slotted between the base and LS models (equipped like a base, but with a V6 and 16" wheels). That has existed since day 1.

Eventually, they are going to have to phase out the Classic -- it's a creaky old platform and more upscale fleets don't want it. It was just a stopgap measure to keep the Malibus from flooding into the fleets immediately. They are doing the same thing with the Grand Am as the G6 comes out.

By the way, it will be interesting to see who's the loser in this game of fleet-sale reductions. Every company seems to want to reduce fleet sales, but fleet is sort of a fixed demand -- they aren't going to buy fewer cars just because GM, Ford, Chrysler, Mitsu, Suzuki, Toyota etc. don't want to sell them.

-Andrew L

--------

The '96-'03 models with sportier headlights and bigger grilles appealed to me more and Andre's comment on the '04 is right on

author: ghulet
text:
The new one is at least visually interesting, if not exactly attractive. The rear end treatment is a bit scary, the backlight is too small. I really think they tarted it up a bit too much, it's just too flashy.

I don't, in general, understand some of Nissan's decisions of late. Since the Altima is now available with up to 260hp to the Max's 265, I'd think they would have made the Maxima RWD, not only to quell the torque steer, but to distinguish it from the Altima, which is now a bit too similar in size, and when fully loaded, in price. I also don't get the SkyRoof in the Max and Quest. I mean, who wants a full-length, non-opening glass panel in their roof? It's like driving a terrarium. They also need to do a redesign on the Sentra, pronto. That car is ugly and basically non-competitive right now, except maybe if you can get one at a steep discount. I can't remember the last time I even saw one.

author: kyfdx
text:

They might be decent cars, but I just can't get past the styling.. and in general, I'm usually more concerned with how cars drive than how they look... My standards for beauty aren't that high, but Nissans have "last call" looks.. I just don't want to wake up in the morning and see one in my garage.

author: ateixeira

I think most of them are overdone. Actually, not that I think about it, they're all overdone.

Any how, I give Ghosn credit for taking so many risks and revitalizing the product line. Except for maybe the Sentra, none of them are boring, at least.

Guy down the street bought a 4x4, TRD Extended cab. I'm not too fond of the looks. And will anyone ever sell an honest to goodness compact pickup again? This thing has to be comparable to a 1980s short bed half ton in overall dimensions.

-Jason

author: ateixeira
text:
I think the Ranger might be the only small one left, and I'm sure it'll get bigger when they redesign it.

Interestingly, it's still the best selling.

-juice

author: andre1969
text: isn't the Colorado still about the same size in most dimensions as the S-10 that it replaced?

author: ateixeira
text:
It's a little bit bigger. I think they call it a mid-size.

Dakota is huge now. Tacoma is bigger.

Ranger is still small, but that's about it.

If you allow Crew Cabs, the Explorer Sport Trac is still kinda mid-sized. Only the Subaru Baja is truly compact.

-juice

author: andre1969
text:
I just did a comparison check on Edmunds, and I didn't realize what tiny little things the outgoing Tacoma and Ranger were! According to them, the regular cab, short bed Ranger is 187" long, while the '04 Tacoma's only 184"! In contrast, the Colorado's 192" long, and the '04 Dakota is 196".

For '05, the smallest Tacoma's stretched out to 190.4"

author: lemko
text: ...a new Mercury Montego sedan. That car would make a really nice Buick. The grille is classic Buick. All it needs is some portholes and a sweepspear!

author: andre1969
text:
I've only seen one Ford 500, and it was at a dealership in Pennsylvania about a month ago. Haven't seen any out on the streets yet.

Any news yet on how well they're selling? Grbeck and I didn't get a chance to sit in the that night because they were closed, but it looked pretty nice inside, IMO.

author: ateixeira
text:
More than half a foot longer, then. Usually it takes 2-3 generations for a vehicle to grow that much.

Haven't seen any of the new big Fords on the road, surprisingly.

-juice

author: stickguy
text:
I also saw a Tacoma today (was at the dealer and wandered the lot). Passed it by at first, since I thought it was a Tundra, until I saw the taillights. It is big (this was a 4X4), and dwarfed the '04 parked behind it.

Seemed to be a reasonble price, but the rear seat (on the extended cab) looked like a torture chamber. Lots of leg room, just terrible cushions/angles.

author: ateixeira
text:
I think they design the seats to fold out of the way easily, and lie flat against the back wall. Seat comfort is not a priority because I bet they are often empty.

-juice

author: scscars
text: Finally saw a new '05 Mustang on the street today. Silver with black rocker panel stripes. It looked great, even if it was the base model. The '05 is definitely larger than the '94-'04 model and it has a more aggressive stance, very much like a '69 or '70.

author: andys120
text:
The '05 is definitely larger than the '94-'04 model and it has a more aggressive stance, very much like a '69 or '70.

Uh oh! That sends up a red flag to me If there's one thing that ushered in the ruination of the Mustang IMO, it was that it just got too large (around 1970 or so).

author: andre1969
text: it looks like the new stang is about 4" longer than the old one, 187" versus 183". I don't think most people would notice that when driving However, the wheelbase is up about 6", to 107.1", from 101.3", which might make some people take notice. However, the turning circle is actually down, from a Caprice-like 38.7 feet to 36 feet. And weight looks like it's up around 100 lb, which given the current trends in cars, probably isn't too bad. The old Stand was definitely a twister anyway, especially in convertible form, so the new body is most likely much stiffer.

author: scscars
text:
Thanks for the clarification on the '05 Mustang. Like Andys120, I thought that the new Mustang would be bloated like the '71-'73 models, since it was to be built on the same platform as the Lincoln LS, Thunderbird, and Jaguar S-Type (DEW98 platform). In the end, Ford opted to give Mustang its own platform and the result looks like it turned out fine. The '05 does not look to be as large as the S-Type or boxy like the LS.

Andre, you are correct about the body being a lot stiffer. I've been reading that Ford stiffened the body to reduce NVH, and to provide a more solid structure for the 300 HP 4.6L in the GT which has 320 foot/pounds of torque.

author: m4d_cow
text:
I don't think so...did it have dealer plates?

no. now that you mention it, it doesnt have anything more than the lincoln marque on it, no designation model, etc...and tinted windows, making me unable to look at the interior

i gotta keep a camera in my car, in case i see it again next time

author: ateixeira
text:
Yeah, carry those cameras!

Someone in the CR-V thread saw a Mercedes test mule, we think it might have been their new small SUV.

-juice

author: jaserb
text:
I just looked it up, and a Tacoma Double Cab with the long bed is longer than any Tundra shy of the new Double Cab that just came out last year. The new Frontier will be a slightly downsized Titan, the Dakota has always been a big truck and I'm sure the Ranger will grow in its next iteration. I have a hard time believing that nobody would want a compact pickup that can be an inexpensive commuter during the work week and haul around a pair of mountain bikes or a load of mulch on the weekends.

Is the market ripe for Isuzu to come out with a new Diesel P'up?

-Jason

author: kyfdx
text:
Wow... This one was in white...

I don't care that they are big fat pigs.. I'd love to cruise around in one..

author: ateixeira
text:
Good catch, Jason.

How bizarre is that?

But they're not unique. The TrailBlazer EXT is longer than a Tahoe (but not a Suburban obviously).

So what makes a mid-size vs. a full-size? The lines have blurred.

Saw a new RL yesterday, looked nice.

-juice

author: kyfdx
text:
Mercedes CL600

Dodge Viper SRT-10 (with temp.tags)

'05 Mustang... probably see a lot of these soon.

author: 210delray
text: A Ford Five Hundred, actually on the road (not on a dealer's lot). Pretty unexciting to look at, just as everyone's been saying.

author: a_l_hubcaps
text:
I took a walk through some dealership lots this morning, and saw the following:

2005 Chevy Cobalt: The dealer had 2 on the lot, both base sedans. There were also a bunch of 2005 Cavaliers for comparison. The Cobalt definitely had a tighter build quality to it. In styling, it was a toss-up...IMHO, the Cobalt has a nicer front and the Cavalier has a nicer rear. The Cobalt interior looked good and lacked the shapeless '90s look of the Cavalier. The base interior looks plainer than the uplevel one that was shown in the press photos, but it's perfectly acceptable for a $15-16K car, which is where the stickers were on the two I looked at.

Cadillac STS: This thing looks BIG, which in my opinion is a good thing. The old Seville/STS always looked too slim and "flattened" to me. The interior is obviously very nice, though I thought the Caddy emblem on the steering wheel looked cheap...it's just a sticker.

Mercury Montego: They had only one on the lot, and it looked very nice inside and out for a car with a $26K sticker. I would have believed $32K. I think Ford has finally noticed that, if they price cars competetively to start, they don't need $5000 rebates.

Chevy Malibu: I just thought I'd comment that the Chevy place had two long rows of 2004 Malibus still on the lot! Maybe people think they are overpriced or something. They seem like nice enough cars. The same place had sold out of 2004 Impalas and Cavaliers, so it's not like their overall sales were just slow.

Saturn RELAY, Pontiac Montana SV6: I actually saw the RELAY on the road, not at a dealership, so I didn't get a close look at it. Both of these vans look BIG. If they are trying to appeal to large-SUV buyers who don't like "wimpy" vans, this should do it. The SV6 I saw was a loaded model with a sticker around $32K. The interior looked much, much better than the old GM vans. The RELAY I saw was a standard 2 model. It had black bumpers, which looked a little cheap, though they are nice for city parking because they don't start peeling as soon as the paint cracks.

-Andrew L

author: toomanyfumes
text: new malibu a few weeks ago. Very nice driver, lots of power with the V6, And I'm not usually a GM fan.

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw a Phaeton, boy are these rare, a year later I've only seen 2-3.

Still haven't seen any Freestyles or Five Hundreds. Or Montegos, or any of the new GM vans (which are actually kinda narrow).

Maybe I need to get out more! LOL

-juice

author: kyfdx
text:
I saw a new Maserati convertible yesterday... The first one I've seen on the streets..

Also, another Mercedes CL600 and CLK500

author: andre1969
text:
first one I've seen on the streets. It was kind of a light brown color, and actually looked good in that color! One thing I wasn't impressed with, was the fit and finish. Most of the panel gaps were pretty tight, but just looked really uneven. Even one of my friends, who was in the car with me and normally doesn't notice things like this, agreed when I pointed it out. He just said "I wasn't going to say anything, but yeah, it does look pretty cheap close up"

But then again, Mustangs have always been slapped together. Heck, that's part of their charm, isn't it? ;-)

Seriously though, I hope they have their act together on this car, because it looks like it could be a real winner. I'm not even a Ford fan, but this is the first Mustang in ages that has aroused my interest.

author: ateixeira
text:
300hp for $25 grand, yeah, they gotta cut corners somewhere.

I was surprised they kept the live axle.

-juice

author: seminole_kev
text:
was visiting relatives and some of us popped out for a few and stopped by the Ford dealership. Had a new, black 2005 Mustang GT on the showroom floor. Now I've liked the new Mustang's looks in pictures, but in person, this car has something that really makes it look great. Maybe it is just the connection to the past, but it looks really, really good (especially in black in my opinion).

Oddly enough, my wife who has no love for Mustangs, Camaros and Firebirds (except for the early 64.5-66 Mustangs) REALLY liked it. (big surprise to me)

First car in awhile that has "clicked" with me stylewise. From the front on view it looks a lot like a 1969 Mustang. Side profile reminds me more of a 65-66 fastback just with the side vents replaced with windows. Interior looked very nice for a pony car. Nice retro touches inside and out. Dash reminds me a lot of the '66 Mustang I had in high school.

author: jrosasmc
text: On Main Street in my hometown over the weekend I saw a new '05 Dodge Ram SRT-10 pickup (the one with the Viper V-10). Needless to say this truck has caught my fancy, as it is just slick-looking! I also have to comment that I think it has a simple elegance to it, while appearing brutal and powerful at the same time.

author: 210delray
text: ...two C6 Corvettes, both yellow. The exposed headlights make them easy to tell from the C5. Plus the big butt of the C5 has been nicely toned down in the C6.

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw a Phaeton, then a new Odyssey on the way to work today (first on the road I've seen). Looks beefier.

Also saw a new Grand Cherokee yesterday. Too little too late? I hardly noticed it.

-juice

author: kyfdx
text:
Porsche 911 GT (2?, 3?.. something like that). It is the special edition non-turbo with all the racing stuff.. special wheels, suspension, brakes, fixed spoiler, etc.. In a nice gray with tan interior..

Sitting at a side street intersection, then pulled out behind me... Very cool.

author: anythngbutgm

author: ateixeira
text:
Might have been the one from the C&D Supercar shootout.

-juice

"Spotted a Noble M12"

wow thats a rare one, the steering wheel is supposed to be on the right side isnt it?

wow thats a rare one, the steering wheel is supposed to be on the right side isnt it?

You must be near my in-laws, they're in Darien, CT. My brother-in-law lives in Milford. When we're up there we end up on that parkway often.

Saw an STS on the road. With a front license plate to break the monotony of the front bumper, it looks better. Definitely looks better in person vs. in photos.

author: ateixeira

Saw an RS6 here in DC and boy did it look sweet. I realize it's not new but they seem pretty rare.

author: jaserb
text:
saw a new A6 with the monster schnoz. Doesn't look bad at all, IMO.

author: ateixeira
text:
I've seen a lot of Magnums but my wife saw her first up close yesterday. She absolutely hated it, compared it to a hearse, even.

Funny because I think they look cool.

I prefer the old A6. Audi was on top (in terms of styling) so there was no where to go but down.

author: andys120
text:
I spotted a new Buick Allure, the Canadian version of the LaCrosse (it had Quebec plates). How ironic that the first LaCrosse that I see would be the Canadian version, given that the first thing I read about 'em was that GM decided not to use the LaCrosse name in Canada because French Canadians
associate the word with self-gratification (?)

The car I saw was silver and struck me as blandly handsome design that could've been great with a few distinctive touches. I recognized it as a Buick immediately.

author: stickguy
text: saw a new pointiac (G6?) at Target. actually looked kinda good outside (almost Mazda 6-ish). Didn't check out the inside though.

author: i_luv_toyota
text:
I saw a 2005 Pathfinder today. I think it was green, but I saw it during morning twilight, so I can't really be too sure. Looks a bit like the Mazda Tribute in the back, especially the taillights.

The jury is still out on the front end, though...

author: anythngbutgm
text: There is a small furniture store nearby and you'd think that Audi was their company car. The employee parking lot has 2 older S4's, a brand new S4 and an RS6. Those RS6's and new S4's are mean looking. Gorgeous body lines on those.

author: toomanyfumes
text: Ia surpisingly roomy inside. The dash design is nice,too. Not busy like some other Pontiacs. It's almost too dull, lots of grey and flat black in the one I sat in.

author: teds1
text: Well I am new but I saw this and had to make a posting b/c I had a crazy week for sightings. I live in Manhattan where the pickings are ripe, and in the last week I saw a G55, a maybach 57 and a rolls phantom (next to each other)a continental gt (just gorgeous) a maybach 62 parked (and nobody seemd to notice it), an Arnage and a black gallardo on my block. It's fantastic, instead of reading the dupont registry I can just take a stroll down in soho on a sunday. people have too much money here I think

author: ateixeira
text:

-juice

text: I saw an RS6 wagon on Friday night, dark grey, didn't realize they had the wagon here... very cool car, the new a6 looks nice as well, lareger more A8ish and elegant, I saw it from the back though so I couldn't fully absorb the trapezoid grill...

author: andyman73
text: Saw a G55, the other day, that side exhuast looked sweet!

author: kyfdx
text: A gray S2000 with the hardtop on... I love the way roadsters look with the hardtop.. First time I've seen an S2000 this way.

author: alexradu
text:
A wonderful red/black Smart. I absolutely loved it - it was a beauty.

http://www.mercedes-benz.ca/mbccustom/smart/getsmart/

It gets about 3.7L/100km of Diesel in the city. I know it does not fly from 0 to 100, but who cares ? Few people actually need a dragster, right ? :-))

I'm really happy they finally decided to import it here.

author: ateixeira
text:
Very cool, love how open that looks.

I'd seriously consider one. I want an open top commuter to eventually replace my Miata. It has to be small, fun, and efficient.

-juice

author: teds1
text: I saw a blue and Black smart car last night on Amsterdam avenue in Manhattan, I did n't know they were imported yet, I had read there is a gray market guy in California who only does the four seater version but I definitely saw a two. Makes a lot of sense for parking, but can it go highway speeds? does anyone know? what about pricing for the US model?

author: andre1969
text: I went to the Chevy dealer to get a power window switch for my '85 Silverado. It's right next door to a Saturn dealer and a Toyota dealer. Saturn dealer had 3 or 4 Relays sitting out in front. Somehow, they're not quite as bad looking in person as they were in the pictures. Still nothing to get orgasmic over though, IMO...

author: ateixeira
text:
I was driving behind another new Ody yesterday, 2nd I've seen on the road. Supposedly Honda will have more supply this time around so maybe prices won't have markups.

 

-juice

author: m4d_cow
text: a maybach down the I-5, the shorter one (57?), kinda like blueish silver colored. 1st time i see one not in black.

author: alexradu
text: Apparently, from what I've read, they should be able to hold their own on the highways in America, since the speeds here are very low anyway. Of course, in Europe you'd have to keep the first lane, but here how many people drive over 120 km/h ? Because that's what they say is the max maintainable speed of this car. Of course, its purpose is mainly city driving. And, considering how many Navigators and other "buses" I see on the roads in the city, rarely carrying more than the driver and a cellphone.... I think that this kind of transportation should be strongly encouraged by the governments (incentives and so on). Not to mention that it consumes almost nothing (about 4L/100km - with a tank of, say, 30L you'd go almost 800km - if you drive, say, 50km in average perday, you'd have to fill it every two weeks, at a cost of less than 12$)

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw another Ody so I guess they're common now.

 

I also keep seeing a dark blue Phaeton, but I think it's the same one, and I just keep seeing it, because it's always on the same road at about the same time.

 

-juice

author: teds1
text: the LIE is always a fruitful highway for interesting sightings. Last weekend I saw a testarossa, which looks soooo dated now, I can't belive that not that long ago it was the epitome of automotive style and technology. Also a Jag xk-120 trailered with the hard top. It needed some restoration but it was clearly gorgeous. I can't believe Ford hasn't thought about resurrecting something like it. Instead of the potential F type which although nice is a small xk8 you could go for a more retro stlyed 50's roadster in the lower price range.

author: kyfdx
text:
Stretch limo....

 

Really long one.. The car seems perfectly shaped for this application.

author: i_luv_toyota
text:
I finally saw the vehicle I wanted most to see on the roads in motion, a silver 2005 Toyota Tacoma Double Cab 4WD.

 

Looked as good moving as it was standing still!

author: kyfdx
text:
It has been parked near my son's school the last couple of weeks.. brand new, temporary tags.. not garaged.. I think his girlfriend lives in the apartments near there..

 

But, today.... something different.. He now has 22" chrome wheels.. With the corresponding ribbon-thin-sidewall tires. Unreal how someone can spend $80K on a car, then screw it up by spending $3K more!!

author: jaserb
text:
A guy down the street has one. The styling is OK right up until you get to the wheelwells. As bad as the Trailblazer "square" wheelwells are, these are worse. There's a wierd kink at the back, and the more I see it the more it grates on me. Too bad, as I think the Tacomas were about the best looking small trucks from the early '90s up to about 2001 (whenever they put the pseudo-Dodge mean looking grill on it).

 

 
Edit: Here, see for yourself.



-Jason

author: kyfdx
text: I'm not in love with it... I see quite a few every day, as a Toyota parts distribution center is near where I work... All of the managers get company cars.. and they all drive like madmen.. I can barely get around them..;-)

author: andre1969
text: and truthfully, the things still look tiny to me. Okay, so they went from an A-cup to a B-cup, but there's a whole lot more to the alphabet than that! ;-)

author: jaserb
text:
I mean, wheels are round. How do you fill out the wheelwell if the wheelwells aren't round? Somebody needs to take the designer's crayons away for a while.

 

-Jason

author: stickguy
text: just trying to look cool or macho. You see the shape of an H2 lately?

author: jaserb
text:
there was a white H2 in the parking lot here at work today. Covered in moo-cow black spots, with the name of some realtor plastered all over it. Parked in a handicapped space.

 

Now, did it get my attention? Yup. But combine my general opinion of realtors with my opinion of people who drive H2s and my opinion of people who park in handicapped spots and you can guess how likely I am to ever deal with that guy...

 

-Jason

author: kyfdx
text: I saw a new Acura RL today.. first time in person..

author: m4d_cow
text: are common views here (mostly in red or black), along w/ merc c-class, vw passat, civics, and lexus sc430 (very popular in my sisters highschool)

author: seminole_kev
text: but I spotted a new bright yellow Ferrari 360 Modena in Oklahoma City tonight at dinner. Rare sight here.

author: shiphro
text:
In Olde City in Philadelphia, I saw a white G55? The big square MB SUV. Customize with chrome everywhere (blinged out?). Was defintely a vehicle for someone who craves attention.

 

I don't know if it was knew, but it certainly was an unusual ride.

author: chidoro
text: I've seen a Bentley Continental GT twice this past week. Early in the week getting gas and on the weekend he was coming out of my dry cleaning place. Although he was only leaving the parking lot, you could hear how absolutely wicked that engine is. The James Earl Jones of engine sound if that makes any sense.

author: ateixeira
text:
juice chiming in from Brazil!

 

Boy have I seen some unique cars, in fact they're almost all not sold in the US.

 

Fiat Uno, Palio, Strada.

 

Chevy Astra, Celta, Vectra.

 

Peugot 206, 306.

 

Renaults are all over the place.

 

VW Gol (not Golf, Gol), Voyage, Parati, and Saveiro (pickup).

 

Some if the wackier cars I've seen include the Citroen Xsara Picasso, which my brother owns and looks exactly like an egg. So does the Chevy Mariva, you can't tell if it's coming or going!

 

And the SUVs here are diesels, including the Blazer (old model), Hilux (4Runner), and Dakota crew cabs (also old model).

 

Coolest car was my dad's dune buggy, a VW beetle chassis with a fiberglass kit on it. Soooo fun.

 

I'll try to get some pics of my faves and then host them when I get back in January.

 

Later folks.

 

-juice

author: jaserb
text:
Have a good time - Recife, right? I really like all the itsy bitsy pickups like the Saveiro. The US market has pretty much given up on compact trucks, let alone subcompacts.

 

-Jason

author: canuckguy
text:
spotted a nuber of weeks ago the new Honda Ridgeline a 4 door /pickup similar to Honda pielo

sharp looking vehicle more like SUV than truck

due out in the spring.

author: ateixeira
text:
Yeah, I'm in Recife now.

 

Saveiro is the VW pickup, 2 seats, truly compact. Now that US compacts are really mid-size, you wonder if there would be room for these.

 

Chevy has one called the Montana. It's based on the Opel Corsa sub-compact. But the bed is pretty long, more so than a Baja or most of the Crew Cabs, at least.

 

They carry a payload of about 500kg, or about 1100 lbs, not bad. Subaru Baja only has 800 lbs.

 

-juice

author: teds1
text: I got a chance to check out a parked a6. I like it much better than the old one which never really did it for me as an audi fan. The trapezoid grill is pretty crisp and looks better than in pictures. the proportions are better and I like the thin chrome trimlines. Interior look veeeery nice as well. Very spacious back seat but the A6 has always had that compared to a 5 series or E. It was also parked next to a 993 (I think thats the code for the last water cooled models) carrera 4s, my Favorite 911 iteration by far so it was a good sighting

author: ateixeira
text:
On the opposite end of the scale for VW/Audi, I saw a relatively new original Beetle. They made those here until recently, although I think Mexico has even newer ones.

 

-juice

author: andys120
text:
of a couple of '05 models I haven't seen before and only caught a quick glimpse of as they cruised down a busy street:

 

-Audi A6 3.2 Sedan, big-mouth grille and all, otherwise looking very much like a new A8.

 

-BMW 645i Coupe, looking a little porky from some angles but basically pretty attractive as befits it's heritage.

 

Both were more attractive than photos would suggest they'd be.

 

Parenthetically I'm astounded by the apparent popularity of the controversial BMW Seven series in the NYC-LI area, they seem to far outnumber Mercedes S class, Audi A8 or even Lexus LX430s.

 

Perhaps they stand out more since they don't look much like any other Bimmer.

author: ghostbuster23
text: I saw a Nissan NX Sportback. The wagon version of the Pulsar NX. It looked very robotic or space shuttle-ish. Pretty cool.

author: m4d_cow
text: saw a white M5 with orange underbody neon lights, i thought thats illegal, right?

author: ateixeira
text:
Might vary by state, but I think that is illegal around here.

 

-juice

author: ghulet
text:
...they should be, or at least morally unjust, on an M5!!

 

Last night, when leaving for work, parked in front of my place was a brand new Mazda6 S V6 5-speed hatchback sedan, in charcoal gray. It was as though someone ordered it for me, it was exactly as I'd like one. I'll have to find out who it belongs to.

author: teds1
text: On 87 northbound NY state thruway on Friday 31st of January I saw a test mule of the new 06 (?) Mercedes M-class. It was covered in the standard black cladding but you could makeout the new shape. It has a smaller emblem up front and sleeker lines. Think a hybrid of the current model with the original rx 330 and a little nissan murano. It's about time becaus ethe current editions are dated to say the least and were recently rated the worst vehicles to own by a British magazine. The best part was that the prototype was bing issued a ticket by a trooper when I passed it so I guess it is fast

author: scape2
text: all band new! On the way home from work today I spoted 3 pontiac G6's today. At first I thought they were some sort of new Acura. Colors were silver, black and red. These are nice looking vehicles. The Black one was of obvious higher level trim. I feel Pontiac will sell plenty of these with no problem...

author: stickguy
text: I saw a G6 recently in the Target parking lot. Actually didn't realize what it was, and went over to take a look. Nice exterior, and the interior seemed to be a big improvemet (although the baseline was set pretty low!).

author: andys120
text:
in my 2000 528iA(E39). I find that I'm starting to warm up to the styling of the E60s. I still like the E39s better and I think the shape of the head and taillights are overdrawn but in the right color the new ones are good-looking in their own way.

 

Like a lot of new designs it owes a lot to Audi, especially the side view.

author: fintail
text: I am seeing at least one Ford 500 a day now...they seem to be selling. Are they going to fleets or are more cutting-edge Crown Vic folks moving out of the 60s?

author: andys120
text: I saw one yesterday that was obviously a fleet car belonging to a state agency.

author: ateixeira
text:
Oddly enough I haven't seen the Five Hundred or the Freestyle, yet plenty have sold. What gives?

 

-juice

author: teds1
text: They are so boring you probably didn't notice. You probably thought they were Passats and explorers. The only guy I know who has a 500's Mom owns a dealership and he is driving it for free right now.

author: 210delray
text: Unless you're up close and see one from the side. I haven't seen a Freestyle yet.

author: scape2
text: The 500 is "boring" yet the class leaders like the Toyota Camry and Honda Accord are not? Now these two cars have no soul or lines of distinction whatsoever..

author: m4d_cow
text:
actuallly imo the accord and camry are just as boring

i think i saw a freestyle once, quite a rare one around here.

author: ateixeira
text:
Well, they're not new, so of course they're not being mentioned in this thread.

 

Subaru had a record year in 2004, best ever, due largely to the new Legacy and Outback. So don't be surprised to see lots of those around, especially in the snow belt.

 

-juice

author: ghulet
text: ...you're not going to mistake a Camry or Accord for anything else, IMO, but the Five Hundred doesn't have any styling cues (good or bad) to distinguish them from the likes of the Passat (which is currently in its EIGHTH year with this body style).

author: m4d_cow
text: true that, yet the passat is still good looking even now.

author: ghulet
text:
....the Passat is still nice looking, just no longer ground-breaking, so the Five Hundred just looks like what it is, an imitation. Nice looking car, still.

 

Saw my first new Mustang (I think it was a non-GT, it had the smaller alloys and a rear spoiler, which I think ruins it) today, parked at the supermarket.

author: andys120
text:
I saw a new E500 Parked on a downtown street and took a few minutes to check it out. The car was Steel Blue with light beige upholstery and it was beautiful.

 

I thought it was so nice looking that I'm not sure how you could justify the expense of an S class, it's hard to tell them apart IMO. I notice a similar thing when I saw the TV ads for the new A6, it looks just like an A8.

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw 3 different RLs this weekend. Must be off to a good start.

 

-juice

author: stickguy
text:
there has been a "Stang V6 at the local rent a dent type rental place for quite a while now. Always seems to be out front when I go by (every week or 2). Red, looks quite nice actually.

 

Can't wait to sit in one at the car show. The convertible is real nice looking...

author: m4d_cow
text:
i spotted an M3 csl for the 1st time in the states, silver grey on black

i got the chance to test drive this vehicle last year in germany, 370 ponies, goes 0-60 in 5 secs flat (the best i could get), i got 262 kph on top speed, and handlings as sharp as it can be.

the downside: harsh suspension, horribly noisy thanks to its screaming engine and 19"wheels combined w/ low profile tires, thinly padded seats uncomfy even on shorter rides.

great car? indeed, worth the cash? not for me

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw a Ford Five Hundred, finally, my first on the road.

 

I see dozens of new Odysseys, those got out quickly.

 

-juice

author: andys120
text:
I saw a new Mazda 6 four dr in front of a dealer in a color I'd never seen on any car. I pulled in to see what the color was called and the name on the Monroney read "Pebble Ash Metallic".

 

I have no idea what color Pebble Ash is, in fact I don't know what it is. The color was a beige with green, gold and gray hues in it, very cool.

author: ateixeira
text:
They had that or a similar color in 1996, the year after we bought our 626.

 

-juice

author: scott1256
text:
I have seen several Ford 500s and one Montego on the road.

  

I have not had Ford on my radar screen for years - but these cars are impressive. Attractive, well fitted interiors with understated/classy looks.

  

And....41.3" of rear seat legroom! That keeps 6'0"+ passengers comfortable for hours.

  

The 250+ HP engine will add to the appeal when it becomes available

author: ateixeira
text:
J Mays brought over the Audi look with him, also. But it's a shame they're not more original, they're too copy-cat.

 

Price/size ratio is quite good.

 

-juice

author: andre1969
text:
the new Ford 500. It has to endure my usual whine of "I wish the seat went back further", but truthfully that's the case with most vehicles these days, I find. Gone, I guess, are the days when I would reach out as far as I can with my left foot and still just barely touch the firewall. Although, strangely, I can do that with the new GTO!

 

The back seat was nice and comfy, though.

author: andys120
text: Those adjustable pedals don't help Andre?

author: andre1969
text:
I forgot that these cars had adjustable pedals! My bad ;-)

 

Anyway, I really didn't get a good feel for how one of these cars would fit me, because the power was disconnected to the 500 at the auto show. I sat on the passenger side, which was manual fore/aft, to at least get a rough idea.

 

I am kinda curious, sometime, to actually try out a fully functioning 500 to see how it feels.

author: ateixeira
text:
I can explain that - the GTO chassis dates back to a 1993 Opel, so basically it was designed in the days you recall with nostalgia. ;-)

 

-juice

author: andre1969
text: and I'll confess, that while I haven't really paid much attention to the new GTO, because of the bland looks, once I sat inside one I really got to like this car! In the end, I'd just prefer something with a bigger back seat and a bigger trunk.

author: kyfdx
text: but..enough about your girlfriend.. lol

author: paul182
text:
I just saw a 2006 Volkswagen Jetta in Mankato, MN.

It had dealer plates. Just thought people may be interested.

author: Kirstie_H
text: I saw one last Friday cruising I-70 from Missouri to Illinois, with Illinois dealer plates. Big difference from the old Jetta.

author: kyfdx
text: Good? Bad? What????

author: Kirstie_H
text:
I haven't decided. Interestingly, as I was following this car (the new NEW Jetta), it pulled up alongside a Jetta of the same color, but an older model (the old NEW Jetta). The new Jetta appeared somewhat larger, and the back end is definitely reminiscint of recent Toyota styling (See: Camry, Corolla).

 

I had a 2000 VR6, and I was a fan of the square-ish styling. So, initially, it's not my cup of tea. But if it's as fun to drive as earlier versions, I could forgive the change.

 

I guess I don't want to be one of these people who believes that a model should look like it's always looked. I want to be open to letting change grow on me.

 

kirstie_h

Roving Host

Host, Future Vehicles & Smart Shopper discussions

author: kyfdx
text:
I'd have to agree with the Corolla analogy.. and that is NOT a good thing..

 

I'm a real fan of VW design.. just not sure I could bear owning one, considering their penchant for being in the shop...

author: Kirstie_H
text: I had my '00 for two years - allegedly a model year riddled with a variety of electrical issues. It didn't spend a single day in the shop. Sometimes you get lucky.

author: paul182
text: I thought the "new" Jetta looked okay. One thing that will take some getting used to is the front of the vehicle; the nose of the car really sticks out in front.

author: stickguy
text:
Motor Trend came yesterday, and there is an article about the new Jetta. I didn't read the piece, but checked out the pictures. Does nothing at all for me. Ugly nose, bland Corolla-ish tail, looks kinda large and lumpy.

 

Just don't think it is going to be a hit with the buyers that made the old one popular, and the older crowd would probably go with a Passat instead (that one looked better in the pics).

author: ateixeira
text:
I don't get why VW is doing the same thing as Audi is with the huge front grille. I had figured they'd hedge their bets or at least try to distinguish the two brands more.

 

Jetta looks Japanese, doesn't it? It lost some Euro character. It is a whopping 7" longer, but I still wouldn't call the rear seat roomy.

 

I too much prefer the Passat.

 

-juice

author: jif
text:
sat in one the other day

 

it is kind of a weird car.

 

the lines are attractive when you view it from the side but i don't think i could live w/ the head lights ( like s-class w/ it's face stretched back)

 

also the side windows are so short it almost looks like the top is chopped.

 

rear seat is very tight to get in and out of

 

and the sticker 65k base but w/ options around 75k plus dealermarkup of 5-10k

 

i would rather have a s-430 or e-500 4matic for around the same price

 

but what do i know

author: teds1
text: you are totally right... it is a very weird looking car, just swoopy enough that you almost want to say it looks good but not quite. Kind of like the new slk, which is a great improvement and still looks good but is missing something. I saw both for the first time at a special MB pre NY auto show preview near my office. The cls was a wood mock up (same one thay had at the show BTW)so I couldn't get in it but I think it looks odd, especially in the forest green they had... yuck. I worry as well about stretching your customer base too thin along too many product line extensions. Does anyone really need something between an E and an S? Especially something with questionable looks and a high price tag. I guess b/c it shares a lot of parts it was worth the gamble for them. If you want an MB coupe get the still gorgeous C. or the comparative bargain CLK, which although not as flashy, is a classy looking car.

author: ateixeira
text:
I like it, it's very low.

 

I think it's for people that only take passengers on occasion, not all the time. It's supposed to compete with the BMW 6 coupe, for instance.

 

Saw a new Five Hundred, then an SLK350, then a new Ody today.

 

Someone here at work has an SLK350 on order and has been waiting since Fall, still waiting.

 

-juice

author: fintail
text: I saw one of those Chevy Uplander or whatever they are called "new" vans today. They've got to be joking. The grafted on new front end does not work, it is disjointed and just plain odd. Come on, GM.

author: andys120
text:
Acura RLs a few minutes apart so it looks like they'll be popular here on Lawn Guyland where I'm visiting.

 

Nice looking cars.

author: rsx-sfan
text: Oh yeah. RLs look great. I've been seeing a lot my- self. I also saw a Buick Terraza and a Pontiac Relay and yikes! They have something wrong with the front facsia. It's too slabbed for a mini- van. I've also seen a few Cobalts, which look nice, but I can't wait to see a Cobalt SS.

author: ateixeira
text:
I see RLs all the time here, they must be off to a good start. Saw one this morning.

 

-juice

author: ghulet
text:
I saw a new RL the other day, in a strange green color, the car looks better than in photos. I think this thing will now be an honest contender versus the likes of Es and 5-series.

 

I also finally saw an SSR (black), which I've heard is already being discontinued(?). I was a bit surprised to see it in any case, February on the north side of Chicago isn't exactly the time/place one typically sees a $40k, RWD, convertible, sport-truck thing.

author: teds1
text: I have a hard time spotting them as I find the roofline too similar to the accord. there must be more in manhattan than I've seen yet. Sounds like a wonderful car though with that super handling awd system and relatively low price. the TL was such a great car for the price as well and looked much better than the rl but that fwd killed me. I think they should have saved the tl design, stretched it a bit and given it to the RL. Probably would have made a much bigger splash

author: ateixeira
text:
SSR got a bigger V8 this year, it's still being made at least for MY2005.

 

-juice

author: logic1
text:
Ghulet:

 

Too weird! I saw a yellow SSR on the North Side [of Chicago] the other day. It was pretty shiney. Maybe the owner just took it out for a bath.

 

I also saw a spanking new black Aston Martin near the Board of Trade Building. Wow! Those look nice.

author: chidoro
text: I saw a smart car on the garden state parkway on my way to work yesterday morning. It was black with a silver rear pillar swoop paintjob. It passed me so he must have been going at least 70ish.

author: ateixeira
text:
Cool sighting.

 

Was it a 2 seater or 4 seater?

 

I sat in the tiny Brabus roadster at NAIAS, it was cramped but soooooo cool.

 

-juice

author: ateixeira
text:
Pic:

 

http://www.imagestation.com/album/pictures.html?id=2132269877&amp- ;idx=72

 

I could barely squeeze into that thing. The seat was very low so it takes an effort.

 

-juice

author: chidoro
text: I am pretty sure it was the 2 seater. There was no b pillar so it could only have 2 doors. It's hard to oggle for long on the north end of the GS Pkwy because it's so busy.

author: Kirstie_H
text: You should share your Sky photo in the Sky forum - only pic I've seen thus far.

author: ateixeira
text:
So you saw the ForTwo. Cool.

 

They keep thinking about bringing it here. To be honest I think they would need some help, maybe cheaper parking like is offered in Europe.

 

Kirstie - will do.

 

-juice

author: ateixeira
text:
Hmm, thread link?

 

I didn't see Sky under Saturn, nor did I see it under Future Models.

 

-juice

author: Kirstie_H
text:
Looks like we just got the category updated:

http://townhall-talk.edmunds.com/direct/view/.ef57f0e

author: fintail
text: I finally saw CLS in the flesh today. It's an unusual thing. The one I saw had Designo trim with matte finished wood and nice perforated leather. Sticker = $75K. Here are some cellphone pics:

author: andyman73
text:
When I first saw it in the rags, I thought, wow, kinda funky, I'd drive it. I'd even be willing to pay for it. But can't afford that kind of scratch.

 

I like the swoopiness and low slung look. Make mine an AMG please.

author: andyman73
text: On the way to work this evening I passed an xA 1.0, looked sharp, like it should have been made that way all along.

author: fintail
text:
The CLS was nicer looking than I had expected based on photos. The swoopiness works. It's not very large inside though, it really is a coupe in interior proportions. My SWB 126 and even the fintail seem a lot bigger inside. Frameless door windows are a first for a modern MB sedan too, as far as I know. Very nice interior. It needs to be bright inside, as the windows are really short.

 

I think I could spend 75K better, though.

author: teds1
text: I Saw a couple of STS's for the first time this weekend. They looked pretty good, and I'm not a huge fan of the industrial art and design thing Caddilac has going. It fits this sized sedan best of anything I've seen yet though out of them. Meaner looking than a cts or srx. The DTS pictures I've seen though look disapointing. they are looking for the same old tired geriatric demographic with that one. They could be selling a dynamic looking less expensive competitor to the s, 7, xj set and make a mint but they made a sharp angular looking buick instead

author: ateixeira
text:
CLS is so low, you have to see it in person to understand the scale. My opinion of it improved a lot.

 

-juice

author: fintail
text: I saw my first Buick Lacrosse on the road today, or at least the first one I have noticed. Being a GM sedan, of course it was a rental car. It's new, but it'll attract the same Century/Regal set.

author: anythngbutgm
text: I've got 2 neighbors with new Avalons. One Ltd (White) and one XLS (Light blue). Interesting, because the one with the Limited just had a brand new Lacrosse for a month or two before hand... Pretty sharp looking, though I would not be in the market for something so large.

author: ateixeira
text:
They had a loaded one at the mall, I dunno, it was over $30k street price. Seemed a bit steep. I've seen about two on the road so far.

Avalon does look improved. I've seen one or two, but of course I live near a Toyota dealer.

-juice

author: erics6
text: Saw my 1st Lotus Elise on the road today. Very nice!!! It was night. Tailights looked very Ferrari like. Looked like a bumpy ride too. Hmmm... do I have a spare 50k for a impractical but fun car?

author: 210delray
text:
Saw my first one today, in beautiful bright blue.

I can see why they're sold out for a year or so.

Texas vanity plates, "Crewe."

author: lemko
text: ...black Mercury Montego on Rhawn St. near Veree in Philadelphia.

author: ateixeira
text:
I would not mind spotting an Elise in my driveway!

-juice

author: jaserb
text:
Every bit the abomination I imagined. I honestly have no idea what you would use that dorky little pickup bed for.

-Jason

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw one of those the other day, also. But just one so far.

They didn't take off like the original H2 did.

Saw a Five Hundred on the road this AM.

-juice

author: teds1
text:
There is a hospital near my office
(in NYC) that always has the Docs cars out front with special dashboard signs permitting them to park. There is a changing cast of cars with the same black D.A.R.E PA plates which have to all belong to the same guy. He has by my count, a Black new Viper (replacing his old grey GTS coupe, the 06 Vette convertible in orange, a cayenne, and an SUT. Must be nice... except for the SUT bit. What a useless piece of crap. The only person I know who likes this thing is an insane right wing Nam Marine vet and even he prefers the wagon version. Plus driving that thing into the city from PA must cost like $80 a trip. Crazy

author: 210delray
text:
I spotted the huge bulging hood first and then saw the "SRT" script on the quarter panel.

The driver pulled out of a crossroad without stopping as I was approaching...far enough away that there was no danger of colliding.

author: bksward
text: Saw a car carrier on I-405 heading south from Long Beach with 4 new M45s yesterday afternoon.

author: turboshadow
text:
Saw a black version of Honda's new pick-'em-up. Looks like a 7/8 scale Avalanche, the naked one that is.

Not bad looking, but not worth 30K, IMHO.

Turboshadow

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw a couple of Equinoxen on the road. Is that the plural form of Equinox?

-juice

author: jaserb
text:
Sometimes a vehicle looks better in the flesh than in pictures? This was the opposite. The rump end especially looks awkward and ungainly. Then again, that's not my best side either, so maybe I shouldn't be talking...

-Jason

author: 210delray
text: Aren't the prettiest in my opinion. They look like a throwback to the late 50s and early 60s. This is one instance where retro doesn't work.

author: andys120
text:
There is a hospital near my office
(in NYC) that always has the Docs cars out front with special dashboard signs

A friend's Dad worked in St. Luke's and stopped wearing MD plates cuz it was an invitation to
break-ins (junkies looking for drugs).

------
I think I saw a Freestyle, they're hard to tell from Explorers being basically 7/8th scale replicas that ride a little lower.

author: ateixeira
text:
New Pathy does look a little strange. We'll get used to them soon enough.

-juice

author: bhill2
text: Well, I like your suggestion of Equinoxen as a plural.

author: fintail
text:
Reverse C-pillar = Rambler Cross Country, which is fitting seeing as a Pathfinder and Armada (and other SUVs) are big jacked up station wagons at a masquerade party.

It's not a new car, but I am seeing Aveos every day now. Someone is buying them. I think.

author: andys120
text: Maybe in Canada, Fin, they're pretty rare around here but small cars of all kinds are more common up your way..

author: ateixeira
text:
They're rare here around DC.

-juice

author: fintail
text: I think some of them might be rentals, but I know of 2 where I work alone. Kind of odd, but they are just about the only new tiny cheap car.

author: ghulet
text: ...they do have a cheap base price (US $9995 for the strippo hatch), but by the time they're equipped for human consumption (A/C and stereo), I think their price must approach that of a Scion xA, Focus or base Corolla. Plus, reviews of the Aveo (both published and by consumers) say it gets lousy fuel economy for a car its size (unlike the Metro it replaces). So, where's the upside?

author: fintail
text:
I saw maybe 5 or 6 of them out on the road today, all but one the pudgy little sedan, which is IMO the worst looking one of the pair.

I've also seen several Cobalts now.

author: rsx-sfan
text: I saw a new Avalon driving around. I like the fron end but the back kinda looks bad. I also saw a Benz CLS with black 19" rims. The CLS was really nice, better than the pictures I've seen.

author: lemko
text: ...new silver Mercury Montego.

author: ateixeira
text:
I've seen a couple of Avalons also. Looks much better now.

Odys are all over the place now.

-juice

author: chidoro
text:
...they do have a cheap base price (US $9995 for the strippo hatch), but by the time they're equipped for human consumption (A/C and stereo), I think their price must approach that of a Scion xA, Focus or base Corolla.

I think people are getting OTD prices w/ AC and stereo for under 8k. MSRP is a starting point but it's certainly not the price people end up paying.

I finally saw the new RL about a week ago. In fact, I saw two different RL's the same day and not once more since then.

The Continental GT I've seen around is definitely from someone in my neighborhood. He eats at the same deli every saturday afternoon around the time I do my dry cleaning in the same strip. It really is a beautiful car and this is coming from someone one is not a real fan of coupes, even luxo coupes

author: odie6l
text:
I'm afraid that I'll have to wait and see a Freestyle on the road when I end up buying one...lol. Everytime I think I see one it's a some other car. I swear they should call owners of the Freestyles U.F.O (Unidentified Freestyle Owners).

Odie

author: ateixeira
text:
I don't see them often either. I think I've only seen one or two so far! And there is a Ford dealer 2 miles from my house.

Slow launch? I saw one article that said Ford underestimated demand for the Haldex AWD.

-juice

author: andys120
text: Ford expected about 40% of Freestyle and 500 sales would be AWD models but IIRC the demand level is more like 50% right now.

author: andys120
text:
a Mazda6 at a stop light and noticed the small seam at the top of the rear window that let's you know it's the five door hatch. That has to be the most completely disguised hatch ever made, it looks nearly identical to it's four door
counterpart.

author: ateixeira
text:
Very sleek, I think. You lose some rear headroom, but noone would know it's a hatch.

-juice

author: seminole_kev
text:
..Couple of thoughts.

The new Acura RL looks much better in person than what I had seen in photos.

New VW Jetta is hideous. Real step backwards. Looks like a VW built Corolla.

I'd chew my own ears off if it would get me a Ford GT (as in the GT-40, not the Mustang...which I do like as well though).

New Lexus GS, ugh. Do not like that fat bottomed Maxima look. Same to the new Avalon's rear (though not as bad as the GS).

Don't care for the back half of the new Jeep Grand Cherokee. Just a little awkward looking.

New Audi A6 didn't look as bad as I had feared from photos. Looks much larger than the previous version.

..Oh, and Andre, I saw the new Dodge Charger. It is different looking, but it isn't ugly to me. It does stand out in a sea of generic sedans, which is good. Like the front. The butt is a little off though. Much better than I had feared.

author: seminole_kev
text: ..but the new Honda Ridgeline is beyond ugly. Wow. That thing could stop a clock.....just ugly. Of course that is just my opinion, but.......wow. Just bad looking.

author: ateixeira
text:
Wild, I spotted a new Golf driving in Bethesda, MD, this weekend.

What's strange is that it did not have diplomatic or manufacturer's plates. We're near the capital so I see diplomatic plates all the time.

I don't think the Golf is due here until early next year, so that was quite a shocker.

-juice

author: ateixeira
text:
Wild, I didn't expect to see these so soon after their auto-show debut, but I followed a GS300 AWD on the way home today.

Looks good in person, better than photos. It's longer than it looked, pretty sleek. It just flows better in person.

AWD is a sweet addition, too.

Complaint - the rims looked way too small, fender gaps are huge. Looks built to handle a Plus Two or so.

-juice

author: davem2001
text: Saw one on the road today, red with a black top...it's still sorta cold where I live....the top was UP, the driver wasn't frozen solid!

author: odie6l
text:
I saw a Mustang Conv. today pulling out of a local Gas Station (with top down and 42 degrees out). It was a dark grey color....really nice looking to.

Odie

P.S. - Still waiting to see the Freestyle driving around, local dealer has 15 on its lot. Guess I'm gonna have to try the Jedi Mind Trick on my wife (even though it hurts me to get rid of my Escape).

author: ateixeira
text:
Wild, I saw one yesterday. V6 coupe, with some vinyl graphics on the side.

Saw another Ody today, they're all over the place.

-juice

author: lemko
text: ...sort of an orange-red Chrysler Crossfire.

author: jaserb
text:
Porsche Carrera GT. It was extremely yellow, which made it seem more exotic than the silver I've seen in pictures. It was parked in the same spot I generally see either a 356 or a 968 cabrio.

-Jason

author: ateixeira
text:
I went to the Brazilian Embassy today, and I usually see some cool cars on Embassy Row (Mass Ave in DC). No such luck!

-juice

author: fintail
text: Not so unusual anymore, but every day for the past week I have seen a loaded looking Cobalt sedan drive up my street...dark blue with deluxe wheels and I believe a small spoiler. Sure beats the plastic hubcap strippers (not a single deluxe model to be seen) sitting on the Chevy lot.

author: teds1
text: I was down in Destin FL this weekend for business (panhandle near Pensacola) and I saw a bunch of nice and rare stuff. Hundreds... and I mean hundreds of new mustangs every color and decal combo but no convertibles. Old ones too Boss 302's etc... I saw a black panoz esperante, tre rare, a navy Maseratti Quattroporte, a pair of prowlers (not that they are cool), a whole club of corvettes mixed years, and an e-type Jag. It is a resort area so I guess there is money, but that seemed like a lot for 3 days. Nice spot on the carrera GT above by the way... are you in TX? I heard there is a yellow one there

author: ateixeira
text:
Must've been a club meet of some sort going on? They aren't that many on the roads yet.

-juice

author: jaserb
text:
Don't laugh - I've seen an Enzo in the parking lot of the local mall, and driving down the main drag in town, I'm sure the Enzo is Richard Losee's car, the one that was in the Road and Track article.

-Jason

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw another GS on the road. I gotta say the RL/GS/M comparo would be fun to do. All are significantly better than their predecessors.

Costlier, too, though.

-juice

author: stickguy
text:

Today I spotted them setting up with an original Maybach (the pre world war II kind), some 70s concept car in orange that looked like a delorean with gullwing doors, the new M class, and Coolest by far the CLK DTM. That is the 583 bhp, 100 examples only, not sold in the US, ultra hot CLK which makes you question the value of the SLR. author: andre1969
text:
was always a bit funny because of the dealer network up there. Instead of having standalone Chevy, Pontiac, Buick, and Olds dealers like what used to be the norm in the US before GM started to decline, in Canada they paired Chevy up with Buick (or was it Olds?) Well, whichever one got paired up with Chevrolet, Pontiac got paired up with the other.

As a result, Pontiac became more of a clone of Chevy, rather than a step up. And in many ways it became like Plymouth, which could never get too upscale for fear of stealing the thunder from the Chryslers they shared the showroom floor with.

Most of the smaller Canadian Pontiacs were just clones of Chevies, with slightly different grilles meant to suggest a Pontiac. For example, a Pontiac Beaumont was a Chevy Chevelle with a Pontiac-ish looking grille. But it had a Chevy interior and sheetmetal, and not Tempest/LeMans sheetmetal/interior.

Where it got weird though was with the full-sized Pontiacs. They used Chevy engines and the shorter Chevy wheelbase, but then used Pontiac interiors and sheetmetal. So a 1969 Canadian Pontiac Parisienne actually looked like a 1969 US Pontiac Bonneville at a quick glance, but overall rode a wheelbase 6 inches shorter, and was about 10 inches shorter overall.

At some point though, they started importing the "real" Pontiacs like the Catalina and Bonneville to Canada, to sell alongside the home grown models. And by the time downsizing hit in 1977, it eliminated any differences in wheelbase between a Chevy and Pontiac anyway, so the cars became much more similar, although I think they were using Chevy 250's, 305's and 350's instead of Pontiac 301's, 350's, and 400's.

author: davem2001
text:
The Grand Am (and Old Calais and Buick Somerset Regal) were the N platform - first came out in 1984 (85 MY)

The Corsica/Beretta were the L platform - first came out in 1987/88.

author: andre1969
text:
They actually went through the effort to rename the Corsica/Beretta as the "L" body? It was the same underneath as the N-body. But GM did things like that. Back in the 80's, the only real difference between the FWD C- and H-body was that the C- had a more upright C-pillar and the back seat was further back, giving it more rear legroom, but a bit less trunk space. The Seville from 1980 onward was just a 4-door Eldorado/Toro/Riv, but it carried a different designation..."K", versus "E".

The N-body was actually derived from the J-body (Cavalier, et al), riding a slightly longer wheelbase (103.4" versus 101.2"), and being about 5-6" longer, overall. They were originally released only as 2-doors, which might seem odd, but GM's reasoning for that made sense, at least a few years earlier. Back when these cars were first being designed, everyone was afraid that $3.00 per gallon fuel was going to be the norm, and even the radically downsized late 70's era GM cars were still too big.

Believe it or not, these N-bodies were originally slated to replace the RWD Regal, Cutlass Supreme, Grand Prix, and Monte Carlo! In fact, if you notice, the 3 N-bodies that were released for '85 were named after high-spec versions of the GM RWD coupes. Somerset and Calais were originally sporty versions of the Regal and Cutlass Supreme. They didn't have bigger engines or more hp, but usually had bucket seats, floor shifts, t-tops, alloy/rallye wheels, etc. And the Grand Am was one of Pontiac's last attempts at a muscle car (the '73-75 moreso than the '78-80) Once fuel prices eased off and the gas was flowing again, GM held off on axing the RWD coupes, and instead tried to pit these things as something of a BMW fighter, an upscale compact. And with the X-body being pulled after 1984 (Omega/Phoenix) and '1985 (Citation/Skylark), that was going to leave GM without a compact 4-door, so 4-door N-bodies were released for '86.

The X-body was the basis of the FWD A-body (Celebrity/6000/Century/Cutlass Ciera), which lasted from '82-96, and probably would have gone on longer if more stringent side impact standards weren't looming in the near future.

But, when I got up close, I noticed it was "creamy", but not so "pale".. That is when I came up with "butter".

author: davem2001
text:
Yep - those cars were designed with the thought that gas would be $2, $3 a gallon - they were meant to replace the RWD Grand Prix, Cutlass, Regal...

Same as the Eldorado, Toronado, and Rivera that came out around the same timeframe (MY 86)...they were all built on the premise that gas prices would be sky high.

author: andre1969
text:
that GM couldn't have given the E/K body a reprieve, once they figured out that gas prices were going up. As it was, I think the '85 Riv, Toro, Eldo, and even Seville hit record, or near-record sales, as people realized this would be their last chance to get a big 'un. That should have been a hint to GM right there.

But then again, maybe not. IIRC, sales of the mammoth '76 Ninety Eight and Electra hit record, or near record sales, as people rushed to buy the last of the big ones. But when the small '77's hit the market, sales soared to even loftier heights.

Eventually, the E/K body would have to have been redesigned, but I'm sure they could have gotten at least a few more good years out of it. And once GM started getting a bit more serious with its engines, such as improving the 3.8 V-6, and ditching the Caddy 4.1 for the more reliable 4.5 and 4.9, performance of these cars would have improved.

author: davem2001
text: Well, again, as we always say, GM is too slow to react... if they could move more quickly, yeah, they could have just scrapped or delayed the '86 E/K and kept on building the old ones for another 3,4 years... Just like they kept on building the old RWD "A" sedans (Pontiac Bonnevile, Buick Regal, etc..) they just renamed them "G" when the FWD "A" came out. It would have been cheaper and more profitable for them just to keep on building the '79-'85 E for a few more years...

author: navigator89
text:
This high school is the American School of Kuwait. You find some pretty cool cars here in Kuwait, however a lot of the models that you have in America aren't sold here. For example, there is no Acura, Pontiac Buick or Saturn. Infiniti is here, but you don't get some models like the G35 sedan, and I haven't seen the M35/M45 sedan either.

Here are cars that you have in America, but are not sold here.

Toyota Sienna (we get a newer Previa)
Toyota Matrix (we have a Corolla wagon)
Toyota Corolla (ours looks different on the outside)
Toyota Sequoia
Honda Element
Chevrolet Malibu and Impala (we have the Caprice and Lumina, they are rebadged Holden vehicles. The Lumina SS coupe is your GTO)
Ford Five Hundred/Mercury Montego
Mercury Monterey
Ford Freestyle
Dodge Magnum
Chrysler Pacfica

There are few more that I forget. What do you think is the most popular SUV and car in America? Here the most popular car is the Ford Crown Victoria/Mercury Grand Marquis, and the most popular SUV is either the GMC Yukon/Chevrolet Tahoe or the Toyota Land Cruiser Prado.

author: a_l_hubcaps
text:
I drove through Philly today and I saw THREE different 2005.5 Jettas! All of them were loaded cars too, with the sunroof and alloys. Interestingly, I saw even more Jetta billboards than Jetta cars. I counted 6 billboards on 95. After I saw the three cars (all fairly early in the trip), I was pretty surprised because I really didn't think the new Jetta would be a hot seller, particularly the loaded $26,XXX models. Then a conspiracy theory occurred to me: Could VW be hiring people to drive new Jettas up and down 95, as a counterpart to the billboard blitz? Sounds silly, but I was just shocked that I saw 3 of the things so soon after launch. I notice cars, and I almost never see so many of a new model that quick -- particularly here in PA, where people tend to drive older/cheaper cars. When I used to live in NJ, the average age of cars on the road seemed to be quite a bit lower than it is here.

-Andrew L
