author: andre1969
text:
but I got a chance to ride in a PT Cruiser convertible today. I was walking out during lunchtime to go to the bank and get something to eat, when I see one of my friends parked out in front of the building. His daughter works in my building, and he used to work here, too. Well, he normally has a silver 300C, but it had to go in the shop because of some sensor that needed to be replaced. This convertible was his loaner.

One thing I'll say for it, is that it's actually a nice little car. I can fit in it, both front and back, and it has a nice, high, 40's/early-mid 50's seating position. It's a decent little 4-seater. One thing I don't like about it though, is that in the back my head is actually higher than the "basket handle" roll bar! It's annoying because it lines up roughly with my eyesight, but it also makes me wonder how much good this thing would do me in a rollover! Overall though, I do like the open, airy feeling you get with the top down. Kinda like an old convertible. One thing I don't like about some of the current convertibles is that you sit so low, and the beltline is so high, with a windshield that curves back almost over top of you, that even with the top down, I still feel like I'm inside. With the PT and it's relatively upright windshield and high seating position, I don't get that feeling.

It was a silver GT model with leather, turbo, etc, and a sticker price of around $29,700. Lots of hard plastic inside, and not a whole lot of soft-touch stuff, but it made me think of a subject that comes up in these forums from time to time, about "plastic is plastic". Well, it's not. This interior was kind of an off-white/creme/pearl color, and I thought it looked nice. The hard plastic has kind of an "elephant grain" to its texture, similar to the hard plastic in my Intrepid. I thought it was pleasing to the eye, if not to the touch.

One thing I thought was a bit odd, though...every time I got in this car, I'd forget to put my seatbelt on! And usually that's a reflex for me! You'd think that, getting in a convertible with the top down, putting the seatbelt on would be the FIRST thing on my mind!

author: ateixeira
text:
Those have impressive leg room, more than a lot of bigger cars. And reliability has been good in ratings.

I'm not a fan of the interior, though.

-juice

author: navigator89
text:
just spotted a black Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution VIII being tailgated upon by a red Porsche Cayenne (ugly). Lancers are pretty common around here, but the Lancer Evolution just gives an awesome feeling of speed just watching it go. Must be the body kit and spoiler.

Also spotted a white Bentley Arnage today. Nice car, but the new Flying Spur looks better.

author: teds1
text: I spotted an SLR McLaren on the west side highway on Friday. It was going south and turned at a light in midtown right in front of me. They look soooo cool in person, but that is definitely the first one I've seen in the street. I also saw a maserati gransport parked the same day

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw another today, but I might be seeing the same one again. Dark Blue with temporary tags, so she must've just bought it.

-juice

author: andys120
text:
It's not often I see two new cars of British origin in a single day but today I saw a brand new Jag S-Type R and a new Mini convertible, both in dark green and lookin' pretty good by me.

I also saw a couple of new Honda Ridgelines, the second was towing an E-Type Jaguar production racer thereby making good use of the reputed 5000lb towing capcy.

author: kyfdx
text:
S55 AMG

Nice!!

author: ateixeira
text:
Haven't spotted one yet. I wonder if they got off to a good sales start.

-juice

author: davem2001
text:
I've only seen one of them on the road so far.

I've seen a few new Avalons - they look better to me in person than in pictures

author: kyfdx
text:
I saw one Friday, when I took my CR-V in for an oil change..

The one they had in the showroom was the top trim level... $33,XXX + about $2K in accessories on it.. I've only seen two on the road..

The only thing that I don't like is the transition from the passenger area to the bed.. It is a downward sloping angle and looks a little off.. By contrast, the Avalanche looks a little "cleaner" (just in the transition area, not overall).

regards,
kyfdx

author: ateixeira
text:
I think they call them.

I think normal crew cab trucks are oddly proportioned. Like 3 boxes. Honda was probably trying to mask that.

-juice

author: navigator89
text: Spotted a silver Jaguar X Type wagon today in the fast lane of the highway. It looks like a nice car, I wonder how it will compare with the rest of the cras in the class, such as the C Class wagon, Volvo V50, Audi A4 Avant.

author: lemko
text: ...two Pontiac G6s - one silver, the other black. Last night I saw a black Ford 500.

author: kyfdx
text: New Mercedes SLK, with the top down.. I'll take one..

author: andre1969
text:
to be fair, there isn't a whole lot you can do to a crew cab truck that has a tiny bed in back. None of them look proportioned correctly, IMO. The only crew cabs I think look "correct" are the ones with a standard 8 foot bed. But then you have about 22 feet of truck to pilot around, which is a helluva a price to pay for being "proportionally correct"!

I seriously doubt that we'll ever see anything that's a crew cab with a <6 foot bed that ever looks "correct".

author: ateixeira
text:
Look how long a Dakota is, and that's not even full-sized.

Saw an SL500 at lunch just now, though they aren't exactly new.

-juice

author: andre1969
text: 218.8" for the Dakota, regardless of whether you get the crew cab or the club cab. I think my '85 Silverado, with its 8 foot bed, is "only" 212...

author: kyfdx
text:
Aw heck, andre...

That new LeMans is 208", right?

author: ateixeira
text:
Does that make it a "compact".

-juice

author: fintail
text:
I saw my first G6 that I vividly remember on the road today. Kind of a maroon/burgundy with chrome wheels. Not a bad looking car...but at the same time, not a revolution.

I am seeing 500s and the Murcury sibling almost daily.

author: davem2001
text: I've been seeing more and more of them lately. Not bad looking, not great either....To me, the styling of them isn't the biggest problem, it's the pushrod engine and the 4-speed auto.

author: ateixeira
text:
...and MSRPs in the $28k range.

Hyundai offers more technology in their powertrains for $10 grand less.

-juice

author: davem2001
text: Well, we all know that the MSRP on a GM is sorta irrelevant, you're going to get a $4000 rebate and the 0% financing, but yeah....$28K is way too high

author: ateixeira
text:
But it's just silly with GM. A 3 year old model might be worth $10 grand used, how can they even put that kind of price on the window? Some luxury brand cars sticker for less.

-juice

author: davem2001
text: If you're in the mid-size segment, you can't be priced higher than a Camry/Accord and expect to sell ...who in their right mind would pay $28K for a G6 when you could get a nice Camry or Accord for A LOT less?

author: teds1
text: I just saw an Audi A8 W12... I'm sure there are less than 200 of these on american roads total right now. It looks nice the trapezoid grill looks kind of stately on the largest Audi. I am a big fan of the A8 looks overall though. It would definitely be my pick in the class if I was in the market for such a car

author: ateixeira
text:
Love it, aluminum and AWD. So the body will last forever, and during that time you can go anywhere.

Makes the Phaeton redundant, too.

-juice

author: toomanyfumes
text: Mark LT, I think it's called. It was a greyish-silver. Did'nt really stand out, basically looked like an F-150 with a fancy grille. :surprise:

author: teds1
text: Not a new car I know, but I spotted a 70's yellow Ferrari Daytona Spyder last night whcih sounded sooooo great. Made my evening

author: lhess
text: spotted a silver Pontiac Fiero today at lunch. I hadn't thought about those in forever and they started talking about them over in the Solstice forum a couple days back and then I see one today. I hadn't seen one in a loooong time. A guy at my high school got a white one for his birthday and his parents put it in the school parking lot with a big bow and hung the keys in his locker (with the help of the principal). Pretty cool. The paint literally peeled off of it (and that big glue-on Fiero sign at the bottom) at the automatic car wash. He traded it for a mustang. That's ok. I was looking good in my Chevette!!

author: merc1
text:
There I was ambling along on a rainy I-88 not expecting to see much of anything considering the conditions and whoa....a Black Rolls Royce Phantom with new car tags! Looks like something a cartoon villain or devil would drive. Such an immense and imposing car! I don't think any other luxury car commands more presence on the road.

M

author: kyfdx
text: In light silver-blue metallic... very nice..

author: PF_Flyer
text:
New car spottings are always a topic of discussion at our chats. So stop in tonight with your checklist!

PF Flyer
Host
News & Views, Wagons, & Hybrid Vehicles

The Mazda Mania Chat is on tonight. The chat room opens at 8:45PM ET Hope to see YOU there! Check out the schedule

author: merc1
text:
You seem to have seen every Mercedes model on sale in the U.S in the last few weeks!!! What part of KY?

M

author: stickguy
text:
hows that for a mouthful?

Big honking car. I cheated though, it was on the showroom floor when I stopped at the Audi dealer.

Scariest thing is either the 122K sticker price (ouch), or the fact that it had a "sold" tag on it!

author: kyfdx
text:
Near Cincinnati.. and my commute takes me right through the city..

I normally don't see that many AMG cars... I was sort of stunned myself.. S55 AMG a couple of weeks ago, and now the E55 AMG.. Both seen on the same road... suburban office park type area..

regards,
kyfdx

author: fintail
text:
If I have any luck you'll be able to come to my house and see a C43.

Today I saw the new facelifted 911. Driven by some 60-ish year old woman in the slow lane, at about 5 under. I don't get it.

author: andys120
text:
911. Driven by some 60-ish year old woman in the slow lane, at about 5 under. I don't get it.

Prolly belongs to her boyfriend :P

author: merc1
text:
Probably the rarest luxury sedan in America. I've seen everything else either on the road in a showroom, but this W12 A8 never! I was starting to think it didn't exist.

BTW, I did see one at the Detroit autoshow this year and it has a 146K price tag. It has a "special build" Quattro GmBh package on it. The interior was easily the best I've ever seen on any car this side of a Maybach or Bentley.

M

author: merc1
text:
I've saw a man once driving a SL55 AMG and he had to be at least 90. Really dressed and very suave looking. He had on his little derby and all, tickled me.

M

author: navigator89
text:
Saw a blue Golf R32 with a body kit. The driver was crazy, kept weaving in and out of cars.

Also saw a Chevrolet Uplander today. Doesn't look that different from the Venture.

author: andre1969
text: must be readily available now, because in the past couple of days, they seem to really have popped up around here.

author: fintail
text:
There was a W12 A8 at the show in Vancouver too. Gorgeous car, but so expensive.

When I'm old I hope I'm that old man in the SL55. But I'll probably be an old man in a fintail or something.

I've only seen one Cobalt coupe on the road here, but the sedans are now very common. Hey, at least they are selling.

author: davem2001
text: Saw one on the road for the first time yesterday.

author: stickguy
text:
there is one in my town now. Saw a lady driving it, and later saw it in a parking lot.

Tres ugly in my opinion. Just looks squashed and mis-proportioned.

author: davem2001
text: Yep, I agree, not my favorite, either... sort of looks like a "chopped and channelled" E -class or like someone stepped on a clay model of an E-class and "smooshed" it

author: lemko
text: ...from the Phantom - I spotted a Scion xC, Saturn Ion with the new grille, and a Suzuki Aerio.

author: ateixeira
text:
Cheated and went to a dealer to see the new A4 up close and outside of a car show. A3 also, though their demo was wrecked on a test drive, can you believe that? So I didn't get to sample the 2.0T engine.

Saw the new Boxsters and 911s in person, huge improvements to those faces, both.

-juice

author: ghulet
text: ....just bought a ML350, looks OK, but definitely looks smaller than the last ML (back is definitely more sloped), and way too much like a Kia Sorento (which, admittedly, was a shameless copy of the original ML). I guess I feel the same about the new ML as I do about the newest CLK and E-class--they just don't look as 'substantial' or something, I just can't put my finger on it. Maybe Mercedes strive to make their cars look 'sleek' is making them look too low or too small, I'm not sure, but I don't think it's the best idea. In comparison to other cars, they don't look as special any more, and not like they should cost $50k. Of course, now that Buick LaCrosses, Avalons and Chrysler 300s can have $38k MSRPs, I guess $50k isn't such a big deal any more. :surprise:

author: merc1
text:
Very interesting point. I've said the same thing every since the 2003 E and CLK were first shown. They're "prettier" than the cars they replaced, but a little less distinctive. Then I get a look at older Mercedes and see how upright their winshields/A-pillars are an I'm like that thing was a good looking "box" back in the day. Older Mercedes were "cleaner" in design. Upright, less cutlines and more broad expanses of sheetmetal and very, very subtle "character" lines. The direct opposite of what the new SLK has running down its side for instance. Now the CLS is "clean" like Mercedes of old, but its far swoopier. If you look at the current SL for example, way too many cut lines and little nicks on the body for various styling elements like vents etc. Then look at the R129 SL. Clean block styling that is timeless and sturdy, but the new car is sleeker and "prettier".

Of course I like the way these newer Mercedes' look, but I clearly see that they aren't as distinctive as before. Thats seems to be the price of change. Wait until the new S-Class appears. The front end has to pass those Euro pedestrian safety standards which is going to kill that sloping hoodline Mercedes has been using for the last few years.

As you noted one of the biggest negatives about Korea's shamless copying is that the origial isn't free to evolve anymore. The new Lexus GS and Maxima are another example. Lexus had the look first back in 1998, then came the 2004 Maxima with from the rear, especially the rear glass treatment is pure 1998 GS. Now the new 2006 GS unfortunately looks like a Maxima. The Koreans are more bent on copying than the Japanese ever were imo. This new Sonata is pure Honda Accord from the rear and collection of various cars everywhere else. Oh well.

M

author: fintail
text: I liked the older generation styling too, of course. They made bank vaults look pretty good. The 126 S-class and 124 E-class are the perfect examples. The modern cars are a little 'pretty' and over-detailed in some regard, but at least they aren't ugly. And I do kind of like the E wagon and the big CL hardtop/

author: merc1
text:
Yeah the W124 E was the best! The current CL though is by far Mercedes' best styled car at the moment. The CLS is stunning also, imo.

M

author: merc1
text:
If I have any luck you'll be able to come to my house and see a C43.

I just noticed this comment. Due tell!!

M

author: fintail
text:
The 124 was a great platform, they got a lot of use out of it. 10 years, a sedan, wagon, hardtop coupe, and convert. You still see them on the road all the time. The M103 6cyl is also usually regarded as one of MBs best engines too.

I think I mentioned the C43 incident on the chronic car buyers thread. A couple weeks ago I noticed one at the local Porsche lot...they marked the price down a bit and I went and drove it. Of course I ended up liking it a lot, so I was going to come back the next day and make an offer, afer I sorted out what to do with the 126. I came back, and it had sold. So now I am leisurely seeking out another one.

I saw a red A3 yesterday...maybe they're starting to pop up.

author: andre1969
text: I saw both a Ford 500 and a Freestyle, side-by-side. I think this is the first Freestyle I've seen on the road. Good looking wagon.

author: ateixeira
text:
I saw a new ML on the road also. I kinda like them, actually. The old one seemed to tall and narrow.

Perhaps those that like the trucky/substantial look will prefer the old one?

-juice

author: andre1969
text:
the phrase "SUV" really wasn't as much of a buzzword as it is today...we just called 'em what they were...trucks. Or just called them by name (Blazer/4runner/Bronco/etc). When that ML first came out, I didn't know what to make of it. IIRC it was the first, or one of, the first SUVs that seemed to attempt blurring the distinction between car and truck. It wasn't as trucky or macho as your typical SUV. I actually thought they looked more like minivans than SUVs! I think the first time I even saw one was on that second "Jurassic Park" movie.

The new one looks pretty good, though, in a Kia Sorrento sort of way.

author: ateixeira
text:
Yeah, that hood did give it a minivan front end. Over time they refined it to look beefier.

The new one's hood is taller, less sloped, probably to avoid that stigma.

-juice

author: lemko
text: ...black Toyota Prius.

author: PF_Flyer
text:
I thought all the Prii (that's apparently the current plural in vogue) were silver!

PF Flyer
Host
News & Views, Wagons, & Hybrid Vehicles

author: kyfdx
text: of new C6 Corvettes....

author: davem2001
text: Ironically, I've never seen a silver Prius on the road - I've seen a cranberry red, a light blue, a biege/tan, but never silver...only in pictures.

author: fintail
text:
Up here in the NW, Prius are very common, both the old and new style. Heck, there's a couple of em in my parking lot at work. I saw a pleasant blue shade on one this weekend that I hadn't seen before. Most I see are white or silver.

I finally saw my first new style Corvette today

author: ghulet
text: I see the current Prius all the time, usually in that metallic light blue, but I don't see the old version much. That and the Volvo XC seem to be the vehicles-du-jour among our local nouveau riche townhouse dwellers. I also saw my first new Vette today, what a coincidence (and it was parked in the lot at the county court building at 26th/California!). It was a red coupe with chrome wheels, very nice. I like the non-hidden headlights.

author: fintail
text: I like it more than the old one anyway, yeah. Looks more athletic and modern.

author: ateixeira
text:
They've been out for a while, I think I see 4-5 a day around DC/MD.

-juice

author: davem2001
text: Just haven't happened to see one in silver yet....

author: teds1
text: You know what I haven't seen yet though anywhere? The escape hybrid... and I've been looking for the tell tale vents in the rear quarter windows... Did Ford just make one as a marketing tool or are they actually selling these things? I don't think the american auto companies get the mass market appeal of these yet. Don't just make small weird looking compact hybrids as some sort of honda insightesque curiosity... Make a hybrid version of normal useful cars that people drive anyway. Look how many rx400h's Toyota has already booked, if they had a hybrid tahoe, or explorer they could do the same. Honda seems to have made a hybrid sportier than their regular accord. Who wouldn't want to see that torquey 240 hp v6 in the new sky/solstice body or a Mustang that got 30+ mpg. This is a no brainer to me. I am waiting for the powerful hybrid Subaru wagon which will be the greatest vehicle ever known to man ( in my opinion)

author: davem2001
text: I've seen an Escape Hybrid parked at the local Ford dealer that I pass every day going to work, but I haven't seen one on the road yet.

author: ateixeira
text:
I nominate the Forester (non-turbo) as a good candidate.

Why? Because it already gets 22/30 with automatic, 23/30 with manual.

The RX400H and Highlander hybrids only get 26-27 mpg highway, so the Forester could outpace those by far.

The Escape hybrid is a lot heavier and the 2.3l engine struggles to move all that weight. Subaru's 2.5l is both stronger and more efficient plus it's pulling a lighter vehicle.

Hence the perfect candidate. It would easily be the most fuel efficient SUV, it almost is now even without the hybrid powertrain.

-juice

author: kyfdx
text: You don't see Escape Hybrids, because by the time they get up enough speed to get out of the garage, it is time to go home...

author: anythngbutgm
text:
"You don't see Escape Hybrids, because by the time they get up enough speed to get out of the garage, it is time to go home..."

I guess they're selling very well in L.A. and we have 1 or 2 around where I live. But you can't wink without seeing a Prius or Civic Hybrid. Quite a few Insights as well.

author: stickguy
text:
Black. But, it was on the showroom floor of the Ford dealer (behind ropes even).

Pretty sharp. Even gets 21 MPG highway.

really sad thing, I stopped to look at a Stang convertible, and they were nonexistant.

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw a Continental GT today here in Washington Circle, nice. 2nd time I've seen it, pretty sure it was the same one.

-juice

author: ghulet
text: There's a Bentley coupe living somewhat near here, I see it fairly regularly (once double parked on a side street). Today I saw my first Cadillac STS (in a strange metallic sage green) AND (even better) a Lotus Elise, in dark gray with a half canvas top. Cute little thing, looked fun to drive, though it was on the interstate in heavy traffic and was completely dwarfed by everything.

author: ateixeira
text:
I love those, I saw a yellow one the other day with the top down. Some kid behind the wheel, must've been in high school! Spoiled brat! :P

Saw 2 Cobalts yesterday, a coupe and later a sedan.

-juice

author: teds1
text: I saw two of these Bentleys in the last 24 hours up close, I know they aren't new but they are still show stoppers. They look fantastic, people are going to be collecting those thirty years from now for sure... assuming we still have any gasoline then. One of them looked like it was being driven by an NFL player or something, huge guy barely fit in it

author: teds1
text: I saw one out at Lunch today, they look much better moving than still. Growing on me for sure but i'm not yet in love. I also saw a new Mustang GT crashed into the oncoming lane... oops

author: teds1
text: I saw one off those Mercury Ford 500s today on my way to work... I don't get it what's the point? Car companies think they are being clever by re-badging the same car but if you have to market the same vehicle with a different grill twice where are the cost savings? Nobody thinks a Mariner is different from an Escape, or a Mountaineer is different from an Explorer. The brands don't mean nearly as much as in the 50's when everyone's dad was a "Plymouth man," or and "Oldsmobile man." When you re-badge the same platform it dilutes any brand identity these dinosaur marques may have had. What matters today is the vehicle. Look at the success of Mazda and Subaru recently. Ford even uses the Mazda 6 platform extensively in it's lines, and twenty years ago those brands had completely different images. So please American large car companies, either make different models for different brands, or lose the brands.

author: ateixeira
text:
Well, Saab sells the 9-2x, a Subaru clone.

Subaru has not yet sold clones in the US, but in Europe they sold a Justy (Suzuki Swift clone) and in Japan they sold a Traviq (Open Zafira clone).

Often it's just economics. Dealers are very powerful and they want a full line of cars to sell, so they have to come up with something cheap/quick to please the dealer.

-juice

author: teds1
text: Understood, but with the exception of the 9-2x (don't get me started on that thing!) you are talking about different geographical regions. It is one thing to market a car under a different nameplate in another country, but I feel that this is different from why Ford has it's Mercury division. Mercury does not have one unique product . They are all Ford clones. So why keep the separate brand? I don't think the dealer power is an issue here because almost all the Ford dealers I have seen are also Mercury dealers. I am against killing off historical brands and nameplates because there is still tremendous name recognition involved to say nothing of history. But they should have separate vehicles to maintain an identity. I'm not even talking about platform sharing which is fine. However when you produce two 500s and slap a different grill and badging on one for sale in the same dealership in the same country, you have to wonder why.

author: ateixeira
text:
Well, Cougar was unique, and look how much good that did them!

They took that risk and got bitten hard, maybe now they are gun-shy.

Around here, Ford dealers stand alone. Mercury dealer partner with Lincoln.

I thought Mercury should sell the Ford of Europe vehicles, like the Mondeo and maybe the Fiesta. Or make the Fiesta a Ford and let Mercury sell the new Focus.

-juice

author: navigator89
text:
Saw a yellow Hummer H1 pickup today, and he was trying to overtake a bunch of cars stuck in a traffic jam by driving on the curb.

Saw a red Lamborghini Murcielago and a yellow Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution parked outside a mansion.

Saw a black Mercedes Benz ML55 AMG. The styling looks really old, I'd take a Cayenne or X5 anyday.

Also my first 2005 Avalon in white color. Looks better in person than in the pictures.

author: fintail
text: I didn't see too many new things on my little trip. I did see a couple new ML, and quite a few Cobalts are showing up....mostly sedans. I hope it's a good sign, they do look like a decent enough car. I saw several G6 too, but something tells me they were rentals. They all looked kinda basic. The new Avalons are starting to really move up here too, I saw maybe half a dozen of them.

author: merc1
text:
Bentley Continetal GT - now I'm conflicted. This car in my eyes had all the style of an old thrown away shoe, but it does have a presence on the road that is undeniable.

Lotus Elise - little bitty thing, but looks like fun.

Jetta - a baby Phaeton.

M

author: ateixeira
text:
Such the stereotype, too. :mad:

Saw a couple of Cobalts on my road trip to the beach. At least one Avalon, and several new Odys.

-juice

author: bksward
text:
I've seen 3 or 4 new M45s, but I haven't seen an M35 yet. Pretty nice car. One oddity about it is that the key for the trunk is inserted vertically into a keyhole in the license plate area. I guess with remotes, most people don't use it so it eliminates it as a styling element.

Actually figured out that it was the one car I couldn't identify at a market research thing I attended here in San Diego back around February. (The cars had all badging covered, but the other ones I looked at were the current Maxima, ES330, Chysler 300, Buick LaCrosse, and a 5-series.)

I also saw a new Lexus GS on Saturday morning.

I've seen a half dozen Elises on the street around here. I can remember Yellow, Blue, Silver, and Orange.

author: davem2001
text: San Diego would be a great place to have an Elise - you could drive it year round there - in the Northeast, it's a summer-only toy.

author: ateixeira
text:
I've only seen one or two around here. They're pretty rare.

-juice

author: teds1
text: I have yet to see an M45/35 which is pretty odd given NYC's ridiculous bounty of 5s GS's and Es. I have seen some Elises but not in the city... I have a feeling the potholes would be too much in that tight track suspension

author: kyfdx
text:
I think Infiniti gets a lot more press and interest from enthusiasts than is reflected in actual car sales...

So, I hear a lot about them... but, I just don't see very many...

author: anythngbutgm
text: Spotted a CLS500 over the weekend. My wife's business partner picked it up on Saturday... What a ride!!! :shades:

author: ateixeira
text:
And there is an Infiniti dealer about 2 miles from my house!

-juice

author: teds1
text: You may be right, Q45s at least are quite rare, but everyone and their mother has a G35 (with good reason, they rock) so I am surprised that I haven't seen the M yet. I did however, almost get run over by a truck today as I sprinted across the street to get a better lok at the black maserati Quattroporte parked in front of a Starbucks nearby. Every reviewer says the transmission sucks but it looks soooooo good. Then a classic jag xk 120 drove by... now that is a rare sighting in downtown Manhattan

author: merc1
text:
As we came to one of those intersections where the right lane must turn right and the left must turn left, I got to hear the the SLK350's exhaust note loud and clear as he went left and I right. The SLK also had its top down. Very slick n sporty little Benz. Total about-face from the previous SLK.

M

author: ateixeira
text:
And they drive a lot better, too. The 3.5l engine has a lot more torque than the 3.2l it replaced. Plus that car has 2.3l, 2.3l kompressor, and 1.8l kompressor engines that were slotted below the old SLK 320.

-juice

author: merc1
text:
Yeah this time I'm glad the 4-cylinder is history. The new entry level model will be a 228hp SLK280. I'm waiting to "spot" the 55 AMG version now. They're rare as can be it seems.

M

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw my first new Jetta, a silver one, young woman driving it.

Doesn't really stand out much, it does sort of "look like a Corolla" like everyone seems to say.

-juice

author: kyfdx
text:
IMO, they really screwed this car up, in the looks department... I can live with the new schnozz (like the Audi), but the side and rear views... Corolla is an apt description..

It is a real shame.. the previous Jetta was one of the best looking small cars on the road.. I'm all for change, but not this way...

regards,
kyfdx

author: ateixeira
text:
Sales are slow, they only had 2.5l models and even then mostly automatics. Coupled with high prices they're collecting dust on lots.

-juice

author: davem2001
text:
That's just the new VW corporate look - I've seen pictures of the new Passat and it looks very similar, too...

Jetta seems pretty expensive to me... there was one at the COSTCO last weekend, so I checked it out.....Sticker was over $24,000..didn't even seem to be extremely "loaded", either

author: ateixeira
text:
Yeah, the one C&D tested was over $26 grand, and that's a 2.5l sedan auto. No turbo, no wagon, no AWD. Imagine what one equipped like that would cost - probably over $30 grand!

-juice

author: stickguy
text:
You should get a Passat.

Actually, if you can live with the excitement of a V-Dub (and I don't mean the driving experience), the Passat with the 2.0T and 6 speed 9or DSG if you prefer) sounds like it might be a nice package, if the price doesn't get out of hand.

Wonder when they will be out to be sighted (to keep OT)?

author: davem2001
text: Well, if a decently equipped Jetta is going for $24-26K, I'd imagine a Passat will be near $30K, at least... I still have a hard time thinking of VW as an "upscale" luxury brand....maybe I'm just showing my age...when I think of VW, I think Beetles, Rabbits..... "luxury VW" seems almost like one of those oxymorons like "jumbo shrimp" to me.

author: ateixeira
text:
They will market these new cars to girly-men, since we're on a roll with oxymorons.

-juice

author: davem2001
text: market these new cars to girly-men that's a new Beetle and Beetle convertible.

author: a_l_hubcaps
text:
Yesterday I walked to the grocery store because it was nice out, and two exotic cars passed me. I really don't pay attention to cars I'll never be able to afford, so I don't know much about exotics. One was a Bentley coupe and the other was a Maserati convertible. Both were definitely very late-model. I did not like the Bentley at all...it looked cheap, like a kit car or something. The Maserati looked quite nice, though. I have always liked the Maserati grille.

-Andrew L

author: ateixeira
text:
On the way home I saw a red Mustang GT, looked good. I like the new front end.

I was behind a Lotus yesterday, nice V8 rumble heard clearly because I had the top down.

Ford 500 later, too. Those are finally becoming more common.

-juice

author: andys120
text: it was coming at me so I only got a brief look, frankly it seemed a little plain but perhaps that was cuz it was white. Not a good color for a ragtop IMO.

author: merc1
text:
ASTON-MARTIN DB9!

In front of the club last night. Oh my gawd! The car is so sleek, low to the ground and so well proportioned. Shaped like it is not of this earth and mere human designers. Without question the best looking production car on earth, imo.

M

author: boomchek
text:
I keep seeing a late model Peugeot 406 coupe in the vancouver area with local plates. Funny thing is Peugeot doesnt sell cars in North America, and you can't really import one in, the costs are huge.

Car looks nice though

author: seminole_kev
text: " Funny thing is Peugeot doesnt sell cars in North America" - I believe Peugeot does sell cars in Mexico if I remember correctly.

author: 210delray
text: ...the new BMW 3-series sedan on the road last week. I didn't know they were out yet.

author: ateixeira
text:
Test fleet car, maybe?

Did you notice the plates, i.e. where they special?

-juice

author: kyfdx
text: They started delivering cars to customers last Friday, the 6th...

author: teds1
text: I thought I might have seen one this weekend, but it's tough to tell when driving. they aren't radically different in shape from the old bodied 3 s. I'm sure I will see them soon enough. I'm dying to drive one, I used to run a program with 330xis and 325xits and they were so damn fun to drive. I want to see what 30 more HP will do.

author: andys120
text: Today I saw two different new 'Stang ragtops, one on the road, the other at a dealer both red (different shades), both not GTs, They looked good, better than the boring white I saw last week.

author: ghulet
text: Saw my first Mustang convertible last night, kinda dark red metallic, base model, looked very nice and well built. I also saw a Dodge Magnum, which in itself isn't all that unusual, but this one was a TAXICAB. Not a bad choice, I guess, though I know rearward vision is bad; combine that with the customary awful, careless cab driving and you have a dangerous combination.

author: 210delray
text: The reason it caught my eye was the different rear end/taillight treatment from the old model. Not Bangled, but definitely different!

author: andys120
text: I drive past a Dodge DDealer regularly and have yet to see a Charger, they've got lots of Magnums (Magna?) though.

author: kyfdx
text:
I saw a Mustang GT today.. It had the stripe package just like the Cobra II from the late '70s...

It sure looks a lot better on this model..

author: nwng
text: I think the rear wing on the gt does not match the rest of the car

author: teds1
text: I haven't seen any chargers yet either. Anybody know when they will be out? Actually they should be my favorite of the three styles. Big and Ballsy though the 300 is (especially with a tighter mesh aftermarket grill) I could not see myself driving one... Still too ugly. The magnum is way better for me because I love wagons but it looks so big it would be unwieldy to drive. I loved the chargers at the NY auto show, not the silly yellow and orange 70's racing striped ones but the srt-8 looks mean and they had a DUB magazine concept edition that was really nice. I definitely don't mind the four door look. It should be a hit

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw a new 330i. Black, driving on MacArthur towards DC this morning.

Looked nice. I'm not crazy about the tail lights, but otherwise a nice overall shape, and by far Bangle's best effort to date.

It was the first one I saw on the road. I'd seen it at the auto shows.

Right after that - I saw my first Honda Ridgeline on the road! Dark red.

I guess we have to start talking about the 2006 models.

-juice

author: chidoro
text:
It was a busy day for new car spotting at lunch today. Saw two M35x’s (first time I ever saw one), a white avalon (actually reminded me a little of the G300), and a 645 convertible. The bimmer had it’s top down and I have to say, the thing looks pretty massive in person. I was really surprised how much space this coupe displaced.

I love my aging car to death because it’s served me so well these past 7  years but I really get an itch to buy when I see all of these nice new cars riding around.

author: ateixeira
text:
And the back seat is still useless...

I agree about the Avalon resembling the GS.

-juice

author: ghulet
text: ....unfortunately, they remind me a bit too much of the latest Maxima, though the taillight treatment on the GS is nicer (that's not saying much). I dunno, now when I see a Maxima (as opposed to even a few years ago), I can't help but wonder what would make someone spend an extra ~$5k over the much less ugly Altima 3.5; same engine, about the same size. I don't know if there's still some 'prestige' factor versus an Altima, or the newness of the design, or what. All that said, the new GS is crisp and nice looking, though perhaps a bit less distinctive than the last generation was when it debuted. The new Max is perhaps too distinctive.

author: ateixeira
text:
I don't really like them either, and they cost a bunch more.

Nissan needs to improve the interiors, apparently they have, but I haven't seen them lately.

-juice

author: odie6l
text:
I heard the Charger was suppost to ship to dealers to go hand-in-hand with the Dodge Dealer 500 NASCAR Race, but they got pushed back to be released with the new Dukes of Hazzard movie. I hope this is only a rumor and not true.

Odie

author: kyfdx
text:
What is it with Nissan and the goofy moonroofs.. Horizontal across the front seats seems to have worked for 40 years... and now, somehow... it just isn't good enough?

Also, the Pontiac G6... Does anyone else see problems with that moonroof after 3-4 years of body flexing?

Also.. SUVs, Minis, the new A3... all of those have extra large moonroofs.. They look great from inside the car, but they look like problems waiting to happen.. not to mention the solar heating...

Okay... done ranting.. carry on..

author: bksward
text:
Saw two of them today, a white one on the road and a black one on a flatbed. Looks like someone stretched and warped a Ford Taurus. Either that or the back end is an Olds Aurora with Taurus tail lights... (There was a white Taurus one lane over from the white CLS500 on I5 this afternoon...)

I've also seen a BRG Jag X-type wagon... I think it looks better than the 3-series wagon, but ownership might be a different deal...

author: anythngbutgm
text: My wife had a C230K coupe (The not so well liked one) which had the skyroof option. A huge piece of glass like that makes for alot of squeeks... But the amount of light that was allowed into the cabin was great. And there awas a sunshade (power) that covered the whole think up if you wanted to keep the sun off of you. But it was squeeky...

author: lemko
text: ...black Chevrolet Equinox.

author: teds1
text:
Saw my first last night... looked good. When you compare the next to eachother(as you can in the small pictures under 3 series at bmwusa.com) It looks a lot more modern and sleeker, though by itself it doesn't look that different. I also saw a continental GT on the same block... They are really everywhere in New York now, I see at least two a week.

Also I too hate the new Maximas though a 20 gallon fuel tank is nice. Just ugly

author: ateixeira
text:
kyfdk: imagine a G6 after an accident that caused frame damage.

I prefer a moonroof like the Mercedes C-coupe or the Mini Cooper, glass front and back, with the front half sliding back over the back half.

I saw a CLS yesterday also, though I like it more than you do. :P

-juice

author: jaserb
text:
A local dealer brought a couple of cars to my office today so people could try to win the GM Hot Button promotion, without actually having to step foot in a GM showroom. :P
They had a Buick Lacrosse and a Silverado SS. The Lacrosse actually is better looking in person - seems more compact and athletic than I've seen in the pics. Interior was much better than my dad's Lesabre (this is not your father's Buick?) but still not fantastic. Doesn't matter much to me, since I didn't win.

-Jason

author: navigator89
text:
I was behind a 2006 BMW 3 series at a stoplight, so I only looked at the tailights of the car. Still, they're not that great looking. It reminds me of a certain Ford model, can't remember which one. The headlights look pretty good.

It's funny, I seem to like the old looks of the BMW 3,5,7 series better than the new ones. Well, the 7 has been out for a while, I'm getting used to it, even liking it a bit. But the 5? No way, looks uglier than any other car in it's class. The 3 series isn't too bad, I guess I'll get used to it.

Also saw a dark blue BMW 1 series at a parking lot. I have to say, it looks really nice in that color..

author: kyfdx
text: Where do you live, that you see 1-series?

author: teds1
text: You saw a 1 series??? Where? In the US? I'm pretty sure we don't have those yet. I'm not too fond of the hatchback one that will be imported here anyway, the cs1 convertible concept was nice but I'm not sure they are making a production version. I've seen a few more of the new 3s and they are growing on me. I still hate the 5s and the 7s are better but still make the drivers look like russian gangsters. The 3 is the first of the major redesigns (I'm discounting the Z4 here which I like) to strike my fancy immediately. Maybe it's because I've driven every iteration of the previous body style and I love them.

author: davem2001
text: Navigator99 is writing to us from Kuwait!

author: navigator89
text:
Yeah that's right, I am writing from Kuwait.

We get a lot of European brands that the US doesn not get like Peugeot, Citroen Renault and Seat. We also get the Mercedes A Class, not available in the States.

And we also have Japanese brands like Nissan, Toyota ,Lexus, and Honda. Infiniti is starting to make an appearance here with the FX45, QX56 and G35 coupe. Acura is non existent here.

We have American brands, but only Chevrolet GMC and Cadillac. No Pontiac, Buick or Saturn. Lincoln only sells the Town Car and LS, no SUVs.

The disadvantage to living here is that vehicles debut much later than in America. The Nissan Armada is just arriving, and the 2002 Camry arrived as 2003 model here. The Ford Mustang just made it's debut. Also, the 7 seater Pathfinder hasn't made it's way here yet.

and it's navigator89, not 99

author: fintail
text:
"The Nissan Armada is just arriving,"

You guys are better off without that super-sized Rambler Cross Country. One of the more difficult to look at vehicles on the road.

Today I saw a new style A6...in blue, and beautiful. I hated the grille when I first saw pics, but now it is fine.

author: merc1
text:
Cadillac DTS. I thought it was Dubya. It is basically a smoothed over DeVille with new front and rear ends.

M

author: navigator89
text:
"You guys are better off without that super-sized Rambler Cross Country."

If you think the Nissan Armada is a super-sized Rambler Croos Country, you should see what the most popular full size SUV here is - GMC Yukon/Chevrolet Tahoe. These two aren't as big as the Armada, but the Suburban is, and it is extremely popular. You can find all model years here, even the ancient ones. We once had an idiot in a 1980's Suburban tailgating on us in the fast lane at 120km/h

I actually like seeing the Nissan Armada. I didn't like it's styling in the pictures, but it looks better in person, and it is a welcome change from the monotone of the GM full size SUV's and pickups.

Also, GM full size trucks own the full size market here. Spotting a Ram is rare, unless it is tricked out or a Rumble Bee version. F-150's are just springing up. But there is no doubt - the Silverado/Sierra are the most common work trucks.

author: danf1
text: of 2006 Mitsubishi Eclipses went by me today. It looks much better than the current model. Also much better than in pictures.

author: merc1
text:
Very good looking car. Doesn't look as "truckish" as I first thought. I still would like to see a Coupe version though.

M

author: lemko
text: ...red GMC Canyon, silver Chevrolet Cobalt coupe, gray Buick LaCrosse, and black Mercury Montego.

author: ateixeira
text:
Well, actually it was Hot Rod weekend in Ocean City, MD, a bunch of car shows along the beach. I guess SSRs are trying to fit in with the old school crowd because I saw more of these things in one day than I had in my entire life!

At one point I was driving next to a red one, and we saw another red one just like it across the street. Then we drove by a yellow one a couple of blocks later. And later on we saw yet another yellow one, parked in a used car lot.

At the outlets we saw 3 new Avalons parked in the same row. It was the sidewalk sale and they must have had a senior citizen discount.

Saw a lot of new Mustangs, too. Almost all domestic cars there.

-juice

author: andys120
text: it looked pretty good in Steel Gray Metallic. I think I prefer the Magnum tho

author: ghulet
text:
....today I saw a new Mercedes SLK 55 (the AMG version). Nice car, a definite improvement over the outgoing version, but still doesn't quite look as 'expensive' or exclusive as Mercedes used to. I'm also not too fond of the pointy beaks and multiple character lines on the newest sporty Benzes. It's probably just me, my perceptions of cars are stuck in the '80s or something. I did notice it was wearing wheels nearly identical to those on the highest-spec Chrysler Crossfire (the million-spoke alloys that are a real pain to clean).

I also saw a new Lincoln Zephyr; looked nice enough from most angles (though it's small, definitely smaller than an Accord or Camry, and likely more expensive), except the taillight treatment is a bit awkward. I can't remember exactly what it looked like, but reminded me of kind of a skewed Mustang from the rear.

author: davem2001
text:
also saw a new Lincoln Zephyr;

I didn't think these were on sale until the fall?

author: i_luv_toyota
text:
I forgot to report this, but I saw an M35x (AWD) a couple weeks back at the local CVS. It was black with chrome wheels (stock) and looked like it was thoroughly washed, waxed and detailed.

Very nice I must say, even though it was parked slightly over the line...

author: 210delray
text: So did you ding his door? :blush:

author: ghulet
text:
I saw the Zephyr in downtown Chicago (on Clark between Lake and Wacker, specifically). It's possible they might have been filming it for a commercial or something, I saw it driving but then I saw a prop vehicle and film crew. The guy driving it (a really heavy, kinda older blue-collar uniformed guy) couldn't have been in the commercial, though, so maybe not....I dunno. In any case, the car was silver with dark gray interior and missing the center caps on its alloys.

I had no idea the car wasn't coming out til Fall, I just checked and it isn't even mentioned on L-M's website.

author: merc1
text:
Today must have been city S-Class and SL Mercedes day. I mean I saw like 7 2003 or newer S-Classes today and every SL had the top down. It was a pretty day here, but not all that warm at 66 degrees.

M

author: fintail
text: Not an exciting new thing to see, but I have seen many of the rebeaked GM minivans lately. Either people have actually been fooled and are actually buying these things, or they are really popular in the rental fleets.

author: davem2001
text: It must have been for a commercial shoot, then. I saw the Zephyr at the Detroit Auto Show back in January, but it's not for sale to the public yet. Not too impressed with it, either. You would think Lincoln would have learned a lesson from the Cadillac Cimmaron. Apparently not. This thing is a loaded Fusion with different grille and taillights.

author: ateixeira
text:
LOL, good one! Nice pick me up for me this morning, thanks.

Tell me the Zephyr isn't getting the same 3.0l Duratec engine as the others (Ford/Mazda/Mercury). Please.

-juice

author: davem2001
text: I'd assume they will eventually get the 3.5L engine that the 500 also is waiting for, but when they first come out, they will have the same engine as the Fusion/Milan/Mazda 6, etc... Like I said, it's a loaded Fusion with a different grille - Lincoln's Cimmaron

author: lemko
text: ...first Honda Ridgeline. Also spotted numerous Chevrolet Cobalts - red coupe, a blue sedan, and a gray sedan.

author: ateixeira
text:
Lincoln should have waited for the 3.5l.

-juice

author: teds1
text: I have been seeing some ridgelines in NYC with commercial markings. Nobody in their right mind is going to own a pickup truck for personal use in the city but the ridgeline actually makes a lot of sense as a work truck as long as you aren't in heavy construction. It's not big enogh to haul cement and rebar but it would be very useful for an interior contractor for example. I think it will be a sucess... goofy looking though it is

author: anythngbutgm
text: Spotted a truckload of Subaru Tribeca's in Nashua, NH...

author: stickguy
text: I see them occasionally on the road. The more I see them, the uglier I think it is!

author: ateixeira
text:
They're in dealers now. The local dealer has 10, I'm test driving one today.

Two people here on Edmunds already own Tribecas.

Remember, Subarus are supposed to be ugly.

-juice

author: anythngbutgm
text: Not so much ugly as they are polarizing. :P Interior is top notch IMO. Very warm and inviting, I'd say. :shades:

author: ateixeira
text:
Interior looks great and has the biggest DVD screen you can get in any SUV at any price (9"). In park you can even view movies on the NAV screen.

But does size matter?

-juice

author: davem2001
text: I like just about everything about it until I see that ugly Edsel nose. The interior is very nice. The exterior looks good from just about every angle except the front.

author: teds1
text: As a true Suby fanatic and owner I take mild offense to that! Sure WRX's are a bit ungainly (but oh so awesome), and the plastic cladding on outbacks is repulsive... but Legacy's (espicially GTs) have always been sleek. Nice touches like the rear spoiler on the wagons and the functional but subtle hood scoops have always looked great to me. I think the new legacy's and outbacks are better than anything BMW or Audi has produced recently by far... But I hope and pray that the tribeca grill will be killed off and not made into the corporate face a la trapezoids on audis. It looks like something mailman would drive in Belgium... I hate that thing

author: lemko
text: ...one of those Chevrolet Classic rental cars with the tiny "e" sticker. The Classic is the old Malibu and still uses the "wave" logo with the Chevy bowtie superimposed within it.

author: kyfdx
text:
Not necessarily brand new.. It was the big CL coupe.. Maybe a couple of years old..

I thought it said CL55 on the back... but, when I passed it, it said V-12 on the front fender..

Is that right? CL55 AMG has a V-12?

regards,
kyfdx

author: davem2001
text: I'm not positive - one of the big AMG engines is a 5.5L V8 either turbocharged or supercharged (not sure which). The other is a twin turbo 6.0L v12

author: navigator89
text:
Today on the way to my dentist I saw a plethora of rare vehicles. I'll list them in the order I saw them.

Yellow Acura NSX parked in front of a house

Black Roll Royce Phantom parked in a driveway!!! There were some other expensive vehicles there too, an Infiniti QX56 and a BMW 745Li

Red Ferrari 612 Scaglietti!!!!!!!! I didn't know they were out! It was parked at my dentist's office

and finally, a HOT PINK Cadillac Escalade. That has gotta be the ugliest SUV out there, after the BMW X3

author: kyfdx
text:
My first sighting of an Infiniti M35..

I predict the hoopla over these will wear off fairly fast, along with the GS300.. They are both fairly generic looking (along with the Acura RL).

regards,
kyfdx

author: ateixeira
text:
Just a joke, I love Subies. We own 2 and I test drove a Tribeca just yesterday.

In reality my point is that styling has never been the main draw for a Subaru. Tribeca may be love/hate, but my guess is the styling will draw those that love it in to showrooms.

Saw an NSX with pop-ups (early model) yesterday as well.

This morning I drove by a CLS500.

-juice

author: chidoro
text: Saw three more RL's on my way home from work last night. Two sivler and one black. I have to say, the more I see it the more I think it got a case of the "Bangles" in the rear. Someone at my office just got a new Outback. The '05s sit a lot higher than I expected. Looks pretty good for a wagon imo.

author: anythngbutgm
text: So where can I go to read about your test drive? Would love to hear your imprsssions on the Tribeca...

author: ateixeira
text:
It is raised, but it flows with the body. The BMW 7 has that square trunk lid plopped on top of a curvy body. Stands out more so it's far worse.

-juice

author: boomchek
text:
The CL55 would have the 5.5L Supercharged V8 producing 493HP
The CL65 would have the 6.0L Twin Turbo V12 producing 604HP

The 5.5 V8 Supercharged engine is also in the S55AMG, and the SL55AMG, and the V12 Twin Turbo is also found in the SL65AMG, and now the S65AMG (sedan).

Maybe the owner added some fake AMG badges on it.

author: kyfdx
text:
Didn't look fake... I might not have noticed the rear badging being CL65, instead of CL55.. Maybe I just expected it to be 55..

It definitely had V-12 badging on the side, though.. got a nice long look at that..

It had all the other AMG stuff, as well... Lowered, wheels, exhaust, etc...

CL65... I guess that would be even more rare... for some reason, I'm seeing every AMG Mercedes under the sun lately...

regards,
kyfdx

author: merc1
text:
Yeah I was going to say it was probably a CL65 which Mercedes just sold a bunch of it seems. Most dealers here had at least one in stock...a pretty rare car.

M

author: teds1
text: Very rare car... The 65's just came out and are stickering at around $180k. apparently they are entirely too torquey to grip any tire made right now and are actually slower to 60 than the 55s because they just burn rubber. If it was a CL65 the side badging would have said V12 Kompressor, not just V12. Also the regular V12 mercs (aka the 600's) have the badge in a drawn out oval. The V12 kompressor has pewter or silver colored sraight lettering like the stuff on the rear. I actually saw an S65 yesterday in a dealership on Park avenue that I walked by. Lower Park is one of the main "Financial services / real estate power corridors," so there are literally hundreds of various limos lining the street and several high end show rooms. I also saw an E55 wagon, a CLS500, and a Maybach 62 in the same window. A White rolls phantom was across the street parked, and the Ferrari showroom nearby had a 612 scaglietti, 430, 3200 gt maserati, quattroporte, and a maserati spyder.... also one of those goofy segway scooters for shoppers to glide around on... must be nice

author: kyfdx
text:
Thanks.. those are all good identification tips... Unfortunately, I can't see the car from here... maybe, next time...

I'll be looking more closely from now on.... I didn't even know there was a CL65 until you guys told me...

regards,
kyfdx

author: kyfdx
text:
A co-worker just leased this one.. I took it for a drive around the parking lot at work today (it is a big lot..lol). 6-speed, Grand Touring pkg, 18" performance rubber... Titanium Gray with black leather...

Very cool.. getting an itch...

author: fintail
text:
Maybe it was a rebadged CL55. Some posers like to rebadge MB, and often do a shoddy job. I have seen rebadged SWB "SEL" 126 cars, and it is not uncommon to find V12 emblems on V8 140 cars.

Back in the day, people would de-badge their lower line MB, but about 15 years ago maybe that changed. I've seen debadged fintails, 116s and 126s.

author: kyfdx
text:
Oh... from the looks of it.... No reason that it couldn't have been a CL65..

Debadging is cool... Rebadging sucks...

author: boomchek
text: You must be in a nice area. Over here the regular Beemers and Benzes are so common, even the SL's, that they don't seem like exclusive cars anymore. Haven't seen too many Phantoms, or Maybachs here yet. Some Ferraris though.

author: andys120
text: which hardly ever happens, I think it was an S55. I also found myself parked next to what I thought was a new Lexus GS. I was surprised when I backed out of my space and found myself staring at a badge that read "AVALON". :confuse:

author: odie6l
text:
I'm starting to see the Freestyles pop up everywhere now. I even got one as a loaner while my escape was in for it's 65k service. There are still a poop-load on lots up here around the hershey, pa area.

Odie

author: merc1
text:
I haven't seen where they "65" models are actually slower than the "55" models. I did see where C&D clocked a SL600 at 3.6 secs to 60 and a SL65 at 3.8 secs to 60 mph. I don't think that SL600 time was legit.

M

author: andys120
text: Mustangs and more Mustangs are popping up in my area. If you want to stand out don't buy a silver convertible w a black top they're everywhere. Ford has a huge hit on it's hands

author: navigator89
text:
Saw a medium blue Mustang coupe today. Love the styling, it really stands out in a good way.

I also saw a white Mercedes CLS500. Beautiful car.

author: kyfdx
text:
Saw the first Mustang car ads in the paper touting price.. $72 over invoice for any Mustang on the lot... 12 available.

I'm surprised it took this long..

author: stickguy
text:
True, but they are all going to be V6 AT coupes. Also possible they have lots of ad-ons to drive up the price.

I don't think you r are getting a GT or a COnvert for $72 over real invoice anytime soon.
\
And, make sure this isn't 1 new one, and 11 left over old style ones!

author: kyfdx
text: I'd say just about October for the convertibles..

author: stan6201
text: I saw a car based (like a mini El Camino) pickup on the I-15 in Corona, CA. On the tailgate was "Toronado". I do not know who makes it and have not been able to find any info. It looks like the perfect size for what I want in a second car and would really appreciate any input.

author: seminole_kev
text: perhaps something sold in Mexico?

author: lemko
text: ...just bought a new gray 2005 Hyundai Sonata GLS SV. He traded his white 2000 Hyundai Sonata for it and got the 0% financing. Apparently, he's happy with Hyundai.

author: fintail
text: Well, I am now living in a semi-trendy part of Bellevue WA, which is like a yuppie haven. I've seen just about every current model MB, BMW, and Lexus over the past 24 hours.

author: ateixeira
text:
I bet all they have on the lot are V6/automatics, the secretary's special. The GT is in higher demand, and the drop-top is still new.

Edit: what stickguy said.

Saw a Freestyle on the road today...still not that common though.

-juice

author: merc1
text:
Speaking of Ford I did spot a Ford GT yesterday. A pretty awesome sight on the road. It was red with the usual white stripes. Saw a Gallardo earlier this morning.

Also saw a "Mars Red" SLK350. The new SLK is becoming a regular sight now.

M

author: merc1
text:
Finally saw a SLK55 AMG tonight. Real exotic looking at night especially from the back. Typical rectangle MB tailights with a smaller dot on top. Really classy.

M

author: fintail
text: I've seen several new GS over the past 24 hrs, a few new SLK and ML, a M45 (I was blown away by its unremarkable looks - I actually like the old one), a new Vette, and a Mustang convert that I think was a rental

author: merc1
text:
Also got a chance to really notice the Hyundai Tucson, drove beside it for miles. This is the cutest little SUV on the road. I mean it’s as cute as a speckled puppy.

M

author: davem2001
text:
I haven't seen where they "65" models are actually slower than the "55" models.

It was either C&D or R&T (I can't remember) but they did say that the 65 had just so much torque that it overwhelmed the tires and the "lesser" model was actually quicker to 60.

author: anythngbutgm
text: I read in a few sources that the S/SL65 motor can pull 1000 ft/lbs of torque, but had to be de'tuned to the 800 ft/lbs because MB couldn't find a tranny strong enough to handle that kind of power... That is just plain nuts, Wow. :surprise:

author: merc1
text:
Yeah that was the SL65 vs the SL600, not the SL55. That time of 3.6 secs that C&D got for the SL600 hasn't been duplicated by anyone else. The SL65 was clocked at 3.8 secs, but I suspect that SL600 time was very abnormal. No one else has been able to get a SL600 to 60 mph in 3.6 secs.

M

author: odie6l
text:
http://www.geocities.com/odie442/pictures/ute1.jpg

http://www.geocities.com/odie442/pictures/ute2.jpg

Did the car based pick-up look like either of these?
The 1st link is the 2005 Ford Falcon XR8 Ute.
The 2nd link is the 2005 Holden SS Ute.

I personally think these would fly off the lots here in the states.

Both vehicles are sold in austrailia, but from what I've heard you can purchase the Falcon Ute in Mexico.

Odie

author: davem2001
text: Maybe it was the nice weather - saw an Escape Hybrid on the road (first one I'd seen), then a new Rolls-Royce.

author: ateixeira
text:
Baja has not sold well, even with the turbo.

But those are 2 seaters with a bigger bed, not a crew cab with a tiny bed.

Saw a Five Hundred and a new Sportage.

-juice

author: seminole_kev
text: I see a ton of Ford 500's here. Must be selling well in this area.

author: jaserb
text:
I still see the old ones, usually with a diesel, every once in a while. Seems like it would be a natural fit with the new TDI engines. A light duty runabout pickup that gets 40++ MPG would fill the gap left by the supersizing of the Frontier, Dakota, Colorado, Tacoma ...

Edit: Here's a Brazilian version, actually looks surprisingly butch. These are tiny, much smaller than the current Ranger, but something more the size of a Jetta wagon would probably work here.



-Jason

author: navigator89
text:
Saw the refreshed BMW 7 from the rear. It was parked in someone's driveway along with a black Cadillac Escalade and black Cadillac SRX.

The car's taillamps look incomplete, as if the bottom segment is missing. When I see previous generation BMW 7's, some of them look really good, better than the current version.

Also saw a white Ford Thunderbird, and a silver Lincoln Navigator. I know they aren't new, but for me they're pretty rare.

author: fintail
text:
I saw a current model 6er cabrio today...not so unusual, but this one was absolutely filthy, looked like it had just driven the Alaska Highway in winter or something. It was white, which didn't help.

A blinged out G-wagen just drove by my window, looked like it had 24" wheels. Money and taste are mutually exclusive.

author: ateixeira
text:
Jason - that's based on the brazilian Gol, which is a smaller platform than the Golf. In fact it's even smaller than the Polo.

They'll never certify that for the US, but maybe something Golf-based like you mentioned.

-juice

author: stickguy
text:
I was going to vote yes, you are crazy, but that picture does look pretty slick.

VW might as well give it a try. They need something to liven up the brand.

The biggest problem these days might be the cabin space. 2 seaters are a touch sell, unless the top goes down.

But, if they package and price this right, they might sell a few.

author: kyfdx
text: Umm... I think this is why the last one didn't work..

author: stickguy
text:
worked OK on the Rbbit and Rampage (Dodge OMni varient), since they were small and not really designed (or sized) to carry heavy loads or do any towing. Certainly not a good idea for an F150.

Throw on Quattro if you are worried about traction.

author: kyfdx
text:
I didn't think it worked on the Rabbit... I still can see guys with a load of Sakrete or mulch going down the road with the front wheels bouncing off the ground... The Rampage... well.. it had enough other problems, just being an Omnirizon at heart..

I'm still iffy about the Ridgeline... even though it is AWD, it is still a FWD based system... Not good for hauling..

I guess you could get a Baja.. then there would be three of you....

author: ateixeira
text:
There are at least 5 or 6.

-juice

author: jaserb
text:
Most of the fleet trucks I see (think auto parts runners, etc) are still 4-cyl reg cab Rangers. The only redeeming quality I see in them is the 25/29 EPA rating, which is far and away the best you're going to get in a truck. My buddy has an Diesel Isuzu P'up that he won't sell for anything, because it hauls stuff and gets 40 MPG. Maybe make the VW TDI pickup a mini-Ridgeline with 4 doors and a small bed and you're getting somewhere. Make it a bit bigger then the Baja with Touareg styling and I'd buy one. Baja didn't fail because it was a bad idea, it failed because it's Ugly with a capital Ug.

-Jason

author: kyfdx
text:
It was still a bad idea.. It was bad when they made the Brat, and it is still bad..

Of course, here in german sausage country, we pronounced it Braht..

author: i_luv_toyota
text:
I finally have seen my first Ridgeline today. I have seen them at the Dealer lots before, but never on the roads until today. It was red with the obligatory (at least around here) chrome reflecting front plate with chrome Honda logo on it.

Not only was I blinded by the sunlight coming off of it (the plate), but I was also blinded by the sheer ugliness of the thing, LOL.

author: andys120
text:
Ridgeline are getting popular here in NH which is Pickup Country.
A friend of mine recently bought a Nissan Titan, which is huge. He's already concerned about poor mileage .

I told him he should get a diesel Ford if he wanted a big truck but he didn't listen.

author: fintail
text: I've seen about 5 Lotus Elise over the past few days, and yesterday I drove behind a silver Bentley Continental. I expected it to be bigger somehow.

author: fintail
text:
I saw a new style Jetta today, and it was a lowline - from what
I could tell, it had plastic wheel covers. Not a good look...

author: boomchek
text: Keep seeing the Audi A3's at the Automall where I work. It's actually a very nice looking vehicle, with good lines no matter from which angle you look at it. I guess they must have arrived about a week ago.

author: navigator89
text:
Just saw the new Aston Martin DB9 as it drove by me. It was a nice grey color. The car looks better than it does in pictures. The styling is fantastic.

Also saw a silver Bentley Continental in the fast lane of the highway. One of the best looking vehicles out there for sure.

And finally, a brown BMW 1 series. I'm glad BMW didn't goof the styling. It looks perfect.

author: lemko
text: ...red Corvette C6 coupe. This car is BEAUTIFUL!!!

author: teds1
text:
Last night a Silver Aston Martin DB9 (possibly vanquish I was distracted and they look really similar) slowly turned a corner in front of me driven by Michael Strahan (NY Giants player). He was with a a laughing blonde and seemed to be lovin life. The car was stunnning so I can understand why.

I also saw my first m35x infiniti... I don't know why it's so boring looking. The g35 sedan which is'nt thaaaat gorgeous blows this one away. i know it is suposed to be a great car but it doesn't convey any exitement... same with the new gs lexus

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw only my 2nd new Jetta V. They're still rare around here.

-juice

author: anythngbutgm
text:
GS300 AWD at the carwash this morning. Nice gun-metal Gray color, very sharp.

Drove up to Nashua,NH (approx 20 miles from my home). Counted 14 new Avalons on the way there and back! Challenging the Ody for most popular new model I guess...

author: andys120
text:
I'm seeing a lot of new Avalons too (I live 35 miles the other way from Nashua).

I got a good look at a metallic Red C6 Corvette coupe. It's nice enough to look at but didn't really blow me away. Fit and finish were very good but IMO the 'Vette needs a new design language. The styling isn't nearly as impressive as the performance.

author: ateixeira
text:
Must be a hit because I've parked close to 3 at a time once. They are all over the place.

Saw a Buick Terraza, the nose and rest of the body almost seem like 2 different vehicles. At least it helped in crash tests, but it ain't pretty.

Plus I think I've only seen about 2-3 CSVs, as GM likes to call them, so far.

-juice

author: stickguy
text:
An Avalon today, couple of Jettas, and a C6 coupe.

Also a very recent Ferrari in a local neighborhood.

author: kyfdx
text:
and anything else that Toyota comes out with.. There is a Toyota parts distribuition warehouse about a mile from my workplace, and all of the managers get company cars..

Amazingly, they all drive like teenagers... If any type of Toyota blows by me at 90 MPH on the freeway on the way in... you can guarantee it has the Ohio distributor license plates..

regards,
kyfdx

PS: the Avalon is a good looking car for what it is..

author: i_luv_toyota
text:
Aside from no sales tax, you seem to have a lot of 05 Avalons up there! Here in Connecticut (where everything is taxed...), I have only seen 3, and only ONE of those had CT plates (the others had ME and NY plates, IIRC). I love the way they look and want to see more of them on the road!

And speaking of the Ridgeline, I saw one today with something done to it that I wouldn't think would happen this soon. It was silver with 20"+ chrome rims on it! Luckily I only saw it for 2 seconds max as it rolled by my workplace.

I never have figured to see a "pimped out" Ridgeline so soon! I fear it's only the beginning...

author: i_luv_toyota
text:
"Amazingly, they all drive like teenagers... If any type of Toyota blows by me at 90 MPH on the freeway on the way in... you can guarantee it has the Ohio distributor license plates.."

It's probably not their own personal car, so the whole "rental car" theory would come into play here (drive it like you stole it!).

"PS: the Avalon is a good looking car for what it is.. "

Yes, it certainly is!

author: kyfdx
text: They are definitely company cars, and not personal company-subsidized leases.. I understand the whole "rental car" thing.. I'm just not sure how they keep their licenses....

author: fintail
text:
I saw a new Maserati whatever they are called coupe...very pretty, and you can see the Ferrari influence somehow

I'm seeing 3-5 new GS every day now, but I do live a few blocks from a Lexus dealer, and a Lexus here is like a Toyota elsewhere.

author: boomchek
text:
Yes the Avalon is a fine looking vehicle. I actually like it better than the Lexus ES330. If you like the exterior you should check out the inside, especially with white/light beige leather. It's so spacious and the dashboard is very nicely laid out.

Speaking of the Ridgelines we "pimped out" one in our showroom with 20" chrome rims, it looks really sharp.

author: ateixeira
text:
Maybe the same one stickguy saw.

I heard the staccato of a nice V8, thought Ferrari, and sure enough, pulled up next to an F430 Spyder, the thing was just gorgeous. Deepest red paint I've ever seen, felt like it had 70 coats of shining paint.

Light turned green and heard the V8 rev up to pull away, but then he turned left and I went straight.

It was more fun to hear than it was to see.

-juice

author: bgill
text: Yesterday in Hyannis MA, I saw a Mercedes CLS60 AMG with badging indicating a biturbo V-12 engine. I can't even find anything on the web indicating that such a car exists, but there it was.

author: davem2001
text: I think the top end CLS is a 55 - supercharged V8, not a 65 - twin turbo V12.

author: fintail
text:
Looks like a shoddy rebadging...the highest CLS is indeed the CLS55

Of course someone might have taken it upon themselves to drop a V12 into it....but I can't imagine.

author: ateixeira
text:
Pathetic, there are pretenders even at that level.

-juice

author: davem2001
text:
Heck, it was probably "just" a base CLS (350? 500?) with AMG wheels and a fake badge job....

What would be really bad is if the owner doesn't know any better and got taken by a shady used car dealer.

author: bgill
text: actually, I see that Edmunds' future vehicles reports a CLS AMG with a biturbo V-12 to be on sale in September. The only difference from what I saw is that they call it a CLS65 rather than CLS60. So maybe this was legit, and somebody got hold of an early release from MB.

author: davem2001
text: I really doubt it - just the fact that it has 60 instead of 65 screams that it's a fake to me.

author: anythngbutgm
text: I agree the Avalon makes the ES pretty redundant. A woman here at work just traded her 96 Avy for a new Limited. Her old one hit 190,000 miles and she just wanted something different. Nice ride, very nice.

author: teds1
text: Unless it was a CL65 which does exists and the spotter got confused about the lettering, just a possibility. The cls is pretty unique though... fyi the word is that there will not be a cls65 (twin turbo v12) only a 55. I'm getting used to it and I saw it on MTV cribs already so I guess not everybody hates it... when I first saw it though I didn't like it at all

author: anythngbutgm
text:
My wifes business partner has one. Nice car, beautiful Earthy gree color, more Walnut on the dash than plastic. Rediculously quick.

It's a CLS500 "designo edition". Who the heck is Designo? Is there a "Cornholio edition" too? :confuse:

author: fintail
text:
Designo is special paint and interior materials

CLS has a nice interior, but I am not won over by the body

author: andys120
text:
CLS has a nice interior, but I am not won over by the body

Me too. I was reserving judgement til I actually saw one and now that I have
I wasn't impressed I'd rather have an E-Class, that's a beautiful car!

author: fintail
text:
I saw a goodie today...I guess it belongs here. It was a current S class sedan badged as a S55 AMG. Well, it had a single exhaust. The AMG badge looked kinda big. It had these ridiculous blingy wheels that would have looked better on some cliched Escalade or Denali etc. And the worst part was this odd chrome trim applied to the borders of the headlights and taillights. The ultimate poser.

Oh, and I did notice the other day that the 6cyl S-class is coming back to NA, S350. It's about time. Now we need the CDi.

author: ghulet
text: Is this in the current body S-class or the new body? It would seem kind of strange to start selling a six in the current body since it's been out for six years now.

author: fintail
text: It's for the 06 model

author: fintail
text: Someone in my building just bought one of those F series Lincoln trucks. No further comment

author: boomchek
text: I saw one on the road already, the Lincoln Mark LT, looks just like the F150, except for the wheels and front.

author: fintail
text: Ah yeah thats what it is. I don't know what they were thinking...but hey, they sold one anyway.

author: fintail
text: Today saw a few Elise, 2x Continentals sitting at the Bentley dealer, and a CLS55

author: anythngbutgm
text: My first Infiniti M. Brilliant Silver M45 roaring down the highway. Nice prescence to it, beefy, planted stance, almost reminded me of an older Mercedes. Nice... if you can afford one.

author: kyfdx
text: Wrangler Unlimited... The stretched one.. Either the first one that I've seen, or the first one I've noticed..

author: anythngbutgm
text: Jet black Charger R/T. Nice, very nice.

author: boomchek
text: Charger is on sale already?

author: anythngbutgm
text: Must be just hitting the showrooms, this thing was brand new, parked at a house party. Jet black, R/T with spoiler. There's a Dodge dealer right in town (Fitchburg, MA) Looks real sharp.

author: danf1
text: A dealer down the street from me has about 10 of them sittimg in fromt of his showroom. It looks better than the pictures, but I still like the magnum better.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new Maserati Quattroporte this evening...dark blue and quite lovely. Just a glimpse tells you it is something special.

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw my first A3 on the road, looks sharp, too bad it's so small.

Saw another Jetta, only my 2nd on the streets. Slow start, older Jettas are abundant around here.

This was wild - saw a brand new Mercedes A-class today - too far away to see what type of plates but I guess they were diplomatic. Looks a bit better than the dorky old one.

-juice

author: stickguy
text:
Saw a new Tribeca yesterday at the minigolf place. A sort of mint green, not an attractive color IMO.

It had manufacturer plates on it, but not surprising, since I live about 10 miles from SOA headquarters.

I actually think the butt may be even less atrtractive than the nose. At least the profile and interior seem nice.

From what I have read, it is a very nice driving and comfortable unit. Also seems to be a good value (at least if you stay away from the techno stuff). I just think Sube went too far making it distinctive. Have to imagine that they could keep the basic shape while cleaning up the nose and tail a bit, and sell quite a few more.

I also saw a pic of a recent Alfa concept (upcoming on my car of the day claendar). You can really see the relationship on the nose!

Also saw a black Charger on the street (only one so far). Had temp tags, so it had at least been sold.

author: jaserb
text:
The Charger I saw was black as well. Has a nice presence, without being as "out there" as the 300. The Accord Hybrid I only noticed because it had special "clean air" plates that allow solo driving in the carpool lanes. Very different from the Prius' "lookit me, I'm drivin a HYBRID!" styling.

-Jason

author: ateixeira
text:
Looks better in dark colors, my wife fancies the black one. They should offer a black mesh grille insert to tone down the front a bit, that would look better than the wide horizontal chrome strips on there now.

Here's a comparo of the noses - Andreas Zapatinas is the head designer for Subaru and guess where he worked before? Yup...Alfa.

Spotted at the beach this weekend: Ferrari F360 and a black Ridgeline that my wife said resembled Batman's ride.

-juice

author: odie6l
text:
I've seen 3 H3's running around the Hershey Area (and that doesn't count the one I test drove). They look alot better than the H2. It kinda reminds me of a Wrangler on Steroids.

Odie

author: navigator89
text: a red Land Rover LR3. The second one I've seen.

author: fintail
text: This morning I saw a black Maserati sedan and a Mercedes Sprinter van. Not a Dodge, but a Mercedes...it had the star and the emblem, etc. It was a MB dealer service vehicle, so for all I know it was a Dodge with a different front end assembly.

author: kyfdx
text: Of Hummer H3s..

author: davem2001
text: I've been seeing them lately with FREIGHTLINER badges, too... The only thing that's different, as far as I know, is the badge on the grille.

author: ghulet
