text: Yeesh. It goes for about $27k on this side of the border, and it's not like shipping from Australia to Canada is that much farther.

author: fintail
text:
I've seen about 20 new Corollas in the past couple days...must be some big attraction.

Also my second G8...a high model I assume as it had a lot of cladding.

author: ateixeira
text: Still odd looking to me. Looks like a gigantic hatchback.

author: boomchek
text:
this morning on the way to work: a new charcoal C63 AMG. Very aggressive exhaust note.

Also a new 2009 SL in black. I'm not sure I like the new headlight design of it, from afar it looks like a SLK, up close the front, and the side fender cladding (vents behind front wheels) make it look tacky, especially on black color.

author: fintail
text:
Damn, I still haven't seen a C63. My indy MB mechanic said a guy who bought one stopped by to show it off, so there's one around. I suspect they aren't sitting on the lots very long. I've heard the exhaust on youtube, it's sick...in a good way of course.

I'm not sold on the SL facelift either. It seems to be change for the sake of change.

author: boomchek
text:
Out of the recent Benzes I never liked the CLS front end nor the new SL. Just really unusual headlight shape.

I too don't like change for the sake of change, but I guess it's cheaper to redo the front end rather than the whole car.

author: lemko
text: Spotted a dark red metallic Chrysler Crossfire convertible last night.

author: kyfdx
text:
..spotted while driving on I-26, a few miles from the BMW plant..

An X6 and a 1-series convertible..

author: boomchek
text:
I've also seen a X6. I think it's a silly looking car but the looks are growing on me.

Anyone seen any Challengers on the road yet? A week ago some Chrysler head office guys pulled up in one to our dealership. But we haven't seen any land in our store yet.

author: bumpy
text: The Crossfire died a few years back, then it came back for a year before dying again. :confuse:

author: fintail
text:
What's the big new open Rolls called, the one with the strange A-pillar and suicide doors? Is it just a Phantom convertible?

I actually saw one on the road today. It's massive, almost cartoonish compared to a normal car. I wish I could have snapped a pic, but I was out for a walk.

author: guss
text: Very nice.....but it is od to see a Jaguar that does not look like a Jaguar. It was very similar to Lexus styling.

author: ateixeira
text:
It's out of production, along with the PT Cruiser convertible.

They had way too many convertibles competing against each other - the PT, the Sebring, and the Crossfire, all in the same showroom!

Saw a black 2009 Forester driving on Route 50 while on the way to the beach on Friday. They're becoming abundant rather quickly.

author: texases
text:
"Saw a black 2009 Forester driving on Route 50 while on the way to the beach on Friday. They're becoming abundant rather quickly. "

Should become even more popular - the Forester just got rated CR's top small CUV.

author: ateixeira
text:
I just got my issue last night, haven't read the article yet.

That surely won't hurt.

author: kyfdx
text:
On the used car lot of a local dealer group... We went by on our way to dinner tonight.. and my son said: "There is a Challenger there next to that Viper"..

No way... why would they have that down here on their used lot?

Sure enough, on the way home... there it is.. :surprise:

author: lemko
text: ...still make the Viper?

author: qbrozen
text:
yes, for now.
recently came out with their newest track version, too. The ACR. It did very well (performance-wise) in a comparo this month vs a 911 Turbo, Z06, and GTR.

author: guss
text: I went in for an oil change at the dealer and they had 2 of these. I get the feeling they will be the next Aztec. I give Ford credit for thinking outside the box, but they should have come up with something other than a box.

author: boomchek
text: I've seen one as well (Ford Flex) and read a recent Motor Trend review on it. MT says that Ford hopes it will be their next 85 Taurus, or 65 Mustang (meaning a sales hit), but I think, it's just another run of the mill crossover. I'm not too fond of the looks. I like the Pacifica better imo as it's the same class of car.

author: ateixeira
text: Rogue and an Altima coupe this weekend.

author: guss
text: I saw the MT article also and was wondering if it would look better in person. It may be space efficient, but the simulated woody look has got to go. I give it 3 years before they restyle it.

author: guss
text: on the way to work today. Kinda looks like the old Charger on steroids.

author: explorerx4
text: it was orange. it didn't look as big as i thought it would. at first glance i didn't think it was bigger than a mustang. it seemed kind of wide but that was always the style. i like it, although i prefer mustangs.

author: stever
text: Only this one was bright yellow with ads all over it.

author: texases
text:
"bright yellow with ads all over it. "

I bet they'll sell lots of smarts for advertising, just like Scion did with the xB. I saw an all-black smart last week - kinda of missed the point, seems to me. No ones going to think it's 'bad', and it lost lots of visibility in all black. :confuse:

author: fintail
text: Today's new sightings - a Ford Flex and a MB McLaren SLR roadster (on the same street I saw the RR Phantom convertible, no less)

author: boomchek
text: There's a lot of companies in Vancouver using the smart as a promo vehicle. We had the smart for about 3 - 4 years nowin Canada and I think it does make a good promotional vehicle as it's different so it stands out, good on gas (we had the diesel here) and it's inexpensive to buy.

author: fintail
text: This morning I saw another new style SL and a new Pilot.

author: stever
text:
Spotted a green Zebra of all things tonight.

Like the smart car I saw the other day, this one was being used as an ad car. With 4 doors, it looks more practical than a smart. Until you wanted to go more than 25 miles at 40 mph anyway.

author: kyfdx
text: In Red... haven't seen too many of these.. no local dealership, yet..

author: bumpy
text: That thing was a lot bigger than I had thought it would be.

author: lemko
text: ...off-white Ford Edge.

author: andys120
text: I noticed a couple of off-white/cream colors Lincoln MKX's. Maybe that color is making a comeback which would be OK with me since there are few cars that look good in the boring Frigidaire White that is ubiquitous now.

author: andys120
text:
I'm seeing Honda Fits everywhere, 7 out of 10 are silver or grey. 6 Months ago I'd see one a month, now I'm seeing one or two every day.

It's probaly sell even better if it didn't have a stupid name. :P

author: boomchek
text:
I think we're going to see much more subcompacts everywhere with the gas prices the way they are.

We're a Chrysler store, but we sell a ton of 1 year old Yarises. Can't keep them in stock.

author: andys120
text: I'm seeing plenty of Yarises but I think the Fits are outnumbering them as well as the Nissan Verve.

author: fintail
text: A friend of mine says he saw a Hyundai commercial being filmed in downtown Seattle the other day - the cars had the fake plates always seen in ads. He says he saw a Genesis and some very small Hyundai, he didn't know what it was. I wonder if it is even something for the NA market.

author: 06stang
text:
but I saw the new 2009 Dodge Challenger yesterday. Didn't even know they were out yet :P I took a 3-day trip to the coast and there was one parked at the Tillamook County Smoker.

Also, nothing special, but i saw at least 20 of the new 2009 Hyundai Sonatas. Saw maybe 2-3 of the new Accords and Malibus, but seemed like there was one after another of the new Sonatas. How well are these things selling?

author: fintail
text: Today I saw a Jag XF and shortly after the new Lincoln which somehow reminds me of it.

author: fintail
text: I'll bet those Sonatas were mainly rentals...up in Seattle anyway many fleets carry those.

author: 06stang
text: Ah.. that makes sense. I couldn't believe that the new Sonata's were doing THAT good. :blush:

author: magnette
text:
Went to the London Motor Show today. Among the highlights were the launch of the new Lotus Evora (it's been code-named Eagle until now, and I'm not sure about the name they settled on). Also sat in the Alfa Mito, which is really quite nice, although very much from the Fiat school of interior finish...



Girls on the Alfa stand looked good too

author: boomchek
text: The shape of the Lotus, especially the greenhouse, and the way the windows kink up at the B pillar, reminds me of the old Lancia Stratos

author: lemko
text: Oh, there were plenty of privately owned 2009 Dodge Challengers on display at the Carlisle Mopar show.

author: fintail
text: To me, Evora sounds/looks like an Aussie name...but cool cars. You should come to NA and attend a show, you'll be blown away by the awesome stuff available here

author: fintail
text: I saw an Ariel Atom today...first one of those I have seen in motion

author: boomchek
text:
Dropped by my old Honda dealership today, and had a look at the Pilot. My buddy showed me one they have that they use for demos, as they can't get any in, and wait list is on till September.

Looks better than in pictures. I'm not fond of the Pilot's bulldog face, and some of the plastic trim inside, but otherwise it's anice change from the old one that was getting boring to me.

author: qbrozen
text:
A wait list? Huh. Should send the buyers to NJ.

I also stopped at the Honda dealer this weekend. They had one in their showroom and more on the lot. At first, as I was sitting in the showroom, I looked over and thought "huh. why would they put a Pathfinder in their showroom."

I really don't like it. Previous gen was much better looking. And the price has gotten up there, too. Our '03 EXL was about $31k. I checked the sticker and this EX with no leather or moonroof was over $32k. Then the dealer tacked on a bunch of crap, including $1300 running boards!

author: boomchek
text:
Then the dealer tacked on a bunch of crap, including $1300 running boards!

I find Honda is notorious for overpriced accessories. I learned that when I went to work for Nissan, and then Chrysler, and found most of the stuff including running boards and spoilers to be half price.

author: andys120
text: I agree Boomchek, the old Pilot looked too much like a Minivan, the new one has a much stronger look that will probably attract more male buyers, perhaps at the expense of females.

author: lemko
text: ...spotted by a Camry Hybrid and an Accord Hybrid in the same champagne color.

author: andys120
text: I'm no big fan of boxy SUVs but the black RR Sport I saw this morning had a certain appeal, perhaps because it's so rare these days to see 70s-style tall side glass.

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw one of these little buggers this morning, also with ads plastered on the side.

I've seen a couple of Pilots and they don't look any better in person. Maybe I'll get used to them.

author: kyfdx
text:
I'm starting to see a few of these every week...

Somehow, I don't see them taking off like the MINI...

author: magnette
text:
They did here .. I bet if your prices get as high as ours, they would be more popular there, too - but only in urban areas, as I can't imagine anyone would use one to cruise across the praries, or something....
Having said that, I was passed by a Smart Fortwo the other day on the motorway - I was doing more than 80mph, and he came past at more than 90.... Probably still doing 50mpg, even then

author: kyfdx
text: All automatics over here.... I doubt any are getting 50 mpg..

author: qbrozen
text: On my way home from work on Friday, I spotted an orange Challenger parked out in no-man's land in a nearby office parking lot.

author: texases
text:
"I spotted an orange Challenger parked out in no-man's land in a nearby office parking lot. "

I saw my first one yesterday, coming the other way. OK, but lacks the 'wow' factor the current model Mustang had for me.

author: lemko
text: ...black VW Eos convertible as I was coming home from work yesterday afternoon.

author: texases
text: I saw one of those VW Eoses (?) too - looks didn't do much for me, seems that making a hard top retract results in odd proportions.

author: kyfdx
text: It does have the stubby nose look.. gets worse with the top down, IMO..

author: texases
text:
"gets worse with the top down, IMO.. "

Yes, and that's the opposite of what most (regular) convertibles do...

author: boomchek
text:
New Lambo Gallrdo roadster. White color. Way cool. Came into our dealership (he bought a Jeep from us before). He showed us how the front suspension raises for speedbumps and driveways.

He also has a black Bentely Continental GT that he lets his teenage son drive :surprise:

author: ateixeira
text: I think a lot of hardtops look that way, though, i.e. not as clean as a soft top.

author: ateixeira
text: Saw a new one in our garage. Camry Junior.

author: kyfdx
text: Sounds like you are on a tilt... better stay away from the car lots..

author: ateixeira
text:
At work, I mean, not ours.

Though I am thinking about a new Miata... and I have 3 buyers lined up for my 93 Miata.

author: lemko
text: ...was behind a black Porsche Cayman at the corner of Cottman and Oxford in NE Philly at lunchtime yesterday.

author: ateixeira
text:
That's funny because I've seen 2 of them this week, and they're still pretty rare around here.

One was at Summit Point raceway, another here in DC.

I have also seen a couple of new Corollas driving around.

author: fintail
text: Parked beside a new TSX the other day. I have seen them on the road but not up close. It seems to have grown about 20% in every direction...and not in a good way. It just looks kind of bloated now, compared to the relatively elegant old one.

author: ateixeira
text: I sat in one at the local mall, and know what you mean. It's not the compact it once was.

author: fintail
text: I'm pretty sure I saw an 09 Fit on the road today.

author: lemko
text: ...yellow and black Smart car at work last Friday! Seems one of my co-workers bought one as I saw it going in the gate at lunchtime.

author: bksward
text:
And which super hero left his shield sitting on the front bumper?

Its like an Accord mated with something from Cadillac...

Makes the chrome on the bumper of the current generation Jetta look subtle...

author: andys120
text:
Not the more truckish looking 2009 model but brand new '08s, the first I have seen.
Al so spotted in my rearview a brand new E92 BMW M3 in a pretty shade of LeMans Blue (BMW has more different blues than anyone). In the rearview I mistook it for a 335ic, I didn't notice the hood bump but when it blitzed past me I spotted the tailpipes
and the M3 emblem.

author: fintail
text:
That's a good comparison, it has some Caddy DNA, and not in a good way.

I also really do not like the ad campaign for these things, touting it as a car for that mysterious common-as-hens-teeth demographic of ultra-successful young entrepreneurs. Most TSX I see around here are driven by middle aged women. Blaoting up the car and making it chromey won't make the 3/C/IS/G set run to it, nor those who "start a business, sell it, and buy another" who probably drive Ferraris, Porsches and the like..

author: fintail
text:
I have seen a couple new M3s....they are more subtle than the previous version, but you can sure hear them as they go by. Still haven't seen a C63.

I also saw a new style A4 last night...I give it a year before LED running lights become as much of a cliche as fender vents.

author: lemko
text: ...or is there actually going to be a BMW M3 with a V-8?

author: texases
text:
"or is there actually going to be a BMW M3 with a V-8? "

Yep, a 4 liter one, I think. I'm sure it's faster, but it seems like they're leaving some history/character/whatever behind. Kind of like when Saab stopped selling hatchbacks.

author: andys120
text:
Yep, a 4 liter one, I think. I'm sure it's faster, but it seems like they're leaving some history/character/whatever behind. Kind of like when Saab stopped selling hatchbacks.

I agree with you but given the gas price situation I'll bet the next M3 is more like the current 335i (turbo 6) than the current M3.

The twin turbo 135i is quite the little rocket, nearly as fast as the new M3.

author: fintail
text: I saw a white new M3 a few minutes ago, and as a strange coincidence a black late 80s M3 also drove by.

author: andys120
text:
I look in my rearview and see what looks like an A-M V8 Vantage coming up, a second look reveals that it is in fact a Jaguar XK, when he passed me I noticed two things, the driver and passenger were in their late 70s or early 80s and the car wore a small "R-Type" badge (performance model).

This was a great looking car, better looking than photos. It looks too much like an Aston but those are, after all, some of the best looking cars out there. Once you realize that there will never again be a car as beautiful as the Series I E-Type, you can accept the XK-R as the beautiful car it is.

BTW, it was a silver coupe. :shades:

author: lemko
text: Spotted a black Mercedes-Benz S550 on my way to work this morning. It was driven by a very casually dressed older man wearing a baseball cap.

author: ateixeira
text:
This was funny - we drove by a Smart dealer the other day and did *NOT* see any Smarts.

We did not go inside but I guess they have none in stock. Perhaps you have to get on a wait list?

The lot was full of big Benzes.

author: ateixeira
text: Any by the way I'm finally starting to see a few of these. They're not popping up like the MDX when it was launched, though, so I bet sales are down.

author: bumpy
text:
We did not go inside but I guess they have none in stock. Perhaps you have to get on a wait list?

Yep. You sign up and put down your $99 deposit online, wait 6-9-12 months for the email password to configure your car, then wait another 3-4 months to go to dealer and pick it up.

There should have been some demo cars around, though.

author: guss
text: I saw a black and white one the other day at a busy intersection with a for sale sign on it. I was in a rush so I did not get to see the asking price. I am sure the owner was looking to make a profit though.

author: ateixeira
text:
I just drove past the front of the dealer. Saw a big "Smart" sign but no cars. I'm sure they had one in the showroom.

I've seen about 2 or 3 Infiniti EX35s already. Those things are so small - like a sport utility hatchback.

author: texases
text:
"I've seen about 2 or 3 Infiniti EX35s already. Those things are so small - like a sport utility hatchback. "

I thought about looking at one, but, like you said, they're SMALL, very tight rear seat. NYT article talked about them as a 'reward car' for women. Top it off, they weigh 4000 lbs. Ouch!

author: lemko
text: ...last night on my way to my second job.

author: fintail
text:
" NYT article talked about them as a 'reward car' for women."

Ouch indeed!

I would at least see men driving the FX (I rarely see men driving RX and X3 etc).

author: lemko
text: Reward for what? I thought that was what jewelry was for? My girlfriend would want either a new Buick LaCrosse or a Cadillac CTS.

author: boomchek
text:
One of my co workers just picked up a fully loaded EX35. It's a nice lil hatchback SUV if you need the space. He doesn't have kids anyways so back seat is not an issue.

I like the around view monitor in that car, pretty neat.

author: texases
text: Yes, it looks like you can get a load of interesting options on it. No kids = no problem with the back seat space.

author: ateixeira
text:
True, but...why not get a G37 coupe, then? Much sportier.

The EX doesn't make a whole lot of sense to me. Where's the utility?

The 360 degree camera thing is neat, but that's looking at the glass half full. A half empty point of view might complain that they created massive blind spots in the first place. Then of course they charge you thousand of dollars to address a poor visibility issue that they basically designed-in.

Ka-ching. Infiniti cashes in on their own mistake. Sucker consumers pay extra for a needless (if visibility were OK) gadget.

author: texases
text:
"The EX doesn't make a whole lot of sense to me. Where's the utility? "

I agree, not much cargo/people room, and especially about the visibility. Nissan/Infiniti has been especially bad on this. I just don't get it. Kinda takes the "U" out of SUV/CUV.

author: boomchek
text:
I guess it appeals to same kind of people that want a small roomy vehicle ala X3, Tiguan, even CR-V or RAV4 but more luxurious.

People buy weird stuff that doesn't make sense all the time. That's what keep me employed.

author: fintail
text: I saw an X6 today in Vancouver, Barf

author: boomchek
text: The X6 is starting to grow on me but I think I'd take a X5 any day over it. The X6 reminds me of a useless suv like the Suzuki X-90 thing: you ride high but can't pack much stuff in it.

author: andys120
text:
The X6 is starting to grow on me but I think I'd take a X5 any day over it

Better yet, a 535xi Sport Wagon, for me. The overweight, but not very roomy X6 is a rare total miss by BMW's product planners.

author: ateixeira
text:
Yeah, different stroke for different folks.

I like small cars, too, but the EX is very heavy, and perhaps should only have 2 doors?

Of course that has failed in the past, so they may have kept the 4 doors to give it a better chance.

author: ateixeira
text:
We own one, and yesterday we saw one, identical to ours. Limited model, Newport Blue Pearl.

It was like looking in a mirror.

Foresters are absolutely flying off the dealer lots, sales up some 50% or so. I took last week off and when I came back I found myself congratulating SEVEN (!) new owners here on Edmunds that had bought one.

author: fintail
text: I have a stinking suspicion they will probably still sell a few, as the idle trophy wife demographic loves any kind of tall wagon with a snobby badge.

author: kyfdx
text:
Even non-idle, non-trophy wives like those.. ask me how I know.. :surprise:

But, when I pointed out an EX35 to my wife, she said, "That's not an SUV, that's a wagon... I don't want a wagon."

Trust me.. when it comes to the wife's vehicular preferences, logic will not prevail... any attempt is futile..

author: andys120
text:
Trust me.. when it comes to the wife's vehicular preferences, logic will not prevail... any attempt is futile..

Tell me about it....

author: boomchek
text: Two BMW X6s on the way home in one block span. One was burgundy, one was blue. It's growing on me but I'll still take an X5. The X6 reminds me too much of an AZTEK :surprise:

author: fintail
text: I spotted this new lowline BMW soft-roader yesterday :P

author: boomchek
text:
Nice a/m grille.

Saw a bunch of cars on my trip this long weekend to Whistler.

2 Aston Martin Vantages, one convertible, one coupe.
Red Pontiac G8
Orange Boxter
Two Porsche Cayannes parked under our hotel balcony: can you spot the difference?
See more Car Pictures at CarSpace.com

author: fintail
text: The one on the right is the new one (I think). A car I care for about as much as the X6, in these parts a Cayenne is one of the ultimate posermobiles.

author: kyfdx
text:
The fastback coupe, whichever one that is..

Nice, but compared to the Aston-Martin, it looks like a Vega.. :surprise:

author: boomchek
text: Correct, the right one is the newer gen Cayenne. However I didn't go downstairs to see the diff

author: ateixeira
text:
Also, the one on the left has hood strakes so it's probably an upgraded engine option.

Why do people put fake badges on cars, who do they think they're fooling? It offends BMW owners and probably Kia owners, too.

author: kyfdx
text:
The hatchback... T5 model..

In blue metallic with chrome wheels...

author: lemko
text: ...black Lexus LS460.

author: bumpy
text: convertible, top down. The lack of a roof really highlights the brickishness of the car. :sick: :sick: :sick:

author: boomchek
text:
photos of the new TL.

Boy oh boy I hope it looks way better in real life than in photos, as that's one ugly looking car imo.

It seems as if Acura lost it's styling touch, going from beauties of the 90s (their ENTIRE model line) to these freakish lookign cars today, especially the bucktooth TSX and TL. :surprise:

author: texases
text:
"Boy oh boy I hope it looks way better in real life than in photos, as that's one ugly looking car imo. "

While I haven't seen one on the streets, I saw an ad for Motor Week on TV, and the shot they had of the TL driving towards me made me feel sick...no, I don't think it'll look better in the flesh...

author: qbrozen
text:
There's a new 128i sitting here in the parking lot at work with a temp tag. dark grey mettalic, black interior, and a stick shift. I still think its a good looking car. I don't know what all the complaints are about.

So the oddball today I spotted going the other way on one of the backroads I take to work. It was a scooter with 2 front wheels and 1 rear wheel. Now I know I've seen videos of those with 4 wheels, but I don't believe I've seen one with only 1 rear wheel. Seems very odd to me. I'm not sure what the advantage to that would be.

Edit:
A quick search leads me to believe it must have been one of these Vespas.

author: ateixeira
text: I think they look OK minus the Transformers grille.

author: praz
text: Saw a silver Passat CC in Phoenix today during rush hour.

author: ateixeira
text:
Seen a few of these lately, maybe 2 or 3 of them.

Large coupes never really appealed to me - I guess I'd rather just get a sedan, or something light if I really only need 2 doors. They look OK, though. Not sexy like the G35c.

Also saw a Smart ForTwo this AM.

author: kyfdx
text: I've only seen the Passat CC at car shows... Did it look like a production version that someone owns?

author: praz
text: Yes, it looked like production version and had PASSAT badge on the trunk without the CC. It looks awesome in pictures but on road it does not stand out. To be fair enough, it is much better than the TSX, Maxima, Passat and current TL. BTW, it had Dealer Perm registration of AZ so I called a dealer close to where I spotted the vehicle and they said they don't have one. Hoping to test drive one soon.

author: stever
text: I think it was an '08. Whatever - it was new to me. These must be rare birds, and TMV is $1,100 below invoice.

author: kyfdx
text:
The 9-7X is just a rebadged TrailBlazer/Envoy.. But, there is no budget model.. Even with the 6-cylinder, the lowest model stickers for about $42K..

With GM employee pricing, and the $8000 rebate, you can take one home for under $30K...

If you don't mind 14 mpg city.. :surprise:

author: stever
text:
Yeah, I knew it was a rebadge. It's just the only one I've ever seen. I bet they don't sell 5,000 copies a year.

Did I mention that I spotted a new 08 Grand Caravan? Last week I got a free upgrade from a Caliber to one so I got to drive it a week (I really wanted the Caliber, knowing how highly you thought of the rental Bob had in Santa Monica last year ).

I was enjoying the Caravan until my sister riding shotgun asked if something was wrong with the tires or something or did they all roll that much.

author: ateixeira
text:
Finally saw one. They seem pretty small to me.

Also saw a new Vue and a Corolla.

Oh, and saw my first Lincoln MKX. The wife liked it. I feel mixed about it.

author: boomchek
text:
Oh, and saw my first Lincoln MKX. The wife liked it. I feel mixed about it.

I'm not a big fan of the Edge or MKX either. They are kinda huge and expensive for limited use SUVs that don't stand out that much, or that don't have any unique qualities imo.

author: fintail
text: Yesterday I saw a Ferrari 612 Scaglietti, today I saw a 599 Fiorano, along with a facelift Cayenne and a facelift SL63. Some people must still be a little cash flush...or they just decided to cash out of a collapsing investment market and buy some toys.

author: lemko
text: ...white Dodge Challenger on Woodhaven Road near the Franklin Mills Mall in NE Philly.

author: bksward
text: Orange one in a parking lot at one of the Visitor Centers at Grand Teton NP about 2 weeks ago...

author: lemko
text: ...black Bentley Arnage T in the next lane over on my way home from work. What was more unusual was it's driver - a young blond-haired guy in his 20s with a white baseball cap worn sideways. Either I just saw Eminem or somebody's got a really generous or trusting father.

author: boomchek
text:
Could have been a rocker from some famous band, loaded snowbaorder or skater, actor, or like you said a random guy with a generous father.

Saw aSLR McLaren today in a MB showroom. What was different was that tghis one was a convertible. I thought they weren't out yet.

author: fintail
text:
Yeah I have seen a SLR roadster on the road here too. They've trickled in. I wonder where resale values for those will be in 10 years...

Bentley boy could also have just been some random pro athlete, lots of teams in Philly. Or maybe dad owns a highline dealership.

My new car sighting today was an 09 Fit in kind of an orange metallic...not the best color.

author: fintail
text: Spotted a new Mazda 6 today....it's a noticeable change.

author: lemko
text: ...some for the first time: silver Hyundai Genesis, light blue metallic Jaguar XF, medium gray metallic BMW 1-Series, white Mercedes-Benz CLS550, maroon Cadillac XLR.

author: ateixeira
text:
Agreed, big change. Literally, the car is huge.

I went to test drive a Miata and sat in one real quick.

The back seat is a lot roomier but you have to duck to get in the back seat.

I have mixed feelings, especially since they ditched the 5 door and wagon.

author: fintail
text:
A friend of mine has a 5-door, V6 model, I think it is an 04 or an 05. They like it and have had no problems with it, although IMO some of the interior finishes are harsh. But the average consumer doesn't notice things like that. It's versatile and they got it for a decent price.

The new one kind of looks like it could be a 5-door, but it's just a big sedan. The whole flared/bulging fender thing to make a mass-market car look aggressive is iffy too...I am sure I will have something to say when I see my first new Maxima.

author: ateixeira
text:
I agree about the interior, actually, plus it was just too close in size to the Mazda3 5 door, which is boxier and probably had more head room.

I like the fenders because it mimicks the RX8. The miata hints at it, too, only on a smaller scale.

author: fintail
text:
The new one sure looks bigger than a 3.

There's a common design theme yeah...I guess I just find it funny when cars that will in most cases be put into duty by middle-of-the-road types who aren't car enthusiasts try to look sporty and aggressive.

author: texases
text:
"I guess I just find it funny when cars that will in most cases be put into duty by middle-of-the-road types who aren't car enthusiasts try to look sporty and aggressive. "

This whole 4-door coupe thing is getting nuts - either there's not a lot of headroom in the back seat of the new 6, or you're sitting on the floor :sick:

author: fintail
text:
I can't imagine tall people fitting well back there. Even in the 5-door 6 my friend has, I think it is tight...I swear I rode back there once and if I leaned back I ran out of room.

Is the little window looking thing in the C-pillar an actual window, or just decoration? Asian design seems to love an upward kick at the end of a window line. But hell, it's better looking than a Camry anyway.

author: ateixeira
text:
Like I said, I had to duck to get in.

Headroom is actually OK, I'm 6" and had a couple of inches to spare above my head.

The seat is low, though.

The car looks better in person, though I'd say that about a lot of cars.

author: fintail
text: Today I saw a facelift Cayenne, a new Maxima (front end is weird IMO) and most noteworthy, what I am pretty sure was a Bentley Brooklands Coupe...it was behind me in traffic and made a u-turn and I barely caught a glimpse as I just assumed it was an Arnage behind me (not an unknown sight here), but it was a coupe and looked smaller than the big old 90s Continental.

author: andys120
text: I Isaw a new Maxima the other day too, I thought it looked good, perhaps the best looking Maxima yet.

author: fintail
text: I've always thought the 89-94 models were the cleanest looking, if maybe a little dull (but not bad for the time). I see too many weird creases and curves today, existing simply for the sake of having creases and curves. Bangle, you're a [non-permissible content removed].

author: boomchek
text: lol, I agree with you on the 89-94 maxim looking the best. The generation that followed lost all of it's sporty looks imo, and became another round looking mid size sedan.

author: fintail
text: The one that came after the "4DSC" was such a bland design, like the kind of debadged car you see in insurance commercials. I guess they were pretty reliable and sturdy though. The one that came after that, for MY 2000 I think, was the oddest in my eyes, like three different designs in one.

author: lemko
text: ...two Lincoln MKS - one black, one white. The first time I've seen them in the "wild."

author: andys120
text: I've seen a couple of those MKSs, they're a lot sexier than Town Cars.

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw my first one outside of the car show arena. Looked good, orange.

It was owned by the service writer at the local Mazda/VW dealer.

While I was there, I also sat in a Tiguan (too small) and also saw a Routan.

Funny thing about the Routan - the Monroney said it had alloy wheels, but this model had cheap plastic wheel covers over what seemed to me like black steel rims. I pointed it out to the salesmen, who didn't seem to mind.

How about some quality control, VW? Wrong wheels, seriously?

I went there 4 days later to pick up my Miata (had some body work done) and the same sticker was still on that van, so apparently noone cares.

author: fintail
text:
I saw 2 MB badged Sprinters today. I know the Sprinter is not new, but are they coming with the star already attached now?

I also saw 2 new Fits.

author: guss
text:
The Sprinter had a Mercedes star and a Dodge name plate ? That is weird.

My company bought a Sprinter 3 years ago and it is tough enough already to get a union member to drive it , I am sure within a week the star would disappear.

author: kyfdx
text:
Sprinters come badged as MB, Dodge or Freightliner..

Don't think there are any actual differences, other than the badges..

author: fintail
text:
Today I spotted a new M3 Cabrio and a C63 parked within a couple blocks of each other.

Also, I saw a Genesis...caught the corner of my eye, and without looking at it couldn't decide if it was an Accord or a BMW. So I had to look closer, and I saw what it was. It does have an upmarket look.

author: boomchek
text:
Fintail, you always seem to spot the nice high end stuff.

I actually saw a VW Phaeton today, and a slammed new M5 with chrome deep dish rims yesterday.

New 2009 Ram just arrived as well to our showrooms. Not bad looking truck.

author: fintail
text:
Too many people around here with a bit more money than sense, methinks.

I like the C63 a lot for what it offers, but I think AMG cars have lost one of their key values - subtlety.

I see a Phaeton parked on a street near where I live from time to time. They look like a used bargain. Locally I saw an 04 W12 model for under 20K.

author: boomchek
text: I'd hate to run into problems with a Phaeton though. I wonder what the advanced electrnics cost to fix. It's pricey enough in a run of the mill Jetta, let a lone a flagship. :surprise:

author: fintail
text: Audi parts availiability combined with VW service, sure to be fun as the car ages.

author: boomchek
text:
Especially stuff like the draft free quad zone electronic climate
control. I bet if the system goes it would cost as muich as a decent used car to fix. :surprise: :lemon:

author: fintail
text: I think those cars have a few application-specific bits that will eventually die and never be fixed. Imagine a 15 year old Phaeton with 150K miles on it, needing HVAC and engine management work.

author: lemko
text:
I imagine at least 2 tons of very prestigious scrap metal.

I saw a 1988 Rolls-Royce Corniche at the Fall Carlisle meet for sale. A sign taped to the windshield claimed "$10,000 in mechanical repairs recently completed." What did he have done? A brake job, an oil change and maybe a radiator flush?

author: fintail
text: You're probably not far off on that

author: fintail
text: I saw another black C63 today, just like the first. It could have been the same car.

author: lemko
text: ...one of those new Acura TLs with that weird chrome nose.

author: lemko
text: ...silver Dodge Nitro at lunchtime today.

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw my first new model on the roads. Looks better in person than it does in photos.

Basically looks like they modernized the old one...an evolutionary update. Which is exactly what they should have done.

author: qbrozen
text: I've been seeing those for about 9 months, maybe more. I guess its just more popular in my area? Although I can't figure out why. Fugly hummer-inspired styling, heavy, bad mileage, low power, etc, etc.

author: lemko
text: ...silver-gray Dodge Journey - first time I saw one in the "wild."

author: q45az
text: New Dodge Challenger's one Black and one silver... Amazing looking machines

author: andys120
text: It didn't look much larger than the old design but I recognized the new tail, not-bad-looking if you can't see the grille.

author: fintail
text: I've seen a few Challengers in the past couple days. They do have a presence.

author: boomchek
text:
I'm seeing the all over the place. Saw 3 new ones on Sunday.

Also saw an orange Lambo Gallardo with an N sign in the back. In BC, N signs signify New Drivers (both young and old that just got their license).

The driver of the Gallardo looked like an 18 year old (lucky bum!). He pulled off into an expensive nighbourhood.

author: fintail
text:
I've noticed quite a few new style Fits around here too. If I had one I think I would rebadge it as a Jazz.

I bet the Lambo has some "custom bodywork" within 6 months or so :sick:

author: boomchek
text: That would be funny if someone tries to add a body kit to a Lambo.

author: stever
text:
Think new teen driver and tree.

Makes for a different kind of bodywork.

author: fintail
text:
That's exactly what I meant

But I swear I have seen pics of customized Lambos ...so maybe it will have custom bodywork twice.

author: boomchek
text: ahhh i get it now. lol. He wasn't speeing though or driving like a maniac.

author: stever
text: Not yet, LOL.

author: lemko
text: ...red Chrysler Sebring retractable hardtop.

author: ateixeira
text:
And I saw a soft top one this morning.

What bothered me about that car is that the hard top's window is no bigger than the soft top. That's lame. Visibility isn't any better than with the soft top.

Look at the Miata - the hard top is totally different. The rear window is both wider and closer to the driver, so visibility is notably better with the top up. Chrysler should have done the same thing.

I saw a new Fit as well, plus one of those new Jag sedans.

author: fintail
text: Spotted another Genesis in traffic today...same color as the one I saw a few weeks ago so I suppose it could be the same one, but it was about 15 miles away. Strangely enough, the driver looked Korean, too. Also saw a MKS.

author: boomchek
text:
A subaru Impreza STi, pulled up to our showroom.

I like the bulging fenders, quad exhaust, the wheels, and the interior seats. Really nice all around package. Silver color too.

author: guss
text: I saw it from behind and thought it was a new Acura because Acuras have gone weird now. Well, at least the MKS is something different from the usual Lincolns, I can't say I loved it but it was OK at best.

author: kyfdx
text:
These are truly stunning!

However, the LED DRLs have got to go... They are so hokey looking... Plus, whenever they use the turn signal, the one on that side goes out.. :surprise:

author: boomchek
text:
Plus, whenever they use the turn signal, the one on that side goes out..

The Dodge Rams have the same feature. I think so that the turn signal is more visible by oncoming traffic.

author: kyfdx
text:
Yeah... I knew why.. :shades:

Still... tacky..

author: texases
text: I always notice those LEDs on the A-4 replacing the C-class commercial. Not a good look

author: andys120
text:
I'm noticing a lot of new Ford Flexes recently. My wife says it looks like a Mini Cooper on steroids. I guess Ford is keeping those Exploder buyers in the fold, Ive seen a few Taurus Xs lately too.

I got a good look at a Hyundai Azera today and I was pretty impressed by the quality of the (silver) paint as well as the tight shutlines . I wonder why it doesn't sell better as it would seen a good alternative to buyers of Centuries, Sables and the like.

author: ateixeira
text: I parked next to one - at a Chuck E. Cheese!

author: lemko
text: I spotted a tiny white Daihatsu Midget II pickup truck near Five Points by Cottman, Rising Sun, and Oxford in NE Philly at lunchtime today.

author: davethecarnut
text: I saw one from the back and almost thought it was a Maserati Quattroporte. At least by the shape of the taillights.

author: davethecarnut
text:
Starting to see these alot in So. Cal. Saw the SRT, the RT and even the base SE.
Good looking cars. I hope they help Chrysler.

author: boomchek
text: We just got some Challenger R/Ts, one in the Titanium Grey with crhome wheels. Very nice looking.

author: fintail
text: I've seen a ton of new Mazda 6s lately...I suspect some are in a rental fleet.

author: explorerx4
text:
i saw a black challenger parked near the street, which looked ok. then i saw a sliver one with some dark stripes on the hood which looked really good.
i really think that car needs some contrasting stripes on it, no matter what color.

author: lemko
text: ...it was called a GEM which stood for "Global Electric Motors" a Daimler-Chrysler Company.

author: guss
text: My local Dodge dealer was carrying these(until they went out of business). Basically a golf cart on steroids. The top speed is 35mph and can go up to 40 miles on a charge.

author: boomchek
text:
Saw a bunch of Ford Edges, new Aston DBS, some nice Alfas.

I think Ford has a deal with the Bond franchise provide their cars. Casion Royale had the new euro Mondeo in it. This time the Edges get lots of screen play.

author: bumpy
text: with the wannabe-Audi Malibu Stacey front end.

author: davethecarnut
text: Aston used to be a part of Ford

author: boomchek
text:
Aston used to be a part of Ford

I remember when in early 90s I had a buyer's guide and there was a picture of an Aston Martin Virage interior, and the steering wheel was straight out of the Taurus.

author: fintail
text: No way, that has to be photoshopped

author: stever
text:
Here's a '91 - different wheel.

Here's a '92 - different wheel.

Here's a '95 with a suspicious looking wheel. :shades:

author: fintail
text: Ouch! That's just shameful.

author: boomchek
text:
Yes way Fintail.. I think the Astons that were sold in markets that required a driver's side airbag, came with the FoMo corporate wheel. Probably cheaper to install then to reengineer a new one.

If I'd be the owner the first thing I'd do is swap it for a Momo wheel or something.

This is not the first time that an exotic shared parts with a lowline car.

Check this out: Lotus Esprit vs Saturn SC1 coupe.

author: fintail
text:
I can see sharing parts, like Ferraris that have had Fiat switchgear...but the steering wheel! For all that money couldn't something exclusive be designed?

I always thought it was amusing that early MB R129 have the same steering wheel as later W126 cars, but those ones you post are just insane. I honestly had no idea about that Aston or the Lotus.

author: boomchek
text:
Yeah it's funny. Good thing it has sorta went away.

I think the big reason the steering wheels were shared was for the airbags, as initially they were big and bulky, and you wouldn't be able to fit one in a smaller sports type steering wheel.

The Aston/Taurus steering is probably the most extreme and ugliest example of parts sharing.

author: fintail
text:
That Taurus wheel irks me...my mom had a Taurus of the generation that had that wheel, and although it dodged the common maladies (trannies and head gaskets)...it wasn't exactly a leather lined luxo cruiser like the Aston is supposed to be. I can't imagine any of those still wear that wheel...if the owner realizes where it came from, anyway.

Does anything like that exist today at all?

author: boomchek
text: Maybe secretly, the Taurus owners bought these cars to feel like they're in an Aston

author: kyfdx
text: In black... stunning!

author: explorerx4
text:
i just posted over on new car sales, that i saw an S5(black) at the auto show, and that it was my favorite.
i don't think i was influenced by the tv commercial.

author: explorerx4
text: i still see the steering wheel with the rectangular center every time i get in my 1991 mustang!

author: fintail
text: I saw a red Audi R8 today, all body color, no odd trim. The driver looked like Jeremy Clarkson...in another 20 years with maybe 50 more pounds.

author: kyfdx
text:
Not sure what all they hype is about... It looks a little like an RX330... And, the Taurus X and the Pacifica have done the wagon thing, already...

It is fairly attractive for a whatever it is..

author: fintail
text: It's a minivan/SUV hybrid...for those without the self-confidence to drive a minivan, but who fear the social stigma of an SUV. Brilliant target marketing, dumb name, Toyota looks.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new TL today....man, that's a weird looking car, and not in a good way.

author: ateixeira
text: I like it except for the overdone grille, but what I don't get is why is costs a LOT more than the Sienna despite sharing an engine and being smaller.

author: fintail
text: A white R8 just drove by my window...I saw a blue one on Saturday

author: kyfdx
text:
Lotus Elise... in orange.. Guess he was picking up a bolt... or one screw.. :surprise:

Looking down into the car... It looks like the seats ride about 6" off the pavement.. I'm not even sure I could get in and out of it.. (though, I wouldn't mind trying..)

author: imidazol97
text: How does that Lotus handle in snow. We had a coating on Saturday and all the idiot drivers around here were playing bumper pool.

author: kyfdx
text:
Yeah.. I was wondering... I'm sure that it would come with summer tires.. Can't really see someone switching out for winters on a Lotus..

I did find out that the stock tires on my new AWD Subie are really crappy in the snow... which makes no sense at all.

Messing around with my son... driving down the street... almost took out a neighbor's mailbox... :surprise: So much for fun in the snow..

author: imidazol97
text:
>. Can't really see someone switching out for winters on a Lotus..

I asked the local Ford dealer a couple years back about the GT they had in the showroom and if snowtires were available for it. I'd imagine it's like driving a Firebird on snow.

The salesman didn't seem very amused. Maybe that's why they're closed.

author: kyfdx
text:
It seems that 20%-30% of our local Ford dealers are gone, including some bigger ones that I wouldn't have guessed..

I think Ford has been really aggressive about buying back dealerships... that's the one way they can actually get rid of them...

author: andys120
text:
A couple of near exotics:

-Aston-Martin DB9 Cabriolet, seen parked w top up, gorgeous, as are all current A-Ms.

-Nissan GT-R, it looks more exotic shooting thru traffic than when standing next to a parked one.

author: ateixeira
text: I saw an R8 yesterday, while driving home. Amazing presence on the road. Looks much better out in the real world.

author: lemko
text: Spotted both a new orange Mustang GT and a yellow Challenger on the PA Turnpike. Also spotted a Smart car on a secondary road outside of Elkins Park, PA.

author: guss
text: I think the new 370Z is better looking.

author: texases
text: Saw first one, at lunch, silver with dk grey wheels (don't like that color on wheels, looks like they're dirty). Doesn't look like much, but I'd be happy to have one... Coincidence - saw the Top Gear last night where they raced one across Japan against a bullet train, etc. Funny!

author: ateixeira
text: Coupes, two of them yesterday.

author: berri
text: Is it just me, or is the new Challenger too tall and squat? It reminds me more of an old Duster than Barraccuda or Challenger.

author: boomchek
text: I know what you're saying. From some angles it does look tall and narrow.

author: andys120
text: I agree, the noveau Challenger just doesn't have the rounded curves that distinguished the original, It's as if they'd squared it off and besides, it's too big.

author: lemko
text: ...red-orange metallic BMW 1-Series. In this case a 135i.

author: andys120
text: All of my ambivalence about the styling of this car disappeared with the sight of this jet black GT-R. It's amazing what coat of shiny black paint will do for the looks of a car about which you are ambivalent. I've noticed the BMW 1-series coupe which looks a little tallish and/or cutesy in other colors looks sensational in black.

author: andys120
text:
I saw a silver four-door backing out of a space and at first thought it was an E60 BMW 5 Series and I'm thinking "If you don't see the nose, that's a good-looking car".

Then he came around towards me and I could see that it was no Fiver but the new Hyundai Genesis and it was indeed a good-looking car for lacking the visual trauma of the E60's nose but retaing the clean sides and roofline.

Thus it is pretty generic but quite handsome in it's way.

author: texases
text: Driving to work last week, wondered why the traffic's so slow, finally make my way around a bright red Maserati Gran Turismo. Like he was worried about doing 40 mph. :confuse:

author: fintail
text: I saw another new Acura TL today...sorry, that styling can't grow on me. A mess of random angles and edges, the weird grille, the somehow unhappy greenhouse...it's like a Japanese version of Art + Science, but a lot less unified. A shame, as the 04-08 generation was a decent looking car.

author: boomchek
text:
The 04-08 is indeed very nice looking. Even the generation ebfore that I enjoyed.

I agree with you on the new TL. I think there's a lot more "handomse" luxury vehicles out there in this class.

Lexus ES, Infiniti G or even M.

I'd actually even get a Hyundai Azera or Genesis over the new TL.

author: lemko
text: ...black VW Tiguan. Why does VW name its SUVs/Crossovers these WEIRD names? Did the Tiguan replace the Toureg? What the heck is a "Tiguan?" What the heck is a "Toureg?"

author: kyfdx
text:
The Tiguan is smaller than the Touareg (notice all the vowels!).. It is based on the Rabbit/Jetta, and has the 2.0T engine that the upscale VW models all share..

I think all their names come from the African desert (remember Scirocco?).

author: andys120
text:
I think all their names come from the African desert (remember Scirocco?).

Golf, Scirroco and, Jeta, Bora and Passat were all names of winds that originate in North Africa and blow across the Mediterranean into Europe. Maserati also used the same naming convention in the 70s- Ghibli, Khamsin and Bora were all winds from Northern Africa.

The Toureg was named after a tribe of nomads from Morroco and Mauretania. I think they just made Tiguan up.-they could've used Bedouin or Berber.

author: fintail
text: All of those look better than the new TL, for sure. It's just such a disjointed design, harsh for the sake of being harsh.

author: fintail
text:
Lots of new E-class pics have been releases

I don't like it. It's funny how the Asian makers for so long have copied German styling, and now the Germans copy Asian copies of German styling. What a horrible cycle! Look at those Hyundai taillights...inexcusable. Maybe proof that Europe is going downhill...

author: boomchek
text:
I can't believe the E class is already due for a redesign. Has it been that long? Time flies.....

As for the styling I was going to say the same thing. The tail lights look like they came off a Genesis.

I don't mind the looks, but I agree with you. Mercedes looks like it ran out of styling ideas about 10 years ago. The C Class looks nice, the S Class is new but nothing that blows other luxury sedan away in the styling dept, and this E Class is ok I guess.

I do like it in the chocolate brown color, I think it look very elegant.

author: fintail
text:
W211 was introduced for the 2003 model year, was in Europe by spring of 02. It's getting pretty old.

I don't mind the C, and parts of the S, but this E with its wannabe Asian styling doesn't warm my heart. Jeez I miss the days of cars like the W124, such competent solid designs, not needing gimmicks and derivative cliches.

Not many cars can pull off brown.

author: boomchek
text:
I agree with you on the W124. I think my fav is the W140. I know most people though it was bloated and heavy looking, but it had presence, even the big coupe.

The W126 would be my second place choice as one of the modern Benzes that had presence.

author: fintail
text:
I used to like the W140, then I didn't, now I am appreciating it a little...maybe as it is heading for 20 years old now. The coupes always had a strange interest for me, such a big bulky thing, very odd, but it pulled it off, maybe not as well as the 126 coupe. Bruno Sacco owns a beautiful blue C140.

I see the W126 as pretty much a perfect design, I can't imagine MB or anyone else repeating something so balanced and timeless. Modern cars don't seem to bother with simple elegance.

author: lemko
text:
Sheesh! Until I saw the three-pointed star, I thought I was looking at a concept car for the Lexus GS! What's with those goofy taillights? They DO look more Korean than German.

Someboduy visiting a next door neighbor pulled up in a black W126 S-Class. That is still a sharp-looking car to this day!

author: fintail
text: The W126 was good enough to be copied by Toyolex when it was 10 years old...

author: boomchek
text: I like the first and mildly redesigned second gen Lexus LS too. Very hansome lines imo.

author: fintail
text:
Yeah, I don't mind those either, they were derivative of something good. Lots of them still out there too, so they have proven themselves.

The 01-06 (I think) design has to be a derivative of the W140, too. It wasn't quite as decent looking, a big isolation tank.

The current pretentious model does nothing for me, although I should give credit that it is finally its own design.

author: guss
text:
What the heck is a "Tiquan?"

I read that it was a combination of tiger and iguana. It is supposed to represent the traits of both animals. Go figure.

author: boomchek
text: Bentley Azure (convertible) driving in the evening. Huge car, and has ton of presence. Very nice.

author: kyfdx
text:
.. first time I've seen one, "in the wild"..

Take away the star, and it looks like a Mercedes from the front... Still not seeing $30K-$40K+ for one, though...

author: fintail
text:
Not completely new, but I got behind this commuter car on my drive home from work today, and just had to snap a few pics

A good around-town runabout

Snappy acceleration for highway merging

Great for cruising suburban roads

author: texases
text: Coincidence - saw a new TL (black) parked next to a new Genesis ('sapphire blue pearl' they call it, dark). There was not a line on the TL that looked good. Odd front (especially in black, I imagine silver would conceal the grille surround), odd front fender bump, odd rear side window, heavy looking rear trunk, narrow/slanted rear window. The Genesis looked fine, nothing that offended, clean lines. If I had to choose between those two it'd be the Genesis. I'll be going to the Dallas car show in two weeks, I'll compare the Genesis to the CTS.

author: fintail
text:
The Genesis looks fine as it is 100% derivative of existing German designs :shades:

The TL really is a train wreck.

Local MB dealer has half a dozen GLKs sitting on the lot now. Not worthy of me snapping a pic...the world doesn't need more dopey little SUVs.

author: guss
text:
4 door hatchback. Did these just come out for '09 or have they been around awhile and I did not notice them ?

Anyway, they look much more useful than the sedan. Kind of a cross between a Fit and a Aveo.

author: bumpy
text: Yep, the 5-door is new. The Fit, Rio, and Aveo all come in that configuration, and the xD is really too big to be a suitable substitute.

author: kyfdx
text:
Canada has had the 5-door for a couple of years... You can see a blue one that the main characters drive on the USA Network show, "Psych".

I agree.. the best configuration..

author: lemko
text: ...cream-colored Ford Escape on my way back from lunch.

author: ateixeira
text:
I swear every single Chrysler Sebring sedan on the road was in Florida. That seemed to be every rental I saw.

That and the Grand Caravan.

I've never seen so many.

author: fintail
text: Saw my first Venza today...meh...another tall station wagon for those who can't handle driving a station wagon.

author: lemko
text: ...dark blue Maserati Quattroporte at Rhawn and Bustleton in NE Philly.

author: texases
text: At least the Venza's styling is an improvement over Toyota's previous station wagons. They seemed to have a knack for some odd styling on the Camrys. Corollas were OK.

author: kyfdx
text:
At the car wash... Man, is that thing big!

Little old lady driving it... I noticed as she pulled the door closed, that it has power door closers to snug it up tight.. no slamming needed.. :surprise:

author: ateixeira
text:
I've seen one in person. They look pretty good, and I agree that the old Camry wagon was hideous.

The grille is a bit overdone.

It might make sense to someone shopping for a Lexus RX that wants to spend a bit less.

author: fintail
text:
I was thinking the same, it has a strong resemblance to a RX but probably costs 40% less. It'll probably sell quite a few on that alone.

I'll take a weirdo Toyota over a boring one. Bizarro dual rear wiper Camry wagons and strange boxy 4WD Corollas are almost exotics in a world of pigsnout Camrys and Matrix (or Matrices?)

author: ateixeira
text:
Yup. Dealers near me have well equipped models from $31k or so and up.

To me, though, the Sienna is a much better value, and about $8 grand less for a Sienna LE.

author: fintail
text: I you're actually hauling people and not in it for image, I agree.

author: anythngbutgm
text: is Toyotas answer to the Nissan Murano and Ford Edge. I think it looks better than both of them. It could in some ways be a competitor to the Outback or Volvo XC70 as well, but I'm not sure how many of those buyers will be takers to the Venza

author: ateixeira
text:
The overseas model is the Mark X Zio, and offers a 3rd row.

I guess they figured they have that segment served here by the Sienna and Highlander.

The Zio looks far more conservative IMHO:

author: fintail
text: Nicer grille anyway

author: ateixeira
text: Those headlights could have come from any of a dozen other cars, though. Very generic.

author: fintail
text:
Very Toyota :shades:

The busy US Venza grille isn't cool in a weird way, it's just busy.

Toyota tried to be cool once, RWD cars and all.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Yeah, I'm not really a fan of that one. Too Generic.

There are a few neat styling touches on the Venza that I think sets it apart from the Nissan or the Ford. Most notably the rear with the Volvo-esque tailight treatment and the contouring on the hatch. And the Grill, while a bit overdone I think it works with the overall design and is inlike anything else out there. I might even go so far as to call the Venza styling "Bold" or even "Daring" (Ducks behind computer screen) I also like the cockpit dash layout and the interior has a really rich look to it in higher trim levels. I think it's classier than the new Highlander even.

I mean, the Venza isn't rolling excitment, but it has a bit more style than more recent models. I'd like to think that this is at least a sign that Toyota is going to add a bit more styling to the budget on future models.

author: ateixeira
text: I know what you mean. Even though I don't like the grille, I do prefer the Venza over the Zio, and that's probably because of the risks they took.

author: lemko
text: ...black VW CC sedan going north on Oxford Avenue near Magee in NE Philly.

author: fintail
text:
I visited a few dealers today with a friend. He wanted to see the CC. He was impressed with it, but mentioned he'd never pay 36K for a 4cyl car. That one was loaded save for the engine, and the dealer still had the nerve to put a $999 ADM on it in this economy. Idiots. They also had a barebones version. It's a pretty elegant car all in all, and an interior that's exceptional looking even for VW.

Stopped by the BMW dealer, they had a smattering of lowline 1 series coupes, kind of odd to see them not loaded up. Audi dealer had a loaded RS4 with some kind of titanium trim package that looked pretty mean. They also had a CPO 07 S6 and S8 side by side...those can't be common.

Another dealer carries some odd makes, had a trio of Spykers in the showroom, including a convertible - never seen one of those before.

author: boomchek
text:
The Passat CC is a nice looking car, but for the money I think there are other nice alternatives.

Yesterday I saw a new Jag XF black on black, looked really stunning. Driven by a upper class looking older lady leav9ing the liquor store parking lot. As we were leaving the store, the bums in front of the store were admiring it too out loud.

It's one of the nicest sedans out there right now imo.

author: fintail
text: Saw my first new style Z car today

author: guss
text: I saw my first Jaguar XF yesterday , it was coming from the other direction in traffic. I had no idea it was a Jag until I got right next to it.

author: andys120
text:
I had no idea it was a Jag until I got right next to it.

Therein lies the problem IMO, they tried too hard to make the S and X-Types look like MkIIs and ended up with dated looking cars out of the box. Methinks they tried too hard to come up with a contemporary look for the XF and ended up squeezing the "jaguaricity" out of the XF.

OTOH, if they'd reshape those headlights they might have something.

author: qbrozen
text:
Saw my first MKS today.

positive: its unique and stands out

negative: its very tall (was behind it as we drove past many other cars, and it seemed to fall just between a minivan and 300C). And what the heck is up with the upturned rearend? I could see everything up to and including the rear suspension. Very unattractive from that angle and once the exhaust pipes start to gather rust, it will look HORRIBLE.

author: andys120
text:
I saw a new silver A5 coupe today. It was great looking even in a bland color like silver, makes the competition at Mercedes and BMW (CLK & 6 Series) look like last decade's cars.

It's the first one I've seen outside of an Auto Show or showroom.

author: lemko
text: ...white Mercedes CL550 on Oxford and Cottman in NE Philly.

author: ateixeira
text: Looks decent, though I'm not convinced it should cost more than a Passat. For the price it seemed a bit ordinary.

author: qbrozen
text: Actually, according to the quick take I just read in ... I think C&D ... the 2.0T CC is actually a few hundred bucks cheaper than a comparably equipped normal passat.

author: ateixeira
text:
Really?

I guess I didn't realize the Passat had crept up in price so much.

Of course I test drove a Passat 1.8T in 1998, so it's been a while!

author: fintail
text:
The loaded 4cyl CC I looked at was 35K. A pretty car with an excellent looking interior...but that's a pretty penny.

On the new car front I saw another new TL yesterday. That design is just a mess. The TSX can almost carry it, but the TL is a nightmare compared to the nice looking previous model.

author: texases
text:
"On the new car front I saw another new TL yesterday. That design is just a mess. The TSX can almost carry it, but the TL is a nightmare compared to the nice looking previous model. "

Same reaction to the TL at the Dallas car show. One other bad trend-instead of shiney chrome-plated plastic grilles, lots of makers are now going to matte-finished chrome work. Didn't look good to me. :lemon:

author: fintail
text:
I have noticed the TL kind of carries the hokey shield design at front and back, while the sides are forgettable blandness. Did Honda hire the Aztek design crew?

The matte finish chrome, which usually looks like plain old silver paint, doesn't give an air of quality.

author: texases
text: I'm going to give Acura the benefit of the (great) doubt - lots of cars are now showing up with tall grilles and hoods, thanks to the EU. I wonder if the Acura "shield" is part of meeting those pedestrian crash requirements? Like the 'nose' on many recent Toyotas? (equally ugly, to me)

author: fintail
text: I think the TL might be a NA-market-only product, or maybe NA and Japan...I don't know of they are sold in Europe. I know the RL exists there, but it isn't offensive. I believe they are just trying to develop a corporate styling theme, like the Europeans have done for generations...although I am sure the ugly high front does help in dubious pedestrian regulations.

author: boomchek
text:
I haven't seen too many of the new TLs, at least not up close to be able to have a good look.

I'll reserve my judgement to when I go to our Auto Show. The trunk lid crease though reminds me of the old CL coupe.

author: fintail
text:
My eyes! Ouch!

That rear shield...I just can't like it. What's the point of that?

Oh yeah, the auto show is coming in a few weeks...I'll be coming to Van for that too

author: lemko
text: I can almost see the "Decepticons" logo painted on that shield-like surface. The TL's "beak" has the purpose of opening very large old-school beer cans.

author: kyfdx
text: I'd like to have one of those beers...

author: fintail
text:
My theory behind it all is that BMW has seen massive success with questionable designs that are pretty much different for the sake of being different. Acura wants to see if this can help them now.

These just aren't cohesive designs.

author: boomchek
text:
Also I don't know if I read it here, but I heard the trunk access into ther TL is inconvenient due to the shape of the trunk lid.

Let me know which day you'll be down here fintail, maybe I'll run into you at the show.

author: fintail
text: I'll be there for several days, an acquaintance of mine has a vacant condo near there they rent out now and then, so I have it for about a week, a nice mini-holiday. Are you working the show, or does your dealership do that?

author: boomchek
text: Our dealership had a day allocated at the show last year and I worked it. However this year the show has been cut to only 5 days I think, so not sure if we get a day. I usually end up going 2-3 times every year anyways, so there's a good chance we can meet there.

author: fintail
text:
Do you actually sell anything via the show?

I noticed on the website it's shorter this year. Somehow I prefer it to the Seattle show...easier access to the highline cars, and the venue is more fun. I have that entire week free, so something will work.

author: imidazol97
text:
>Did Honda hire the Aztek design crew?

That was my thought when I saw one.

author: boomchek
text:
By law we're not supposed to doi any transactions at the show, so no, we can't sell.

Last year a customer wanted to buy a Cahllenger, so we whisked him back to our dealership where he laid a fat deposit on one.

author: stever
text: You mean the dealer is afraid that the buyer could try the three day cooling off period rule and try to back out of the sale if a car was sold at the show? I don't think that's an issue from some links I found a year or so ago. link

author: kyfdx
text:
In Ohio, dealers aren't permitted to sell off-site.. (including the car show) I always assumed that it had something to do with the three day, right of recission laws..

However, in KY, the local dealer association will have a big "tent sale", anywhere there is a huge parking lot (university, race track), and all of the dealers will trundle their stock over there, and can sell freely.

Just two examples..

author: fintail
text:
Probably a tough venue to get a sale anyway...so many lookie-loos. Of course, if one is spending $10 to look at cars, a few might be serious.

Maybe I will ask the MB guys weird technical questions about the cars and receive puzzled looks in return....that's always fun. Either that or asking when each model will finally come here in diesel form.

author: boomchek
text:
No it's not that. We don't have a cooling off period in British Columbia. We (dealers) are governed by a motor dealer council that isseus licenses to premises and salespeople selling cars. A dealer that wants to sell off site, like at an auto show, needs to apply for a seperate license which in most cases is not worth the money time and hassle just for a 5 day show.

Hence there is no selling at the auto show.

It's easier to bring the customer from the show to our dealership. Or to take their name and number. Besides the vehicles at the show are usually not dealer owned, but manufacturer owned and travel across counrty during the show season, so we cna't even sell those if we wanted to.

author: stever
text:
Ok, but why are you there if you aren't "selling"?

Seriously, are you paid to attend and do you hang out at the cars your dealer sells to answer questions and chat folks up? (I don't want to know if you have to wear an evening gown and heels :P ).

author: berri
text: New TL looks like it has a shovel up its [non-permissible content removed].

author: boomchek
text: We're there to gather potential leads, and to answer questions. We dont' get paid but attendance is on a voluntarily basis. Usually we do end up winning stuff from the manufacturer for being there.

author: stever
text: mmm, swag. Thanks!

author: guss
text:
New TL looks like it has a shovel up its [non-permissible content removed].

The next TL I see I will be trying hard to get that image out of my head. Five or 5 years ago Acura had the most clean designs around . Did their lead designer leave ?

author: ateixeira
text:
I think it peaked at least one generation ago.

I can see why they want a family resemblance, but I don't like chrome and they seem to have a lot of it, and the fake stuff at that.

author: boomchek
text:
chrome and they seem to have a lot of it, and the fake stuff at that.

I can imagine, you tap it and it gives off a plasticky vibration and feel.

author: ateixeira
text:
Thing is - I like the overall shape.

I know the RL wasn't selling well, but it looked better before this latest face-lift.

author: boomchek
text: I liked the line of the RL before the facelift too. Really well balanced, well proportioned. I imagine it must be a great used car bargain, just like previous RLs were.

author: lemko
text: ...of the Acura RL, but the exterior is hideous! I guess it's a great car if you don't step outside it and look at it.

author: ateixeira
text: Nah, it may be slightly bland, but it's pretty unoffensive.

author: fintail
text: That's the TL

author: andys120
text: four door sedan, looks like a cross between a Sentra and a Versa, sized right between them. Sonora license plate, dealer tag from Nogales, Son.

author: kyfdx
text:
In a "panel van" configuration... No back doors... Used as a small delivery/repair vehicle, I'm guessing.... In white...

Didn't even know they came this way..

author: bumpy
text: Tiida IS the Versa.

author: bumpy
text: Yep, GM kicked that one out a year or so ago. Local Chevy dealer has had a white one on the lot for a few months now.

author: guss
text: A painter near my work has an HHR configured that way with a roof rack. It actually looks pretty practical.

author: kyfdx
text:
I agree.... my only issue would be that it's front-wheel drive... You couldn't really load it up, like a van...

Great for light stuff, though...

author: texases
text: Kinda like this?

author: kyfdx
text:
Yeah..... only about 1% of the cool factor, though..

Actually, it looked 3 times better than a regular HHR...

author: imidazol97
text: I kind of like the HHR. If it only had bench or split seats...

author: stever
text:
I agree.... my only issue would be that it's front-wheel drive... You couldn't really load it up, like a van...

What kind of load are we talking about for a FWD van anyway?

a modest load

~550 sq ft of flooring

Anyone see a Kia Soul in the wild yet?

author: ateixeira
text:
Now that's a big load!

No Soul yet.

author: kyfdx
text: Neil Young says that, "even Richard Nixon has got SOUL.."

author: fintail
text: I saw a new TL today...black. The matte finish chrome on the car doesn't look awesome against black paint.

author: boomchek
text:
Kia Soul at a dealer's lot.

New TL in the parking lot. Still looks kinda weird.

More Ford Flexes. I don't care for them that much.

author: stever
text: Edmunds' View Inventory feature says there are 4 Souls in Boise. I'm too lazy to drive out to the dealer to take a gander.

author: guss
text:
I like the soul from the pictures I have seen. They pull off the box theme better than the xB and Cube.

I saw an Audi R8 on a congested road, much more angular than I thought it would be. I was afraid for the guy,way too much too lose in that kind of traffic.

author: ateixeira
text:
Brand new...in my driveway. :shades:

Stormy Blue Mica, hard top, Touring with the suspension package.

Basically the sportiest Miata you can get - 6 speed manual, Bilstein shocks, uprated springs, fatter roll bar (PRHT's front anti-roll bar is bigger than the soft top's), Torsen limited-slip rear differential, summer tires on upsized 17" rims.

It's swee-eeeeet. :shades:

author: anythngbutgm
text:
One of the guys here at work brought in a TL loaner while his 2001 MDX gets its 180k mile routine maintainence. It's a base model, no Type S but he likes it and was thinking about buying one anyways so call it an "extended test drive".

I took a look at it during lunch and the exterior is too extreme to go with the base wheels and tires. I think the Type S trim works better here. The interior is fantastic though, and a definite upgrade over the outgoing model. The seats, the ergonomics, the drivers view is excellent. The only thing I don't like about it is the rear view is tricky with the raised boattail, and the long nose which is tough to judge. I'm not toally enamoured with it, but I don't find it offensive. Once the Type-S AWD, 6-spd comes out, I'll definitely take a more serious look at it.

Also, the Venza seems to be selling very well around here, and based on this link, it satnds as the #3 "mover".

link title

It's a good sign that so many higher priced vehicles are popular, maybe it's a good sign for the economy.

author: berri
text: Isn't it ironic that the Venza seems like it will be a hit while the Chrysler Pacifica and Taurus X were essentially marketplace failures? I wonder how Honda's entry next year will fare?

author: andys120
text: Congratulations Juice, there's nothing like a real sportscar.

author: ateixeira
text: Thanks. :shades:

author: qbrozen
text:
congrats! enjoy.

Funny, I just spotted one for the first time here at work this morning in the parking lot. Red. The retractable hardtop gives it an interesting/distinctive look.

author: boomchek
text:
a new Ferrari 612 Scaglietti, in red, with tan leather, and a baby seat in the back seat. Parked at a restaurant we finished eating at.

Lucky baby!

author: micro_chip_man
text: I was on my way to Washington State yesterday and spotted the New Audi Q5. Those little cars are sweet. The European's sure have a way with style...

author: lemko
text: ...yellow Lotus Elise.

author: lemko
text:
The Associated Press

ELGIN, Ill. - He freely admitted that his dream car is a red Nissan Altima with a push-button ignition. A 21-year-old man was charged Monday with burglary and attempted theft for allegedly trying to steal one from a Nissan auto dealership. Police said the man saw the car on the showroom floor around midnight on Sunday.

Police said he broke in and started the car, but couldn't find a way to get it out of the building. Police said he then broke a showroom window, but was unable to maneuver the auto out the building.

He was discovered a short time later by police, who arrested him

author: fintail
text: Amusing news "story" yesterday...an anchorwoman was going on about some "news" of smaller SUVs (probably a ploy to try to induce some car sales, we all know what the media revolves around), and the Nissan "Rouge" was mentioned...when she got to the VW Tiguan, she couldn't even say it, she had to spell it. I had a nice laugh.

author: lemko
text: ...beautiful red Corvette Z06.

author: boomchek
text: Sometimes it's funny when journalists pretend like they know what they're talking about but they really don't. Once our local paper did a story on modified cars but the terminology used by the reported didn't make sense. The reporter was talking about people putting in turbo suspensions, and short shifters that give cars more power :confuse: It was funny to read.

author: ateixeira
text:
Funny.

Speaking of which, I saw a Tiguan at White Flint Mall on Saturday.

Those things look sooooo small. Our Forester dwarfs it.

author: fintail
text: Maybe they talked to the owner of a souped up 99 Civic coupe or something. You know a short shift kit and an oversized sheet metal spoiler are both good for at least 20hp apiece, right? :shades:

author: fintail
text:
The new Forester is a pretty decent sized vehicle...I see them and I think it might be a new style Tribeca or something.

I saw a GLK yesterday. The baby SUV fad is booming. Beats roadways full of Excursions and Yukon XLs anyway.

author: fezo
text: Oh, you dog! Way cool. You're hitting my car lust button!

author: fintail
text: Saw the new Volvo small crossover/jacked up small wagon/whatever one wants to call it.

author: stever
text: Never seen a Ferrari logo on a Tiburon before. :shades:

author: ateixeira
text:
I saw a GLK also, driving on Rt. 28 in MD, right next to me.

It's not often I say this but there's a vehicle that actually looks worse in person.

Very odd proportions. It has a big greenhouse yet it's stubby, sort of like a short guy with a big head.

I have yet to see the new Volvo but I actually look forward to it, as those are attractive.

author: fintail
text: I saw a GTR driving on a Vancouver street today. The driver was a guy who looked to be about 80 years old. I hope I am like that if I make it to 80...

author: lemko
text: Actually, that was Benjamin Button and he was only 18 years old.

author: fintail
text:
The short guy/big head thing is true. To me the GLK looks like a toy car...there's something kind of Tonka-ish about it to me.

I've seen the volvo a couple times...inoffensive.

author: fintail
text: Ah that might be it!

author: boomchek
text:
Thanks for meeting me there Fintail. We had a good chat about cars in general as we strolled through the show. Here's some observations:
