text: My friend's has the Hemi V8. And it actually impressed my wife quite a bit and his wife loves it too.

author: fintail
text: I wonder if any will be built that way. Base engine with top spec. Even the middling spec one I drove had the V8.

author: ateixeira
text: Very likely Dodges makes 'em all V8s. Standard V6 allows them to advertise a lower (bogus) base price.

author: boomchek
text:
You'll get the one-off with a base engine that someone custom ordered that will be unsellable.

We ran across top spec base engine models before when I worked at Chrysler and nobody wanted them. Especially when it comes to a big SUV.

author: fintail
text:
That sounds right - Mr Loaded will be the one to want everything, and if he is a used buyer, an engine with 25% less cylinders won't make him smile, so it will be a dust collector on the lot.

I wonder if offering a smaller engine in every trim line helps mpg claims too.

Today's newbie sighting - new nose Tiguan.

author: iwant12
text: I've got the Pentastar in my Grand Cherokee and acceleration is just a tad bit more than what I would call adequate. I know the Durango weighs a bit more. At the pump, I get a consistant 21 mpgs, and that's 70% highway. Going to Utah this last summer, we recorded 24 MPG on more than one fillup. Comfort and driveability more than make up for lack of power compared to the 4Runner I had before. Hadn't purchased a domestic since '98. So far, happy with the Jeep!

author: anythngbutgm
text:
But the glass company next door has replaced their fleet of Econoline and Chevy workvans (whatever they are called) with a fleet of those new Nissan workvans (6 of them).

Also got two co-workers who picked up new Camrys this week, one XLS and another an SE. One trade was a Buick Lacrosse and the other an older Ford 500.

author: ateixeira
text: In the garage at work. What's with the blue transluscent grille?

author: stever
text: Do those Nissan vans look a lot bigger in real life than the Transit Connect? From the pics I've seen, they look like they may be as big as Sprinters.

author: fintail
text: They are closer to a Sprinter than a Transit, for sure. Local dealer always has about 10 laying around.

author: boomchek
text: The Nissan vans are full sizers, whereas the Transit Connect is like a mid size car with a van box mounted behind the b pillar. I like the Transit Connect euro design though. It works well for small businesses as not everyone needs a full size van that's a pig on gas.

author: stever
text: We need more smaller boxes around here. But I want a Transit Connect with a 5 speed. :shades:

author: lemko
text: ...white Fiat 500C with a maroon top on Hartel and Rising Sun Avenue in NE Philly.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
As others have noted, they are definitely larger than the Transit. They might even be a smidge larger than their domestic (Mexican?) Replacements.

They're certainly not pretty by any means, they are definitely function over form, right down to the squared off haunches instead of the rounded over ones on the others.

author: stever
text: That's more Ford Flexy - the pics I had seen had the tall roof added on. Probably a better highway runner than the Transit Connect.

author: fintail
text: I saw, of all crazy things, a Fisker Karma in traffic today. It's different.

author: boomchek
text: Wow, already in Seattle? There can't be too many of them around yet.

author: fintail
text:
Driving in Bellevue just a few blocks from where I lived. I even exclaimed the name of the car as it drove by (turning left in front of me as I was at a light) - even though I was alone in the car.

There's also a Tesla dealer in the mall not far from here.

author: fintail
text:
Went out and browsed at a couple lots today, killing time on a nice warm day. Saw a couple Scion iQ - these look much better proportioned than a Smart, but still kind of dopey. One had no price, the other was decked out with bric-a-brac and had an MSRP of about 20K. Seems a little dear. Toyota dealer already had a CPO 12 Camry too.

Also saw a couple Evoque, 4 door models - somehow I don't mind these as they are so rakish (yet insanely impractical), both were loaded up and had MSRP around 55K. No thanks - metal look grille is even plastic. Nothing remarkable at MB, BMW, Lexus, VW, Subaru dealers.

author: ateixeira
text:
still kind of dopey

I pity the person in charge of designing such small cars. Tough work.

CPO 12 Camry

Press fleet? Stay away from those given the abuse they take.

author: ateixeira
text:
C coupe this AM, about the 3rd one I've seen.

Also an appliance-white Prius V.

author: fintail
text:
Luckily for them, those who want tiny cars will think they are cute. 20K though, tough pill to swallow.

This Camry was loaded, had 3K miles on it - they still wanted ~30K for it. Maybe a demo or something.

This morning saw a C coupe as well, a base model Camry, and a dirty black Evoque.

author: ateixeira
text:
20k is insane money for that. Even with an Aston Martin logo.

They priced it higher than the Yaris, but I guess marketing thinks they can still sell them. ForTwo set the bar real low.

Evoque is winning awards left and right, but that's a head-scratcher to me. $44k for a boutique soft roader with a Focus engine?

Then again, it will sell well, just watch.

author: fintail
text:
If the Cygnet was 20K, they'd sell every one and then some. We've devolved even further to a thoughtless status addicted society, and Aston is a darling of ostentatious new money.

44K is also a base Evoque - from what I have seen, good luck finding one. Average MSRP at the local dealer was closer to 55K.

Of course it will sell well - something sportier for the RX crowd who wants to be different.

author: ateixeira
text:
My friend has a Range Rover Sport and they wanted $3 grand for tires and brakes, at just 22k miles. :sick:

I don't think the Evoque's success will be sustainable. First time they realize they have to spend that kind of money to put new tires on those Dubs they'll bail like there's a fire drill at the Land Rover dealer. Resale will drop, and we'll see a death spiral in 2-3 years.

author: fintail
text:
I hope your friend regrets their choice :shades: ...just had to pose, didn't they.

Evoque could end up being little more than a new century Freelander. Resale on Rovers is like day old bread to begin with.

author: stever
text: No Rover could be as bad as a Freelander.

author: boomchek
text:
I think it will be succesful. I don't think it's meant to be an entry level Range Rover but rather a premium small soft roader for those who want the newest with most gadgets, but without the size. At least I think it will be a hit here in the Vancouver area.

Now don't get me wrong, I don't work for Land Rover so I could care less whether it will do well or not, but from working in the ultra luxury car market for the past 6 months I see what clients spend their money on, and many who are very well off will not hesitate blowing this kind of coin on this kind of car. And because of who is buying these cars, I don't see maintenance being an issue either.

author: fintail
text:
The Vancouver market is kind of something in itself, with all of the new resident kinda sketchy new rich.

I do think it will sell to the wifey RX/ML etc kind of market.

author: boomchek
text:
Haha, no doubt.

When working at my previou dealership, we had a client who bought a used Freelander that had nothing but issues. After we sunk money into it to fix some of the things, he still had issues with it.

He came by about 6 months later to get it appraised to get into something else. I took the vehicle for a quick appraisal drive and came back telling him what it was worth. He flipped and stormed out. He got into his Freelander and couldn't start it even though I just drove it 10 minutes earlier. He stormed back in asking me what I did to his Freelander and why it wasn't starting. Last thing I needed was in irate customer stuck here with a car that he thought I broke. Luckily one of the techs played with the ignition for about 10 minutes and got it running again. :lemon:

author: boomchek
text: That's exactly who I think will be buying these, wifey kinda car. Add to that the fact that Victoria Beckham had a hand in marketing it (they say she helped "design" it, but that's up for interpretation) and you will see many housewives driving these in ritzy neighbourhoods.

author: kyfdx
text:
I think they'll have a hard time moving it... Freelanders sold, because they threw cash at them and got the transaction price down between $26K-$32K (admittedly, this was a few years ago...)

LR2s never sold... even in the mid-high '30s, no one was picking them over X3s....

You can get a pretty well-equipped X3 2.8 for around $45K... a loaded X3 turbo with 300 HP or a maxed out Q5 for $50K... Most Range Rover buyers don't like going down-market for a cheaper model.... and, they've given up completely on the Land Rover crowd...

I predict they will be as common as an Isuzu Axiom or VehiCross... :surprise:

author: ateixeira
text:
To defend my buddy - at least he really uses the 4WD on sand. He's got an annual pass to the Deleware shore, and actually does get out there regularly.

So not a poseur. I think Land Rover chased him there to get photos for the brochure, though, since he's the only one who uses it as intended!

author: fintail
text:
Drives a British car on a saltwater beach? More money than sense, then :shades:

I don't know if any real die hard off roader drives a RR Sport - it's kind of a realtor/lawyer/trust funder/kept housewife car, in my eyes. Once they get past the well heeled original owner that boomchek mentions, they also depreciate swiftly (I can get a first year supercharged Sport for under 30K), suggesting they are not easy to maintain.

author: ateixeira
text: I'm sure it will last one day beyond the rust perforation warranty.

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw my first don't-say-New Beetle, all black, yesterday.

I dunno. If it doesn't appeal to girly girls, who's gonna buy it?

Also saw another Veloster, and a silver Camry LE.

author: texases
text: Same here, first 2012 Beetle yesterday. Articles talk about how it's so different, but I don't see it. Mild styling refresh to me.

author: stever
text: Too bad, thought the pictures looked good.

author: texases
text: Oh, nothing 'bad' about, but I just didn't get the 'now guys will like it' comments from some of the articles. :confuse:

author: stever
text: Maybe if they stuck a Hemi in it....

author: ateixeira
text:
They made Beetles in Brazil until... 1986? IIRC.

Down there the Baja Bug was popular. Basically big tires and fender flares, raised clearance.

Couldn't do that today on a FWD platform, though. They could fake it, I suppose.

author: ateixeira
text: On the DC Beltway this morning.

author: fintail
text: Saw a Prius V today, going about 10 under with maybe 6 cars behind it.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Spotted (2) Prius V's and a slew of new Camrys (exterior styling is not wearing well IMO, compared to the outgoing one).

Also spotted a pair of new CR'V's, one red and one in a carbon gray. This one I think looks better than the outgoing one.

Lastly, a new Impreza hatch in Boston. Sport model.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new-new Beetle today. The lavender color pretty much destroyed VWs stupid aims of pretending the car is somehow more masculine. And I noticed it has a face that reminds me of a dumb dog. Should continue to sell to the same demographic anyway.

author: boomchek
text: I like the new Beetle done in the retro look in black with black looking steelies and metal dog dish hub caps. Less girly than the previous one imo.

author: fintail
text: Actually, I like those wheels and hubcaps too, odd retro touch for that car. Seemed familiar to me somehow, then I realized what it reminded me of - current Matchbox cars:

author: robr2
text:
Saw a new-new Beetle today. The lavender color pretty much destroyed VWs stupid aims of pretending the car is somehow more masculine.

Lavender color? No lavender on the configurator.

author: lemko
text: a white ...uh..."hatchback-fastback" BMW 535i in the parking lot at work.

author: fintail
text: Hmm. Closest thing I see there is the "denim blue", but hard to match a configurator to real life. Either way, not a good color, but for the demographic, it will work fine.

author: fintail
text: "Hunchback" works well for that, while the rest of the world continues to get the much more stylish wagon.

author: ateixeira
text:
Impreza sales are off to a very strong start, up 87% last month. I think the snow belt crowd had been waiting for a fuel sipper.

I saw my first CR-V in the flesh also. A bit extroverted for Honda.

author: ateixeira
text:
Don't hold back, tell us how you really feel.

Saw a black one, maybe Black Betty again?

author: tifighter
text: The Impreza will carry Subaru this year, like the Outback did in 10 and the Forester in 09. Question is, will people get anywhere near those EPA ratings or not?

author: ateixeira
text:
They are in the 2012 Impreza thread, actually. Low 30s is common.

The CVT uses very tall gearing cruising on the highway.

It worked on the Outback, too.

author: ateixeira
text: Looks better in black.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
This time a sedan, in red. This new design seems much more cheery to me, I don't know how to explain it. Maybe it's the new satin grill.

I'm looking forward to checking out the XV. :shades:

author: fintail
text: Black Impreza, they are hitting the roads now.

author: ateixeira
text:
They need to start building those (or Foresters, or both) in Indiana.

Kick Toyota out of SIA, and run the 2nd assembly line there.

author: fintail
text: Someone in my building just bought a new 370Z, bright blue. Brand new, temporary permit issued today. It parks 3 spaces from me, I could even smell the newness form there.

author: fintail
text: New CRV this morning, out in the mildly snowy weather.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Spotted (2) new CR-V's, one black and one silver. Went by the Honda dealer nearby to see them for myself and the place was certainly hopping as well. Didn't bother trying to find a sales rep (they were all busy) since I knew I wasn't going to buy and I had better things to do than spend 3 hours going thru the runaround.

Also spotted a new Camry at the Honda dealer. A V6 Sport model with 8500 miles on it. They wanted $24,500 which was tempting.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
And a not so new spotting but my friends 2004 BMW 330XI overheated and burst into flames on Friday night.

Total loss... Shame it was a fantastic car, pretty much drove like brand new, even with 304,000 miles on the clock

author: ateixeira
text:
In between the hundreds of Subarus and Audis in the employee parking lot I spotted one brand new C250 coupe.

PS Skiing > snow boarding, but the kids feel the opposite way

author: robr2
text:
PS Skiing > snow boarding, but the kids feel the opposite way

I agree with your kids. Riding is soooo fun.

author: ateixeira
text:
I may be the old dog who can't learn new tricks, but I can skate board, water ski, slalom water ski, stunt ski, ski jump, ice skate, and snow ski ... and I could not pick up snow boarding. :sick:

Kids whined about the ski boots even though they fell down a lot less on skis.

author: robr2
text:
I started boarding at 42. Best tip I learned was to look and point where you want to go. Your body will naturally turn in that direction.

Keep your knees bent and always lean downhill. And never ever look down. I always fall when I focus on where I am as opposed to where I want to be.

author: ateixeira
text:
I'll tell the kids.

Falling on my tail bone hard once was enough for me. :sick:

OTOH, I had not gone skiing in a while and picked it right back up. Had a ball, actually. :shades:

author: stever
text: I switched from skiing to snowboarding when I was ~48. Still hoping to go soon; most of the hills are finally open around here. Hard to spot anything new with snow all over the rigs.

author: explorerx4
text: We must have a dozen Subaru's at work. 3 inches on snow today, and only 1 showed up. Posers.

author: fintail
text: Saw 2x A7 today, surprised how many of these I have seen given the price of admission.

author: stever
text: Posers? Maybe they were out playing in the snow. :shades:

author: anythngbutgm
text: Sedan, black base model with hubbies, and a Hatchback Sport model with the bigger Premium wheels. THought I would like the sedan better but the hatch is growing on me. :shades:

author: ateixeira
text:
Bingo.

I'm essential staff so I'm that one who makes it in to work.

Funny how I'm "essential" when it's time to work but not when it's time to hand out the big paychecks!

author: ateixeira
text:
These are slowly becoming common.

I see more new Camrys and that just came out recently.

I have seen a couple of Mini Countrymans lately.

author: andys120
text: I spotted a Lamborghini Gallardo Spider, orangy-red w black hood, top down.

author: anythngbutgm
text: Top down? Wow, aren't you in New hamster? That's gotta be mighty cold!

author: andys120
text: Nope, I'm wintering in AZ, highs in the upper 60s.

author: andys120
text: I saw my first new Chevy Sonic, a red 5dr hatchback, nice looking but a bit conventional compared to a Focus

author: ateixeira
text:
New ones seem tall. Then again, from the point of view of a roadster, everything seems tall.

Did a U-turn thru the median to get out of traffic, funny. Probably about as far off road as it will ever go.

author: ateixeira
text:
5 doors look really good, still a fresh design even though I've seen a bunch.

I love the taillight detail.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Nothing exciting but a new hatch passed me as I was merging on the highway yesterday afternoon.

A neighbor of mine brought home a new Camry last night, Black SE V6. Had a current gen Impala before it. I think he must've gotten a healthy Christmas bonus or something because his wife has also been driving around in a brand new loaded Venza for the past month or so (used to drive a Saab 9-4x).

Going to try and check out the new Impreza this weekend. :shades:

author: ateixeira
text:
C&D tested all the B-segment cars and they actually found the Yaris to be one of the more fun-to-drive ones.

So much for stereotypes.

author: fintail
text:
Oh boo hoo, could the "stereotype" be from truth? Previous iterations of the Yaris rank pretty much in the penalty box category, especially the awkward trunkback versions.

Toyota has crafted its own image, can't cry about anyone passing judgment.

author: ateixeira
text:
Don't shoot the messenger. I was actually surprised, too.

Chill?

author: fintail
text: Meh, nothing to chill about, just don't get the commotion when anything critical is said about Toyolex. It's not an unfounded stereotype. 20 or so years of beige builds expectations.

author: ateixeira
text: No commotion except from you this time...

author: ateixeira
text:
Hilarious ... not new, but had to share.

They installed a new electronic speed trap on Canal Rd, I got 3 warnings in the mail, luckily no fines.

I guess the fines started coming out, and it looks like someone vandalized it. 2 cops were there today fixing something.

Well, guy in a Prius is in front of me, rolls down his windows and reaches his arm out. Instead of a peace sign, BOOM, middle finger! Waves it around, too. Hysterical.

I guess he got a ticket in the mail from them as well, but it was not a warning.

author: imidazol97
text:
>They installed a new electronic speed trap on Canal Rd, I got 3 warnings in the mail,

Is that trap located in an area where speeding regularly occurs?
Is it in a location where the higher than the limit speed is actually dangerous?

author: ateixeira
text:
Yes, average speed is definitely high there. It's almost like a parkway, but they set the limit at an artificially low 35mph. I'd say the 85th percentile is way up around 55 or so.

It's not a residential area, though. It parallels the C&O Canal, and the Potomac River beyond that. Bikes and joggers go on the other side of the canal, so zero pedestrians.

Dangerous? Not at all, IMHO. I've been driving on that road for 19 years and I have not seen a single serious accident, not one.

Local governments lose money on those, too, so it's very controversial here in MD. They make some money at first, then people figure out where to slow down, and then the revenues stop, but the maintenance costs remain.

By rule they usually have to be within a certain distance from a school, but the odd thing is there is no school there. There is a private school up on MacArthur Boulevard ... let me search.

No way, 2.6 miles away, not even close.

author: fintail
text: More cameras should fall to that fate, or worse.

author: imidazol97
text:
Dayton City has put up speed cameras. One is on a 6 lane wide street with a separating turn lane in the middle and parking lanes on each side. The businesses and industry are long gone. It's safe to go over 35 on that 3 block strip close to the main post office sorting center.

Speed cameras--gotta make that money for the floundering city.

I suggested since the city says they aren't using them to make money, but to improve safety, that they send the money from the "fines" to the surrounding 5 counties. The locals will know the cameras are there--the out-of-towners will get caught because they don't know they're coming up. So the fine money should go to those counties for schools funding, e.g.

author: fintail
text:
Only a handful of light cameras in my burb, and they are at intersections which can legitimately be troublesome at times. But when cities can't buy the tech and have to send zillions off to supposed "independent entrepreneur capitalist" etc etc etc organizations who get to own the machinery, all the while safety links are tenuous at best if existing at all, it makes one wonder.

Didn't see any new cameras or cars on the road today :shades:

author: fintail
text:
I'd say complaining about a "stereotype" when said stereotype is justified is kind of looking for commotion

Pity Toyota, everyone is so mean to the maker of such great driving machines.

author: ateixeira
text:
OK, so I looked closer and the camera is in DC. So forget the logic of putting them where they make kids safe.

Yeah, the same DC that re-elected crack-smoking Mayor for Life Marion Barry. Gotta pay for the crack some how!

They may make a movie about him with Eddie Murphy in the starring role. He would be PERFECT!

author: stickguy
text:
or soon to be.

The Philly car show (highlight of my social season!) starts next weekend. I was looking at their website, they should have a lot of stuff I want to see.

for the wife, the Escape, mazda CX5, For C-Maxx. not sure about the next Santa fe, but I hope so.

And that new dart really caught my eye. not that I am going to buying anything new for me for a long time, but man, that pushed my buttons.

One thing I need to do though is get my wife off of her "I don't want a Ford" kick.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Few new CR-V's and a couple of new Civic Si's (sedans).

Also tried to check out the new Impreza but with the snow we got, the dealer was scrambling to move the inventory around for the plowtrucks. But I did check out a Premium hatch. Had the big sport rims, no roof, cloth interior (well done IMO, simple but well built), Auto tranny (36mpg)...

$22,600.

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw a light blue Nissan Leaf this morning, and then a black Volt a little later (I keep seeing the same one, HOV sticker and all).

Also saw my 2nd CR-V.

author: andys120
text: Saw my first Chevrolet Volt outside of auto shows parked near a Medical office.

author: lemko
text: Spotted a bright yellow Chrysler 300 taxi! It's probably the first and only time I saw one being used as a taxi.

author: ateixeira
text:
Volvo C70 convertible, with the new droopy front end.

Then a Lexus IS250 convertible.

Then an Infiniti G37 convertible.

Then a Benz E coupe, but with the sky roof.

Finally, a VW Eos, with the new front.

Pity it's damp and foggy!

author: fintail
text:
The rare thing will be seeing any of those cabrios with the top down. They seem to sell to a group who loves the convertible image but are scared to feel wind in their hair.

Local MB dealer had a gorgeous CPO E coupe in the showroom, loaded, sable/brown with kind of a tan interior, odd combo and somehow it worked.

author: fezo
text:
Today was a day where I could have had the top down which would have been the second time in January which for NJ isn't bad at all. Unfortunately I got a bit of a bug and napped instead. Dang!

That's a nice collection of cars. One of the reasons for ending up in the Solara is that for a convertible it has a nice trunk. Those folding hard tops tend to have enough room in the truck for a box of tissues.... (The classic for that was the original Miata.... but it's a Miata so who cares?)

author: lemko
text: ...silver Mercedes CL 500...smashed-up on the back of a rolltop truck. Somebody's insurance just went up exponentially!

author: ateixeira
text:
I had the top down today. :shades:

For me the rule is 40+ and dry, top down.

author: fintail
text: Being of that age, easy total I am sure. Insanely expensive car to fix.

author: ateixeira
text: I prefer the sedan for looks, which is odd because I've always liked the hatch/wagon better in the past.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Also saw another new Impreza this morning, Blue hatch with the premium wheels.

Also saw 2 truckloads of new CR-V's and then a truckload of new Camry's (and a Venza hanging off the back).

author: fezo
text: Oh, you dog! You are just enough south of here to get the better weather, though I will admit it is over 40 here.....

author: fintail
text: Saw a 2012 Rio 5 door

author: ateixeira
text: They ought to stuff the turbo engine from the Veloster in that thing...budget sleeper.

author: ateixeira
text:
In my dad's driveway.

He picked up a dark copper S model, Pentastar V6, folding hard top, last Thursday. Fully loaded with GPS, heated leather, Boston Acoustics sound, etc.

author: fintail
text:
That would be amazing.

I hope your dad is keeping the new car for the long haul, I have to imagine short term resale on those is scary.

author: ateixeira
text:
I expressed the same concern in the CCB thread! Funny.

Link: http://townhall-talk.edmunds.com/direct/view/.ef2c24d/23567#MSG23567

Looks like you've read it already.

$33.5k paid OTD today, $22k value tomorrow.

I paid $22k for my PRHT 2008 Miata and I bet they're already worth about the same money!

author: fintail
text: Sounds right. He'd hate that Miata no doubt....he's the perfect demographic for the Chrysler, and I hope it serves him well and is problem free. The more domestics that can perform, the better.

author: ateixeira
text:
He'll probably put 4k miles per year on it, so it should last a while.

He has an 01 Outback with ridiculously low miles. They kept it since it's been trouble-free. He has a long, hilly driveway so I doubt the Chrysler will make it out if it snows.

author: stickguy
text: noticed over the weekend that I am seeing quite few 500s around here now. Must be selling some. There is one in my office parking lot, and saw a few different ones parked in driveways.

author: fintail
text:
Sunny day boulevard cruiser - exactly what the car was made for.

Maybe by the time he is finished with it, you'll be old enough to want it

author: ateixeira
text:
Oh, that was below the belt!

That's the car I'd rent if we went to Florida for a week. I wouldn't want to drive it daily even if he gave it to me.

Well, I might leave it at the beach condo, and only use it while I'm there. I'd need a battery tender for the off-season, though.

author: fintail
text: Just wait another 25 years, you won't be wanting to get in and out of that Miata :P

author: stickguy
text: That's one reason (a big one!) that I don't have mine anymore. Too darned painful, especially since I just did not fit.

author: ateixeira
text: It may not take 25!

author: fintail
text: On somewhat different ends of the spectrum, today I saw a new C coupe and a trunkback Versa.

author: lemko
text: ...new gray metallic Infiniti M37x with temporary plates at work.

author: kyfdx
text: It's very nice looking... .hate to think of the depreciation hit that guy is going to take..

author: texases
text:
Strike 1 - waiting at a light, a BMW X6 drives by - "why buy that instead of an X5 or 5er" I think..
Strike 2 - 10 seconds later, a 5 GT goes by in the opposite direction - ugh...
Strike 3 - Now I hear that BWM's doing the 'GT' thing to the X3, creating the new X4... :sick:

author: fintail
text: Money, taste, and sense don't seem to have positive correlations :shades:

author: ateixeira
text:
It will be worth 50% of MSRP the day after he buys it.

40% the 2nd day.

author: ateixeira
text:
I was behind a new one of these, it had more chrome on the rear bumper than you see on most Lincolns. Not one, not two, but THREE (!) strips or chrome on the bumper itself. One a step/protector, two at the bottom that appear to surround non-functioning exhaust outlets. Actual exhaust smoke was exiting from below the bumper.

Wonder if that's a cheesy dealer add-on or what?

author: fintail
text:
Sounds like an add-on to me. There's a late base IS250 that lives near me - by the plate I think it is about 8 months old. Has all of the chrome pillar and window frame trim you can imagine. Looks just wonderful.

Saw yet another C coupe yesterday, they seem to be selling OK.

author: ateixeira
text:
Hmm, I dunno, it's on this one, 2nd photo shows what I'm talking about:

http://www.autoblog.com/2012/01/05/2012-mercedes-ml350-bluetec-w-onandoffroad-pa- ckage-quick-spin-review/

Not sure if it's standard on the BlueTec or if that's the off road package.

Direct link to image:

http://www.autoblog.com/photos/2012-mercedes-ml350-bluetec-w-onandoffroad-packag- e-quick-spin/#photo-4716547/

I know Americans love chrome but I hate the stuff.

AMG is different:

http://www.autoblog.com/photos/2012-mercedes-benz-ml63-amg-la-2011/#photo-461690- 7/

author: tifighter
text: Speaking of this review, I was surprised to hear that MB was going to bring this off road version to the States. Seems to be opposite of what most others are doing, save for its platform-mate the Grand Cherokee...

author: ateixeira
text: I wonder how much they have in common underneath...

author: fintail
text: Oh, that's not how I imagined it. Yeah, looks like a bling package. Chrome came back into style...whitewall tires have to be just around the corner now

author: ateixeira
text:
Chrome wheels are worse - more unsprung weight.

At least spinners came and went quickly...where's the roll eyes emotorcon?

author: lemko
text: I was out at lunchtime and passed by a house that had a car under a cover in the driveway. The cover was falling off the car and revealed a brand-new black Mercedes E63 AMG with the hood all stomped in, the glass all busted and the wheels missing! If that was my car, I'd be inconsolable - insurance or not! Good God, you can't have anything nice in this city without some knucklehead messing it all up! Thank God, my Cadillacs are in secured storage for the winter!

author: ateixeira
text: Maybe he was a Fund Manager and lost the life savings of all the people who vandalized it.

author: fintail
text: Spinners passed, then there was a short period where those wheels that give the illusion of standing still came in. Both are gone thankfully. But oversized wheels are still popular for everything, and IMO older highline cars with blingy aftermarket wheels look trashy. Most of the wheels also come from China, which makes me worry about durability, not a place known for good metallurgy. I suspect in a few years there will be huge amounts of cracked and broken wheels out there.

author: fintail
text: Who would park something like that outside in Philly to begin with? I am surprised your cars haven't been messed with. One of those things that makes me happy I live where I live...I lost a couple fintail hood ornament back in the 90s when that was cool (and I was in a college area, so idiots were around anyway), nothing since.

author: lemko
text:
My Cadillacs are never left outside. If I saw "Black Beauty" looking like that Benz, I probably would have a heart attack.

I remember that fad. Cadillac wreath and crest hood ornaments were also stolen. You saw a lot of Caddies and Mercedes with the hood onaments missing in Philly back in the late '80s/early '90s.

author: imidazol97
text:
>Cadillac wreath and crest hood ornaments were also stolen.

You'd see youths with chains with Mercedes and Cadillac hood ornaments. They would wear them around their belt.

author: lemko
text: ...spotted both a new red Scion xB and gray Scion IQ parked together on Stanwood Street near Palmetto in NE Philly.

author: fintail
text:
Especially with the insurance knowing about the depreciation on those cars. You need to keep that thing mint for awhile.

I remember seeing those ornaments used as big pendants for awhile, VWs were also susceptible to loss.

author: texases
text:
"spotted ... a new red Scion xB "

If it was RED (and not some dark burgundy) you saw a

"HOT LAVA xB
RELEASE SERIES 9.0
Starting Price $18,840*
Scorching "Hot Lava" Finish
Suede-Style Trimmed Seats
Illuminated Vehicle Locator Badges
Honeycomb Grille
ONLY 1500 CREATED"

Woo-Hoo!

author: ateixeira
text:
We'll try to contain ourselves.

I guess a lot of these niche cars do that, though. Miata has special editions almost every year early on. VW launches new colors for the Beetle this way, too.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Especially love this Special Edition

link title

And Miata wise, this one is pretty sweet too

link title

author: slorenzen
text:
I grew up in northen California.

If your car broke down it could stay on the side of the road for a few days until it could be collected and dealt with.

When I moved to Oregon, I was astonished at what I witnessed.

If you break down here, within 2-3 hours, someone has slashed the tires, busted the windows and stomped on the sheet metal, virtually destroying the car.

WHAT IS WRONG with people here?

:confuse:

author: fintail
text:
Maybe someone had enemies?

I've never seen it that bad, although they are areas of this region where I wouldn't want to leave my car out for 15 mins, not to mention overnight - and not just for vandalism, but for outright theft.

It's all part of the race to the bottom. A second world standard is slowly approaching.

author: martian
text:
Saw one yesterday-ya gotta wonder what goes on in people's heads.
You buy a Chrysler 300 (a good sedan in its own right), and stick phoney "B" (Bently) badges all over the thing.
Who do you think you are fooling?
Its like the poor guy who rents a suit and car for an evening out-the rich guys who see him are laughing their heads off.

author: stickguy
text:
3 that I wanted to see. All roped off of course, but you get a good look up close.

the new Escape. Very nice. The Dodge Dart is a quantum leap ahead for Chrysler. and the Sube BRZ? Man, I want one of those some day.

of the other normal cars, the Imprezza was a great package.

author: lemko
text: slorenzen's post reminded me of that E63 AMG I saw last week. That was downright evil what some [non-permissible content removed] did to that car.

author: ateixeira
text: Yes, very nice Miata. The black top sort of disappears.

author: ateixeira
text:
Same here, the DC one, anyway.

Escape sure did look nice. Ford also had a pair of Focus STs. Loved the electric yellow paint ($495 option available on other models) and the seats! New Escape make the old one look 100 years old.

Dart also looked good in person. DC had a cut-away, sort of on its side, did you see that display as well?

BRZ was cool. It was roped off but we talked them in to letting us in. The seats were great, perforated leather steering wheel cover also telescoped. Back seat was useless, though what did I expect? 2 cheap details - the fake fender vents, and the front bumper insert. If it comes in at mid 20s like they say, though, look out, they won't have enough to meet demand.

Impreza was surprisingly roomy - bigger inside than a 3 series or the Lexus CT.

author: lemko
text: ...yellow Lamborghini Gallardo turning right onto Robbins Street from Tabor Avenue in NE Philly.

author: fintail
text:
I wonder if insurance fraud was maybe in the works. A certain amount of cosmetic damage could be an easy total.

Speaking of E63, I visited the local MB dealer to see if anything weird was hanging around. The assortment was pretty average - all normals with about 5 AMGs thrown in, one a loaded diamond white E63 that had been a demo for the owner of the dealership. It was pretty hot, everything but performance package, they wanted something like 15K off MSRP for it. But, one of the wheels had been scraped, and they didn't fix this before putting it in the showroom. Poor attention to detail.

Also saw an R8 cabrio, a newer (LEDs) GTR, and a new X3 on the road.

author: ateixeira
text: Seeing these on the road lately, seem to be getting out of the gate quickly.

author: mitchal
text: I saw a mini cooper that has a sedan look to it today. Don't know if it is altered or not. I will snap a pic of it tomorrow if it's still there. Pretty neat looking!

author: tifighter
text: That's the new coupe. I've seen a few around...there's a butt for every seat.

author: fintail
text: Walked past the BMW dealer yesterday and saw a new SWB 7er sitting amongst the LWB models. I thought the SWBs were gone.

author: andys120
text:
saw a new SWB 7er

Maybe it was a 5er, they're much the same as the 7er these days.

author: fintail
text: They probably are the same size as an E23 or even E32, but this one even had 750 badges. Brought back nice memories of the rented SWB 7er I had in Germany.

author: fintail
text: Spotted a trunkback Sonic...thought it was some kind of new Mitsubishi from a distance. Rental.

author: robr2
text:
Been busy at work but spotted this week:

Hyundai Veloster
RR Evoque
Plug In Prius - had CA plates and Zipcar markings

author: andys120
text:
I saw a Nissan GT-R for the first time outside of an Auto show, it was bright red but looked rather ordinary if you didn't see the huge grille in front. Coincidentally I also saw an
Altima Coupe in the same color afterwards and thought that it's basically a nicer looking design for perhaps 1/3 the cost.

Performance is another matter.

author: ateixeira
text: A pair of each.

author: ateixeira
text:
I haven't even seen it yet, but a friend of mine just told me he got one of these. Traded a 3 series wagon in for it.

I'll have to ask him to take me for a spin later. I have mixed feelings about a Maxi Mini, but at least it's AWD.

author: fintail
text: The Fisker Karma I saw a few weeks ago is sitting in the used car section of the local Lexus dealer this morning. In a bit I have to head that way, if it is still there I will grab a pic.

author: texases
text: There's a review of the Karma in the latest C/D - not much to like, expensive, heavy (over 5000 lbs), cramped rear seat...

author: ateixeira
text:
Maybe the owner realized that and traded for a Lexus.

Or maybe the Lexus dealer is acting as an agent. How are they distributing them?

author: fintail
text:
Actually I just did a little digging, and the same dealer group (family owned, inherited of course) who owns the Lexus dealer owns the Fisker dealer, but the actual sales location isn't here. Maybe a mucky muck is demoing it.

I can't imagine the same person who would buy a new LS etc buying one of those, it would scare them away.

author: fintail
text:
And here it is:





No warranty!

author: texases
text:
WOW - no warranty! On a limited production car full of new/untested technologies! Wonder why it hasn't sold...

And just so others know, that PV array in the roof only helps charge the 12V system, no the main battery. Takes a BIG array to do that.

author: fintail
text:
You don't want to roll those dice? It's not listed on the dealer website...I wonder how much they want for it. I think it must have arrived there later Saturday or Sunday.

On a similar note, I went to the local mall yesterday, which has a Tesla dealer in it. They had a 4 door model on display. Very Audi like. Friend who was with me snickered at the 300mile/6 hour range for the best/pricey battery option.

author: texases
text: Of course the 4-door's not available..."Bloomberg reports this morning that Tesla may have seen its loss widen in 2011's final quarter. We can't imagine why. Well, other than the Model S sedan isn't expected to go into production until mid-2012 — and that they've killed the $109,000 Roadster and a replacement isn't coming until 2015 — and Tesla's main revenue source right now is supplying battery packs to Toyota and Daimler.'

author: lemko
text: I don't know if you watch "American Dad" but this past Sunday's episode had Steve Smith and Roger the Alien playing their TV detective alter-egos "Wheels and the Legman." They were driving what appeared to be an orange 1970 or so Mercedes 280S.

author: lemko
text: ...black Chrysler 300 at Cottman and Oxford and bright green Camaro at Oxford and Sheffield in NE Philly.

author: qbrozen
text: temp tags at the daycare. The back end is very volvo'ish.

author: fintail
text: Pretty sure there's a new GS sitting in the showroom of my local dealer, but it's hard to tell for sure from a distance. The Fisker is gone, too.

author: andys120
text:
I saw a new Camaro convertible, orange w black top. I liked it better than the coupe because the taller roof line w the convertible top up makes it look like a real car. The squashed roof of the h/t makes it look like a cartoon car IMO.

Now if they'd clean up that geeky interior...

author: anythngbutgm
text:
I swear I saw one of these heading the other direction on the highway this morning. Are they even out yet? :confuse:

Saw a few new CR-V's and a slew of new Camrys this week. Along with the new Impreza which appears to be strong right out of the gate. I actually have a co-worker is thinking about getting one as well.

AWD and 36mpg is really getting noticed...

author: fintail
text:
I heard the new Lexus GS is just hitting the streets, stopped by the local dealer to take a peek - they had maybe 10 of them in various trim and colors. I looked one over and sat in it, a pearl white "F Sport" trim car. Very nice, very high quality materials and with tons of gadgetry, huge nav screen which is like having a tablet screen on your dash, this car might actually give the competition something to work against. It's big too...still has some awkward design ideals, but I certainly wouldn't object to one. The one I saw had metal accents inside which were cool too, a strange textured metal that reminded me of some kind of Japanese art metalwork. Dealer was trying to get me into one too, offered me a $1500 conquest deal coming out of a MB, offered the lease deal, etc.

They also had a LFA on display, apparently you can buy them outright now rather than just be involved in some kind of lease, but buyers must meet "approval", which I was told was mostly to prevent grey market activity.

author: texases
text:
Saw my first "ActiveHybrid 7" the other day. About $20k more than the 'regular' 750i, save maybe a few hundred$ per year...but it's a hybrid!

Note that I drive a hybrid, but mine's a 'breakeven' proposition (maybe better than that at $4+/gallon). I just think spending $20k to save $2k is anything other than grandstanding.

author: fintail
text: MB is the only one who plays the luxohybrid game correctly - makes it the cheapest model.

author: stickguy
text: a New Nissan work van. man, that thing is hideous. Nasty snout, and the body looks like some kids in auto shop got stoned and started playing with the tools. I have seen better looking body work on redneck pickup conversions (you know, when they cut the back of of a minivan?)

author: kyfdx
text:
It may be a hybrid, but it still has a twin-turbo V-8... :surprise:

They had one at the local car show.... lots of wood and leather.... pretty nice ride, if you don't mind the price..

author: fintail
text: Saw a yellow Tesla roadster this morning, I know it was one due to large "TESLA" lettering on the side.

author: ateixeira
text:
Lost count.

Camrys also.

Another Veloster, still not a turbo. Those should be out?

C250 Benz coupe at a stop sign near the kids' school.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Drove a new CR-V and a new Impreza.

First the Impreza. Nice car. Very nice car actually and certainly an upgrade on the inside and outside compared to the outgoing one. This one was a Premium model with cloth and the CVT. Seats were good and the ingress/egress was excellent, especially for rear seat users. Speaking of rear seats, the legroom is as much as my wifes Outback... easily. Regarding the powertrain, the new 2.0 is quiet, smooth and doesn't have much of the Boxer growl. It also feels a bit smoother than my Impreza with the 2.5.

Then there is the CVT. Absolute deal breaker. Wife could not stand the whine and it bugged the crap out of me too. Especially when the radio was on and you could still hear it. I'm sorry but 36mpg is incredible but I would rather give up a couple of MPG's for a conventional automatic (heck even the current 4-speed) or I would go with the stick all the way (33mpg). Sticker price for a loaded Sport Limited was just over 25 grand which is a great price for AWD, BT, heated seats, Nav, moonroof and foglights. But this car was for my wife and the CVT killed it for us.

Next, the CR-V. Sticker price was just over 30 for an EX-L with Nav. My wife loved the step in ingress and the seats were better than the ones in her LL Bean OB. I owned a 2000 CR-V which I loved but my gosh this new one is like night and day. The engine, the acceleration, the road noise were all exceptional for this class. Even the visibility, which I was expecting to be poor was just fine for seeing out the back. I especially liked the amount of windsheild there was, it reminded me of the old Hondas in the visibility/airy cabin dept. Powertrain-wise, again, the acceleration was good and the engine was very quiet. Now, I pretty much haven't met an automatic that I actually liked, but the one in the CR-V was downright perfect. There was no gear hunting, there was no droning and the changes were timed exactly when I wanted them. I could live with the Automatic on the V. Oh, and the test drive consisted of a couple of not-so-great roads and the thing soaked up the bumps great.

Basically, there was not one thing about it that I was disappointed with.

Except.

No Homelink... :sick:

Seriously, what a stupid ommision. out of all the electronics on my wife's Outback that get used the most, I'll bet homelink takes second only to the Stereo. I have a 2 car garage and it is just plain assinine to think that I am going to carry around a keychain with (2) transmitters or I'm going to have (2) different "clickers" hanging from the visor. :mad:

Oh sure, Honda will install one of those Gentex rear view mirrors with Homelink but it'll probably be another 500 bucks and they'll have to take apart the interior to do so which could introduce rattles. Stupid, stupid, stupid.

Anyways, other than that, it looks like the CR-V will be at the top of the list for my wifes next vehicle. But, hopefully by the time she's ready, Honda will add this feature to an already excellent array of gadgets. And if there are people out there who don't mind the ommission, I highly recommend a test drive.

author: ateixeira
text:
Teach her to drive stick! :shades:

CVT may be seen as a necessary harm with upcoming CAFE regs. Subaru has the AWD handicap across the board (BRZ excepted), so that makes meeting CAFE numbers even harder.

You can still get a Forester or H6 Outback with a conventional automatic.

author: fintail
text:
Funny, that car has appeared in the show before:



If you've watched the not as good as the movie animated "Napoleon Dynamite" series, the grandmother character drives a bustleback Seville which is often rendered well for such a show:



Today's new sighting, Impreza, seeing them off and on now.

author: berri
text: I think CVT may be one of the dumbest innovations in cars. I don't see one advantage. They don't drive as well and the mileage seems worse. Every Altima I've rented gets several less mpg than others like Camry.

author: ateixeira
text:
In theory, a CVT can put an engine at an ideal RPM and keep it there. Peak torque, for instance, or peak HP.

It's all in the tuning. They can even simulate gears.

People tend to love 'em or hate 'em, though. In the Subaru threads that's how it is, love/hate.

I will say that MPG reports have skyrocketed for all the models that got CVTs (base Legacy/Outback and Impreza).

Thankfully you can still get a manual in the Impreza, Forester, and Outback. I can't imagine craving a traditional slush box, no matter the car.

author: fintail
text: New Impreza hatch in the outdoor lot of my building this morning

author: iwant12
text: A buddy at work just traded his FJ for a CR-V AWD EX-L. I went and checked it out and was relatively impressed with the whole package. Overall, I liked it, but not as much as my '11 Grand Cherokee 4x4.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new CRV today, a filthy C coupe, and a 2 door Evoque.

author: anythngbutgm
text: I actually have the GC at the top of my list for my next vehicle as well :shades:

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Looks like people up here in N.E. are taking notice of the rising gas prices. Took a trip to Southern Mass yesterday which included a good protion of Rt95/128 and I counted 10 Nissan Leafs during the trip whole trip, down and back.

I also lost track of how many new CR-V's I saw. But definitely the most common vehicle on my trip had to be the Honda Pilot. All different years. They are as common as Subarus and BMW's.

Couple of one off sightings, a Panamera, a new Toureg, a new Durango (a rarity around here), a new CLS, and even a new 3-series.

author: stickguy
text:
We are thinking about replacing my wife's Odyssey later in the year with something smaller (and not a van after 17 years in one). So, I have been showing her pics of the newer stuff coming out (Escape, CX-5, etc. since we are looking for a small/mid size CUV).

I also had the program fromt he Philly car show (she was sick and could not go with me).

after looking at the book, and some stuff I showed her online, the "normal" one she liked the best? The Hyundai Santa Fe (current style, not even the one coming out later in the year).

She also does not want to go too small, and I think something like the CX-5 won't be big enough for her. But, the Hyundai seems to hit that sweet spot of a big small one, or a small big one.

author: ateixeira
text:
You just reminded me, I saw my first one spotted in the flesh. Cute little crossover. I bet it sells well.

The one I saw was a bright blue.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Red, on the highway yesterday afternoon.

I can't think of another place to mention it, but I also saw an old SVT Contour as well. Almost forgot about those, man I wanted one badly when they were out.

This one looked a little rough, the passenger side rocker was missing and the whole edge was rusted plus there was rust around the rear quarters, But I rolled my window down while he went by and the engine purred like new. Oh and it was actually green! That's got to be a rarity in of itself. :surprise:

author: kyfdx
text:
Both with temporary tags...

Much better looking than the last model.... especially from the rear.

author: ateixeira
text:
I test drove a Contour V6 back in 1995, when the wife was car shopping. It was pretty decent, manual trans and all.

SVT came out later and earned rave reviews. Shame this owner is caring for it better.

author: fintail
text: On the used car section of the local Lexus dealer, sits another Fisker Karma tonight, different than the one a couple weeks ago. I wonder if it too is "as is - no warranty".

author: stickguy
text:
I had a 1995 Mystique (V6 stick shift) that I got in 1998. good car overall, but it did get 2 cat replacements while I had it (3 years). good thing i didn't pay for either one.

They were nicely equipped (very euro) at the beginning, but they pulled a toyota and made them cheaper every year is seems. Worlds different from the '98(or '99?) 4 cyl AT my son had for a while.

author: jwilliams2
text: Was the dealers "as is - no warranty" Federally mandated sticker on the window? If so, it could just mean the dealer doesn't warranty it, because it's still under the manufactures warranty.

author: fintail
text:
This was on the previous car, I didn't stop to look at the new one:



To me, it implies no manufacturers warranty either.

author: ateixeira
text:
I think they used the CD4E automatics in there, those were awful.

Manual was the only way to go.

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw 3 of these last night and today. Good looking SUV minus all the chrome trim on that rear bumper, it kinda spoils an otherwise attractive vehicle. I hate chrome - belongs on pimped out Escalades.

Also saw another new CR-V. Seems like I see them often now.

Finally, a Chevy Volt was behind me early today.

author: stever
text: First one I've seen in the wild.

author: kyfdx
text: You have to get out more....

author: stickguy
text: You missed the point. he meant literally in the wild (where he lives). You expect many up there in the wilderness?

author: kyfdx
text: Actually, I think he left on a road trip, today..

author: stever
text:
Spotted it somewhere around Bloomington IL. :-)

When did it come out anyway - two years ago? :P

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw a new SL, temp tags, the one with the L-shaped headlights.

Yet another CR-V. One of the quickest sellers out of the gates.

author: kyfdx
text: As a previous Gen I and Gen II CR-V owner.... I really like Gen IV... (Gen III, not so much)..

author: ateixeira
text:
My brother has a Gen II, albeit a 2.0l model in Brazil.

I was never a fan of the underbite, but I will say it's much nicer inside than out.

author: fintail
text:
Was killing some time earlier and stopped by a few local lots. MB dealer had nothing really exciting but a salesman said he wanted to buy my car when I was ready to sell. Saw a new style 3er - loaded sport 335i sedan, 57K sticker - same dealer had a zillion leftover 11 3ers. Audi dealer had nothing unusual but I will say the A6 is lovely inside, weird overbite on the trunk though. Saw a Lexus LX570 with a 92K sticker and they also still had a good 10 or more new GS. Subaru only had a couple new Imprezas and nothing else noteworthy, VW had many new Beetles and Jettas but the most interesting car on the lot was an old SLC. Toyota had many new Camry and Yaris, a few Scion iQ too, one with a 20K+ sticker.

MB dealer said the B should be here by the end of the year and the A is definitely coming, will be interesting to see new niches chased in the US.

author: stever
text:
Looked bigger in the Outback parking lot than it did at the auto show last year. Still had the temporary tags on it. Looks like a real car, compared to a Smart.

Saw a few hundred brand new VWs today but was too far away to tell if they were all Passats or not.

author: explorerx4
text:
Did you drive by the factory?
I see lots of Cruze's every time I drive through Lordstown.

author: stever
text:
Yeah, there's a new nature park out there adjacent to the factory so we went for a three mile walk this morning. Lots of the new cars are under "shade" islands - keeps the bird and hail mess off them I guess. Maybe we'll be able to get on a factory tour one trip south.

Passed about 3 car carriers on the Interstate the last couple of days full of Mazdas and Chevys. SAAR hit a huge 15.1 million for February so there should be lots of new rides to see. Heading to Florida in the morning so I'll keep my eyes peeled for new Caddys and Buicks. :shades:

author: qbrozen
text: Evoque and Sonic hatch. Both black. I didn't spot whether the evoque was 2 or 4-door as it didn't click with me (since i was focused on getting somewhere quickly) until the sideview was out of sight.

author: ateixeira
text:
Still rare, I've only seen a couple of these on the road. Top was up, since it's cold, though I'm not sure it would look any better with the top down.

Also saw an H3 and an H2 this AM, not new, but I don't see either nearly as often as before. I guess most have moved away from urban use to rural areas? Who knows.

author: fintail
text:
Saw the silver Karma from the car lot the other day out on the road. Being driven by a high level dealer person I am sure.

Also saw a truckload of new cars - all Imprezas and various Nissans. Maybe the factories are close?

Oh, funny thing from yesterday at the MB dealer - after having a salesman want to buy my car, I went to the used section and was approached/ambushed by a saleswoman. I told her I was just looking to see if anything new and weird was on the lot, and she asked several times about what I would want to buy if they had it. I told her the specific color combination high option bluetec that likely doesn't exist. I think that scared her off :shades:

author: ateixeira
text:
All Imprezas are made in Gunma, Japan. Maybe you're close to the port? Or some storage facility?

They should kick Toyota out of SIA and put a Forester/Impreza assembly line in its place.

PS I use that tactic, i.e. asking for something I know they won't have. In my case it usually involves a manual transmission.

author: fintail
text:
Oh, I thought they were USA made now. Must be a storage issue then, as I am pretty sure the local dealers are unrelated.

My imagined bluetec - quartz blue with light (almond or beige) interior, P2, pano, sport - I really doubt it exists, would have to be a special order. I'd even choose a wagon if we had a diesel here.

author: ateixeira
text: And I want any diesel wagon with a manual but that ain't happening either.

author: fintail
text: Jetta, right? If you feel lucky, anyway :shades:

author: ateixeira
text: One I can trust.

author: kyfdx
text:
Port is Portland or Seattle... something like that ... for Imprezas...

I think Mazdas come in there, too... Remember the ship that rolled over? Didn't those cars all come in up that way... then, straight to the salvage yard?

author: ateixeira
text:
Cougar Ace IIRC?

Yeah, Mazda crushed them all to prevent sub-standard parts from making it to to the gray market.

Think about how many Miatas died.

author: stever
text:
Me too!

A black one, top up. I was in a bit of traffic passing through Atlanta and didn't really get a very good look at it.

author: ateixeira
text: 5 door, nice looking car...

author: stever
text: Convertible. Anxious driver in traffic. Was on the brakes every two seconds.

author: kyfdx
text: Geez.. where are you slumming?

author: stever
text:
That sighting was around Clearwater Florida. It still was "outclassed" by the ~$500,000 motor home in the campground we landed in last night.

Hard to believe there's a recession just driving around. $4 gas sure isn't slowing anyone down either.

author: stickguy
text: it's only a recession if you are out of work.

author: ateixeira
text: Not its best color, the grille is dark and looks odd contrasting a light colored body.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
The light blue is the most popular up where I live, and then the Silver, Black and Green.

I like the Burgandy myself, and the Titanium is pretty sharp as well.

They are a very common sight now...

author: kyfdx
text:
The first one I've seen on the road... (or noticed, anyway)..

I guess you'd call it a wagon... If I were getting a Prius, it would be this one..

author: anythngbutgm
text: 2 new Lexus GS's, one black yesterday and a gun metal gray today. Gotta admit the nose looks better in person and the whole car looks pretty good overall. I'd rock one.

author: ateixeira
text:
Close ups with fish-eye lenses almost intend to make it look bad.

Though I do prefer the non-F Sport bumper.

author: lemko
text: ...black VW Passat on Napfle and Rising Sun Avenue in NE Philly.

author: fintail
text:
The grille is still...hmmm...kind of unique, to put it nicely. I don't think anyone has to put any effort into making it look a little odd.

I actually prefer the more garish bumper on that car, distracts from the grille and kind of livens things up.

author: ateixeira
text: Saw a blue Leaf yesterday, then the usual suspects today. Another white CR-V (different plates than last time).

author: lemko
text: ...a new GMC Yukon Denali at Magee and Oxford...SITTING ON FOUR CRUSHED SODA CRATES MINUS ITS WHEELS!!! This is happening FAR too often nowadays! This isn't far from the burned-out and stripped Mercedes-Benz E63 AMG I spotted about a month ago. This isn't a bad neighborhood, but it abuts some that are pretty much becoming ghettos. Sad thing is, these ghettos themselves were really nice not that long ago, like a mere 10-15 years ago.

author: stickguy
text:
This the same area that is on the news all the time now in Philly, where they alternate between slashing and stealing tires, with an occasional spray painting mixed in?

Surprised that street doesn't have a bunch of security cameras up on it by now.

Anyway, this really just means it is time to move to Jersey like the rest of the Philly MC did!

author: ateixeira
text: A set of tires can cost $800 or more, even on a mainstream car. You'd think at least they would not destroy them...

author: fintail
text:
Not to mention some OEM wheels.

Next time I need to make an insurance claim, I know where to park :shades:

author: stickguy
text:
It seems to one street or small neighborhood (and not a "bad" one) up toward Lemko-ville. They had a rash of slashings (tires, not people, that is other parts of Philly!), and other vandalism. Last round though was actually steeling wheels right off a bunch of cars (how no one heard or saw that is a mystery).

One of the man reasons I would never live some place where I had to street park. I don't even like to leave my car in my driveway in a quiet suburban 'hood. And I am amazed at how many people with 2 gar garages can't even get 1 car in them!

And Fin, making cars disappear for insurance claims is a city pasttime. Make the right connection, and as good as done.

author: lemko
text: Ironically, the Yukon was parked in the driveway to the home as was the Mercedes. Too often, people have their garages filled with worthless hoarded junk leaving their vehicles outside and vulnerable. Dumb.

author: fintail
text:
I'd feel bad if I sent my car off in an insurance scam - not about the scam. but about the car :shades:

I know what lemko means about the garages, some people hoard so much useless crap and either fill up garages with it or pay far more than it is worth to store it. And around here, one can easily find a 500K++ house with no garage at all. Low crime area, though.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new E coupe today, not particularly odd, but it was a quartz blue pano car, which is nice to my eyes.

author: kyfdx
text:
Let one cut in front of me in a traffic line, yesterday.... so, got a good look at it for about five minutes...

Geez.... what a big, wide booty on that thing!!

author: stever
text:
For the last couple of days down here in Florida I've noticed quite a few cars that have a light lemon or pale green color. Lots of them look like Key lime pie. Often they are luxo barges - Caddy SUVs, etc. They look really nice in this climate.

Today I realized it was just my sunglasses and they are all shades of white. :blush:

author: texases
text: As much as I'm not a fan of the Panamera's booty, it's remarkable what that sedan will do. The latest CandD's track test has it faster around a road couse than many outright sports cars, 911 included.

author: berri
text: Better watch it down there Steve or you'll come back wearing plaid pants and white bucks and belt!

author: andys120
text: Some guys like a big booty.

author: qbrozen
text: Blue one here in the parking lot at work.

author: ateixeira
text:
It's the Kim Kardashian of cars.

Actually, though, I see it more as the Hunchback of Notre Dame. :sick:

author: ateixeira
text: The new Lorax movie it promotes was a hit, too. $70.2 Million and runaway #1 status.

author: lemko
text: ...white Chevrolet Sonic on Oxford Avenue near Magee in NE Philly.

author: stever
text: Have only seen one at an auto show. This was a white one in the St. Pete Beach area. Parked in a mundane unmetered space - no free juice.

author: tjc78
text: Saw two brand new Police spec Chargers today on the Delaware Mem Bridge. Still with window stickers and no markings. They looked pretty sinister in all black with the steel wheels. I guess Dodge is trying to grab some of that market now that the Panther is gone.

author: explorerx4
text: Not sure which way they were headed, I'm guessing south, but Delaware has had some for a few years.

author: tjc78
text: Actually they were going north. This was the first police version of the redesign I've seen. I passed a DE SP Charger on the way down, but it was the old style.

author: texases
text: Saw a new Buick Lucerne with the fake convertible top treatment, the whole nine yards, including that metal strip around the base with the snaps for the fake tonneau they must have bought for the fake top... :sick:

author: tjc78
text: What is even worse is the $2500 the dealer probably charged for it. I've seen a Lucerne with a top treatment like that. I've even seen late model Camrys and Altimas.

author: ateixeira
text:
Quietly drove by my street. All you hear is tire noise, strange.

Also saw a new Benz R-class, new nose.

New CR-V. More than one, actually.

Drove behind a Juke, too.

XC60 is popular around here, too, I saw 3 (!) of them all at once today.

author: lemko
text: Spotted a purple-ish blue Mazda 5 with aftermarket plastic eyelashes over the headlights! STRANGE!!! :surprise:

author: ateixeira
text: I saw some lashes like that on an orange Kia in a Target parking lot. We took photos and shared on FaceBook. It got a lot of laughs!

author: fintail
text: I see stuff like that in my area quite often. A certain demographic thinks it is cute. I see it as embarrassing a car, like putting goofy clothes on a pet.

author: fintail
text: New rides this afternoon - new Avenger rental, new Charger rental, new Avalon rental, late model S63, new Range Rover with the dorky LEDs.

author: stickguy
text: saw one at my office that must have been on a test drive. Still had the window sticker,various decals, plastic on the seats, etc. Just like it came off the truck. No idea why someone had one like that at work.

author: ateixeira
text:
First new style 3 series I've seen in the wild. Still not a fan of the headlights, but other angles look OK.

Also another CR-V, very common around here.

author: lemko
text: ...white Honda CRZ Hybrid on Verree Road near Oakmont in NE Philly.

author: texases
text: Talk about a no-show - I've seen maybe 5 of those CRZs, total.

author: ateixeira
text: Rare even here in DC, a political town full of pro-green types.

author: explorerx4
text:
Headed into Hartford as I was headed out.
Very yellow and strange looking.
After trying to look it up, maybe it was something else.

author: fintail
text: Today - 2x Leaf, 2x IS with LEDs, 4 door Evoque

author: stickguy
text:
Not sure which hot-rod 911 it was (GT2 or GT3), but a newish version of one of them.

interesting part, it was on a trailer with a tire rack, so looked to be some sort of race car (maybe auto-X?) Not full on race stuff, but must have been more than just a road car.

real interesting part? The tow vehicle was another Porsche, a Cayenne. Expensive tow truck there.

author: tjc78
text: New Gallardo in lime green at a major shopping area. I sure hope he wasnt parking that thing anywhere in that madness.

author: robr2
text: Saw the first Taurus cruiser today. Very interesting since the Boston Globe auto section today had a story about the new Explorers the State Police just put into service. They ordered 140 of them to go on-line in the next year.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
In a row, new E-class coupe, 911 GT2, Range Rover Evoque, Porsche Panamera, Lamborghini Murcialago convertible (ragtop on = fugly). Also a slew of new CR-V's parked on Newbury along with a new 328i.

Just walking down Newbury, I was passed by an Audi RS4, new Cayenne Turbo and an incredible SLS convertible... 6.3 AMG and all :surprise:

Then there was a "tuned" Sti than took off like a bullet on Mass Ave. damn...

Wynton Marsalis at the BSH btw, if he comes to your area, definitely go see him. Phenominal performance.

author: qbrozen
text: I think that's the same one I have autocrossed with (was the 911 white?). I mean, really, how many Cayennes towing 911s can there be? It is a GT3, BTW. Very very fast car that gets beat to hell by the owner and his codriver, who also happens to be the organizer of the Northern NJ SCCA events. One of them is typically in the top 3 times of the day. Amazing to me that someone can afford to trash such an expensive car.

author: ateixeira
text:
Must've been an embassy car, as I'm not far from there, but I saw a Corolla Verso tall wagon type of thing. At first I thought it was a Prius V, it's tall like that, taller even.

Only one I've ever seen in the flesh.

author: fintail
text: Not new, but I saw 2 Regals today, only one was a rental. Another decent enough car that was a failure to launch.

author: ateixeira
text:
Is it just being sold in the wrong store?

Seriously, even with a good product, are young GM buyers who want a sport sedan even choosing a Buick dealer? Sure some recall the GNX but that was in the 80s, over 25 years ago.

Look at the steep discounts they are offering. It's like Buick is competing with Chevrolet, just smaller and sportier, but no one knows it.

author: fintail
text:
That's probably a big part of it. Buick isn't completely reinvented yet - and I think the MSRP is inflated in typical GM style, compared to attainable transaction prices. That has to turn off more than a few,

I've seen Regal CXL down not much over 20K in screamer ads, not terrible for that.

author: ateixeira
text:
Regal is a bargain if your alternative is a TSX or something like that.

It would have made more sense with the Pontiac name, though I get that they kept Buick for China. This is just a bad side effect of that decision.

author: fintail
text:
Yeah. It's maybe half a size too small for a Camcord competitor, but it's still some bang for the buck. Unfortunately, the base DI unit can be kind of coarse, and isn't a screamer - but it gets decent mileage from my experience (had one as a rental).

With no Pontiac, tough decision as to where it should live. Maybe should have been a Malibu.

author: tjc78
text:
Just imagine if the regal was born a Pontiac. It would have some form of huge plastic body cladding, orange and red interior lighting and who knows what the front end would look like.

To your point there aren't many cars it competes with. It is a tweener in terms of size (not quite midsize, but not compact either). The only direct competitor really is the TSX and I guess you could throw in the Volvo S60.

author: ateixeira
text:
Yeah, slightly smaller, lighter, and sportier than the Camry/Malibu etc.

The previous Mazda6s and Legacy GT could be put in the same class, but the new ones bloated up and got bigger.

Who else? Maybe the Kizashi if VW and GM had not starved them of a decent engine.

Fact is, these are better suited for Europe, where the narrow bodies are preferred over the fat cats we get here, most of which are full-sizers now.

author: fintail
text: In Germany, it more or less is the Malibu equivalent. Maybe just not a good idea to bring it here, where local custom dictates something wider and blander for the mass market.

author: ateixeira
text: And then they sell it next to the Lucerne, because we all go car shopping with our grandparents, right?

author: stickguy
text:
yeah, the GT3 was white. The Cayanne was silver/gray. Heading south on 295 (so south of you and heading souther)

and heck, for the money they cahrge to make it into a "race car", it better be able to put up with some hard use!

author: fintail
text: And then barely market it, delay the performance model, don't offer it at half the spec of Europe, and fail to bring in the wagon.

author: stever
text:
In Detroit rush hour traffic, blowing by in the left lane (did catch up with him ~3 times).

Not new, but also saw a very secure undershirt wearing guy, smoking with the window down, driving an older Thunderbird that was brilliant pink.

author: qbrozen
text:
Yup, that's the one.

Here it is in action last October


And here it was in 2010:

author: kyfdx
text: Life isn't fair, huh? :surprise:

author: lemko
text: ...black Chrysler 200 at Napfle and Verree and silver BMW X3 at Faunce and Verree in NE Philly.

author: stever
text:
Not every day you see one of these.

Thank goodness.

Slipped up and didn't get my own pic.

author: kyfdx
text: That reminds me.... saw the wienermobile on I-75, once...

author: ateixeira
text: Textbook GM - snatching defeat from the jaws of victory.

author: tjc78
text:
Saw two Equus today within minutes of each other. That makes for a total of 3 since they came out.

Also saw a brand new Porsche Cayenne. I looked it up, they redesigned last year but this was the first "new" body style I've seen.

author: fintail
text:
Must have been some Hyundai dealers out for a demo run or something :shades: ...60K+ seems steep for a mountain of KDM style with how the big boys depreciate, but I guess there's a butt for every seat.

I wish I could say I have only seen one new Cayenne - in my area with too much idle money milling around, they seem to sell well. No uglier than the old one, anyway.

author: fushigi
text:
From the "Comparisons and Conclusions" section of Edmund's Equus wrap-up: http://www.insideline.com/hyundai/equus/2011/2011-hyundai-equus-long-term-test-w- rap-up.html:

Most significant of all comparison points between these vehicles was resale value. Based on a private-party sale, Edmunds' TMV Calculator showed that the Equus depreciated just 17 percent from its original MSRP. Under similar conditions the 528i and M56 depreciated 22 percent and 26 percent, respectively. Hyundai products have not traditionally fared well in the resale realm. So this is a big step in the right direction.

Personally, I wouldn't buy one. If I had $60K to spend on a car I wouldn't; I'd much rather spend $30-35K and have lots of change left over. I'm simply not in the target demographics. But for what it is - luxury at a value price - the Equus is not a bad deal.

author: stickguy
text: my opinion in general is that you hit the law of diminishing returns pretty quickly. you get to a certain point, and the huge increase in $$ gets very little real value back.

author: fintail
text:
How many of these exist to determine real world resale value? I'd love to know the details of that sale, but I bet they don't exist. I am a little skeptical. Of course, it doesn't really compete with the much smaller 5er and M anyway. Cars compete in more than price. This thing is trying to compete with the LS especially, then the Germans and probably Jag too.

Locally there's a ~25K mile 08 S63 P3 special order nearly full option load car (original MSRP 145K) that I could pick up, add an extended warranty, and still come out the same as a deluxe Equus. That's how I would do it anyway, same money, similar lux, nicer to look at and better to drive. Alas, I can't blow 65K on a car either way :shades:

Oh yeah, saw a new small Prius today. If I wanted to go that route, I think I'd choose that one.

author: ateixeira
text:
Isn't the S63 a SWB model?

I think a driver would buy the AMG, while the Equus would be more chauffer driven.

To me the Genesis is more appealing vs its big brother. For mid 30s you can get 333hp, 29mpg highway, 8 speed automatic, and the real leather dash package.

So basically a nice, big RWD car for the price of a base C class, with a powertrain that will be under warranty in the year 2022.

author: ateixeira
text:
3 wheeler, last night.

This morning I saw a ZDX and a Camry.

Of those 3 I'd take the Can Am! :shades:

author: fintail
text:
Only SWB W221 in NA have been the diesel and the hybrid. A regular S550 which is something more comparable - not tuned, would be a bit cheaper yet for the same model year, could get one still under factory warranty for the same money. Just can't see how the pseudo LS Equus has appeal, unless you are a rabid Korean expat.

I agree the Genesis is a much better value, so much so that I have my doubts it is even being sold at a profit - just too much for the money.

author: fintail
text: I picture the same person who would buy a ZDX as buying a Can Am

author: texases
text: To me the Can Am combines the weaknesses of a motorcycle (exposed to the weather and no crash protection) with none of the benefits (carving down a canyon road). I'll pass.

author: ateixeira
text:
Didn't realize that about the wheelbase lengths, I guess we learn something each day.

I wonder if those Equus are bought up by the limo companies? I would not be surprised if half of them are for that type of fleet, and those customers want new, not used.

so much so that I have my doubts it is even being sold at a profit

Agreed. For mid 30s is doesn't raise any eyebrows, either. That's loaded mainstream sedan money.

author: fintail
text:
I believe there is a SWB S63 available elsewhere.

For the Equus, how many are really being bought at all? I wouldn't doubt some are selling commercially, I wonder about the transaction price in those cases too...probably not 65K.

Original Lexus LS was no doubt sold at a loss here to get things going, I think the Genesis is the same. Awaiting the Kia version.

author: fintail
text: I think they just have kind of an awkward looking riding position. Expensive, too.

author: ateixeira
text: Not many ... 284 in Feb, 292 in Jan.

author: fintail
text: Probably 90% sold to dealers or Korean embassies :shades:

author: ateixeira
text:
The other 10% to wealthy Korean businessmen.

Tell you what, though, it's pretty nice inside those things. I wouldn't mind being driven around in one of those bad boys. I think the ceiling is lined with suede...

author: kyfdx
text: On the plus side: If you ride wearing khakis and topsiders, you'll fit right in.... :surprise:

author: fintail
text:
That's pretty much the demographic. A sportbike for the Goldwing set, I guess. I think I have only seen two of them on the road.

Saw two new freshly plated Mazdas today, a 3 and a 5 with the ridiculous side detailing. Both rentals.

Not new, but also saw the SL65 AMG I saw the other day, sounded amazing.

author: ateixeira
text:
ridiculous side detailing

Unfortunately that's the trend now, and not just for Asian brands.

author: fintail
text:
But look at that overdone upper detail:



Dopey, embarrassing - who do they think they are kidding, a diagonal swoopy line doesn't make a shoebox a race car. Reminds me of the accent painting on modern RVs. And that with the gormless smiling face...maybe if I was a 15 year old girl who lives in Japan...

Sadly, the copycat sycophant ranks of car designers will probably spread this everywhere.

author: ateixeira
text:
Funny thing is that's the last Mazda that used the old design language, since discontinued.
