The new B-class added "surface excitement" as well. The old model was clean and cute, now it's busy looking in profile.

To be fair, I do think it lowers the tall wagon visually, at least.

author: fintail
text: As long as you can still buy a new one, that's current enough for me. Nice to see they finally realized their mistake. I don't know if the B-class has that weird feathery detailing, and thankfully will also lack the dumb face. I see it as faux interest, making something boring look complex.

author: ateixeira
text:
I guess (?) it's supposed to make you look lower down, so the car doesn't appear so tall and awkward (which it is).

I liked the last one more - it was the only minivan you could get with a manual and factory Navi. We deemed it too small, and ended up with the Sienna. No regrets.

Nagare was a bad phase for Mazda, fortunately a short one.

author: fintail
text:
That might be it, it's a distraction. Kind of like a bad crash - you can't help but look...look at the weird details, ignore the overall boredom.

Not even the dorky anime generation embraced those faces. There's a fine line.

author: stickguy
text:
when I was looking at the CX-5, they had one parked right next to a CX-7. Much different looking "face" on the new model.

The nagare style always reminded me of this (especially on the 3):

author: ateixeira
text:
Mazda tried too hard to create a family resemblance. I looked for a left over 2008 MX-5 rather than get a smiley face 2009.

The CX5 will be successful. It's the most efficient in a segment that is hot, and MPG is big right now. Today they just announced it's an IIHS Top Safety Pick and I doubt that will hurt.

I bet it outsells the CX7 2-to-1.

author: fintail
text: Hah, that's a good one...maybe a Mazda stylist took inspiration here

author: anythngbutgm
text:
A Toyota dealer last night to see if they had any FR-S but they did not.

On the other hand, they had 6 Prius C's and every single one of them had a "Sold" or "On Hold" tag.

Only one of them had a ton of options checked and rang up at $24,625... Not a bad looking little car once you add the alloys.

author: ateixeira
text:
That's a bit spendy ... buyers would be wise to do a little math. You can get a nice Fit or Fiesta for high teens. You can buy a lot of gas for that difference.

Fitzmall has 6-7 of them and they were $21-22k , which actually makes sense. You save about $6-800 per year per EPA's web site, so you'll actually make it up by the time you pay off your loan.

author: fintail
text: Friend of mine who wants to replaced a miled up Accord test drove a Prius C yesterday. He liked it. At his local dealer (ATL suburbs) it was the same story, all but one was loaded and with ~24K stickers. Looks better than the dorky normal Prius and the big one, anyway.

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw a pearl white one with the new gunmetal color option on the wheels - best looking color combo I've seen on the new one. Thumbs up.

Also saw a plain silver one and it didn't look nearly as good.

Another Camry, and 2 Prius Vs.

author: qbrozen
text:
I'm confused by their marketing campaign for that car. seems to me they are saying you have to be a dork to buy one. :confuse:

I'm not agreeing or disagreeing with that sentiment, I just don't get why they'd want to market it that way.

author: stever
text:
You can buy a lot of gas for that difference.

IHS Global Insight says gas could hit $8 a gallon by the first of next year. Alarmist but the pundit isn't an idiot either. (USA Today).

We may have to expand this discussion's title to "I spotted a NEW (insert make/model/bicycle/skateboard/city bus/ZipCar/golf car/electric scooter) today!"

author: texases
text:
That's a big 'what if' scenario. Certainly possible, but there's a difference between than and what will happen. Same kinds of predictions were made the last time gas made a runup. Also possible - drop in demand and/or reduction in tensions cause a price drop.

Who knows?

author: fintail
text: Maybe honest marketing? :shades:

author: fintail
text: If the tail that wags the dog gets their war, I could see it. Would create a low level economic collapse, too.

author: stever
text:
The stories will sure help sell a lot of Prii. Even some Volts.

Thought I saw a Smart car on the last leg home yesterday, but noted as it passed that it was another iQ.

Not long after that my wife had to brake hard to avoid three deer running across the road at midday. Two more were loitering on the shoulder ten minutes later. Even the minivan isn't big enough for smashing into one of those.

author: ateixeira
text:
We tend to reach equilibrium one way or another. The market corrects itself - gas jumps up, the economy slows, people drive less.

We haven't seen cheap gas in so long that many are putting a higher priority on MPG. Greedy oil barons may not have their cake and eat it this time.

author: stickguy
text:
well, I can say that MPG is a big consideration as my wife and I look for the next vehicle to replace the minivan. Within reason, that is.

If I really was concerned, we would be going even smaller to eke out better MPG (a mazda 3 hatch, maybe a Jetta wagon, or something small car like).

So we are still shopping in a class that overall does not get as good mileage (compact/midsize CUV), but within the class, there is a pretty big spread.

Right now, the mazda CX-5 is looking good. My wife also wants to scope out a CR-V. But something like a Highlander is out (too big and trucky anyway). As is the Pilot.

at year end when I get a car for myself that will likely come into play also, but not as much (since I likely will be buying used, and don't put on many miles).

author: ateixeira
text:
I like the CX5, too.

Wifey has a Forester, it's a good "medium", i.e. right-sized. Not too big, but not too small. The CX5 is close in size, so it should serve well all around.

The Sienna is huge, but we've used every bit of space it has. Plus I don't have to drive it in the city. Around here it feels big and clumsy, but out on the highway it's great - a smooth and comfy way to eat up the miles on long trips.

My MX-5 is definitely small. It's my daily/commuter.

I'm not sure which car I'll replace next. To be honest I'm happy with all of them. I'd like a more tolerant ride (the Miata has the big rims and sport suspension), but every time I think about trading I get a nice sunny day and that desire goes away.

We have had a GREAT spring for convertibles.

Back to NEW cars, I'd love to see a SkyActiv Miata. :shades:

author: fintail
text:
Local Lexus dealer still has a good 8-10 or more new GS on the lot - either there are no more "supply issues" to fall back on to defend weak sales, or these things aren't selling. Maybe customers are holding off until the newness declines and prices become negotiable.

Also saw a couple C coupes, a few new Camrys, and a Leaf that was filthy with a couple scrapes and a hood that apparently didn't latch correctly.

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw a GS on the road today.

February sales were up 587% for the model. Not bad...

Feb 2011 was pre-tsunami, too. For the next few months we should see huge gains across the board for Lexus.

author: anythngbutgm
text: Two of them over the weekend. I can see them selling well if the price of gas keeps going up this summer. For a basic city car for a single individual it's perfect. Gotta wonder what is going to happen to Smart sales tho...

author: fintail
text:
I haven't seen one driving yet, which is surprising as I live close to the dealer. What did they sell in Feb 11 - 20 units? The gain has to be massive...I'd have to question anyone who bought the old one at the end of the run, as it was so terribly outclassed and invisible compared to virtually every competitor.

Saw a trunkback Sonic today that wasn't a rental.

author: ateixeira
text:
Yeah, 11 sales are 1000% more than 1 sale, right?

GS seems to be building share, though, which is something its predecessor never did.

They won't exceed the class leaders but at least they would show up in a pie chart now.

author: fintail
text: I think the old one lost massively with each new year after the updated style, so there is only one way to go - up. The new one looks competitive - so it should put up a fight, especially if it can undercut just a little price-wise. Maybe there will be some good end year lease deals.

author: ateixeira
text:
Quick searches for press releases, let's see, the first February for the last model was 2006 and they sold 2049, and that includes hybrids+V6+V8. By 2007 it had cooled to 1563 sales, and by 2011 just 349. Ouch!

New one sold 2396 with just a V6 model. So it already beat the record for the last one by 20% with no hybrid out yet.

They will have to sustain those sales, though, with constant improvements, and maybe new model intros (hybrid, V8?).

A good start, though.

author: fintail
text:
I'd like to talk to those 349 people. Family of dealers or dealers themselves maybe? Seems fishy. I can't imagine a normal consumer who would want to go that way.

Hybrid is coming, but I bet there's a good chance there will be no V8.

author: tjc78
text:
I'd like to talk to those 349 people.

Some people have no idea of upcoming models. They walk into the dealership and buy what they see.

The previous gen GS might not have been a class leader, or heck even relevant compared to the competition, but to most people it still was/is a really nice car.

author: ateixeira
text:
I think once the new IS arrives, they should put a V8 in the GS. Even if it's a low volume GS-F.

If you look at the volume models in the segment, they offer multiple engine options and even wagon body styles. GS can only do so much with a pair of sedans.

author: fintail
text:
GS-F wouldn't have to just be a V8, but a completely tuned car - or it will be laughed at by the E63/M5/S-RS6. Might not be where Lexus wants to go, and I think the market is slowly moving away from V8s in those cars anyway - V8 cars in the competition are less and less common over time. W212 E550 and 550i are seldom seen, where in the past V8 E and 5 were much more common.

The competition does have more styles, something Lexus hasn't traditionally done for any model. That won't be happening. GS will likely be just the 6 and the hybrid - if a V8 does come around I'd wager it is no more than 5% of sales.

author: fintail
text:
I guess non-car people buy cars too. I could see my mother buying one if she had that kind of cash.

349 sounds more like a yearly sales total for the end of that line. It just got overwhelmed, where even when new it didn't exceed.

author: ateixeira
text: It becomes a tough call, near-lux customers seem to be accepting turbo 4s, would a blown V6 make more sense, perhaps?

author: fintail
text:
A lot can be done with a 6, and there's not a lot of need for a V8 these days anyway (my next car probably won't be one)...they could make a "super" 6, but if they go the F route with that, they better be careful, as it will be compared to other tuned cars, and won't match up.

I don't see Lexus even doing that though. The new GS is a fine car and will sell well, competition won't be redone for several years yet, so it won't be quite as tight as the previous model.

author: ateixeira
text:
I think they need to avoid what happened to Acura - no V8 flagship meant a sinking image.

They have the LS, though. Plus they try to pitch the hybrid as more than a V6, but a lot of people (myself included) have trouble seeing it that way, since it's heavy.

To date hybrid+economy has worked, hybrid+performance has not worked. I'm not convinced the GS will change that trend.

author: fintail
text:
Is the updated high tech RL even made anymore? I've seen used ones for like 15K. It vanished.

Yeah, their hybrid is in a tough position, like it is for the white elephant LS600h. Minor performance improvement, negligible mileage gain, significant price jump. I don't think most will run for it. So far for GS stats I have seen something like 10% or so mileage gain, but similar price gain, and I doubt any better performance.

author: ateixeira
text:
Used RLs sell for roughly the same as used TLs. That's not OK.

Infiniti shook up the segment with the M hybrid, so Lexus had to respond if only to defend its turf.

We'll see how it shakes out, but to me "hybrid luxury" is still an oxymoron.

author: texases
text:
"Infiniti shook up the segment with the M hybrid"

I thought the LS600h came first.

author: fintail
text:
RL is a used bargain though, can get one that looks almost new for the price of a nicely equipped Rio. Should be dead reliable if not a bit bland. Bang for the buck.

I wonder what the take rate is on the M hybrid, even 10%? The old GS had a (non selling) hybrid variant too, so it's nothing new for them.

Hybrid luxury has to offer more than 1 extra mpg or .1 less 0-60 for less than 10K.

author: ateixeira
text:
The M was the first to make a legitimate attempt at being sporty, though. I believe it's significantly quicker than the M37 V6 model.

Usually the hybrid uses some fuel sipper Atkinson cycle version of the donor engine, de-tuned to get good MPG.

author: ateixeira
text: A pre-beak RL is a bargain, plus the Nav was pretty nice for its day and age (2005 IIRC?), one of the early systems with traffic data.

author: fintail
text: Correct on both counts. If I was used car shopping right now, I'd definitely take one for a drive. 300hp with AWD, looks that aren't exciting but have aged well, tech that isn't obsolete, high build quality and reliability, priced in the mid teens - this is why I don't like new cars.

author: ateixeira
text:
2005 w/84k miles for $16k, with SH-AWD.

That was a $50k car new. For less than 1/3rd the price of new, and it's got tons of life left in it.

I looked at these in '09 when my wife was shopping. She wanted a new car and you know what they say, happy wife happy life.

At least she picked a new car with very strong residual value.

author: fintail
text:
I say a couple other things - no wife happy life, or I have 99 problems but... :shades:

I bet you can get them even cheaper, too.

author: ateixeira
text:
That's asking price on a quick search. I'm sure you could do better.

Funny thing is back in 2009 they didn't cost a lot more than that - some were already under $20k.

author: fintail
text: Depreciation floor for the new style - slow to fall. One just a couple years older is worth half that, they go for nothing - but they are pretty old looking nowadays.

author: ateixeira
text:
Yeah, I think prices plunge when you first buy it, then they level off after a while.

For the cost of a Scion iQ I'd take the RL SH-AWD with 80k miles, yeah....

author: fintail
text: I bet you could find one with 50K or even less on it for 1K more. And that price is a base iQ - one I saw on the lot here was over 20K! Bang for the buck is seldom brand new.

author: ateixeira
text: For that money get a Prius C at the same store. Bigger and more fuel efficient, so you're not really making any trade offs, either.

author: fintail
text:
Nor would you be forced to take on a few grand worth of mandatory "optional" accessories - although from what I hear, a base Prius C is pretty rare too.

Smart failed at something like 12K, can't see how the iQ will cut it for much more.

author: ateixeira
text:
I thought the ForTwo was more like $16k? Maybe that's how they all came equipped. Worst transmission I've ever sampled.

http://fitzmall.com/ has 4 iQs but they're all $16.2-16.4k, so probably un-customized.

Even at that price a Yaris makes so much more sense.

author: fintail
text:
I think base sticker was 12-13 at most. Probably like some other cars, hard to find a base one, dealers want the profit margins.

Now that we are finally getting decent enough small cars - all of them from all makers seem to be much improved, buying a tiny city car like a Smart or iQ is only for image or if you really need the smaller footprint - as the normal car often has just as good mileage, not to mention comfort and practicality.

author: texases
text:
The 'Pure' smart was $12.5k base, the 'Passion' about $14.5k...not that I'd have much 'passion' for that...

Of course dealers were asking $22k+ in the 'good old days'. :sick:

author: ateixeira
text:
These are trendy cars that probably make sense for a small business owner to advertise on the cars with those huge stick-on banners. They certainly get attention.

Most ForTwos I've seen were that way, some small business plastered on the side.

Today's sub-compacts are actually decent cars, though. Direct injection engines and more features than an 80s luxury car, they're not the wheezy econoboxes I saw back in college. Remember the 4 on the floor, vinyl seats, and passenger side mirror optional?

Kids these days...they have it good!

author: fintail
text:
I remember a local "green car" dealer was grey market importing them and asking like 25-27K! This was back around when the housing market peaked too - maybe not unconnected.

Of course, back in the summer of 2000 people were paying that for loaded PT Cruisers, too.

author: fintail
text:
Pretty sad when a car's most viable use is as a tax write off.

The good old days aren't always good...music and movies were better then anyway :shades:

author: ateixeira
text: Hunger Games was good. :shades:

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Not that it is a new vehicle anymore... but rather has become a rare sighting nowadays.

Is there something going on with these things? When they first came out, I saw them all over the place, now I rarely see one in an entire week! :confuse:

author: fintail
text: Saw a white Rolls Ghost today (driving pretty fast, probably in the 0.1% who doesn't have to observe any laws) and 2x new 5ers.

author: fintail
text: This morning saw a Veloster, 2 new unplated Passats, and 3 recently plated base model cloth rental 300s.

author: lemko
text: ...black and gold Shelby GT-H Mustang at Levick and Bingham in NE Philly.

author: stickguy
text: saw a temp tag Veloster on the turnpike last weekend. early middle aged couple driving it (say, early 30s?) I actually kind of like it, then again, I really like the Kia Soul too!

author: texases
text:
"early middle aged couple driving it (say, early 30s?)"

No WAY am I asking you to describe me! Early 30s = middle age?

author: stickguy
text:
you don't even want to know what that makes me.

What you would call them then? Not kids (that they target these cars to), but not old farts (that actually end up buying them).

author: fintail
text: Saw a W12 A8 this morning, whoa

author: lemko
text: Aren't those W-engines fiendishly complex?

author: texases
text:
"Aren't those W-engines fiendishly complex? "

Maybe not as bad as you'd think, the W-12 is basically two of the VW VR-6 engines on a common crankshaft. Amazing how many engines that VR-6 has spawned...

author: fintail
text: The entire car is insanely complex, and I think that highline model bases around 140K. It'll be fun as a 10 year old worth 10K - no deferred maintenance risks there.

author: lemko
text: ...somebody at work bought a new dark red Chevrolet Volt.

author: fintail
text:
Not new, but I gotta vent.

I got behind one of these catastrophes today:



And I have to think, it's not evolution, but devolution, when this is what came first:

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw a Toyota Harrier. Right hand drive to boot!

Also a Lexus GX Toyota Land Cruiser Prado.

Never seen this before - Toyota Allion sedan. A tad smaller than a Corolla.

Also saw a Nissan Skyline (Infiniti G).

Hint: I flew direct, so it's less than 4 hours from DC.

author: hoosiergrandad

Too bad they didn't do it right and turn the drive train around and put it behind the seats. IMO two-seat roadsters should have their drive wheels in back.

Entry level Audi/BMW/Lexus/Mercedes test drives.

author: andys120
text:
I road in a Miniand it was like riding in an old truck

Depends on what you're used to I guess. The combination of very short wheelbase and sporty suspension will cause ride motions that you won't find in larger cars but I found the ride of a Cooper S on frost-heaved NH roads quite acceptable, in fact better than most of the SUVs and Pickups I've been in.

author: fintail
text:
Saw an Equus parked at Costco today, which somehow makes sense - if Costco sold their own brand of luxury car, I could see it being that thing. They also had a dorky looking Mini coupe on the "new car" display as you exit.

Visited a few dealers - MB dealer was very sparse, only a couple of each model on the lot, either sales are amazing or stock is in short supply. BMW and Audi dealers had more, saw a gorgeous loaded A8 (which made the normal A8s beside it look invisible) and a few new 3ers and many leftover 11 3ers along with several 6ers which seem to have been there for ages, nothing else unusual. Lexus dealer has a ton of CTs and new GSs, so they aren't in short supply. Scion dealer had a base ~16K iQ along with a couple wearing the 4K "Axis" (seriously) package, Toyota dealer had nothing remarkable but a ton of new Camrys. Saw a new diesel Passat being taken for a test drive, Subaru dealer had a couple new Imprezas. Jag/Rover dealer had nothing odd but an Evoque that I think was acting funny - I walked up to it and the mirrors retracted, and I could see the instrument lights came on. Dealership was closed. I heard it do that again as I walked away - and further back on the lot a Range Rover alarm was going off. British electrics?

author: lemko
text: Saw the Equus' other extreme today - white Hyundai Accent travelling north on Bingham Street near Borbeck in NE Philly.

author: fintail
text: Friend of mine is in LA, called me to say he got a 4K mile Accent as a $15/day rental from some off brand company.

author: anythngbutgm

author: fintail
text:
Look for barcodes...they are becoming staples in the "premium" rental segment, especially now that the Panthers are dead.

This morning saw a new trunkback Versa which still looks bad to me, and a new 7er driving with all the windows down...yeah, new car smell, yuck.

author: robr2
text: ...Ford Taurus in police spec and B&W paint scheme. Was in my town but was a cruiser from a city that borders Boston.

author: ateixeira

What happens when a Honda Crosstour and a BMW X6 have a child out of wedlock? Look below... lol.

2013 Honda Crosstour


BMW X6

Odie

author: fintail
text: It's hideous, like a big fat parody of the normal car. Q7 DNA, I think. Should sell well to the gilded age new rich in this devolving society, sure to be a huge hit in China, Arabian peninsula, maybe Vancouver, Moscow, etc.

author: qbrozen
text: We already know I'm a bit odd... so I kind of like it. I mean... it will be FAR better after I lower it and put car-sized wheels/tires on it.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Spent some time with the new Acura RDX yesterday and I walked away pretty impressed. The salesperson we spoke with was highly informed, thorough and answered all of my questions to "T". We went through all the features, even down to the standard stuff like the cupholders and then without any sort of pressure, handed the keys for a test drive. They grabbed a copy of my liscence and we were off...

The Drive: Being based on the CR-V I was expecting a lot of the roots to show through clearly, but I was surprised at how quiet and refined the RDX was. Having owned a 2003 MDX which my wife loved outside of the gas mileage, the engine was familiar, the interior layout, seat comfort (very good btw, not Volvo but close) was all very familiar. What was nice was while the MDX felt like an elephant on the road, the RDX was a very comfortable size. More like driving a Toyota RAV4.

The ride was fantastic, soaked up bumps like a champ and there was handly an upset in the chassis. This is one of the big things I look for when buying, I hate having to make severe corrections to a vehicle after rebounding from a pothole, bump, etc...

The engine was straight out of our old MDX, and in the RDX, it was smooth quiet and gutsy. Not once did I have to put the pedal to the floor to merge or pass other cars. a little kick and it would drop a gear and accelerate with plenty of gusto, never needing that extra kick down to an even lower gear ratio. The transmission is all new, a 6 Speed auto with paddles (that I didn't use). Put it in Auto and it accelerated with ease, although the thing didn't feel like a rocket like I was expecting. Quick but not blistering. The RAV4 V6 will waste it off the line and highway passing, but then again it weighs probably 300 - 400 lbs less.

One note about Honda autos that I don't like. I don't know if anyone else notices this, but for some reason Honda's V6 drivetrains always feel like they are being "held back". It's really hard to explain, but it almost feels like the thing is carrying a 2000 lb load behind it. Sorta strained I guess, but more like re-strained as in engineered for strength rather than lithe...

Oh and the tech... This one was a loaded AWD with the tech package. Pretty neat features including a 3-view backup camera (probably used on other makes as well but it was cool). The ELS sound, my gosh... Incredible. Even in a Crossover the bass response, the clarity, the crispness... Fantastic. But as other reviews have mentioned ,there is no Blind spot detection (I could care less about that one), adaptive cruise (I never use Cruise) pre-crash stuff, found in those German makes. But I was not really phased (again I never use the stuff = wouldn't really miss it )

Lastly, it all came down to the looks. And... well... Meh. Not bad, but not stunning either. I feel like most Acuras nowadays you don't really "arrive" rather than "just show up". There was no elegance, no "presence" and certainly no attitude. It was just a decent looking, no frills, bubbly, soft roader with tall, skinny, boring wheels and forgettable style. Interior was definitely the high point with it.

In the end, I walked. I wasn't really planning on buying but I was interested in checking it out thoroughly. And did walk away mostly impressed. For the money it's a compelling choice against rivals like the X3, Q5, GLK (maybe) or Infiniti EX. But my top pick in this price is still the XC60...

Unless, you spring for a non-tech which lowers the price by a couple of grand, well under the Bimmer and the Audi and right in line with the deals Infiniti is giving to move their slow selling EX.

But in the end, it is not a vehicle I really aspire to own... Nice, but...

My .02

author: stickguy
text: at least from the pictures I have seen, it looks just like the CRV to me (from profile). I am sure the front view is nicely uglified over the Honda.

author: ateixeira
text:
They ditched the one thing that stood out to me - the SH-AWD. It now shares a more basic AWD system with the CR-V.

So think of it as a V6 CR-V.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
I think they are looking to mirror the Lexus RX/Toyota Highlander business model, only under cut the both of them in price/content.

BTW, the handling was pretty good in the new RDX. But I don't think buyers in this class cared about handling in the first place. Mileage is the priority now and 28mpg (FWD) and 27mpg (AWD) highway numbers are a few ticks better than the RX and with more hp to boot.

I see the Lexus RX as the RDX's most direct competition.

author: ateixeira
text: For a big V6 that mpg is indeed quite good.

author: anythngbutgm
text: Shoot, that engine in my old MDX was lucky to get 20mpg! That was with required Premium fuel too.

author: ateixeira
text:
Is it required for the RDX? Or just recommended.

Premium fuel economy is an oxymoron.

author: anythngbutgm
text: The salesperson told me it is only recommended this time around.

author: ateixeira
text:
Buddy pulled up in one of those dark bronze-colored Venzas. Loaded up V6 model.

Replaces an unreliable Touareg.

author: fintail
text:
Is he an active boomer? :shades:

New Mazda 3 popped up in a spot a couple down from me in my building's garage. Woman who parks there had a 98-02 style 626 - she needs a smaller car. Seeing her park was always laughable, she'd make it a 5 or 6 point affair trying to park nose-in. I can park both of my cars, backing in, in one step, in the modern car I don't even look back more than once, just using the mirrors.

author: ateixeira
text:
In his 50s, less active nowadays.

I back up my van so I know what you mean. Backup cam helps since you can't see anything below 4' or so.

Speaking of the Mazda3 ... saw a new white one, with the much-improved front fascia. The smiley face is all but gone. Much, much better.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
From what I gather you can score leftover 2011's pretty cheap. Guy here at work bought a decked out one that stickered for 38 and change.

Walked away with it for 33... :surprise:

author: ateixeira
text:
Still, 33k is a lot of dough for a Camry wagon in drag.

And that's coming from a Toyota owner.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Sorry, forgot to include that he rolled in the sales tax in the purchase price (Didn't get into the nitty gritty details about it).

Little pricey, maybe but this thing is decked out to the gills and has AWD, something even the most decked out Camry doesn't offer.

I also consider the Venza to be more like an Avalon wagon than a Camry. That huge glass roof and the spacious interior I think elevate its status, at least in Limited form which I think his is...

author: texases
text:
"Still, 33k is a lot of dough for a Camry wagon in drag."

I imagine you can option a Camry up to $33k. And it's that or a Highlander, I'd go for the Venza (no use for a tight 3rd row).

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Also, consider the Outback H6 ($35 large with similar equipment) or the Volvo XC70 T6 which can break into the 40's after you grab the comparable options, I'd say the Venza at that price is reasonable.

But MSRP? No way...

author: fintail
text:
Sounds like the type shown in the marketing propaganda. But I'd take a Venza over a Highlander, too.

I've seen a few rental Mazda 5s with the overdone side detailing in the past few days.

author: ateixeira
text:
Wow, 33k ain't much nowadays.

I just looked and a loaded Outback is $33.4k, with tax $35.4k here in MD.

I guess that is a good price. I'd compare the price of a Crosstour but unfortunately I'm not blind.

author: odie6l
text:
I wish I could have gotten a picture of it, but I saw a Venza with the fake vinyl roofing done to it. it was classy, yet hideous all at the same time.

Odie

author: berri
text: I'd probably go with the Highlander. For very little more out the door you get more room and better trade value down the road. For better or worse, depending on your perspective, the US market has moved away from wagons.

author: texases
text: We looked at the Highlander, but were turned off by the interior, just seemed kind of plasticky. No Venza was available at that time, but the ones I've sat in since have a classier interior, IMHO.

author: explorerx4
text: Lot's of Bimmers. A black Fiat 500. Audi A7(nice!)

author: berri
text: I think you're smart to drive them back to back. I haven't seen the 13 Venza, but the only problem I saw on the previous model was driver's legroom was a bit tight if you're a six footer. Highlander also needs to get a six speed auto like the competition. Even though its smaller than an Explorer or Traverse, it's current AWD EPA gas mileage isn't much different.

author: ateixeira
text:
fake vinyl roofing

And probably a retiree inside.

I've heard them marketed as "simulated convertibles", LOL. As a convertible owner the last thing I want is a top-UP look on a car.

Inside the Venza is nicer than the Highlander for sure, but I'd still opt for the extra cargo space of the HL if I had to choose between the two. Sienna crushes both - tons more space and you really don't sacrifice much dynamically, and it actually cost less back in 2007.

author: lemko
text:
Red Nissan Versa.
Silver Ford Focus.
Red Nissan Cube.
Silver Honda Insight.

author: kyfdx
text:
I don't think the Focus is a subcompact.... that would be the Fiesta.

I really like the 5-door hatchback version.... it's a nice looking vehicle!

author: ateixeira
text: I like Ford's new styling themes. Fiesta, Focus, and especially the upcoming Fusion. Even the new Escape looks nice.

author: odie6l
text:
I've seen my first iQ (I pronounce it ICK) out on the road. Thought the little old lady was going to have a heart attack when me in "The Beast" and a Excursion pulled up on each side of her.

Odie

author: fintail
text: Ick...that's great. I've only seen one base model, the loaded ones on the lot for 20K seem like the worst way imaginable to spend such money, you can get a proper car that gets similar mileage for no more.

author: fushigi
text:
I just looked and a loaded Outback is $33.4k, with tax $35.4k here in MD.

From the Subaru site:
Outback 3.6R Limited w/sunroof & navi = $35.4K + tax.
Add a trailer hitch, mud flaps, and a couple other accessories and I'm at $36.9K + tax for how I'd equip it. And that's still not "fully" loaded.

Two and a half years ago when I bought my Outlander the Outback was considered but the price took it off my list.

My next door neighbor has a Cross-eyed-tour. And he loves it. :sick:

author: qbrozen
text: first one I've spotted (or noticed). Its actually far far better looking than the standard Prius. This one was black with temp tag. It is quite small, though.

author: ateixeira
text:
I wasn't using MSRP - a local dealer has no-haggle prices, so I picked their most expensive Outback in stock.

Much smaller discounts than the Venza...then again it's selling well so maybe they don't need to give 'em away.

author: ateixeira
text:
I think so, too, plus it's some 500 lbs lighter. It uses a smaller battery pack and is a lot shorter. Makes sense for a city car.

I saw one, to, in bright orange. Toyota calls the color "habanero" as in the pepper.

author: fintail
text: Saw a loaded Optima hybrid today, with brand new temporary registration, and a new E wagon, the latter of which somehow to me reeks more of money than a new S-class.

author: ateixeira
text: I saw it's Hyundai clone (also hybrid).

author: kyfdx
text: Wow!

author: fintail
text: Saw an iQ on the road today, a nice A7, and a facelift Taurus.

author: tjc78
text: Saw a whole truckload of the new Infiniti SUV (JX?) on the road yesterday. Looks nice, but the front grill may be a tad much.

author: ateixeira
text:
Pathfinder will be a toned-down clone for less.

They ditched the body-on-frame and went with the mainstream unibody competitors. One look at sales, and you can't blame 'em.

Nissan has about a billion unibody crossovers now, though - Juke, Rogue, Murano, Pathfinder, EX, JX, FX, did I get 'em all?

To me the funny thing is the JX costs less than the FX despite being a lot bigger.

author: fintail
text: Visited the local MB dealer yesterday - a few oddities on the lot. E Bluetec without sport package, which is less common. Well optioned CL63, 166K sticker, didn't care for the white on black scheme. Nicely equipped E wagon, wheel package and pano among other niceties. And the oddball of the lot was a new style ML63, loaded, designo, something like 105K. Ludicrously expensive, very rare with the options.

author: ateixeira
text:
First for me...I'm sure I'll be seeing a lot of these as I'm only about 2 miles from an Infiniti dealer.

Also spotted another Prius c.

author: fintail
text: Oh yeah, also got behind a Fiesta - barely seeing any of these, maybe not surprisingly as a similar Focus can be had for very little more Refreshingly, in my area anyway, very few of the awkward trunkback Focus too, the hatch has won.

author: ateixeira
text: Love the 5 door's styling. Best in class vote from me.

author: fintail
text:
It's so European, pleasant surprise it has been accepted here.

My sister has an 04 ZX5 that I think she's miled up to about 160K now, almost trouble free.

author: ateixeira
text: My little brother has a sedan in Brazil, bought used and still going strong. No idea how many KMs.

author: robr2
text:
Got to ride in one yesterday - it's my Dad's new car.

EX - Twilight blue. Perfect for the folks - easy entry/exit, economical and I expect mind numbingly reliable. It's their 3rd CRV.

author: berri
text: Those Honda CRV's hold their resale value very well.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Spotted a black Nissan Murano Cabrio on Sunday. Top up, ugly as ever. Even with the matching top...

Also a new JX in a neighborhood in town. Driven by a younger looking couple, car seat in the back.

Then there is the invasion of new CR-V's... Wow.

author: ateixeira
text:
Another new new Beetle, black with tinted out windows.

I know they want us to think it's manlier, but I'd say less girly instead.

Also saw a Mazda2. They very badly need SkyActiv on that model, it's still very rare, yet I see the Mazda3 all over the place.

New Impreza sedan at Home Depot. Odd - for the first time ever, I think the sedan looks better than the wagon/hatch. I'm a 5 door kinda guy, too.

author: fintail
text:
Funny I mentioned the Focus trunkback yesterday - saw 2 this morning, but at least one was a rental.

I've seen a Fisker Karma every day since Sunday, too - a dealer just opened several blocks from me, I suspect they are being driven just to get exposure.

I agree about the Beetle being less girly rather than manly, and about the Impreza sedan too, it is actually a fairly nice looking car. The rear end of the hatch seems too blocky or something.

author: ateixeira
text:
The concept was gorgeous, lemme find it...

http://www.thetorquereport.com/subaru_impreza_design_concept_5.jpg

I expected changes like a higher roof line and door handles and mirrors, but I was hoping they'd keep it closer to that design.

The hatch is chunkier.

author: fintail
text: Not even really a concept, just cgi. The Japanese makes are pretty good at wooing us with cool ideas then blanding it up a bit when reality sets in.

author: ateixeira
text:
First one that I noticed at least. Didn't realize these were out.

Another CR-V.

Camry SE.

author: stickguy
text:
anyone anxiously waiting for something new to show up to take a look at?

At this point, I really want to see the new Escape (This month? June?), the Dart (June) and Santa Fe (probably September). I think though that is all of the pending stuff that I have an interest in seeing, for a practical reason, other than seeing something new!

Only found out yesterday that the Santa Fe is going to come in 2 models (standard 5 seats with 4 cyl power, and a stretched 3 row model with V6).

author: tjc78
text:
About the only thing I am interested in seeing is the new Avalon. From the pics so far the front end looks like crap, but you never know until you see the real thing.

The new Sante Fe may be a candidate for the Fianc but she told me she doesn't want another Hyundai.

author: stever
text:
the Santa Fe is going to come in 2 models

Yeah, the Santa Fe Sport is the original Santa Fe. The 2013 Santa Fe is the old Veracruz, 3 rows only.

I think....

author: stickguy
text:
pretty much. Both old models are being replaced, and I am pretty sure it is really just a stretch job (think tahoe and suburban).

different engines too. I am interested in seeing the sport with the 4cy turbo motot. Should be a good compromise.

author: stever
text:
I'm not sure I agree with the naming convention.

Kind of like a Mitsu Montero and Montero Sport. Just breeds confusion. Lots of people say Jeep Cherokee when they really mean Grand Cherokee but at least the Cherokee is defunct now the Liberty.

author: ateixeira
text:
I would consider the 3-row Santa Fe if I had to replace the minivan right now (not that I'm looking).

The new Sienna suffered cost cutting, the Ody is ugly, the Quest is small, the Kia is dated, the Dodge was only half-updated.

There's no van out there now that appeals to me, plus the Hyundai gets way better gas mileage than any of them, costs less, and looks better.

What I'd like to see is for Kia to hit a home run with the Sedona replacement, I really liked the KV7 concept:

http://www.insideline.com/kia/kia-kv7-concept-2011-detroit-auto-show.html

Not that it would look like that, but still...

author: ateixeira
text: Another one, still kind of rare in DC, though.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Not one but 2 new Mazda CX-5's. Guess it breaks up the monotony of all the CR-V's...

Brand new Mercedes SL roaring down the highway, I believe it was a decked out AMG. Mean looking but the front overhang is really pronounced with the redesign.

Oh and another not so common sighting, a new Z4 in Blue. Twin turbo version.

author: stever
text:
Well, as much as I love them, vans never have been especially good looking. Just functional. I like the styling of the Caravans best, but could live with a slab sided Odyssey just fine.

I remember seeing the KV7 concept at the Detroit show, but the door was a killer. Be good for keeping the rain off but not so good in the garage and I don't know why they bothered with them even on a concept. Liked it enough to take a pic of it though:



Next big thing for a minivan would be pocket doors. Hide the gas filler cap behind one of the taillights.

Maybe the VW Bus concept will reappear and they'll dump the Routan.

author: ateixeira
text: No way would the doors make production, but the overall shape hopefully would. That plus a DI engine and much improved MPG/range.

author: tjc78
text:
I like the styling of the Caravans best

The early 90s Caravans always cracked me up.

You could go from this disaster:


To this, IMO pretty decent looking (at the time) trim level:

author: fintail
text: My dad had a Grand Caravan, I think a 93. It was a medium blue with multi spoked hubcaps (I think) that did a fair impersonation of wheels. It had no troubles, but was traded for a T&C in 97 or 98, that one ate a transmission early on.

author: stever
text:
My first one was an '89 Voyager shaped like that, sans the fake wood trim. Still about my favorite shape, even though it only had one slider and the sliding door track wasn't hidden. Had real rain gutters though.

The more curvy ones in purple (aka eggplants) weren't my favorites. Did like the curvy Previas but couldn't afford one when they came out. Otherwise I might still be driving one.

author: lemko
text: My Dad had one of these back in the day. It was more or less a Ford Ranger truck underneath:

author: tjc78
text: Someone in our family had one of those. I remember riding in it as a kid and you could plug headphones into jacks in the back and change the station. It must have been pretty loaded up for the time.

author: lemko
text: My Dad's van was like that too! Funny how he got a minivan at the time both my brother and I were already out of the house and my sister was a freshman in high school.

author: stever
text:
Lots of those were good runners but drove more like a truck. Could get them in 4WD too. And access to the engine was okay, if you didn't mind crawling around the seats to get to part of it.

In topical news, I saw a new...oh what am I saying, until the tourists get here in a few more weeks I'm not seeing anything new. :-)

author: fintail
text: Not new, but saw a Ferrari 612 today. Also a new E wagon with pano.

author: ateixeira
text:
Top was down, which surprised me. Then he put it up, which surprised me even more, given it's a nice day. We were not near any garage yet, so odd.

Also saw a 5 door Focus.

Then saw a new Impreza Sport. Don't say "Outback Sport" any more. Do like the dark gray wheels.

author: ateixeira
text:
A dealer sponsored this event so I saw:

Sonic in that nuclear orange.

Cruze LT loaded up with 18"s and stickering for $27k.

Equinox facing a new CR-V. 'nox wins exterior, Honda wins interior.

Acura RDX - nice inside but $38k, didn't an MDX used to cost that?

Camaro convertible - white with orangish/red stripes.

Fiat 500C - white with red top. Too small and when I sat in it, didn't feel like a convertible at all. Way too enclosed for me, so it's officially off my shopping list.

Dealer-modded Jeep Wrangler Unlimited, it had a lift kit, big wheels and tires, fender flares, and a $43k sticker price. LOL.

No Malibu Eco oddly.

author: tjc78
text:
Cruze LT loaded up with 18"s and stickering for $27k.

Does a Cruze really need 18s? Also, at 27K there are some serious mid-size contenders. Camry SE 4cyl comes to mind.

author: ateixeira
text:
No, 18"s are ridiculous. There was almost no sidewall at all. The ride can't possibly be tolerable.

I can remember when Chevy toted the 17" on a Corvette.

This was fairly loaded, so a similarly equipped mid-sizer would probably be low 30s. Plus I'm sure it would carry a street price around $24-25k.

Lemme look...

OK, first a correction, must've been an LTZ, not just LT.

Yeah, sticker in the low 27s carries a street price of $25.5k.

Not too bad I guess. But these make much more sense:

base LS: $16,810 (that's not the 1.4T though)
ECO: $19,483

Prices from fitzmall.com.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Woman at the gym I go to has a BMW 1-series "E-drive".

I had to do some research on this one. Seems that BMW only built 700 of them so it is ultra rare.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Another CX-5, this one black, base model with a stick.

Couple of new Acura RDX's. One red, one white.

Mercedes CL550 coupe.

Aston Martin Vantage convertible.

very sharp Volvo S60 R-design in Black. Volvo really knows how to style a car, this thing was damn sexy for a sedan.

author: kyfdx
text:
Electric?

Do you live in the NorthEast?

author: anythngbutgm
text: Yes.

author: ateixeira
text:
In Black.

Doesn't stand out the way that traffic-cone-orange color does.

They look much more conventional than the regular Prius. Even down to the shifter. Also 500 lbs lighter, supposedly.

Decent little city car.

author: robr2
text:
Woman at the gym I go to has a BMW 1-series "E-drive".

I had to do some research on this one. Seems that BMW only built 700 of them so it is ultra rare.

I saw one yesterday as well in the Chateau Restaurant parking lot in Waltham, MA. White with all IC graphics.

author: lemko
text: ...black Chevrolet Sonic near Knorr and Rising Sun Avenue in NE Philly.

author: kyfdx
text:
You had to apply to get one, I think... sort of like when the MINI - E, came out... early adopters only, need apply.. leases only, too, I think.

I think it was restricted to the NE and California..

author: qbrozen
text: I think some dealers may have been skirting that. Freehold BMW (NJ) had one out front a couple of weeks ago when I drove past. (unless it was a customer's car they were using for advertising till it was retrieved.)

author: kyfdx
text:
Yeah... I may be thinking of the MINI - E, that had the application process...

I'm often wrong... lol

author: robr2
text:
The BMW ActiveE is being called a field trial. 700 vehicles leased for 2 years at $499 a month and the drivers report back their findings through on board telematics and smart phones.

New York, Boston, LA, San Diego, San Francisco and Sacramento are the test areas.

It's a 100% electric with lithium ion batteries.

author: explorerx4
text: I'm pretty sure Hartford, CT was on the list too.

author: lemmer
text: Somebody that lives very close to me has decided to make a Nissan GTR their daily driver. I see it constantly.

author: robr2
text:
Saw at the dealer this AM an all black Explorer PI with dealer plates. Looks mean and scary.

Changes I could see were the 18" steel wheels, Explorer labels deleted, shifter moved from console to columna and the rear seat deleted.

Based on the paperwork sitting on the front seat, looks like it's a show piece.

author: kyfdx
text: A friend of mine has ordered one.... ETA in August... :surprise:

author: ateixeira
text:
Plain silver color, I prefer their blue.

Looks better in person. Features don't seem as exaggerated as they look in photos.

author: ateixeira
text:
Losers (days' supply, from cars.com)

2012 Porsche Boxster: 250 days
2012 Infiniti M35h: 174 days
2012 Infiniti EX35: 134 days
2012 BMW 650i convertible: 128 days
2012 Nissan Murano CrossCabriolet: 120 days
2012 Volkswagen Eos: 115 days
2012 Mitsubishi Outlander: 115 days
2012 BMW 750Li xDrive: 114 days
2012 Nissan NV cargo van: 113 days
2012 BMW 640i coupe: 111 days

Boxster is low demand, but looks like they made way too many.

M35h - I'm guessing hybrid shopper don't even enter their store. Also the whole performance hybrid thing is an oxymoron since they're so heavy.

EX - told ya it's too small. It's new-ish, too, so that's really bad news.

CrossCabrio is also on there, looks like Nissan overestimated demand for ugly/expensive.

Source:

http://blogs.cars.com/kickingtires/2012/05/aprils-fastest-and-slowest-selling-ca- rs.html

author: tjc78
text:
I've seen exactly one Murano CC (thank God) and I didn't even know they still made the Eos.

The powers that be at the office actually looked at the Nissan NV, no comparison to a Sprinter.

I don't get those hybrid luxo-barges. I mean who are they kidding?

author: robr2
text:
The powers that be at the office actually looked at the Nissan NV, no comparison to a Sprinter.

I've been seeing more and more of these. They are ungainly but I think many small mom and pop shops are leery of the Sprinter. We here wouldn't blink at it but Mrs. Smith might not like the idea of her plumber showing up in a vehicle with a 3 pointed star on it.

I think the new T series from Ford will be the one that gets the Euro style van accepted into the US marketplace.

author: tjc78
text:
We are on our second Sprinter. The first one was a Dodge branded model and aside from a sensor or two it was bullet proof. The new one is Freightliner branded.

I had to take a trip in it once and I was amazed at the gas mileage. I can't remember exactly but it was low 20s at 75-80. It also was packed to the gills.

author: explorerx4
text:
I was just going to write that the most interesting thing I saw in my 1600 miles in 50 hours was a carrier loaded with 3 Interceptor Utilities.
1 was all black, the other 2 had white doors.

author: fintail
text:
Is the current Z-car direct injection? There's a 4 month old one that parks a couple spaces away from me, and it made terrible noises at cold start yesterday, if it isn't the DI clatter, something is wrong.

Saw a base looking new A6 this morning.

author: tjc78
text:
Is the current Z-car direct injection

Yes it is.

You should have heard my V6 Genesis at start up it was bad too. I had a co-worker who is into cars ask me if I was low on oil.

author: anythngbutgm
text: The wife's Outback rattles like a diesel upon startup. But I don't think it's DI, it's got to do with the SUL Emissions equipment on board. My Impreza with essentially the same motor doesn't make the same noises.

author: fintail
text:
That explains it. If either of my cars made that racket, I'd panic. I remember my rental Regal sounded clattery for the first few seconds, too. There must be some way to mask that noise.

A few new cars out at mid-day - saw a Veloster. a new MB badged Sprinter cargo van with a 36K "Costco member" MSRP, and a late model C-class in the nicest color - quartz blue.

author: ateixeira
text: Black one. They sell every one they can make, but gas prices are dipping so let's see if they can sustain the demand.

author: tjc78
text:
Funny thing is my DI Buick (3.6) doesn't clatter on startup. I was actually expecting it.

The Genesis clatter wasn't DI it had something to with the oil draining out of the top mounted filter and taking a few seconds to build pressure.

author: andys120
text:
I was at the Vintge car races at NH Speedway yesterday and a new Five Series parked next to me with a "535d" flash on the trunk, the front bore a plaque that read "BMW Advanced Diesel" in place of the front license plate.

All very curious since AFAIK there's no such model in the current BMW lineup.

author: bhill2
text:
All very curious since AFAIK there's no such model in the current BMW lineup.

Well, there isn't (so far) in the US, but there sure is in Europe. I wonder if BMW is planning to bring it in. I personally think that it should have been a no-brainer from the start.

author: kyfdx
text: Definitely driving distance from HQ in NJ... maybe, a corporate car for testing?

author: andys120
text:
Doh! I didn't make note of the tags but I think I'd have noticed if it had a Jersey "Mfr" plate.

Yeah, I should've said there's no 535d in the US lineup, I'm well aware there are lots of models we don't get here that are sold in Europe.

author: lemko
text: Red Hyundai Veloster on Borbeck Street between Rising Sun Avenue and Verree Road and blue Mustang GT convertible with the top down travelling east on Rhawn Street near Tabor in NE Philly.

author: ateixeira
text: I prefer the ones with dark gray wheels, the Sport models.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new (facelift) CL63 sitting way too high - these cars have adjustable suspension, either malfunction, or more likely, owner error. Looked goofy, like a big AWD coupe.

author: odie6l
text:
was it the sedan or the sport wagon version. the SW looks alot better than the sedan IMHO.

I saw one of the new CoD Wranglers today. Nice.

Odie

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Through the sea of new CRV's I spotted a couple of new Acura RDX's, one red, one granite and one in white. The white was actually a good color for the profile.

Also looks like Infniti may have a hit with the new JX. Saw a few of those as well.

author: fintail
text:
Saw 2 new X3 this morning, one with the silly body cladding. Also a Veloster, and a new style 5er debadged and with the full [non-permissible content removed]/mafia "blackout" package - black car with windows tinted to a point that has to be illegal, black headlights and taillights.

New CRVs are almost a daily sight here now. Also saw a Lexus CT doing loaner service, hope this doesn't mean sales are slow, as for loaners, the dealer previous used the hybrid HS250h hybrid h that barely anyone bought.

author: stickguy
text:
The CRV does hit a sweet spot for many people (which is why we might end up getting one!). Far from exciting, and no rocket, but it does a lot of things well (mpg/performance/comfort/etc.), and is a nice size (compact but plenty of room) and is loaded with neat features. Combine a reasonable (for a new car) price, and the Honda badge, and not surprising it is selling well.

my wife found it comfortable and nice to drive, and it felt "right" to her coming out of an Odyssey. Honda may have lost their way a bit lately, but they still know how to do ergonomics (at least when they keep the button count down).

author: fintail
text: Saw my second new GS on the road, a grey F-sport model, also a deformed new Nissan Quest (rental I am pretty sure) and a freshly plated Rio trunkback sedan.

author: ateixeira
text:
Wagon, I see far more wagons on the road, in fact saw another Impreza today.

Also saw a Leaf. Still rare here.

And a Veloster.

author: tjc78
text:
And a Veloster.

Been seeing more and more of them in my neck of the woods, guess they are selling well.

author: anythngbutgm
text: Seen a few of them on my highway commute. Funky styling, not sure if I like it. I still think the the front end with all the "Slits" makes the car look like it was in a knife fight... and lost.

author: ateixeira
text:
They've sold a bunch, though, and when you consider that it's basically an Accent underneath, for a lot more money...

and it hasn't hurt Accent sales...

and it hasn't hurt Rio sales...

I'm sure they've had to hire more accountants to count all the profits on that cash cow.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
The last remaining Swede seems to be getting a boost, sales-wise as I have been noticing a ton of S60's and new XC60's in my area. Both are very sharp looking cars IMO, although I think the front end styling works the best on the XC than it does on the S60.

Oh, and the XC90 seems to be a pretty long lasting vehicle as well, I see a ton of them on the road as well, most of them the older T-5 and 3.2 models. My wife and I were actually driving to the Cape last weekend and we were literally sharing the highway with (5) XC90's at the same time! I also looked over at the traffic heading the opposite direction adn saw (2) more at the same time...

I don't know if it is indicative of the overall state of Volvo at the moment, but I am glad to see they are still selling well as I have always really like the style and that minimalist Scandanvian interior sheme. :shades:

author: anythngbutgm
text:
For the past month or so, I have been passing the same guy almost daily driving a decked out Tiguan SEL. Gotta say, it is probably the most handsome of the "Cute utes" IMO. I like those flared 19's, it makes it look a bit brawier than a regular Tiggy.

Also, seeing a few more of those new Passats. I don't know... ya, it's a little more generic than the older Passats, but for some reason it just looks more solid and the details really make it a handsome vehicle, especially in Black when it's been detailed up.

Got passed by a CC yesterday as well. One of the best looking cars on the road IMO. At least in the under 40k pricepoint

author: ateixeira
text:
Wonder what that Tig cost, though. They really get up there.

I think the Q5 is much nicer looking, and of course costs more.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
I priced out an SEL and got it up around 35k with pretty much all the options. An SE would satisfy me though and that one rung in around 32k.

From what I gather, the new Escape can get into the middle thirties as well, so the price isn't unnusual.

I used to like the Q5, but the S-Line is really the only trim I like and that sucker is almost 50 grand :surprise: Yikes. I'd rather get an afformentioned XC60-T6 and 60 thousand miles of maintainence for 41-42 grand. I think the Q uses premium as well if I am not mistaken?

author: stickguy
text:
I don't care for them much, but I do really like the Kia Soul (and see quite a few of them).

And yes, I am way the heck older than their target demo, but that never stopped me before! Though my wife might have a cow if I brought one of them home.

author: kyfdx
text:
You can get an SEL with NAV .... up around $38K.. :surprise:
I like the way the 19" wheels look, but that's a crazy size for that size vehicle...

Saw a new Acura ZDX today.. they are not growing on me....

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Isn't that 38 grand number including the Dyna-Audio package tho? I don't know what is so special about it, but it's a 3 thousand dollar add-on which is why I didn't include it in my build.

Edit: Just noticed the upgraded Nav with touchscreen is in that price as well. Still the SEL Premium gets a Navi which is what I would get.

I do agree tho that 35 grand for a compact ute is a bit much.

author: ateixeira
text:
Premium fuel I'm sure....

Co-worker has one. They're quite nice, if a bit on the small side. She replaced her BMW X3 with one. Hubby has an Audi A8. They use the A8 for trips. She commutes to DC in her Q5.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Spotted a white one and then a Silver one at lunch today.

Then a White Fiat Abarth, are they on sale yet? :confuse:

author: fintail
text: A working woman in an Q5? Like a hen with teeth :shades:

author: robr2
text:
Then a White Fiat Abarth, are they on sale yet?

Yes they are.

author: ateixeira
text:
Even more rare - her X3 had a manual trans.

Only Lux CUV owning working woman who can drive stick in the whole world, pretty much.

author: fintail
text:
She must have been be quite a catch. Stereotypes are only 99% accurate I guess. Heck, my mother once had a Beetle with a Porsche 912 engine...now she drives a white Camry.

Saw a facelift Taurus today, I wager a rental.

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw a Leaf.

753 CR-Vs and 986 Camrys.

Old school - spotted one of those Olds Cutlass Supremes from the "this is not your father's Oldsmobile" era.

GM really missed with those GM10s. A big, FWD 2 door when everybody pretty much wanted the exact opposite.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
753 CR-Vs and 986 Camrys.

lol, You beat my score by a dozen Camry's but I think I've seen a hundred more CR-V's than you

author: ateixeira
text:
Camry may take a hit as Nissan is dumping Altimas now big time.

Heard an ad for a local dealer, $19,999 plus freight for a Camry, but the Altima was $16,999. Same dealer, too.

Talk about a bargain....they've gotta be losing money at $17k.

author: stever
text:
Guess they are blowing Altimas out because the redesigned 2013s go on sale on June 26. $22,280 plus $780 destination for the base.

Redone 2013 Nissan Altima pricing, sale date, details (USA Today)

$17k is cheap.

author: ateixeira
text:
For sure, and the new one is supposed to get a 37mpg rating, which will make consumers go wild.

Scratch that, gas is almost free again. They won't care until the next time gas prices spike (consumers are naive and think short-term).

$17k plus freight and $89 processing, IIRC. Still dirt cheap. Those are big sedans.

My buddy in Annapolis has one. The seat's way too low for my tastes, hard to get in and out of. The CVT is actually good, Nissan should teach other companies how to get those right. His stereo is also quite good, and it's not even a loaded model. Decent car overall and a real bargain at that price.

author: ateixeira
text:
There's boxy, and then there are boxes.

The Nissan NV is a box. It could be the box a Leaf came in.

These things make 60s Dodge vans seem downright sexy!

author: anythngbutgm
text:
One thing that is lacking in the Camry that I was really surprised about was the headroom, especially with the moonroof. Otherwise, it was a solid, well built car and a notch or 2 above the Altima IMO. It's probably the first Camry interior that I have actually been Wowed by in my life.

But buyers will probably overlook that if it comes down to the pricetag.

author: kyfdx
text: That's what we rented to go to New Orleans.. averaged 30 mpg at pretty quick speeds...

author: kyfdx
text:
Jag XK-R in black with tinted windows... really sharp.

New Lexus GS350 F-sport model.. Not bad looking... sportier than an Infiniti....

author: fintail
text: Saw another GS F-sport model too, this one white.

author: ateixeira
text: With the air scarf thing, looks a bit odd when deployed but I get that it's functional.

author: berri
text:
One thing that is lacking in the Camry that I was really surprised about was the headroom

That is a serious deficiency I've noticed on several Toyota's since I'm over 6ft tall. I can't get comfortable with the sunroof, so it precludes me from considering something like a Camry other than the base models since leather requires a sunroof. Base model Toyota's sometimes seem a bit short in thigh support as well on longer drives. I've also found some of the Ford's lack legroom for taller drivers. Luckily, there are lots of choices out there, so it pays to test drive thoroughly or rent before you buy.

author: ateixeira
text:
A working woman in an Q5?

Just saw her, she showed me a receipt for a brake job: $978.

Ridiculous. It's 2 years old with 16k miles, a grand for brakes already?

No wonder they need 2 incomes.

Edit: IIRC front pads for my NA Miata were under $20. Later a rebuilt rear caliper was $30 something. I guess Hans needed to make the next boat payment.

author: tjc78
text:
she showed me a receipt for a brake job: $978.

Things like this make me very aware that I will never own a German car.

I know that there is a possibly the dealer is very expensive and replaced more than necessary, but still. :confuse:

author: ateixeira
text: Check my edits for Miata brake parts prices...

author: texases
text: Audi pads + Audi rotors + Audi labor? $1k, easy!

author: anythngbutgm
text: :surprise:

author: ateixeira
text:
I think they itemized it like this:

$85 parts
$120 labor
$773 for Hans' boat

author: ateixeira
text:
Range Rover wanted to charge a different co-worker $880 a set, that's $1760 for all 4. :surprise:

His tires are also over $300 each. Would have been $3 grand for tires and a brake job.

Probably wears the brakes to stop all that inertia of the giant wheels/tires it came with.

author: andys120
text: Today I saw, for the first time, the convertible Nissan Murano, driving around with the roof up. OMG, what an awful mess! Steel top versions of it look just fine but add that awkward looking roof and they've come up with an eyesore worse than an Azz-tek. I wouldn't have thought it possible. :sick:

author: tjc78
text: I saw one yesterday too. I try to block it out. Seriously, ugliest car since the Aztec hands down.

author: odie6l
text:
Got to see on from the backside today on my way into work. Looks nice. I'm still surprised the Scion version is not also being cross-badged to Toyota as the new Supra.

Odie

author: fintail
text: Saw a white BMW F30 3er today, and 2x Prius C, black and white.

author: explorerx4
text:
I think it would need more power to be named Supra.
As a Toyota, it would be a Celica.

author: stickguy
text: still waiting to see one of these. anyone know if they are at the dealers yet, or when they are supposed to show up?

author: explorerx4
text:
One of the five local dealers I checked has one listed as in stock.
I was there a couple of days ago, but didn't walk around much.
Maybe it was there. It's a top 'o the line Titanium model.
There's $500 customer cash available.

author: odie6l
text:
Actually the Scion TC is the Toyota Celica if it was to be rebadged. They could smack a Twin Turbo or a Supercharger for the boost in HP if needed.

Odie

author: stever
text:
To quote always reliable Wikipedia ( ), according to Scion, tC stands for touring coupe.

I like your version better.

author: tjc78
text:
If Winner doesn't have one yet, they probably aren't allocated yet. They always seem to get good allocations. When I was looking at the Taurus they had a nice selection.

I looked at Holman Maple Shade and they don't have any either.

author: lemko
text: My ex-girlfriend got a bill for a front brake job on her then-new Jetta for $650 and that was back in 1994!

author: stickguy
text: crazy. I have a quote for the Odyssey to do all 4 corners, with brand new rotors/pads, for $600. If I want to just keep the old rotors the pads/labor will only be about $300.

author: ateixeira
text: I prefer real names, so that would have made more sense.

author: ateixeira
text:
Or AWD.

First CVT in an Infiniti, also. At least Nissan implements those well.

author: stickguy
text:
I got an invite to one at my local BMW in the mail today. Probably won't make it up there though for it, but we shall see.

When I went last year for the X3 launch, they had cookies/drinks/fruit set up, and I got a stainless coffee mug as a gift for showing up.

author: ateixeira
text:
I got a hat, but it's not even the quality of their earlier ones. Funny.

Oh, and no fruit here. I was hoping for a veggie tray at least.

author: kyfdx
text:
Same here... cheap hat...no food..

My dealer used to really put out a good spread... hope this isn't a trend...

author: ateixeira
text:
They used to pamper you and make you feel special. Boo hoo.

May try to test drive some cars this weekend with my sister. She's crossover shopping.

Wonder if I can transfer the $1000 rebate to her? X1 starts at $31.5k so it's not too much of a stretch. Not sure exactly what her budget is, but probably more like $25k.

author: kyfdx
text:
I bet every X1 on the lot will be $38K and up...

I walked the lot after the shindig on Friday... got a serious case of sticker shock... Most of the 3-series (not the new sedans) that were on the lot were all $48K and up.... NAV on every single unit... Most of the X3s were over $50K...

author: andys120
text: I got a quick look at the new Fiat 300 Cabrio today, top up. An interesting grayish green with a tan roof. Nicely done I thought.

author: ateixeira
text:
Sticker shock is right, I just got a quote for a SkyActiv Mazda3 touring for $17.6k.

That Bimmer has that much in options.

Could've done just about an even trade for my '08 Miata but there was a mutiny in my household, kids said no freaking way. Hysterical.

Then I saw the Elan episode on Wheeler Dealers and decided to keep my soul intact. The MX-5 remains. :shades:

author: stickguy
text: http://www.jsautohaus.net/used/Toyota/2011-Toyota-Camry-d4f2a4b2404638d300ad4bb0- 020a83bd.htm

author: kyfdx
text: Wow... it's like catching a snipe on a snipe hunt!

author: tjc78
text: Probably one of three made.

author: stickguy
text: and damned, I would go look at it except that it does not seem to have a moonroof! what are people thinking when the order cars?

author: texases
text: In my case, headroom. None of my cars have had a sunroof, and none will, if I can keep finding them.

author: qbrozen
text: damn you, stick. I think you might have trumped this rarity I just posted on the CCBA board.

author: ateixeira
text:
Unicorn all the way.

Isn't that the final year they were made?

Last of the Mohicans.

author: kyfdx
text:
They tried to butch it up.... looks too much like the Outback in the rear...

The previous 2008-11 model was better looking...

author: andys120
text:
Got a quick look at the new 3 Series (F30) this AM, it was the same shade of red as the one in the TV ads. It looks better in the metal than in photos which make the nose seem a bit too long.

I also saw my first Toyota Prius C it was smaller and better looking than the "big" Prius .

author: ateixeira
text:
I like the new one more.

Though the funny thing is, I used to like the hatch more, now I think the sedan is better looking.

Sales have more than doubled, though that may largely be due to the MPG improvement.

author: ateixeira
text: The c is about the length of my Miata. It is a lot smaller...

author: stickguy
text:
Finally saw one in person. Actually 2 (an SE that we drove, and an SEL in the lot).

Pretty flashy, but a bit overdone in some areas (in and out). But overall, light years ahead of the old one!

author: kyfdx
text: Looks good, in a nice inoffensive, generic way...

author: ateixeira
text:
I swear that's what I thought I read, for a second or two.

Alas, 'twas a Verano.

Of course Buick hopes it'll make the brand more youthful, so maybe I was right!

Also saw 2 Leafs. Leaves?

author: tjc78
text:
New Range Rover Evoque. Really good looking SUV in a stunning red color.

Stick, DO NOT show this one to your wife. You will be begging her to buy the RDX. :shades:

author: stickguy
text:
I can guarantee that she will hate it, so not worried there.

She did, however, really like the Porsche Cayanne, but that is a tad out of the price range!

she actually asked me today, what I would get. I picked the 2013 outback. And only partly because it would keep about $7,500 in our pockets (real cost differential). I also really liked it, and think it would be an excellent choice for us.

I actually made it a decision for her of the OB or a CRV. Basically the same price if anything, the sube is cheaper.

author: tjc78
text:
She did, however, really like the Porsche Cayanne

My Fiance loves them too. Waayyyyy out of my price range I can tell you that.

I just saw in SFTSF NYC's parents have one and just cost them over $500 for an oil change. :surprise:

I picked the 2013 outback

I have only driven one Subaru, which was a first generation Forester it was a competent little wagon. I know quite a few people that just love their Subis to death. A solid choice.

What are you doing with the van? Going to trade it or Craigs?

author: stickguy
text:
Craig's baby. wanna buy it?

after selling my Accord (one of those "unsellable" stick shifts) the first weekend for just under asking, I'll use that again. I pocketed 3k on that move (over trading it in), even after deducting the sales tax credit.

There is an advantage to having a Honda with reasonable miles on it (the Odyssey is a 2005, just hitting 73K now).

I don't expect it to be a hard item to sell.

author: fintail
text: Haven't seen anything new of note in my past week or so in FL and GA. Saw a couple SLS cabrios in Miami Beach, but there's a good chance those were exotic rentals. I've noticed more Volts here than on the west coast, which surprises me. One thing I have noticed by its absence is Subaru - people don't buy them down here.

author: tifighter
text: Neighbor down the street just picked up an electric Focus in a silvery blue color. Didn't know these were available yet, but at least the mini-Aston front end is distinctive from other Foci.

author: fintail
text: Looked at cars with my friend here yesterday, as he is always kind of thinking to replace his miled up Accord. Stopped at a college town MB dealer - salesman said bluetec cars sell poorly there, and nobody will touch their relatively base E350 wagon - but the gasser Es with sport and lower cars do sell. Odd...on the west coast, wagons and diesels don't seem to sit on the local lot for long. They also had a new E63 and S63 sitting around, can't imagine those will be an easy sale. Adjacent Nissan and VW dealers (same owner group no doubt) made it clear they would club a baby seal to make a deal, very strong sales pushes.

author: lemko
text: What's Bluetec?

author: tjc78
text: Fancy name for diesel.

author: fintail
text:
The marketing driven name for MB diesels, based on the emissions system...you will know one when you see one, as they are badged on the trunklid.

Right now, NA gets a bluetec E sedan and S-class along with ML and GL, and the bluetec C and GLK are coming soon.

author: texases
text: I think the BlueTec includes the urea injection, right?

author: ateixeira
text:
absence is Subaru - people don't buy them down here

Useless trivia factoid: Subaru's market share in Vermont is 14 (yes, fourteen) times what they have in Florida.

Funny.

It's not just the AWD - Subarus are not flashy and pretentious enough.

You still in Miami Beach? Notice even the mannequins in store windows are, um, shall we say, turbocharged?

author: ateixeira
text:
had a new E63 and S63 sitting around, can't imagine those will be an easy sale

Lots of folks in Miami have big money, I'm sure they'll sell.

Took my nephews there last summer, and they almost didn't leave the parking lot. I think we saw 3 Lamborghinis, just parked.

They also saw a Ferrari and a Spyker. Pretty cool for a little kid from a small town in Brazil.

author: ateixeira
text:
How can you see out of those things?

Don't you love how automakers remove windows, then get you to pay thousands for surround-view cameras.

author: lemko
text: Spotted a red Can Am Spyder travelling west on Rhawn Street near Tabor Avenue in NE Philly.

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw one of these boxes running down the road.

Funny, it looks small on the bottom, but huge on top. Almost like a box truck fell on top of a Sentra.

That's an illusion. It's just that the sides go straight up. It's as wide at the top as it is at the bottom.

author: fushigi
text: In white. Luckily I hadn't had lunch yet.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Saw one this morning in kind of a yellowish, green color. Big thumbs down on the styling IMO, I liked the old one a lot better.

Saw a Blue Subaru BRZ on the highway yesterday afternoon. I'm really digging this one, need to take it for a spin.

Also a couple of JX Infinitis, those seem to be selling well.

Neighbor a couple of streets over bought a new CX-5 this weekend, they had one of those Pontiac Torrent clones before this. They also have a 2012 CR-V which they got back in March/April timeframe which replaced an older Ford Edge.

Another neighbor brought home a loaded Ridgeline that he traded his 375k mile Toyota Solara for. The dealer actually gave him 2500 bucks for his Solara!

I'm still toying with a new vehicle for myself. My 2007 Impreza hatch is going to hit 100k soon and I'm getting the itch. It's tough because other than brakes, tires and a PCV Valve cleaning, she needs nothing at all. The battery is starting to go maybe as she has had a couple of hard starts lately, but 31mpg, manual hatches are rare and I love this one but I'd like a few more "toys". Current vehicles in the running are the new Acura RDX, JGC and Volvo XC60.

author: ateixeira
text:
May be hard to find a BRZ in stock, and even if you do there may not be test drives unless they know you're a serious buyer.

CX5 is nice, if a bit small, but the small engine is taxed with all that weight, at least the loaded AWD automatic we sampled.

31mpg, manual hatches are rare

Another Impreza, a Focus, Golf TDI, or Mazda3 SkyActiv. Those are my suggestions.

author: lemko
text: ...blue Ford Fiesta at Rising Sun and Knorr in NE Philly.

author: ateixeira
text: Temp tags and all, with so many LEDs you'd think they just wrapped Xmas rope lighting around the whole car. This is getting tacky.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Thanks for the recommendations juice. My plan is to keep my little Impreza for as along as I can. But my commute is about 50 miles each way and I think something a little bigger, more comfortable and effortless acceleration are in order.

Like my S2k, the Impreza will be used on those good weather days (I have kept it in immaculate condition), maybe I'll even get into a bit of tuning and getting her out on a local trackday.

Out of the three choices, I would definitely go with the new Impreza tho. Love our Scoobydoos!

author: stickguy
text: based on that criteria, if you aren't obsessed with every last MPG, you should really like the RDX.

author: ateixeira
text:
The new ones get dramatically better gas mileage. Back seat is HUGE. Dwarfs the Mazda3.

Heck, the back seat has a lot more leg room than the CX5.

author: fintail
text: I think that's the origin of the name, yes.

author: fintail
text:
Oh, this was in Athens, GA, Nice college town, but probably not a good market for 100K+ cars (well, the E63 was pretty base, 95K).

Miami Beach is a good place for exotic rentals, too. Saw a Phantom Cabrio on one rental lot, aside various sundry Lambos, Ferraris, and 2x SLS.

I spotted this new Bentley coupe cruising among all the Sunday evening douchiness on Ocean Dr.:

author: fintail
text:
"This is getting tacky"

More copycat sycophant designers at work.

author: fintail
text:
Probably a good 10x in Seattle vs FL, too. I saw only a couple Subies apart from a few trashed loud WRX in FL.

Miami Beach is its own planet. Fun for awhile, but I have found I prefer things from about the space coast northward.

Oh, I swear I saw a new Fusion on the highway in northern FL yesterday, but it was a split second corner of the eye glimpse, so maybe not. Also saw a Verano on a small old time multi GM make dealer somewhere in southern GA.

author: ateixeira
text:
DC is the polar opposite of Miami. Conservative, banking town, boring.

I like visiting Miami, though, in a point-and-laugh kind of way. I think more people speak Spanish there than English. Depends on what part of town, I suppose.

author: fintail
text:
Many parts of the area made me think of what the more developed parts of South America must be like...and not only in good ways.

DC is probably about as corrupt as Miami, anyway.

author: ateixeira
text:
Drug Lords down in Miami.

Nah, DC is far worse - politicians.

author: fintail
text: In terms of societal damage, sadly, that's correct :sick:

author: kyfdx
text:
In Teal.. with the top down...

Made my soul hurt...

author: ateixeira
text: Actually, the Soul is a Kia not a Nissan.

author: tifighter
text:
I had to look on the Nissan website to see this. They call it 'Carribean', and some designer probably thought it was 'ocean-inspired'.

Talk about making a salesperson's job even harder...

author: fintail
