text: Thanks. Bluetec, of course. I weighed the pros and cons, and thought I might not have this cheap an opportunity again. Amazing lease deal, they gave me a fair price for my car and I know it will go to a good home. I am still kind of on a high from it.

author: ateixeira
text:
Pano is nice.

Is the trim piano black? That's how my Miata is, a bit dark but open the lid and ... who cares!? :shades:

author: fintail
text: It's a very dark grey wood, pretty black, but it is kind of shiny. The silver trim looks nice with the other dark colors, and the materials are very nice, a level above the old car. Like you say, open the pano shade, and it is nice and bright inside. That shade will stay open most of the time.

author: ateixeira
text:
Is it hard to keep such dark carpeting looking clean.

PS Made in Germany?

author: tifighter
text: I spy the Bellevue Square parking lot. I can recall some night hoonage there in a friend's volvo back in high school. Gotta learn handbrake turns sometime.

author: fintail
text:
I'm getting a set of MB rubber mats thrown in, so the carpets should stay fresh.

Built at Sindelfingen, which I actually visited in November. This car was born pretty recently, December build date.

author: fintail
text: I love the rooftop level of that garage - great for photography - always a nice empty spot, and nobody will bug you.

author: imidazol97
text: Nice. Congratulations.

author: ateixeira
text: I have rubber mats for the Miata, too. Better than those white salt stains on black carpet.

author: lemko
text: Nice! Good luck with it! White will make it easier to keep clean and scratches won't be as visible.

author: bhill2
text: Great looking car, Fin, in and out! Please keep us updated on your impressions and experiences as you two become acquainted. The new E-class is looking good to me, and a Mercedes diesel strikes me as about as good as it gets.

author: lemko
text: ...white Lexus RX450h at work and a black Chevrolet Malibu on Oxford Avenue near Unruh in NE Philly.

author: fintail
text: I also think white works well with the design of the car. Some cars look better in the color than others. It's also a good contrast for the pano roof. And unlike the dark grey car, I can drive it for 10 miles in the rain and not have it look like I've been off road.

author: fintail
text:
I'll post any issues, for sure. The car has a little quirk to be adjusted already. I went over it with a fine toothed comb, and the fuel filler door is maybe a couple mm out of adjustment. I have an appointment Monday to have it aligned. A normal person might not have noticed. But if I am taking on a car payment again, I want it perfect. Otherwise, it's a piece of heaven, relaxing to drive, more tech than I know what to do with, good mileage. And dare I say it, it might even be a little pretty.

Speaking of new cars, when I bought my car, they had a beautiful C-class on the lot. C300 4Matic, Diamond Silver on ash leather, P2, pano, loaded, big 48K MSRP. Today, it's gone. Maybe it sold.

author: fintail
text:
Around here the problem is debris, especially pine needles and leaves.

The fintail doesn't even have carpeting up front, just rubber floors. I wipe them down now and then, easy.

author: ateixeira
text:
Do you get pine tar or are both cars under cover?

I have a car port for 2 cars, but the 3rd car is exposed. Sucks when it snows.

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw a blue Golf with plastic wheel covers and 65 series tires.

Looked it up - 2.5l engine is standard, so no 2.slow like the base Jetta, at least.

VW needs a car to slot below the Golf/Jetta just to get away from these stripped base models.

author: fintail
text: Both cars are garaged. I'd want to sell the old car if I couldn't keep it dry - it would decay pretty fast in the damp here.

author: ateixeira
text:
The salt they use on the roads around here would eat an older car, too.

Was the fintail's steel galvanized?

author: fintail
text: Nope, I don't know if that had been invented yet. Some design issues in old cars are also rust nests - floors, trunks, rockers, headlight areas - places that retain moisture.

author: ateixeira
text: I think galvanization became mainstream in the early 90s but it would not surprise me if Benz was a decade or more ahead of the curve.

author: robr2
text:
Porsche started using galvanized steel back in 1974. The rest of the industry caught up by mid 1980's.

Galvanizing covers a broad spectrum of applications using zinc. The best application is hot dipping but that leaves a thick finish that can't be painted or welded.

IIRC, cars are dipped in a zinc rich primer that bonds to the metal with electricity.

author: ateixeira
text:
I remember seeing 2 year old Hyundai Excels with massive rust. They came out in 1985 IIRC.

I guess it was phased in and the cheapies got it last.

author: stever
text:
2013 Ford Escape owners are concerned about rust already showing up underneath, including the knuckles and such around the wheels.

I'm wondering if that's intentional - maybe Ford is using the oxidation for "protection"? I've seen a few "steel" commercial buildings that are intentionally allowed to rust. "Weathering steel" they call it.

author: ateixeira
text:
Frightening to see this early, but it does appear to be surface rust.

Still - can't they dip those parts? Or at least paint them?

Reminds me of my '91 Ford Escort GT - I had rust on the fuel filler neck right away, brand new. Fortunately it never got worse, but it sure was ugly.

author: ateixeira
text: Fix Obstinate Rust Daily

author: fintail
text: Some MBs are known to be rusters, others not. W126s and W210s can get bad. Models in the past decade seem to be OK, but even some 90s cars, not the best.

author: texases
text: The W210 was a recent low point for MB, it seems, coming after the bulletproof W124, with problems (like rust) I never would have expected.

author: berri
text: I suspect some of those who rushed over to Ford because they didn't take a bailout are going to be disappointed. I think "Quality is Job 1" is just marketing puffing. In my experiences with them they really aren't that different than GM, particularly after the warranty runs out. Incidentally, my neighbor has a 4 or 5 year old F-150 with around 70K and it already needs a new transmission and he told me he has a friend with a similar issue. So much for "built tough"!

author: texases
text: Ford looks about tied with Nissan and Subaru, a little better than GM, etc.:

author: fintail
text: 124s don't seem to rust, even 123s do OK, but some 210s - not pretty. A HBS case study in bad planning.

author: ateixeira
text:
I'll put money on Subaru improving. Their achilles heel was coolant leaks in the head gasket, and now that the coolant was re-routed it simply won't (can't) happen any more.

Interesting curves from BMW and Hyundai, too.

author: busiris
text:
I remember reading that the Chevrolet Vega was one of the first GM products to use some sort of dipping-galvanizing method (I know.... Hard to believe), but the process was poorly designed and implemented, and the rustproofing materials never made it to many body locations.

That, coupled with a thinner steel body and no fender-well liners in the first several year model runs, and owners got bodies that rusted quickly...

From Wikipedia...

After a six-stage zinc phosphate rustproofing process and two minutes submerged in a 65,000 US gallons (246,052 L; 54,124 imp gal) electrophoretic painting vat (Fisher Body Division’s "Elpo" electrophoretic deposition of polymers process) to prime and further protect them from rust, assembled bodies were dried, wet-sanded, sealer-coated, sprayed with acrylic lacquer and baked in a 300 F (149 C) degree oven. Fisher's rustproofing was faulty. Failure to penetrate a gap between front fenders and cowl allowed moist debris and salt to rust the untreated steel, and trapped air prevented coating inside the tops of the front fenders, which on early Vegas had no protective liners.[8] The finance department had rejected liners as they would have added a $2.28 unit cost. After GM spent millions replacing thousands of corroded fenders under warranty, Chevrolet installed stopgap plastic deflectors in late 1973 and full plastic liners in 1974. Rust also damaged the rocker panels and door bottoms, the area beneath the windshield, and the body above the rockers. It sometimes seized the front suspension cam bolts, preventing alignment work, necessitating removal with a cutting torch and replacement by all-new parts.

author: fintail
text: Saw another new unplated E today, also a new Accord, 2x new ES, and a new A6 loaner car.

author: tifighter
text: I saw an new Accord Sport today and must say, its a big improvement on the last model. Honda seems to have put on their rally caps.

author: fintail
text: It looks a lot better, the styling is refined. I saw a brand new Civic last night too, the cheapo looking edge seems to be off it.

author: ateixeira
text: I noticed one, too. I thought Honda was phasing out the badges but I noticed the Sport badge on it.

author: fintail
text: Another new Accord tonight, the brakes work well on these, as this one looked like it wanted to plow into a line of stopped traffic, braking just in time. Also saw a dirty dark red Tesla, a Dart, and another new unplated white W212 E-class with pano, couldn't tell the model but not a Bluetec.

author: andys120
text:
I've been wondering when I'd see the new little Dodges since the competition from Ford and Chevy are everywhere. Yesterday I saw two new Darts, the first was black with those damnable black wheels and sported an R/T badge (I think, it was pretty small).

The second was a nice bright blue.

author: robr2
text: I saw a Dart yesterday as well. I spotted about 4 new Fusions and I keep seeing the same Suzuki Kazashi.

author: ateixeira
text: For whatever reason I very, very rarely see any Darts. They simply don't sell here in Potomac, MD. DC, too.

author: boomchek
text: I haven`t seen any on the road yet, I think they`re too new still? When did thwey come out, about 3 months ago?

author: imidazol97
text:
>very rarely see any Darts

It may be that they don't stand out when I see one usually from the rear. I recognized one a couple weeks ago on the interstate downtown. In black. Looked okay. Then I realized it was next to a black Focus, a new one. Their rears look similar other than the Focus has Sonata syndrome and is overstyled. The width of the Dart rear or the fenders make it look diminutive; the taillights on the Focus make it look dominant. Dart rear needs more ooooomph visually.

author: berri
text: Isn't DC kind of like the west coast - a mostly import town? Bad news for Detroit, because regardless of what people may personally think about gov workers and contractors, they tend to be a highly educated workforce, which means they tend to be consumer decision leaders rather than followers.

author: ateixeira
text: Import friendly I suppose. Not many manufacturing plants, lots of foreign diplomats, and a transient population. We do see a lot of livery cars on K street and on Capitol Hill, and cabs. Mix of stuff.

author: robr2
text:
Isn't DC kind of like the west coast - a mostly import town?

DC to Boston is like that - coast to about 150 miles west. Highly educated, leaders instead of followers, et al.

author: ateixeira
text:
Was taking the dog for a long walk and it looks like neighbor bought a new one.

Looked better out in the daylight vs at the auto show. Rear fenders actually look a bit muscular. I still think the rear looks like a Genesis but that's a handsome car as well.

Moonroof is tiny, that's a let down when the Optima has a huge dual roof.

Saw the new 2 screen Nav. Bottom half is touch screen, upper screen shows the map supposedly, smart solution to easy interface with no finger prints.

Thumbs up. Honda is trying again.

author: fintail
text:
Still not a fan of touchscreens, for the fingerprint issue. I am just too OCD. I do agree the Accord is a lot nicer looking than the previous one, more refined.

Saw an X1 today, looked barely taller than the Prius in front of it. It's really a wagon.

author: texases
text: I'm looking forward to sitting in the X1 at the next car show. Not enough headroom in a 3er, but like smaller/cheaper than X3. Get an X1 with rwd and (possibly) NO sunroof. Big hit to resale value, I know, but I like my headroom.

author: ateixeira
text:
I just can't deal with scrolling to one letter at a time. Give me a full keyboard.

Took a road trip in an Audi S4 convertible and it took us 20 minutes to find the address for a Subaru dealer, for 2 reasons:

* Audi actually removes Subaru dealers from their POI database (what if your wife owns one?)
* Entering the street address manually was a one-letter-at-a-time affair

Voice recognition is better so hopefully you can avoid that in newer Audis, but otherwise give me a touch screen any day.

author: ateixeira
text:
It's more of a small hatchback than a wagon, even.

My kids are tall, but my 13 year old said it was not a car for tall people.

author: lemko
text: ...blue Chevrolet Spark on Rising Sun Avenue near Cottman in NE Philly.

author: fintail
text:
Had my car in for a couple of adjustments this morning - spent an hour at the dealer, sat in everything on the floor. Kind of amused that the CLS appears to have basic C-class HVAC controls. The C really does feel smaller and lighter than my E, not to mention less equipped. But not bad, the interior materials seemed nice enough. Sat in a new S63 with a 150K sticker - ooh boy.

Also saw 2 Tesla sedans, one parked at the MB dealer, the other at an alignment shop.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Acura RDX sales are strong now that dealers have inventory to sell.

Spotted a new Range Rover, man that thing has presence...

Also the Acura dealer nearby has a silver RLX on display, nice looking car in person. In a 2002 Lexus LS430 kinda way...

Audi is on fire around here. I have seen more late model A6's A7's, Q5 3.0T's and RS4's around here than BMW 3-series. Although the brand new 3-series is becoming a little more common.

Neighbor down the street got an XC60 - "R" design in a cool electric blue color. Had a first gen MDX (2001 - 2002 with the single exhaust port) before this.

Saw a few revamped Honda Civic sedans as well. The new tail is pretty upscale looking. Also saw a few ILX's, i think the lease deals on those are helping...

author: boomchek
text:
Yeah I see the new 2013 Civics here too. They did a good job with the refresh as other than the car's general shape, it does not look much like the 2012 Civic.

It's funny because I see 2012 models on the road and they do seem plain compared to the 2013's. The 2012 looks like a design that could have come out in 2001, it's so dull. I've never seen a manufacturer do a big refresh like this only 1 year after a full redesign. Gotta give Honda credit for listening to the criticizm but on the other hand it makes you wonder what they were thinking in the first place? The reputation they earned from the last 20 years is not enough to carry a new model into sales record books amid the competitive small car market today.

author: fintail
text:
I like the theory that the 2012 Civic was decontented as not to compete with the ILX - but I guess that doesn't hold as much water in Canada. The 12 really does have a bland cheap look to it, even the exterior plastic just doesn't look up to snuff. Really bad planning, I wonder what it cost them.

Saw a Fisker Karma on the road not long ago.

author: explorerx4
text: 'Problems' need to be defined in order to interpret that graph.

author: explorerx4
text: My wife has a 2013 Escape and the lower front control arms look awful because the are pretty big, so you notice them.

author: stever
text: If your's has "rust" maybe you can head over that way and reassure folks.

author: explorerx4
text:
I may have posted about that over there already.
Maybe there will be a Customer Satisfaction program to address it.

author: stever
text: Thanks!

author: andys120
text:
Last winter I bought an '01 BMW 3-Series convertible and it looks like I may have started a trend to convertibles in my nabe as this winter three new flip-tops have appeared. One is even older than my 330CiC, it's a Geo Metro 3 banger bought by a guy who drives mostly big pickups (still has his long-bed Ford F150).

The other two are brand new, one is a Volkswagen Eos with the folding hardtop. It looks pretty sharp in black but it's one of the few convertibles I've seen that actually looks better w the top raised.

The other newbie is a dark grey Camaro SS with a black top. I'm not a big fan of the current Camaro h/t because the squashed roof makes it look like a cartoon version of the original Camaro. The convertible rook which is a tad higher (at least it looks it) looks much nicer to me. IMO the car looks great with the top up or down.

For an area where the cars of choice are Camrys, Lacrosses and Grand Marquis that's progress! :shades:

author: lemko
text: ...another Chevrolet Spark, silver, outside the gym I go to last night.

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw one today on the Whitehurst Freeway.

Before that, a new Accord sedan, and a new Accord coupe.

author: fintail
text: Saw an Azera this morning too (like the Genesis, seems a lot of local Koreans choose these), and my first wrecked ATS, near a customized W212 E63 and a Testarossa with a lightweight front end:

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Saw my first ATS this morning. Other than the swoop in the headlights, there is very little differentiation from it and the CTS. Still looks something that came from the same designer who had nothing but a ruler and a block of Butter for inspiration.

Also saw a loaded new Mazda 6 Touring this morning. What a gorgeous looking car.

author: lemko
text: ...black Buick Verrano turn left from Unruh onto Bingham and then left onto Fanshawe from Bingham in NE Philly.

author: boomchek
text: Ouch on the Ferrari and the E63. At first I thought it was one of your nose-to-nose photo shoots with your E class and a Testarossa you acquired :shades:

author: fintail
text: I'll admit I like the Testarossa, but I'd actually prefer one in white - very 80s. Would match the new car, too :shades: ">

author: boomchek
text:
Yeah white Testarossa, very Miami Vice-ish.

We had a red TR at the dealer I worked at. Moving it around was a challenge: no power steering, no visibility, very wide and difficult to maneuver. I haven't driven one in the wild though, it's probably a fun experience with a flat 12 , rwd, and no traction control. :surprise:

author: lemko
text: Anybody remember the "Married with Children" episode where Al Bundy leased a "Testica?"

author: fintail
text:
I am sure it is a pig to drive, but would go nice with a pastel colored casual suit :shades:

Probably better off to find a custom C126 with cheese grater rear quarter trim.

author: boomchek
text: I wonder how many of these widebody 80s Benzes survived? There has to be only a handful of these ever built, maybe in the low hundreds worldwide?

author: fintail
text: I think it ended up being a lemon. I also seem to remember him winning a ~88 Mustang convertible, which only appeared in one or two episodes.

author: fintail
text: Very few. Low production and I bet many were neglected. I'd love to have one though. When I was maybe 12 years old, something like that was a real dream car.

author: lemko
text: I recall another episode where Al would take luxury cars for an extended test drive. In the beginning of the episode, you saw him at the light in a Mercedes S-Class. Later on in the episode, he had a Lincoln Town Car.

author: boomchek
text:
Just like you can see many 90s imports nowadays with mismatched and cracked body kits, mismatched wheels, tacky glued on accessories, etc...

When import tuning was all the rage in the 90s I knew that in 15-20 years we will be seeing neglected "import projects" like this, in the same way that in the early 90s you could see many neglected "project" american cars like 70s and 80s Camaros, Mustangs, etc.. with bondo, miscolored body panels, etc....

However with these Benzes I can imagine they're neglected but you see very few on the road (I'm talking about the wide body kit models) as they're most likely sitting in people's garages hiding.

author: lemko
text: When I lived in my old neighborhood, there was a lady with a metallic green wide-body C-Class that was all blinged out with chrome and gold-plated add-on trim. It was about the tackiest Mercedes I have ever seen. Fintail would shudder if he'd have seen it! :P

author: fintail
text:
Those custom cars will suffer a different neglect. They sold to people so wealthy, when they were tired of the car they didn't sell them on, just relegated them to a dusty corner of the compound. So, many cars might still be intact today, just need to be reconditioned to get back on the road.

Here's an AMG SEC that comes to the local MB show each year, and gets some attention. Not a widebody, but still a period style:

author: fintail
text:
I think I remember that too, along with the Town Car.

The constant references to the German cars of the Rhoads/D'Arcys were also funny.

author: tjc78
text:
Later on in the episode, he had a Lincoln Town Car.

So Al did have some class!

Ed O'Neill drove a LTC in the movie Dutch as well, if anyone even remembers that movie.

author: fintail
text: Saw a C-Max hybrid today, possible rental (no plate frames, lost appearing driver). Also a brand new unplated 750Li.

author: stickguy
text:
not rare at this point, but interesting.

my neighbor had a 4 door Focus and a new Escape parked in his driveway one after the other. Both silver. From a house down, I was surprised by how alike they looked. Seemed to have the identical taillights, and the shape was very close. Pretty much the escape did look just like a a Focus wagon that sat a little high!

author: tjc78
text: My best friend just picked up a new Focus. All loaded up minus navigation. Its a nice car, but seems a little pricey to me

author: kyfdx
text: Went to the new car show on Sunday.... after that, everything seems pricy.. :surprise:

author: explorerx4
text:
I'm pretty sure they share the same architecture.
Lots of examples of that.

author: ateixeira
text:
I'm seeing price creep, big time. Mainstream SUVs loaded up are hitting $50k, an Escalade is closer to $70k nowadays.

At that level prices have shifted upward about $20 grand over the past decade. Scary.

author: fintail
text: I think it has really exploded in the past 5 years - more of that inflation the powers that be don't want to admit. Still amazes me that a 3er can hit 60K these days, that 5ers and Es can get to 80K.

author: anythngbutgm
text: Escalade Platinum's are priced in the 90's.

author: ateixeira
text:
$90s....wow.

Speechless.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Seeing a few of those new Evoque's around lately. I'm digging the styling except for the gun slit rear end.

Also another new Range Rover, this one in Triple Black.

Base model Mazda6, couple of new Altimas, a new Fusion (which is surprisingly rare find) and a Hyundai Equus.

author: ateixeira
text: Have not seen a 6 on the roads yet.

author: robr2
text:
Escalade Platinum's are priced in the 90's.

Not quite $90K. They ESV Platinum with every option ticked (ok - wheel locks are the only option) is $86K.

For comparison:
Navigator L $70K
Lexus LX570 $92K
The various Range Rover models start at $83K to $130K. The Autobiography model tops out at $139K!!

author: ateixeira
text: Just add dealer-installed diamond encrusted DUBs.

author: boomchek
text:
A loaded Escalade here in Canada is pushing close to $110k, which I think is a bit outrageous for basically a dressed up Chevy frame and powertrain with a SUV body, 3 bench seats, and some leather and wood trim.

Escalade price

author: fintail
text:
Canada gets hosed on a lot of car related things. Are those prices inclusive of tax?

I notice the Canadian equivalent to my new car is about 10K more - but Canadian models have standard leather.

author: boomchek
text:
That's plus 12% taxes = so it's about $120k with taxes, and I think there's a gas guzzler levy of $5000 on top of that too. :surprise:

Surprisingly small economy cars are priced about the same now as in the US, it's just the luxury cars that are priced more.

author: fintail
text: 120K+ - who'd spend that on an Escalade? Sounds insane even for a Rover or a G-wagen.

author: boomchek
text:
I'd blow that on a G if I were looking for the most capable SUV out there.

Not a Range Rover though. I see the last gen 2004 and up models for $5-$10k at the auction, with the usualy saggy suspension, dashboard lit up like a christmas tree, and half the electronics not working :lemon:

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Capable yes, but for less than the price of either the Gangsta's School Bus or a RR, I go right for a Mercedes GL which is quicker, tows more, gets better mileage (even in petrol form) and costs less. Then there's that diesel... :shades:

Mercedes also nailed it with the styling as well IMO.

The Gelandewagon is cool but I think the old Oxcart suspension might be tiring for me and the thing has the aerodynamics of a brick

author: boomchek
text:
The GL is actually quite spacious. Our friends had one and when we were on holidays, after checking in to a hotel we were able to explore our vacation destination in their GL, with 4 of us adults, and our 2 kids in baby seats, plus 2 strollers and other baby stuff.

The only thing he had to replace was the tranny but since it was under warranty it saved him about $7k :surprise:

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Yikes, 7 grand! :surprise: Was it an older one?

I hardly hear of Mercedes trannies going South, at least not until they get into the higher miles. My wifes business partner had one of the first CLS's and he replaced his about 130k but he is a pretty aggressive driver as well.

If I had a big family and I needed a hauler, (and had theat kind of coin to spend ) the GL320 would be it.

author: boomchek
text: I think my friend's GL was a 2006 or so.

author: fintail
text:
A diesel G would be an interesting way to go - not for this market though, unless you import it yourself.

Range Rovers are dangerous. The pre-03 are becoming extinct already, along with early Discos.

author: fintail
text:
At the MB dealer today, spotted a pair of SL63s - red and black. Roughly 170K apiece.

And not new, but the 5er GT that's been sitting at a higher line used lot is still there - maybe 3 months now? I am kind of feeling sorry for it.

author: boomchek
text: I saw a 5 series GT on the road a few days ago coming towards me and it's an akward looking beast. My buddy who has the CLS said he sat in it and loves it and would buy one if it was cheap enough (he's 6'3" and like 230+lbs) so maybe it's spacious for his size, but I can't get used to the looks from any angle on that car.

author: fintail
text: The one here is a 550i, high options, and I am certain it could be had for under 40K now. Probably a lot of car for the money, if one can get over the bizarre looks.

author: tifighter
text: Although I expect to get flamed, I don't really have a big issue with the 5GT. If it remains unwanted and depreciates enough, I could be convinced. First choice? No, but if the deal was really good, and it had xDrive...

author: tjc78
text: Yesterday on RT 73 in NJ, a silver CTS Coupe (stunning), and a sliver XTS with a temp tag. They were behind one another in traffic.

author: anythngbutgm
text: New Avalon HSD in a color eerily identical to the Copper used on the Kia Optima.

author: stickguy
text:
2 doors down. Noticed it in the neighbors driveway when I walked my dog tonight. no front plate yet.

This AM their old (I think gen 1, maybe 2) CRV was still there. So I am guessing that the dad upgraded to new wheels (the mom has a pilot for toting around the 3 kids).

They broke up the run of 4 straight multiple Honda (if you count my fleet of Acuras). In between us is another CRV/Pilot combo, and the other side of them is a Pilot/Accord.

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw a new Escape.

Then, right next door to that new Accord I saw recently, a new Civic. Probably jealous and had to get a new Honda as well.

First of the new Civics I've seen up close, nice face lift at the front.

author: fintail
text:
Someone in my building has a new trunkback Impreza. Not a bad choice.

Saw a number of new Audis as I used the car wash located alongside the local dealer (free perk with the new car) - they don't really make me drool, aside from the A7.

author: boomchek
text: I agree, the A7 is stunning. The others are nice too but they look like they've changed very little from the mid 90s to now even though they went through several complete redesigns.

author: jpp75
text:
Does the Impreza have the CVT? I've liked the Legacy's I've rented lately except for the transmission.

I love the A4 from a styling perspective but don't understand why they sell so well. My partner has one and it's underwhelming to say the least. Nyccarguy mentioned that his wife drives the 328xi every chance she gets, that's how a car should be. I only drive the A4 if it's the logical choice based on how the cars are parked in the driveway.

author: fintail
text:
The A4 especially makes me kind of yawn, and even the A6 and A8 don't appeal to me like the competition. Like the A8 rental I had in Germany - superfancy car, but no emotional stigma - where if I had a comparably equipped S or 7er, I might be more excited. Maybe it's my own bias, but maybe not.

Oh, just saw an X1 apparently out for a test drive, had the dangly temp dealer plate stuck to the back.

author: fintail
text:
I think it does. I know the new Impreza is capable of impressive mileage for an AWD car, something like 36 highway.

Another Audi issue is that the published lease rates seem to be a lot higher than the other Germans.

author: jpp75
text: That's much better than any other car I've had, the Legacy does get decent mileage but I just can't warm up to the rubber band transmission.

author: texases
text: A number of Impreza tests haven't been able to get those mpgs. CR averaged 27 mpg overall, less than most of its competition.

author: boomchek
text: Somebody in our condo complex got a new X1 as I see it in the garage all the time. Cool little wagon thingy I guess.

author: lemko
text: ...black Hyundai Equus going south on Roosevelt Blvd. near Grant in NE Philly.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Saw quite a few new RAV4's, these things have been for sale for what a week now?

Also in Boston on Saturday, spotted a sinister looking ML63 AMG.

author: tjc78
text:
A little longer than that. I know someone who has had one for about a month. They had the first or second one the dealer sold.

I've seen quite a few too. Much improved looks IMO. No spare tire on the back finally!

author: texases
text:
"I've seen quite a few too. Much improved looks IMO. No spare tire on the back finally! "

Because there's no spare at all. But I guess that'd be OK with me. I never did like the outside mounted spare.

author: ateixeira
text:
CR averaged 27 mpg overall

That actually matches the Elantra. No wonder Hyundai owners complain.

If you need AWD, though, that's as good as it gets.

author: ateixeira
text:
there's no spare at all

Pretty sure I saw a donut spare in one of the video reviews...let me look...

Yeah, 4th image here shows it:

http://www.autoweek.com/article/20121217/CARREVIEWS/121219903

author: texases
text: Oops...I had heard otherwise, hadn't bothered to check. That's even better! I prefer a spare to a can of fix-a-flat.

author: ateixeira
text: Can't blame ya - the commercials talk about making the old spare tire disappear.

author: fintail
text: Latest - white RR Ghost driving far over the flow of traffic - no need for laws when you can buy justice, 2x Altimas one rental, white Equus, Tesla sedan, what I assume was a Scion FR-S rebadged as a Toyota, and not new but weird, an HHR converted to a "Nomad" - even had grafted on fins.

author: boomchek
text: in white color, creeping in a supermarket parking lot. Very nice looking car.

author: stickguy
text:
they got rid of the totally useless 3rd row (that few people even bought) and converted that space to be the spare tire well.

If Toyota had come out with this model last summer, I would have given it serious consideration before we bought the Acura.

author: fintail
text: Saw an Avalon, must have been a higher model as it seemed to have a lot of chrome, the weird fish mouth was definitely out there.

author: tjc78
text:
they got rid of the totally useless 3rd row (that few people even bought)

Yeah, my Mom's has that. I don't think anyone but a small child could fit back there.

Fintail,
I hate that grill on the Avalon. It's not a bad looking car, but the front is a deal breaker.

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw a white one today, the odd thing was it had CA license plates (in DC).

Really has presence on the road.

author: fintail
text:
Saw 2x Tesla sedans, both white, I suspect it was actually the same car. I noticed the front LED turns off when turning, like an Audi - doesn't look right to me.

Also a new Sentra - high trim model not rental, a new Accord that had distinct DI clatter, and a new Civic.

author: robr2
text:
I noticed the front LED turns off when turning, like an Audi - doesn't look right to me.

I've noticed on Audis that the white LED is replaced with a yellow LED turn signal now.

author: andys120
text: I saw my first new (restyled) Chevy Impala. Except for the rear it looks exactly like a Malibu. This could be a problem for Chevy since I often mistake the Cruze for a Malibu.

author: fintail
text: Saw a dark blue Tesla sedan today.

author: iwant12
text: Saw a black Tesla in Fort Worth yesterday, dealer tag on the back. Very nice-looking ride. I had my windows down and all I heard from the Tesla was wheels on pavement.

author: fintail
text: Saw a silver Tesla sedan today, boring color - you can spot the LEDs from a mile away though. Also a new Nissan Quest, rental, Michigan plates.

author: tjc78
text: All you guys seeing Teslas. I haven't seen one here in Southern NJ.

author: ateixeira
text:
You guys get very cheap full-service gasoline there.

Insurance it what kills your costs, right?

author: tjc78
text:
Insurance it what kills your costs, right?

Don't remind me. It's crazy $3400/ year 2 drivers, 3 vehicles (2 full coverage). No accidents, no tickets.

I'd rather pump my own gas, its faster. I know I'm certainly in the minority.

author: fintail
text: That is insane. One driver, two vehicles (1 full coverage, one vintage), no accidents or tickets, costs me maybe $1500. And I am trusted to pump my own gas.

author: texases
text:
"All you guys seeing Teslas. I haven't seen one here in Southern NJ. "

I'm seeing one every day now, somebody's parking a white one in the garage at work. Haven't seen more than a couple on the road, though.

author: fintail
text: Today - black Tesla, white on white (!!!) BMW Gran Coupe, 2x X1, Sentra that was likely a rental, and an Equus with shiny wheels that made me think "Buick".

author: tjc78
text:
Yeah, my Buick has shiny wheels. I kinda like them!

Saw a new Encore at the dealer tonight. Didn't have time to check it out, but it was parked in front of an Enclave and looked tiny.

author: fintail
text: The whole car made me think "Buick", but I know what you mean. These wheels looked to maybe be a polished metal rather than bright chrome, but still pretty shiny. The overall car design says "suddenly it's 2006!" to me, like a big cross between a similar year Lacrosse and Lucerne.

author: tifighter
text: They are rolling out a refreshed Equus this month at NYIAS. Maybe they'll bump it up to 2010 or so.

author: stickguy
text:
Shop. Allstate keeps going up, but even with the platinum plan, after the rebate it is about $3.600/year. So, I was getting solicitations from AAA, so I called them. $2275 for a year, for same levels coverage, though they don't offer "accident forgiveness".

but, this is for 4 cars, 4 drivers. 2 full coverage, 2 liability only, and a 21 YO male and 17 YO female.

You are getting hosed!

author: tjc78
text: I've compared with quite a few of the big companies and Geico was always the best I could do, but never AAA. Do you have to be a AAA member? I'm not.

author: stickguy
text: Yes, I think so, but that is fairly cheap. In theory they give better rates for longer term members, but who knows how true that is!

author: fintail
text: Can't wait to see its LED jewelry :shades:

author: stickguy
text: was up around Princeton tonight, so no shortage of nice iron. Was at a light, and up next to me pulls a nice looking new black Ferrari convertible. Just don't ask me what model. But sounded real sweet pulling away!

author: explorerx4
text:
Wasn't sure what it was until I saw the Toyota emblem.
The rear lights form sort a horizontal shelf.
Forgot to look at the front.

author: ateixeira
text: Not far from a new-ish Legacy.

author: fintail
text: Saw a Dart in a color I will call "General Lee Orange" (ok, it was maybe a shade lighter).

author: lemko
text: ...white Chevrolet Caprice police car in Oaks, PA. It's the first time I've seen one in the wild.

author: lemko
text: ...silver Dodge Challenger SRT8 and one of those huge gray Nissan vans based on the Titan at Cottman and Oxford Avenue in NE Philly.

author: ateixeira
text: I didn't get the memo about all black new cars this week

author: fintail
text: Altima, X1, Fusion hybrid, rental Avalon, SWB A8

author: tjc78
text:
rental Avalon

New style or old?

author: fintail
text: New style, likely a National/Alamo car.

author: tjc78
text: That didn't take long. I'm surprised. The 05+ style took a few years before appearing in fleets.

author: fintail
text:
I think nowadays, sales are sales. 10 years ago, a Camry was rare in fleets too - now they are everywhere.

I didn't see many Avalon rentals til 2011 or so.

author: stickguy
text:
neighbor just got a new truck. Dodge 2500 diesel. 4 door cab. Black with silver accents. Couldn't read the side badges to see what specific trim level but it looked loaded and fancy.

That is a big piece of iron.

Replaced an older vintage of the same thing, minus the rear doors.

author: lemko
text: Heck, I spotted a new VW Beetle in the Enterprise rental lot at Knorr and Rising Sun in NE Philly this morning.

author: fintail
text:
Yep, those are occasional rentals. I know a friend of mine got one last year. Jettas and Passats are common rentals too, and Tiguan/Touareg are not unknown.

Today's sightings - Altima non rental, another white Gran Coupe, Fusion.

author: boomchek
text:
Don't see too many but spotted one today. For some reason it looks smaller than the previous generation, at least the size of the rear doors - they look shorter. Maybe it's just the lines.

Looks decent, and I always liked the looks of the previous generation too, just hated the cheapo Cobalt interior.

author: fintail
text: Saw a loaded looking non-rental trunkback Versa - wheels, spoiler, roof, etc. Some dealer is happy. Also a new red Altima rental at work, a normal Fusion, and a C-Max hybrid.

author: stever
text: I thought I spotted a newish Versa hatch parked in front of one of the local bars yesterday; turned out to be a metallic gray Yaris as I drove by.

author: boomchek
text: Saw a base one today. The sedan Versas are kinda ugly looking, disproportionate.

author: ateixeira
text: The 5 door looks so much better. The sedan is awkward.

author: fintail
text: Yaris hatch is better looking than Versa sedan, anyway. Something just off about that specific trunkback. I have to imagine it has a huge fleet percentage.

author: ateixeira
text:
The Note is much nicer than the sedan:

http://www.edmunds.com/auto-shows/detroit/2013/2014-nissan-versa-note-hatchback-- debuts-2013-detroit-auto-show.html

author: boomchek
text:
Yeah, speaking of fleets, at the Hyundai dealer I worked at, for every 1 Sonata we received for retail, there were about 3-4 that went to fleet.

Wait a few years and they'll be the next fleet GM cars of tomorrow selling for dirt cheap.

author: fintail
text: I guess it was overdo for an overhaul. The original Versa sedan made me think "Dacia".

author: fintail
text: I can believe it. Check out any airport rental yard. Heck, first new style Optima I saw on the road was a rental. Those sweet leases must be as subsidized as the big Germans.

author: ateixeira
text:
And not in a good way.

Brazil is getting some of those cheap-sters, the Logan is sold there as a Renault. The appeal? They're mega cheap.

author: fintail
text: Dacia Duster is becoming popular in western Europe - I almost want to like it, reminds me of cheaper off brand SUVS from 20-25 years ago, relative to the modern competition. But you can still buy a Lada Niva there too.

author: ateixeira
text:
I wrote Logan but I meant Duster.

They sell a bunch in Brazil. 40% cheaper than a Forester or a CR-V.

Given how bad the roads are it might not be a bad idea for someone on a budget.

author: texases
text: Speaking of the Lada Niva, would you like to take one into space?

author: fintail
text:
I saw that, funny. Those are cool little rigs, although probably terrible to crash and not much better to drive.

Spotted a new style Range Rover today, and a maroon/burgundy Tesla sedan.

author: boomchek
text:
One was on the highway, a pearl white one driving beside a 2010 or 2011 Accord. Funny enough the Accord seemed like it was as wide as the Caddy, almost the same size. I just checked the specs and the Accord is only 0.2 of an inch narrower so no surprise there but the Caddy seems like it is too narrow for such a large car, even though overall it's not a bad looking thing.

The other one I saw was a dealership car in black color I think on the highway as well.

Cadillac needed a newer flagship for a long time but not sure if this one will cut it.

author: robr2
text:
Cadillac needed a newer flagship for a long time but not sure if this one will cut it.

It's not supposed to be the flagship. Cadillac plans on bringing out a proper RWD, 7/S/LS competitor shortly.

The XTS is a placeholder and will stick around for livery service.

author: tjc78
text: I love the XTS, but for some reason it seems smaller inside than my 12 Lacrosse which it is based on. I agree it's not a flagship sedan, but cushy FWD cars do sell (think Lexus ES). I bet they become a great value used.

author: ateixeira
text:
Near the Krispy Kreme store in Gaithersburg, MD.

Owner should not eat too many donuts as it's a fairly compact sports sedan.

author: lemko
text: Wow! I can't wait! Hope they don't disappoint me!

author: robr2
text: It's going to be a large RWD sedan based on the Omega platform. Look for it for the 2015 model year.

author: boomchek
text: I guess it replaced the DTS which I don't see on Cadillac's website anymore.

author: stickguy
text: an XV Crosstek on the road. I like it. Just seems nicer (more substantial? Taller?) than an Imprezza.

author: andys120
text:
I guess it replaced the DTS which I don't see on Cadillac's website anymore.

They had to, DTS market is mostly gone to the Great Showroom in the Sky. I've always wondered why big FWDs are so popular in places like Florida and Arizona but the old folks really think it's safer even where it never snowqs.

author: boomchek
text:
Yeah the DTS has been around since 2001 when it was called the Deville/Deville DTS. I think it got a mild facelift and had its edges sharpened about 4 or 5 years ago and was renames the DTS then.

I liked the Devilles from 01/02/03 as I rented them a few times and for those days they were nice cars to cruise around in.

author: stever
text:
FWDs are so popular in places like Florida and Arizona but the old folks really think it's safer even where it never snowqs

Lot of them are snowbirds. Then there's the friend I got my Outback from in Anchorage. She got another new one and took the old one to her AZ condo.

author: berri
text: Honestly, I wonder if more than 10 or 15% of Cadillac buyers really care FWD or RWD. AWD might matter a bit though.

author: fintail
text: Today saw a new Avalon rental, and a new S5 that I thought might rear-end the Accord in front of it, but hit the brakes in time.

author: stever
text: The FWD ones may feel roomier without the transmission hump in them.

author: andys120
text:
Lot of them are snowbirds. Then there's the friend I got my Outback from in Anchorage. She got another new one and took the old one to her AZ condo.

True, I'm one of those but ironically I have RWD in NH as well as in AZ. My Dad never drives anywhere north of say Orlando but wants FWD and he's not unusual.

author: explorerx4
text: i Miev. Looks a lot smaller/narrower than a Leaf.

author: ateixeira
text: Are those only sold regionally? I haven't seen one in person.

author: boomchek
text:
I've seen one too. Looks like a narrow fiberclass kind of car. Not sure if they're retail units as all of the ones I've seen have those electric car graphics on them.

Well Vancouver is open to this tyoe if vehicle experimentation so you see a lot of funky cars here from time to time.

author: fintail
text: This morning saw a new rental Altima, loaded looking Fusion (really resembles Avalon from the side), Allroad, and not new, but saw a E350 coupe in unusual designo "Mauritius Blue", and the poor 5er GT on a local lot is still sitting there, I think about 3 months now.

author: ateixeira
text: People at the dealer cold not show me the two different ways to open the hatch. I don't even think they want to sell them.

author: fintail
text:
Probably some poor training, average BMW salesman is probably used to only showing people how to lease a base 3er. That GT will eventually be a bargain, I bet it could be had for no more than 35K now, would have been well over twice that new.

New cars this afternoon: 2x 2014 Forester at the dealer, 2x Tesla sedan (one at dealer, one on road), local Lexus dealer literally has 30 or more CTs sitting on one side of the lot, weird.

author: ateixeira
text: Saw a dozen or so new X5 and X1 at Rockville BMW while at a furniture store next door.

author: tjc78
text: New Avalon at the store this morning (great side profile, but the front is just hideous). Then I sat in a family members new 328 xdrive. Meh. I could find better ways to spend 47k. I didn't have the heart to ask, but I'm pretty sure it was vinyl interior. They said they already had the start/stop disabled.

author: fintail
text:
You can load MBs up well into the 60s with a vinyl interior. But....it's a really convincing pleather. That doesn't get to me - Euros making xenons optional or part of expensive packages irks me, with base lights being pretty weak.

I saw an X1 with stop/start the other day, it was noticeable when the engine restarted.

author: andys120
text: Saw a new Cadillac XTS pulling into a parking space. I'm never gonna be a Big-a-llac type but I must say this was the best looking big Cadillac I've seen since the 60s. For a scaled up CTS it wears it's proportions very well and the detailing is very nice. I particularly liked the tailfin-shaped rear lights which added a little flamboyance to a conservative design.

author: tjc78
text:
For a scaled up CTS

No relation to the CTS at all. FWD layout shared with the Buick LaCrosse. I agree its a looker.

author: ateixeira
text:
I saw one yesterday, from perhaps the least flattering angle - the rear view. Looks much better from the front and in profile.

Still a handsome car. 12.1" LCD screen - yes please! :shades:

author: robr2
text:
Euros making xenons optional or part of expensive packages irks me...

Extra charge for metallic paint is what irks me.

author: ateixeira
text: Extra charge for a manual trans is what irks me!

author: fintail
text:
For most of them, that extra manual charge isn't cheap - pack up and move to Europe!

I can deal with the paint thing - that's been a longstanding tradition in Europe. It allows for greater color variety. But in year 2013, decent lighting packages on 60K+ cars should be standard. Some of the base lighting looks 1990s tech.

I visited the dealer today to pick up my floor mats, and sat in a new loaded GL450 - 80K sticker. Nice tank, but would be a shame to ruin something so pretty (pearl white, beige/almond leather) with devilspawn kids.

author: ateixeira
text:
I got to ride in one and my heart was broken - it handled like a pig.

Even compared to my minivan.

They're just too massive. Felt like 3 tons. Shoot, probably is.

author: texases
text: Went this weekend to the Dallas car show, not earthshaking, but I was happy to see the X1 had enough headroom, even with a sunroof. Same for the new Rav4, the Escape, and the C-Max. But the sedans were a washout, I don't see much in the way of a replacement for my MKZ hybrid, they all come with sunroofs and limited headroom.

author: fintail
text: It's a tank. Nothing that tall and heavy can handle like a car. Probably no worse than a Lexus LX though.

author: ateixeira
text:
Even M-B can't cheat the laws of physics.

5401 lbs, no wonder. My van with an F1 car on the roof rack.

author: fintail
text: I'm sure it would be nice for long road trips, especially as a passenger.

author: fintail
text:
Saw 2x Verano today, at least one wasn't a rental.

I also noticed the swoopy H on the rear of the Elantra GT is gigantic.

author: ateixeira
text:
At Fitzgerald Hyundai White Flint.

Not as big as expected, 3rd row will be for tots only.

author: stickguy
text:
that is the problem with mid size 3 rows utes. The seat is barely usable, and if it is up you have no cargo space.

basically OK for running a few extra kids around town, as long as they don't have sports gear!

last year I rode in the 3rd row of an MDX> It was painful.

if you really need 3 rows, you need a minivan. Unless you don't mind driving a Suburban.

author: tjc78
text: Imagine the third row in my Mom's RAV 4. :sick:

author: stickguy
text:
I couldn't believe they ever tried that. I looked at one, and couldn't imagine ever using it.

I guess no one else did either, since they got rid of it in the redesign. Much better as a space for the spare tire!

author: ateixeira
text:
Yep, the 3rd row is gone, and probably shouldn't ever have been there in the first place.

The new RAV4 looks smaller, or is it just an impression? I remember the last one had different wheelbases, the US model was longer than the one that Europe got. Wonder if they went to just one now?

author: tifighter
text: New RAV is two inches shorter in length, half an inch taller, basically same width. Mostly, its a styling trick.

author: ateixeira
text: Is the European model the same size now? I wonder.

author: texases
text: And the length difference is probably just the result of moving the spare tire inside.

author: kyfdx
text:
3rd row? When we test drove a RAV4 in Fall, 2011, I thought the 2nd row felt like a jump seat...

I didn't like it, at all... (well.. the 268 hp V-6 wasn't bad.. )

author: ateixeira
text:
Great engine, the 2GR. For a while that was Toyota's quickest vehicle to 60mph.

Ironic!

author: fintail
text:
I feel like I am seeing 100 new ES per day, now. Also saw a silver Tesla sedan - silver is so played out, it is even boring on that vehicle.

Senior director level manager (aka big bucks) at work talked to me today, told me he is thinking about a Leaf. He now drives a 5er and his wife has a Highlander. Gas prices are irking him. I told him to go for it and take a drive, it might suit his commuting grind well.

author: ateixeira
text:
I think it has decent low-speed acceleration, too.

Also saw a new ES today, impatient driver was honking at people, LOL.

Then I saw a new Accord V6 with Christmas lights (LEDs under the head lights).

author: kyfdx
text: qbrozen has a Leaf...

author: andys120
text:
I watched as a couple of good-sized people got into their Scion iQ. It was a little like watching one of those circus clown car acts in reverse but once in they looked pretty comfortable. It is amazingly small for a four-seater, it appears to be no larger than the 2-seat Smart Car.

I'm seeing a fair number of those out here and Fiat 500s seem to be selling well too (not much bigger than the iQ).

author: fintail
text:
Electric torque, too bad all good things come to an end.

Saw an ES again today, along with probably the same silver Tesla from yesterday, a yellow Dart, and a new style RAV4.

Regarding horns, I told myself the new car would mellow out my horn use(gotta wake up these distracted dolts, the lights don't stay green forever) - it probably has, but I know what it sounds like now :shades:

author: lemko
text: One thing I noticed is, the nicer the car you are driving, the more distracted and idiotic the other drivers seem to be.

author: fintail
text: For me, the faster the car I am in, the more clueless the idiots around me. I used the E55 horn a lot more than I use the fintail's horn - but it doesn't get used zero, either.

author: stever
text:
No wonder I never have any stories for Inconsiderate Drivers, Lemko.

It's all clear now.

author: kyfdx
text: Yeah... it's all based on your own fear of loss.... :P

author: stever
text: lol, yeah, I have nightmares that I'm going to experience unintended acceleration pulling into my garage and wind up totaling both the Outback and the Quest. Oh, the humanity (not to mention the $5,000 loss!).

author: kyfdx
text: Spotted a new BMW 650i Gran Coupe on the road, today... That's the 4-door version of the 6-series... It's very nice...

author: boomchek
text: I like the 650i too, the 4 door one, one of my fav BMW's on the market today.

author: fintail
text: Saw a white Gran Coupe this morning, and some kind of electric motorcycle.

author: robr2
text: Saw a black Tesla over the weekend with Mass plates. I guess the suit by the auto dealers to block Tesla in MA isn't working.

author: lemko
text: ...red Dodge Dart near Montour and Levick in NE Philly.

author: stickguy
text: Darts must be getting out there finally. I saw a black one (or was it red?) yesterday, and a white one today.

author: fintail
text: Saw a privately owned Verano and a white Tesla sedan this morning.

author: odie6l
text:
I spotted my first Ford C-Max in the parking garage at work today. It had that ehh styling to it in natural light.

Odie

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Selling briskly, I'm seeing lots of them.

Spotted a new RR yesterday, what a beast. Looking forward to checking it out in NY. :shades:

author: iwant12
text: A surgeon I work with bought a new black Tesla S and gave me a quick spin around the block yesterday. Impressive acceleration for sure, kinda strange, though, without any exhaust note. Not so sure I like the interior that much. While the seat was comfortable, it could use a better center console with real cupholders. For that kind of money I'd get a BMW or a Benz.

author: qbrozen
text: Do you know which version it is?

author: fintail
text: Saw a white Tesla S today, probably one of the ones I've seen before. Also a couple of new Fusions with private plates, don't seem to be as rental-happy as before.

author: iwant12
text: It's an S model. He said he checked off every box when he ordered it 4 months ago.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
I've seen a few new Fusions as well. Still think the lower trim levels make the car look fat and droopy. Hard to explain but everytime I see one go by it looks like the thing is weighed down like they've got a full load of people when there's nobody actually in it!

I actually think I would spend a couple of bucks more and buy a Taurus instead :blush:

author: qbrozen
text: The S is the model, but there are various levels of batteries and power. I was just curious because all the reviews so far have been of the top-of-the-line range/power version and I'd like to know more about the base version as far as real-world range and power. I'm actually not sure the base is available yet. That's the one that is supposed to start at something like $55k.

author: fintail
text:
I've seen a surprising amount of hybrids.

For the Taurus, the facelift isn't bad.

author: tifighter
text: The new Range Rover in white in the neighborhood. The tires look like rubber bands on those big rims...perfect for off-roading I'm sure.

author: iwant12
text: I think he paid around 90 for it. It's the Performance series. He said it could go 500 miles per charge, but the website says more like 265 miles per charge. I'll ask him again next time I see him what kind of mileage he's getting. The base (53 K) on the website says it achieves 160 miles per charge. Heck, I could drive to work, drive to the lake afterward, and back home easily on that.

author: texases
text:
"He said it could go 500 miles per charge"

He's going to be sorely disappointed. Guess it's like 'that baby'll do 170' or 'yep, gets 70 mpg'...

author: fintail
text: Saw a dirty dark colored Tesla sedan today, unplated, and a new SantaFe Sport with decent body damage down the passenger side.

author: explorerx4
text: Yesterday on the highway there were 2 black Range Rovers in front of me. While still in sight, another black Range Rover and a black Evoque passed me.

author: explorerx4
text: I think the long wheel base and the lower body kit type style contribute to this.

author: jpp75
text: I've yet to see a Dart outside of rentals, kind of odd given how long it's been out.

author: jpp75
text: Saw a new MKZ yesterday, silver 2.0 Ecoboost. Not a bad looking car, but definitely not the car Lincoln needs to make a comeback, much less survive.

author: jpp75
text: I see a lot of new Fusions as well. The front is appealing but for me it's just too big, the back goes on forever. If I wasn't a car guy I would have picked up the last generation when they were trying to unload them for $7k off. Decent car for the money.

author: ateixeira
text:
Saw an Audi A1, a first.

Then an older Skyline.

A new Hyundai minivan, not a 12 passenger model but not an Entourage either.

Mazda Demio, also. Lots of small cars and transport vans there, basically.

They drive on the left and that reminded me of my visits to Suriname.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Spotted my first, looked like a non X/T model with all the trimmings. I didn't realize they were on sale yet.

Also a gorgeous weekend brought out all the "toys" so a few Lexus IS convertibles, a couple of new Z4's, SLK's, a 911 Turbo Cabrio...

author: fintail
text: I'd have expected some exotics in a shady money hideout like the Caymans.

author: ateixeira
text:
Only a couple, an older SL .... can't remember the others.

Saw tons of that in Miami on my way back. Probably drug money.

It is funny, though. "World Headquarters" with only 6 staff there.

author: fintail
text:
Oh yeah, Miami is a paradise for untraceable money. When I was there last year, I saw more exotics on South Beach than I could count - and don't ask where the money comes from.

I would have expected Caymans to be like Switzerland in a way, but maybe just not enough of a road network to make a cool car fun.

author: ateixeira
text:
You could get around the island in 5 minutes in an exotic.

I was impressed by the flow of the traffic circles. The USA could learn a bunch by studying traffic patterns there. Roads are busy yet you almost never stop.

Simple yet impressive.

author: fintail
text: I bet drivers licensing standards are higher, too. I have met people from South America, not known for high standards, who laugh at what goes on here.

author: ateixeira
text:
I'm one of those people, LOL.

Though the Brazilian driving test may go too far in the other direction. They even include a mini psych evaluation.

I passed the test in a stick shift Beetle. Fusca down there.

author: fintail
text:
And I am talking someone from Colombia, which seems to be a level less developed than Brazil. At least the motorcycle tests still require a little wherewithal.

On the new car front, was just out and saw a couple new Accords, Altima, Tesla, Equus (white with chrome wheels, which make the garishness less obvious).

author: ateixeira
text: Saw a black one today, new decorated headlights.

author: fintail
text: New like 2014 facelift? Did it say E250? That would have to be one of the first on the continent, I was thinking they were still several weeks off.

author: ateixeira
text:
I don't think so...maybe wasn't a diesel, then. Must've been a regular E350.

Will they have 2 diesel engine choices?

author: fintail
text:
But not a facelift? I haven't seen one of those yet.

I think E250 is it for 2014, and will now have available 4Matic.

author: robr2
text: There is someone over in Tales from the Sales Front that is awaiting a 2014 E class which is due in the next 2-3 weeks so they may be out already.

author: fintail
text: I had heard end of the month, so that makes sense. Production started a couple months ago, and they have already been seen on the street in Europe/UK.

author: ateixeira
text:
I must've seen a pre-production model. They're not common around here, but M-B sells a lot here and they sponsor all the big golfing events. I'm only a couple of miles from Avenel.

Talk about wealth...

Saw a light silver SLS today on M Street in Georgetown.

Now that I think about it, we saw an SLS in Miami, too. That's 2 in a span of 4 days.

author: fintail
text:
I see at least one late model Ferrari/Lambo/Bentley/Maserati etc every day. I know what you mean.

As the cars are in production now, you might have seen one of the first on the continent. MBUSA HQ is in NJ, not terribly far from you.

author: ateixeira
text:
Subaru is also in NJ, in Cherry Hill. They've grown so they're shopping for a new HQ building, but trying to stay close to the current one.

Audi/VW are near here, in Northern VA, I think.

Oddly enough I don't think I've ever seen any pre-production Audis. Maybe they're smart about staying away from the crowds.

Edit: yes -

2200 Ferdinand Porsche Dr.
Herndon, VA 20171-5884 USA

author: ateixeira
text:
ILX on the way home last night.

Then an RDX on the way in, seems more popular than the ILX. I think the big V6 and the extra space were a good idea.

Coming in - a new Accord, becoming ubiquitous.

Saw sales numbers and Nissan actually sold 100 more Altimas than Camrys sold. Then again price them and the Altima is priced more aggressively. Accord costs a bunch more. You wonder if Nissan is making any margin on those, or just making it up in volume.

author: fintail
text:
I think RDX and MDX have to be the majority of Acura sales now.

Retail sales? Altima is a real fleet favorite these days, while a rental Accord is almost a unicorn.

author: ateixeira
text:
Yup, RDX is #1 (up 285% YOWSAH!), MDX #2, and TL a close 3rd.

MDX is about to be replaced, though. This summer, they already showed it at NY. RDX has had eleventh-consecutive monthly sales records. American love the big V6 over the old thirsty turbo.

ILX outsold TSX, though I'd pick the latter no contest, especially the wagon.

Acura had a great month, up 26%.

author: fintail
text:
I'd pick TSX too - ILX doesn't wow me, styling alone hurts it.

Maybe with the new RLX coming, sales could be up 26.01% :shades:

author: ateixeira
text:
The RLX went on sale March 15, per their press release. They only sold 336.

I actually like the LED headlights, but FWD and a high price aren't exactly compatible.

author: fintail
text:
The lights are so flamboyant while the rest of the car is bland. Odd mix.

I'd give a few months to see what sales will really do - I have yet to see one on the street. A tough fight.

author: ateixeira
text:
Well, I liked the old Gatlin-gun style lights on the Infiniti Q, but it never sold well, either.

FWD, no V8 ... this is a knife in a gun fight.

author: fintail
text:
Weird detail on an otherwise anonymous design, can be tough.

No V8 might not a killer - the competitor V8s sell in very small numbers, maybe just a halo effect. FWD and super-sized Accord styling will hurt more.

author: tifighter
text: I honestly don't think it offers $20K+ more than the Accord Touring. Which is also FWD with the high tech LED lights.

author: boomchek
text:
I'm on a 3 week trip to Israel with my wife and son to see her family. An interesting mix of cars here from Europe, Japan, and the US.

Most popular and common brand here is Mazda, with a ton of Mazda 3's (mostly sedans), Mazda 6's, but interesting enough the last gen Mazda6 is a tiny bit smaller than the NA version. And I've seen a couple of the new new gen Mazda 6, including one wagon.

Next most popular has to be Hyundai, then Toyota (with a ton of Corollas), both Euro and NA spec Honda Civics, lots of euro Accords - our TSX.

Other notable brands here are ton of Fiats, Peugeots, Citroens, Renaults, Daihatsus, Mitsus, VW's, euro Fords, some Chevys, and surprisingly you see a newer Buick from time to time. Very few Benzes BMWs, or Audis here.

We have a rental euro spec Focus sedan - decent car but it's auto and I was hoping for something French or Italian, like a supermini hatch. Plus it seems gutless and I can't pop the hood to check the specs because the hood release has been removed for some reason :confuse:

Gas here is about $2/L (or about $7.50/gallon) so most cars are small and fuel efficient.

Plus car prices are higher than North America, and roads are rough, so car ownership here is very expensive.

A 2 year old Mazda 3 mid trim will run at about equivalent of $25k. Not cheap.

I'll post some pics up when I get back.

Cheers.

author: texases
text:
"because the hood release has been removed for some reason"

My guess is to prevent major pilferage, maybe even engine swapping. Kind of like when Hertz had a recent high performance Mustang, and put security wire on it to be able to check for engine swaps.

author: tifighter
text: 3 weeks..well done. Have fun!

author: boomchek
text:
Forgot to mention....

It was cold as hell but we took the train to the city, interesting enough station wagons in Amsterdam are as common as SUVs in North America. SUVs there on the other hand, are as common as wagons in North America, meaning very few.

It's neat to see a wagon version of almost everything, especially a ton of MB C wagons and BMW 3 series wagons. My kind of city!

author: stever
text:
I can't pop the hood to check the specs because the hood release has been removed for some reason

My sister had a flat in England a couple of years and someone phoned the rental agency for her. They were fast getting her moving again; the odd thing was that the spare was locked in the boot. (Bit surprising that it had a spare in the first place).

author: fintail
text:
Sounds like you're having a blast. Car spotting can be more entertaining than being in a museum somewhere.

I remember I was at FRA right after the W212 wagon was introduced, and they had a line of them parked at one of the doors. It was a good sign.

author: fintail
text:
Many new rides on the road this afternoon - Tesla S, Dart, C-Max, Escape with what I think was a very audible ecoboost, base base F30 3er (no sunroof, base wheels), Elantra GT, Caprice State Patrol car, hideous white X5 with M kit and loud exhaust that screamed "I bought my way in from Russia/China/Arabian Peninsula".

And not new, but the lot that had a 5er GT for several months either sold it or sent it packing - nowhere to be seen. But...another lot a few blocks away now has one, 550i, loaded - a quick peek revealed HUD, adaptive cruise, pano, parking - so it probably has everything else too. Something like 40K on it, they want 35K for it. Not great resale, probably cost 80K new. Weird thing.

author: ateixeira
text:
The competent new Accord may be Acura's biggest problem.

Going away from SH-AWD is a mistake, IMHO.

author: ateixeira
text:
Boy these things are lo-oooong.

I think my MX-5 would fit in its back seat.

Solo driver, probably a lobbyist heading to K Street.

author: ateixeira
text:
Pretty soon we'll be seeing tons of these:

http://www.autoblog.com/2013/04/04/bmw-x4-concept-images-leak-ahead-of-shanghai-- - debut/

Kinda looks like the Jolly Green Giant stepped on the back of your X3.

Why get a Utility vehicle if you can get a vehicle without utility?

Rear headroom and cargo space get lost in translation, I guess.

author: fintail
text:
I've seen it compared to the old 2 door AMC Eagle. BMW is chasing money.

If you're an idiot but can't afford an X6, I have the vehicle for you...

author: ateixeira
text: I bet they sell tons of 'em. A sucker's born every minute.

author: tjc78
text: Is it me, or is there simply a whole lot of ugly going on right now?

author: ateixeira
text:
Ugly is in fashion for sure.

The odd thing is that this time ugly is selling.

author: fintail
text: Money and sense/taste often exist with an inverse relationship, especially as the former rises.

author: fintail
text: BMW and a few Asian makes seem to be conquering that market. Scary when Kias are nice looking cars.

author: ateixeira
text: Wait until the Chinese arrive. We ain't seen nothin' yet.

author: texases
text: Nissan/Infiniti (especially) seem to ape BMWs, and not in a good way.

author: texases
text: ...when viewed from above. SUPER short trunk:

author: fintail
text:
Yeah, Nisfiniti definitely has a BMW complex.

The 06+ Lexus GS was the first one to irk me with a too-short trunk.

author: ateixeira
text: Doesn't bug me. That's a very handsome car in person. You never see it from that angle unless you're Juliette and Romeo is driving.

author: texases
text: Good one. But I have noticed the super-short trunk when I parked next to one. Hate to try and load my Sam's Club stuff through that :P

author: anythngbutgm
text:
No rental tags, but a dealer plate. Black, small wheels and what I presume to be the V6 since the 4 cylinders are supposed to be arriving later on. Looked good, better than the Taurus but not the Azera IMO.

Also, a few "revised" JGC, I think they lost a little bit of elegance with the first 2 model years. The back end especially went from stylinsh and unique to a Lincoln MKX knockoff.

Saw an Accord Sport in Black this morning, very sharp looking car.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Brand new 335i X-Drive in freshened guise.

Hawt and ridiculously quick...

author: lemko
text: Looks like a fastback. Maybe they can bring back a term from the late 1940s and call it a "sedanette?"

author: lemko
text: I was at a funeral for a coworker's father and they had a Lincoln MKT hearse! It was about the ugliest hearse I've personally seen! If my last ride is in this monstrosity, somebody is in for a serious haunting!

author: fintail
text:
Funny, whenever I see a MKT (just saw one yesterday), I think "hearse'. Something so odd about it.

Should be plenty of old Caddy hearses left for your final ride :P

author: lemko
text:
There is a guy in my chapter of the Cadillac-LaSalle club who has several nice hearses from which to choose! If I die an untimely death, I can have a 1974 Cadillac flower car and a choice between a 1963 and 1973 Cadillac hearse. Another guy has a super-cool 1961 Cadillac hearse on which he did an extensive nut and bolt restoration.

How's this for a final ride?

author: fintail
text:
Do any club members rent out their hearses for the ceremonies of departed enthusiasts? That might be kind of an interesting niche market - vintage hearse rental.

Fintail hearse wouldn't be a bad way to go, or for something more modern, a W126 works, too:

author: tjc78
text: S350 Bluetec this morning. I didn't know they made the S class in the diesel.

author: ateixeira
text:
Mail slot opening.

Check out the trunk opening on a Camaro. Smaller than it even needs to be.

author: ateixeira
text:
Driving on the Whitehurst Freeway approaching Georgetown.

Matte black, done right. I've seen a lot of folks try and fail, but this paint job nailed it. It was just stunning.

The car it was on didn't hurt, of course.

author: lemko
text: Look at this tiny opening on the 1965-1967 AMC Marlin:

author: fintail
text: Not just that, but they are all AWD, too. Oddball, probably some deals on them right now.

author: kyfdx
text:
I see a bunch of these, obviously... they look like a much more expensive car.. a class above the normal Chevy, and also seem larger than their competitors...

Maybe, it's all appearance... but, I really like them.... reminds me of a Euro sport sedan..

author: ateixeira
text: Here in the garage. A little Accord coupe-ish but still a handsome car.

author: explorerx4
text: Has a big looking front bumper with narrow vertical slits(for LED lights?) and Explorer like rear lights.

author: ateixeira
text:
It has grown so much.

I think the Impreza XV is bigger than the original '98 Forester now.

Sales were up a bunch last month so I guess it is family sized now.

Get used to seeing lots of them.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Made it to NYC on Saturday for the Auto Show and the sightings as follows:

- Spotted some of the BRZ-FRS club in Connecticut, maybe 6 or 7 of them lined up at a rest area.

- A few members from the Miata club about an hour later heading up 95

- New Acura RDX were a very common sight

Tesla Model S, Couple of Panamera's, latest Boxster S in screaming bright yellow, a few new RR's, new Foresters, XV Crosstreks, new SLK350, couple of new CLS's (one AMG :shades: )

I made the mistake of going down 95 to get there, what a miserable, congested and pot hole ridden disaster that was... My little Impreza took a beating on that road, especially on the Bronx Expressway where hitting a frost heave was like driving up over a sidewalk :sick: Going to take her in to check the alignment and suspension this week...

On the way out, we took the most gorgeous, smoothest 65 miles out via Rt 5? where doing 80mph was considered slow! I got passed by Mercedes after Audi after Bimmer, Lexus, Acura, Volvo like I was standing still. Felt like being back in Germany actually.

And the only cop I saw was one in one of those new G8/SS cop cars sitting in the island of an exit ramp with a busted wheel (rolled underneath) and lol you would think people would have slowed down when they saw him? Nope :surprise:

Needless to say, if you are going to head into the Big Apple, I highly recommend this route! I think it dumped us out around I684. near White Plains.

author: ateixeira
text: New style, with temp tags and all, in Washington Circle here in DC. Loaded up, SX-L V6 I think?

author: ateixeira
text:
the only cop I saw was one in one of those new G8/SS cop cars

You reminded me, last week I saw a new SS, but it only had a "Caprice" label on the back. Was an unmarked cop car, lights hidden behind the grille. He was driving on Westlake near Montgomery Mall. I wonder if Montgomery County police will start using those?

First one I've seen around here.

author: anythngbutgm
text: They had one on display at the show as well, with one of NY finest there to pose for pictures.

author: kyfdx
text: No comments.. just spotted them...

author: explorerx4
text:
So now you know why so many people like to drive SUV's.
I swear the ramp from the Major Deegan to the GW bridge has been a mess since the 60's. Maybe they just never get a chance to fix it.
Kind of sounds like you took one of the Parkways back.

author: fintail
text: Saw a Buick Encore on the road today

author: stickguy
text:
I can vouch that it has been a mess there since at least 1979.

so the 60s is a distinct possibility.

author: tjc78
text:
IMO every road in and around the GW bridge is messed up. There is just so much volume any repairs don't last long. I don't go up there very often at all, but if I'm heading to CT or further north I've become accustomed to taking the Tappen Zee. Yes, its further and still congested but must less stressful.

Saw quite a few new Altimas yesterday, seem to be selling well.

author: stickguy
text: me too on the TZ. I know that in theory it is more miles and should take longer, but I usually don't care. Plus, whenever I am going up that way, it is usually to Hartford or Boston so I have to end up North anyway.

author: ateixeira
text:
With the rims and the styling.

Not common, I see far more hybrids.

Also saw an Avalon on the way home.

author: fintail
text: A lot of SEs in my area are rentals - keeping it grounded to the ground makes for a safer drive on unfamiliar roads, you know :shades:

author: tjc78
text: My mom had an 09 Camry SE it was firmer than an LE but I would bet that they handle at the limits exactly the same.

author: fintail
text: My mom has an LE, kind of roly poly when pushed beyond a straight line. I look at it as a Ciera for the new century. She likes it a lot anyway.

author: ateixeira
text:
The rear spoiler keeps the rear end planted ... at speeds the car cannot reach.

For all the criticism they get, they're actually not very different from most other mid-size sedans. The differences are far more subtle than we are led to believe.

author: texases
text: Edmunds pretty much liked their SE long-termer. I always wonder why the mags test the LE in comparisons, instead of the SE, while using the Accord Sport, for example. (recent Automobile compare).

author: ateixeira
text:
LE does the volume. I bet even the XLE outsells the SE.

For that car, I would opt for the LE, most likely. Maybe even the hybrid version, which is surprisingly quick (better FE than Passat TDI and much quicker).

If I want something sporty, I'd get something else, most likely. The LE should offer a very comfortable ride and great NVH control. SE would add big rims and compromise both of those.

Though I like the new Accord more. Honda did a great job with the latest one. Altima would be tempting only for the seats and the 38mpg + large fuel tank = incredible range. I also like the Fusion and the hybrid version of that.

To be honest, though, I don't want a sedan.

author: fintail
text:
Maybe it's because with so many Camrys on the road, and a demographic that adores them, one is more likely to see a stupid driver in one, and then a bad vibe is created. I know in my area, they are embraced by those who, to be nice, seem to lack situational awareness.

On the new car tangent, saw a new style Range Rover today.

author: berri
text: Haven't had a Camry for awhile, but the SE at least used to be the main rental version at Hertz. The wheels may have changed with the new model, but prior to the 12's I had driven quite a bit in Camry's and didn't really think the LE and SE drove all that differently. If it has over-sized wheels now, I'd avoid it frankly.

author: ateixeira
text: Not designed for enthusiasts, so a model that pretends to be like the SE picks up a lot of flack.

author: fintail
text: Yeah, fake sporty is a tough sin to forgive. Like 90s Pontiacs, or the Corolla S.

author: texases
text: The SE really isn't 'fake sporty', it has a beefed up suspension and tires, along with an upgraded interior and seats. Kind of like the Accord Sport. No body cladding or rear trunk spoiler, unlike the Corolla S...ugh.

author: fintail
text:
Doesn't the SE have more aggressive looking bumpers and maybe a side skirt?

Never been able to embrace a spoiler on such a car, especially one taller than a lip spoiler.

author: texases
text:
Yeah, looks like it has a side skirt, but not too big. And no rear spoiler, at least.

Here's Edmunds take on their SE:

"During the trip [LA to SF] the Toyota proved once again that this is the best Camry since the mid-1990s. And it's a great road tripper. Comfortable. Quiet. And economical.
