Saw another one in the hertz lot last week and it's a large vehicle but similar to the current one and I predict it will sell nicely especially the LTZ model. With the right alloys, it really is a looker and reminds me of the new Cadillac ATX, a real stunning vehicle! GM is starting to finally come out with models that look pretty decent with nicer interiors, an area where they have dropped the ball lately. Am totally in love with the Buick Verano and if I were going to replace my current ride, that would be on my short list. Even though it's a bit pricey, am betting with the right dealer at the right time of month, one could pick one up with a power seat for around 20 large or so. Haven't seen that many in the rental fleets as of yet, a good thing, and it looks nothing like the Cruze, another good thing as they are many in the rental company's I drive for. Chevy needs to work on the Malibu now and bring it up to Camcord standards which I think will definitely happen.

The Sandman :sick: :shades:

author: lemko
text: ...an acquaintance bought a new black Cadillac CTS-V wagon. This is a very rare vehicle according to a guy who works at a Cadillac dealership.

author: texases
text:
" new black Cadillac CTS-V wagon. This is a very rare vehicle according to a guy who works at a Cadillac dealership. "

Some 'car guys' are always complaining about how they don't build enough wagons, enough performance cars, etc, etc. There a reason they're rare, people don't really buy them! I've heard there won't be a wagon version of the new CTS.

author: explorerx4
text: Obviously, your acquaintance is bipolar. I wish I was bipolar.

author: fintail
text: Saw a Tesla S today that lacked the optional turn signal package - they must be building them like BMWs now :shades:

author: andys120
text:
Continuing the theme of new GM iron I saw a new Caddy XTS, the first I've seen in black which looked really sharp (it was either brand new or freshly washed).

When I was growing up in the NYC area black was the dominant color for Cadillacs, I seldom saw one in the flamboyant 50s pastels or reds that collectors so prize. Black nicely emphasized the copious chrome trimming of the 1950s styling.

author: explorerx4
text:
A black Fiat 500 Abarth
and a black jacked up Mini

author: lemko
text: The pastels and flamboyant reds must've been a Florida/California thing. Philadelphia 1950s Cadillacs were most likely blacks, grays, and dark blues reflecting the sober Quaker ethic prevalent among the city's elite.

author: fintail
text:
Saw my first RL-X on the road today, without the headlights it could really pass for an Accord. Also saw a Tesla S on the highway - must not have range anxiety.

Best sighting was a late model Camry with a faux cabrio top. Wait, this was different. Red, black top and C-pillars, A-pillars were still red, with a chrome strip between paint colors. No vinyl, just paint. A weird fake convertible, horribly tacky.

And a truckload of new Kias.

author: Sandman6472
text:
Have started to see many of these on the Florida road ways as of late and agree that they've hit it out of the park here. The new Civic still leaves me somewhat cold...if they could just take the Accord and shrink it by a 1/4, think the Civic would be outstanding. But right now, the Elantra seems to be the class leader as the new Forte is not out yet, or at least not down in my area of South Florida. The Elantra has all the bases covered with the sedan and now the coupe and GT, a real stunning vehicle!

Hopefully the new Corolla will be all that but if not, I think Hyundai and Honda will become the top dogs in the import categories as their vehicles are truly class leading in most respects!

The Sandman :sick: :shades:

author: explorerx4
text:
Chevy Cruze is the #1 seller in that class right now.

In the parking lot at work, a new white ML350 and a black 535 xDrive.

author: fintail
text: Saw my first 2014 IS on the road. Non F-sport model, I was just a few blocks from the dealer and the car still had a window sticker, driver could have been a salesman. Also a white Gran Coupe.

author: Sandman6472
text:
Still hardly see many Verano's on the roads which I don't get...besides being more expensive than the Cruze, it's such a better vehicle and it looks nicer to boot. I saw one and a new ILX at a traffic light the other day and liked the Verano a bit better actually. I have sat in a few at the dealership and the seats are very comfortable also. Call me silly, but the Verano is the only vehicle that I'd trade into right now...strange but true!

The Sandman :sick: :shades:

author: explorerx4
text:
I agree, the Verano is a good looking vehicle.

In the parking lot at work today, a couple of new CR-V's, both white and parked side by side.
Also, a new 3 in the visitor area.

author: fintail
text:
Saw a 2014 IS F-Sport, but this one was again not far from the dealer, and had a window sticker. The cow catcher grille will take some time to become normal.

Also saw a couple Teslas, what I think was an S8, and late model (facelift) CL550.

author: ohenryx
text: I saw a Chevy Volt during my morning commute today. First one I have seen.

author: jpp75
text: I stopped and looked at a new IS 350 last weekend at the dealer, very sharp car and a nice improvement over the outgoing model. Will probably drive one when the lease on the G37x is up later this year.

author: fintail
text:
It makes the old one look ancient. Anyone buying a 2013 IS right now better get a nice deal.

I test drove one - go for the F-Sport, for the trick gauges alone (and a few other niceties). It's less claustrophobic inside (I didn't care for the A-pillars in the old one) - and from inside, you can't see the front end :shades:

author: tjc78
text:
and from inside, you can't see the front end

I didn't like the new Lexus front end at first, but after awhile it becomes less offensive.

The same effect has happened with the "big mouth bass" front ends on the Fusion and new Avalon. I'm not a huge fan, but don't hate it as much. I guess you just get used to it.

author: explorerx4
text: A new ES350 and an new Civic coupe.

author: fintail
text:
If other designers copy it (and they will, as recently the profession is not the most creative), maybe it will normalize. Still kind of iffy though. I see the weird chipmunk cheek Infiniti face is in competition.

I don't mind the Ford, it's an Aston homage. The Avalon is odd on two levels - the big maw, and the fact that it has an upper and lower grille.

author: tjc78
text: Saw a new Kia Cadenza on i95 yesterday near Baltimore. It was a metallic brown, not flattering for the car.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I finished reading this sci-fi book about a cockroach that wakes up one morning and finds himself turned into a human being. So anyway, he moves to Manhattan (where else?) and buys himself a Lincoln 4D in dark brown metallic!

author: tjc78
text: Lol! IMO brown cars need to go back to the 70s where they came from.

author: stever
text: I liked the khaki Honda Element but it was more of a tan I guess. Pretty "rare" bird. Some of the old brown Volvos weren't too bad.

author: tjc78
text: Brown is for UPS trucks! :P

author: stever
text: I'm sure some of the old brown Volvo wagons were confused with UPS trucks.

author: andys120
text:
On Mercedes Pagoda SLs and Porsche 911s. At least it's not just another boring shade of grey/silver.

Two shades of Metallic brown are on the current Porsche configurator. Make mine Mahogany Metallic.

author: fintail
text: Brown is also awesome on a MB 6.9, and can work on a W126 (not my first choice, but not my last). I think the E63 wagon is offered in brown, that could be workable.

author: andys120
text: Yep, dark brown was popular on 60s and 70s Benzes and went very well with an orangey-brown upholstery (MB-Tex?) they had.

author: fintail
text: The old color name was "Havanna Brown", after the early 60s unpleasantness changed to "Tobacco Brown". The "palomino" interior color was popular in the 70s and 80s.

author: stickguy
text: My wife likes a lot of the browns (probably more metallic bronze at this point) on some of the new cars available. But, the only option on the RDX we bought was too light.

author: fintail
text:
Yeah, brown on a modern car needs to be dark to look good. But a nice golden brown can work on a 70s car.

Like a 6.9 - my first choice would be a light silvery blue, but brown is probably my second choice:



For new cars, I drove by the local Lexus dealer and saw about a dozen new IS sitting outside.

author: berri
text: I dunno Fin, my wife grew up on a farm and refers to vehicles in that sort of hue as "calve sh.." - just kidding! Seriously though, I'm personally more geared toward a goldish tannish sort of color because it's the brown hue's answer to silver - doesn't show dirt much and inconspicuous to police cruisers. I know; Boring!

author: bhill2
text:
I'm personally more geared toward a goldish tannish sort of color because it's the brown hue's answer to silver - doesn't show dirt much and inconspicuous to police cruisers.

Yeah, that's the color of my '85 380SE. MB called it 'Champagne'. It's attractive on a Benz but I wouldn't drink champagne that color.

author: andys120
text: Yesterday I parked next to a new BMW 5 series GT, the GT is the one with the controversial hatchback. This one didn't look bad from the angles I saw it at (mostly front 3/4) but I get why people don't like it. It's supposed to be 7 Series based but it didn't look much larger than my old (2000) E39 5er parked next to it. White doesn't flatter many cars but this one looked OK to me.

author: texases
text: Saw a Benz SLS leaving Lowe's yesterday, followed it a few blocks. Impressive, not what I'd call beautiful...how much fun can somebody have with that in town?

author: fintail
text:
Most of them are just to show off...so lots of fun on the boulevard.

Saw a 2014 E-class, white.

author: fintail
text:
A poopy (excuse the expression...or not) brown won't work on a modern car, but it works when such colors were trendy. A friend of mine who mocks 70s cars has different names for each maker's brown - each having to do with doo-doo.

Gold can work sometimes, but can also be kind of beige.

author: fintail
text:
Not brand new, but saw a W221 S65 today, sounded like a muted WWII fighter plane. If only gas was cheaper. It was cooler than the murdered out current style ML63 I saw soon after.

Local Chevy dealer now has a line of 4-5 new Impalas, one at the end looked like the base model.

author: Sandman6472
text:
On the way up to and back from Orlando yesterday must've seen a dozen or so new Imapala's so they are starting to really show up now and it's an awesome looking vehicle compared to the rental fleet from 13 and earlier! GM did an exceptional job here and should be commended. Am very excited about getting one in the fall or winter for a trip to Orlando or Tampa...want to get some seat time in one to really see how good the vehicle is. On this same note, I'm not a lover of larger vehicles but the new Tahoe's we've driven lately have been very nice drivers and it's time for GM to do their magic and bring it into the 21st century. And first thing they need to do is get rid of that ridiculously wimpy steering wheel, hell, even the Chrysler 200 has a nicer and meatier wheel to hold on to! A small complaint I know but it's something that has to be used daily and to me, it's those little touches that really make or break a vehicle...that attention to the tiniest detail no matter how inconsequential it may be. I guess that's what puts the luxury brands above the mainstream ones, it's their attention to detail to make even the smallest thing a work of art. I guess there's no one perfect vehicle out there but some of these guys are pretty close! Just hope that on my next vehicle I can get some of that refinement for myself!

The Sandman :sick: :shades:

author: tjc78
text: Yeah that steering wheel is too thin. I recently drove a Yukon Denali and was stunned at the wheel, in an otherwise really nice vehicle.

author: fintail
text: Had time to kill earlier, went car browsing. MB dealer had facelift E coupe cabrio and wagon but no sedans sitting around. No GLK Bluetecs, but did have an ML. Talked to the salesman who sold me my car - he won a company sponsored trip to Germany and got to tour Sindelfingen, visit AMG, etc - he was still excited about it. He's an actual enthusiast - drives a similar Bluetec to mine, also has an old 911S, has had W126 and W116 - I like to see things like that. Lexus dealer had maybe 15x new IS, all but one a non-F-sport, only saw one IS350. BMW had a 7er with a white interior (not creme, not platinum - white), and an M6 Gran Coupe MSRP 126K. Also an active hybrid 3er with MSRP a couple hundred bucks shy of 60K - that's almost the cost of my E. Toyota dealer had an Avalon with zero options, must be unusual - and a metric ton of 4Runners.

author: stickguy
text:
saw a new MDX in the wild (1 for sure, and I think a 2nd one). Hard to tell from a distance, because it really does look a lot like my RDX, just bigger. Fancy LED headlights though. I think it is going to do well, but 10K more for same basic platform, just a little bigger with a tiny 3rd row and a few toys, is a large premium.

Also a Ford C-maxx. looked smaller than I expected out and about.

author: andys120
text: I spotted a new (2011-12?) Spyker-era Saab 9-5, a nice looking vehicle. I also saw a 9-3 station wagon from late in the GM-era and a misbegotten "Saabaru" (an Impreza re-badged as a Saab 9-2X). All of these are rare sights even in Saab-loving New England.

author: fintail
text: Saw a 2014 Silverado sitting at the dealer, and an electric RAV4 on the road (ugly nose).

author: fintail
text: Saw a white Tesla S in my building's garage today - never seen it before, I assume it was a visitor (no charging stations here).

author: stickguy
text: new model must be selling, because I am seeing them all over the place.

author: fintail
text:
Rode in a co-workers rideshare van today - new Grand Caravan with just a few thousand miles on it. For a base model fleet vehicle, it was surprisingly not bad. Definitely cheap, but it was smooth and quiet enough, dual AC worked well, seemed to be put together just fine. Sliding doors had power windows, which is something not seen back when I was a kid riding in minivans. A very honest vehicle.

I also saw a new Boxster driven by an old couple - looked to be in their 80s anyway. It looked highly optioned, and was a blinding kind of electric blue color. The old guy was watching me as I slowly jogged by (warm day), I think hoping that I would give it a stare, so I obliged and nodded.

author: stickguy
text: stopped at the VW dealer, which is right next to the Porsche dealer. Man, did they have some seriously nice stuff parked outside.

author: fintail
text: Saw a 2014 E-class on the road, didn't have the deluxe lighting. Also saw a couple Tesla S.

author: fintail
text:
Saw a white 2014 E wagon today, admittedly driving away from the dealer's holding lot.

Also a red Tesla S, parked at a high end body shop, appeared to have rear drivers side door damage.

author: qbrozen
text: i've been saying many of these. I was just commenting the other day to the wife that I see those more often than the Leaf.

author: lemko
text: I can't recall the last time I saw a Leaf outside a car show. The only thing more scarce than a Leaf is a MiEV.

author: fintail
text: Come to Seattle - the tree huggers love them - subsidized 199/month lease helps too, more money to devote to the energy guzzling suburban tract mcmansion.

author: explorerx4
text: Lotus Evora - It was kind of a strange color for that car. Not sure if I liked it or not.

author: bhill2
text:
I can't recall the last time I saw a Leaf outside a car show.

I saw one yesterday, doing about 80 down the carpool lane of the southbound 101. Hope there was an electrical outlet at the end of the journey.

author: qbrozen
text: haha. I've done that with mine. I've actually had it up to 95. The battery does indeed deplete is a great hurry at those speeds!

author: lemko
text: ...a coworker's new black Cadillac ATS w/V-6 engine.

author: fintail
text: Spotted a new MDX with the 754 headlights.

author: stickguy
text:
spent last week at the shore (Jersey) in one of the richest towns anywhere. the money down there is just depressing (when it isn't yours).

anyway, it is a fantastic place to look at nice iron. Among other things, a new big roller just street parked like a "normal" car. More BMWs and Benzes than you could shake a stick at. Mulitple Panameras.

but my favorite, the first Jag F type I have seen in the wild. Man, I want one of them. Bad. Power ball special of course, but a few tickets I can afford!

author: stickguy
text: I have seen a few of them. really have to see it from the front or up close to tell the difference from my RDX.

author: berri
text: Saw what I believe was a red mid 60's MB roadster today. A replacement for the Fintail???

author: lemko
text: Margate?

author: anythngbutgm
text:
I counted (5) of them this weekend between trips thru MA and one to NH. The headlights were the only way I could decipher them from the hundreds of GEN 2 models around here.

Also spotted and R8 V10, an XK-R and a mint condition early NSX that looked like it just rolled off the showroom floor.

And one that I wonder if the resident GM fans can answer. It was one of the current Sierra pickups in blue that looked like it was well cared for but the underside had a ridiculous amount of rust. I was behind it on the highway and the rear axles was completely brown, the shock mounts were covered, the U-brackets, the brakes. Then passed around the side of it and the frame was full of rust as well, not full but the welds, sections of the chassi... this thing was a bucket. :sick:

My buddy had rust problems on one of his lemons back in 2006 but the rust on that thing was confined to the bumpers and the spare tire well. This thing looked like it had been sitting in a salt bath for it's life.

author: fintail
text: Stopped by the MB dealer to begin the wild goose chase for a couple fintail parts, and what do they have on the showroom floor? A CLA. Papers on the car said it was just for display, no demos. I was actually kind of surprised by it, it really kind of resembles a 3/4 scale CLS.

author: stickguy
text: Stone harbor/Avalon.

author: tjc78
text: We were in Sea Isle Saturday night. No shortage of new expensive iron there either !

author: fintail
text: Saw a Mitsu MiEV - it looks...special.

author: fintail
text: A new Mazda 6 has appeared a couple spots away from me at home. Appears to be a standard model - no sunroof anyway, I don't think it had leather either. I did look and see it was a J VIN.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new Impala LTZ on the road - pano, fancier wheels, etc, it was red, not a rental.

author: lemko
text: Black Fiat 500-L with white roof on Bingham Street near Robbins in NE Philly.

author: explorerx4
text: a new ES hybrid

author: stever
text:
Black, and going gangbusters on the Interstate (at least 85) before cutting over three lanes to an exit.

Dealer plates.

author: tjc78
text: Encore.... Tiny little sucker.

author: Sandman6472
text:
Haven't seen one yet at the airports but I like them. A bit too pricey but bet they'll be quieter than the Sparks I've driven. Buicks tend to do a nice job with their noise reduction and interiors as the Chevy looks decent enough though a bit low rent.

The Sandman

author: tjc78
text: You can hear a pin drop at 80mph in my Lacrosse.

author: Sandman6472
text:
The Lacrosse and Regal I did drive was extremely quiet and was very impressed even though I only drove them each for under 10 minutes. I've not been able to snag any Buick product for an extended run yet as someone always seems to walk a bit faster to the particular vehicle than I do. In fact, yesterday was the first time I was right in front of a vehicle I wanted to drive that was chosen to go to the auction so I grabbed it even though my co-worker tried to nudge me out of the way...he did it in fun so we both laughed but he actually gave me a small body slam to move me away! I know my time will come to get a Buick for a longer trip once season ramps up again...gotta try that Verano!!!

The Sandman

author: imidazol97
text:
>You can hear a pin drop at 80mph in my Lacrosse.

Just returned from a trip to Pure Michigan Saturday at 78 mph and can carry on a normal voice conversation in a 2003 leSabre with 160,000 mi and Michelins worn about 60%. Cobalt also has a similar quiet ability although there's some air noise from underneath above 70 mph (new Michelins).

[IMG] http://www.michigan.org/blog/wp-content/uploads/PureMichigan.jpg [/IMG]

author: tjc78
text:
I've driven a similar vintage LeSabre and yes very quiet, my 98 Eighty Eight (same basic car I believe) wasn't bad either.

I recently drove the 04 Grand Marquis from south Jersey to Richmond and was surprised how quiet that thing still is. Managed to squeak out 25 MPG running at 75-85 the whole way. Not bad for a dinosaur!

author: berri
text: I actually saw a very basic new Impala LS on the road with cloth interior, so they are not all loaded ones on the lot. No rental sticker on it, but an old guy was driving it.

author: tifighter
text: I was at the SLC airport a few weeks ago. Avis had the new Impalas everywhere. Not a bad looking car.

author: berri
text: I think the Impala is a pretty sharp car too and it's styling lines and cues may actually stay fresh longer than some of the new Ford stuff, but of course styling is a very subjective and individual thing. Unfortunately, the large sedan is a shrinking market I'm afraid. I think if GM had put that kind of styling effort into the Malibu they'd have a home run on their hands. It gives me some hope that GM might be starting to return to it's former styling leadership! I guess time will tell the story one way or the other.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
I was in Boston over the weekend and I had my car parked in two different garages during that time. Each one had an Avis rental hub and not one of them had the new Impala. Old ones sure, but no new ones so far. They had a ton of Cruzes and quite a few Rentibus, but no Impalas. Oh, they even had a couple of Volts as well.

I was kind of disappointed because it could have given me a chance to view one up close without having to deal with going to a dealer and getting the runaround...

Still a pretty scarce car here in N.E. I have only seen 2 on the roads so far.

author: robr2
text:
I was in Boston over the weekend and I had my car parked in two different garages during that time. Each one had an Avis rental hub and not one of them had the new Impala.

Probably because the Impalas are at the airport location. Boston is in full tourist mode at this time of year and the hotel locations are geared toward residents renting for the day or weekend.

author: Sandman6472
text:
Now that the tech is out there and with the success of the Caddy ATS, hopefully the next generation Malibu will get the attention it needs to be one of the best midsizers out there. We drove one up to West Palm yesterday, an LTZ unit, and it is a looker but the interior is still a disappointment unfortunately. It drives well enough but it's really dated compared to the new Sonata I also drove yesterday...it just feels so old school. If GM just gets all the pieces to fit, it could give the Accord and others a good run for the $ as there are many folks who want to purchase American and the Buick Regal being a bit to expensive.

GM knows what they have to do and I know they will step up to the plate with the next generation Malibu.

The Sandman

author: stickguy
text:
and saw a huge # of the new Rav4s. Wife thinks they are ugly, but they must be selling a ton of them.

also saw a number of the C Maxx Fords. either they are finally getting out there, or just a coincidence.

author: fintail
text:
Lots of the RAV are rentals, too.

Saw an ATS rental today, barcode read LCAR (luxury class).

author: Sandman6472
text:
Fin, saw a black Fintail like yours over by the Sixt place here in Lauderdale...it's been there for a few months now and never seems to move. A real sharp vehicle!!

The Sandman

author: stever
text: My second in the wild - this one was parked in front of a Fresh Market (upscale grocery).

author: kyfdx
text:
Must be spending all of their saved gas money...

We like to go to Fresh Market, but mostly just to window shop. They have some specialty items that are harder to find at regular grocery, but a lot of their staples are just overpriced... Looks good, though..

author: fintail
text:
Ha, local dealer to me must have at least 50 Leafs sitting around the lot, they even used an adjacent vacant lot to store them. Seriously.

I've been in podunk areas for several days now, haven't seen any remarkable new cars. No Teslas out here!

author: stever
text:
Fresh Market has really nice flowers so we usually grab some for my mom. Got a good deal on a two pack of orchids this time and gave some to my sister-in-law for putting us up.

Camping last night got me thinking (actually it was the rudenik who cranked his rattling diesel rig up and swamped the campground with fumes, but that's a different discussion), you'd think more cop shops would embrace hybrids and plug-ins. Using just the EV mode, they'd be able to sneak around the neighborhoods more easily, especially with some quiet tires on.

author: lemko
text: ...white 2014 Chevrolet Impala travelling north on Bingham Street near Levick in NE Philly.

author: fintail
text:
That big diesel truck was probably also registered as a commercial vehicle and is being used as a business expense. They do that in WA anyway - and I think the older ones have no emissions equipment, and the newer ones remove it. When you see a 00s era truck "rolling coal" being driven by the stereotypical compensator driver, you know something had been modified.

Cops also like to catch people and go on adrenaline-filled chases, not going to happen in a hybrid or especially something like a Leaf. I don't think an EV is going to be any sneakier than a slow moving conventional patrol car either.

author: stever
text: It wasn't all that big though - just an F-150 size, not even a double cab.

author: fintail
text: Dodge diesel pickup drivers seem to be the best at the loud annoying truck. It doesn't take more than a rig driven by a wannabe cowboy who lives in a tract house and works in a suburban office complex (it's hilarious how much of that exists in the PNW - gotta have a truck for the yearly trip to Home Depot!).

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
I'd love a video game where I can blow up Dodge 2500 diesel trucks and Harley Davidsons. (without occupants, of course).

If you've ever ridden a bicycle in traffic, you'd understand.

author: texases
text: A guy I know with one of those Dodge diesel pickups talked about how he was going to tweak it 'to get 30mpg, like a friend of mine did'. I just had to bite my tongue....

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Lots of people put various 'chips' in them, but it sounds risky.

author: texases
text: Those add-on controllers are risky, for sure. Long discussion on another forum about how a guy fried his $50k Ford diesel with one, brand new, and of course Ford AND the controller maker said 'tough luck'...OUCH.

author: fintail
text: So he's going to tow it half the time with a larger truck?

author: fintail
text:
Often the same group own both. With occupants wouldn't be much of a loss either.

http://youtu.be/ZdDxjge5hmY

Only in a second or third world area, which is a lot of the country.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: bad karma, that.

author: fintail
text:
Fun comments there.

It's really past time that such trucks have license endorsement requirements. Of course, that wouldn't be "business friendly", so there's no chance. Especially now that I am visiting in a less urban area, I see a lot of stupidly driven large trucks on the road.

author: stever
text: Scion FR-S, with FR-S vanity plates.

author: berri
text: While out this morning I saw a Scion coupe in an odd color that looked like metallic grey primer. It seems like Ford and Toyota share a trait of occasionally putting out an odd and ugly color that generally only sticks around for one model year. But flubbing a grey; usually it's some green, yellow or purplish hue when it happens.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: and the point of those license plates...is? LOL!

author: stever
text: The plates were a big help to me to help me ID the car.....

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: True, all new cars should have bar codes that you can swipe with your cell phone to make an ID.

author: stever
text: If there's not already an app where you can snap a photo and have the car identified, this group should write one. The posters in here could do it in real time!

author: berri
text:
"True, all new cars should have bar codes that you can swipe with your cell phone to make an ID."

Careful buddy or the Snowden paranoia people will be chastising you for that thought!

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Yeah, probably would be illegal--well it would only identify the car not who owns it.

author: fintail
text: Saw a looooaded A7 TDi today, 77K sticker.

author: fintail
text: Only if a money sucking fake private sector company like BAH is involved (insert broken down car emotorcon)

author: fintail
text: New car has popped up in the spot next to mine at home - new style Malibu, not a rental. Parked next to a new Mazda 6. Lots of newer cars in the garage these days.

author: andys120
text:
Lately I've noticed some new AWD wagon joining the automobile fleet in NH. I've seen several not- very-Mini Paceman All4s in various colors. I was prepared not to like them because they'e just too big for a Mini Cooper but the grey/green example I saw with dark grey-spoker wheels looked cool in a butchy way.

I've seen two or three new Audi (A4) Allroads today in black and silver. They are not much bigger than my old '98 A4 Avant/B5 but ride a bit higher-- nice looking cars that split the difference between a CUV and a station wagon nicely.

author: fintail
text: Went by a high end body shop today to get advice on my little paint chip (they said just touch it up, not worth performing an actual repair - yes, I am OCD) - there was a Tesla S with no front clip, and a C63 coupe with side damage. I also remember I saw a Panamera Hybrid the other day.

author: fintail
text: Today I spotted an Equus with private plates, an Acura soft-roader with 754 headlights, and an Infiniti Q50.

author: robr2
text: Fin: What are "754" headlights?

author: anythngbutgm
text:
I spotted not one but two of the new Mitsubushi Outlanders this morning. Then again, in person they look like something that could have come out in 2003 so nobody but car fans probably recognized it as new...

Another new RAV4 at work this morning, took the wifes new car to work today. It's a green color which I like the best so far. Sucker was over 31 grand, yikes.

author: fintail
text: This goofy look that Acura thinks is the next big thing:

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Looks like something you get in a cereal box.

author: bhill2
text:
"Looks like something you get in a cereal box."

Looks like something you get in a dirty bathroom.

author: lemko
text: ...dark gray 2014 Chevrolet Impala near Knorr and Rising Sun in NE Philly.

author: explorerx4
text:
a Gray CX-5, Green Fiesta, Maroon Nissan Pathfinder. I had a 2011 Explorer, which looks somewhat bloated. Pathfinder looks like a rejected Explorer design.
On the road...
Twice i have seen Nissan Rogue 'Krom' Editions. Cheap looking rear center dual exhaust feature.

author: fintail
text: Saw another new MDX today (maybe the same as yesterday), 2x Tesla, SL63 with recent plates, Pathfinder minivan.

author: Sandman6472
text:
Saw one in the ready line and it is an impressive looking vehicle...have yet to drive one but just can't wait. Last weekend on my 4 Ft. Myers to Lauderdale trips I had 2 Jeep Liberty's, a Sentra and something else that slipped my mind right now, senior moment! Did a couple Orlando runs this week and had a Hyundai Tuscon and the next day a Hyundai Elantra...these were all going to the Manheim auction in Ocoee.

Things are starting to pick up a bit and hopefully we'll be back in full force after Labor Day!

The Sandman :sick: :shades:

author: bhill2
text: Sandman, once you do drive one please be sure to post your opinions. It's been awhile since Chevy has made a sedan I wanted, and this one sounds promising.

author: stever
text: In the parking lot of the natural foods coop in Taos. Talk about a cab forward design.

author: fintail
text: Was out goofing off with a friend, stopped by a few dealers as he is a perpetual browser. Drove by an Infiniti dealer who had a Q50 sitting outside. Jag dealer had signs on each XJ (my friend loves those) that claimed 10K off, and also a 699 lease deal on a SWB car. Audi dealer had A6 and A7 TDi - 64K and 78K MSRPs on those. Stopped by MB dealer to ask if the little rock chip I got via negligent road works would be a lease problem - it isn't nearly big enough for them to notice, so that's cool. Now just to deal with the running light. Saw a loaded to the gills designo 13 E550 with a 79K MSRP, and a 14 E550 cabrio with a 77K MSRP. Also saw a Cadenza on the road.

author: tifighter
text: Anyone see Juice post recently? Seems like its been awhile, but maybe I'm not following the right posts.

author: stever
text: Seems like he's been on vacation all summer.

author: fintail
text:
Hopefully just in Brasil for a long spell rather than something unfortunate.

For new cars, I saw a rental Cadenza on the road today, and a 14 E wagon with freshly issued plates.

author: imidazol97
text:
Kia Cadenzas are already in the rental fleet. There goes the marque down the drain.

I looked for one at my local Kia dealer and couldn't see one anywhere.

author: fintail
text: I've seen a few on the road, and the Flyertalk rental forum has many sightings. Kia is HUGE in fleets, at least in my area.

author: explorerx4
text: Front and rear styling are kind derivative, Accord front, Sonata rear, but it's supposed to be a pretty good sedan.

author: fintail
text: Just saw an E63 wagon - totally debadged, but you could see and hear it.

author: lemko
text: ...light gray-silver Cadillac ATS near Montour and Passmore in NE Philly.

author: tjc78
text: Saw a burgundy one today too. It just seems to small for a Caddy.

author: lemko
text: I got to drive one at the Philadelphia Auto Show back in February thinking it would make a nice car for my wife, but I liked it. The car I drove was the turbo four. I think Cadillac is going after the BMW 3-Series. The CTS seems to have grown to the 5-Series size. If any car is too small, it's the XTS which is too small to be the flagship Caddy. That, and its lack of a V-8, will see me in my DTS indefinitely.

author: stickguy
text:
cylinder snob? The 306+ HP and 6.7 0-60 not good enough for you?

we do have different tastes, size wise. I think it is a grossly oversized whale that I would never want to have to pilot around!

author: stickguy
text:
pretty sure the first one I ever saw on the road. No idea of the range, but it was a brave owner. It was on the NJ Turnpike, and flying (probably doing close to 80 when it passed me). Had delaware plates, and it was heading south near Princeton, to something like 60 miles from there.

did look like the Lotus it was derived from though. Only new what it was when I saw the name on the back.

author: andys120
text:
This week I've seen two late model cars wearing those stick-on portholes, one was a Mitsu Outlander, the second was an otherwise slick looking Mercedes CLK.

Did she really want people to think her Benz is a Buick? :sick: :confuse:

author: lemko
text: I can't get past the psychological barrier of the lack of a V-8. A V-6 is OK for my diminutive wife, but I DEMAND a V-8! To me, the XTS is apologetically petite. Even my DTS is kind of small. Something the size of my Grand Marquis seems perfect for me. The 1977-era GM B and C body cars fit me like a custom tailored suit.

author: lemko
text:
I've seen those stick-on portholes on all kinds of cars and trucks! My neighbor has a Chevy Avalanche with them on it!

How did you get the Emotorcons?

author: andys120
text:
How did you get the Emotorcons?

The e-cons and format helpers appear at the bottom of original posts but not on replies.

[Insert emoticon for typical half-***sed Edmund's IT]

author: tjc78
text:
I have the XTS's poorer cousin (2012 LaCrosse) and an 04 Grand Marquis. The Lacrosse actually has more front and rear legroom. The Marquis is wider inside with more headroom.

I would buy an XTS, but have to say that Caddy's flagship should be Lexus LS / BMW 750li sized with an optional V8 and RWD.

author: andys120
text:
The Lacrosse actually has more front and rear legroom. The Marquis is wider inside with more headroom.

Anyone who has ever sat in back of a CV/GM taxi can tell you the legroom sucks (I'm only 5'6")

I would buy an XTS, but have to say that Caddy's flagship should be Lexus LS / BMW 750li sized with an optional V8 and RWD

The XTS is not intended to be Caddy's flagship, that will likely be a sedan versionof the Emiraj concept car and will be V8-powered and RWD/AWD.

I think the XTS is supposed to appeal to the old folks who are looking for something to replace their Deville/DTS and are convinced the need FWD even tho many or most live in the Sunbelt.

author: kyfdx
text: Dealer tags.. at the supermarket. Diesel

author: fintail
text: Got behind a 14 E cabrio in traffic, top down, driver met the assumed demographic :shades:

author: lemko
text: ...black Hyundai Eqqus on Rising Sun Avenue near Cottman in NE Philly.

author: fintail
text: Got behind an unplated new white Touareg TDi in traffic today, gagrice's twin.

author: texases
text: Don't know if it's just because I notice them more, but in Dallas it seems like new Cayennes outnumber new Touaregs 3:1...

author: stever
text: On display at a city garden, of all places.

author: kyfdx
text: We had an X1 for a loaner, this past weekend.... I really liked it.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
I assume you probably got the Turbo 4 model? Was the power enough for the size and weight? My wife really likes them as well, but I'm steering her towards the Mini Countryman instead.

I'm itching to try that motor in the Z4 but I don't want to waste the dealers time driving something I probably won't buy.

author: fintail
text: The same in my neighborhood, lots of trophy wives etc around.

author: texases
text:
I'd sure want to drive the X1 and the Countryman back to back before going for the Countryman. Seems like the X1 has more to it. Just sat in both though, haven't driven either.

A rwd X1 turbo 4 is on my short list of future vehicles....

author: kyfdx
text:
240 HP... I'm partial to inline-6s, but it's got more oomph than the 6 in our X3.... It's a real screamer compared to the turbo-4 in a Q5..

They have an easy button to lock out the stop/start feature, too.... So, that's a plus...

It's a snug wagon, though... feels like a sedan from the front seat.. (which I like)

author: tifighter
text: today, a 2014 Tundra. When in doubt, add more chrome...

author: anythngbutgm
text: E350 4matic in White. Love what they did with the headlights. Still my favorite large sedan...

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I really like that Diamond White metallic paint option they offer.

author: ohenryx
text:
Spotted a Murano Cabriolet on my drive in to work this morning. First one I've seen in the flesh.

It's different, I'll give you that.

author: texases
text: As much as the 'Cross Cabriolet' is hated, can anyone name a new convertible with equal or more room for 4 adults?

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: phaeton?

author: texases
text: Maybe I should have added "for less than $100k"... :P

author: Michaell
text:
Maybe I should have added "for less than $100k"...

Jeep Wrangler 4-door?

author: robr2
text:
Jeep Wrangler 4-door?

How about something that doesn't rupture a kidney??

author: Michaell
text:
How about something that doesn't rupture a kidney??

Well gee whiz, I thought we were looking for a convertible that had room for four.

Now your're putting in all these other restrictions.

:-)

author: fintail
text:
Under 100K, room for 4 (ok, not particularly roomy), decent ride - 3er, E, A5 cabrios come to mind, with the MB being roomiest and most expensive.

Speaking of new cars, I was at the free dealer operated car wash today, and a guy in a black 2014 E350 talked to me about drying the car off after it is washed (even though it has driers, I pull over and do detail work after it is washed).

author: texases
text:
"3er, E, A5 cabrios come to mind"

Yes, all pretty tight for several 6+ footers. All about identical, according to MS autos:
http://autos.msn.com/research/compare/interior.aspx?c=0&i=0&tb=0&ph1=t0&ph2=t0&d- t=0&v=t116256&v=t116280&v=t115812&v=t117296

I guess that's because the E cab/coupe are based more off the C sedan chassis.

author: kyfdx
text:
Walking through a full parking lot this morning, my wife exclaims with disgust, "What is that?"

You guessed it.. Murano with the top down. It truly is hideous.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
On Friday I came up on an S-class with badging "CSS 500"... Did some searching and it's some sort of "performance" Arm for Merc?

It was an older model, maybe early 2000's and this car was immaculate. I've seen a few big Mercs from this generation that have a good amount of cancer around the lower rockers, door trim and wheel wells but this one looked like it rolled off the showroom floor.

Also another blast from the past that looked like it had just rolled off the showroom floor, an 87' - 88' Honda CRX Si. That was a sight to see as I remember how popular they were back when I was in high school...

Then there were floods of new RAV4's, a few Model S cars, A sexy new Boxster and a hopped up Porsche Panamera.

author: texases
text: Never heard of a 'CSS' - what did you find out about it? I didn't find anything.

author: bhill2
text: Did the badge look like it may have been altered? Is it possible that someone added the "CS" to an S 500 badge? Maybe his or her initials? I have never heard of a CSS either.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: CSS is a Benz tuning operation in Europe--could it be? But it's not factory authorized or anything like that.

author: bhill2
text: That sounds more probable.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
My apologies leaving that post hanging, I didn't have much time to respond yesterday.

It looks like "CSS" is a performance company that soups up Benzes as well as other makes such as BMW. I guess it's not really a sighting rather, a One-Off "Tuned" model. Oh well...

https://www.google.com/#q="css+performance"+MERCEDES

http://www.chiptuning-files.net/VehicleList/vehiclelist.html

author: fintail
text:
Yeah no such car as a CSS and I am unaware of any tuner using those letters. Odd that it might be a car with a mere chip tune, but maybe the owner is proud. Closest thing to me is a CLS500, which would be a MY 2006 only vehicle.

Saw a truckload of new Touaregs being delivered to a rental car lot today.

author: explorerx4
text: They take their lunch hour very seriously. Don't contact them between 12 and 1 pm.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
New Infiniti "Q50" which IMO should remain the G37 but still...

Great looking car, especially in white.

My neighbor who is a contractor bought a runabout to offset his fuel costs of his Chevy 2500 pickup. Loaded Toyota Yaris...

Lastly, a sexy SLS hardtop in Silver.

author: fintail
text: Saw a 2014 E-class and a GL63 AMG

author: stickguy
text:
an F type. On the road (GSP outside NYC). Red with the top down. SOunded real nice pulling out of the toll booth in front of me. it was an S type per the badge. Had vehicle manufacturer tags.

It was sharp. I would be very happy to have one. as long as I don't have to pay for it!

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Very nice. I have yet to hear one in person myself.

Not sure how many folks here watch a TV show called "Covert Affairs" (Excellent show btw) but this season has introduced a character who happens to drive one and you can tell by some of the action shots that Jag is a sponser. Every now and then they give a gratuitous minute or so of just various camera angles as it's driving along, including some nice amplified engine sounds

If there was one car I would replace my beloved S2000 with, it would be that one.

author: andys120
text: I got my first good look at the new Jaguar XJ, in fact I've seen the same black sedan several times and it's quite spectacular IMO. It's almost enough to make you forget what Dick Van Dykes's XJ ended up looking like>

author: explorerx4
text: I saw one of those the other day, but in pre charcoal'ed condition.

author: fintail
text:
Must be an Italian built model.

Saw an RL-X today - so they've sold at least 2 now. Also another (!) GL63, and an X5-M driven in an expectedly douchebaggy manner (dopey illegal u-turn on a busy street).

author: bhill2
text:
I saw one of those the other day, but in pre charcoal'ed condition.

I never read anything about what caused DvD's XJ to flamb. Does anyone know?

author: kyfdx
text: Diagnosis: Murder

author: qbrozen
text:
Actually saw a Mitsu i-miev in the wild! It was even on my street. Too bad I wasn't in the Leaf at the time. 2 e-cars on the same street in the boonies of NJ has to be like alignment-of-the-planets rare.

This morn, spotted a new Infiniti JX with temp tag. Not bad looking. Reminds me alot of Lexus, though. Like an enlarged RX330.

author: lemko
text: ...but it's certainly unusual! I spotted a white Chrysler 300-C somebody converted into a 4-door convertible! Unfortunately, it was spoiled by a roll-bar looking device at the B-pillar.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: the roll bar was probably to hold the body together.

author: kyfdx
text:
Fairly new... parked in front of my house.. No idea whose car it was, or who they were visiting.. This is Mercedes' version of an M3 (sort of)

White with a black roof (carbon fiber or transparent.. .didn't really take time to look)

Sharp, though!

author: stickguy
text:
the Impala was out on the road, and I think the first I have noticed in the wild.

Fusion not new, but I got to check out the sticker (it was in my neighbors driveway, and is a demo since he is a Ford salesman). Not bad looking. It was an SE. nicely equipped, with basically everything I needed (power drivers seat, moonroof, XM, alloys). Sticker was about 27.5K. This was a 1.5l model (odd, I thought the small engine was 1.5l).

author: explorerx4
text: The largest engine, NA 2.5 is base, 1.5(2014) and 2.0 turbo engines are upgrades.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new MDX with the zillion lights - looks bigger than the previous model.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Audi SQ5, there's some great sounds coming out of that one, and man did that thing move.

Fiat 500L - "The Italians are coming!"

More than a dozen new MDX's

Audi R8 Cabrio in white - Gorgeous

Couple of refreshed Volvo S60's with the new nose and flashy wheels. Classy looking car...

New BMW M6 - Sounds like the Forth of July if you are lucky to hear one at WOT...

(2) new Infiniti Q50's, both silver

A couple of new Lexus IS which the online pictures do ZERO Justice to, they look really slick in person. Best looing in the class, followed by the Q50 and new 3-series IMO

Mini Paceman, 2-door AWD

Tons of new Subaru Foresters, and a few of the revamped Outbacks with the proper round foglights out front.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
but still a crazy sight:

"Gentleman's express" Mercedes Benz S-klasse, V12. Only this one was flat, and I mean like Charcoal black, with black lettering, black anodized wheels and exhaust tips. This one also had full LED lighting at the front and rear, and those custom Quad pipes out the back made wonderful noise.

author: fintail
text: Stopped by the local MB dealer to ask about the E250 - they didn't know when any were coming in. They did say CLA will be in on Wednesday, but all are spoken for. New S is due in November. Saw a GLK250 Bluetec on the lot, being inspected closely by a middle aged couple. There was a nice E63 on the floor, loaded, 116K MSRP.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
One Black and one in a salsa red color which was probably the best one I've liked so far.

I do wish they offered a manual with the AWD like Audi and BMW do. Or even the Acura TL...

author: ateixeira
text:
Blue color seems to be popular. Saw one without tinted windows, and then one with tinted windows 5 minutes later.

Seems to have jumped out of the gate pretty fast.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Actually started seeing a few new Corollas, one of them was an "S" model in white which IMO, actually looked pretty good! Maybe a touch better than the new Civic, but still no Mazda 3

Also saw a new Accord hybrid, the subtle touches made it noticeable from the dozens of Sports and other models in the lineup.

Spent the day in Boston yesterday to watch the Pats take down Atlanta. Counted 13 new Tesla's on the 120 mile roundtrip! Becoming a common sight around the suburbs. Also met some friend in town from San Fran who got a new Impala as a rental for the week. Jet Black, 4-cylinder, actually had leather interior and a moonroof, base 16? wheels/rims... 3200 miles on the clock and the rear window was already broken and a nice puff of blue smoke upon startup... Yay quality...

It was a rental so can't judge the thing just yet...

This morning a loaded black Q50 passed me on the highway doing about 90. Man does that thing look good. Also another Accord hybrid and another Audi SQ5.

Don't know what made the weekend better, the Pats being 4-0 or Eli going 0-4

author: ateixeira
text:
Accord is funny - Sport looks great, but the plug-in model is hideous. Have yet to see the hybrid (which falls in the middle, I suppose) in the flesh.

I like the Q50 also, and I see lots of them because there's an Infiniti dealer about 2 miles away. I see them daily.

author: fintail
text: Saw a 4 door Fiat 500 today, and a big sighting, a 2014 S-Class, on the road no less.

author: lemko
text: ...black Volkswagen CC in the Auto Zone parking lot near Oxford and Bleigh in NE Philly. I've also been seeing a lot of the latest generation Nissan Altimas with the "Pure Drive."

author: ateixeira
text: I always felt like getting rid of Maybach would let Benz be all it could be. Look how sweet they look now...

author: ateixeira
text:
Still have not grown on me, wow these are just painful to look at.

The trunk looks like it needs to be about 2 feet longer to look acceptable.

author: fintail
text:
The new S does seem to be 80% of a Maybach for 30% the cost. It was an odd experiment.

5er GT...I wonder if most we see are 2010 models, can't imagine they sell many now that they aren't a novelty.

author: fintail
text: I wonder how many Altimas are rentals - seems half the rental cars on the road here are Nissans.

author: fintail
text: Saw a red CLA in traffic today. Looked small.

author: berri
text: I think that's been true for awhile. Nissan's at the majors, but Chrysler 200 / Avenger's at the cheapies. Ironically, around here at least, it seems like Nissan dealers offer some of the crappiest deals. Doesn't make sense to me to push rental cars over retail sales, nor why one would pay more for comparable Altima versus so many other nice alternatives.

author: ateixeira
text:
Altima is interesting - in certain colors is looks awful, but in other colors it works. There are some odd creases in that design.

Then again they got a 38mpg highway rating so I'm sure form followed function.

author: texases
text:
"There are some odd creases in that design. "

Nissan and Infiniti are leading the way with 'odd creases' in lots of their designs. BMW's not far behind...

author: ateixeira
text:
But in some colors is looks totally fine, even attractive. So strange.

Nissan is hit or miss in terms of design. I like the Versa Note, but not the sedan (at all). The Juke is ugly but the Cube is unique. I don't like the Rogue or Murano much, but the Pathfinder works. Max and Sentra also seem fine.

Not a whole lot of family resemblance except maybe the big sedans.

author: fintail
text:
The new Sentra seems to be what the Altima was 20 years ago.

And the Altima...maybe a 21st century Cutlass Ciera.

Pathfinder would be fine as a smaller minivan and a suitable name.

author: ateixeira
text:
Sentra's back seat is HUGE. It really stands out. Significantly roomier than the Malibu, which is supposed to be one size up.

I haven't driven one but reviews are really disappointing, no one seems to like the way it drives.

Altima is more well liked. Big fuel tank + 38mpg = range of a diesel without the cost.

I'd be more interested in a Versa Note if they put a decent powertrain in that thing. Maybe a bigger fuel tank, as well.

Pathfinder sales are through the roof. They should just have given it a different name. Sure looks better than the bolt-upright Quest!

author: fintail
text:
I'd still lean towards Accord vs Altima, simply for aesthetics.

Most Quest and many new Pathfinder I see in my area have a rental barcode. The latter could be renamed the Mallfinder, for its demographic and off road prowess. Funny how it changed from a competent enough, if old looking, small SUV.

author: ateixeira
text:
Same, I like the Genesis (you probably know that) and the Accord reminds me of the Genesis.

Honda's packaging is also a little better, base Altimas come with cheap wheel covers, and no backup cam either. Add that stuff and the Accord's a better value.

Pathfinder seems to change every generation, radically so. From unibody to body on frame, and back. More than once. What does the name stand for? It has an identity crisis.

No one bought the truck, and people line up for the psuedo-minivan. A neighbor bought one to replace an MDX. They used to complain about premium fuel cost so I'm sure fuel costs were a major factor.

author: berri
text:
" MDX. They used to complain about premium fuel cost "

I understand the 2014 MDX still does even though the latter Lexus RX crossovers don't. I don't understand that logic at Honda. Around here at least, premium is almost 50 cents/gallon higher. But then I'm a bit leery even on the Pilot because there seem to still be issues with the V6 engine cylinder deactivation system and consuming oil.

author: stickguy
text:
big debate on the RDX forums. I have used regular and could not tell the difference. it is not required now, just recommended.

I think it is a marketing deal as much as anything (luxury cars are supposed to use premium, right?)

author: texases
text:
My ES300 'recommended' premium, even though it had the identical engine as the V6 Camry, which recommended regular. Same for the RX and the Highlander. I used regular, never had a problem.

With Acura there area some differences between their engines and the Honda versions, aren't there?

author: stickguy
text:
minimal at best I think. and if there are, probably at the upper range of the tach where I never usually go!

if the CR is the same on the Accord and RDX (I think they share the engine) than I really doubt it.

author: texases
text:
Take the Pilot and MDX:
Pilot's 3.5 l puts out 250 hp, 10.5:1 CR
MDX's 3.7 l puts out 300 hp, 11.2:1 CR

So there's a basic difference for those two.

author: fintail
text:
I'd like a revised Genesis more - the current one is getting long in the tooth. The Accord is similar, lots of BMW hints in their styling. Oh those designers. Accord is probably the best value in its class right now, a mainstream car I'd actually consider.

Pathfinders traditionally have been very old when finally changed, no surprise sales were weak. Now it's another glorified minivan pretending to be butch...perfect for these times, I guess.

For something like a RDX. premium might be recommended, but that's not a performance engine. It'll do fine with regular, maybe put the good stuff in on a rare day for fun. For a tuned or high output engine, then go for premium.

author: Sandman6472
text:
Saw a new '14 Corolla on the road today in white...meh, pretty plain Jane folks especially in white...think we'll pass. Got to drive some interesting rentals a few days ago. A new Pathfinder but the tranny was screwy and I had to take it back to the dealer for Sixt...when it got up to 40 and I let off the gas pedal, it shook and shaked violently, a real nasty drive so it was sent back for a look see at the cvt. Drove a black ML350 to the dealer for an oil change and wow, what a vehicle...just awesome. Then I had a Bug going back to the dealer for some work and it wasn't that bad actually.

Had eye surgery on Wednesday but going back to work tomorrow...I won't have to wear glasses anymore for my myopia...it is gone as is the astigmatism. Took a couple days off to recuperate.

The Sandman :sick: :shades:

author: fintail
text:
Good luck with getting a good car.

I think I will just mention the oddballs at the Avis/Budget I pass by most days. Today they had a Prius, maybe not usual away from the west coast.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Sounds like you drove the Pathfinder that hadn't undergone the recall for bad torque converters.

https://www.google.com/#q=NISSAN+TORQUE+CONVERTER+RECALL+PATHFINDER

My neighbor bought one of the first new Pathy's and had theirs replaced under a TSB before the actual recall was announced. Since then, she says the thing drives like a dream and hasn't had an issue since (Something like only 7000 miles but still).

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Speaking of the ML, the current design is kinda old isn't it? I think they have tweaked the styling and features over the years, but the current one dates to something like 2009 IIRC. I have seen quite a few of the new ones tho, easily identifiable with the rear chrome treatment on the lower bumper...

Ironically, I work with a gentleman who is still driving a 98' ML350 with something like 300k on it. It's needed a bunch of different things over the years and it's got some rust on various sections of the body but he says the overall vehicle is a tank and he won't get rid of it "till it stops moving under it's own power"...

author: ohenryx
text: On my commute this morning, I spotted something rather unique. It took me a few looks to figure out just what I was looking at. A Volvo S60, lowered, with rubber band tires. Very strange looking. Very.

author: fintail
text:
The current ML is MY 2012+, but it does kind of resemble the 06-11 style.

Those early models were troublesome, I bet many electrical components have been replaced.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
You might have seen an "R-design" model, noticeable by the rear ducts under the bumper and the more aggressive wheels and tires.

http://pictures.topspeed.com/IMG/crop/201303/volvo-s60-r-design-1_600x0w.jpg

I find these, (as well as the XC60) to be some of the sexiest cars in their respective class, a smidge moreso than the new Infiniti Q and way more than 3-series. I drove one back in 2012 and despite being a front-biased driver, the thing was an absolute hoot to drive and stupid quick... Would have bought one had the wagon (V60 next year) had been available at the time...

author: ateixeira
text:
It's all new but but you can hardly tell by just looking at it.

I test drove the old one when it first came out. M-B had an event at FedEx Field. I have to figure out why they dropped me off their mailing list, because I didn't get an invite for the new launch. LOL

Did it get the new, smaller diesel? May be better to keep the big one since those might actually haul/tow a little.

author: fintail
text: ML is still the V6, probably for like you mention, potential heavy duty use. GLK is the 250.

author: ateixeira
text:
Makes sense.

The ML looks a lot better than the GLK to my eyes, but I'm not shopping for either, really.

$44k plus per cargurus for the GLK250 diesel .... I'd either spend more and get the ML or spend a lot less and get a different box.

Speak of the devil - here's AB on the next one:

http://www.autoblog.com/2013/10/04/mercedes-benz-glk-spy-shots/

author: fintail
text:
Base GLK250 Bluetec is 38K. A comparably equipped ML (to a 45K GLK) will probably be 55-60K. Of course, these prices are negotiable. And of course, everything is optional.

Not my cup of tea either...if I had the money, I'd just go all in and get a GL Bluetec, but that'll be much pricier and much more posh. Or privately import an old G and not pretend.

author: fushigi
text:
Congrats on the eye surgery. Note that if your DL shows you have glasses you may want to get it updated. Wouldn't want an LEO questioning your vision should you be involved in an accident.

(My wife had eye surgery in 2002 and never regretted it once.)

author: Sandman6472
text:
Funny, the wife mentioned this to me when she came home yesterday. Hopefully they will not make me take the eye test again and pay another fee as mine is valid till November of 2018. I will give it some time to make sure I heal properly and will wait till the eye doctor tests me to make sure that I am perfectly fine.

The Sandman

author: Sandman6472
text:
You are probably right here but it was really a nasty drive back to Nissan and I would be a very angry customer if it were my vehicle! A new vehicle should not act like this as Nissan has used CVT's for awhile now and the bugs should have been gone long ago. Just look at the new Accord...no complaints that I've heard about their CVT tranny but maybe they have just handled any problems with minimal reporting to the auto press. Either way, I'd hope Nissan would've compensated folks with a couple of free oil changes or something for the hassle of going through this ordeal...give the customer something of value to make up for this weird experience!

The Sandman

author: stever
text:
When I had mine done, the doc gave me a wallet card. Didn't bother sticking it in the glove box, but I did get the restriction removed the next license renewal.

Saw some new Fords on a small dealer lot the other day (while my wife was at the eye doc), but just some trucks and SUVs (Edges, mostly). Nothing in the wild.

author: fintail
text: Stopped by the MB dealer today, because I spotted a new S-Class. I got to sit in it. It's pretty impressive - like a mini-Maybach in a way, especially the rear seating, which is pretty decadent. This one was a corporate demo with no sticker - so I couldn't get the full option list - but I could see it had pano, distronic, sport, AMG wheels, fancy stereo, and the rear seating might be part of a package too. MSRP on this one supposed to be ~120K. Also saw someone taking delivery of a red CLA. Dealer has some E250s on their website, but none on the lot.

author: robr2
text:
Saw a matte gray one parked outside of a CVS north of Boston. NH plates.

At least I thought it was an SL. MB has come out with so many models, I can't keep the alphabet soup they've made straight anymore.

author: Sandman6472
text:
Have seen a few of them this past weekend and think white makes the vehicle look very plain yet the red is outstanding as well as the gray color. Also saw a new CLA but was totally underwhelmed, guess I still think the C Class is the nicest one of them all. Don't get me wrong, I'd drive one in a second but I'd prefer the C if I did have a choice. But doubt that will ever happen since I don't think I could, or would spend that much on a vehicle. I think $20k or a little above would be the highest I would ever spend on a depreciating asset. But one never knows what could happen in the right situation...all I do know is that I am going a bit more lux with the next vehicle no matter what. We even discussed that today over lunch and I got no resistance what so ever except that whatever I do end up getting, the wife will be able to drive it when she wants to so I kinda said...o k. Since we have different driving styles, I am a bit hesitant to let her drive my Civic as that constant on and off the gas pedal just drives me nuts and wastes so much petrol...I prefer a constant pressure with my right foot at all times and a smoother drive at all times. But I've always disliked whenever someone, even the kids, drove my vehicle as I like things a certain way and hate when things are "changed". I even hate it when someone looks into my closet or drawers without me being around...a personal flaw I know but I am a bit protective of my stuff.

The Sandman :sick: :shades:

author: lemko
text: Can you get an S-Class as lavish as the old Maybach, i.e. reclining rear seats, window curtains, etc.?

author: fintail
text: There is going to be a special LWB and Pullman version of the new S-class that will pretty much be like a Maybach for half the 2004 MSRP. The car I looked at had rear bucket style seats that reclined.

author: fintail
text: Saw a couple new Fiat Ducato-based Dodge vans this morning, along with a 2014 Mazda 3 (I don't think it's pretty).

author: ateixeira
text: Really? I think it's the closest we'll get to an Alfa hatchback here. The sedan isn't as good, though.

author: ateixeira
text:
Friend's dad has been having health issues and could no longer climb in and out of a Boxster, so he sold it and got...an Acura RDX.

I will have to hit him up for a ride once he's feeling better.

author: fintail
text: Yeah, I saw a sedan. Meh. The hatch has always been the best 3.

author: fintail
text: Saw a RL-X (so they've sold 3 now) and a CLA with aftermarket wheels, that was quick.

author: robr2
text:
and a CLA with aftermarket wheels, that was quick

Well since they probably leased the car they might be doing rent to own on the rims.

author: fintail
text: I don't know if the highline lease crowd is the same as the rent-a-rim crowd, at least in my part of the country. Even a lease on one of these is probably going to be too dear for that demographic. They might be cheap Chinese wheels of debatable metallurgic quality, however.

author: robr2
text:
I don't know if the highline lease crowd is the same as the rent-a-rim crowd, at least in my part of the country.

It's a CLA not a CLS.

The driver is probably a $30K millionaire living in his parent's basement financing $15 martinis on his Green Card.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Did a walk around on a 2014 Impala this AM. I dunno..nothing earth-shattering here...it sort of says to me: "Oh, GM finally gets it and is making cars that look like they were built in 2014".

author: fintail
text:
And a 35K car (as most will be) is still above average, and out of reach for the majority of buyers. At that level it is really no different than the classic base C/3er/A4/IS/G etc that has been a lease favorite for eons. It just has more flash.

You still need good credit and some cash flow to lease - not as easy for youngsters as it once was. Unless mom and dad sign for it or something.

author: fintail
text: Compared to the previous one, which was a mediocre at best 2006 car still being made in 2013, it's a leap forward.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: yeah, it does look up to date. I didn't drive it, though, because the salesman was hovering over me like a yellowjacket on a piece of chicken. Very annoying. The man was hun-GRY.

author: fintail
text: The cars change, the tactics don't. In an area like SF, I have to imagine such a car is a slow seller, so anyone showing interest will be pounced upon.

author: stever
text:
Just read a consumer review today where the dealer "lost" the customer's car keys.

And yet, after a five hour ordeal, the customer still purchased a car from them. Just makes me shake my head. That trick must be as old as me.

author: lemko
text: That's why you always bring a spare set of keys.

author: robr2
text:
You still need good credit and some cash flow to lease - not as easy for youngsters as it once was. Unless mom and dad sign for it or something.

One doesn't need that much cash flow to be approved for a $349 lease - especially if they are living at home.

I know you are partial to MB and probably dislike the idea of MB reaching out to the bourgeois.

author: fintail
text:
You'll also need a few grand up front, some kind of income, and good credit. In this devolved economy, those all exclude a lot of people.

It's nothing new, I do find it funny that someone is trying to denigrate the car or its customer base when it is a segment that has existed since boomers started weaseling their way up and ran to 3ers and 190s 30 years ago.

:P

author: fintail
text: I can believe it. And that gets me too - dealer treats you like crap, and you buy from them anyway? WTH?

author: robr2
text:
It's nothing new, I do find it funny that someone is trying to denigrate the car or its customer base when it is a segment that has existed since boomers started weaseling their way up and ran to 3ers and 190s 30 years ago.

I just had to with your remark about the "highline lease customer base." You and I both know that the CLA is being offered in order to bring less affluent buyers into the brand. There's nothing highline about the CLA, S3, forthcoming 1 series and IS250.

Now those 3's and 190's from 30 years ago - those were highline.

author: stever
text:
That's why you always bring a spare set of keys.

Have you priced replacement keys and fobs lately?

What you bring is your cell phone, and then you call the cops. You might be talking grand theft in some states. :-)

author: fintail
text:
Nothing highline about a base C/A4/3er/IS, etc either. This is nothing new, and real world pricing will be the same as an existing base C. MB is desperate for the illusion of youth, and this will do the trick. Seeing as the car has been a virtual sellout so far, it looks like the plan is working as intended.

Those basic cars in the olden day boomer yuppie era had vinyl seats, no toys, no real higher spec than the modern cars and no better image other than maybe that the brands were less common then.

author: ateixeira
text: It's a big, cushy ride, with a smooth engine. I think you need to drive it to appreciate it, perhaps even on a long trip.

author: ohenryx
text:
What you bring is your cell phone, and then you call the cops. You might be talking grand theft in some states.

Nah, not necessary. I stand in the middle of the showroom floor, and let rip in my loudest voice:

I WANT MY CAR KEYS. NOW

Take a very deep breath, let the words come out from your diaphragm. Deep, solid, loud, reverberating from the rafters. Repeat every 10 or 15 seconds until the car keys are in your hand.

Pay absolutely no attention to anyone trying to tell you, "Please calm down, we're looking for them." Go for deep and booming, not shrill.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Sounds like a Toyota. So when do the domestic fans start referring it as an "appliance"?

Bet it never happens once.

author: ateixeira
text: Well if you want a sports sedan you get an ATS or CTS. The Impala doesn't pretend to be anything but a competent full sized car.

author: kyfdx
text:
That's exactly it... They tried this stunt on my mother. I was about 20 years old, and I told the salesman that if he didn't have the keys in her hand in 30 seconds, he was getting his --- kicked..

Sort of the same thing... especially, since I hadn't hit anyone since I was 12 yrs old, and wasn't really planning on trying it then, either.. ;-)

Worked, though...

author: explorerx4
text:
I went with my mother to buy her Fiesta a couple of years ago, she was close to 81 at the time.
When the salesman asked if he could have her keys to check her trade in, she reached in her pocketbook and put them on the desk.
Then she reached in her pocketbook again, held up another set of keys, and said, 'I brought my spares with me'.
It caught me completely off guard and I was mortified.

author: kyfdx
text: Way to go, Mom! lol

author: anythngbutgm
text: Just spotted a new Blue Corolla S on my walk at lunch and a company down the street from me has a Black Model S in the parking lot. Also saw a brand new Mazda 3 hatch last evening, what a looker.

author: tifighter
text: Grey Cruze diesel on the freeway. Far right lane, going about 55mph. Seems like someone was going for a high score on the mpg reading.

author: fintail
text:
Saw one of my favorite local new cars - a white on white BMW Gran Coupe. What a combination.

Also saw a 2014 E-class, these seem to be selling very well.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Gorgeous Model S in white of all colors. Best color I've seen on this puppy.

And another Corolla S at Starbucks this morning, this one in red. Ironically parked next to a new Rav4 in Green. It was like Christmas...

author: ohenryx
text: Saw one in a parking lot yesterday, while walking to lunch. Wasn't at all sure what I was looking at, first one I ever saw.

author: ateixeira
text:
Suzuki, actually.

That's a clone of the compact GM pickups. Basically a place holder in dealerships to fill a void in their lineup.

author: anythngbutgm
text: C63 AMG. Dear lord that thing sounds incredible and goes like stink...

author: andys120
text:
I saw a new Range Rover Sport, parked downtown. I could tell it was the new design by the way the roof sloped down @ the rear (ala RR Evoque).
It was snow white but managed to look good in spite of that.

0

author: robr2
text:
...while out today:

black Jaguar XF
white Viper driven by a blond guy wearing Ray Ban aviators and a green sweater over his shoulders
brown Buick Encore

author: anythngbutgm
text:
"white Viper driven by a blond guy wearing Ray Ban aviators and a green sweater over his shoulders"

LOL, did he take a detour from Santa Barbara to San Diego by way of New England or something?

author: robr2
text:
LOL, did he take a detour from Santa Barbara to San Diego by way of New England or something?

He must have been on his way to Greenwich from Nantucket.

author: explorerx4
text: New Cadenza, looked pretty nice. CX-5, looks pretty plain.

author: ohenryx
text:
Suzuki, actually

You're correct, it is a Suzuki, not a Subaru.

That's a clone of the compact GM pickups.

That part turns out not to be correct. Quoting from Wikipedia:

The Suzuki Equator is a mid-size pickup truck based on the Nissan Frontier and assembled by Nissan.

...

Sales of the Suzuki Equator since 2009 have been 5,808 overall, and it rarely sells over 200 units per month.


Easy to understand why I've never seen one before.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Nothing really special about them IMO, but they seem to be selling rather well already. Already as common a sighting as the new RAV4...

Reworked XC60, I like the subtle changes like the integrated exhaust and a sleek new Mahogany color.

Spotted a few more Model S's in Providence, RI area.

author: anythngbutgm
text: Also saw a new Tundra with MA plates (sold) and another out for a test drive. The looks of it aren't as bad as the pictures and for some reason the paint and chrome work I found very rich. It's a pretty classy looking rig IMO...

author: ateixeira
text: Probably a 5 layer pearl white paint job. You get what you pay for. :shades:

author: ateixeira
text: I bet he was playing the soundtrack from Risky Business.

author: ateixeira
text:
I saw a Cadenza on K street the other day.

Nicer than the Azera twin.

Also saw a Versa Note. I like it better than the sedan, and much better than the old hatch. All it needs is the Juke's powertrain and it would be a cute little hot hatch.

author: ateixeira
text:
I stand corrected.

The GM clone was badged as an Isuzu.

Both of those are no longer on the roads.

author: fintail
text: Yesterday in eastern WA I saw a truckload of new Infinitis, headed for Spokane I am sure. Mostly Q50s and a few soft roaders.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
2 new Tundras both black Limiteds.

Q50 in a gun-metal grey color, looking better and better each time. It's a nice update IMO.

Green Corolla, base model, hubcaps...

A couple of new RLX's and Cadenzas, I think the Cadenza is nicer.

author: ateixeira
text: There's an Infiniti dealer 2 miles away so I see new Q50s on the daily. Looks better in person than in photos. I'll have to test drive one at some point.

author: fintail
text: Saw a RLX out here in the small town world, kind of odd as the nearest dealer must be nearly 2 hours away,

author: stickguy
text: on the highway. I caught it from behind. Distinctive rear end for sure. Did not know what it was until I got close enough to read the (giant) lettering on the butt. Unique styling. Might not be for everyone, but you do notice it!

author: tifighter
text: In Amsterdam; saw the new BMW i3 today. Silver with the black roof. Bigger in person than it appears in the pictures.

author: ateixeira
text: Saw several of those in Times Square this weekend. Made me think they might be using them as livery cars?

author: explorerx4
text:
I saw a new RLX yesterday, too.
Very plain with some strange styling.
Quad exhaust pipe, but they were hidden and there were these bright sliver trim pieces in the bottom corners of the rear bumper.
It looked like they changed their mind about the exhaust styling at the last minute and eliminated the through the bumper style.
Rear lights looked cheap, too.

author: explorerx4
text:
It looks like they literally added a drive train to the front of an 8x12 cargo trailer.
Look at the rear suspension and you will see what I mean.

author: fintail
text:
It's like a 4:3 scale Accord. I don't understand that car.

On the new car note, I spotted an E250 Bluetec sitting on the local lot, so I had to stop by and have it started so I could hear it. There's definitely a minor amount of more noise, but I don't mind that. EPA highway mpg estimate is 10 more than the V6 - with 4Matic no less. I am very curious about this car.

Shots of the 2015 C-class interior have been officially released, too - a mix of good and bad. I like the upmarket HVAC controls, dislike the static tablet style screen.

author: ateixeira
text:
That looks like my custom setup on my van - my Magellan actually resembles that and sits in the same position, at the top/center of the dash.

It does look tacked on but they needed a lot of space, and being closer to the driver should help make the maps legible. I'm sure M-B will use a sharp, HD display.

author: explorerx4
text: Parked on pedestals outside an assembly plant in Toledo.

author: fintail
text:
It'll be a nice big screen anyway. Maybe I will warm up to it. A HD display might make it worth it. The current display, although the interface is far from the most efficient, is still one of the best at any price point.

When I went to look at the E, salesman (who is an enthusiast) dropped a hint that a C wagon might be coming. C250 diesel 4Matic wagon would have me buying instead of leasing.

author: ateixeira
text:
The execution will be so important...done well it could be eye candy. A low quality pixelated display would be an eye sore.

I wouldn't mind that smaller diesel engine given my GPS says my average speed is a whopping 22 mph in DC traffic. It used to be 20mph so I changed my commute path to a longer, more scenic route.

I had a C wagon loaner once, from a Subaru dealer, of all places. Made me scratch my head as Fitz doesn't have an M-B franchise.

author: texases
text: Hope thieves don't think it's removable...

author: fintail
text:
I wonder if it's the same unit from the CLA. I haven't seen one operate in person.

The smaller unit will return better mpg overall. I can average around 40 on the highway, but in my sub-20mph commute, am usually down around 23-25.
