text: Not really a spotting since it's just from a popup ad (grrrr)... yet another version of "the future" (get in line behind the Segway I suppose)

author: odie6l
text:
looks like they smacked a Scoot Coupe enclosed body on a Spyder.

Odie

author: fintail
text: I didn't know Elio was still a thing. If that's the future...it's a motorcycle with doors and none of the fun.

author: texases
text: Elio's made a bunch of noise lately, mostly of the 'once we get $XXX million more we'll be ready to go!' type of thing. Waste of time/money, IMHO...

author: PF_Flyer
text: Keep your hands and arms inside the ride until it comes to a complete stop

author: stever
text:
Nissan NV 2500 with temp tags on I-25 and a Transit Connect EV on a side street off Central Avenue (aka Route 66) in Albuquerque.

Not new but saw a Smart car on the freeway with a rancher's cowboy hat on the dash that amused me.

author: explorerx4
text:
In the parking lot at work...
A new Ram quad cab and a BMW 4xx power folding hard top.
Also, new TLX, with some kind of, I hope, after market body kit on it.

author: PF_Flyer
text: My most interesting smart sighting was on the DC Beltway at about 4PM one day. The driver looked a little too tense to be intimidated by my Versa

author: laurasdada
text: On the road this morning, a BMW i8 and Caddy ELR. Electrifying!

author: PF_Flyer
text: Not new, but getting pretty rare... A Daewoo Lanos with no wheel covers, a missing gas filler door, and a late teens guy with his seat leaned way back, windows open and music thumping

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: that's the way they came from the factory

author: PF_Flyer
text: And it was making SUCH a pathetic sound when he was all the way down on the gas. Sort of a resonant, hollow sound... whhhhaaaaaaa

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I actually borrowed one of those for a few days when a friend was thinking of investing in a Daewoo dealership way back when. My answer was "Ah......NO".

author: laurasdada
text: Aston Martin Rapide, Florida plates. Nice. But, only for those who can't afford a Jag... Is that right? Yeah, thanks Jeremy Clarkson.

author: fezo
text: I so wish I had taken a picture back when. There was a Daewoo dealership up here and at that point it was dead. What inventory there was sat under a foot of snow. The only light was a neon OPEN sign.

author: fintail
text: I remember when Daewoo hit the market, the local dealer was also the MB dealer (and Toyota, I think). The MB and Daewoo shared the same building, which made for unique signage.

author: andre1969
text:
These Daewoo stories that paint such a miserable picture make me think of a time when I went with a friend of mine, back in college, to go look at cars. The Hyundai Elantra had just come out, and he wanted to give it a try. I remember it being crude, noisy, slow, sounding strained, and at the end of the drive, there was some kind of burning smell coming from under the hood. Needless to say, he didn't buy it. I think that was 1991. At the time, he was driving an '89 Ford Escort LX hatchback coupe, but he wanted a new car, and his brothers were going to get the Escort. Ultimately, he held off and got a '92 Corolla.

I actually thought the Daewoos were kind of neat looking little cars, in an offbeat sort of way. I think the bigger one, the Leganza, was ultimately redesigned and sold as a Suzuki something-or-other.

author: explorerx4
text: In the parking lot at work a new white Audi TT.

author: Michaell
text: The Elite is $45K or thereabouts.

author: qbrozen
text: Our '03 Pilot EX-L stickered at $31k. It is now $38.5k. Inflation calculator tells me $31k in 2003 is $40k today, so I guess they've held the price down. Still hurts to see these prices, though. Ugh. Pretty soon I'll be sitting in a rocker telling the kids what things cost in my day.

author: robr2
text: Not only have they held the price down, they have added features such as the back up camera, bigger wheels and tires, maybe more airbags, et al.

author: Michaell
text: That's probably true for all cars. In a previous wife-time, we bought a new Accord LX in 1993 for a "one only at this price" of under $14,000. Today that's about $23K. You can easily get the LX for under $20K and it's a much more loaded car - new tech, new gadgets, new safety features.

author: texases
text: I think that's right. I was a little shocked by Edmund's latest test review of a Suburban LT 4WD, $63k, about twice what we paid for the '95 we had. But with inflation, it's right on the money, plus a lot of features ours lacked.

author: fintail
text: Saw an MB AMG GT in traffic today, it's an eye catcher.

author: stickguy
text: not that rare or new, but got behind a CLS550 tonight. As always, my daughter commented that is was ugly. She says it looks like a stinkbug, which is actually pretty accurate.

author: stever
text: Awfully new looking Miata hardtop in "triple" black with temp tags. Looks like only the Grand Touring comes in black for 2015.

author: robr2
text: This evening I saw a BMW i8 on I95 north of Boston. He was stuck behind another vehicle doing about 60. As soon as that car moved over, he accelerated and was gone in a few seconds.

author: fintail
text:
Saw a Kia K9 (00) today, don't know if that's one for this thread or the obscure car sightings. I see more Equus than the Kia variant. IMO the Kia is better looking.

Stopped by the MB dealer to ask a question. They had a nicely loaded diamond white 16 E400 on the lot - 73K. I think it is carryover from 15 save for new COMAND buttons - production will probably be finished by end of the year, ramping up for W213. Showroom had an S63 coupe, GLA45 with lots of options but no nav, and the usual cars.

author: anythngbutgm
text: New Pilot, Black. I assume it was a Touring model. Looked great, very expensive looking, I'd even go so far as to prefer it to the current MDX

author: stever
text:
Nice - I've noticed a few comments saying for the money, you should just go to an MDX instead of a higher trim level Pilot.

So... maybe not.

author: odie6l
text:
Don't know if its a good or bad sign, but when we went past the Manheim Auto Auction today there were two '16 Pilots sitting in the "sale" line going into the building. I couldn't believe it so I had to U-turn and drive past again to make sure. Yup, one Black, one Blue.

Odie

author: texases
text: Any chance they're wanting to see how much over MSRP they can get for a new model? That way they won't upset their regular customers with an "ADP" sticker...

author: berri
text: I actually ran into a Ford dealer recently that had ADP stickers on every new model on his lot, I guess so he could exaggerate customer savings? I mean, more than a few of these models are pretty common Ford fleet or government vehicle sales, so can the dealer really expect there are those many rubes running around their sales lot willing to pay it?

author: Michaell
text: I suspect there are enough out there to make it worth his while.

author: fintail
text: Black S63 coupe, white Ferrari FF (don't ask where the money comes from!) , couple of late model Maseratis, CTS-V coupe with no plates in the worplace parking garage, M235 driven by 30 something guy blasting music trying to look cool and not doing a convincing job, and not one but 2 M4s - one that obnoxious light green/gold color that means you just know the owner straddles the line between incorrigible and punchable.

author: robr2
text: Spotted a 2016 Explorer. The updated front and rear are definitely evolutionary. They are more muscular than the previous nose and tail.

author: laurasdada
text: You've really gotta start hanging out in better neighborhoods...

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: The M4 might just be replacing the Jaguar as the "cad's car". You heard it first here.

author: texases
text: New S550 in the parking lot, black, pretty impressive looking. But the tires must be 40-series, REAL thin looking on a car of that 'heft'.

author: fintail
text:
BMW has had that market for awhile now. The M4 might own it now that the M3 has been relegated to being a sedan. Jaguar is now something for more mature drivers with at least the pretense of refined taste. Infiniti and to a lesser extent Lexus (F-sport) get a little too, maybe those afraid of the maintenance. They all lease though so it doesn't matter. I suspect a majority of M4 don't have the turn signal option package.

There's been a Lexus L F-Sport on the lot I drive by every day - a bit garish for what is usually such a mellow car.

author: fordgirl15
text: How common is it to see the Tesla? Haven't seen one since proly March. Tht wud have ben the first one I saw since they started making them.

author: robr2
text: I saw 3 yesterday....

author: fintail
text: I see at least 10 per day here. Successful older techies and wannabes just love em.

author: Michaell
text: There are a handful in my town of 60,000 just outside of Denver .... I'll usually see 1 when I'm out running errands.

author: laurasdada
text: A Tesla store has opened right next to where I live. It was formerly a Lincoln Mercury dealer, bought by Herb and moved. First Tesla store (dealer) I"ve seen not inside of a mall. Maybe a service center? But, half a dozen new Teslas on site.

author: Michaell
text: The zoning laws must suck where you live ...

author: stever
text: Never seen one. That I know of, anyway.

author: fordgirl15
text: Hmmm. All I can say is there not very popular or something here in Iowa....

author: stickguy
text: It was dream car week on price is right last week, some lady won a tesla.

author: Michaell
text: Which will haunt her big time when she has to register and pay sales tax on it.

author: fordgirl15
text: Exactly! Those things aren't the cheapest vehicles out there! Anyone know how much they run? My dad said if he could get a new car he would get a Tesla!

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Depends on which model you buy--what size battery pack. But if you want the longer range Model S, and some nice options, you could bust $130K easy. But I think you can buy 'em as low as around $80K.

author: robr2
text:
Did they spiff up the outside? That old LM store had a very 70's look. Dedham is a good spot for a store.

According to the website, it's only a store. The service center is still in Watertown.

author: laurasdada
text:
Hi, Rob: Still being spit and polished, but the building remains the same form. But, brighter, cleaner and more modern looking inside (so far). Looks like 8 charging stations are going up on the left side of the dealer. It's coming together pretty quickly. The "Automile" is at least an "Auto5k" now.

Amazing how common it is to see Teslas around here. There's at least one BMW i8 in my area, too. Still prefer that propulsion proposition over all battery, all the time.

Still haven't decided what to do: condo or i8! The fact that I'm cross shopping these two items shows my financial prowess and the reason I should really not be allowed to have any money... Oh, I forgot the third item: 8 years of college tuition. Yeah, there's the winner right there.

author: fordgirl15
text: laurasdada, where u frm tht the Tesla has made a grand appearance there and not here?

author: texases
text: Please speak English.

text: Excuse me? Wut did I just speak? Don't know anything but English!:-)

author: texases
text: U r usg 2 mny abrvs.

author: fordgirl15
text: I'm sorry, texases! Sometimes it is easier to use abbreviations instead of the full word. Is that better??:-)

author: texases
text: Yes, sorry, this old guy doesn't have the lingo down!

author: fordgirl15
text: Oh thts fine! I guess when you are young you don't stop to think about the older people who don't use abbreviations. My grandma is the same way! I'll try and do better in that!

author: robr2
text: It's a forum, not a text message. No need to abbreviate.

author: fordgirl15
text: In other words you are saying- don't use abrvs??

author: Michaell
text:
It helps ... lots of folks from different generations post here. Not all are conversant in the ways of the younger folks.

FWIW, I don't even use abbreviations when I text. Acronyms, yes, abbreviations, no.

Welcome aboard and hope to hear more from you - we need some fresh perspectives.

author: fordgirl15

Michaell said:
show previous quotes


Yard House is a nationwide chain owned by Darden Restaurants, the purveyor of Olive Garden and LongHorn as well as The Capital Grille and Seasons 52.
I thought OG got spun off ... or, that there was a shareholder revolt that led to some changes in the board at Darden.

They sold Red Lobster in early 2014. There was a revolt by Darden's largest shareholder - an equity firm - in which they managed to change the entire board. The equity firm presented a 294 page report highlighting ways to make Olive Garden more profitable which included cutting down on the breadsticks, the salad, and the dressing. Oy - getting into the minutia...

author: Michaell
text:
robr2 said:
show previous quotes


I thought OG got spun off ... or, that there was a shareholder revolt that led to some changes in the board at Darden.
They sold Red Lobster in early 2014. There was a revolt by Darden's largest shareholder - an equity firm - in which they managed to change the entire board. The equity firm presented a 294 page report highlighting ways to make Olive Garden more profitable which included cutting down on the breadsticks, the salad, and the dressing. Oy - getting into the minutia...


OK, so I was close. I remember reading about that in the business media.

author: ab348
text:
robr2 said:

They sold Red Lobster in early 2014. There was a revolt by Darden's largest shareholder - an equity firm - in which they managed to change the entire board. The equity firm presented a 294 page report highlighting ways to make Olive Garden more profitable which included cutting down on the breadsticks, the salad, and the dressing. Oy - getting into the minutia...

That's why you seldom see successful restaurants run by bankers. A recipe for failure is all they know about the business.

author: kyfdx
text:
robr2 said:
show previous quotes


Is that a local place? Or the chain restaurant? We have a Yard House in Cincinnati. Nice place, with 100 taps!!
Yard House is a nationwide chain owned by Darden Restaurants, the purveyor of Olive Garden and LongHorn as well as The Capital Grille and Seasons 52.

Yes.. I knew my local Yard House was part of the chain. Just thought maybe there was an independent up that way with the same name.

author: berri
text: Never seen a Darden Yard House restaurant. What's there spin on the menu and theme? I find Darden chains to usually be decent moderate priced places.

author: kyfdx
text:
berri said:
Never seen a Darden Yard House restaurant. What's there spin on the menu and theme? I find Darden chains to usually be decent moderate priced places.
It's a beer-centric restaurant... A big rectangular bar in the center (60 ft by 20 ft?) with taps all the way around.. The food seems to be consistent with TGIF, or maybe a step up. Typical prices. We've been there a couple of times and it's good.. but, always crowded, which is why we don't go more.

Obviously, a great craft beer selection on tap.

author: robr2
text:
kyfdx said:
show previous quotes
It's a beer-centric restaurant... A big rectangular bar in the center (60 ft by 20 ft?) with taps all the way around.. The food seems to be consistent with TGIF, or maybe a step up. Typical prices. We've been there a couple of times and it's good.. but, always crowded, which is why we don't go more.

Obviously, a great craft beer selection on tap.
It's so crowded, nobody goes there anymore....

author: kyfdx
text: @robr2 LOL

author: berri
text: Yard House - beer: Duh, makes too much sense. So are those 1970's pubs going to be the next big thing in restaurants again?

author: stickguy
text:
spent last week at the beach on vacation. Jersey shore. Stone Harbor for those that are in the area, which happens to be one of the wealthiest beach towns (not that I qualify to be there of course!). Car watcher heaven. more Benzs than you know what to do with (a particularly nice e63 EMG caught my eye!). In the space of 1 hour, a convertible and coupe Jag F type. a few Bentleys and Ferraris. A garish RR convertible (the new one).

also the first XC90 I have seen in the wild too. Very sharp. and too many more to recall!

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: don't use the word "recall"

author: explorerx4
text: A new HRV at the grocery store. Fairly comparable in size to the original CR-V. The new one pulled into the parking space just vacated by the CR-V.

author: stever
text: There was a review in the local paper on the HR-V and supposedly it's already cannibalizing CR-V sales.

author: robr2
text: Now I've read that there has been minimal impact on CR-V sales with high end HR-V sales displacing low end CR-V sales. I'm guessing Honda makes more on a $23K HR-V EX than it does on a $25K CR-V LX.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new S63 coupe driven by a 20-ish year old looking girl/woman - I assume daddy's car. She was being very cautious and had impeccable turn signal use, which is unusual for the typical often above the law local driver of cars in that price range. Saw the new style facelifted Prius V too - I hadn't noticed how overwrought the front end is. Someone else posted this on another forum - this overstyling trend is kind of the malaise era for Japanese car styling.

author: explorerx4
text: CR-V starts out 4k+ higher than an HR-V, plus it's got a lot of volume, so does Honda make more on a CR-V with 2k upgrades or HR-V with 4k upgrades? I think CR-V still is more profitable.

author: stever
text:
fintail said:
Saw the new style facelifted Prius V too.
Wait, the 2016 is out? They aren't on Toyota.com yet; must be trying to clear out the 2015s. Have to go check 'em out.

author: fintail
text:
It had the front end like this:



Ghastly
stever said:
show previous quotes
Wait, the 2016 is out? They aren't on Toyota.com yet; must be trying to clear out the 2015s. Have to go check 'em out.

author: stever
text:
Cool, will have to go bug the local dealer now. Didn't think they'd be on the streets for another month or three. Thanks!

(btw, it's supposed to handle "better", being based on the old Echo platform. )

author: fintail
text:
I don't think it's an entire new model, just a facelift. I think the new one isn't out yet. Reminds me of that hydrogen (or whatever) Toyota that is upcoming, that is overstyled to the point of cringing hilarity.
stever said:
Cool, will have to go bug the local dealer now. Didn't think they'd be on the streets for another month or three. Thanks!

(btw, it's supposed to handle "better", being based on the old Echo platform. )

author: stever
text:
Ah, k. Yeah, the design of the hydrogen one is supposed to bleed over to the V, but maybe not until 2018.

Oh well, I can wait.

author: berri
text: Is anyone neutral on the Prius? It seems to be one of those love or hate automobiles.

author: tlong
text:
berri said:
Is anyone neutral on the Prius? It seems to be one of those love or hate automobiles.
I like the economy and reliability of the Prius and would consider it if a) they had a bit better driving dynamics; and b) had a bit more upscale interior. So I'm kind of neutral on it. I have driven one and it is an interesting ride and larger inside that you would think.

author: fordgirl15
text: Aren't you supposed to get really good fuel mileage with a prius? I'm not a fan of them cause I don't like the way they look!:-) any vehicle that gets good fuel mileage is nice! Then you don't have to pay for gas so much!:-)

author: fintail
text: I liked the Prius more before it became "bold" and gained angry Pokemon styling themes. Now the tame appliance, along with the rest of the Toyota line (even the Yaris has a face now) is trying too hard. Prius is a great transportation pod and would be a good autonomous car.

author: Michaell
text: I've not driven a Prius, but I have test driven a Prius C, and I'll echo tlong's comments. I'd take a small hit in the MPG if it didn't drive like a penalty box - reminds me a bit of the econoboxes of the 80's, truth be told.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Spent yesterday at the Newport Jazz festival in RI. Lots of sightings from a BMW i8 to and AMG GT, a new XC90, couple of new Honda Pilots, a 650i Gandcoupe, heck even a customized Chrysler 300 Convertible.

Don't know if it's a trend or not, but there were a couple of cars running around without hoods on them, specifically a heavily modded Audi TT and a 335i... Strange...

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
I think that's because the Prius took over the role once played by 1980s era Volvos---"the car for people who hate cars"

It's an anti-car car, if you will.

author: stever
text:
The rumor mill says the new V (that's the "big" Prius station wagon) is going to get 55 mpg. Toyota is trying to damp expectations.

Aren't you in diesel country anyway? Plenty of VW TDI drivers are getting over 50mpg and you get a "better" driving experience. The fumes are a trigger for my wife's mild asthma so there's no interest in diesel around here.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I won't even drive behind any kind of dirty diesel, like trucks. I pull over. I can't stand that smell. Lucky for me I don't live in Asia.

author: stickguy
text: I actually love the smell of diesel trucks. Brings back fond memories.

author: fordgirl15
text: Same here, stickguy! If diesel wasn't so spendy that's what I would drive. I've heard diesel and manual transmission combined gets really awesome fuel mileage.

author: fintail
text: Saw an i8 this afternoon, and 3 new Pilots on a transporter this morning.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: yes, but did you inhale?

author: kyfdx
text:
Lexus IS-F.

Pushed up the inside lane to cut me off, when I was merging from an on-ramp. Nice.

author: stever
text:
HR-V, C-Max, Encore, V Three.

Yep, hit a few car dealers this morning. Details at 11.

author: explorerx4
text:
In the parking lot at work...
Lexus IS with PFHT and nuclear green Crosstrek XV hybrid.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I had to look that up PFHT---did you mean PRHT?

author: laurasdada
text: Went for a run yesterday, including through the new Tesla dealer lot down the lane... Shiny cars, can't afford 'em. But, I hooked my mp3 player up to an exterior charging station. MP3 player exploded, whodathunkit? Paging Mr. Jackie Childs, ESQ!

author: explorerx4
text:
@Mr_Shifty,
Ok, I retract that.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new S550 coupe, new AMG GT and a custom ordered E63 wagon at the local MBCA gathering today.

author: laurasdada
text: That S550 coupe is a beauty! Looks like the Tesla dealer is in full swing, lot full of cars, a couple on the chargers as I drove to work this am.

author: fintail
text:
Saw an orange Lexus RC sitting front and center at the local dealer this morning.

Here's a nice S550 coupe and AMG GT from the local MB show:

author: fintail
text: Saw an Alpina B6 Gran Coupe today, the big wheels looked painful on a torn up street.

author: berri
text: I know the new Merc's are years ahead in performance and refinement, but my heart still goes with the classic MB's like that white walled convertible. M-B was something unique and special back in those days.

author: anythngbutgm
text: Spotted a new S-Classe over the weekend, white with AMG wheels, damn that thing has presence...

author: odie6l
text:
Got to actually see one of the TRD Pro 4Runners out on the streets today instead of just on the lots. Funny thing it was behind (chasing) and old Green Aztek.

Odie

author: fintail
text:
Lexus dealer now has a second orange RC sitting right in front, first one is still there. Not the best color IMO.

Saw a Q3 today, these are still pretty rare here compared to the Q5, which is on every corner.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Everywhere I look, new Honda Pilot, new Honda Pilot, new Honda Pilot. They are popping up faster than new Subarus around here...

New C-classe is a hit as well, I see more of them than I do CLA which is more attainable. Also got behind a hawt new Maserati Coupe yesterday, the exhaust note was heavenly at about 80mph. Also an odd duck, a Morgan! One of the newer "Aero 8" I believe, but couldn't confirm because I passed it going the other direction.

author: jpp75
text: I saw a new Volvo XC90 yesterday, looked sharp. I need to stop by the local dealer and see what the interior is like.

author: stickguy
text: Interior on the 90 is gorgeous. And I expect the pilot to be a massive success for Honda.

author: fintail
text: Saw a Pilot "Elite" today, I guess enough time has passed from the time of the Gran Torino Elite.

author: tlong
text: ....it's not your father's Grand Torino!

author: boomchek
text: I spotted the new Volvo XC90 a week ago too. Looks great. Clean but elegant styling. It was about time for them to redesign it.

author: fintail
text:
I've seen 2 of those - definite hit. The old one was more than a decade old, and needed help.

How've you been?

author: boomchek
text: I've been good, thank you. We had a second child born, a duaghter, 3 months ago so we've been busy. I'm still in the car business. Are you coming up to Vancouver for the Luxury Supercar show next weekend?

author: fintail
text:
Good to know. 2 kids, wow. No time like the present to get her interested in cars

The concours attached to that event looks interesting, but I don't think I'll be able to make it. Actually, next weekend is also the PNW Concours at the LeMay Museum, I might attend that.

Speaking of new cars, an S4 and GLA have recently shown up in the garage of my building - it's a booming place around here.

author: boomchek
text:
There isn't really a concours where the cars drive through, just an award ceremony at the end of the day. Otherwise the cars are parked the whole weekend, but there is a lot of interesting vehicles, new exotics and classics every year.

I see a lot of GLA's in Vancouver too. Decent looking cars for someone wanting to get into an affordable Benz.

author: fintail
text:
I'd be more interested in the classics - I see enough show-off stuff around my own neighborhood (apparently there's a LaFerrari floating around somewhere now). I'd be more impressed by a cocaine-white Countach or Testarossa that cost a fraction of the money.

I might prefer a GLA to a CLA, seems like it would be more comfortable inside, and less melty styling. AMG versions help, of course.

author: fintail
text:
I saw a prototype or test mule today, a BMW pickup. It was badged "X10", and it didn't have any camo on it at all, it looked ready for the street. It appeared to be a 2WD or low riding AWD model, extended cab, 3-series sized, very plain practical styling. Amazing sight out in broad daylight.

Actually, it was a 90s era S-10 that someone had converted, but it made me look and laugh, and I had to mention it. It was fully converted - kidney grille, roundels, I think wheels, "X10" badge. Someone has a sense of humor.

author: odie6l
text:
Are you talking about this???


The owner of this lives in North Lebanon near Jonestown, PA. I see it all the time.

Odie

author: fintail
text: Nope, not even that real looking. This was literally a mid-late 90s S-10 extended cab that had been slathered with BMW bits. That makes it even funnier.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Jaguar F Type "R" convertible---great exhaust note as it entered the freeway ramp. Unfortunately, you can only get them with AWD.

author: stever
text:
X6 with temp tags.

Test drove an Elantra GT and Soul Plus today, both loaded 16's.

Oh, and a new Mary Kaye Caddy SRX, also with temp plates.

author: explorerx4
text:
In the parking lot at work...
A dark blue BMW 3 series 4 door with a rear hatch.

author: Michaell
text: We had someone come to the new house yesterday to measure for window coverings. She showed up driving an X6 5.0

author: stever
text: Must be good money in drapes and curtains, LOL.

author: kyfdx
text: So... which one did you like best?

author: stever
text: Still liking the Soul but the GT was a nice ride too.

author: Michaell
text: But your wife still ranks the Encore #1

author: stickguy
text: Hummer FX.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
New Mitsu Outlander over the weekend. Looks much more substantial than the outgoing one. Almost Pilot-esque.

Speaking of which, new Honda Pilots were in all over the place from here in ME, down to Cape Cod and back up thru Vermont where our roadtrip led us.

author: laurasdada
text: While grocery shopping, a bright white Mazda 6....with a standup Lincoln hood ornament!

author: explorerx4
text: In the parking lot at work... New Rav4 and Mazda 3.

author: robr2
text: This past weekend I saw two different B Class Electrics here in the Boston area.

author: boomchek
text: Last week's Luxury Supercar show in Vancouver. The LaFerrari was a big attraction at the show, and after, when it pulled out onto the street and was waiting for a transport truck back to the dealership. More pictures here of new and older cars: Luxury Supercar Show Vancouver

author: fintail
text:
I've heard there's one of those in my area, but haven't seen it yet. Man I'd rather have a 250GT Berlinetta Lusso than that.

Better driven than the one belonging to the Quatari garbage in Beverly Hills anyway, I'm sure.

author: boomchek
text: Yes for sure. I was told that to qualify to purchase one you need to be a serious Ferrari collector, owning several vintage and historic multi million dollar Ferraris.

author: ab348
text: I am no longer impressed with supercars after seeing the hundreds that Saddam Hussein's son had in his collection - many of which ended up getting destroyed in the mayhem over there. All of which were purchased, of course, with ill-gotten gains. Seeing the Qatari jerks with theirs only adds to my disdain. Until I am convinced otherwise, I will assume that anyone who has one is a Bad Person.

author: fintail
text:
You're not far off. IMO, once a certain price point is reached - maybe middle-upper 100s at the most, the amount of "good" people buying them (at least when new) becomes a small minority.

This is the new Belle Epoque.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new style C63 on the road, should be a fun thing.

author: fintail
text: Saw an i8 in traffic today, poor job stopping at a crosswalk, but it is a BMW after all. Also an X4 for those with a difference sense of style.

author: stever
text: Transit Connect 7 passenger at lunch out of town today. White. Owners are loving it.

author: odie6l
text:
Going to have a nice grouping of sightings coming up in the next few weeks with the Big Hershey Auto Show getting ready to start. You never know what till show up. Mostly older models, but every now and then a new one sneaks in.

Odie

author: fintail
text: Saw 3 6er Gran Coupes - one an M6, 3 new style Bentleys, 1 convertible 2 sedans (maybe the same car), and a new style Range Rover which had a "driver" with his phone to his ear - perfect time for progressive traffic fines. That's my hood.

author: fintail
text: Saw an i8, kind of a dark grey with blue accent. Also a new XC90, which is a nice comfortable looking thing.

author: stickguy
text: parked at a restaurant, a new Miata (red of course, not even sure if any other colors are out yet). I really like the looks of this style. Can't wait to find out if I fit in it now!

author: laurasdada
text: That was just me, doing a few test drives...

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Spotted a new Audi TT H/T today. Sharp.

Also a new GLE Coupe over the weekend. What a beast.

author: fintail
text: Saw a GLE this afternoon, first one. It has presence - not pretty, but not as obnoxious as an X6. Will probably attract some of the same beloved demographic.

author: robr2
text:
GLE Coupe or GLE CUV?

If the former, I saw one about 3 months ago at the local MB store. Based on the MFR plates, I'm guessing it was the regional rep. IMHO, it is a very homely vehicle answering a question that BMW answered but nobody asked.

author: fintail
text:
One of these subtle beauties:



Definitely a bit homely, and not a "coupe" no matter the soulless marketing spin. Unfortunately, as I see X6s and X4s regularly, someone did ask the question. There's definitely a demographic for them.

author: robr2
text:
Just saw at the local purveyor of MB vehicles, two MB Metrises (Metrrii?). One was a panel sided white work van, the other a blue 7 passenger version.. The latter was adorned with MB Tex. No Monroney stickers.

I was surprised both were wearing Hankook tires.

author: explorerx4
text:
Got a ride in a new XC60.Seats are comfortable, but ride is stiff and it has some creaks at 1800 miles.
Also, annoying start/stop.

author: stever
text: Volvo doesn't seem to have start/stop figured out very well yet.

author: explorerx4
text: Timely comment by me!

author: fintail
text:
I think Hankook is used on a few other MBs too. Maybe they have a good model, or it is just another way for some suits to get a big bonus.

Start/stop on my E is pretty seamless, but it is annoying when creeping in Seattle traffic, or using a multi point turn when backing into a parking spot. Luckily, it is disabled with a simple push of a button.

Today spotted a pretty blue M235 and a GLA45 with the big dorky spoiler and a "driver" with a phone to his ear.

author: fintail
text: Saw a Maybach S600 on the showroom floor of the local MB dealer today. MSRP ~190K IIRC. They also had a loaded up S63 into the 160s.

author: odie6l
text:
I got to see a BMW i8 near Hershey today. It has to be because of the big Hershey Auto Show coming up next weekend.

Odie

author: fintail
text: Oh yeah, at Costco saw one of the Fiat CUV things, and a surprisingly rare sight, an HRV (or they are just blending into the background).

author: berri
text: Sadly, too many new cars seem to blend in these days Kind of takes the urgency out of buying a new one.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Can it be switched off? I haven't driven the newer version but I absolutely loved the 3.0T-6 with the Polestar tune. That sucker was silly quick.

Over the weekend I saw another GLE Coupe, an X4 and a couple of X6's . It was just that kind of sighting weekend for those. I definitely don't dislike the segment, in fact the GLE in AMG guise is pretty sweet IMO.

author: stever
text: Yeah, you can turn it off. It goes off in Sport mode too.

author: fordgirl15
text: What is the sports car that looks like a camaro? I have seen it and there is no marking on it to even give you an idea of what it is. It looks like the new Chevy camaro but my dad doesn't agree with me. Maybe someone else knows.

author: texases
text: A Dodge Challenger?

author: fordgirl15
text: I haven't seen the new challenger yet so cudnt say. It was red and had a black gas cover. I looked up the camaro and that's what it looked like. I'll look at the challenger.

author: fordgirl15
text: It doesn't look like the challenger. The front didn't hardly look like a camaro but the shape was camaro. If that helps any!

author: stever
text: Corvette?

author: fordgirl15
text: Too big for a corvette. It almost looked like a mix of different models in the sports car world.

author: stickguy
text: Hyundai Genesis coupe?

author: fordgirl15
text: Nope. Ok. Let me get myself straight. It was the shape of a MUSTANG, had the front of a DODGE, but it looked like a camaro. Bigger than the corvette. Ok. So it almost looked like a cross between Ford, dodge, Chevy. Like I said there was no marking to distinguish it from other sports car. It was a sports car. I have only seen one other one besides that one.

author: stever
text: Have you been listening to Johnny Cash again?

author: fordgirl15
text: Lol! No! Why??!!:-)

author: stever
text: Is this warmer or cooler?

author: texases
text: Nissan GT-R?

author: fordgirl15
text: Cooler

author: fordgirl15
text: No. Don't look like it. Sorry if you are getting fed up. Or maybe this is providing a challenge for you.

author: explorerx4
text:
New small Porsche CUV while I was out walking. Somehow, they got it to sound like it has a flat 6. It doesn't right?
Yesterday driving by the back lot of a car dealer a Super Duty 4x4 on 4 vertical 4x4's (someone stole the wheels).

author: kyfdx
text: Nope... it's a turbo V-6, I'm pretty sure

author: fintail
text: Today saw an F-type cabrio, facelift Bentley Continental, newer Stingray.

author: odie6l
text:
Was it one of the Pontiac Trans Am body kits?



Odie

author: fordgirl15
text: Looks like you might be a little closer.

author: tjc78
text: That body kit is ummm... interesting.

author: fordgirl15
text: Odie, I think you answered my question! Just looked at the back end of it and I think that was what it was! Thanks! So what wud you say the make and model is?

author: robr2
text: Both Trans Am Depot and Lingenfelter are offering kits to convert the current Camaro to various generations of the Trans Am and the former also offers a kit to make a GTO.

author: fordgirl15
text: Interesting! That's cool to know.

author: odie6l
text:
I know some will bash me for this, but you have to admit the T-Tops work on it. I bet with todays tech, they had to have fixed the leaking problem from models past. I bet it would be a popular option if it was available on the Camaro.

Odie

author: odie6l
text:
It is still titled as a Camaro, but I think you can have it retitled as a Trans Am, but has to keep the Chevrolet Manufacturer on the title. As for the price, you have to pay the extra over the price of the Camaro too and they run around $65k total (kit & car) to start.

http://www.transamdepot.com/trans_am_showroom.html

Odie

author: anythngbutgm
text: Warmer? That thing is smoking hot!

author: anythngbutgm
text:
IIRC, the majority of the problems with T-Tops was the structural rigidity of the car itself rather than things like the design of the seals or the gap tolerances. For instance, from what I recall, Nissan offered the T-top option in the Datsun 240 all the way up to the 300 ZX and there was no problems with structural rigidity and body twist. But I did have a friend with a 300ZX TT that his T-Tops suddenly never fit right after owning it for years. But he took that thing to the NE Dragway a few times and I'm sure it had it's share of flogging in the corners as well...

But with the growing interest in weight savings, it may be A. too costly to engineer the car to overcome the body twist or B. the weight of the glass or the effects of the glass on the cG of the vehicles is not worth the effort.

IMO, the T-Top thing is a fad that will remain in the history books...

Now with that, I'll be VERY curious about the structural rigidity of Teslas new Model X with the Gull Wing Doors and whether that design will see the same issues as traditional T-Tops.

author: explorerx4
text: Some current cars have convertible in mind when designed. A CamaroBird might be ok with T-Tops.

author: fintail
text: Not new, but I think I saw about 15 Teslas today on my ~4 mile jog. It was like there was a convention in town.

author: carnaught
text: It's kinda weird that I see more Teslas when out on a typical outing than I do new Ford Tauruses.

author: fintail
text:
I definitely do, as the market in my area largely abandoned fullsized American cars years ago.

Saw 2x BMW M235, blue and red.

author: berri
text: just go over a county or two from King

author: fintail
text:
I guess with the size of some counties here, you could end up in Yakima or Spokane and see more.

Today saw a nice C450 with a 60K MSRP and a high option C63 with 86K MSRP.

Saw a loaded

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
As you might guess from looking at this Tesla Distribution Map, most of them reside in heavily populated metro areas. Surprised to see Atlanta stepping out. Also surprised to see so few in groovy uber-rich Boulder.

Tesla doesn't have to worry so much about leaking roofs. Tesla has to worry about making a profit for the first time.

author: qbrozen
text: well, we can say that most who have chosen to report themselves to that website live somewhere near a heavily populated metro area. I see MANY in my neck of the woods, which is 1 hour from both NYC and Philly. Certainly way more than the few people who reported to that website. Maybe those in uber-rich Boulder just have better things to do than give their info to some website dude. haha.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Hard to say what's going on. In some uber-rich, ultra green communities, it's not cool to be too ostentatious. You drive a humble Subaru but fly off to a one-month luxury tent trek in Mongolia.

re: Jaguar F Type -- what I really like about the car is how it sounds, especially the "R".

author: fintail
text:
Not surprised by that map, I feel like I live near Tesla HQ sometimes, I see at least a dozen of these a day now. On a per capita basis, this area has to be among the top. I see a lot of greenie rich aging techie types who sure as hell love to show off a bit. Time to end those undeserved tax breaks.

I am most surprised to see central FL so high, but then again with a largeish population and a banana republic style socio-economic structure, there is a decent enough sized group at the top who can pull it off I guess.

author: bhill2
text: Want to bet that cluster in Eastern WA is in the tri-cities?

author: fintail
text: That and Spokane, for sure. Some money in both places, and enough population to have people into it.

author: ab348
text: What is the source of wealth in the tri-cities? The one time I spent some time there it did not seem particularly prosperous.

author: stever
text:
Bioremediation pays well I think. Just don't drink the water.

New Sedona and Soul yesterday, both with temp plates. The Korean brands seem to do well in this town, but not as well as muscle cars.

author: stickguy
text:
I see tons of new kias. They come into Philly now (the transport ships) and the storage/prep lots are right down by the river, under one of the bridges. They are spreading down there like Kudzu. I have no clue how they keep track of them all, but they have to keep scraping together more parking for them all.

cool site coming over the bridge, looking down on 1,000s of cars still with the while plastic on them.

author: robr2
text: Zoom in and you can see exactly where the Tesla is. I was surprised that the 1 one in my town was listed as being at a Shell station.

author: bhill2
text: Well, the Hanford facility is there and nuclear workers get paid pretty well. But I was thinking more of the nerd factor, which is through the roof.

author: fintail
text: I think some large companies have locations there, wikipedia probably lists it. An old school friend of mine lives there - he can work from home, and his wife works at Hanford. The house they bought for 300K would be 1MM++ where I live, which was a key motivator - not a bad place to raise kids.

author: berri
text: Do the nuke workers there need lights, or is their glow sufficient at night As I recall, there have been lot of issues and problems at those facilities.

author: bhill2
text:
When I worked at the facility I got a yellow tee shirt with a purple radiation symbol that said "In case of a power failure, stand next to me; I glow in the dark." I heard that if you wore it to work you would be fired. Never tried it, but 35 years later I still have the shirt.

Oh Fin; at least when I was there it was indeed a great place to raise kids. Unfortunately, there were about 3 guys for every girl and I didn't make the cut.

author: fintail
text: For people who worked at the main facility in the past, there were many problems yes - it is public sector after all, you'll run into ineptitude and a lack of accountability, as people in charge effectively can't be fired. But the facility is huge and employs a lot of people. It will probably never really be cleaned up or out of operation.

author: fintail
text:
Affordable housing can do a lot if you can find a good job. I could deal with living in eastern WA, as I spent a bit of my youth there and I generally like the climate. The Seattle-Bellevue-Redmond style jobs aren't easy to find there yet though.

I spent a bit of my childhood in Moses Lake. It was a good place for kids at the time too. Maybe not as great now - lots of gang/drug activity there. Still afforable housing anyway.

I am in a small western WA town now, no new cars here, but I saw a new Ducati Scrambler of all things yesterday.

author: PF_Flyer
text: Saw a Nissan Leaf on the road today. Second one I've seen, but this one was the first local owner. I may have to check back with them to see how it handles our winter.

author: fintail
text: Today - new facelift Accord, CX-3 that looked like it would fit inside the Graf Zeppelin Q7 behind it, S550 coupe, C450 on the road, and a BMW S1000R - not the RR, but the more upright R, which I like a lot.

author: anythngbutgm
text: My wife has a customer with one and supposedly it's a tank in the winter. She loves it and has no issue en the N.E. winters and that was coming from a RAV4 before it.

author: anythngbutgm
text: Spotted a new Q7 yesterday. Certainly rides lower than the last model, about the same height as the Allroad but with a taller roofline.

author: robr2
text: Saw an S65 today at the local dealership. The PDR guy was massaging the hood. He better be good - it was a black vehicle and any little imperfection will really show.

author: PF_Flyer
text: I'm thinking more along the lines of the effects of cold and snow on the range

author: explorerx4
text: Over the weekend, a Black Bentley convertible with the top down during snow flurries, driving up our street.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: BMW 650i convertible. Nice looking car but with the top up, those "flying buttress" C pillars are pretty unattractive.

author: PF_Flyer
text: Doing a road trip to DE this weekend, so who knows what I might see

author: fintail
text:
I suspect the depreciation curve for a loaded 6er cabrio is like a stone thrown off a cliff.

MB day today - current style E63, W222 S63, W222 S65 (the big money).

author: odie6l
text:
Were you in Hershey? I saw a Bentley Convert as well on wed. with the top down cruising around like nothing else mattered in the world.

Odie

author: explorerx4
text:
@odie6l,
Not in Hershey, in central CT.

author: fintail
text: Saw a P85D today (I usually don't even look at the badge, but I did for unknown reasons), must be the diesel model

author: bhill2
text: Please. We're talking about a breakthrough car here. It's diesel-electric

author: berri
text: Sounds like a railroad engine drivetrain

author: fintail
text:
That'd be cool. Diesel hybrids exist. Doubt they'd get the tax help though.

A friend of mine excitedly texted me to say he saw a BMW 340i on the road.

author: explorerx4
text: A new black Miata convertible. Looks like how I picture a small Jag convertible.

author: stickguy
text: I saw one miata on the road. Red. Did not realize any other colors were out yet.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Saw a new Miata as well, also in red. Still not a fan of the looks.

In the obscure sightings column, I actually saw an Isuzu Axiom over the weekend as well. I remember thinking how odd and over the top futuristic it looked when it came to market, now it just looks cheap and outdated.

author: Michaell
text:
I saw an Axiom over the weekend as well .. wasn't that one of the first vehicles available with direct injection?

Also saw a lovely 70's Riviera - the generation after the boattail.

author: texases
text: I always liked the Axiom, didn't understand the criticism when it came out. A clean modern look, IMO:

author: qbrozen
text: I thought the Axiom was interesting, too.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
I think the criticism was more with the fact that it didn't look like a traditional SUV like the Explorer, Durango, Jeeps, Pathfinders, 4Runners etc. that were so wildly popular when the SUV craze started taking off. And it wasn't really as sleek and luxurious as the early entries to the soft roader segment by Lexus (first RX300 was a breakout hit) Acura, who released the first gen and also wildly successful MDX the same year. To me, that front clip was polarizing in the same way the Jeep Cherokee is when I see one or even Isuzu's own Vehicross when it was out.

IIRC, didn't it consist of a lot of shared parts from the Rodeo?

author: anythngbutgm
text: Looks like you are correct, wikpedia says it received DI in 2004.

author: iluvmysephia1
text: Ditto on the Isuzu Axiom, guys.

author: robr2
text: IIRC, It was pretty much a Rodeo Sport that went to a cosmetic surgeon.

author: qbrozen
text: Can't say I'm an expert on this by any means, but I seem to remember the Axiom having a trick AWD system (for the time) and a high output (again, at the time) 3.5 engine, neither of which was found in the Rodeo.

author: fintail
text: I saw a couple new style C-class wagons today (I am in Germany), they look as good in person.

author: fintail
text: Saw an S63 coupe and a CLS shooting brake today.

author: fintail
text: Saw a ghastly orange-ish G63 AMG at a MB dealer, and a new style Q7 on the road. Quite a few new style Smarts around, too.

author: berri
text: I sometimes see a Smart when I'm in places like Seattle or San Francisco. It always raises the philosophical question to me as to what is "smart" about it?

author: stickguy
text: not that rare, but I saw a bevy of Mazda 6's today. In about a 3 block stretch by my neighborhood, I saw 3 different ones. Must have been a convention.

author: tjc78
text: New Maxima in the parking lot at work. Looks sharp, but the front "buck tooth" is meh. IMO the manufacturers are struggling in the front end department. It seems we either get downright funky or big mouth bass.

author: robr2
text: It's small and nimble. Easy to park, easy to dart in and out of traffic.

author: Michaell
text: Yeah, but the fact that it's RWD is odd, to me.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
You have a problem with driving a phone booth that gets no better gas mileage than a car twice its size and is equipped with the worst automatic transmission ever made in the history of man?

Ah, well, Smart critics, be assured. This car is going to disappear from the market very soon.

author: fintail
text:
S-class cabrio, it's a big thing:



Smart might not live forever in the US, but it seems to be doing fine here in Germany.

author: robr2
text: Well the engine is in the rear so it makes sense from that perspective.

author: robr2
text: Um, no it isn't. The 2016 FourTwo was just introduced. It's a little wider and they now are offering either a 5 speed manual or a 6 speed dual clutch as well as a new engine.

author: stever
text:
What do you think the tipping point will be?



(Washington Post)

author: slorenzen
text: I see what you did there...

author: berri
text: I'll drink to that

author: stever
text: Saw one this afternoon, but not sure if it was a new model. It was mostly hidden by one of those little bitty temp plastic signs like the politicians use.

author: fintail
text: It doesn't get much newer than a camouflaged prototype (I am pretty sure this is MB W213, upcoming new E-class)

author: ab348
text: Looks to be a plumped-up C-class design. Not sure I like that sloping tail.

author: robr2
text:
It is. The recent S class styling first infected the C class and now it's a full blown epidemic as the E gets it.

I like the S class. I just don't think it's styling translate well to the other models.

author: fintail
text:
Audi BMW and MB are now all in the "same sausage different size" model theory.

New S and C (they are everywhere here too) are big hits, the company likely assumes this will translate to E sales.

author: berri
text: Geez, looks liked its wrapped in black & white 60's psychedelia

author: stickguy
text:
so, got to check out a new Tuscan today. In the showroom, while I waited for my Sonata to get serviced. Looks nice. Classier interior. terrible looking rear visibility. Should do well.

but, I immediately crossed it off the list. Failed the headrest test. Way too big and pushed forward. Felt like someone was shoving a football against my head. Oh well. Plenty of other choices!

and yes the headrest test is an acid test for me!

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
It'll take a year or two to die in the US market, but it's simply not sustainable here. The numbers tell the story.

In October, the ForTwo sold how many in the USA? Guess.......it's 721 units. And THAT was among their best months for 2015. July was 441.

author: fintail
text: Renissan/Nissault styling is a thing

author: robr2
text: Saw the new Civic at the local dealership. It didn't look as good in person as in the photos. Also, the new wing across it and the Accord protrudes a bit too far for my taste.

author: tifighter
text: Saw the new Tacoma on the road. Black extended cab. I found the looks to be...challenging.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: The polite term when addressing the new owner is "Oh, that's an interesting effort".

author: fintail
text: Spotted a PINK CLS350 Bluetec Shooting Brake in the hotel parking garage - not the best choice.

author: Michaell
text: Mary Kay is in Europe?

author: tifighter
text: Saw a few of these CLS shooting brakes in Zurich two weeks ago. For sure it is nice, but I can't say I'm a huge fan. Like the E wagon, though.

author: fintail
text:
E wagon is a classy thing. I wish NA got the diesel.

CLS shooting brake has been around for a couple years. The surprising one is the CLA shooting brake - I've seen a number of them. It seems droopy like the CLA sedan. Rounded shooting brake designs are hard to pull off.

Here's an oddball - MB E200 Natural Gas.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Saw not one, but 2 different Chevy's this week, on Monday I saw a new Volt. This one was Blue, not bad looking if a bit derivative of a new Honda Civic.

Then this morning I got behind this white sedan that looked kinda like a new 200C but almost looked like a knockoff like something out of China. So I got closer and low and behold it was a brand new Malibu. Impression of it was meh, looks like a rental car... And with a really dopey looking front end...

http://cgi.chevrolet.com/mmgprod-us/dynres/prove/image.gen?i=2016/1ZB69/1ZB69__1VL/GAN_LFV_MNH_IP1_RRY_MNHgmds1.jpg&v=deg01&std=true&country=US

I don't think either of these cars are available for sale yet, but there are mules here in the New England area apparently.

author: Michaell
text: The Volt is starting to trickle out to the dealers now, but not certain of the Malibu....

author: explorerx4
text: In the parking lot at work, a new red Civic. It just revealed one for sale already?

author: Michaell
text: Starting to trickle onto the lots, it seems.

author: robr2
text: I stopped at the local Honda store last week. They had about 10 new Civics in stock. They show 76 units in stock across their 4 locations.

author: qbrozen
text:
Spotted my first S-class coupe. I was approaching from behind and had no idea what it was until I got a look at the badges. An S550 4matic, to be precise. Not bad looking from the back. Still not sure what the interest is in such a large 2-door, though.

I guess this one has been around about a year, but this is definitely the first I've seen in the wild. Wonder how many they have sold.

author: fintail
text:
Selling quite a few in the Seattle area, anyway. I have seen several new S-coupe in Germany, too. The interest is in the style, and the $$$. And to a point, it is 8/10ths of the panache of a Bentley for a lot less money.

Saw a Tesla in Zurich, and speaking of Volt, the unusual Opel Ampera. Also 3 non-taxi Lexus. a record. Approximately 2 minutes worth back home. A couple of RX in city traffic and a CT going really slow on the highway.

author: tlong
text: Saw a new Volt on the road today. Looks quite a bit nicer on the outside IMHO than the old one.

author: fintail
text: Saw another Lexus today. One. I was on the road for hours. It's a different world.

author: explorerx4
text: A white Miata convertible and a black Jag XF convertible. Both looked good in their own way.

author: stever
text:
Aston Martin.

Yeah, it was in the Bond flick - the chances of actually seeing one here are pretty slim.

author: anythngbutgm
text: So how was Spectre anyways? I saw it opened at #2 this weekend and made something like 14 mil in the US. Kinda mediocre for an opening weekend.

author: robr2
text: Actually, it's the 3rd weekend for Spectre. It did $70.4 million the first weekend, $35 it's second. This past weekend it had to deal with Katniss and JLaw in a leather catsuit will always win over Daniel Craig.

author: stever
text: I heard that the reviews were so-so. My wife didn't think it was all that good (usual gratuitous violence) but I enjoyed it a lot. Typical escapist fare that required perhaps a bit more suspension of disbelief even for an 007 flick. I like the G character - nerds rule, lol.

author: PF_Flyer
text: I like the new portrayal of Bond. You hit him, he gets bruised. Kinda the of the other end of the spectrum from Roger Moore

author: ab348
text: I long for the day when the public turns its back on entertainment that is largely CGI-based. But I suspect the video-game generation pretty much means that won't happen in my lifetime.

author: PF_Flyer
text:
Amen... I would LOVE to see someone make a movie where they had to figure out how to create an effect rather than "dialing it up". Happened to see the Wizard of Oz last night. The effects hold up pretty well for 1939!

And while we're at it, how about a 2D cartoon feature

author: stever
text:
You guys are lucky that we still (mostly) have real live actors. In art imitating fiction, Laura Croft did go "live".

Can't wait to take my autonomous car to the drive-in.

author: fintail
text: Got home, took car in for service. On the showroom floor was a C63S - 84K or something, I think. Showroom was half empty as they apparently sold a ton yesterday.

author: fintail
text: Saw my first new style Lexus RX in the wild today. As usual for new style Toyolex products, it offers a lot of styling per dollar.

author: fintail
text: Saw a CX3 this morning, and although not new, an Electric RAV4, and a new style RLX - a car that I hear sells at least 5 units per month.

author: ab348
text: Not particularly rare, but new to me today - a Fiat 500 Abarth Essence, black, red stripe, black wheels but looked like it just rolled out of a showroom, not a speck of dirt on it. Still a bit of a goofy thing, but this one was really eye-catching. Nicely done.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: That Abarth has a wicked exhaust note for such a tiny little toaster.

author: stever
text: Must use really good speakers for the exhaust note.

author: fintail
text: Today the car inside Costco was a now with more styling! RX Hybrid, and there was also a Kawasaki 250 dirtbike - talk about different worlds.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Hah! No, the exhaust note is real, unlike SOME cars we know....

author: robr2
text: There is an Abarth around here that has an aftermarket exhaust. It sounds amazing for a 1.4L.

author: stickguy
text:
in the wild, a new maxima. about the best I can say about it, is that you know immediately it is a Nissan.

I think when they merged, Nissan inherited all the Renault designers.

author: stickguy
text: and not exactly new, but an S55 AMG. And a B5 Alpina. on the same road at the same time.

author: fintail
text:
I saw a B7 Alpina the other day, it was going amusingly slow. What's the point in a car like that?

Got behind a nice new XC90 today, and honked at it because the "driver" was apparently a chicken with its head cut off.

author: berri
text: ...or they were still trying to figure out the controls!

author: fintail
text:
Maybe the nav confused them.

It was the typical east side of Seattle perplexed driver - dawdle when light turns green, go 20 in a 30, signal then change mind, creep forward, signal again then change mind, then signal and actually turn - at about 2mph.

author: PF_Flyer
text: Was behind a new Leaf at a traffic light on this chilly morning. Was a nice looking creamy white, but all I could think was... it's cold out but he doesn't look cold so he has the heat on. He's on the brake since his brake lights are on, and the turn signal is blinking... all of which are eating at his range.

author: slorenzen
text:
3 mile commute.

He'll probably make it...

author: PF_Flyer
text: Most likely... probably

author: fintail
text:
Spotted another new RX, soon to be among the top 10 selling cars in Bellevue.

Also saw a newer E63 wagon in the workplace parking garage.

author: PF_Flyer
text: Maybe it was the grey, wet morning that made it stand out, but I saw a car carrier, obviously heading towards the local Ford dealership with 6 vehicles on board, various models, but all white. Not sure I've ever seen a load like that before.

author: ab348
text: Maybe it was a fleet order of some sort?

author: PF_Flyer
text: Well there was a Mustang in there. Maybe some kind of holiday promotion for the showroom? Put red bows on them and all that

author: anythngbutgm
text: Saw quite a few new Tacomas over the weekend. Seems to be off to a good start...

author: berri
text: Should get GM to start discounting the Canyon. Pick up leader Ford is behind the 8 ball on this segment.

author: stickguy
text: they should just bring over the Ranger. That looks cool.

author: PF_Flyer
text: That roll bar reminds me a lot of the Avalanche

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Didn't that thing kind of flop?

author: stickguy
text: never made any sense to me. especially the bizarre midgate.

author: PF_Flyer
text: A friend had one for less than a year before it passed along to his son. I think he excpected something different and felt it was too "trucky"

author: stever
text:
My nephew in Chattanooga has one with about 300,000 miles on it. It has a lot of electrical problems but he loves it so much he keeps nursing it along while driving an F-150 as his main ride. He's a big camper/kayaker outdoorsy guy and loves all the cubbies for stashing gear. He really hated to hear they quit making them.

Oh, the midgate was especially cool - he could stash his longer boats in the short bed with a couple feet of the kayak(s) in the cab and cover the whole shebang.

author: texases
text: Guy at work is on his second one, tried a Tahoe after the first one then went back. He coaches youth sports, so it must be useful for what he does.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Always a pleasure to drive long distances with the bow of a kayak by your side.

author: stever
text:
Used to do that all the time with the Tercel - split the rear seat so whoever got to ride in the back enjoyed admiring three sets of tele skis with their sharp edges.

People need to get their priorities right - cars are just cars.

author: explorerx4
text: Not sure what it was, but a very Porsche looking from the back, Mercedes coupe.

author: fintail
text: AMG GT, most likely:

author: explorerx4
text: @fintail, Yes that's it, even the same color. Looks good.

author: ab348
text: Spotted my first new Civic in the wild this weekend. Really does look like an 8/10 scale Crosstour. Not sure that's a good look, though it is more palatable on a smaller car.

author: js06gv
text: Loved my 2005 Avalanche. It was one of the best vehicles I've owned. No truck had a ride as smooth as this one did. No separate cab and bed, and it was basically a Suburban with a bed carved out of the back. They had a very loyal following by owners. I was set to buy one of the last 2013 models, but unfortunately GM hadn't done much since 2007 to update the rig since it was slated for extinction and I moved to the Ford camp for an F-150. Sold the Av at 8 yrs and 53K in mint condition to a guy who works for me. I see it every day, but it's not nearly as clean as when I had it. I have to just look the other way now....

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Took my S2000 to the dealer for an oil change before tucking her away for the winter. I ended up waiting for it and in doing so saw (3) different people coming in for test drives of the new Civic sedan. One was driving a 98 Accord similar to the (2) that I owned in the past, one person had a current body Fusion-Martin and another had a last gen Rentibu.

In higher trim lines it actually looks decent, pretty unique for the segment. Mini-Crosstour, yes but it translates well to the smaller car.

Also noticed quite a few new XC90's. Handsome looking SUV, I'm really curious what they do with the XC60 which is still competitive but now going on 6 years old... Oh and also saw one of those Cross Country S60's which if there was ever an ode to those Subaru Legacy Outback sedans, it was this.

author: robr2
text: A redesign of the XC60 is expected to arrive for the 2018 model year.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: They sure are taking their time refreshing the XC60---this car is getting old in the tooth.

author: robr2
text:
It's Volvo. It'll be 10 model years old when it is replaced - just about their average.

Based on their plan, the just introduced XC90 will be the oldest vehicle in their lineup in 2018. The next XC60 - along with the S60 and V60 - will all be on the same platform and the next S40. V40. XC40 running on another new platform.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Thankfully for them, it is still their best selling model.

https://www.media.volvocars.com/global/en-gb/media/pressreleases/171102/volvo-cars-reports-best-sales-month-in-its-88-year-history-and-260-per-cent-growth

author: fintail
text: The most I have seen of the upcoming MB W213 E-Class - looks pretty impressive inside.

author: PF_Flyer
text: Not sure that it counts, but since Steve and I were on the lookout for one... hey, it was 10:30 at night and I was walking past the Tesla showroom!

author: stever
text: Does it count if it's not in the "wild"?

author: stever
text:
Oh, almost forgot. We saw a BMW i3 yesterday.

On a flatbed - appeared to be getting towed.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Oh, no! Real Life. Quick, hide the children!

author: PF_Flyer
text: Saw an i3 back in State College a couple of weeks ago. It was working a bit better than that one

author: tifighter
text: I test drove the i3 when they landed on lots. It was a pretty fun car. I was 6 months too early for decent inventory and needed a car then. Otherwise, it could have happened.

author: Michaell
text: Folks have been getting some insane lease deals on the i3 ... under $300/mo in some cases, for a car that retails north of $40K.

author: tifighter
text:
Yeah that sounds pretty good. The lease on the Leaf is up in July so I'll be looking at all the options. With the 16 Leaf having more range and things like the Bolt just around the corner, BMW is going to have to get creative with the i3 to compete next year.

Happy BDay, BTW.

author: stickguy
text: I saw an i3 out driving around a few days ago too. still odd looking.

author: PF_Flyer
text: In Santa Monica, CA with MI plates, a Buick Cascada

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Ah, a topless Verano but really an Opel Astra. Kinda merely adequate engine--I dunno. We've have to see what buyers say.

author: fintail
text:
MI plates = test car, cool.

Today I saw another newly styled not boring! RX and although not new, the Kia K9 (yes I know) is worth mention.

author: stickguy
text: That buick could work for me in a few years. Though a turbo engine would be nice.

author: ab348
text: Why anyone buys a convertible with a black interior never ceases to amaze me.

author: tlong
text: Fin, in the same post you mention a Kia and also an RX that you like the styling of?!!! WTF! Who has taken over fintail? Lol.

author: fintail
text:
I never said I liked it just that it has more styling - which is a Lexus selling point these days. I am sure it is an excellent vehicle for its purpose, and will be as reliable as one can imagine.

Kia K900 will be a future once in a blue moon car, if it isn't already - I appreciate the obscure

author: Michaell
text: Thanks. Not sure how much longer the i3 deals are gonna last

author: PF_Flyer
text: I just wish I had noticed it sooner BEFORE it was moving away from me. I coulda had a lot more angles on it.

author: PF_Flyer
text: Prowling around the streets of Santa Monica this morning looking for cars, but just the usual crop of run of the mill BMWs, Maseratis, Benz and Porsches. I was reduced to shooting alternate rental transportation

author: stever
text: Spotted this ride this morning at the beach.

author: stever
text:
And a closer look.

According to the label on the window, this car is known to the state of California to cause various ailments.

author: Sandman6472
text:
Have seen a few new Civic's at the Honda store where we have our Hertz kiosk. They have one in the showroom right now, locked up tight, an EX-L I think which stickers for over $30K...absolutely nuts!! They do have a $1495 appearance package which I'd just ignore personally. Just haven't come to terms with the look of it though. Like the dash and the single digital speedo but the outside looks a bit to transformerish, at least to my eyes. I've only owned one Honda, my 2006 LX, and still don't get the whole "Honda thing". It was an adequate vehicle, ran pretty well except for a few recalls and problems that were anything but "Hondaish". Corporate only stepped up and paid for half of those "issues" which left me a bit unhappy to say the least since I had always heard how bullet proof they were...mine certainly was not! Got rid of it with just under 47K on the clock two years back and don't miss it all that much to be honest.
The only Honda that interests me now is the HR-V but until they put knobs back on their infotainment systems, they will not see any of my greenbacks! There are just too many other better vehicles out there now to be honest. Honda should really be keeping their eyes on Hyundai/Kia as they are doing some amazing things with their vehicles. Honda, and Toyota for that matter, should keep a very very close eye!!

The Sandman

author: iluvmysephia1
text: sandman, wow, you are one of very few on Edmunds who understands the value proposition of Hyundai/Kia vehicles. The more I look at the 2016 Scion iA and the upcoming 2017 Mitsubishi Mirage re-design, the more I think I'll just hold with my 2011 Kia Soul base clear white 5-speed stick. I've had a really good record with all three of my Kia's. For the money paid and IMO the body design, Long-Haul Warranty and engineering, Kia's are hard ta beat. I prefer Kia styling over Hyundai styling or I would totally include Hyundai in my argument.

author: tjc78
text: I don't think I'd ever see you write that!

author: tjc78
text: Yes, If I had a convertible it would certainly have to be light beige or light grey. Black would just be too hot.

author: stickguy
text:
Not many reasonably priced, not too large convertibles available that also gave a back seat and decent trunk room.

Besides, it's really an Opel!

author: PF_Flyer
text:
Lesson learned. I need to get the camera out of the bag before I hit the street. Went out to take a morning stroll before the flight out and had just started walking up the street when a car pulled away from the curb and was pulling a U-turn. Then it hit me, it wasn't making much noise! Until I could get the camera out, lens cap off and turned on, my "Tesla in the wild" had almost gotten away!


Coming out the the Edmunds company party, I saw this Volt and Leaf at the watering hole, fighting for sustenance

author: fintail
text: Tesla in the wild? Come to Seattle!

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I see at least one a day on the road, some days 3 or 4. Fun car to drive if you get the chance.

author: texases
text: 2 Teslas in my parking garage at work, in TX (no dealers) no less.

author: Michaell
text:
I saw two the other morning on my way to breakfast!

Colorado has some of the highest incentives in the country for electric cars.

author: fintail
text:
I might see 10 a day, no kidding. The novelty has worn off, the trickle down incentives, not so much.

Kind of on that idea, I saw an electric motorcycle this morning, kind of a pseudo-sport style. Those should have a Tesla incentive too.

author: tjc78
text: I wonder how the last generation Solara Convertibles drive? I had a 2000 V6 Coupe and it was a fantastic car.

author: stever
text:
I saw my first one in the wild leaving Santa Monica on I-10 this morning. It was in the HOV lane and I didn't have the camera handy. We passed it.

Also saw a nice black MB ES 350 (I think). It had these wheels:



Arrived in Palm Springs and have spotted another i3.

author: tlong
text: Or California!

author: tlong
text: I saw a CLA 250 Hatchback today. I didn't realize they came in a hatch - is that new? It was much better looking IMHO than the sedan; I had to take a closer look. I presume it's still kind of unimpressive like the sedan? Or is it generally though of in a better light?

author: texases
text: I think that's the GLA.

author: Michaell
text: The GLA is the mini CUV version of the CLA sedan

author: fintail
text:
Must have been a GLA. There's an A hatch and a CLA shooting brake, but neither are sold in USA or Canuckistan. Mexico does get the A hatch.

That reminds me, I saw a GLA45 AMG .

author: tlong
text: Thanks for the clarification guys.

author: iluvmysephia1
text: All this Tesla-talk has me thinking the $6,800 Elio Motors 84mpg rig. Under development for many years and pretty much struggling ta get off the ground, it'll freak thousands of people out if they actually get delivered to any of those who put money down on one. 3 Wheels of Fortune for ya there!

author: explorerx4
text: In the parking lot at work, a GLA and couple of RAV-4's.

author: PF_Flyer
text: We've had electric motorcylces for the campus police here at Penn State for a while now

author: stever
text: Low gas prices will kill them if nothing else. Even California gas is under $3 a gallon at lots of stations.

author: iluvmysephia1
text:
Even California gas is under $3 a gallon at lots of stations.

That freaks me out!

author: laurasdada
text: No dearth of Teslas in the Boston area. And, leavin' on a jet plane tonight for LA. Hope to go to the Peterson. But, first, Frozen on Ice!

author: fintail
text:
That's a maxi-scooter

I am pretty sure the one I saw was a "Zero", like this:



Cool, but ridiculously expensive compared to gasoline bikes.

author: ab348
text: Those electric bikes are a bit dangerous in that they make virtually no noise, so they can sneak up on other vehicles and pedestrians who are unaware of their presence. We've had a few accidents here attributed to that.

author: fintail
text: Or is the real problem vehicles and pedestrians not paying attention? Any bike should have headlights on while moving, so past that, someone else needs to take responsibility too. It touches on the "loud pipes save lives" theory, which isn't supported by any data.

author: Sandman6472
text:
Saw a new 2016 Rav4 at the new rental car intake area yesterday. Liked the front and the alloys on the LE model. Was typical white rental car but they tweaked it nicely for this mid year refresh. Have liked all the Rav4's I've driven at work and they seem to be pretty popular down here in South Florida along with the Mazda CX-5, Hyundai Tucson and the Kia Sportage. For some unknown reason, cuv's are particularly popular down South here and hey, even I was bitten with the bug for a little more than a year back at the end of 2013 before I came back to my senses and went back down to a small vehicle.

The Sandman

author: iluvmysephia1
text:
For some unknown reason, cuv's are particularly popular down South here and hey, even I was bitten with the bug for a little more than a year back at the end of 2013 before I came back to my senses and went back down to a small vehicle.

I agree, sandman. I am going to lightly research this new Mazda CX-3, mainly because I was really wanting their new Mazda 2 hatchback. And yes, that is exactly what the new CX-3 is. But I won't give Mazda $25,000 or over for the cool little hatchback. I do like how they designed the little zoom-zoomer.

But the larger rigs are for someone else, my rigs need ta be small, maneuverable rigs. Them are me favorites.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Those of us who ride BMW motorcycles are used to that stealth quality

author: Michaell
text: @iluvmysephia1 - I test drove the CX-3. It's not really large inside, but you do sit up higher than in a regular car.

author: stever
text: Walked by a new MDX an hour ago. Temp tags. Kind of a red wine color.

author: stickguy
text: parked next to a new Mustang today. Real dark green, a GT (stickshift even). really, really sharp.

author: fintail
text: I saw a CX-3 today, too.

author: iluvmysephia1
text: Did you drive an automatic CX-3, Michaell? Does Mazda even offer a stick CX-3?

author: explorerx4
text: Last night at a holiday party, an Acura RLX(?). The big one.

author: stickguy
text: No stick shift option on the CX-3. Automatic only.

author: Michaell
text: Automatic.

author: iluvmysephia1
text:
No stick shift option on the CX-3. Automatic only.

I knew there was something else I read about the 2016 Mazda CX-3 that I couldn't live with. Ugh. Because I do like the design. To spend $25,000 on one of these was not something I had totally crossed off my list because I really love the design of the little hatchback. It's just that lack of a stick shift thing - that does cross it off my list totally. Thanks for the information, guys!

author: robr2
text: $50K for a FWD bias, compact SUV. Ouch.

author: fintail
text: And they can hit 60K without a ton of effort.

author: Michaell
text: Guess I'm a bit surprised that there isn't an X1M from BMW to compete against the GLA45 and SQ5

author: kyfdx
text: They haven't done an X3M, yet..

author: texases
text: New S550 coupe, all the windows down - does MB make the only true hardtop coupes now (no 'B' pillar)? Nice look, distinctive rear lights, not just a 2-door version of the sedan.

author: PF_Flyer
text: Out for breakfast and a red Soul parked outside the window I was sitting at. Thought it looked really sharp with the black trim. I wonder if some tasteful white pinstriping would enhance it!

author: stickguy
text: Read a review recently in local paper on a soul (the papers road test guy). Liked it a lot. Seems that the 14/15 were a big improvement over the prior iteration.

author: PF_Flyer
text: Hamsters were NOT driving it

author: ab348
text: I see a lot of them around and don't mind them, but they always look to me like they would blow over in a crosswind.

author: stever
text:
This rental Prius is working well. Some real irritants, like the stupid location of the USB plug - if it was ours, an extension cable will live there permanently. The overall impression is yep, it's a car. More comfy than the current van, not quite as comfy as the Quest was.

Wish I could do a long road trip driving a Soul now.

Spotted a new Highlander this morning with temp tags.

author: explorerx4
text: In the parking lot at work, a JGC SRT 8.

author: fintail
text:
Is the Bentley Continental a HT?

MB has had at least one 2 door HT model in continuous production since 1961.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: It looks like its a HT--I can't see a B pillar in the photos. Lovely car, and man, does it scoot! I'm sure I'll trip over one in Marin County soon enough and I'll be sure to ask the owner.

author: texases
text: Yes, looks like the Continental is a hardtop, I just can't find a picture with the windows down.

author: fintail
text: Here's a dealer pic:

author: texases
text: Bingo!

author: PF_Flyer
