text: Not particularly special, just weird. On the way back from the gym this morning, I found myself on the rural road that leads back out to my place in a strange 4 car parade of vehicles. I was vehicle #2. 1,3, & 4 were all dark blue Hyundai Elantras. I think they were 2011-2012 range. Only wish I had been standing roadside with my camera

author: berri
text: Do you think they were fleet or rental cars maybe?

author: PF_Flyer
text: Nope, just folks driving in the same direction for a bit. One turned off just before my neighborhood, one into my neighborhood, and the other continued on. Just a really strange happenstance

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Must have been the Hyundai Elantra Nationals. Very intense competition.

author: PF_Flyer
text: Ya, the Bulgarian judge is particularly hash

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Oh, yes, don't get judged by Yovkov!

author: stickguy
text: Same vein, at supermarket yesterday, a nice white TLX (still don't see many of them). And about 3 spits down, an identical one!

author: Michaell
text: I've seen a couple of TLXs around the last week or two. Starting to grow on me.

author: stickguy
text: I like them. Still on short list for next car in 2 years. Though that list tends to be quite fluid.

author: Michaell
text:
stick, you and I are in the same boat, just a year apart.

Tell me (well, us) - is there anything that is absolutely not on your list when you lease again?

author: stickguy
text:
Well, hopefully I don't lease. But either way, not much! It won't be big though. Very possibly slightly used.

I can't wait to find out myself!

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Audi R8---not many details on engine or year---went by too fast!

author: stever
text: 2004ish Buick Century in white this morning. That one and the similar era "Taurus" type of sedan reminds me of the puffy car we saw at a museum earlier this week:

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I warned them not to dial in too much boost.

author: tjc78
text: You would cringe at my driveway with my two tanks! When is the Sonata's lease up?

author: stickguy
text:
November 2017. So I got time.

Could be another full size mid sizer (what I consider the Sonata class these days), but ideally either a sporty car or a more compact (Jetta/A3/G37/S60) size sedan.

author: Michaell
text:
I think the G37 is a fairly large car compared to the others you've listed.

I'm a year ahead of you - the lease on the Elantra GT is up November 2016. No idea what I'll replace it with.

author: stickguy
text: G37 I think is about 184"? Not really much bigger than a Jetta. That size range is fine to me. The "mama bear" size.

author: kyfdx
text: Yeah... in real-world experience, the G seem fairly compact. It's a big heavy pig, though..

author: stickguy
text: well, if the MPG doesn't bother you, the 337 HP can probably haul the pork around just fine.

author: kyfdx
text:
I've had my daily driver for 5.5 years (235 HP), and it has a top speed of over 150 MPH, and yet, have never touched 100 MPH, even once.

But, the G37, which we had on a three year lease? At least a dozen times.. It was just too easy.

author: fintail
text: Saw a couple new Civics at the dealer today. Looks a lot bigger, not sure if I am convinced by that window design.

author: stickguy
text:
I still haven't seen one up close in person. Soon enough. Car show is only 6 weeks away!

seeing a ton of new Pilots. at least 2 in my neighborhood now. And a few houses up, someone has a new design maxima. Odd looking beast.

author: texases
text: Really strange that I haven't seen a single new Pilot.

author: qbrozen
text: I spotted something new last night I wasn't even aware of. It was dark and I was on the highway, so I didn't get the best look. But I was cruising along when I spotted an odd-looking SUV coming up the onramp near me. I kept staring at it trying to figure it out. Looked to be some sort of Kia but also a bit Evoque'ish. Later down the highway, it passed me. It was a new Discovery Sport.

author: berri
text: For a vehicle that has been out several years now, I also don't seem to see all those many Highlanders. But then, so many cars really don't seem to have styling that stands out, so maybe we actually see more new vehicles than we think?

author: ab348
text: I used to see a fair number of the original Highlander, but later/larger models are almost non-existent around here. They seem to have gotten quite expensive.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I think the base LE in the real world runs around $35K out the door but the hybrid models just get started at $50K. I loaded one up online and ran it to $55K, before taxes.

author: jpp75
text: Yep, my only issue with my G37x was fuel economy, but everything else more than made up for it. I miss that car.

author: berri
text: This weekend I saw a new Lexus RX and what I'm pretty sure was the new Maxima. What in the heck is going on with front end styling anymore - hideous, putrid, vile... These cars will look like '61 Plymouth's in a few years!

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I think designers are finally running out of ideas....or at least ideas that can be built efficiently.

author: PF_Flyer
text: Movie and music maker s seem to be running out of ideas, can't imagine that designers would be as well. But seriously, a LOT of ideas have been tried already, so we are down to variations on themes. Maybe fins aren't going to come back, but some vestige or variation of fins in combination with other design elements could lead to something that's pleasing to the eye. Sometimes the attempt isn't quite a box office boffo smash (think Aztek) but I like that they at least tried. I really didn't like it when everyone was on the aerodynamic jellybean kick and all the cars were starting to look like Tauruses that had gotten different amounts of water!

author: stever
text: Not much else they can do until we go magnetic or whatever and lose the wheels.

author: berri
text: Talk about running out of ideas - what are there, something like 4 different cable TV series dealing with Alaska and a bunch more about outdoors and northwoods? A year or so ago it was a bunch about the southern boonies. I suppose next year it will tons of big city shows? Maybe this is what happens when the government moves education from critical thinking and creativity to standardized multiple choice tests.

author: stever
text:
Follow the money.

Alaska provides big subsidies to the TV/Movie industry and reality shows are cheap to make.

author: fintail
text:
The design industry also seems to be inhabited by a lot of sycophants and copycats - one does it, the rest join in, or does things to agree with and impress their boss or professor.

Regarding TV, indeed, reality is cheaper - no actors, no special effects, no highly developed scripts (just lowly developed scripts). And the masses watch it. The old timers who grew up in such a more strenuous education environment (yeah right) are still in control and are approving all this stuff, you know.

author: berri
text: I just can't fathom how people can watch these cable channels of the same show over and over on a given night. Maybe I've just got ADD or something.

author: fintail
text: Remember what Elvis did to his TV

author: stever
text:
lol, had to look that one up. Thought I knew a lot of E.A.'s trivia, being from that part of the world, but I missed that one.

The show about the wilderness homesteaders is typical of the fakery. We've stayed at that place (Jewel's family owns it), and it's like 7 seven miles down a paved road from Homer. When you get bored from filming, you can pop into the Salty Dawg for a brew in about ten minutes. .

author: texases
text:
"Regarding TV, indeed, reality is cheaper - no actors, no special effects, no highly developed scripts (just lowly developed scripts)."

And no reality! Read an interesting article on how 'House Hunters International' is pretty much 100% staged and scripted, sellers aren't real, buyers aren't real, maybe the house/condo/hovel actually did sell, but not by them or to them.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Saw a few new RX's this weekend. Hard to distinguish it from the NX when it's coming at you. Still not sure what this fad is with the broken D-pillar as it looks odd and probably doesn't save much on weight.

Speaking of which, also saw a few new Murano's, again the broken D-pillar...

author: fintail
text:
House Hunters and similar shows are just propaganda for the real estate and connected industries. There's a large and financially influential/controlling demographic out there who is addicted to houses and all that stuff, so it works. Keeps the money flowing. Eventually you get an economy dependent on it.

On topic, lots of realtors seem to drive Lexus RX, which is a new car that will sell out for the honeymoon period.

author: Michaell
text: Our realtor bought a new car earlier this year ... Ford Explorer.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I think cars are becoming to each other like computers and tablets have become to each other. Probably the Italians are the only ones willing to go way out there on design. In the JDM, there's some pretty wild stuff being conceptualized, but it rarely comes to market.

author: explorerx4
text: I think the exterior of the NX looks good, but the interior is a disaster.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: The NAV looks like something somebody made in shop class.

author: ab348
text: Come on, Shifty, wagons are the new Hemis!

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Maybe when the nerds take over the world and give up on their Pacers and Dodge Darts.

author: iluvmysephia1
text:
Maybe when the nerds take over the world and give up on their Pacers and Dodge Darts.

Don't forget their AMC Gremlins!

author: stickguy
text: wait, I had a Gremlin and a Dart (well, technically a Duster, but close enough)! And a Hornet for good measure.

author: iluvmysephia1
text: Yeah, I had a Plymouth Gold Duster, if we're confessing Mopar possessions.

author: stever
text:
lol, '89 Voyager here.

And the minivan was the new hemi and saved Chrysler. For a while.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: But Lexus has no excuse for design like this. They aren't a cash-starved entity like AMC was back when. I'm sure the NAV system is not held up by double-sided tape, but I'm going to look for myself, just in case.

author: laurasdada
text: My Mopar moment, '99 Chrysler 300M (preceded by company car Dodge Intrepid). Both, somewhat poorly screwed together, but reliable and fun. For grande sedans...

author: tifighter
text: I saw a Chevrolet SS in silver. That has to be a fairly rare bird; I've never actually seen one until now.

author: tjc78
text: I saw five of them the other day.... In a line all with Police badging.  Must have been new fleet additions.

author: stickguy
text: yesterday on I287 in Jersey (the northern part where the money is!), not 1, but 2 Maserati Ghiblis, in the space of about 5 minutes. Sharp car.

author: tifighter
text: There's a house I drive past on the way to the office that looks pretty divey, but has a white Ghibli and a new Camaro with a matte blue wrap in the driveway. I want to know what's going on there, until I realize I probably don't want to know.

author: explorerx4
text:
In the parking lot at work.. a new XC90.
On the way home, I saw a new Prius or Volt, not sure which.

author: fintail
text: New style 7er, with the chrome hockey stick on the side. Structurally interesting car, will need good luck to fight the S-class.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Also the 7 series needs to continue to ramp up reliability. This car is still shaking off a terrible reputation from the past.

author: texases
text: While I haven't seen the new 7 on the road, the photos make it look just like the current 5 and 3. Not very high end...

author: fintail
text:
The new 7 is pretty anonymous, the hockey stick is the key. I think the F01 was reliable enough, but the previous two could be troublesome.

Saw a new RX slowly going around a corner, followed by a loud HONK that made me laugh. Also a new XC90, this one caught my eye as it had very noticeable rear bumper fitment issues. I assume it got hit (or backed into something, this is Bellevue) rather than was made that way.

author: stever
text:
Designed in Germany, Built in Chattanooga.

2016 Passat in the lobby of the Chattanooga airport.

author: explorerx4
text: Our local Hartford area airport has Fiats, Jags and Maserati's.

author: stever
text:
Airports are kind of dangerous places to park a new car.

Woman Returns Rental Car to Baggage Claim (Fox)

author: stickguy
text:
seems logical to me.

what can you expect from an oldster driving a minivan, right Steve?

author: explorerx4
text: Hmm, I wonder if my F 150 will fit through doors so I can get close to the baggage carousel?

author: stever
text:
lol, now you know why I had to move from Boise.

My brother took off to Florida and left me the keys to his house and car. They are pulling the popup with their F-150 so I get to drive ... wait for it ... their 2013 Odyssey.

author: fintail
text: Good security there

author: berri
text: Now that's curbside service. hahaha

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Good thing she didn't rent an F350

author: PF_Flyer
text: Well at least she actually saw another car there and not some giant poster of a car

author: qbrozen
text: i saw my first GLE coupe in the flesh on the road yesterday (a 450, to be exact). Man, that thing is UGLY!

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: It bears an uncomfortable resemblance at certain angles to a Pontiac Aztek.

author: stickguy
text: can't wait to cruise the MB display at the car show in a few weeks.

author: fintail
text:
BMW and MB have now filled every niche, and are forced to copy each other. The GLE Coupe is aimed at the X6 and its usually ostentatious demographic.

The fastback SUV trend definitely reminds one of the Aztek.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Even Jaguar is jumping into the crossover game.

author: fintail
text: Got behind a new unregistered Range Rover today. Speeding, poor lane positioning, poor signal use - the French handled this demographic perfectly a while back.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Probably trying to reach the repair shop before flame out.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Saw quite a few RAV4 hybrids this weekend. Also saw (2) new GLE Mercs, non-coupe flavor.

Supposedly there will be an X2 in the BMW camp, so the Coupe-Crossover isn't going away any time soon. I actually really dig the GLE Coupe myself.

Lastly, I spotted (2) new Audi Q7's. European SUV's are really popular around here. Not Honda Pilot or Explorer popular, but they are prevalent.

author: fintail
text: Not new, but amusing and I don't know where else to put it. Yesterday I saw a previous gen Acura TL, with the beak - this one had a "full Florida" treatment including a very padded cabrio look top with blanked out rear quarters, and chrome wheels. Wacky.

author: Michaell
text: Not new, but rare. First was a jaguar X type wagon, sec it was the Murano cabriolet

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Never understood why anyone in his right mind thought a Murano cabriolet was a good idea.

author: stever
text: Off road convertible that's a bit more comfy than a Wrangler? Actually thought it'd be good for snow country. High clearance and AWD for pushing through the drifts, and then drop the top in the Spring and Fall. Save a space in your garage.

author: laurasdada
text: Yes, but the Jag F-Pace does not appear to be a hunchbacked doorstop bit of ugliness... Plan to go to the New England Auto Show Friday. Maybe NYIAS in April?

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Yeah, nothing like mending fences or wild sheep hunting in your Murano cabriolet. Steve, go to your room.

author: Michaell
text:
I have thought for some time that an AWD convertible would be a great car to have here in Colorado.

Not many choices available now - Audi A3 or A5 and the Wrangler.

author: texases
text: Only thing going for it to me was the decent rear seat room. Any other convertible that could hold 4 adults?

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: This could work:

author: fintail
text: Saw a new style 7er on the road today, without the chrome hockey stick it would be hard to notice.

author: fintail
text: Saw an i8 on the road today, and a big mouth bass Prius C, likely a rental.

author: tifighter
text: Last week, I saw an i8 and a Fisker Karma within 2 minutes while driving through, wait for it, Puyallup. Definitely a WTH moment.

author: fintail
text: The nav must have misrouted them on the way back to Bellevue.

author: tifighter
text: Maybe. Saw my first Model X today in Mercer Island. White. That makes more sense.

author: fintail
text: Good sighting, haven't seen one of those Faberge eggs yet. Most remarkable thing I saw today was a Lexus NX that was actually being driven in a mildly lively manner.

author: tifighter
text: Yeah, the white color does nothing to dispel the egg analogy. I was driving with my wife; when I pointed it out to her, she commented about how not special it looked.

author: Sandman6472
text:
That's why I like my blue on my Golf especially with the 17" Joda wheels...have gotten a few comments at gas stations while pumping petrol and even a few at the supermarket. I did consider red for a nano second but it's really red and thought I'd stick out a bit. With the right alloys, the white would look great to. I know on our A3, the white fits it and the nice lines of the vehicle. After having silver vehicles for so long, decided I'd get something totally different, the white was all the dealer had with the options the wife wanted last December. We had a white Cutlass Supreme back in 1985 with a blue vinyl roof and blue interior and come to think of it, I had a '96 white over blue Corolla, so we have done white also. One tends to forget after awhile what vehicles one owned over the years.

The Sandman

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Probably the gas pedal jammed in the floor mat

author: ab348
text:
That was blamed for this bad valet parking job yesterday:

http://www.wcvb.com/news/valet-crashes-jeep-into-indoor-pool/37569766

Good thing there was nobody in the pool. I like how the wipers stayed on the whole time.

author: fintail
text: Not "Only in a Jeep". I wonder how many mats get blamed for pedal misapplication.

author: berri
text: "blame someone else" isn't that the American way, perhaps furthered along by the huge excess of law school graduates out there. Heck, daytime TV ads seem to be dominated by pharmaceuticals and trial attorney commercials.

author: fintail
text:
Stopped by the MB dealer for a sec while out doing errands. Loaded C450, 63K MSRP, high option
GLE coupe 76K MSRP - I admit the pano is cool in it, E63S with few options for 107K, and blowout lease on 2016 E already - base 4Matic car for something like $450+ tax with I think a few grand up front - there will be deals on these come summer.

author: qbrozen
text: I will be keeping an eye out for the GLC 450, but that's probably about it as far as the MB lineup goes these days for me. While an E63 would be appealing, of course, the price is just way out there for my budget.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Is anyone actually buying the GLEs?

author: fintail
text: Normal GLE is just the new name for the ML - they will sell them by the boatload. GLE coupe is MBs version of the X6, and will sell to a much smaller customer base. I think I have seen maybe 5 on the road so far.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Yeah, I meant the GLE coupe. I can't imagine why anyone would want one, nor can I imagine why Benz (or BMW) even builds things like this. Have they all gone "niche-crazy"?

author: texases
text: Yeah, and BMW's the worst niche maker. How many 3/4 series variants are out there? A dozen?

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: How ironic that the Germans are trying to replicate the AMC Eagle for $70,000 bucks.

author: fintail
text:
There's a segment of the affluent who like homely brash jerky cars - enter the X6. They are often driven by a specific demographic here. MB saw that BMW is likely earning good margins on those, so they made their own. BMW and MB are trying to out-niche each other, and it has come to the point where they sometimes simply copy each other.

Subaru replicated the AMC Eagle best, for a mere ~30K.

author: fintail
text: And what did I see this afternoon - white GLE coupe, and the driver was the expected demographic.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: a blind person?

author: fintail
text: Nah, just showy, and probably lucky at receiving gifts. Their prior car might have been an X6.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Oh, it shows something all right. More dollars than sense.

author: fintail
text:
That sums up a lot of people with a lot of dollars in my area.

Today had a new unplated i3 next to me in the workplace parking garage, and found out the black Ferrari 458 I see now and then is indeed the chariot of the CEO.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Car and Driver summed it up nicely:

"The bobtailed GLE-class is more perplexing than it is attractive. Its athletic stance implies something small and svelte, yet the Mercedes footprint approaches that of a Chevy Tahoe,"

author: texases
text: Saw my first new Pilot. Not very distinctive, Edmunds isn't particularly liking theirs.

author: berri
text: It's a modified minivan to me. Unlike the aircraft builders, the stretched version (Odyssey) came first

author: texases
text: A new 'smart' car in the lot at work...'smart'? I think not! Just got a terrible rating from CR this month.

author: texases
text: I also saw a Macan, not that unusual except I noticed it has a HUGE hood. Wonder why???

author: fintail
text: I saw what appeared to be an X4M today - looked like it had the badging, and it was launching with the subtle non-dbaggy 5K off the line jump typical for many M car drivers around here. Also a Kia K-9(00).

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I hear they vastly improved the transmission on the Smart car--now it's just pretty awful. To be fair, I haven't driven a brand spankin' new U.S. one, but I did drive the 4-door in Europe recently, and that was a manual transmission. All I can say is it's a bit better than a Fiat 500.

author: texases
text: One can get a Fit for about the same money as a 'smart'...let me think.....

author: fintail
text: i8 with a license plate "FUTURE", a little obnoxious.

author: kyfdx
text:
Short road trip, yesterday..

Tesla Model S

Maserati Coupe . Don't know the model, but it looked like a supercar, coming up from behind.

Volvo S60 T6 AWD - handsome car.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Speaking for myself, I'd rather have one hour in a vintage BMW 2002Tii than a week in one of those.

author: fintail
text: I think the i8 is actually pretty cool - but it is a bit ostentatious right now.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I wonder if anyone will want this car when it's 3-4 years old?

author: fintail
text:
Depends how the tech ages. Old BMWs sometimes don't age well. I doubt it will be like an M1 is today, anyway.

On the road today - new Civic, GLE coupe (probably the same car I saw the other day), GLC, 2x Murano - one a rental.

author: stever
text: Fiat 500L. Don't remember ever seeing one of these in the wild before.

author: texases
text:
I parked next to a Lamborghini Aventador at the grocery store. Of course, they were probably going to the Starbucks next door...gone when I got back, too bad, I wanted another look-see
Looked just like this:

author: Michaell
text: Could it have been a rental? I see them quite frequently around Denver.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Oh, well....the cheap Lamborghini......

author: texases
text:
"Oh, well....the cheap Lamborghini......"

I thought that was the Huracan? $400k+ for the Aventador, $250k+ for the Huracan?

author: stever
text: Maybe, but I'm thinking it was a local. Three passengers and they looked a bit college-ish. The university is on the right in this snap and they turned left into the student housing/shopping kind of area.

author: fintail
text:
By the plate frame, I doubt it is a rental. Maybe an ex-rental, although I am sure someone bought one (actually, there was one in my old workplace parking garage).

Speaking of that garage, saw a new unplated A5 cabrio there today.

author: stever
text: The other factor is that we don't have scheduled air service here. We do have a couple of busy rental agencies, but I think the inventory is less than someplace of a similar size with some flights coming in. The airport rentals around here probably have Texas plates (although the rental I got last month had Colorado plates on it).

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Yes, you're right, unless we're comparing it to a Porsche 918 Spider (about 2X the price of an Aventador?) . I got my Lambos mixed up.

author: tifighter
text: A study in silver. Sighted yesterday - Cadillac ELR. Silver. Sales failure aside, this is a good looking car. I'm sure it would be better in another color. Second sighting - New Prius. Silver. First one I've seen. Ugh. Lee. And I'm afraid to think that silver is probably one of the better colors for it. Avoid airport taxis, if possible soon.

author: texases
text: ELR - RIP

author: Sandman6472
text:
New Elantra at the Hyundai store, a mini Sonata. A GLA, my favorite and multiple CLA's which are doing well down here in South Florida. Live very close to our local MB store and see a lot out on test drives. South Florida, like California I suspect, is a very car conscious area and with dismal public transport, owning a vehicle is almost mandatory. And with the great economy and car sales at all time highs, lots of new iron on our roads!

The Sandman

author: berri
text: ...or drug money

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: or inheritance.

author: berri
text: Miami is like LA though, you can spot a lot of expensive and not too often seen elsewhere vehicles driving around.

author: tlong
text: It's interesting - I'm in SoCal but work a lot in the Bay Area. In Southern Cal we see a lot of everything, except perhaps US-nameplate sedans. In the Bay Area, a disproportionately large number of Teslas, Prii, Leafs, the new BMW electric, etc. Kind of interesting.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: San Francisco is a small city---kind of a toy city a rich man might buy his kid for Christmas. So an electric car makes more sense here. In L.A., people drive 100 miles for a good taco.

author: tlong
text: Agreed, but the Bay Area is the entire peninsula down to Silicon Valley, plus the east bay. My sightings pertain to the entire area from SFO down to San Jose.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: That's more wide open than a large metropolis, that's true, but still pretty dense. SFO to San Jose is only 35 miles. Even a Nissan Leaf can do that round trip. I don't know about southern Cal, but in the South Bay / East Bay corridor I do see a lot of charging stations in shopping centers. It's very "groovy/greenie" up here.

author: tlong
text: Plenty of high cost vehicles in the Bay Area. I think when you see a US-nameplate sedan it's usually a rental.

author: laurasdada
text: There was a silver ELR at the New England Auto Show. No information near it, no kiosk, plaques, nothing. Just the ELR plugged in to a facsimile charging station. Have they killed it? I thought they skipped the 2015 model to bring out an improved '16, at a lower price. But, with yesterday's Volt mechanicals. Still gonna be a tough sell at $65k, if it is still with us.

author: texases
text:
What I read said it's dead.
http://jalopnik.com/the-cadillac-elr-is-dead-1756976035

author: anythngbutgm
text: Seeing quite a few new Lexus RX's these days. Looks decent in darker colors.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: New ML350 with I think factory installed runningboard lights? Nice looking SUV but those lights are super-tacky. They look like something from Home Depot.

author: kyfdx
text: Fiat 500L

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Oh you met the one person who bought one!

author: stickguy
text:
That would be the pope. He had 2. And 1 just sold for 82k!

http://www.autoblog.com/2016/01/30/pope-francis-fiat-500l-auction/

author: kyfdx
text: Someone just said they rarely saw them, and I passed one during my commute, today. Have to say, it is a pretty rare sighting.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: The pope is a curbstoner? Who knew?

author: stickguy
text: Just business baby.

author: stever
text: Guess that was me.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Ok, so we have 3 confirmed sales of the 500L now. More than I thought...

Oh, just kidding. Sales figures for January 2016 show 389 sold in the U.S., and 18 in Canada.

author: texases
text: With all the different vehicles Fiat sells, you'd think they'd have something better to bring over than the 500L. 389 sold in the US in Jan.? Why bother?

author: stickguy
text: Fiat dealers need something to out in showroom.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Well 2015 was apparently better--I think they sold something like 7,000 of them. Not exactly the 1964 &1/2 Mustang....

author: stever
text:
2016 CR-V. Spotted the temp tag first.

Also a new Soul - looked like a white/red Special Edition with extra red stripes on it.

author: stickguy
text:
at the shop rite, a new Pilot parked next to a new Edge. Liked them both. Very sharp looking. Really like what they did to the Edge. Should have sat in one at the car show!

and a real oddball. An Acura RL.

author: berri
text: You should probably sit in that Edge. Seems to be more than a little bitching about Ford moving to short seat bottoms, so you'd definitely want to check that out on it.

author: stickguy
text: yeah, I consider a short seat bottom a deal breaker. So would certainly have to sit in one. Though we are not in the market for anything like an edge even with the next purchase, so it was really just "sightseeing"

author: Sandman6472
text:
Just in conversation with the better half, seems like she's not thinking long term for her A3 as she did with her Mazda, she even mentioned the four year mark meaning that's when she thinks it might be time for something either Korean or Japanese. Quite understandable as she's not as happy as I am with our vehicles, that old appliance thinking creeping back in I suspect. Cars just don't mean that much to her, and never had.
I, on the other hand, tried to convince her otherwise, that we need to take a more real time view at that time. If things are fine, why rock the boat. But she brought up the cost of repairs, etc., things I hadn't thought about since things are all good right now. Again I said, let's wait till that time comes and see where we're at, then go from there. Just want to enjoy these first couple years of ownership, before the need for new tires and such.

The Sandman

author: stever
text:
Not new but odd. We live in a neighborhood that you access by a long, dead-end paved road up against the Organ Mountains. You can't go over the mountains even on foot, because it's fenced and guarded by the folks at White Sands Missile Range. Most all the side roads are gravel.

So last night coming home we got behind a semi-sized car carrier with six newer used SUVs and sedans on it. I was tempted to follow it but he was doing 30 in a 45 and so I passed him. If he's a neighborhood curbstoner, he's sure got the rig for it.

author: stickguy
text: probably someone getting a car delivered? Could be a shipping company.

author: stever
text:
That's a thought. Kind of odd to be delivering a car at 8 pm on a Friday night, but hey, happy weekend.

At first I figured he'd gotten off the Interstate and the GPS steered him wrong, but when he made the turn into our area, I assumed he wasn't lost.

author: berri
text: Those guys, if you can find one, have a long clock. Once had a car picked up at almost 10pm while it was snowing.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Bit surpised that I counted/spotted (8) different new Prius's this weekend. Gotta say in some colors the styling is not as offensive as I would have thought. From a side view, the nose and hood have a similar profile to a Mazda RX-8 and the tail certainly won't be mistaken for anything else...

My neighbor got a new MB GLE, I believe it replaced a current gen Explorer. Another neighbor got a new Mitsubushi Outlander (with "100 new improvements") which looks to have replaced a GM C Terrain. It definitely is an improvement in styling , those Terrains are the fugliest new vehicle on the road IMO, especially in base trim which he had...

Also spotted a ton of new Tacomas, including one that was wearing tires you would see on a jacked up F-250.

Lastly, the wife and I visited an Audi dealer this weekend to take a look around. We are really interested in the Q3 which is just the right size for her and the reviews say it's one of the most fun to drive vehicles in the class (GLA/X1/NX) but at 41g for a modestly loaded model, I think we'll just look at the X1 for the same coin.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: The GLE is no beauty queen either.

author: stever
text: Were all of these in the wild or at a dealer? We had planned to go look at one today but I got tied up.

author: anythngbutgm
text: Wild. Metrowest Boston area.

author: texases
text: Saw a new V60, nice except a little 'Infiniti overstyling' in the front hood area when viewed like this:

author: stickguy
text: Neighbor seems to have swapped his CX-5 for a new Toyota Highlander. Quite the large beast now. Lots of sharp lines and angles.

author: stickguy
text: Looks like the plug in hybrid version of the Volvo. Or a weird place for a Gas tank!

author: Michaell
text: My neighbors across the street traded in their 2013 Highlander for a 4Runner a couple weeks ago.

author: stever
text:
Looks like one of the three that were in inventory here has sold. Have to keep my eyes peeled.

That V60 does look pretty nice @texases.

author: fintail
text: Saw one of those Scion Matrix 5 doors today, with an Uber sticker. It's a car.

author: Sandman6472
text:
Drove a Prius C today and was underwhelmed. Horrendous road noise, bare bones interior. So glad I said no a few years back after the test drive. If I were to get any Prius, I'd get the 4 door wagon as thought it drove nicely and was definitely quieter. Glad my VW Golf is bringing home almost 40 mpg on my highway commute, makes getting rid of the Tucson that much better since it got under 29 for the same trip. Am using less petrol in gallons as not taking the price into account here since the amount would be the same no matter the price.

The Sandman

author: iluvmysephia1
text:
Saw one of those Scion Matrix 5 doors today, with an Uber sticker. It's a car.

It's basically a Corolla wagon, to Scion's credit it's available with a stick shift. I like it but not a lot.

author: fintail
text:
I wonder if it will become a Corolla or a Matrix once Scion is gone.

Prius C, they have to sell in significant numbers to fleets now. I still think of my friend who had one, and drove it from Atlanta to Seattle. By the end of his lease he was parking it where he thought trees might fall on it.

author: Michaell
text: When I picked up my rental Corolla last week at LAX, there were a number of Prius C's available to choose from. Since I was going to be spending a lot of time on the highway, I decided to pass.

author: iluvmysephia1
text:
I wonder how the Scion/soon ta be Toyota iA would fare in comparison. Long-term happiness, those buying it seem very pleased. It is small, but has enough room...whether the ergos of it's driver's seat is long-term good is not yet known.

Even owner/operators of the very small Mitsubishi Mirage claim football-player sized men are comfortable up front driving their Mirage's. Humm.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Driving one vaguely reminded me of the old Citroen DS, except that the Prius isn't sexy, cool, exotic or entertaining. It is innovative, though, as was the DS, I must grudgingly admit.

author: iluvmysephia1
text: The Prius mpg is what...53? Haven't spotted a new Prius on the road yet here in Dodge but we do have Lewis Toyota here in town. I'm attracted to a Prius about as much as I am to a Dodge Caravan minivan. IOW's - not very much.

author: stever
text:
Drove a '16 Prius today - was disappointed, and was a bit surprised to be disappointed. Also drove a Dodge Caravan today (and everyday, lol, just my '09, not a new one).

Enjoyed sitting in a Scion iM. Very nice cockpit, nicely executed interior. Not ready to downsize quite that much but liked it. Also spotted a nice Blue xB with a cheap MSRP. And there was a FR-S on the Toyota lot too.

Drove a '15 Soul ! with the leather. Killer panoramic sunroof, most all of the bells and whistles (including those darn 18" wheels). I was ready to talk numbers when my wife brought me back down to earth a bit.

Then drove a '16 Soul + with the killer panoramic sunroof. Went around the block and I looked up and got blinded. This one also had leather but it was the thicker "base" leather (per the salesperson) and the ventilated seats didn't seem to work as well as the seat in the '15 did.

My guess is that we could save a couple of thousand bucks going for the '15 vs a '16 ! with similar options. But since we drive them forever, I kind of want the newest I can get - the price over ten years is only an extra $200 a year.

Wish the mpg was better but I like the box and I like the higher seating position of the Soul. Kia really needs to take a page from Buick - the very nice Encore gets 28/34 while the Kia only gets 24/31.

author: Michaell
text:
Thanks for the update on the shopping.

Doesn't the Soul ! have the more powerful engine? 2.4L with 160-170 HP?

author: iluvmysephia1
text:
Wish the mpg was better but I like the box and I like the higher seating position of the Soul. Kia really needs to take a page from Buick - the very nice Encore gets 28/34 while the Kia only gets 24/31

As often as my eyes stray to the Scion iA soon-ta-be Toyota iA or this little orange '68 Datsun 411 Bluebird, I love my small clear white Soul from Kia. I don't know why I can't seem ta just stay content with it, it is a "lower end" rig, but, I wouldn't want a Scion xB box, either. I don't like how they look. We just went over 60,000 miles in our Soul, too.

And since it's "our" money, I can't just swing deals however and whenever I want. I know one thing I ought ta be very thankful for, and it's this: because of the Mrs. and her stance on flinging cash at different new and used rigs I fall in love with, we've got more retirement nest tucked away for that special 'R' time coming up. We'd both like ta head back to either New Mexico or Arizona.

Concerning spending on new rigs (or used) and just doing it come hell or high water, when I decided I wanted to trade our 2001 Kia Sportage 4X4 in on a new model of car, the 2008 Mitsubishi Lancer GTS, I just planned it all out, grabbed a spring coat and the Sportage keys one Saturday afternoon and headed for the front door of the house.

"Where ya goin'?"
"I'm goin' ta get a new Mitsubishi!"
Her response ta this insanity?

"I'm comin' with!" Couldn't believe it - but, no matter what her response was, I was going to go get my own "baby EVO." We got up to Avondale, which is about 9 miles west of Phoenix, headed in to Avondale Mitsubishi, I told them that I had talked to them earlier on the phone about a new '08 Lancer GTS in Rally Red paint and 5-speed transmission. The kid greets me and said it's in the showroom. It was an automatic CVT transmission. I was livid!

"Didn't I say I wanted a stick shift Rally Red Lancer GTS?"
Yep - it's right there. I looked at Mrs. iluv incredulously and wanted to raise my voice. They drove it outta the showroom, we took our test drive, I loved it, and on in to negotiations we went. I just couldn't believe that the sales guy didn't get it that paddle shifters aren't the same thing as manual transmissions!

author: stever
text:
Base is a 1.6l, 130 hp, 118 ft-lbs.

Other trims are a 2.0l, 164 hp, 151 ft-lbs.

Curb weight comes in under 3,000 pounds so that helps a bit.

@iluvmysephia1, we hit 85F today. If you and the missus need to get out of Dodge and warm up, come on down. (Yeah, I've been waiting years to finally have someone I can feed that line too, lol). Found a new spot today - Dick's Cafe. Greasy spoon with good burgers for me and good Mexican food for my missus.

author: iluvmysephia1
text:
Other trims are a 2.0l, 164 hp, 151 ft-lbs.

This is the engine size and hp/ft.lb.torque our 2011 clear white base 5-speed Kia Soul is. If I get far enough on our taxes later on today I'm gonna hook my new hose up and give her a wash out the back of the house. It's a long overdue thing, the Soul is dirty outside and it also needs a vacuuming of the carpet and a wipe-down of the dash/cupholder area.

In fact, perhaps I should just start with the Soul cleaning project and then do our Fed/State income taxes after that. First things first, eh? Happy ta see you're considering a Kia Soul, stever. Hey, BTW, when the Mrs. and I were at Viva Kia (you could drive the 40 miles south ta Viva Kia in El Paso and give them a try, too, for Souls) I asked if they had any Nissan cube's available ta test drive and look at. Nope - not a one - even thought Viva Kia/Mitsubishi also sells Nissan's. Bummer dude - I really wanted ta test drive a Nissan cube - love the funky shape and design. Nissan discontinued making the cube, but, I was still interested.

Yeah, we're just 525 miles NE of Alamogordo from Dodge City, KS. And it's all on Highway 54.

author: stever
text: Yeah, the first 2016 we test drove was at that El Paso dealer. Must have been back in November.

author: texases
text: About that panoramic sunroof - is there an inside cover that blocks out 100% of the light? If not, you might be buying an 'easy bake oven, solar powered version'!

author: stever
text:
Yeah, and the glass also opens after you open the cover. Or at least the front half opens.

The inside cover can be partially closed (from the back to the front). Just punch the button when you want it to stop.

A sun screen would be nice addition too. Think it was the Elantra wagon we tested that had the sunroof with the sunshade, in addition to the inside cover.

You'd hate all of this iirc, since you already will lose about 4" of headroom with the pano roof, before taking on shades.

You also lose the ability to easily add a roof rack, but I can live without those now.

author: texases
text: Yeah, that 4" hit to headroom would likely be a deal breaker. But some of the CUVs have enough headroom, even with the now almost mandatory sunroof. I think I fit in the RDX, the Q5, and, most importantly to me, the CX-5, which is on my list. But nothing soon.

author: tjc78
text: New MB GLE ... Interesting rear tail lights.  LED gone wild.

author: ab348
text:
Just for laffs, I priced out a new M-B GLC yesterday, almost no options, $46K Cdn. Interesting thing was that to get a sunroof I would have had to add a package that included Nav and a bunch of other stuff I didn't want, almost $5K!

I do like the vehicle very much but I wouldn't want to spend that much just for a sunroof.

author: qbrozen
text: I'm holding out to see how a GLC 450 AMG turns out.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Holy Poundage Batman---the new 550e GLE plug-in hybrid weighs 5,400!

author: Sandman6472
text:
Prefer the GLA 250 here, have driven a few at work and just love it. Hoping that in another year or two, the CPO price will be reasonable. If not, can wait a few more years to get myself one. Plan to fully retire again in another 4 years once I hit 65 and get one right before that, if possible.

The Sandman

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Also checked out the GLC this weekend, It looks better in person than it did in the pics, and the interior is fantastic IMO. The only thing that I would question is the 4-cylinder under the hood of a 4200lb SUV, but that's the thing these days unfortunately. Volvo, now MB... Still, at 21/28mpg, I have to wonder what those stats would be with a nice gutsy 6-cylinder as an optional/upgrade mill. Even the Acura RDX with the old J-series V6 achieves 20/29...

I have read an AMG version is coming, but I imagine a pricetag well into the 60's...

On a side note, my wife actually fell in love with a green GLA250 that the dealer had. I didn't even know that color was offered, it stood out in the see of greys and blacks around it for sure.

Also checked out the Mazda CX-3 again, man what a great looking little package and a very reasonable price loaded. Shame, as the reviews all ding it for sluggish acceleration.

author: stever
text: I found the CX-3 plenty peppy, just a bit tight.

author: texases
text: If you're looking at the GLC, why not the CX-5?

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: 0-60 in 8 seconds should be more than adequate for most people. No slower than a Subaru Crosstrek Premium with manual transmission.

author: anythngbutgm
text: GLC for myself, the wife likes smaller cars which is why she likes the CX-3. The CX-5 would be more my taste as well...

author: anythngbutgm
text: I;ve actually read as high as 9.5 - 10 seconds. Great car in search of more power.

author: Michaell
text: The CX-3 I test drove seemed plenty powerful enough for around town duty.

author: stever
text: My "review" is in the comments to this article from last summer. (found it plenty peppy). The editors said "As with most every vehicle in this burgeoning segment, the CX-3 has only modest power. Still, it makes the most of what it has."

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I think that's too pessimistic. Most tests I've read fall into 8.1 to 8.5

author: iluvmysephia1
text:
I found the CX-3 plenty peppy, just a bit tight.

You can't get a Mazda CX-3 in stick shift form, true? I like it's looks, indeed.

author: Michaell
text: We talked about this recently. No stick shift available in the CX-3, in any trim level. Conventional 6-speed automatic (flappy paddles on the steering wheel for higher trim levels, IIRC).

author: texases
text: At least Mazda's not going CVT, like Honda is. That's a big plus to me.

author: Michaell
text: Me, too. One of the reasons why I like Hyundai, as well.

author: Sandman6472
text:
Mike, drove another car like yours at work and liked it even though it had the bolt on wheel covers. The alloys give it a much better look to be honest and felt very comfy in the drivers seat. Prefer hatchbacks (5 doors) than a conventional sedan for the hauling capabilities when needed and have to have a smallish vehicle to be happy. MPG's aren't as good as my Golf and that was a big reason I swapped out for it. Since I'm up to about 13K/year, want something somewhat economical, once I stop working, don't really care if the mileage is a bit lower because my miles/year will also be going down. That's why the GLA is on my short list as with the lower miles/year, the less miles over all will be just fine. I just want the rest of the vehicles I buy to be super fun with luxury appointments as I drove econoboxes for so long just to get to this point. I feel I deserve what ever I want now in my senior years and luckily, I do not have to get any permission when I do purchase. Figure I'm paying the bills, all of them, on it so I get what I want!

The Sandman

author: berri
text: Saw a Chevy Volt, no dealer stickers, regular tags - I think it was actually owned or leased by someone!

author: iluvmysephia1
text: Wow, a Volt bought or leased by someone? Chevy may sell more Volt's than Mitsubishi sells i-Miev's, but I don't really know for sure!

author: fintail
text: Saw a new squared-off Q7 in traffic today, the new design makes it look smaller.

author: tjc78
text: Spotted a new Chrysler 200 at my house this morning.  It was my Moms rental (minor fender bender getting repaired). I asked her what she thought about it and she said it was a "tinny piece of crap, that can't get out of its own way". Lol, this coming from a 4cyl Venza driver.  It must be slow as all heck.  The Venza is built like a tank, so I understand her there.

author: texases
text: Maybe that's why they're going to quit making the 200 in a couple of years...

author: stickguy
text: They will replace it with something, right? Or are the going with SUVs and a large sedan only?

author: Michaell
text:
Both the Dart and the 200 are slated for extinction .. no plans to replace either.

FCA is on the ropes ... they can't sustain themselves selling trucks and Jeeps alone.

author: stickguy
text: Interesting. I thought they were bringing in a new, modern model that could replace both. Another rebadged Alfa? Or fiat.

author: texases
text: The current 200 and Dart ARE the 'new, modern models'. And they're failures.

author: berri
text: Down the road the Saudi's will freeze out higher cost producers and gas prices will go back up. Historically, that means truck and SUV sales will go down as car sales rise. So I agree with Michaell.

author: iluvmysephia1
text:
Maybe that's why they're going to quit making the 200 in a couple of years...

Yes, this is true, I found out on the Mitsubishi Mirage website I belong to - FCA has already made the decision to axe the 200 and the Dart and dedicate those production lines to SUV's and Jeep's. Interesting - the Chrysler 200 is an interesting design that I sort of like and I do think Chrysler gave it their all on that rig - automobile making is not a business for the faint-hearted...bet you've read that one before, huh?

author: jpp75
text: I saw my first new gen Malibu yesterday, white. It's a good looking car, kind of reminds me of a larger Chrysler 200 from the front.

author: stickguy
text: First (that I recall) new Civic out on the road.

author: kyfdx
text: Toyota HiLux, crew cab pickups. They are all over the place!

author: Michaell
text: Hope you are enjoying your time in Central America!

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: or Somalia!

author: fintail
text:
I stopped by a BMW/Ducati dealership today, when passing some time. The Ducati selection was small - a handful of Monsters, Scramblers, and a couple Diavels (people buy these?) - Bellevue has better selection, it seems. BMW was better, S1000XR that I had never seen before, and either it or a normal S1000RR had a hangtag of 19K, yes, nineteen thousand dollars. Strong dollar huh.

Also saw a GLE coupe with one of the expected drivers, blonde woman with large sunglasses.

author: explorerx4
text: This morning, a black Audi R8 and a white Porsche Panamera.

author: berri
text:
First (that I recall) new Civic out on the road.

Some of the new ones were affected by some piston related issue, so while they were on the dealer lot, they couldn't be sold until the matter was resolved. Personally, I like it's looks better than the previous one.

author: ab348
text: Looks like Son of Crosstour to me. Not a fan, though from the straight-on front end perspective it isn't bad.

author: Sandman6472
text:
Sat in the new Civic and they did a nice job with the materials. Nice seat fabric and controls had a great tactile feel to them. Vision out was excellent and bet they will sell a lot of these puppies. Also was in a HR-V EX and liked it, a lot! Only Honda I'd buy right now and if my Plan A and Plan B don't pan out in a few years, the HR-V could very well be Plan C. Liked everything including the higher seating position, the one thing I miss from the Tucson. Luckily they had steering wheel controls for the infotainment system since I think knobs are essential and will come back to most systems very soon. Pinching and using one's fingers on the screen while driving is a safety hazard to me, as bad as texting because most folks can not drive and do another task simultaneously in a safe manner, we're just not wired that way.

The Sandman

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: The recall was about a wrist pin snap ring that could come loose....not good.

author: ab348
text: Reviews of the HR-V are terrible.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Most reviews liked the car but cursed the CVT and the pokey engine.

author: stickguy
text:
The car reviewer dude from the Philly Inquirer (major Philly paper) tested a Civic (a T sens model) this week. He is doing a comparison of that vs. the Mazda3 GT (will run that review and announce a winner next week).

Much more negative on the Civic than I was expecting. Had a lot of faults listed. Though interestingly enough, he was fine with the CVT (best of breed and relatively seemless or some such).

I still have not driven one but did sit in one at the car show. Better interior at least than the old model!

Oh, this was the same guy that picked the Soul as the winner of a 4 way mini CUV comparo recently.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Apparently the objection to the CVT was that combined with a pokey engine, the laboring of the CVT drives you crazy.

author: fintail
text: Saw a black GLE coupe with a couple of middle aged guys in it - not the typical demographic.

author: Sandman6472
text:
Haven't driven either the Civic or the HR-V yet as am waiting till Hertz gets at least the new Civic in. We picked up 10 new Accords on Monday, just like we did in 2015, so know the Civic purchase will be coming soon. Like the Accord, again we did the same thing last year. So I can wait till that time for a test drive. Doubt Hertz will get any HR-V's in their fleet but will test one in due time. Not that I'd purchase but see no reason to tempt the fates here. But, if I were to buy something tomorrow, it would be the HR-V hands down as I suspect there'd be a small amount of cash plus my Golf to drive one off the lot.
Did check on CPO units of the CLA and GLA and their newness to the market place makes them still out of reach for my pocketbook, an HR-V is definitely doable but the desire is missing. After my first test drive in the Golf, I knew I was going to buy one, soon. Went back for a second test drive a few days later and walked out with a tentative signed sales order with a small down payment left to secure the exact model and to swap out the horrible stock wheels. But once the wife had purchased her A3, I knew inside that by New Years Eve, the Tucson would be gone.

The Sandman

author: fintail
text:
I was once told that if I can't say anything nice, to not say anything at all. As being different for the sake of being different is apparently the key take-away to be learned at modern design schools, I will say it is "different"

I see a few of those Bentleys on the road here, along with the recent Continental facelift. They must be amazing inside, because they are almost kind of awkward outside. Oh, those Horatio Algers.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Or as one socialite once famously said: "If you can't say anything nice about someone, then why don't you sit down here right next to me"?

author: ab348
text: There were 2 new brown E250s on the lot at the local M-B dealer yesterday. Surprised me - normally they only order silver, white or black cars for inventory.

author: fintail
text:
I am pretty sure W212 production has now ended. I suspect there will be some odd and high trim cars showing up at the end of the run, and maybe some good lease deals at the end of the year as people wait for W213.

IIRC, there have actually been two different shades of brown for this style E.

author: stickguy
text: I'm patiently waiting until October 2017 to find one gently used and still under warranty for a big discount. Fine by me if the tried and true current style takes a massive hit in value when the new style comes out!

author: ab348
text: Both of the local cars are Dolomite Brown. Not a bad color but I would prefer a slightly darker metallic brown.

author: fintail
text: The darker brown was/is "Cuprite Brown". This appears to be a 2012 model:

author: fintail
text:
Seeing how they depreciate even now, maybe deals to be had. The W212 appears to be aging very well, it still looks good, and doesn't appear to have any horrible problem areas.

At lease end for me, I might try to find that perfectly optioned 14 E550, last of its type.

author: qbrozen
text: its too bad that, like the Ford Transit Connect, MB isn't offering the amenities on their van to make it a good family hauler.

author: ab348
text: Still available here in Canada, in fact just for laffs I built one yesterday on the M-B Canada site. $82000 devalued Canadian dollars, just over $60K in real money.

author: fintail
text: I still find it funny/irritating that MB has some significant differences between US and Canadian offerings - I am unaware of any other maker doing it to this degree. From features to entire models, there are many differences. I think Canada even has different color offerings than the US. I built a loaded E550 for 86K Loonies, or about 63.5K USD - actually, not bad, as it would have cost more here.

author: ab348
text: A couple of weeks ago I discovered that Kia offers a completely different lineup for the Soul model here in Canada than it does in the US, and has different colors as well. VW and BMW also offer different color choices inside and out for their models between the two countries, although in those cases it is a far more restricted set of choices being offered in Canada, as one might expect with it being a smaller market. M-B's case is interesting in still offering the E550 here. Perhaps it is due to fleet fuel economy averages or some such, as they sell the B-series here which might make room for some thirstier models at the other end of the range.

author: fintail
text: It's funny, as MB seems to have a broader model lineup there than here - more E engine variants, SWB and LWB S, B, and maybe more. Less option variety, with more standard features - very much like MB offerings in the UK. And with the CDN $ right now, the cars there are actually cheaper than here (at least pre-tax). Strange. I see a light-medium blue for the E that isn't even offered here. It's pretty bizarre, I wonder about the logic or reason behind it. You could be right about the E550, as the only B we get is the electric, a real hen's tooth.

author: Sandman6472
text:
Have seen a few B series MB down here in South Florida all with Canadian plates on them. The only exception was a used one at a local lot. I did like the little sucker and it would fit me well, but right now, am happy with what i got and see no reason to swap out again so soon. To get me to trade, the newer vehicle would have to really blow my socks off and be such a good deal, it would be crazy to pass up. Right now, there is no such vehicle and to be honest, healthwise, just don't have the strength to go looking.
The Ft. Lauderdale car show starts today, running through Sunday. Have no plans to go as of yet but if the oldest comes down, think we'll all check it out. She's about to hit 80K on her Versa SL and might be looking to trade soon. So far, it's been a great vehicle with no issues. She's fine with the CVT and lack of get up and go but advised her to look beyond the Versa Note as her next ride. So many great small vehicles out there with up to date tech, which she desperately wants. And if I were her, I'd go for a small turbo with a regular auto tranny this time.
All I can do is help her look and then negotiate...it's her cash so it's her ultimate decision.

The Sandman

author: fintail
text:
Visited the Vancouver auto show today. Oddest thing - MB wasn't there. In a city that I used to think had the highest amount of S-class per capita in NA, the make was absent. I suspect there's some kind of disagreement going on, as it isn't like this region isn't full of the make.

Some things in my memory: I sat in a CT6 with a 101K CDN MSRP. Nice car, but that's a spicy meatball. They also had base 4cyl one (so they made one, anyway) that was maybe 25K less. There was a big Buick concept sedan, roped off. All of the RS Audis were locked, which is funny as one could sit in Maseratis and BMW M cars. Saw a Lincoln Continental and an Alfa Giulia on stands, roped off. Saw a Fiata on display and one on the road. New Chrysler Pacifica had people swarming it, but I think Canadians have always liked Mopar vans. Honda display had a motorcycle and 4 wheeler in the mix, which interested me more than the cars - same for a new KTM dirtbike in a Colorado (no hint as how they got it up there). Lexus had some kind of little IQ sized thing with a predator face, roped off, and a concept convertible. BMW had a lineup of nice loaded cars - dark blue M6 GC with polished wheels and porcelain interior was striking, New Infiniti coupe is memorable too, like a toned down Lexus. Some new model Lambos in a special display drew a crowd, along with the recent Maserarti supercar. Also saw the new Volt and a Bolt. And lots of other stuff that doesn't come to mind right now.

author: iluvmysephia1
text:
I spotted my first Scion iA in the wild yesterday. It was......um.....interesting looking.

The 2016 Scion iA turned now into the 2017 Toyota Yaris iA is...unusual looking to say the least. I didn't like the front when I first saw it but do now. With this car it's the whole package that makes the car stand out as both a bargain for the money paid and a whole lotta car for the money. Push-button start, 7" entertainment screen, backup camera, accident avoidance detection, great Bluetooth connectivity, 31 city 41 highway and all of the Mazda greatness that a great carbuilder like Mazda can put in to a car. I honestly wouldn't be doing backflips over this car if not for the Mazda connection.

I wanted a 2016 Mazda 2 hatchback and it's here as an expensive 2016 Mazda CX-3. I'm sure it's a great hatch but its about $26,000 and does not come in a MT. Eliminated! No longer in the race.

Honestly - I may just hold on to my '11 Kia Soul 5-speed base in clear white and just mile it up. If just the right wild hair should bother me I'll go trade for a '16 Scion iA or a 2017 Toyota Yaris iA. If I don't do that I'll look for an unbeatable deal on a new '16 Kia Soul 6-speed. I honestly think the Kia will be every bit of car the Scion/or Toyota is/will be. They're neck and neck! In fact, just holding on to my '11 Kia Soul 5-speed wouldn't be a bad choice. They've all gotta be inexpensive and great cars. I believe in holding carmakers to the highest standard without needlessly throwing too much money at 'em.

Keep 'em honest. I mean, I don't call gasoline ghastly for nothing. I don't hypermile, though. Give it good ghastly - feel the rpm whirrrr....no hypermiling from this Seattleite.

author: slorenzen
text: More like crack cocaine...

talked to my neighbor today (that just got a new Volvo XC90). Asked how he liked it. Siad it was nice but he only drove it once. His wife (her car) apparently loves it. He kept her old Pathfinder and traded his late 00s 525i BMW because he liked the truck feel and sitting high better (plus has a lab, so easier to tote around).

Funny thing he said is they have to take it to the dealer tomorrow. Nothing wrong with it, but there is so much tech, his wife has no clue how to do anything, and needs a tutorial. So they are going back for training!

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Wow, I had a friend of mine back in high school who drove a bright Yellow LTD of the same generation. Called it the "Terminal Tank" because A. it WAS a Tank and B. it had a Terminal issue with stalling. I remember back in 1990 or so going with him to drop it off at the junkyard.

We drove in, parked it and then left in my car.

Ironically, he then bought a used 198_ Hyundai Excel which he named "Terminal Termite". Termite for it's size, but no Terminal issues for at least a 150k that he had it afterwards.

author: Sandman6472
text:
Hated the wheels on my '15 Golf and after a month of problems with them, they switched out the wrong size, ended up with 17" ones from a Jetta SEL. Joda rims I think they are called. They gave me 5 minutes to pick from 2 different rim styles and it was very difficult really as I really liked both. Mine have 15 spokes instead of the 10 I could've gotten and think I made the right decision. But when I see what I gave up, I have second thoughts. Guess it's true, the grass is always greener!
To be honest, I bought on eBay rims for my '06 Civic LX and they came from a California '05 Civic SI. Since it was a 16" Honda wheel, I knew the offset would work which, it did. Just had to secure new lug nuts and I was on my way. Made the car look so much better to.

The Sandman
