text: Are those the ones that Costco is selling at some locations?

author: fintail
text: Not sure. I googled it, Polaris is in the Costco purchase thing, so probably. The one I go usually has a Kawasaki bike of various types, and a mainstream car, Hyundai comes to mind.

author: stever
text: Friend of mine spotted one at the Clarkston Washington Costco a week ago and took a pic of it. He just said it was a Polaris.

author: fintail
text: That'd be the one. The one I saw was kind of a yellow-orange, I think.

author: fintail
text: Dark red Model X, no front plate because of course.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: 2016 BMW i3. Having seen one before I didn't actually recoil in horror---in fact I was fascinated with its weirdness. Technically it's a very interesting car, especially in construction; but aesthetically, it the automotive version of a very sour pickle---some people will love 'em, but most won't.

author: fintail
text: I think I might have seen a Ferrari 488 Spider today.

author: tifighter
text: i3 is pretty fun to drive. You know you want to try it...

author: iluvmysephia1
text:
Saw another electric Soul today.

fin - you should see a bunch of these in Seattle. And shifty - you should be seeing a lot of 'em in the Bay area.

author: fintail
text:
Yep, this is greenieland. Can't turn around here without seeing a Leaf, Prius, or in Bellevue, a Tesla. I am sure more will come.

I have seen a couple of the new MB small vans lately, and saw a new Volt today.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Haven't noticed any but maybe I wasn't looking too closely. I did price one out with a few modest options and that came to $33,400 for the base trim level. Not cheap considering you could pick up a used Nissan Leaf with similar EV range for about 1/3rd the price.

Loaded up with highest trim level and options brought the MSRP to $38,600.

Ouch!

author: stever
text: A well equipped Volt is a bit over $40,000. Before the $7,500 tax credit.

author: tifighter
text: FWIW, there is $12500 in rebates and incentives if you lease. At least there is in WA for May. With those numbers, I had to take a look.

author: fintail
text: Saw 2 Model X today, blue and black, both unplated.

author: stever
text: You should have snapped pics, but I think it's illegal to photograph one unless the lambo doors are up.

author: fintail
text: The most impressive thing about them to me is the price, and the dopey tax break. The doors are goofy (haven't seen one in the wild with open doors yet).

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Yeah but a much more versatile and handsome car, and considerably faster in EV mode.

The Soul EV has more cargo space, however--but cost almost 2X as much as the gas Soul.

I'm not feelin' it. It's a lot of money for what you get...or rather, don't get.

author: stever
text:
Yeah, I wish the local dealer would get a few in (Volts, that is).

But the Soul looks better.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Well I guess if you want to drive a hamster cage.

author: stever
text:
I really should go youtube some of those hamster ads; don't recall ever seeing one.

Was behind a new CR-V yesterday with temp tags on it. I understand the appeal, but they don't grab us.

author: imidazol97
text: I just priced a Soul EV+ and it's up to $38500.

author: stever
text:
Before the tax credit, lol.

The one we want runs about $26.5 OTD. Exclaim, Premium, Umber 1.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Driving a Soul EV rather than a gas Soul would save you $792 a year, for 12,000 miles a year with a KwH costing .15 cents per, and gasoline at $3 a gallon.

So the $12,000 differential paid for the EV will be equalized in about 180,000 miles.

Makes sense

author: stever
text:
Hm, interesting. That's about ten years assuming we stuck to one car (and had no range anxiety).

That's about a three year faster payback than putting solar on our house would achieve.

author: qbrozen
text: Don't forget savings in oil changes. ;b

author: fushigi
text: ..and brakes (regen braking reduced brake wear), no timing belt to replace, no engine air filters. All kinds of maintenance just goes away.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
True, but not "all kinds"---I don't know about the Soul EV maintenance fees but the Tesla has "checkups" and they aren't cheap. I believe a rough estimate for Tesla maintenance is $600 a year. If you drive a lot, it could be more.

So really, not that much different from a gasoline car still in warranty.

I'll have t collar a Soul EV owner next time I can and ask about that.

author: texases
text: Low maintenance, yes, but Tesla reliability has been poor.

author: fintail
text: Saw a blue Model X today, maybe the same one as before. Hard to tell, this was also unplated, and the driver demographic around here look similar.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: New Subaru Outback, prettty light green metallic color. I used to joke "Does Subaru even HAVE a styling department" but this one looks pretty nice for a wagon.

author: texases
text: The latest Forester's looks are WAY overdone. Used to really like it. Still on my list, I won't have to look at it

author: explorerx4
text: A new Civic in the parking lot at work. Its a loaner.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new Civic coupe today, and something cool, no Model X!

author: laurasdada
text:
First I've seen in the wild, British Racing green Jaguar F-Pace. SUV/SAV/CUV don't generally catch my eye, but this is a looker. Tall, yet sleek and aggressive. Bit blocky up front, but it is an SUV. ONce again, well done, Ian Callum!

And, of course , a herd of Model S and X at the Tesla store down the block. As always, the S is sharp; the X is bulbous.

author: kyfdx
text: Saw my first F-Pace last night.... at a hoity-toity art museum fundraiser. In white. Very nice looking.

author: fintail
text: Maybe not brand new, but I spotted a new style Rolls Royce coupe this evening. It's big. and not quite like classic models (of which one could buy a few for the price of the new one).

author: fintail
text:
Spotted a Jag XE on the lot, had to stop and take a look. I sat in it, surprised that it felt as roomy as it did. Local lot has 2, a base car with a 36K sticker, and a loaded 56K car. Touchscreen-only nav irritated me - I want redundant controls or a knob/touchpad, as I am one of those people who will go insane from fingerprints. Also a couple F-Pace on the lot, one with something like 8K in mop 'n glo type add ons, that didn't give me a good vibe.

I looked at a 12 year old Maybach at the adjacent Bentley dealer, typical Continental assortment, but a 2009 Phantom coupe caught my eye, wearing its original window sticker of 509K.

author: explorerx4
text: Across the street, neighbor came home with a silvery blue Outback wagon.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Did you like the styling?

author: explorerx4
text: There are plenty of Outbacks around here. The styling has improved, not trying so hard to look rugged, and I like the size of them.

author: fintail
text:
I see so many Outbacks, I might not even instantly recognize a new one. They blend in with the scenery in this part of the world.

Was out doing errands, stopped by the MB dealer. This is the doldrums time, not many cars on the lot, maybe more at the offsite lot. Just one or two of each model. A nearly zero option S-class might have been the most remarkable thing, that and a Cardinal Red E63 wagon.

author: stever
text: Saw two identical white Chevy Traverse LT's heading into the college campus this morning, both with dealer plates. Maybe there was an event happening.

author: stickguy
text: New security department units?

author: stever
text: Oh, good guess, that didn't occur to me. These weren't decaled up yet, but maybe they could be for maintenance use too.

author: fintail
text: New convertibles on the road - a new Miata with a smaller older couple who appeared to have been built for the car, and a newer red Bentley Continental cabrio not observing all traffic laws (shocker!).

author: jpp75
text: Saw a new Pacifica parked on the street while visiting friends. Not a bad looking vehicle, reminds me somewhat of the Kia Sedona in the looks department.

author: stickguy
text: an i8 BMW. white with the blue and orange (red?) trim. Actually 2. I stopped at the BMW dealer and they had one on the floor, but coincidentally on the way there, I passed an identical car out driving around.

author: anythngbutgm
text: Triple - Black F-Pace outside Boston. Young kid driving it, maybe late 20's early 30's. Looked fantastic.

author: qbrozen
text: ? What is the 3rd black? the wheels?

author: PF_Flyer
text: A reporter is looking to talk with someone who is currently in the market for a new pickup truck. If you're willing talk about which truck(s) you are considering please reach out to pr@edmunds.com by no later than June 8, 2016.

author: fintail
text: Not brand new, but a Bellevue trifecta of sorts: white Tesla, no front plate, no turn signal. Maybe if they some more ridiculous perks, they will behave better.

author: slorenzen
text:
They were just trying to save power by not using the signals.

Range anxiety, ya know...

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I'm waiting for my first panhandler to approach me with an extension cord in his hand, asking for enough money to get his EV running until he can get to a supercharger.

author: texases
text:
Great post on Edmunds' model X road trip, trailer included:
http://www.edmunds.com/tesla/model-x/2016/long-term-road-test/2016-tesla-model-x-range-and-charging-while-towing-a-trailer.html

author: stickguy
text:
Reminds me why I never will own a pure EV.

And I doubt more than a handful of tesla owners will ever actually tow. You would need to be insane to do it!

author: fintail
text: If you have nowhere to go and all day to get there, why not?

author: stickguy
text:
Way too much stress is why not.

I get the sweats if my gas gauge drops to 1/4 tank and start hunting for a station. Watching an EV running out of range might stroke me out.

author: fintail
text: What still gets me most is the refueling/recharging time. Even if I walked into the station and got a drink rather than just used a card at the pump, I bet I could refuel a modern diesel car in 10 mins, and then have 700+ miles of range - without the need to average 30 mph.

author: fintail
text: Out on the city streets this evening, saw a white Model X, black wheels, no front plate (of course, laws are for plebes). The drones and Stepfords around here have found their new toy.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new unplated F-Pace in the garage in my building last night - thought it was a Cayenne from a distance.

author: fintail
text: First sighting of a new C-class coupe today, well at least in the US - I saw them in Germany over 6 months ago. It's curvy, as all new MBs seem to be, maybe to a fault. Curvy can ride a fine line to droopy.

author: stickguy
text:
C class coupe is quite striking. Just too small for me in the back seat! My son reported it was nice from the driver's seat.

the back end though, if kind of squished up.

author: fintail
text:
It does have a presence to it. The prior one sold better than I expected, I suspect this one will too.

Also saw a new Volt.

author: stickguy
text: I was surprised that they seemed to have quite a few in stock. Must have been 4 at least in the front row, and one in the showroom (in matte gray. Hideous paint)

author: laurasdada
text: Driving east on the Mass Pike, on the westbound side, a black Jag XE. First I've seen in the wild. I suppose I am predisposed to spot Jags, but to me it did have presence. Of course, but a fleeting glimpse. More to come, I"m sure.

author: magnette
text: Saw a Bentley Betayga this week in town - first one I've seen apart from at Frankfurt show last September.

author: fintail
text: Fun coincidence, today saw a white Model X and a black new style Targa.

author: texases
text: Nothing special, a new Pilot. What surprises me is how few I see. New CR-Vs all over the place, new Pilots maybe once a month.

author: Michaell
text: There was one parked at the house across the street last weekend. Wife thought it was a Subaru.

author: berri
text: I don't find the Pilot is a vehicle that sticks out. They also look chopped off to me.

author: fintail
text: I see new Pilots now and then, tons of CRVs as it is a vehicle of choice among some local demographics. I am surprised that I see very few HR-Vs, maybe as they are seen as a little expensive for their size vs a CR-V.,

author: Michaell
text: I don't think the HR-V is as popular as Honda had hoped. What is the best selling small (tiny?) ute? I'd guess the Buick Encore based on how many I see around here.

author: texases
text: I'm seeing some CX-3s, but I'd get the CX-5.

author: stickguy
text: I think a lot of people look at the HRV compared to the CRV, in terms of what you get and the cost, and deem the CRV to be a better deal.

author: Michaell
text:
Sure - bigger engine, more interior space, not that much more money.
texases said:
I'm seeing some CX-3s, but I'd get the CX-5.
Same with the Mazda, though I did see a CX-3 today and admired its looks.

I could live with a CX-3 FWD Touring.

author: stickguy
text: I liked the CX3, but seem to recall it was a little tight up front? small seat or something. I am fine with the overall size, but still need enough room up front to be comfy. I have no problem sacrificing back seat room though. I don't sit back there.

author: Michaell
text:
stickguy said:
I liked the CX3, but seem to recall it was a little tight up front? small seat or something. I am fine with the overall size, but still need enough room up front to be comfy. I have no problem sacrificing back seat room though. I don't sit back there.
I test drove the CX-3 and didn't notice any issues with comfort behind the wheel. Of course, it was a 10 minute test drive.

author: stickguy
text:
they will both be on my list for next year. Of course, very few things won't be on the list.

Next February the car show will be an all day event. Have to drag the wife along this year, and sit in everything. and make notes. She is going to have so much fun! Might need to do cheesesteaks and beer before the show, instead of after like we usually do.

author: fintail
text: I definitely see more Encores than HR-Vs, although I suspect some of the former might be rentals.

author: Michaell
text:
stickguy said:
they will both be on my list for next year. Of course, very few things won't be on the list.

Next February the car show will be an all day event. Have to drag the wife along this year, and sit in everything. and make notes. She is going to have so much fun! Might need to do cheesesteaks and beer before the show, instead of after like we usually do.
Yeah, I was hoping to drag @breld around this summer, test driving everything under the sun.

That plan, obviously, has been scrapped.

author: stickguy
text:
Lots of new stuff today. Stopped at the Buick dealer (was next door getting touch up paint for the Sonata) and sat in a Cascada (I liked it, and could even see out the windshield without looking at the header!). Small trunk, so would take creative luggage selection. Not bad for the MSRP (base car so 33K).

also sat in an Envision (the new mid size CUV). Pretty nice inside, comfy seats, and seemed to be about the same size and cargo room as our RDX (maybe a smidge bigger trunk). But was 46k sticker (premium II), and it didn't even have a moonroof. Considering everything on the sticker (engine/trans/body/assembly) said China, I don't think so. Nice looking design though.

then went to the Honda dealer. Sat in a Ridgeline. Much nicer looking than the old one. Seemed plenty big to me, without being huge and cumbersome. Could even see out of it OK. Roomy inside, back seat seemed fine but I did not play much. Black edition, MSRP 43k. I think these will sell well, if they start bringing in more mid-level models for less money.

author: tjc78
text: 46k?? Wow our Enclave was 47 and change with Nav, Bose, Moonroof and pano roof over the second row. FWD, though.

author: tjc78
text: Some bucks on this car carrier. @fintail would approve.

author: stickguy
text: so, you were counting the cars on the NJ turnpike?

author: tjc78
text: Lol, yes had to run up to East Brunswick. Been awhile, love the new lanes. So much nicer now that the construction is done.

author: stickguy
text: I was going back and forth on a weekly basis to NY for a while over the last couple of years with Parents issues. Starting in the middle of the construction, which was ugly. But once they finished and opened up the new lanes, it was nirvana. It is so incredibly better I can't believe it. No more 2 mile backup at exit 8A ("the merge"). It is downright pleasant at this point!

author: Michaell
text:
stickguy said:
I was going back and forth on a weekly basis to NY for a while over the last couple of years with Parents issues. Starting in the middle of the construction, which was ugly. But once they finished and opened up the new lanes, it was nirvana. It is so incredibly better I can't believe it. No more 2 mile backup at exit 8A ("the merge"). It is downright pleasant at this point!
Did you just use the word "pleasant" to describe the NJ Turnpike?

It's been years since I've had to drive it. Is it that much better?

author: stickguy
text:
yes, the improvement was amazing on the stretch between the Philly area and around the Garden state parkway exit. They eliminated around West Windsor where it dropped from 6 to 3 lanes, and used to back up for miles when busy. Plus the road is smooth, and various other improvements.

they basically extended the truck lanes all the way down, instead of bringing the 2 sections together.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: There's a half-million insurance settlement!

author: fintail
text:
Yesterday I dropped off the loaner I had while the dashcam was being moved to the new car. I got a ride there in a 2014 E63S, high option car, probably stickered at 110-115K or so. At 11K miles, they want 75K for it, and I know you could knock that down a bit. Cool car and sounds amazing, almost crashed it as the lot attendant guy/kid didn't look both ways when pulling out of a driveway. That would have been awkward.

My C300 loaner:



Or is it an E or an S? At some angles and distances, not easy. Definitely in the same sausage-different lengths ideal that BMW has used for a little while, and Audi has used for years.

I drove it under 20 miles, so I can't make a real impression, but it seemed OK. It wasn't loaded, but the seats are nice. Thigh support extensions, BMW has done it for ages, why did it take MB so long to get on board?

author: fintail
text:
I think that's an S on the back, GLC below it. Not something you see every day.
tjc78 said:

tjc78 said:
Some bucks on this car carrier. @fintail would approve.

author: Sandman6472
text:
While at the Honda store moving vehicles yesterday, saw a couple test driving a new white HR-V. Doesn't look that nice in white but they have a dark green color which is really nice. Haven't had aa chance to drive one yet as we have none in our fleet. The couple of Encores I have driven have been very nice and are tuned softer than the Chevy Trax. Do see more Encore's then either HR-V's or Trax's for some reason. Am hoping that they add knobs to the infotainment systems on the HR-V EX and EX-L eventually when I am in the market again. I actually like a hatchback style just for the extra cargo area. The small size is just a bonus.

The Sandman

author: stever
text: Met a woman tonight with a white HR-V. Loves it. Said the AC worked fine (that was an issue with our tester). Said it was the perfect size for her and that the CR-V was just a tad too big.

author: stickguy
text: I found the HRV to be plenty roomy when I sat in it. Never drove one though.

author: ab348
text:
stickguy said:
I found the HRV to be plenty roomy when I sat in it. Never drove one though.
Curious. All the reviews I have read have commented/complained about the lack or room or packaging issues inside.

author: stever
text:
I wonder if you are thinking of, say, the CX-3?

"With the rear seats up on a front-drive HR-V, there are 24.3 cubic feet of luggage space available. Folding the seats flat opens 58.8 cubic feet, which is excellent for this class."

That's similar to the Kia Soul (even better with the seats up):

"One of the benefits of the Soul's boxy design is an abundance of head- and legroom, even in the backseat. Behind the rear seatbacks you'll find 19 cubic feet of cargo room, which grows to 61 cubic feet with both sections of the 60/40-split rear seatbacks folded down. This is greater than compact hatchbacks and on par with some SUVs."

Both quotes from reviews here.

author: ab348
text:
stever said:
I wonder if you are thinking of, say, the CX-3?
Y'know, I think you're right.

I think the negatives on the HRV I've read are related to the powertrain and driving experience IIRC.

author: stever
text:
ab348 said:
show previous quotes

Y'know, I think you're right.

I think the negatives on the HRV I've read are related to the powertrain and driving experience IIRC.
The AC couldn't keep up on our test drive but the owner I met claimed hers was just fine. Other than the AC concerns, we liked it a lot on our short test drive.

author: tjc78
text: As a whole the AC in the newer cars isn't that great IMO. I'm sure between the change from R12 and more efficient compressors that it will be that way going forward. They do the job but no where near the freezers of the 70s/80s and early 90s (I think 93 was the last year the EPA allowed R12).

author: stever
text: Dunno, we've tested quite a few in 90+ temps out here and that was the only one that didn't seem to keep up. The old van's AC does fine too. Then again I'm cold natured and the house feels chilly to me with the AC on 77.

author: tjc78
text:
Don't get me wrong, the last few cars we have had "do the job" but none get absolutely frigid like the old cars. My 04 MGM is pretty darn cold but I remember my 79 Continental would literally blow frost on a humid day. I also recall my moms 92 Caravan was also extremely cold (people in the third row used to say they were cold and it didn't have ducts back there).

I'd put the AC on 68 in the house if I thought it would keep up and I didn't want a $500 electric bill. 73/74 has to do.

author: ab348
text:
tjc78 said:

I'd put the AC on 68 in the house if I thought it would keep up and I didn't want a $500 electric bill. 73/74 has to do.
Ha! That's funny and it reminds me of when I went on vacation with my parents when I was a kid. We would check into a motel that had A/C and I would always have it on full blast. Since it was fairly unique back then even in commercial buildings up here I was fascinated by it.

Years later me and 2 other guys went of a business trip to Florida in June 1988. Both heat and humidity were 90+ all the time we were there. All 3 of us had out hotel rooms set at 68 degrees. The local folks we were meeting with could not understand that. We could not understand why all the local guys we were meeting with were all wearing cotton undershirts in that heat until they explained to us it helped with the perspiration. It was news to us.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
What did I see?

It looked like a Toyota FR-S but the only badging said "GT". I thought that was a 2017 model not out yet?

Pretty neat looking little coupe..reminds me a little of the Porsche 944 in profile.

author: odie6l
text:
I've seen three of the new Ridgeline's out in the wild now (not just on dealer lots). They do look a lot nicer than the
previous version. Two were normal trims, one was a Black edition.

Odie

author: ab348
text:
odie6l said:
I've seen three of the new Ridgeline's out in the wild now (not just on dealer lots). They do look a lot nicer than the previous version.

Well in fairness, I dunno if it would be possible to look worse.

author: stickguy
text:
Vert day. First a nice white BMW 428i, with the top down (always nice to see, but not actually that common). Then a smoke gray M235i. that was sharp.

and a guy in my neighborhood must be doing OK. saw him out detailing a newish Maserati coupe. Also white.

author: fintail
text: Model X, no front plate, this was one of the few with an excuse - it was a demo out for a drive.

author: Michaell
text:
fintail said:
Model X, no front plate, this was one of the few with an excuse - it was a demo out for a drive.
I saw one (!) Model X yesterday in the Bay Area. Given that I was in the heart of Silicon Valley, I was kind of surprised.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
stickguy said:
Vert day. First a nice white BMW 428i, with the top down (always nice to see, but not actually that common). Then a smoke gray M235i. that was sharp.

and a guy in my neighborhood must be doing OK. saw him out detailing a newish Maserati coupe. Also white.
Nah....$3300 down and about $700 a month for a new Maserati on a lease.

author: fintail
text:
Of course, that 700/month is a base Ghibli, right?

Some of the Seattle area is Silicon Valley north, with all the good and all the bad, so Model X makes sense here. Model S are now a dime a dozen, only catching my eye when driven poorly.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Yeah, a measly base model Maserati. But they depreciate pretty hard, and many people don't necessarily know that a 2006 model is a 2006 model that you can buy for south of $15K. I'm seeing 2015s with very low miles already in the mid $50Ks. so figure original owner took a $20K hit the first year. I wouldn't mind having one for the right price.

author: qbrozen
text: I think I've said it before, but I always keep my eye on the Quattroportes. These days, you can find a 2008 with fewer than 45k miles for $30k-$32k. Low mileage 2010s are in the mid $40s, so not really worth the bump, IMHO.

author: fintail
text:
Local Maserati dealer has very low payments on Ghibli, but I suspect they have few to no options, and I know they are 5000 mile/year (!) limits. Ghibli, while it still has a fun exhaust note, is the "affordable" model.

The coupes are the ones that say "money" to me. I bet depreciation on all of them would make even the Germans cringe.

author: kyfdx
text: I think those are striking. Keep putting my hands over my wife's eyes, when I see one.

author: tjc78
text: I saw my first F pace today too at the Jersey shore, sharp car.

author: stickguy
text: Tom, that's where I am. Stone harbor. So many expensive cars here, you become numb. Multiple ferraris so far, and Benz, bmw and Jag dime a dozen.

author: fintail
text: Spotted a new Volt, MB Metris passenger model likely a rental, new hockey stick 7er, and 2x Model X, one registered with no front plate because of course.

author: berri
text: Fin - all these spotting's in Seattle traffic - how do you keep out of accidents. I'm thinking you could actually cut it in Jersey or Hotlanta

author: ab348
text: I checked; the Chevy site calls it black/brandy leather.

author: fintail
text:
I'm observant, also on foot for a few miles per day

Traffic doesn't scare me however, I've spent time in Hotlanta anyway, I don't see what the fuss is about. At least they move along.

author: tjc78
text: We are Wildwood Crest, a few streets from Diamond Beach. Walking to the beach (beach block) the cars were stunning! Two black on black S550s, new C, brand new Escalade, mentioned the F pace, a few Infinitis and one lowly 06-11 Grand Marquis (someone had class lol).

author: fushigi
text: Black BMW i8 in Chicago's River North neighborhood this morning. Went by fast enough I only recognized it by shape.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: It's ironic isn't it? Cadillac spending gazillions on new product and so many of their customers say; "Give me an Escalade, please".

author: tjc78
text: Trucks are still what GM does best IMO.

author: stever
text: Fiat Miata, Tesla Model S and the most exciting, a new Chrysler Pacifica minivan.

author: fintail
text: Blue Electric Soul, Electric Blue?

author: tjc78
text: Lots of new Pacificas this week too.  Chrysler has a hit I think. Best looking minivan since the mid 90s Town and Country.

author: stever
text: Haven't seen anything official yet from editorial, but Edmunds has a loaded Pacifica for the long term fleet. I lobbied hard this morning to let it live in Las Cruces for six months.

author: Michaell
text:
I can see the blog updates now:

"Does the cactus fit?"

"Can the air conditioning survive 105 degree days?"

"Using the Pacifica as a makeshift RV - thumbs up or down?"

author: laurasdada
text: Parked in front of fancy furniture store, a white BMW i8. Cool, think I want one. Also, at the dealer a white Fiata, I think I like it, too. Although the front end looks a bit ungainly. I can only afford one of these. Well, can't really afford either, but what else am I going to do with my $, pay for kids tuition??? Why, yes. Yes I am/will (only 5 more years!).

author: fintail
text: Saw 3 late/current model Ferraris and a Huracan in traffic today - fun place with a booming economy and more than a few people cleaning their money in the real estate insanity.

author: stever
text: I was surprised to read the other day that Seattle was in the top ten big cities with "low" car ownership. Something like 17% of the population doesn't own a car - so my BIL is in pretty good company. NYC leads this list with something like 50% car ownership.

author: stickguy
text: Saw a bently and 2 ferraris. In the same driveway here at the beach. Of course it was about 3 houses from the beach, in one of the most expensive towns on the east coast. Probably a 4-5 million house.

author: fintail
text:
I can believe it, as Seattle has some transit in the urban core, anyway, and a lot of (fair weather) bicylists, to the point of devoting a bit of infrastructure to them, and the goofy ineffective mayor and useless council even getting involved with serious ethical issues over their handpicked and questionably qualified SDOT director . I wouldn't be surprised if the "Seattle" population is defined in a special way, like from Northgate south, and from Columbia City north, and including university students, of course. And I wonder if "own" is in the same category as lease or just use, with someone else holding the papers.

I'd wager in some suburbs, ownership is at 100% or more. You will be very inconvenienced, if not often stuck, in much or most of Bothell or Issaquah or Auburn or Puyallup without a car.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Nobody knows how to punish a car owner like NYC. But then, NYC has an amazing transit system.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Nissan 370Z cabriolet. Couldn't tell if '16 or '17 because they are identical.

But I can say that, "in person", it's not very attractive.

author: stever
text:
Geeze, Wikipedia says Seattle's car-free population in 2000 was almost 35%. Would never guess that.

Drove all over town today, didn't see anything new other than a Kia with temp tags.

author: fintail
text: Maybe not new, saw an A3 E-tron today, and not new, a red ELR. which still stands out.

author: fintail
text: Makes perfect sense actually. A lot of people maybe recently just got a car and learned to drive, which would explain the dearth of driving skill in the greater Puget Sound area.

author: fintail
text:
Stopped by the MB dealer to make sure the sales survey went through (it was glitchy), it did and the salesman was pleased. Nice guy, so I was happy to help him.

On the showroom floor, an S550 cabrio, decent amount of options, 155K sticker. It's pretty striking, and it's a big car - another one that delivers 85-90% of a Bentley for maybe 55% the price.

author: stickguy
text: at the beach, a couple of F Paces, and a bunch of Pacificas. I think they are getting out there now. Good looking car.

author: stever
text: Equus today, but hard to say what vintage it was. Second generation at least.

author: fintail
text: We've ever only had the 2nd gen Equus, the one with "suddenly it's 2008" parallel universe Lexus styling. The eventual replacement will be branded as a Genesis - they finally grasped what many people suggested several years ago.

author: stever
text: No wonder they all look alike.

author: stickguy
text: New Range Rover murano (er, Evoque) convertible. Odd duck.

author: explorerx4
text:
@stickguy,
You reminded me, I saw one of the Evoque convertibles in Hamburg. Riding in it in all its' Orange glory were a pair of newlyweds.

author: fintail
text: Two new grille-less Teslas today, one even had a front plate.

author: explorerx4
text: In the parking lot at work, a black ES350, white Ram crew cab pickup and a gray Subaru Outback.

author: stever
text: Range Rover HSE with temp tags.

author: stickguy
text: hey, all are on my list to look at next year!

author: Michaell
text: Anything with 4 wheels is on your list, stick.

author: iluvmysephia1
text: Lists are good...sometimes.

author: stickguy
text: My wife's list, is a bit shorter. So key is, don't ask her.

author: Michaell
text: If it's your car, does she get to render an opinion?

author: stickguy
text: An opinion, since it will also be our primary together car. Not final say, but if she really hated something, I wouldn't push it too far!

author: tjc78
text:
Wife and I just did an overnight in Baltimore and while driving down and back I was pointing out all the SUVs I want her to check out with me when we are ready for the next one. I suggested we go to the Philly car show and check them all out. She agreed, and then said that she will not go to dealers with me.

Saw a bunch of new Tahoes and Yukons. I can't believe how well they are selling. Seemed to be everywhere. Also saw two metallic brown Accord V6 Touring. Don't like the brown, but I really like the new style.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Spotted (2) new Q60 Coupes, very sharp.

Also visited the dealer this weekend to put a set off tires on my S2000 and they had a total of (1) Ridgline in stock (Black Sport). They are selling as soon as they get them and the rest are ordering them. I may actually make a move on that Sport if I can get over my OCD with owning black cars (my 2007 Impreza is black and it's been a challenge).

author: stickguy
text: I saw a ridge line in the wild this weekend. A white one. I really like them.

author: qbrozen
text: Also saw a Ridgeline, and also white. Not bad looking. Visually smaller than the original.

author: explorerx4
text: also saw a new white Ridgeline today. Pretty blandtastic.

author: kyfdx
text: It's the front end that leaves me less than enthusiastic. If it had the front end from the previous generation Pilot, I could live with it.

author: stickguy
text: Looks nice and clean to me. Though I also think the FS trucks are all brutally overdone at this point, and front ends way to blocky and bulky (false machismo?).

author: qbrozen
text: I saw it first in profile from a distance. I thought Mitsu maybe made a new Raider.

author: stickguy
text: the interior is just a tad nicer in the Honda.

author: explorerx4
text:
Those FS trucks have big blocky front ends because they are designed to tow several times their weight and need lots of cooling.
I saw that one of the car magazines had to have the transmission in their long term Pilot replaced at just over 21k.
Not sure if the Ridgeline has the same one.

author: ab348
text: Plus it makes them look macho.

author: stickguy
text:
you said that with a straight face? Funny how a few generations ago, they had sloped front ends you could see over, and towed just fine.

the new look is all about trying to come across as Macho and tough, practicality be darned.

author: tlong
text: Well given that a high fraction of truck owners (and probably SUV owners as well) don't use their vehicles much for the optimized purposes, practicality IS darned. But it adds profits for the automakers...

author: fintail
text: Saw what might be a Bellevue trifecta - white Model X, Stepford driver, no front plate. Also not new but amusing, saw three "7" Audis in a short span - normal A7, S7, RS7, in that order. The latter is the one.

author: explorerx4
text:
Still looking at buying something new.
Stopped by a multi line dealer today that has Audi Ford Lexus and Porsche.
I was looking for a Ford.
On the remote lot, where most of the Fords are, I saw 4 Audi's up on bricks, with no wheels/tires.
An S5, A6 and 2 TT's. Guessing the TT's were performance models as they had quad exhaust pipes.
Lot of money gone there.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new E class on the road, I think my first not parked at the dealer - the side creases are more horizontal, which might be the best giveaway as it looks so much like a C from a distance. Also saw a guy getting into an i8, very awkward.

author: texases
text: A new Caddy XTS...hearse:

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I used to say "I wouldn't be seen dead in a Cadillac", but now.......?

author: tlong
text: I hope you don't catch me riding in that one any time soon...

author: tjc78
text: I guess they have to make them out of something .... The newer cars just look really stupid as hearses. Town Car and Devilles looked so much better.

author: berri
text: Seems like a lot of hearses, like cop cars, are going the SUV route. I see many Suburban's in livery forms these days.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: FUVs?

author: tjc78
text: They all should use Lincoln MKTs. They look like a hearse straight from the factory.

author: fintail
text: Saw a Caddy XT6 on the road this morning.

author: ab348
text: No, it would have been either an XT5 (SUV) or CT6 (big sedan).

author: fintail
text: Ha, this dopey alphanumeric scheme their one trick pony CEO brought over from Infiniti doesn't agree with my mind.

author: berri
text: I'm guessing that somewhere down the road we may see a return to actual vehicle names. The letters and numbers, at least to me. have really become meaningless in most cases, if not sometimes confusing.

author: stickguy
text: I saw a burgundy XT5 on the apron outside the caddy dealer. Nice looking. Sharper than the SRX it replaced.

author: Michaell
text:
For domestic makes, maybe.

Doubtful we'll see the Germans or the luxury Japanese brands do this, however. Too much cachet in the brand name, not the model name.

author: stickguy
text:
at least the Germans have distinct model naming that helps (the engine/trim, that is off the rails.)

easy to know how to compare a 3/5/7 series. Or a C/E/S class..And X or Q signifies the SUV version.

IMO, does not work the other way, when everything starts with say XT like Lincoln, and there is no apparent logic or consistency to the rest of the name.

and names can be just as bad, unless they are clearly established, and don't change (civic/accord, Malibu/Impala). coming out with new names frequently is just as bad, though maybe easier to learn.

I guess it really is Caddy and Lincoln that are causing the problems.

author: stever
text: Not for some of us.

author: fintail
text:
For the Germans, the engine-related number has become less accurate over time, but the model identifier remains easy to remember. C/E/S, 3/5/7, A4/A6/A8, etc. It's intuitive. MB actually made things a little easier for the CUV/SUV line, by linking them up to their relative position compared to cars (GLA/GLC/GLE etc).

Names changing over time ended up being an issue for domestics. In 1957, a Bel Air was the top model, in 1959 a Galaxie was the top model, and so on. By 1970, both of those were not the top model. Bumping a name down in rank doesn't help with equity. The same braintrust who brought the weird structure to Infiniti has brought it to Caddy.

author: kyfdx
text:
Then, you have Infiniti, where everything starts with a Q.

Why not just leave the Q off?

author: stever
text: Good Q.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Played with a new gadget in a 2016 Ford F150 4X4 today, called "Trailer Assist".

Basically, you put the car in reverse, press this thingie/button, and the truck goes into high idle speed, and a camera shows you a top view of your trailer on the dash screen. Then you use the rotating thingie/button to actually steer the trailer as the truck moves backwards. "It" knows the type of trailer and all the important dimensions because you plug those in beforehand for your particular trailer (tongue length, width, etc).

I'm pretty good backing up trailers already but for some folks who haven't practiced--they really suck at it.

author: Michaell
text: I'd be a perfect candidate for that technology. Not that I've driven much while towing a trailer, but the whole "opposite" thing just confuses me.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I learned how to do it in the Army---even in the dark! It's tricky if you pick the wrong type of trailer for your truck. You can get impossibly fast reactions from the trailer, making corrections difficult.

author: stever
text:
I had a utility trailer I used with my '74 Jeep CJ-5. Should have renamed myself Jack Knife. I learned the hand on the bottom of the steering wheel trick but what I mostly learned was that any idiot can buy a trailer and immediately hit the Interstate and toddle along at 70 mph with no clue.

Over the years, one friend jack-knifed his camper on a freeway bridge blocking the two northbound lanes, two friends dropped their jet boats off their trailers in the middle of busy intersections and another guy had his utility trailer pass him and wind up in a field a half mile ahead of him.

Should be a towing endorsement required on the driver's license for those who pull trailers. Check the safety chains when you see trailers in parking lots - rarely will you see them property hooked up.

And if you see someone toting firewood with a homemade trailer made from a pickup bed, yikes!

author: fintail
text:
Saw an XT5 (is that right?) today.

There should be endorsements for many types of vehicles. As it stands today, I can use the same license to drive a Smart or a 42' behemoth motorhome or a 1000hp Veyron or a relatively large rented box truck, but I need an endorsement for a 250cc Vespa. Someone bought their laws.

author: ab348
text: While at the car show yesterday and just sitting by our cars for a while, we saw on the nearby road - a heavily traveled 2-lane country road - some (presumed) tourists with a big diesel interstate coach-style motorhome towing a large enclosed cargo trailer - probably a 20-footer. Didn't look like driving that would be a whole lot of fun. Normally you see those things pulling cars on a dolly, but I guess these folks drove around hauling all their worldly goods, unless there was a Smart car in there.

author: stickguy
text:
I used to drive the equipment truck for my son's HS marching band, and would pick it up at the rental place (Ryder). Literally all you needed was a DL and a CC, and to be 18, and they would hand you the keys to a truck. I used to get a 26' box diesel Freightliner or International. Eye to eye with the semi drivers!

Let's just say, the instructions were minimal. Mostly where the key went, and how to put it in gear. And off you go.

man, they were so much fun to drive. Just not on tight city streets.

author: berri
text: Hey good buddy, got you a parking spot in the truck lot at tollway oasis and diners. That's a big 10-4

author: fintail
text: Today saw 2x Model X, facelift Model S, and a facelift A4.

author: anythngbutgm
text: Ouch.

author: anythngbutgm
text: 2 Model X, one white and one red (the red looked pretty sharp with the slate gray wheels) and a which Volvo S90. All in Boston last evening.

author: fintail
text: Today's sightings: white W213 E-class, white hockey stick 7er.

author: fintail
text: Today saw an Aventador and a not exactly perfectly driven Model X.

author: explorerx4
text:
In the parking lot at work, lots of average stuff.
3 Rav4's, Honda minivan, Ford Explorer, Lexus ES350.

author: fintail
text: Saw a McLaren XYZ123 or whatever a new one is called, along with a couple of late model Ferraris. Kind of played out here - the BMW C650 maxi scooter I saw in traffic caught my eye more.

author: tifighter
text: Fiata. Brown. I loved the original 124, but I'm not feeling it.

author: stickguy
text: Fiata. Like it. Reminds me of the old Saabaru.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Not sure I like that double grille.

author: tjc78
text: I once drove one of those with my left hand (I'm left handed) in a cast from KOP to Baltimore and back... That stunk to say the least.

author: fintail
text: Saw a white Pacifica (rental) on the road, and a C63 AMG.

author: berri
text: I always felt that white shows up design flaws, so I gotta ask your opinion on what you though about its looks (yeah, I know its just a minivan, but it is all new, so I'm curious)

author: fintail
text: I don't mind it. It looks very European to me, something reminds me of Renault design. It also seems bigger in person than in pics. White is an inoffensive color when not trying to be trendy/

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: White makes cars look larger, so if the styling is a bit porky to begin with, that color will accentuate that IMO.

author: fintail
text: Saw a Model X with a front plate, they exist!

author: stickguy
text: is that the weird wagon thing with rear butterfly doors? I saw one of those last weekend, getting dried off outside a carwash. had the back doors up.

author: fintail
text: Yep. I still have yet to see one in public with the doors open, but I see them on the road almost every day.

author: qbrozen
text: The model X or a front plate?

author: fintail
text: The front plate. Front plate use among Tesla drivers here is low. The model X or a front plate?

author: tifighter
text: Darth Hellcat. Challenger. Full blackout. That's one way to spend $70k, I suppose.

author: fintail
text: Today saw a laughably poorly driven newish A8 and a couple of front overhang Lexus RX on a transport truck.

author: tjc78
text: White over beige Cascada, top down. Wife said "what was that?" I told her new Buick convertible. She said, "wow what a chick car" lol.

author: qbrozen
text: Sighted a Buick Envision yesterday. Nothing terribly thrilling. Just seems to finally be a right-sized Buick SUV.

author: stever
text:
Our realtor has one and it looks nice; white too, think the inside is black though. I bet she'll never put the top down, although she claims she's had it down a couple of times.

When the arroyos washed out in our area the other day, she had to get a ride home - between the 19" rubber band tires and the low clearance, she would have been clunking a lot of rocks in several spots (they get front end loaders out here after a big dump of rain to clear the "boulders" off the roads.

author: tlong
text:
Within 2 minutes of each other:
A lady in a black Q50, in the fast lane in stop and go traffic, paying more attention to her phone than the road.
A Toyota Mirai fuel cell vehicle. I'm sure limited production volumes on that one.
A new Prius

In general, Toyota's styling has gone exceptionally bizarre and not in a good way. In fact the Corolla and Camry seem to be their only normal looking vehicles. The Prius tailights and "wing" are hideous. I also think the taillights on the new Civic are atrocious. For me, Mazda's vehicles are the best looking of the Japanese crowd.

author: berri
text: Don't worry, the Camry is supposed to get a big restyle for 17. Just imagine how fugly that will probably be - perhaps a Japanese horror anime!

author: tjc78
text: Lets be honest, there really hasn't been a good looking Camry since the 92-96.

author: berri
text: Heck, I'm not sure there was ever a really good looking Camry, but hose older ones lasted and lasted. In fact, you'd see the vintage you mentioned in station wagons as taxi's at Reagan National Airport for many years afterwards. Those and RWD Buick Roadmasters.

author: texases
text: Saw two new Cayman GT-4 in the last few days, would be a blast to drive I bet.

author: texases
text: And a new Civic coupe, surprised they're going with this shade:

author: ab348
text: It wasn't ugly enough already, so...

author: fintail
text: Recipe for new cars - just add styling.

author: berri
text: Kind of makes me miss the old Steak 'n Shake lime freeze

author: fushigi
text:
Can still get a drink like that at DQ. Mr. Misty Freeze (now Arctic Rush Freeze) is a slushy blended with DQ soft-serve.

Of late I've been partial to Sonic's Cherry Lime-Aid.

author: fintail
text: Saw a Bentley Bentayga out this morning. From a distance I thought it was an X5, but as I approached, I noticed it was maybe slightly bigger and insanely more expensive. Somewhat erratically driven, as expected from a car of that stature in this part of the world. No doubt a nice reward for laundering money in real estate or working to get that sketchy factory open in a distant land or other bootstrappy pursuits

author: kyfdx
text: I'm partial to orange at Steak 'n Shake.

author: ab348
text: Hmm... happened to drive past the local Honda dealer today. The front of their lot is absolutely awash in new Civic coupes. Most were in grey or black, but they had a few Lime Freeze models there. Color didn't seem quite as retina-searing as the shade in the photo. Still not great though.

author: qbrozen
text: Spent some time at a traffic light today behind a new civic sedan in dark grey with the lip spoiler. Man, that thing is ugly from the rear. I could not even begin to count the number of angles and surfaces.

author: texases
text: So many makes are hard to look at now...

author: berri
text: It's the generation of Anime in car styling, or otherwise Lego friendly

author: stickguy
text: the Civic is starting to grow on me. But is one of those cars that really needs to be in certain colors.

author: tlong
text: I agree; Honda's never been great at styling but they've jumped the shark with the new Civic. Only surpassed by the new Prius. So we're in the era of hideous angled taillights...a look that IMHO won't age well at all.

author: Michaell
text:
The more I look at the new Civic, the less I like it.

For some reason, I'm really digging the classic lines of my new Jetta sedan. Simple, with plenty of headroom and good sightlines. Even better than the Elantra GT I just got rid of.

I fear that in 3 years when my lease is up, my choices for something similar will be even more limited.

author: fintail
text: Saw another Bentayga today, or maybe the same one, I don't know/care. That thing screams "dirty money" at least twice as loud as a G-Wagen.

author: qbrozen
text: Oddly enough, I saw not 1 but 2 Slingshots this weekend. A red and a black. I wonder if a helmet is required with that. It is classified as a motorcycle, after all, right? Guy in the black one had no helmet.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
This note from Slingshot website:

"SLINGSHOT IS A THREE-WHEELED MOTORCYCLE. IT IS NOT AN AUTOMOBILE, IT DOES NOT HAVE AIRBAGS, AND IT DOES NOT MEET AUTOMOTIVE SAFETY STANDARDS. THREE WHEEL VEHICLES MAY HANDLE DIFFERENTLY THAN OTHER VEHICLES, ESPECIALLY IN WET CONDITIONS. ALWAYS WEAR DOT APPROVED FULL FACE HELMET AND FASTEN SEAT BELTS. DRIVER MAY NEED A VALID MOTORCYCLE ENDORSEMENT. DONT DRINK AND DRIVE. 2016 POLARIS INDUSTRIES INC.

So, I would imagine that the helmet requirement would be based on the state you live in.

I checked randomly and most states seem to classify it as a motorcycle. Then I went to Nevada, the "do whatever you want state", and sure enough, it's not a motorcycle anymore.

author: fintail
text: I've seen a couple Lexus GS-F lately. Like a normal GS, but styling applied with a wider trowel. In a way it seems silly, as an M5 or E63 is in a different galaxy, but mild sport tuned models like E43 are coming, and S6 already exists - might be a market for it I guess.

author: berri
text: Trowel , like a Jersey skank applying makeup. Now I'm in trouble But I've also got the Bee Gees "Night Fever" in my head!

author: fintail
text: Saw a new Volvo S90 on the road today. It wasn't far from the dealer, not sure if there's a connection. Also a no-grille Tesla.

author: explorerx4
text: In the parking lot at work, a red Ram extend cab and a silver CR-V.

author: fintail
text: 2 hockey stick 7ers, and a Domino's Pizza themed Chevy Spark.

author: stickguy
text: we walk at a local park most nights, and yesterday, we got there as people were arriving for a softball game. Not sure where they came from, but must have had some money. a nice assortment of BMWs and audis, and a few other cars I would like. But the cream of the crop was a nice white Maserati convertible. that I could live with.

author: Michaell
text: You saw a DXP in the wild?

author: stickguy
text: I think I saw one of those recently too. But don't make me swear to it. My brain ain't what it used to be.

author: fintail
text: Yep, parked near the local Domino's location. I didn't think they were a real thing.

author: Michaell
text: Oh, but they are. Kinda expensive, I've heard - something like $25-30K per. Expensive investment by the franchise owner.

author: fintail
text:
Expensive bustling zip code and only location in the general area, I suspect the owner does enough business to handle it.

I am surprised it would be expensive, fleet price of a basic automatic (I assume) Spark has to be like 10-11K. Oh, but they are. Kinda expensive, I've heard - something like $25-30K per. Expensive investment by the franchise owner.

author: Michaell
text:
Pretty well modified. Only one seat and a gigantic warming oven in the back.

IIRC, they are modified by ASC in Michigan.

author: fintail
text:
For what looks like 15-20K in charges, it ought to be pretty well done. I suppose that's different than having it made at the local mom and pop bodyshop.

Too bad there isn't a huge fleet of them, they'd probably have demand in the used commercial vehicle market for years to come.
Pretty well modified. Only one seat and a gigantic warming oven in the back.

IIRC, they are modified by ASC in Michigan.

author: imidazol97
text: The concept of the Dominos DXP reminds me of the Chevy 210 business coupe back in 1957. One showed up at local shows fairly often. Very practical for business to modify that empty back seat area.

author: stickguy
text: or the Vega and Pinto panel wagons.

author: qbrozen
text: Saw an F-pace with temp tag pulling into my office complex earlier today. It was not as ... stand-outish as I thought it would be. And that back window, especially with the rear spoiler in place, is tiny.

author: stickguy
text: I think it looks really sharp, without being bizarre. Probably true about the back window, that seems to be the trend these days, even with "practical" vehicles.

author: fintail
text: Got behind a shiny new 230i coupe.

author: qbrozen
text: I didn't even know they went back to using the 30i designation.

author: texases
text: More BMW number magic - the '30i' is for the turbo 4 2.0 liter engine, replacing the '28i' designation. This to combat MB's C300 with a similar engine.

author: ab348
text: What do BMW's "28" and "30" designations signify?

author: qbrozen
text: it is all so awful. I pine for the days when their numbers made sense.

author: texases
text: For example, last year's 228i is this year's 230i, both with the same 2.0 liter turbo 4. It's a change for marketing reasons.

author: qbrozen
text: They USED to signify the displacement of the engine under the hood. A 325i has a 2.5 liter engine, etc.

author: texases
text:
But even in the pre-turbo era BMW played number games. At one point the '325i' had a 2.8 '323i' had a 2.5 l NA 6 engine, but they wanted to separate it from the '330i'.

edited- @qbrozen has it right, it was the 2.5l engine. And yes, this was minor, compared to the turbo-induced major number games now being played by BMW and MB.

author: qbrozen
text: But I don't believe that really started until the e90 era. The one exception I recall was the e46 323 with the 2.5. And I think some of the 318 models were a bit scattered.

author: kyfdx
text: More horsepower, this year, I think. 248 vs. 240

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
I spied someone loading some gear into a new BMW X6.

Not to my tastes.

To each his own of course.

author: explorerx4
text: A sliver Chevy RWD police car. It was unmarked, but silver like the state police have here in CT.

author: stickguy
text: I can top that. Today in Philly (on the Ben Franklin bridge) a Smart car police car. weirdest thing I ever saw.

author: british_rover
text: We sold our S90 a month or so ago. We have three in stock right now all inscription T6 AWD models on is a Demo.

author: qbrozen
text: Whoa!! It's BR, everybody!!

author: fushigi
text: Probably used by the meter maids, er, traffic enforcement division.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: "You are under arrest. For your safety and mine, I'm going to strap you to the roof".

author: fintail
text:
Hey long time no see.

Any Chinese-built LWB models yet, aka nobody asked the question (on this continent) but Volvo answered?

author: british_rover
text:
We have sold several S60 Inscription models and if you want the highest level of equipment than you have to get an inscription.

You cannot get a platinum trim regular S60 anymore as of 2016 model year.

author: fintail
text:
Is that's the Chinese built LWB, Inscription?

I have yet to see one, the only odd duck LWB I have seen is an Infiniti.

author: fintail
text: Today I saw a Model X with a trailer hitch and a front plate. Talk about a unicorn.

author: ab348
text: A new-looking Audi A7 3.0T parked outside a medical clinic - probably the doc's car. Dark blue. Man, they are a good-looking machine.

author: stickguy
text: 2017 Golf Wolfsburg. VW simplified the models this year on the Golf, and the WB has a ton of nice features now standard, for a pretty good price. Almost like taking an SEL, adding some safety stuff, and chopping $4k off the price.

author: Michaell
text:
My primary care physician was thinking about getting one of these.

Ended up with an A6 with the TDI.

author: ab348
text: Poor devil.

author: fintail
text: Oddball today - BMW X5 xDrive40e - with a typical cringeworthy driving performance as one expects from such a car in downtown Bellevue.

author: Michaell
text: I suspect you'll be seeing more of them - lots of dealer cash and good lease deals on them.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: It is an odd duck...a real porker and only 14 miles range on electric. Probably performs well, though.

author: stickguy
text: I drove a hyrbid X5 at the drive event a few weeks ago. was pretty quick with just the 2.0t 4. But definitely a barge.

author: stever
text:
2016 Toyota Tacoma, pretty blue, special order with a six foot bed. Belongs to company who flew to Dallas to pick it up - it's going to supplement her 1990 Mazda B2600 with 240,000 miles on it. The salesperson quit so the order got cancelled back in the Spring and then the dealership got sold over the summer and when she finally tracked them down for a status report, the truck had just come in. Luckily they hadn't sold it out from under her. No hurry to buy it, it's not like the Mazda was ever going to die. She drove it up to Alaska and back this summer.

She didn't have a good reason to buy it in Dallas other than the fact that she wanted to visit friends there and then drive home to Arizona via our place and catch up with us.

Didn't order any extras other than a towing package, but she's amazed by the intermittent wipers, the backup cam and especially loves the cruise control.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new grille-less Tesla S today, wearing a front plate! Not a common sight here. Of course, it was making a right turn from a straight only lane, because Bellevue.

author: fintail
text: Saw a brand new unplated white fairly basic looking Corolla today - going straight through a turn only lane. Nearly directly in front of the police station. Welcome to Bellevue.

author: Michaell
text: As a host, I should know this - but, where did the "Inconsiderate Drivers" thread go to?

author: fintail
text: I wish I could explain it. It stopped rising to the top of the list when receiving a new post, and quickly vanished.

author: fushigi
text: http://forums.edmunds.com/discussion/2746/general/x/inconsiderate-drivers-share-your-stories-etc#latest

author: ab348
text: A couple of Sundays ago when I was driving home at night from the boonies I was on a 2-lane road with a speed limit that varied from 40 to 50mph. For about 15 minutes I was stuck behind a Corolla that never exceeded 35mph, and most of the time stayed at 30. There is something about Corollas that attracts that kind of driver it seems.

author: fintail
text:
Around here, they are popular with some drivers, and I won't say more. Also seem to have more bumper scuffs and sometimes Camry dents which might not paint a good picture of the demographic.

It's a thing

author: fintail
text: There it is, Doesn't seem to rise to the top when receiving a new post. I wonder if it offended some inconsiderate drivers

author: stickguy
text: I love the Camry dent site

author: Michaell
text:
As a host, I should know this - but, where did the "Inconsiderate Drivers" thread go to?

author: fintail
text:
Not a new model, but the Safeway nearest to me has a new Ghibli parked in the foyer area for some kind of promotion. Welcome to Bellevue.

I also noticed construction on a combination REI/Trader Joes/Home Goods has just completed near me. No doubt I will be able to see all the latest models of Subaru and Prius there, along with the latest trends in beards and popular dogs

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Probably a coupon promotion. Accumulate 10 billion stamps, something like that.

author: tifighter
text: The new Infiniti Q60 coupe. Dark metallic blue. Looks pretty nice, maybe a little heavy on the chrome on the one I saw, at least.

author: explorerx4
text: A new GMC Acadia. Very similar size to an Explorer.

author: ab348
text: I looked at a new Acadia on a dealer lot. Size is much more realistic, no longer such a tank. I liked that about it and the overall exterior look, but was very disappointed by the dashboard design and controls though. The dash design is just kind of clunky looking, and the steering wheel buttons are covered with a rubbery membrane and so are not distinct buttons on the surface. You just know that over time that membrane will crack/tear.

author: ab348
text: Anecdotal observation: I am seeing a lot of new Civic sedans on the roads up here so it is obviously selling very well. But it seems that maybe 80% of them that I see are painted black. In fact today I was behind a blue one and that struck me as maybe the first I had seen in that color. Seeing all the disjointed angles on that rear end, maybe that is why black is popular because it makes them less obvious.

author: fintail
text: Judging by turn signal use on even newer models, I am not sure Range Rover has detached itself from BMW. If only there was an inconsiderate driver's thread

author: stickguy
text: was out shopping earlier, and a white Ridgeline drove past the store. I like the way it looks.

author: imidazol97
text:
fintail said:
... If only there was an inconsiderate driver's thread
http://forums.edmunds.com/discussion/comment/5257871/#Comment_5257871

author: fintail
text:
The nannies have apparently made a secret decision that the old thread was offensive to sensitive inconsiderate drivers, and made it inactive - new posts don't update it.

For new cars, saw a new Volt this morning - I see them now and then.

A friend said he looked at a new Continental yesterday - claims the sticker was almost 90K.
imidazol97 said:


http://forums.edmunds.com/discussion/comment/5257871/#Comment_5257871

author: berri
text: Could be the depreciation opportunity of a lifetime

author: anythngbutgm
text: Went in to Boston for the day on Sat. I think the new XC90 is the new car to have around there. They are everywhere...

author: qbrozen
text: I'll take a stab at high $30s to $40k retail for a 2-year-old, average-mile Continental.

author: iluvmysephia1
text:
I didn't see the new 2018 Kia Rio 5-door in person but I did see a photo of the car taken at Kia's Frankfurt Headquarters just recently. This Chief Designer hired away from Audi Motors, Peter Schreyer, is really designing these South Korean cars "German" these days, ain't he? This one has caught my eye, indeed. A few engine sizes available, including a 1.0L 4-cyl turbo. I would consider the turbo or the 1.4L 4-cyl motor. Upper-end 2018 Rio packages will offer a 6-speed or DSG tranny and lower-end (me) offer 5-speed manuals and I would say an automatic without DSG transmission. The car will do the "coming out early in 2017 as a 2018 model" confusatory thing. Mitsubishi did this with my beloved 2008 Lancer GTS - it became available for sale in March of 2007.



Pricing will be critical. Our '11 Soul base 5-speed has only a little over 73,500 miles on it now. That red always gets me. The Soul looks great in Tomato Red, too.

author: stickguy
text: snazzy looking.

author: iluvmysephia1
text:
The rear is sharp - I thought of Audi/VW right away here. Yep-it's gettin' me.



The day we traded the hulk of our '08 Mitsubishi Lancer GTS for the Soul I sat in a '11 Rio sedan. Small - intruding cabin area. I didn't see a 5-dr. hatch Rio on their lot to try out. Sat in a '14 Kia Soul and it felt comfortable. The length is increasing on the '18 Rio and I'll check the width - betcha they've upped it, too. Ahh...happiness.

Love ta see what, if anything Toyota does to their newly-acquired Scion iA. Probably just plopping a shiny Toyota badge on that odd-looking, great driving new small car. Still like it - but not like I am starting ta like the '18 Kia Rio.

I'm getting those butterflies in my stomach again.

author: berri
text: There is an article in this week's Business Week noting how ugly and cramped the new Toyota Prius has become. Basically, it states Toyota design is too focused on its home market and not the rest of the world with this anime stuff. It also noted that GM is passing it up as a green leader.

author: qbrozen
text: Weird. I have read nothing but good things about the new prius, although I find it hideous.

author: stever
text: Nothing wrong with it that $4 a gallon gas wouldn't fix in a hurry.

author: berri
text: I dunno what's up with Toyota. They've got some nice stuff, but I think also some stuff that is falling behind, or at least just standing still. Opportunity for Detroit perhaps, particularly the newer GM stuff.

author: fintail
text:
Some people want $5/gallon gas, no matter the impacts to the economy. More demand for rare earths mining, too.

Saw a Q60 coupe in traffic, Lexus and Infiniti are in mild competition for mild flamboyance.

author: berri
text: Things are so screwed up these days on Wall Street, that today oil goes up and so do stocks. The place is run by Ivy League lemmings I think

author: stickguy
text:
can't wait until Friday. Taking my car in for an oil change, and going to the dealer at the local auto mall. So, can check it in, then walk the row to check out anything new I might have missed.

will hit the Honda store (Civic EX-T, hope they have a stick but I doubt it), and Chevy (look at the Cruze hatch). And whatever else strikes my fancy. Want to see the Ioniq, but don't think that will be out for another month or so.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
Anyone have any experience with the VW 1.8T? It's been around a while and I believe it's a pretty well regarded engine for both performance and reliability but would love to get some feedback from the Edmunds community here.

Very interested in the new Golf Alltrack with the manual when it arrives next year as a possible replacement for my trusty 07' Subie Impreza hatch

author: Michaell
text:
There are a few folks here who have the 1.8T - Golf's and Jetta's both.

I've got a Jetta with the 1.4T engine and I really like it. I imagine the 1.8T is even better (read: faster).

author: stickguy
text: I like it. son has a 2014 Jetta, and daughter a 2015, both with the 1.8. quick, smooth, and gets great MPG (have done 39 MPG on highway runs). No issues to report.

author: tifighter
text: Golf Wagon Alltrack. White. Already had J-mounts for boats on the rack. If this had been out a year ago, I would have given it a look.

author: tlong
text: Saw a new Murano today. I noticed that it now has those (IMHO) overstyled taillights - the type where they stick out and the plastic kind of forms a horizontal "shelf" because of the protrusion. I'll say I think that's really ugly, but appears to be a trend. The Toyota Highlander has them as well. Don't like the look.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Saw a new Jaguar XJL Supercharged parked on Broadway in NYC. BIG car.

author: stickguy
text:
starting to see a lot of the new Ridgelines out and about. I think 3 different ones while out doing errands Sunday. I think Honda may have a hit on their hands.

really hope that Ford displays the upcoming Ranger at the Philly auto show.

author: fintail
text:
I heard that a co-worker who had an Xterra for 12 years just got an Escape Titanium, loaded. She's thrilled.

Not a new sighting, but a new experience. I took my 84 year old aunt for a ride in my (modern) car. Her car is an aging Dodge Stratus (she's in very good shape, and gets around without issue, looks 10 years older than she is and acts much younger). She was taken aback by the quiet smooth ride, the talking nav system, and all of the buttons. She had fun.

author: stever
text: Two i3s and three Volts.

author: tlong
text: Two car carriers, about 2 minutes apart, carrying full loads of brand new Tesla Model X's. All white on both carriers. Yes, in the Bay Area on the west bay, not too far from Fremont. Heading north toward San Francisco.

author: fintail
text: New cars for the local Stepfords

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Given the traffic, I'd expect those Model Xs to almost be there by now.

author: fintail
text: Saw an Evoque Cabrio today, for when a CrossCabrio is just too proletarian.

author: stever
text: Spotted within the last hour in the trendy town of Silver City NM. Kind of a nice fall color.

author: bhill2
text: My immediate reaction was "Man the owner's lucky he can't see that thing's butt from the driver's seat." Bummer for the person behind him in traffic though.

author: fintail
text:
Baby got back.

Stopped by the MB dealer. They had a couple of new C cabrios - one with a 60K MSRP, the other was being driven and I couldn't see the sticker. Hiding in back was an S63 AMG Cabrio with a 195K sticker. Belle Epoque.

text: At the VW dealer yesterday. Next door in the Audi showroom, R8 V-10. MSRP $202K

author: Mr_Shiftright

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: You know, I never liked the exhaust note on V-10s. So I think I won't buy that one...

author: explorerx4
