I will say their service isn't bad. I stopped in to get a keyfob battery for the spare key - free of charge. There was also a guy there looking for plastic clips, I think bumper clips for a W211. The parts guy gave him a few for free.

author: explorerx4
text:
I saw my first Model X today. Doesn't look very good. Styling fits Model S much better.
Got my wife's MKC serviced today, but forgot to go to the showroom to see if they have a Continental.

author: tifighter
text: Today in Berkeley- two new Alfa Giulias, one silver and one red. Base models. Not bad but they didn't blow me away. Also saw my first Bolt, in forgettable silver.

author: stickguy
text: another new Pilot with temp tags in my neighborhood. Seems to be popular.

author: fushigi
text:
It's a pretty broad segment now. Even with what you listed there's the Rogue, Sportage / Tucson, and Outlander Sport to consider. If FWD is fine, consider the hybrid Kia Niro .. gets something like 46MPG with a sticker of $28-32K.

Here's the "Star Wars Rogue" from the Chicago Auto Show. Note the stormtrooper int he background; Nissan had 2 there posing for pics with the guests.

author: fintail
text:
Saw a new NSX today, first one for me.

Also a later S63 with a "driver" who had a phone to his ear and didn't bother with signals. Must be all of that hard work and responsibility at play.

author: qbrozen
text: I have noticed quite a few drivers with high-end newer cars with phones to ears. What the hell is that all about? Inability to figure out the BT?

author: fintail
text: Ineptitude and probably some simple lack of self-awareness, too. When you won't be held accountable, why bother? These are the early adopters of microwaves and VCRs who had blinking clocks 35 years ago. I don't exactly have a PhD in computer science, yet I've never had an issue pairing BT to a car.

author: tjc78
text: I point that out the wife all the time.  Just yesterday woman driving a new S-class with an IPhone to her ear.  No way in hell that car didn't have BT.

author: fintail
text: Saw a highline Malibu today, with the big sunroof. Kind of unusual. Also spotted a McLaren, these things just don't impress me anymore. A white late model AMG G-Wagen rounded out the class and taste.

author: tjc78
text: At work a brand new XC90, appeared really optioned up with 22" wheels.  Really a looker, IMO.

author: Michaell
text: Every time I travel to the Bay Area to visit company HQ, there is a McLaren dealership on my drive from the hotel to the office.

author: texases
text: All 345 recent McLaren models look the same to me. And OK, but not great.

author: anythngbutgm
text: Checked out the new V90 Cross Country last night while I was there looking at V60CC. That thing is huge!

author: kyfdx
text: Saw one at the car show a couple of weeks ago. I like it! (except the price)

author: anythngbutgm
text:
The one on the floor had a price tag of 66k and change which puts it in the exact price range as a comparable XC90.

I think I'd actually go for the XC90 just because of V90's length even tho I much prefer wagons over SUV's.

Still, it gives me hope the next V60 gets the same details, it was quite nice. Interior is just as stunning as the XC90 (not surprising).

On a side note, I test drove the new V60CC. Although it cannot be considered "Spotted a new Model" since it is now a year or 2 old and was still on the showroom floor, it was pretty nice. Interior is a bit dated now since it goes back to the original 60 series but it is still a nice place to be. I love the seats, best in the industry IMO. I also thought I was going to dislike the T-5's 4-cylinder Turbo but it was quite peppy. It's definitely not the rocketship 3.0 Turbo Straight six, but it was plenty spunky. One thing I absolutely hate is the Stop/Start tho. If I can, I pledge never to buy a car with it. Ever... But for 40g, it was certainly a step above a loaded Outback 3.6R in interior, seats, power and definitely gas mileage. Not sure if I'm going to jump on buying one or wait for the new XC40 tho...

author: berri
text: Next time you test drive one, see if you can turn the stop start off. I think on some cars you can, but not on others. I don't like that feature either and unless you are stopping an awful lot. I suspect the fuel advantage is quite minimal compared to the annoyance and possible resulting complications if the system goes haywire down the road.

author: explorerx4
text:
Volvo's start/stop is pretty unrefined. My neighbor had an XC60 as a loaner for several months.
We went for a ride and it's very ragged. He was afraid to disable it, so I had to listen to him complain about it.
My Fusion has start/stop. When you stop the car just gets quiet. You notice the engine starting, but just a little kick plus the sound.

author: ab348
text: I've had it on both Chevy and Cadillac loaners and even though it is MOSTLY unobtrusive, you occasionally feel it restart. That alone is enough to make me not want it. Unfortunately the GM implementations are required to meet their EPA mileage ratings, so it cannot be turned off easily.

author: tifighter
text: The new Drive-E V60CC should be hitting dealers now. Car and Driver has a write up on it; sounds like the 8 speed AT is a nice improvement.

author: Michaell
text: The loaner MINI I had on Monday offers start/stop. I disabled it.

author: qbrozen
text: Had an ATS loaner with start/stop. It did not actually turn itself off very often. It seemed to me if I slowed down to a crawl and then feathered the brakes to a stop, it would not shut off the engine. Only if I came to a stop with steady pressure on the brake pedal the whole way would it shut off the engine.

author: fushigi
text: Some work that way to try to figure out if you're coming to a red light (steady braking .. OK to shut off) or in heavy traffic where the stop/start can cause delays/problems.

author: imidazol97
text: There's an input that's the percent of brake pedal depression. Harder than that and the S/S can operate. If you apply brakes lightly or lighten pressure just before dead stop, the car doesn't meet the % brake pedal for S/S. Then there are many other factors including the HVAC system and demand vs outside temp vs actual cabin temp.

author: andres3
text:
Could it be a work phone, and only the personal phone is paired via Bluetooth? Probably a lot harder to pair multiple phones for the same person? I haven't tried yet, and I should !

I know in the old diesel VW you had to select one phone/user at a time.

author: andres3
text: Not sure the T5 drive-train has any advantage power wise over Subaru's 3.6 engine, but I'd agree Volvo is a step up, but also in price.

author: Michaell
text: I've got both my personal iPhone and my work iPhone paired to the Jetta concurrently. I had to rename my work phone so I knew which was which.

author: fintail
text: I am pretty sure multiple phones can be paired at once, and multiple phones can definitely be stored in the memory.

author: tjc78
text: Yes multiple phones no problem, but most only allow on connected at a time.

author: tlong
text: Saw a McLaren in the parking lot. Beautiful in orange even if I wouldn't buy one...

author: kyfdx
text:
How is holding a phone to your ear any different than drinking from your big gulp? It's not like anyone is driving a stick shift, any more (except me).

Holding phone to your ear = OK
Looking down at your text messages = NOT ok

author: fintail
text: Holding food/drink/cig/pet/kid while driving results in just as much stupidity no doubt, it just isn't the flavor of the day in terms of outrage.

author: kyfdx
text:
Studies quoted in newspapers, etc.. say it's the distraction of the phone call itself that is the problem, not the fact that you are holding the phone. I'd have to agree with that.

The bonus of those that use bluetooth is they probably don't keep the phone handy to look at text messages. It's not the holding (phone, cig, big gulp) that is the problem, it's the distraction.

So, my ranking of distraction problems:

1) Texting
2) Talking on phone (bluetooth or not)
3) Passenger who won't shut up (especially those who don't pay attention to driving situations)
4) Drinking/eating while driving a stick-shift (that one is mostly for me). I think this is why they invented longnecks, before we had cupholders.

author: berri
text:
4) Drinking/eating while driving a stick-shift (that one is mostly for me). I think this is why they invented longnecks, before we had cupholders

hahaha !

author: stickguy
text:
I drove sticks as my main car for about 35 years. I never had any problem eating or drinking while doing so. Just took a little more creativity, and coordination.

I really should get another stick when I replace my car. While I still have a chance!

author: fintail
text: Studies can be made to show a lot, but I have to believe that physically holding a device and usually looking at it while talking creates a different real world result than yapping toward a speaker with hands on the wheel and not looking at a phone. It might not even create more crashes, but more stupid slow inconsiderate driving, the kind the LEO community hasn't yet wanted to touch.

author: ab348
text: I found even with Bluetooth, I felt distracted on a phone conversation while driving, at least when it was an important discussion that required thinking. It seemed to take away from my ability to focus on my driving. .

author: stickguy
text: I seem to recall studies saying that. Basically it is mentally focusing on the call, not holding the phone, that is the problem. But at least with bluetooth, have 2 hands available for the wheel!

author: berri
text: I believe the problem with today in many things is that people think they are more proficient at multitasking than they really are.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: The human brain CAN'T multitask at all. You are either doing A or B, but not both at the same time with equal concentration---not even close.

author: berri
text: The real problem may be that too many people know they've got to do A and B, but can't prioritize or spatially coordinate the tasks. Maybe a little too much "me" focus.

author: stickguy
text: house around the corner from me has a new TLX with a temp tag. I still really like these, but you just don't see too many.

author: tjc78
text: The Accord Touring (or whatever the top line model is ) is probably so good it doesn't pay to spend more.

author: fintail
text: Saw my first Maserati Levante on the road - yet another Stepfordian mallcruiser for the idle leisure set.

author: laurasdada
text: Why would anyone buy a Levante when they could have an F-Pace!

author: fintail
text:
Or a normal sedan

A few new models on the road this afternoon:

New style CRV, Genesis G90, GLC coupe, E-class, and the grand whale of them all - a Bentayga. Of course, the "driver" was holding a phone while "driving".

author: kyfdx
text: I see a lot of new 2017 CR-Vs. Might be the best looking CR-V, yet.

author: berri
text: Kind of makes you wonder in most circumstances if the next size up crossover is worth an extra $10K

author: tlong
text: Kydfx - well I guess beauty is in the eye of the beholder. My wife and I took a look and test drive of the latest CR-V. I personally find its styling a mess, don't like the looks at all. We sat in the premium model. The interior is generally pretty nice, but I find the fake plastic wood particularly tacky looking. There is also a big ledge between the back cargo area and the top of the rear seats when folded down - there is like a 4 inch cliff up to the flag folded seatbacks on an otherwise flat load floor. Doesn't makes sense to me.

author: ab348
text: I saw a first edition CR-V on the roads this week - nowadays, a very rare sight around here as they all seem to have disappeared and I haven't spotted one in a while - and was stunned by how small it appeared Was it based on the Civic platform of the day? I always assumed the vehicle was spun off from an Accord but that made me realize it couldn't be the case.

author: kyfdx
text: Well.. I can't see inside, as they drive by..

author: kyfdx
text:
Yes, first generation was Civic platform and engine. 2nd generation was still Civic platform, but Accord engine.

I had a '98 with a stick... You really got to wind out the gears. If you like driving a stick, it was a lot of fun. That one died a horrible death in 2002, and I bought a Gen 2 automatic. Drove that one for 100K+ miles. Repair costs were terrible... $11 + maintenance for the 106K miles and 6.5 years.

author: fintail
text: Funny how older car survival is so regional - I see first gen CRV virtually every day. Some of them are pretty beat up, but they are still moving along. I suspect they aren't immune to rot, especially underneath.

author: stickguy
text:
I agree about not wanting to spend so much money for the bit of extra room in a pilot over a CRV, since I have zero need for an emergency only 3rd row (and if i did, would still have a minivan!)

as to the trunk, I think it has a multi level rear floor. At least, it did. Or I am confusing it with a different car. In any case, you can set it at the low position for more cargo space, or raise to top spot to make a flat floor with the seats down.

and does this model have sliding rear seats? A number of wagons like this end up with a gap if you slide the back seat forward.

author: anythngbutgm
text:
I came close to buying one of the first ones when they came out, a 97 Black, AWD with a stick when I was first looking to dump my 6 month old lemon Exploder. It was pretty slow with only 128hp (power was bumped to 148 for 98') but it was nimble and tossable. Dealer offer the same exact payments as I had on my Exploder so I walked because I thought of it as somewhat of a downgrade.

4 months later, I dumped it for an Accord

author: fintail
text: Saw a MB S600 non-Maybach today today, pretty rare car, probably sold at maybe 1:500 of normal S550. Also saw a S600 Maybach and a GLE with an illuminated grille star.

author: fintail
text:
Saw another new NSX, or probably the same one, as it was the same color. A poorly driven AMG G-Wagen was also a fun sight, and a hockey stick 7er rounded out the afternoon.

And not new, but I am pretty sure I saw a Lexus LS600h, pretty rare car, that might be an LS I'd buy just for the unicorn status.

author: fintail
text: Another Levante today, and a red 911 Targa.

author: laurasdada
text: I want the latest edition Targa. Just love Rube Goldberg contraptions! Of course I could get a Miata RF and save a pretty penny.

author: tlong
text: I saw a Tesla Model S driving down the freeway yesterday with a bike rack hanging off the rear bumper. This was in Silicon Valley...

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: an electric bike no doubt?

author: PF_Flyer
text:
Are you having trouble figuring out how to use all of the technology in your car? If you're overwhelmed with how to operate your navigation system, bluetooth, park assist or other advanced technology feature, a reporter would love to talk to you about your experience.

Please send an email to PR@Edmunds.com by Friday, March 17, 2017.

author: fintail
text: At work today saw a brand new unplated X1 with what looks like a white or very very light beige interior, kind of unusual color. Also parked next to me the past two days, maybe a Challenger Hellcat? SRT at any rate, it has some kind of animal head fender badge. Out of state plates, probably parking by me because I park with care, mirrors folded, up against a pole, so the Challenger would have more room for the huge door.

author: tlong
text:
A pink Fiat 500. At a regional park, where people often hike...
Is that a factory color (I doubt it) or one of those cosmetic selling cars, etc.?

author: tlong
text: I really try to avoid parking next to the driver's side of two door cars.

author: kyfdx
text: I think they call that interior, Oyster.

author: fintail
text: Me too, but I was there first. I usually assume/hope that someone driving something that is kind of an enthusiast car will also be more careful. I try to keep away from big trucks and Stepfordian CUVs/SUVs.

author: fintail
text: Got behind a GLE43 coupe yesterday while in the fintail. It was different, that's all I will say.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: It doesn't work. There's neither the angularity of a trunk or the cut-off of a hatch or the grace of a fastback---it's a blob.

author: fintail
text: It's a MB X4/X6. These brands now copy and out-niche each other more than anything.

author: fintail
text: Saw my first new Lincoln Continental on the road. Appeared to be in livery service, that might not bode well. Also a S600 Maybach, perfect if you made your money in the laundry business (and I don't mean like George Jefferson), and another GLE43 coupe.

author: qbrozen
text: Saw my first S90 on the road today. It was a steelish powder blue yet still looked quite macho (mostly due to those taillights) for a volvo.

author: stickguy
text:
I am really interested in seeing the upcoming XC60. I am sure the wife will be perfectly happy to trade in the RDX on one of those. Only wrinkle in the plan is waiting to hit MegaMillions first so we can pay for it.

maybe in 3 years when the off lease CPOs are out.

author: stickguy
text:
Livery might not be so bad, if it is limo service. At least it indicates luxurious.

back about 20-25 years ago when I traveled a lot on business, I used Boston Coach often. For a while they used S80 Volvos. Then they moved onto big Caddys (FWD devilles IIRC). Might have been something else along the way, but those are the ones I remember. Probably sold a few customers for the car companies, since it mostly businessmen using the service that could become interested in the cars from the back seat!

author: fintail
text: On the road today - GLC coupe (not a MAzda - if an X4 is just too brash), hockey stick 7er.

author: andres3
text:
speaking of rare, ever see a 30+ year old Audi moving along the road?

I remember when my mechanic let me borrow his early 80's coupe that I felt part of a very exclusive club since I had probably the only 30+ year old Audi on the road being used that day in all of CA.

author: fintail
text: Being in the PNW, I see an Audi of that era now and then. Usually a 4000, but there's a GT Coupe in the area I see now and then. There are a couple of 5000s seen every blue moon or so, too.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
The 4000s weren't too bad a car. They could stretch out the miles if you took care of them.

They have certainly gotten more reliable and more fun to drive over the years.

author: fintail
text: I know it irks the devotees of the 4 rings to make "gussied up VW" claimss, but I think the 4000 was much the same as a same era Passat/Quantum. This lineage would lead to the A4 of today, I suppose. A Quantum, there's something not seen too often these days. Surprisingly enough, there are 2 of each on local CL right now.

author: andres3
text: I suppose in the early 80's Audi's were far more affordable apparently, and hadn't made the move yet to be a "luxury" division. They certainly went more upscale with the original A4.

author: kyfdx
text: That is definitely not the case. Audi, BMW, Mercedes, etc, etc... were very expensive in the '80s

author: fintail
text: Yeah, an Audi back then wasn't priced like an S-class, but it wasn't a cheap car. I could see a 1980 Audi 5000 being 15K in those dollars, anyway (where a normal diesel W123 was probably 20K+). Not as luxurious as modern models either, but that was true for German cars as a whole.

author: Michaell
text: When I was still living in CA, my mom and dad's next door neighbor bought a 4000. Kind of a 7-Up can green, and it was the 5+5 (5-cylinder + 5-speed)

author: berri
text: It seemed like there was brief period of time when the Europeans were pushing 5 cylinder engines. Don't know how they sold in Europe and Scandinavia, but didn't seem to catch on here. IIRC some complained the engines were not as smooth.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: New Audi RS3 is a 5-er but there aren't many anymore. But for some reason, 3 cylinders are still in the game.

author: berri
text: I think most of today's 3 cylinders are turbos? If that is the case maybe it compensates a bit?

author: stickguy
text: stopped at a light today next to an X6. Quite odd looking. But tall.

author: fintail
text:
MB day - saw 2 new MB "coupes" today, a new E that might have been a rental (basic looking, out of state plates with no frames), red G63 that screamed sketchy money, and a zillion Teslas as usual.

Speaking of old Audis, I remember back in the 80s, my mom had a friend who had a 4000 coupe. I think it was brown, it seemed a little unusual then and is a unicorn today.

author: fintail
text: Saw a blue NSX again today, has to be the same car.

author: tifighter
text: Spotted this week in Zurich. Whatever it is...

author: iluvmysephia1
text: Possibly the new Kia Rio for 2018?

author: fintail
text:
If only you had got a pic of the plates

There's definitely some tricky red herring in that camouflage, with the hood bulge and design on the C-pillar.

author: fintail
text:
Went out for an errand, saw some new 5ers on the BMW lot. Stopped to take a look - definitely sharper looking than the prior car. A nicely optioned one is 66K. I don't think there's a diesel yet. It was parked beside a black 6er GC with a white interior. The rest of the stuff on the lot was more normal, most interesting was the used car side, which had a couple of year old hockey stick 7ers, and a loaded 2012 S-class, sadly a V8 and not a diesel.

Also stopped by MB to get a key fob battery replacement. Nothing I hadn't seen before, but they all had special lease prices on the window. $1900/month for an AMG GT seems kind of dear.

author: tjc78
text: Took the family to the Zoo today.   I saw at least 5 brand new Pilots.  No wonder they are terrible leases, no reason to give them away.

author: stickguy
text:
I think there are 3 of them at least in my neighborhood, 2 on my block. And see tons of them around.

also saw a nice steel blue MB GLA. Sharp looking in that color. I could be happy with something of that size and configuration.

author: fintail
text: Local Bentley dealer has a fairly bright red Flying Spur sitting in a very visible part of their lot. I wonder who that's intended for.

author: Michaell
text: Saw this at the dealer today:

author: explorerx4
text: So, did you buy it?

author: Michaell
text:
To small to live in - the sticker price was about 60% of the cost of my house.

And, that's where the wife would force me to be if I brought it home.

author: PF_Flyer
text: During our stay in Santa Monica for Edmunds meetings, this little gem was available for rent outside the hotel. We didn't, but the wife was thinking we should have

author: imidazol97
text: Just call it your doghouse for those times when it's best not to hang around the house!

author: fintail
text: On the road in traffic today was beside the CEO in his new Bentley, also saw a new E-class, seldom-seen luxury trim and looked like a high spec car with drivers assistance package. Terribly driven, embarrassing, distracted and phone usage. Time for progressive fines.

author: tjc78
text: Our CEO drives a 7 series. He could easily afford a Bentley but he just isn't the type.  I don't even think he picked the 7, his nephew who works for the company gets that job.

author: fintail
text: Our CEO also regularly drives a later model Ferrari, I think a 458. I am pretty sure he makes a cool 8 figures, so these cars for him are like you or I buying a $700 beater

author: andres3
text:
I have to laugh at "not being the type" for a Bentley, but a 7-Series is OK? If he's really not the type, a Lexus ES would do! Maybe even a Honda Accord V6.

If I didn't care for sport in my cars, I would probably be happy with luxury from Lexus. If I wanted a happy medium, Audi's A-cars are great.

I have a loaner right now. A "loaded" A3. 2.0T, quattro, Bang & Olufsen Stereo, DSG, parking sensors, blind spot light monitor. A nice small car that is comfortable and geared for good mileage. It's laughable how different it is geared (with the same 6-speed) vs. my TTS. About 1K difference in RPM at 75 MPH.

Softer sprung, but still fast in the curves. Only true sports cars would get away from this A3, yet it is comfy.

author: stickguy
text: Add a sport package and that is my sons car. If it is a 2017.

author: andres3
text:
I doubt it because it has nearly 13,000 miles. In fact, the key tag says '15 A3. Still, a quality car, that I know is even more improved for '17, and that's a good thing.

It has the drive SELECT (comfort, dynamic) and 19" wheels, so I'm guessing it is a "sport" model.

Surprised they had parking sensors on the '15's, but it was a new model release at the time.

Main complaint: The interior isn't quite up to snuff by A4/S4/TT standards. In fact, I still feel the '06 A3 had some nicer materials and softer more padded plastics, with nicer trim real aluminum trim accents (sport models). However, the difference is slight and it is still a nice (though dark all-black) interior. It is quiet. It is tight.

author: stickguy
text:
The 17 interior is updated I think. And he has cool virtual dash and nice sport seats.

Fun car, but small

author: andres3
text: Doesn't he have the "brown" interior? I think pictures are justified. For sure, the '15 doesn't have virtual dash screen; it has the center dash pop-up IPAD-like screen.

author: stickguy
text:
yes, he has the dark blue over chestnut. Gorgeous combo. premium package, tech/navi, and sport package. Very snazzy, and the virtual cockpit is way cool.

tough to find a twin (heck, it was super hard for him to find in the first place), but this is close. Only difference is his is cosmos blue not black, and he doesn't have LED lights. But the interior is the same!

http://www.audidevon.com/new/Audi/2017-Audi-A3-Devon-PA-00ca747c0a0e0ae75af8e084a16ab81e.htm

author: fintail
text: I saw a new CX-9 while on foot today. What caught my eye was the sharp looking (literally sharp) edge at the top of the grille/front of the hood. Seems kind of dangerous from the suddenly important pedestrian impact point of view.

author: andres3
text: I said "Jesus" when seeing the $44K sticker. I guess Audi doesn't need to under-cut the competition with price anymore.

author: laurasdada
text:
ON the way to work this morn, a new black (rather dirty, maybe dark gray?) Miata RF. Coming up on it from the center lane, it was in the left, in 3/4 view the front fenders reminded me a bit of the C3 Vette. Tiny car, I felt like I was driving an Expediton when I pulled up next to it!

There was a white BMW X1 playing left lane bandit, so the Miata did a nice, quick slingshot around it (even used turn signals!), followed by a silver BMW 435GC and then my XF. A trio of good lookers (and good drivers)! If only I were as handsome as my car...

author: explorerx4
text:
I the parking lot at work, a red Jaguar XE.
In another parking lot, a Jaguar F Pace. It's only second one I've seen and it looked a lot better than the one I saw in Germany.

author: qbrozen
text: Saw a Continental on the Turnpike today. I still think it is a good looking car. Driver thought he was in a bimmer, though, based on how he was tailgating and swerving.

author: stickguy
text: I saw a continental on the garden state Saturday. Not bad looking. I think it had livery plates on it though, but not positive.

author: laurasdada
text: In mybuilding garage this morning, a very new and very red Alfa Giulia. Will investigate this evening! Wonder if it's a surprise gift for me?

author: explorerx4
text:
I saw a new Lincoln Continental the other day, now that I think of it.
Another F Pace today.

author: tjc78
text: I sat in one at the Auto Show. I wouldn't throw it out of my driveway, but I'm a fan of barges.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new pointy nose CX5 on the road - I have to seriously wonder if the new pointed nose has pedestrian safety concerns. Seems iffy.

author: stickguy
text: saw a new CX-9 in my neighborhood today with temp tags. Sharp looking. I think it is a replacement for a 5 or so YO caddy SRX but i didn't get a good look at the driver. Will eventually see it parked when I am out for a walk.

author: berri
text: Wonder if he took a bath on the Caddy trade-in? Could have been worse I suppose if it was a Lincoln.

author: stickguy
text: I was guessing on the year. Just know he has had it as long as I can remember. probably had it long enough that it didn't really matter.

author: andres3
text: The new '17 A4 quattro I just picked up is most definitely longer and harder to park in a tight space than the little A3.

author: stickguy
text: When I sat in one in the showroom, it felt like a very big car to me. Much larger inside than the A3. I know it is longer and wider (not sure how much), but no clue if it drives as big as it feels from inside.

author: andres3
text: I'll be able to give a "full" report on the A4 flagship drive-ability after this upcoming weekend. I did have one before for just a brief drive and it definitely drove lighter and nimbler than it looks, which I agree, it looks and feels big when you sit inside. I heard it is just incrementally bigger than the previous A4, but it is significantly lighter.

author: explorerx4
text: A black and a white Mercedes GLC, and another F Pace.

author: stickguy
text: my neighbor seems to have traded in his MB GLK for a new GLC. Nice looking, but I realized that the profile looks a real lot like our RDX.

author: kyfdx
text: Yeah, I was behind a GLC, today. Very generic. Probably why it's so popular.

author: stickguy
text: I am fine with simple but attractive exterior (as opposed to overwrought and tacky). At least the Benz makes up for it with a really nice interior!

author: explorerx4
text: Spring must be here, I spotted a Tesla Model S today.

author: fintail
text:
Not new, but interesting in a way, I saw 2 current W205 C-class this morning, one a rental, one a dealer loaner.

The loaner was being used by the proprietor of the Chevron I patronize. His normal cars are a very low mileage 2012 IS-F, and a 3 year old GL. The GL had a strut failing, and needed engine mounts, so it gets to spend about a week in the shop. Kind of alarming for such a young vehicle.

author: berri
text: Now I thought all those gas station owners pled poor man not making any money during the gas price run-ups

author: fintail
text:
It might hurt their gas profit margins, but I think the money from snacks and the car wash keeps this one afloat

On the road today, a late model Aston.

author: stickguy
text: another new CRV. really selling like hotcakes it seems.

author: laurasdada
text: Visited Bentley University with my son and ex. yesterday. Of course, we discussed the cost of college these days... Just as we were making a left onto the street that leads to the Bentley entrance, a (gorgeous!!!) black Aston Martin DB11 passed us going in the opposite direction. No doubt this was the car of the president of the University!

author: tjc78
text: Pilots and CRVs everywhere.....

author: Michaell
text:
A few houses down from us live a brother, his sister and a friend. The brother drives a CR-V and the sister had an older Camry.

The sister picked up a new car to replace the Camry - yep, another CR-V (used, same vintage as her brothers).

author: texases
text: Parked next to a Dawn this weekend, in an office parking lot on a Sunday. Wonder why it was there:

author: explorerx4
text: A new Raptor in white.

author: andres3
text:
The B9 A4 makes for a very capable daily driver that gives you luxury and sport at the same time. It is a very capable car.

At the limits, the brakes will eventually overheat and fade a bit, and the OEM tires are not too happy once they get extremely hot. However, for 99.999% of drivers, this won't matter. I doubt A4 buyers will be tracking the A4, and if they do, I recommend brake pad and tire upgrades at a minimum.

93 MPH to hit 2,000 RPM in top gear (7th gear).

Cruise control can be set to 100 MPH and you'll get 26 to 27 MPG.

I personally prefer the interior layout, style, and quality of the B8 an B8.5 S4 more than this newer version in the A4. I feel like the materials quality is down a bit, and I'm not a fan of the I-Pad on the dash look, nor its functionality.

However, the car is definitely more balanced and lighter when pushed around turns.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Pardon me, but I think this car's front end design is hideous. Did they farm out the styling department to a kit car company?

Well. I'm sure the seats are nice.

author: fintail
text: Today: 2x newer style Audi R8 (one at work, someone is doing well), 2x BMW 7er - one a fancy Rolls-Royce Ghost variant (more revenge for 1945 ) , 2x new CRV.

author: kyfdx
text: Nissan Murano Cross Cabrio.

author: Michaell
text:
I was behind one over the weekend - with the top down.

They beat it with an ugly stick until that stick broke, then they got something worse.

But, in a strange way, I can sort of understand the concept here in Colorado - SUV with AWD for winter, top down fun in the summer.

What other cars can do that?

Audi Cabriolets - not much ground clearance
Jeep Wrangler - punishing ride

Murano CC offers the best of both worlds.

author: laurasdada
text: Well, Land Rover must have thought the Murano Cabrio a good idea as they now have one of their own: the Evoque convertible. Saw one from a distance yesterday.

author: texases
text: Even more general - what other drop tops can comfortably fit 4 adults?

author: kyfdx
text: Well... they are pretty famous for over-the-top ostentation (is that a word?).

author: kyfdx
text: Mercedes S-Class?

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Are you recovered yet?

author: kyfdx
text: Immediately afterward, a BMW i3 crossed in front of me, and looked like an Aston Martin, in comparison.

author: texases
text: I've seen a few more of the i3, but still looks goofy, to me. The new Bolt is much better, IMO:

author: kyfdx
text: The Bolt and Volt are decent looking vehicles.

author: texases
text: Two new ones: one rare, a Levante, one common, a Mustang GT. The thing with this (and many other) Mustangs was a TERRIBLE exhaust system. Loud, but not in any good way. Sounded like a couple of Civics with cheap 'fart can' mufflers. Obnoxious just keeping up with traffic. Why????

author: PF_Flyer
text: Some of the items that wind up on cars are head-scratchers for sure

author: ab348
text: Sure it was a Mustang GT and not an Ecoboost 4-banger?

author: texases
text:
It was a GT, said so right between the taillights! It was so loud, it made me wonder if the owner had removed the cats.

And it's not only Mustangs, a number of Challengers I come across have super loud exhausts, including one of my neighbors I'm surprised I see/hear so few Camaros with loud pipes.

author: kyfdx
text: I had a Challenger go past me on I-75.. Every 20 seconds or so, he would punch the throttle, even though there was no place to go.. vroom.. vroom, vroom.. did it about 20 times. Seems like that would get boring.

author: explorerx4
text: Moved.

author: stickguy
text: GM did a few of those. I think based on the Firebird. Though likely there was a Camaro variant too.

author: fintail
text: Saw an AMG GT today.

author: jpp75
text: I saw a Bolt today in San Francisco. I don't care for the looks of it personally.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: It's awkward-looking but not really offensive.

author: jpp75
text: That's actually a perfect description.

author: texases
text: Do folks prefer the looks of the Bolt or the i3?

author: kyfdx
text:
I think the Bolt looks like a normal car.. The i3, not so much.

Not sure which I like less, though.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Just me personally, I'd feel like a dork driving an i3---like I was on a Segway or driving a Smart car wearing clothes from LL Bean. The Bolt is no beauty but it's a little more "normal" looking.

author: laurasdada
text: So, Mr._S, the Bolt, you ain't a beauty, but, hey, you're all right?

author: fintail
text: Saw a Bentayga on the road today. The perfect car if you live in France - in 1788.

author: andres3
text: Too bad Bugatti doesn't disclose how expensive it is to go 200+ MPH, and how quickly a tank of fuel disappears while doing that exercise.

author: fintail
text: Saw another Bentayga today.

author: PF_Flyer
text: Driving along withe a Tesla Model S. First one I've seen here in central PA, and it was silver, first one I've seen that wasn't black

author: fintail
text: Saw a red new E300 today, loaded with drivers assist and full LED gauges. The high option cars are uncommon, especially in an odd color.

author: ab348
text: In the showroom of the dealer where I bought my ATS, a 2017 Camaro 50th Anniversary edition priced at a cool $60K Cdn. Strangely for a 50th anniversary there is no gold anywhere I saw. Based on a SS convertible, it was metallic gray with a black convertible top and black interior, lots of special badges and embroidery. The option package is a $7400 option. Left me rather cold like all Camaros currently do.

author: explorerx4
text: A new Lacrosse on the way back from the airport. Not so sure about the grille, but the rest of it looks good.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: The Lacrosse gets pretty good reviews but if you pack it up with AWD, driver assist, special wheels and suspension, and all the comfort goodies, you can break the $50K barrier. Seems like the lower end is the better buy (only has one engine option).

author: ab348
text: I hear the bigger wheels/sport suspension on the Lacrosse really mess up the ride too.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Yep, those 20" wheels are going to hammer you.

author: andres3
text:
Yesterday I saw a black VW Passat 3.6 SE. I have to think these big engine 3.6 V6 Passat's are even a lot more rare than a recent model V6 Accord.

I bet the 3.6 Passat is a compelling package at its price point, but greenies don't want V6's anymore.

author: iluvmysephia1
text:
I spotted a 2017 Toyota Yaris iA in a muted, earthtone color, on 135th heading towards I-35 Olathe. I love that car! The gaping maw, in real life, just comes off as cute.

Great Mazda mechanicals. To get the automatic in this iA would be silly. Go for the manual, for sure for sure!

author: ab348
text:
On Wednesday I was at my GM dealer and got to sit in a new Camaro SS with the 50th Anniversary package. First time I sat in one of the current-gen Camaros and visibility is as bad as you hear. However even though the dash looks a lot like the previous-gen model, up close it looks a lot better with better materials and design. The seats in this one were a subtle 2-tone black and dark gray leather with red stitching. A bit too understated for my tastes but not awful. It was painted a dark metallic gray which again was understated but under the showroom lights all the angles and bodylines really made it look good.

They had another SS there in black, which didn't look as good to me on the outside, but which had red inserts in the seats and door panels. With a different exterior color that one might have been really handsome.

author: berri
text: Visibility - how about the basics of getting in and out of it

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Well just plan your day so as to limit the number of times you have to exit. You could, for instance, only eat from drive-ins, use automatic car washes without having the interior cleaned, and I think Walgreen's has curbside service now. With a reclining seat and some necessities for nature's call, I don't see why you'd even have to leave that car for 24 hours.

author: fintail
text: Saw an Alfa Giulia and a MB C43.

author: stickguy
text: A few new Ioniqs. Look sharp in person. I like them. also a couple new Tiquans. Look so much bigger than the old model (which makes sense, since it is!) but very attractive, classy styling. Sadly that sticks out now in a sea of overwrought, Japanese oragami styling.

author: kyfdx
text: The new Tiguan is out? Didn't know that, and I was at a VW dealership, last week.

author: explorerx4
text: The local dealer VW had a big ad in the paper yesterday saying all 2015 diesels are on sale.

author: kyfdx
text: Yeah, that's why I was there, last week.

author: kyfdx
text: Are you sure that wasn't the new Atlas?

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: My friends went to check out one of those 2015 VW diesels--the pricing was RIDICULOUS. They passed. Apparently the wagons are a hot ticket item.

author: Michaell
text: There was an Atlas and the new Tiguan at the Denver Auto Show. The Tiguan is certainly bigger than the previous version, but the Atlas is the size of a Pilot or Explorer.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: From photos, the Atlas looks rather blah. Late to the game, I would say.

author: stickguy
text: Well, it was in Ireland, so I assume it just arrived there first. Pretty sure it was a Tiguan based on the size. An Atlas really would have looked out of place (being so huge).

author: kyfdx
text: Ah... I thought of that, after I posted.

author: fintail
text: Saw a Bentayga today, let them eat cake.

author: laurasdada
text: Saw my first Bentayga in the wild, too. To each, but so many better ways to spend $200+k.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Did you read that Car and Driver article about the guy in the UK that has driven his Lamborghini Murcilago 250,000 miles? Total cost to get that far----$640,000 (including depreciation, gas@ $6 a gallon, insurance, an accident, track time, etc). Still, that does make one's socks roll up and down.....

I especially liked the cost of headlights---$7700 apiece, and total cost of feul @ $162,000.

author: stickguy
text: If he had bought a pedestrian car, say an S class MB, or big engined BMW coupe, would not have been that much lower.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: You mean like an S65 AMG or some such? Yeah, it's going to cost you a lot to get to 250,000 on one of those as well. Of course fuel in the USA is much cheaper than UK, so that will cut costs considerably, and I would hope that an MB or BMW is at least somewhat more reliable than a Lambo.

author: fintail
text: I think a W221 or newer S65 would be worlds better for high mileages than a W220S65. Maintenance will still be enormous, but it shouldn't have constant system failures.

author: andres3
text:
There isn't much data on supercar reliability is there? CR only reports if they get enough responses, so I never do hear much about Lambo, Ferrari, or other such ultra-expensive sports cars.

Part of the problem is many of the owners probably don't daily drive them. I think the R8 was really the first daily drive-able supercar. I suppose there are some that did so with the Acura NSX.

I know of a couple people racking up major miles on their R8's; I'll have to ask them about any unexpected repairs outside of normal maintenance.

I do know they seem to be holding their value really well.

I think a statistic that tracks % of MSRP it typically takes to reach 250,000 miles would be a great data point for consumers. After all, even a $15,000 Corolla probably takes a fair percentage of its original MSRP to get there.

author: fushigi
text:
The cheapest new Corolla is $21,665. It gets a city/highway combined of 30MPG so 8,333 gallons to drive a quarter million miles. At $2.50/gallon that's almost another $21K in fuel. BTW it only has a 13.2 gallon tank so assuming you used 90% of the tank before filling up you'd have 701 stops for fuel.

Add your other operating expenses & you'd be well over MSRP again in operating costs. Probably 5 sets of tires, numerous oil changes, a few brake jobs, etc.

author: kyfdx
text: At 250K miles, depreciation is 99%, no matter what the car. That's pretty brutal when you start out over $200K

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Unless it's a pickup truck, it seems. You can sell someone a pickup no matter how many miles on it.

author: explorerx4
text:
In the parking lot at work, a white Honda Accord coupe and a Mercedes GLK.
The GLK has got to be one of the ugliest Mercedes ever designed, although there was that C class with the hatch that was no prize either.

author: qbrozen
text:
I always liked the GLK design.

And certainly you are forgetting the current GLC coupe for the ugly Benz award.

author: fintail
text: GLK was at least unique, and had a Tonka like charm to it. GLC coupe is a BMW copy, and not in a good way. Kind of funny, as the normal GLC is also quite decent, somewhat close to a lifted C wagon.

author: tifighter
text: My wife loved the GLK. Especially in red. She still points them out on the road, and frowns on the GLC.

author: fintail
text: Saw a C cabrio on the road today, still pretty uncommon.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new E wagon at the MB dealer this morning, along with some usual exotica - S65 cabrio, AMG GT. Most amusing was a C-cabrio that stickered for 60K on the nose, not a penny more or less.

author: laurasdada
text: Haven't seen one, but apparently a Jaguar XF Shooting SportBrake is in the works! Bound for Los Estados Unidos?

author: kyfdx
text:
Mercedes AMG GT S.. with temporary tags.

Impressive looking. And, not as expensive as I would have guessed.

author: fintail
text: Not brand new, but I talked to the guy who lives in my building and has an F-Pace. He's very pleased with it, no issues.

author: fintail
text:
I expected something a little more daring for the new Tesla pickup:



(joke from my brother, who parked his S10 at the newly installed charging stations in the small town where he lives. No doubt catering to travelers, I seriously doubt anyone who lives there drives a Tesla).

author: qbrozen
text: What we need is a video of the owner trying to insert the plug into his gas filler neck

author: stickguy
text: Another new pilot in my neighborhood. In the very common dark gray. Next door to someone else that bough one, but blue. There are at least 2 others in my neighborhood that I know of

author: andres3
text: There's a E55 AMG on my street, but I didn't photo it. However, I did photo these Benz's:

author: fintail
text: 250SE cabrio would be model years 1966-68, I think. Fairly desirable car, I don't know about those grille badges, but probably just a well-loved car. The SL has side markers, so likely 1968+, probably a 280SL.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Good lord! Who tinted the windows? Well, easily corrected at least.

author: ab348
text: A 250SL that I really liked, a nice preserved but unrestored car (but as usual was picked to death by the aficionados) sold last week on BaT for $66K. Yikes.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
That's a risky purchase sight unseen. They are very rust-prone and a devil to put right. But top-notch show quality ones are in the 130K range now. Last year I saw the best one in the world, E-V-E-R, and it sold quickly at $145K and probably could be flipped for another $10K.

People will pay for the very best.

Personally I like the early 230SLs with manual transmission. Much closer to what we might call "a sports car".

author: fintail
text: I think I'd rather have the cabrio. It's basically a fintail, so I would be familiar with it, and it has a timeless class to it that few cars can match. Good solid long term values on those, too (where Pagodas have tripled in 20 years).

author: tifighter
text: I went to high school with a kid that had a 230SL with the 4 speed manual. White. Hand me down from the parents. Early nineties. Extra cringe-worthy now.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Which? The car or the kid?

author: berri
text: I like that rather rich looking sort of cream color and it actually stands out as a MB. That's why I like Fin's Fintail too.

author: fintail
text: A lot of earlier W113s were white on blue or white on red. White was big for MB then. I've seen an early 230SL in the same color as my fintail.

author: laurasdada
text: At the Acura dealer, on my "Automile," a new, white NSX.

author: fintail
text: Saw a white NSX in traffic today, also a new silver C63

author: ab348
text: Saw a Tesla Model X on the road yesterday, a first for me in these parts. Teslas are pretty thin on the ground here anyway but I have seen a few sedans over the last couple of years. I never knew they even made a SUV-type vehicle. Wasn't nearly as good-looking as the sedan to me, looked rather turtle-ish.

author: fintail
text: I call the Tesla design language "egg". I wish I didn't see so many of them, I probably see 10 Model X a day now. Worst use of private vehicle tax incentives ever.

author: kyfdx
text: Mercedes E550 convertible... in red, with the top down.

author: andres3
text: In strong competition for the Cash4Clunkers debacle I'm sure. Arguable which one was a greater waste. I'll go with your call only because at least the Cash4Clunkers horrible idea helped some of the masses in general, while Tesla's are aimed at the 1%. Maybe top 5% given the incentives.

author: andres3
text:
Saw a large bunch of Dodge Viper ACR's at the local Cars N' Coffee Saturday. Apparently they have a Southern CA club. Audi made the strongest showing though, with RS7, RS4, S6, Allroad, A4, S3, A3, TT, and of course my TTS all represented.

The sponsoring "car wrap" company had one of those 200+ MPH Bugatti's being wrapped in a combo of blue and very reflective polished aluminum/chrome look.

author: qbrozen
text: I wonder what happens to vinyl wrap at 200mph

author: fintail
text:
The thing that gets me about C4C is that some nice old cars (quite a few MB 124/126/140, I think) were lost, but hopefully were parted out before they were crushed. It also inflated used car values, at least for a time.

The socio-economic part of the Tesla break is what I find cringeworthy, yes. How there is no MSRP cap is both amazing and not surprising at the same time.

author: berri
text: Tesla and Tesla stock = Bubble???

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Can't make sense out of Tesla---don't try.

author: kyfdx
text: I wouldn't bet against the stock. Not as long as they have no trouble raising all the money they need. Doesn't matter if you are right, if everyone else keeps buying.

author: berri
text: Eventually someone gets caught holding the bubble before it bursts. But you can't time that and markets often don't seem to be rational.

author: Michaell
text: Not having done any research on this, Tesla to me seems similar to the internet bubble of the late 90's. Irrational market values for a company that hasn't turned a profit, and survives due to government largesse.

author: ab348
text: I have to think a few of the top dogs at Tesla are having one heckuva good time these days.

author: berri
text: I think Tesla may have some cash flow issues, which if true can be dangerous.

author: kyfdx
text:
They do burn a lot of cash.. but, so far, they have no problem selling more debt or equity in capital markets. So, no cash flow issues, per se.

I am amazed at the number of cars they've been able to produce and sell. How many people have started a car company in the last 50 years and sold even 20K vehicles?

author: andres3
text:
How many companies have crashed and burned in just the last 17 years trying to make cars for a living?

I know GM was forced to close down a few brands in 2008/2009.

author: texases
text: It seems like Tesla's hope for long term survival is large sales of the upcoming Tesla 3. But now everyone's trying to get into that niche ($35k, 200+ miles range). Given Tesla's poor quality record on the X (especially), I'd much rather buy an EV from a known brand that I can bet will be around years hence.

author: kyfdx
text:
I wouldn't buy a Tesla or invest in the stock.

But, I wouldn't short it, either.

author: fintail
text: Saw my first Lexus LC on the road today, kind of striking from some angles, but the front is still ghastly to me. Just like a Tesla, not how I'd blow through 100K.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Cant' think of one that started 1967 on up and reached that production level. Delorean never made it to 20,000, nor did Bricklin. In the 1950s, there were certainly new car companies that exceeded 20,000, like Lotus and Subaru.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I read somewhere that about 25% of shareholders are holding short.

author: kyfdx
text:
Funny about shorts.. I heard on CNBC that so many Sears (SHLD) shares were shorted, that some of the shares would have to be borrowed from ESL and Fairholme, that together own over 50% of the company.

When the stock starts up, all that short covering sometimes exaggerates the move upward. It's a dangerous game.

author: fintail
text:
I wonder if the perpetual motion machine mouth of inaccuracies of 45 will impact the new cars we see

Hopefully not. Unbelievable.

author: berri
text: Hey, from the video coverage of the trip, maybe the issue is that the old man ain't getting any

author: fintail
text:
Not even that inherited fortune might be enough anymore.

Not many new Chevies in Germany, but plenty of Fords and Opels, and American made German brands. Hmmm

author: ab348
text: Geez, I come here to get away from the constant barrage about Trump online elsewhere....

author: kyfdx
text:
Good point..

Let's can the political talk, or you'll be sentenced to watching cable news for the rest of the weekend.

author: fintail
text: I'd say it is potentially relevant to the auto market, especially upcoming models, but if those who shall not be offended are offended, then I'll refrain with unpleasant realities

author: kyfdx
text: Thanks..

author: stickguy
text: stopped at Volvo dealer with my daughter today. Played with an S90. She was in love with the giant iPad center screen. Was really quite cool.

author: qbrozen
text: Very very expensive way to obtain an ipad. ;b

author: fintail
text: Saw a new hockey stick 5er in traffic today, another product made by an industrial sector that produces material strongly desired by nearly every market

author: Michaell
text: I spotted a new Lexus LC500 last week. Very menacing looking, even in white.

author: tlong
text: I concur about the current Lexus styling (especially front) to be ghastly. I never thought I'd long for the days of bland Lexi.

author: fintail
text: LC doesn't irk me form the side, but the front is a bit flamboyant for my taste.

author: explorerx4
text:
Next door in the driveway. A sliver 3 series coupe, pretty sure an M3(badge on the front fender?).
Looks really good, but nothing over the top about the styling.
It has some kind of wording on the rocker area just ahead of the rear wheels.

author: kyfdx
text:
I bet it's a regular 3-Series with "performance" parts. That's where I've seen that lettering.

M3s have louvered grills on the fenders.

author: texases
text: And a coupe would be an M4 if new.

author: fintail
text:
Took a quick stop at the MB dealer today to see if there was anything odd. Not much, but did see an AMG GT roadster, cool car. Also a couple S cabrios. Used section had maybe 20 more basic spec 2016 C-class, retired loaners or maybe off lease/ex rental. Kind of an odd pile, so many of them. Oddball on the used lot was a 2004 SL600 in Mars Red.

Porsche dealer had a Boxster at almost 100K, gotta love the options.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Porsche is masterful at the Options List.

author: ab348
text: In traffic today, carrying two older ladies turning into a shopping mall, a new M-B C450 with AMG badges. Not sure what is under the hood since I can't actually find it on M-B Canada's site. Probably safe to assume that throttle pedal has never been opened beyond about 10%.

author: fintail
text: I think C450 is a 2016-only model car, now replaced by the C43. MB has become a little schizo with their naming. It's a TT V6 with ~360hp, and has some AMG bits.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new style Rolls-Royce coupe today, black and silver. I hope it wasn't brand new (it was unplated), as the black paint had swirl marks.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Maserati whizzed past me...I have a bit of trouble differentiating the new models...but I sure wish my car sounded like that, instead of like a can of angry gnats.

author: Michaell
text:
@jpp5862 and I visited the Fiat / Alfa / Maserati dealer a few months back. GM fired up the Levante (SUV) in the showroom and demonstrated the two stage exhaust. Normal sounds pretty good, but the 'sport' mode (or whatever they called it) was simply amazing.

Would scare all the other mommy-bloggers that are in line to pick up the kids from the private school.

author: andres3
text: Saw a new-looking 911 with a big wing and the personalized plate reading "SLOW911" I had to smile, as I noticed the internal cross bracing roll cage and Recaro Racing seats. I wonder who has "FAST911" on their plate.

author: ab348
text: Maseratis these days have the best exhaust note around. Not so sure about the rest of the car though.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: They should charge $80,000 for the exhaust system and give you the car for free.

author: fintail
text: I thought that was the point - you're buying a powertrain. I don't know if they have the best image though, the noise seems to bring out the worst in people. Nothing worse than a late model GT revving and weaving in and out of traffic, without signal of course,

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I sort of expect them to behave that way. If I see a Prius doing that, then I'm really frightened.

author: fintail
text: Saw a white Atlas on the road today, it is big and butch, should attract the target demographic for it. Also not brand new but current: S65 AMG, C63 AMG, and I think a C43 AMG.

author: andres3
text: What's with all the AMG's in Seattle? I guess you need the HP to pass all those rolling blockades of Prius you mention all the time.

author: fintail
text: Lots of idle money, and some local demographics who want the most expensive version of any model, no matter what it is. Seems kind of sad for a tuned V12 to idle between lights while going from the gallery mall to the Whole Foods.

author: andres3
text: I think it would be a more disturbing offense if one of those dawdling on-ramp mergerers was an AMG model that couldn't find it in their skill set to be going more than 40 MPH at the top of the on-ramp.

author: fintail
text:
I never really see that, it's the hybrid and Lexus crowd who dawdles on on-ramps - which amuses me, as many Lexus may be somewhat dull, but not really underpowered. The tuned models are often driven with a degree of oblivion, probably because the drivers know they are untouchable on a socio-economic basis.

Saw a facelift SL on the road today

author: stickguy
text: New body style MB C43 AMG. Looked good in white.

author: fintail
text: On the same note, I got behind a C63S AMG convertible today. Black wheels not in good taste IMO, and the driver was more concerned about their hair than driving, given their no-signal lane change. Welcome to Bellevue!

author: explorerx4
text: In the parking lot at work, a doppelganger to my Fusion, but has the 2.0 engine.

author: stickguy
text: not sure how new both were, but at Shop Rite today, it was M day. Parked near each other, an M4 convertible (dark gray over light gray, gorgeous), and an M6 convertible (white over red, also attractive). Interesting is that both were just out in the lot unattended, and both were left with the tops down!

author: Michaell
text: I've seen a couple of M4's recently, one in that loud yellow-green color. One coupe, on the power hardtop.

author: tjc78
text: First new Atlas at Wawa tonight.  Silver, looked like a base model (wheels were 16 or 17s). I don't mind the styling (or lack of).  I think it will sell pretty well.

author: fintail
text: Saw a Ferrari F12 on the road, it's big. Also surprisingly not driven by the 17 year old devilspawn of a newly arrived money laundering investor, but by a typical middle aged guy.

author: stickguy
text: saw a nice new red Ferrari something driving today. Probably because I was just down the street from the Ferrari/Masserati dealer!

author: berri
text: I think the VW Atlas looks better in person than in pictures. I was pleasantly surprised, but am leery of first year models.

author: fintail
text: Odd one on the highway this evening, a white Atlas with Michigan manufacturer plates.

author: stickguy
text: so many CRVs. they are everywhere.

author: explorerx4
text:
In one of the neighbor's driveway over the weekend, a blue TLX with some really nice wheels.
Had a dealer plate.

author: texases
text:
I've seen maybe one new Giulia, now I know why:
http://jalopnik.com/no-one-wants-to-buy-an-alfa-romeo-giulia-1796219373
No Alfa dealer in Dallas proper, have to go quite a ways for one...

author: fintail
text: Saw a Nissan Micra today, BC plates, suspected rental.

author: andres3
text: I think you'd have to have been living under a rock for the past 35 years to want one of those at the prices they ask for them.

author: fintail
text: A Quadrifoglio can be loaded up to insane levels - if you choose a lot including fancy seats and brakes, you're at 90K MSRP - with fees and tax, that'll be 100K in my area. No doubt they don't sell for that, but still, it will scare people off as much as reliability concerns. It'll be interesting to see what happens when leases are ending, if the cars are solid, then maybe some deals.

author: fintail
text: On the road today: 2x AMG GT, Lexus LC pulling into one of the fancier money launderer condo buildings.

author: explorerx4
text: In the parking lot at work, a new white Acadia and a black Durango.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Audi A3 e-Tron. I know they've been a modest success in the U.S. but I rarely see them.

author: fintail
text: 2x CT6 and an electric Golf.

author: fintail
text: Stopped by the Alfa dealer today on a whim. I was in the fintail, so that went over well - a couple salesmen hopped out to look at it. They had a Quadrifoglio in the showroom, 87K MSRP + 10K ADM (!) - Sold (!!). They had a dozen normal Giulias, under 50K. Not a bad looking car.

author: berri
text: Curious Fin, was it a stand alone Alfa dealer, an Alfa-Fiat, or a multi-brand dealership carrying the Alfa's?

author: fintail
text: Alfa-Fiat-Maserati

author: berri
text: Ah, forgot about the Maserati tie. I guess the expensive parts of the Seattle area can handle on of those type dealerships.

author: ab348
text: Out in the Cutlass this afternoon and got behind a Rolls-Royce Ghost. black in color. Never knew there was one of those in town. It had privacy curtains with nice little pleats on the rear window. Kind of unimpressive from the rear view though.

author: andres3
text: Are there any "lifted" Outbacks or Foresters in Seattle?

author: Michaell
text:
You mean, like a lift kit you see for other SUVs?

I've not seen any here in Denver, but have actually seen 'slammed' (lowered) Foresters on a couple of occasions. Seems to defy the purpose of the vehicle, but to each their own.

author: fintail
text:
I am certain I have seen a lifted Forester, and I think a couple generations back Outback could be had with greater ground clearance than current models.

Lowered ones are much more common. If you wear a sideways flat brim cap and have a vape pen always in your hand or mouth, I have a car for you.

author: fintail
text: Not the newest thing, but I saw a Buick Cascada today. Kind of odd looking from the front, like the windshield isn't tall enough.

author: andres3
text:
What's a Buick Cascada? Shows the marketing isn't very strong on that one.

I know all about the real people not actors awards that Chevy wins though. Great initial quality; meaning it isn't junk already when it leaves the factory floor.

Jaguar and Alfa seem to have a lot of commercials on TV lately.

author: Michaell
text: The Cascada is an Opel-derived convertible. 1.6T engine with something like 197HP.

author: fintail
text: On the road today - pretty blue C43 or C63, crawling on 405 as I shot past in the fintail; white S550 cabrio going slow, top up on a sunny day, experienced driver and passenger; new CRV that from a distance at rear I thought was a Misubishi due to the somewhat different styling.

author: andres3
text: You want a slow on-ramp merger, take a look at the White Corolla CE that was in front of me Sunday afternoon on the 8W-I15N transition. I know that car is the "slow" model, but goodness gracious. Even my father commented that he was surprised I didn't honk at them. They deserve a battering ram taking them off the road.

author: fintail
text: Saw a blue Giulia on the road today, not a high spec one.

author: fintail
text: Got behind a Range Rover Sport SVR today. Pretty flamboyant exhaust note, and driven as one would expect, without turn signals - those are for plebes, and you don't make to SVR level by following rules.

author: fintail
text:
Belle Epoque day in Bellevue.

S63 coupe - not brand new, but unusual enough to be notable

S600 Maybach

Rolls-Royce new style convertible (I think the name is "Silver Spoon" )

All were white.

author: kyfdx
text: Audi A5 SportBack with temporary tags

author: Michaell
text: Better or worse looking that the BMW 4-series?

author: kyfdx
text: Tough call. I like it a lot

author: tlong
text:
Nowadays >90% of the cars on the road are black, white, or some variant of silver/grey.
Occasional smatterings of red.

In Europe it is more colorful, and in the 70's here it was more groovy.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Scary depreciation on those Maybachs---you can pick one up now for a fraction of MSRP.

author: fintail
text: I'd expect the current one to depreciate like an S-class, which means quickly. This is the new Maybach, only on the road for about a year or so here, which is more of a submodel of the S600, and has a distinct black money air to it. The prior Maybach 57/62 was a MB W220 with thrice the complexity and 4x the price. They remain surprisingly expensive on the used market given their insane running costs and now-dated styling.

author: fintail
text:
For German cars in this market, black and white are typically the "free" colors, with others commanding a slight surcharge. I think some other makers do that too. Beigegrey is perfect for the Camrollaruis driver, and the makers know it. Non-enthusiasts don't complain about the dearth of color options - if they did, things would change.

Inexpensive cars in Europe seem to be more prone to reds, yellows, and similar than here.

author: tlong
text: But some makes even charge for things like pearl white. Sort of like the airlines, give some minimum base and then monetize as many extras as possible. BMW has been the king of that for many years.

author: fintail
text: Pearl white must be difficult to apply - MB doesn't just charge a premium for it, but often double the premium for a normal optional color. Germans know how to play the option profit margin game. I think Porsche is the winner, where it is not unknown for a car to have options approaching the base MSRP.

author: texases
text: Anything other than straight regular paint (no pearl, no metallic) often gets a premium added.

author: ab348
text: In Canada, Cadillac charges extra for any paint color other than silver or plain black. The red that I have, along with pearl white, goes for $1395, while all other paint colors are a $900 charge. Seems a bit much.

author: berri
text: So we're heading back to the model T days

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Oh, that's right I forgot. They discontinued it in 2013 and brought the corpse back for another funeral.

author: fintail
text: New one, at half the price, seems to be selling at more than twice the rate of the old one. Maybe some different economic realities between 2004 and today, and the lower price helps too. It's more of a niche now, a superdeluxe S600. I doubt many buyers know anything about the name.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Yep, it's "only" $189,000 now. It's a lavish version of the S600, and I think stretched out a bit---even at that price, seems a screaming bargain next to a Rolls Phantom.

author: fintail
text:
I think that's one area where Maybach models and S-class coupe are playing now - it's like 80% of a Bentley or Rolls-Royce for half or less of the cost.

Heck, the Maybach is cheap even compared to the oh so basic Ghost, which itself shares more than a couple bits with the F01 7er.

author: fintail
text: On the road today: Maserati Levante and new style Panamera.

author: tlong
text: Driving through Beverly Hills yesterday on the way to the Hollywood Bowl. Saw a car from a distance, I believe it was a Benz but could have been something else. It was parked on a sidestreet we could see from the red light we were sitting at. It was fully silver chromed! I wish I had gotten a better look. You definitely would stand out with that one.

author: fintail
text: That kind of thing is big among the buy-your-way-in set from a couple areas, I think. With the amount of glare it could produce, I am surprised it is legal. Then again, the same license that you get in a Corolla lets you drive a Veyron or a 42' motorhome, so I guess it works.

author: kyfdx
text: Mercedes E550 Coupe, with the windows down. Nice!

author: texases
text: That's a silver Mylar-type wrap. There have been posts where folks talk about 'gold' cars, when it's just a plastic film wrap.

author: kyfdx
text: A few years back, we saw fully "chromed" vehicles. It was a paint job, not a wrap. No idea how they did it. Not a great look.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new NSX on the road today, and a C cabrio.

author: laurasdada
text: At a Cars and Coffee event this morning, local billionaire's Lexus dealer I saw everything!

author: ab348
text: Saw my first VW Atlas up close. Actually a very nice looking rig. I was surprised I liked it as much as I did given that it is a rather large beast. It was painted a sparkly metallic gray with a hint of blue, which may have had something to do with that. It seems to be getting decent reviews. The one I saw had the 235HP Turbo 4, which doesn't seem a lot to push around a 4000lb vehicle, but I assume it's more than adequate.

author: texases
text: I followed two Tesla X in today, side by side. Looks kinda dumpy to me. And one already had a ding in the rear hatch, and its spoiler wasn't all the way up or down. Oops...

author: kyfdx
text: I agree... not sure the proportions/styling of the S translate down to the new 3 model, either. It's not too pretty.

author: fintail
text: The X looks like an egg to me. In my area, it seems to attract the Stepfordian set who might choose anything between a RX and a Range Rover.

author: laurasdada
text: A BMW i8 in the garage I parked in pre-Moody Blues concert. Yes, I am old. And, I think I want an i8. Wonder if I can get in and out gracefully? Likely, I'd hit my head on the scissor doors each and every time.

author: fintail
text: Bike day - saw something that looked like one of those Can-Am wheeled snowmobiles in the front, and maxi-scooter in the back, 3 wheeler, weird. Someone at work has shown up with a KTM Duke 390, which is a sweet little bike.

author: kyfdx
text:
Was it a Slingshot?

http://www.polaris.com/en-us/slingshot

author: fintail
text: Nope. Single seat, seating like a big scooter, but two larger wheels in front. Front of a Can-Am, rear of a maxi-scooter.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I saw a new compact SUV I couldn't identify--went by too quickly. I wouldn't call it attractive. It had two bulbous fender bumps rising from the back end.

author: kyfdx
text: Toyota has a new one.. C-HR?

author: texases
text: Not a Piaggio?

author: fintail
text: Nope, not an mp3 or similar. It was like rear section of that (or a Burgman etc) but with a more aggressive Can-Am front end. I will have to do some nosing around.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: That's it ! What do you guys think? Not sure if I could get used to it...

author: andres3
text:
Someone in the club just traded in their black RS 5 for a new white TTRS. 400 HP and at least a couple linebackers lighter, yeah, she's gonna enjoy it.

I'm sort of jealous. I like the the mechanical rear wing on my TTS to the bigger fixed wing on the TTRS. I like my rear bumper and exhaust layout/diffuser more too. Front ends looks are a tie in my opinion. However, the TTRS gets 25% more cylinders and size, with 33% more power (stock), probably only about 15-20% heavier engine too; so great numbers. Most importantly, I do believe it still gets an adjustable suspension to match mine, but also adds a tall 7th gear to the DSG transmission (mine only has a measly 6; small weight benefit though) to make it the superior daily driver down a high speed freeway. Of course, all these things are not free.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Is your engine really wound up at highway speeds?

author: texases
text: That C-HR is a mess! And think of the (lack of) visibility to the rear. Add on the small room inside resulting from the 'styling'. Next best thing to a Juke.

author: kyfdx
text: It's Toyota's version of the Nissan Puke. Actually, those don't bother me as much as they used to. Either I'm getting used to them, or that's the way the whole Asian market looks are heading.

author: andres3
text: Not posted limit speeds, but at speeds I like to travel and cruise at, yes. Not quite Miata-like, but I'm pushing 3K RPM at about 76 MPH. Funny the new '17 A4's are barely idling at 80 MPH in 7th.

author: stickguy
text: It's uglier in person

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: That is a bit tight for your type of car. Even the little 1.6L Mini is only turning 3000 rpm at 72 mph.

author: fintail
text:
Don't let overdone bad styling become normal over time. If it was bad then, it is bad even if you get used to it. Now we just have slashes and faux aggression to mask the beige. I still like how the C-HR isn't just a fake off-roader like a CUV, it is a fake CUV. And the demographic will eat it up.

TTRS doesn't have standard turn signals, right? I am certain A/S/RS5 models don't include them

author: imidazol97
text:
Between that CHR and the Civic, I don't want to hear about Aztek again.
Looks like they took the Civic's taillights... The front is not as bad as many of the toyota line, in my eyes.

Beauty is in the eye of the beholder.

author: tjc78
text: The Aztec is still worse IMO, however this is right up there

author: imidazol97
text: LOL.

author: tlong
text: Boy Toyota is swinging for the fences with their weird styling these days. And even Lexus. Only the Corolla looks normal - for now.

author: tifighter
text: I saw a TON of these new Toyotas on the ground in Paris and Zurich two weeks ago.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I suppose...if you are a male banana slug and see a female one.

author: berri
text: Americans are into to too much video games and it has moved to car design...

author: fintail
text: It's not just Americans. This is for people who hate cars and hate driving, but want to appear as dynamic and aggressive. It's a cultural universal.

author: stickguy
text:
new Accord released. I like the design, from what you see in the pictures, especially the interior. but as always, need to see in the flesh (metal and plastic?) to know for sure! At least the equipment levels and driving dynamics (and powertrains) sound top notch. I am really interested in this one. Could be a perfect option for us if I want to go new but not lease.

http://www.motortrend.com/cars/honda/accord/2018/2018-honda-accord-first-look-lower-wider-shorter/

author: tjc78
text: The front is just awful, IMO. The rest I could live with and the interior looks really nice. I like how Honda kept knobs for HVAC and Volume.

author: berri
text: I noticed the new Accord will have about an inch lower seating height like the new Camry. I wonder how that will go over with the aging new car buyer demographic? May not be a big deal in reality, but I'm curious given the increase in crossover sales because among several factors, new car buyers like a higher seating position.

author: fushigi
text:
What's the square in the middle of the front end below the bumper? Really detracts in the photos for me, though I'm sure it probably won't so much in person.

I really don't like screens that look like they pop up. Just seems like it was tacked on at the last moment. Obviously it wasn't but that kind of placement makes it look like it was. And there doesn't look to be any glare shielding.

Power numbers seem fine; being a little lighter should make up for the loss in HP in the 2.0t. But a 10 speed transmission? I can't imagine the gear hunting it might do. Why not just go CVT at that point?

Does anyone else wonder if dealers will stock all 15 trims?

author: stickguy
text:
Hard to tell about that square, but it could be for mounting a license plate, or something to do with the Honda Sensing features. Though that could be a problem, once you mount a front plate. Hard to tell how open the lower grill is. If totally, could be an issue. They had that problem on the 2005 vintage Odyssey for a few years, and condensers were taking a lot of rock hits. there was a whole DIY series floating around for adding mesh to protect the components.

I always need to see a car in person to really tell about these little details.

author: andres3
text: The under-door LED projectors that illuminate "quattro or the 4-rings" onto the ground surface seems to be a more popular option to pay for in Southern CA RS models. However, I will say in Southern CA Audi drivers do use their signals. Must be a regional thing!

author: andres3
text: CVT has proven unreliable thus far pretty much across the board. They are nosier and tend to drone like an aftermarket coffee can exhaust. Anything else, in my opinion, is an improvement.

author: fushigi
text: Ah, unreliable & noisy. That explains why Honda uses CVTs in the Civic, current Accord, Fit, HR-V, and CR-V.

author: andres3
text: Well, the jury's still out on Honda's versions, started no sooner than 2013, so maximum a 4 year window; not long enough to make a judgement.

author: tlong
text: Boy Toyota is swinging for the fences with their weird styling these days. And even Lexus. Only the Corolla looks normal - for now.

author: fintail
text: Saw a MB E43 in traffic today

author: andres3
text:
Toyota Corolla's used to be sold with a "S" Sport Package.

I believe it included:

Aero Body Kit front, sides, and rear = 10% faster
Tightened suspension to be like a Camry SE = 10% faster
TRD Sticker label = 10% faster.

With all these improvements, it is amazing to me the majority of Corollas weren't equipped this way.

author: Michaell
text: So if the 'base' Corolla did 0-60 in 10 seconds, the "S" trim did it in 7?

author: andres3
text: I was kidding about the 30% faster numbers I forgot that the spoiler should make you about 10% faster too. Just stick a big wing on it.

author: Michaell
text:
I know you were kidding - I should have stuck an emoji onto my comment.

I knew two people who bought Corollas with the "S" trim. Same color.

Golf R and Focus RS are pretty rare though, but not quite as rare as a TTS/TTRS.

author: fintail

I'd need about hands to count the Teslas I see every day. Such a bold daring individualist choice.

author: Mr_Shiftright

author: andres3
text:
On the positive side I don't see Tesla vehicles merging on the freeway at 45 MPH, or camping out in the left lane at the speed limit or less as much as Prius owners seem to do.

I also saw someone using one at the local 1/8 mile drag strip; which is perfect for a Tesla's strengths.

author: texases

author: Mr_Shiftright

author: fintail
text: Saw a TTS today, and my second C-HR, which is less offensive in person as the ones I have seen have been dull colors. I notice the ad copy for that sculpture of aggressive beige is as filled with hyperbole and almost snarky exaggeration as every other Toyota ad.

author: ab348
