text: The one I saw today was solid white. It blended in with all of the other overstyled CUVs on the road.

author: texases
text: Saw an AMG C63s, matt grey with yellow stripes. I'm not a fan of getting the most expensive version of the cheapest model. What'd they go for? $100k?

author: fintail
text:
C63s base price is 75K. Of course, everything is optional, but nobody pays MSRP.

For reference, my old 1998 C43 AMG had a MSRP around 53K.

author: qbrozen
text:
Really? So you aren't a fan of the M3? The S3? Civic R? 

Technically, the C isn't the lowest, nor is the 3-series, but you get where I'm going here.

author: qbrozen
text:
Really? So you aren't a fan of the M3? The S3? Civic R? 

Technically, the C isn't the lowest, nor is the 3-series, but you get where I'm going here.

author: texases
text: That C63s is based on a pretty weak starting point, then overdone. Big V8 in a small coupe is overdoing it. The M3 is a highly developed version of a good starting point. The V8 Audis in small bodies were overkill, too, in my opinion.

I couldn't disagree more. But to each his/her own.

Apart from that, I saw a new c300 coupe the other night. Good looking car.

Upcoming facelifted E coupe also looks impressive.

author: stickguy

author: fintail
text: Went for a short walk, saw a new Camry parked on the street, my first sighting in the wild. Rental spec LE - literally, it was a rental, with ACRISS barcodes on both rear door windows, and a "learn more" QR code sticker. Interestingly, it was a Japan-built car.

author: berri
text: I'm surprised they sent any of these early ones to the rental fleets. Wonder if it is for feedback since they tend to mile up quicker? The Pacific coast will often get Japan built vehicles, but I guess I didn't know the Camry was built there any longer. Kind of big dimensions for many countries. Although I suppose they sell in the Mideast and parts of Europe. The latter would be cheaper shipping wise from the States, but probably capacity limited at NA plants.

author: ab348
text: I read an article that said retooling the main US Toyota factory to produce the new model is a very involved process. Not sure why it would be more complex than any other manufacturer but that was the reason the early models are coming from Japan. That surprised me for the same reasons you cited - I assumed Camry was mostly a N.A. model.

author: fintail
text: Yeah, NA likes big somewhat dull things with trunks. Via dashcam videos I see Camrys in Oz and Russia, neither of which surprise me, so there might be demand enough for some other production. I noticed the Japan link through the VIN on the barcode, and double checked it with the VIN near the A-pillar. For all I know, there could be some trickery where the "J" VIN doesn't mean made in Japan. I was surprised to see it in rental use so quickly, although as was said, it would be a good real world testbed.

author: fintail
text: Today spotted a C63 convertible, and not new but rare - a Q70 LWB, the answer to a question asked by nobody on this continent, and probably neck and neck with the RLX in sales.

author: stickguy

author: fintail
text:
4:3 Accord at 2:1 the price and it doesn't sell - shocked, I tell ya!

Re: the Infiniti, it is subtle but noticeable, reminds me of a Dachshund or centipede.

author: stickguy
text: didn't say it was a good value. Just that I found it attractive looking. comfy seats too.

author: fintail
text: It might make a decent used value, if they hit the real market and aren't all expensive lease returns. The late 00s era RL seems like some bang for the buck.

author: Michaell

author: andres3

author: fintail
text: Saw a Giulia today, dark blue, small looking wheels so probably not a QF. Also a Levante.

author: fintail
text:
CT6E - didn't just spot it, but rode in it. A friend of mine spotted a somewhat decent lease offer on this rare bird, and wanted to take a test drive. I went with him.

Pros:
Nice build and material quality. I spotted no assembly issues. This is the kind of Made in China car you want, as QC will be thorough.
Lots of tech and gadgetry. The camera mirror doesn't fail to be cool, and with HUD, night vision, nannies, etc, it can be fun to play with. Also more USBs than I have ever seen in a car.
Extremely smooth and quiet for something with a turbo 4 assist. We took it out with an empty battery, so always using the engine, and it was barely perceptible. I have to imagine it can be eerily silent in EV mode.
Lines softened since the "art and science" days look nicer, and should age better.

Cons:
High price, and junky ADM. The local dealer slaps an additional sticker on most of its cars, for nitrogen filled tires, door edge guards, etc, - 5K in many cases. Funny I don't see those shenanigans at the Audi/BMW/MB dealer. Old habits.
Low availability - the one we looked at was claimed to be the only E model in the area. It was black, which my friend doesn't want, and also makes it look like a livery color.

He didn't sit down and deal, as his Lincoln lease isn't all the way up, and he doesn't want to commit yet. He says the Lincoln dealer says they will give him a very good deal on an 18 MKZ, so he is waiting.

author: qbrozen
text:
He should probably compare the CT6 to the Continental.

I saw my first Alfa Giulia today. It is in a neighbors driveway but could not see which model. It does have a flat black hood for some reason.

author: berri
text: If a dealer is slapping all kinds of ADM and other tricks on the car, move on!

author: fintail
text:
My friend wants something with hybrid or EV tech, so the Continental doesn't work for him. He's happy with the MKZ, other than the drone of the gasoline engine.

I agree on the ADM thing, cheesy.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I've only seen two on a quick glance. Haven't studied one just sitting there. The front end styling is very aggressive.

author: berri
text: Yesterday's Wall Street Journal had an article on the new (or at least heavily revised) Honda Odyssey. What I found interesting was that it said the 10 speed transmission allowed it to cruise at Interstate speeds at only around 2250 on the tach. What I found amusing was way back when we had kids at home or in college I owned a 2004 Ody with a 5 speed transmission. It cruised on the Interstate at around 2250 rpm. So what is the point of the added complexity???

author: stickguy
text:
Fewer dead zones I guess. But I suspect that is 80+. So I like their highways.

I saw a brand new one yesterday. In black. Looked exactly like a hearse, complete with an accent line that resembled a landau bar.

It was awful.

text:
Only partially related, but C&D has a comparison of the new Odyssey vs the Sienna vs the Pacifica. The Pacifica won and the Toyota was last

I can see that based on driving a new minivan. But I think that ranking would flip after around 5 years.

I saw a brand new one yesterday. In black. Looked exactly like a hearse, complete with an accent line that resembled a landau bar.

I have a problem getting into the Ody exterior too. What is more troubling to me is that the interior, including the past comfortable seating position and seats seem to have taken a step backwards.

text: I'm not sure on that MB coupe Fin. I think I'd have to see it in person to really decide. That, what appears to be a rear side vent window, makes me think a bit modern day 49 Ford 2dr sedan in the greenhouse.

Rolls-Royce Wraith and Bentley Continental are also true hardtops.

MB has had at least one hardtop in the range since the 1961 model year.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
I had the same thought when I saw the first all black one. I would imagine a modern Addams Family would drive around in it. Apparently I'm not the only one to make the connection:

The ad says: "A minivan for your weird family".

author: fushigi
text: My '17 AWD QX60 with a CVT does around 2100 RPM at 80 MPH & 2400 at 90. The Ody, in Touring or Elite trim, is actually heavier by a few pounds.

author: fintail
text:
Looks like some new cars are easier to total than others

Shame, local black money will have to find other cars. Knowing local contemptible judges, bail was set at $5 or $5MM.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: That's a class B felony. Not going to be so easy to skate on that one. Carries a max of 10 years + $20,000 fine.

author: fintail
text: All depends on who you are and who you know, this is an oligocracy, remember Although the perp doesn't sound like one of our untouchable monied types.

author: berri
text: Heck, that guy won't spend much time in the slammer. The gov doesn't want to pay for the room and board, let alone his psychiatric treatment. Now if this happened across the lake in Seattle, the guy would be a victim and they would be going after the dealership for having an attractive nuisance

author: fintail
text:
Funny, Seattle doesn't have a dealer for those makes - although it is the largest regional city, all of the money isn't there. Little in the way of mental health services either, of course, because that would be socialist, un-American, etc.

And even with its faults, thousands of skilled intelligent productive people continue to move to Seattle (and here) each month.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: All the more reason he's going to jail--he didn't kill someone, he did something far worse in an oligarchy--he destroyed private property!

author: fintail
text: Mental health might be the get out of jail free card in this case, and this is a somewhat more developed-world type of location. And financially, you can't get blood out of a turnip

author: berri
text: Honestly, states and cities are budget strained, so jail sentences, parole and the like factor economics into their decisions. Not unusual to get a tough appearing sentence and then be out of jail way earlier. The whole judge sentencing thing has become a bit of a fraud at times.

author: andres3
text:
I thought we were at full nearly 100% employment? How can Cities and States still be "budget" strained?

How is it when I call the CA Franchise Tax Board (FTB) on Monday morning they have the technology to put you in the que for a call back (after wasting 5 minutes going through the maze of menu selections for the automated telephone answering system), but the wait or call back time is 3 hours!

Get disconnected before they confirm your phone number again? No call back. Try again. Call at 3 PM because the website says the waiting time for a call back is down to 1 hour 11 minutes, and they don't close until 5 PM.

Machine says "Due to volume of phone calls, you are screwed, and we don't give a damn."

OK, I paraphrased, it said that you should call back another time. As if they had long hours to begin with, or were available weekends! Last time it was so hard to reach an entity that wanted to get paid money, it was the Municipal Courts (Traffic Courts). They've also pulled the "we are getting too many calls, so were not answering the phone anymore during our business hours" message routine.

author: fintail
text:
And so much of it is the courts and LEOs being mental health officers, since we started regressing on the social goods front about 35 years ago.

I've always found "contempt of court" to be a funny kangaroo court style charge, as contempt should be a natural reaction if one is paying attention.

author: andres3
text:
In traffic court I tend to feel only two things:

1) Contempt for the whole charade parading and pretending to be "justice."

2) Intimidation from the formality of it all, the experienced opposition/prosecution/officer, and the tendency for the judge to take on the role of Prosecutor since there is no DA in traffic court.

When in court I try to hide my contempt as best I can, but probably some of it oozes out in my demeanor, body language, tone of voice, and hence, maybe/probably that's why some judges have really handed it to me!

author: fintail
text: Why not? When you effectively know it all, and effectively can't be fired. Speed kills!

author: fintail
text: Saw a white Giulia today, turn signal not in use. So, either a former BMW/Audi driver, or the signal didn't work, equal chance

author: andres3
text: I'd like to see turn signal enforcement from the traffic cops. Not a common enough violation down here in Sunshine State to have seen it carried out right in front of a cops nose though.

author: fintail

And also an introductory "get to know me" call from the Lab Manager in Littleton, NH's hospital. Sheesh. When the sun shines it shines really bright, gentlemen!

But you know, the same problem applies. Cadillac comes in at the wrong price point, and the competition (in the case of the XLR, Benz, in the case of the ELR, their own parent company!) just kills it.

Cadillac was trying to build a 70s era Mercedes 450SL, and Mercedes was just about to launch a 90s era 500SL.

Regarding pot taxes, I have no idea where they go here, obviously not into infrastructure.

author: Michaell
text:
Free market - yeah, right.

The same folks who would scream bloody murder about the EV "rebates" being pulled are the same folks whinging about welfare.

author: fintail
text:
Those who preach free markets are often the last to practice them.

I don't have real issue with a minor incentive for commuter box type cars, but when 100K+ fancy toys sometimes receive five figures worth of combined breaks, it's insane, especially at a time when there's a housing crisis, socio-economic chasm, etc. No doubt the recipients feel it is a reward for "sacrifice", let them eat cake.

author: explorerx4
text: A red Buick Cascada with the top down.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I don't see a bright future for that car. Opel-based, slower than a UPS truck, and not cheap.

author: ab348
text: I think rental car agencies like them.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: There you go--didn't think of that. Perfect Hawaii/Florida rental car.

author: imidazol97
text: Yup. The lottery money in Ohio decades ago was supposed to go for secondary education. That was the main tenet for the lobby for the lottery. However, they put the money into secondary education and took away an equivalent amount of state funding so the schools got the same from the state portion of their funding.

author: Michaell
text:
I think that's what has happened here - the MJ taxes aren't being added to the budget, and what would normally be directed to K-12 is now going other places.

At the moment, the big need here in CO is infrastructure - the legislature has tried for a couple of years to pass a bill to fund transportation projects, but haven't been able to reach an agreement. It may go to the voters next year.

author: kyfdx
text:
All I have to say about that is: Duh...

Just change "Ohio" to the state of your choice. (mine included)

author: explorerx4
text: A dark blue Kia Niro and a silver Alpina B7.

author: stickguy
text: a burnt orange Chevy SS. Did not look as big as I expected. Not bad looking really. and passing by, a bright orange Lambo of some kind (a newer one).

author: fintail
text: Saw another new style XC60, this one with CA "distributor" plates.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new Camry on the road - rental.

author: explorerx4
text: In the parking lot at work, a new white Mercedes X6 clone and a black Jeep GC SRT8.

author: Michaell
text:
GLE Coupe, I'd guess, if it's the same size.

Otherwise, GLC Coupe

author: stickguy
text: I was next to a GLE coupe last week. surprisingly tall. and not at all attractive.

author: fintail
text:
Funny how MB and BMW sometimes copy each other. MB makes CLS, eventually BMW makes 6er Gran Coupe. BMW makes X6/X4, MB makes GLC/GLE "coupes". MB makes B-class, BMW makes 2er "Active Tourer". And so on.

Speaking of BMWs, I got behind a Rolls-Royce Ghost today, it was only going about 20 over.

author: berri
text: '18 Camry rental on the street already. I suppose it is a way to get some miles on a newly released vehicle quickly for feedback.

author: texases
text: I've read a number of good reviews of the Camry, make it sound like a legit Mazda6 competitor in terms of ride and handling.

author: fintail
text: This was my second spotting of a new Camry rental. Maybe production has ramped up. For all the snark about GM and rental cars, Toyota, Nissan, and Hyunkia now are equally as involved.

author: ab348
text: In traffic about a block from my house, a nice-looking Bentley Continental coupe in a pretty light metallic blue. Couldn't see the license plate so no idea if it is a local. If it was, most people here would think the owner must have done something wrong in order to have it.

author: texases
text: Not yet. I don't understand "M" versions of the X5 or X6, or the top end AMG versions of MB's GLE or GLS vehicles, either.

author: fintail
text:
You often don't get that kind of money by following the rules

To be fair, the typical black money set on the west coast seems to prefer German cars, aside from high spec Maserati, Range Rovers and maybe a few AMs or Rolls-Royce.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: In any event, not hard-earned money, if you can easily write off the massive depreciation rate.

author: fintail
text: I think for a Continental, where to the average punter on the street, a 10 year old car looks almost identical to a new one, they are often not on their first owner. I don't know if the maintenance can be written off so easily.

author: ab348
text: Unless there is a local indy shop that does it, the nearest Bentley service center is in Montreal, a fair distance away, especially if it would need to be flatbedded.

author: Michaell
text:
Spotted something unique while out running errands today. I wasn't able to get a picture, unfortunately.

Hyundai badge. At first, it looked like the new Elantra GT (small, hatchback shape). But, I then noticed it has the blacked out wheel arches like a CUV.

New Kona? I thought it would be taller, like the HR-V or C-HR - this looked like the old Outback Sport.

Michigan manufacturers plates.

author: Michaell
text: Looks like it's the Kona - found this via Google Images:

author: explorerx4
text: In the parking lot at work, a new Compass(?), the Compass/Patriot replacement.

author: stickguy
text: I wanted to like the Kona. Maybe in dark blue or gray the exterior would be OK. Need to see one in person when they show up on the lots.

author: Michaell
text: Depends on what engines it comes with. Would be quite fun with the 1.6T from the Elantra Sport.

author: ab348
text: I thought the Kona was strictly a hybrid?

author: Michaell
text:
That's the Kia Niro, which I suspect is on the same platform.

But, the Niro is FWD only, so really just a slightly lifted hatchback.

author: fintail
text: Saw a silver and black Rolls-Royce Wraith parked on the street today, maybe the same one I saw a month or two ago. No plates, no temporary registration.

author: stickguy
text: Niro is the Kia version of the Ioniq, which is all hybrid. The kona is IIRC based on accent, maybe Elantra, and just comes with 2.0l four.

author: andres3
text: I think I do remember noticing rather low speed limits on the island of Maui. I had a rental Sentra.

author: tifighter
text: Kia Stonic will be their version of the Kona. Hard to keep track of them all.

author: stickguy
text: Niro is same platform, different body shape.

author: andres3
text: This body shop gets cars like this all the time.

author: andres3
text:
Most reliable Chevy ever made.

Should have license plate "BadPrkd" RS7

Oh yeah, that Chevy was made by Toyota.

author: fintail
text:
What are the odds the RS7 doesn't have a handicapped placard? Most don't make that kind of money by following the rules.

On that subject, I saw a Bentayga on a flatbed truck, I assume being picked for service by a concierge program. But I can hope it was being towed for illegal parking, and the clueless Stepford or sinister money launderer came out and was stumped about the location of their car.

author: stickguy
text: Volvo XC60. At the dealer. Very good looking. Phenomenal interior. Just sat in, did not drive. He demo had every option, and an eye popping 62k bottom line (before options was low 40s)

author: andres3
text:
Not sure about the odds, but that one did have the ADA placard on the mirror in front; I checked!

Still doesn't excuse the crooked parking job.

author: Michaell
text: Was that a T6 or the T8?

author: Michaell
text: I wonder how expensive the T8 would get?

author: stickguy
text: more if you pile on. This one was over the top, with options I doubt anyone will ever get. Well, very few people.

author: andres3
text:
The "options" cars have available have gone nuts. But, if they are selling them, more power to them.

I just judge every expensive car to the $50K baseline I paid for my '14 S4. Yes I could have more room in an SUV at $50K, but I'd rather have the S4 for every other reason imaginable.

I'm not rich but I got to own a brand new S4 made in Germany for 4 months (made in Escondido after that). To keep things affordable, I did without built-in Navigation, rear-view camera, and perhaps a couple other safety sensors/radars now widely available.

If people realized a loaded up "economy" car wasn't that much cheaper than a stripped out luxury car, I think more would opt for the stripper luxo-sport car. I think the other reason more people don't follow in my footsteps is availability. Higher end dealers don't like taking up any allocation on "stripper" models.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I just priced one out, and yeah, the T6 you looked at obviously had every option box checked.

author: texases
text: Followed a new CRV. The rear end has graduated from 'quirky' to 'goofy', to me.

author: stickguy
text: nice interior, but my wife really does not care for the looks of the butt end.

author: explorerx4
text:
I think Toyota started the trend of lights jutting out sideways from the fenders.
A lot of other vehicles are styled like that now.

author: berri
text: I think overwrought styling is kinda becoming the norm lately. Hello 1959!

author: tjc78
text: It seems at least GM has some restraint.  The Japanese makes certainly do not.

author: fintail
text: I saw a Rolls-Royce Ghost yesterday driven by who I think might have been a football player - very large/built youngish guy with flamboyant hair, probably not a hedge fund owner

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: yeah might be. Some of those guys sign big first year contracts, start spending money and then it hits them "Oh, I owe taxes on this"?

author: Michaell
text:
If it's a football player, rookie contracts are strictly managed in the player agreement between the union and the league.

Now, someone who's signed a new contract would certainly have enough $$$ to get a Rolls.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Yes that's true. They do try to protect newbies. Depreciation on a new Rolls does make one think about "funny money" though.

author: stickguy
text: Could be a loaner? Drives it around for free for publicity.

author: fintail
text: Today saw a white Ferrari 488 and silver Ferrari F12 on the road, and a recently registered Range Rover Sport "Autobiography" (sounds like a model Edwina Monsoon would buy) in the workplace parking garage.

author: fintail
text: Saw my first new E-class coupe on the road today (I have seen one at a show and at the dealer). It's a pretty posh package, and really shows how MB is moving to smooth soft lines from a generation of angular styles and creases. As creases are now the thing with mainstream brands, I wonder when they will follow suit.

author: texases
text: Saw my first new Miata hardtop. Most unusual thing was the paint - kind of a dove grey, not metallic. I can't find it on their web site. Custom?

author: andres3
text:
Is that like a flat looking "battleship" grey? It has been made popular in the Audi ranks as R8's are available in what they call "NARDO."

One woman reviewer on YouTube didn't get it, and called it "concrete grey."

Makes sense that the Military and Navy guys would like it. Lot of those guys around here.

author: qbrozen
text: Saw an F-type before leaving my neighborhood today and realized it is the first one I have seen in the wild. I couldn't take my eyes off it. Front struck me initially as a bit Saturn Sky, but overall the car is beautiful.

author: texases
text: Yes, I almost called it 'battleship grey'. But it was gloss, not flat.

author: andres3
text: Nardo:

author: texases
text: Yep, like that, maybe a shade lighter.

author: kyfdx
text: I really like that color

author: ab348
text: Scion had a shiny non-metallic gray like that too. I think it was called "Cement", how glam. A little too grunge/hippie for my liking but to each their own I guess.

author: andres3
text: I'd of gone with the name "Mortar" myself.

author: berri
text: Wonder how long that clear coat primer will be popular Seriously, it does look better than I originally thought the concept would.

author: qbrozen
text: Speaking of flat finish, this was in front of the PetCo today.

author: kyfdx
text: I can see a Yorkie..

author: fintail
text: MB is of questionable taste, and that's 100% stock. No doubt in a front plate state but not using one, too, as I am sure the law is enforced via socio-economic boundaries.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Flip down the roof, and lose your trunk space. Brilliant!

author: fintail
text: I wonder what amount of late model SLs ever venture more than 75 miles from home.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I always thought hardtop convertibles were a bad idea. I still do.

author: kyfdx
text:
I think it depends on where you live. The increased visibility over a soft-top is great for the 8 months of top-up weather that we have. And, no trunk issues for those months either, obviously.

If it's a daily driver, I could see it.

author: berri
text: Sometimes compromise creates synergy, sometimes mediocrity

author: kyfdx
text: Spotted a new TLX A-Spec SH-AWD. Impressive looking.

author: fintail
text: In a rainy place, a hardtop convertible makes sense - occasional adjustments or repairs of the mechanism are probably easier to live with than cloth top issues in damp weather. I would also prefer it for a DD - I doubt many haul family car-amounts of luggage anyway.

author: fintail
text: A few new ones ones on the road today - A5 hatchback, hockey stick 5er hybrid, Velar (first I have seen)

author: berri
text: Fin, Be careful cruising around right now. I hope you took my advice and bought that pair of oversized aviator sunglasses before Corolla boy finds you or you are discovered on YouTube and become a star

author: fintail
text: I checked Youtube - nothing. This might be my only chance to be famous!

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I think "repairs" are more in the frightening category, if/when they occur. Remember when detachable hardtops were the rage, and NOBODY ever used them? So the hardtop convertible was a compromise. But you have a point--this is more of a toy car than a family car.

author: fintail
text:
Yep, convertibles are toys. They won't see the same miles and hard use as a family car.

I suppose the most worrisome ones would be MB R230 SL, R171 SLK, VW Eos, BMW F30, maybe final run Chrysler Sebring, etc. I know top issues are not unknown on early R230, but aren't universal. I don't know about the rest. I think for detachable hardtops, many just stay on the car. Most R107 SL I see always have the top on, and E36 so-equipped always seem to have it, too.

author: fintail
text: 3 new Camrys on the road today. I think at least one was a rental.

author: stickguy
text: I must have seen some on the road, but if so, I never even noticed. not a good sign.

author: stickguy
text: I must have seen some on the road, but if so, I never even noticed. not a good sign.

author: imidazol97
text: MB AMG GT in dark gray on the road. First I've seen one of these.

author: kyfdx
text: Saw a whole truckload headed north on I-75. Of course, I was just north of the Camry factory.

author: fintail
text:
Lots of beautiful scenery on the road there no doubt

Saw a Titan diesel on the road, not many of those around.

author: explorerx4
text: No Cruze's in the delivery lot at Lordstown.

author: fintail
text: Saw a dark blue hockey stick 5er in traffic today.

author: stickguy
text: Volvo XC60. Fantastic seats and interior.

author: andres3
text:
Spotted a 90's era Camaro joining the ACLA group for a very spirited Highway 33 jaunt. Unfortunately for them, at less than mile marker 10 on the mountain, they ended up about 10' below the road, and about 10' adjacent to the road, and oh yeah, upside down (shiny side down)!

Fortunately for the old man driver (you'd think old men would have more common-sense!), he landed on a bunch of bushes and bushy trees with a bed of soft sand. That soft cushioned landing saved his hide. He was shorter stature, and thin, so he was able to just barely get out of the car though the side window with some help from other drivers.

Lucky only to have some scratches from the broken glass sliding out of the car.

Higher up on the mountain might have been a longer fall than just 10' off the side of the road rolling over. Typical over-correction over-steer issues of that kind of vehicle based on the skid marks. Someone mentioned a Bilstein suspension, but I suspect there's only so much you can do with that chassis that doesn't make it a good selection for canyon carving.

The M3's, 4's, 2's, TTRS, TTS, S4's & S5's, and modern Corvette, and Mustang GT all made it to the end of the day without incident.

author: fintail
text:
Ha, why would you think that?

Saw another new Camry, this one a higher spec, non-rental.

author: andres3
text:
Isn't there an old saying about being "old & wise?"

Maybe he was reliving his youth.

Being that there is no reception for cellphones on that mountain, it was a long time before we realized we had "lost" a third of the group. They were nice enough to stay behind until help arrived.

author: fintail
text: Spotted a new style Tiguan, thought I would see more by now.

author: fintail
text: In traffic today: rental new Camry and a VW Atlas.

author: stickguy
text: I saw an Atlas on the road a few days ago. Nice looking.

author: fintail
text: I think I might have seen a Kia Stinger today. Looked like a shinier fancier Optima, but seemed larger (it was from a distance).

author: kyfdx
text: Cadenza?

author: fintail
text: Nope not a Cadenza, I have seen several of those.

author: explorerx4
text: In the parking lot at work, a white Chrysler 200!

author: stickguy
text: a new Camry out driving around. Not even a rental!

author: fintail
text: Saw a non-rental Camry too, and a Buick Envision - not new, but quite rare, I see more Lamborghinis on the road. I don't know if I can envision myself in a Chinese-made GM CUV

author: berri
text: Envision doesn't seem to get anything better than mediocre reviews.

author: qbrozen
text:
Saw my first V90 in the wild. Black on black with black or charcoal or just really dirty wheels.

Good looking vehicle other than those wheels. Seemed to be sagging in the back.

author: stickguy
text: I just don't like cars that long.

author: qbrozen
text: i think it is more of an illusion. It is only a foot longer than the XC60 and V60, and, interestingly enough, about an inch shorter than a Caddy CTS and only 2 inches longer than a 2018 Accord.

author: fintail
text: Saw another new Tiguan today.

author: andres3
text: Saw a Kia Optima dawdle along holding up traffic until at least 5 cars trailed them on the scenic way home. It wasn't me. I was one of the 5. Idiotic they didn't let people pass.

author: fintail
text:
Laws are only meaningful if the powers that be have the desire to enforce them. They love speeding, and don't care about many others.

Saw another new non-rental Camry, they seem to be selling here. Spectacularly unpretty, but I notice the glass seems to be tall, which is a good trend. Of course, still thick pillars and poor rearward visibility.

author: fushigi
text: Agreed. We've never needed (and still do not need) the 'no cell phones/texting while driving' laws as there have been distracted driving laws on the books for decades. What was always lacking was enforcement.

author: fintail
text:
Enforcement and IMO citations with teeth. Some of the fines out there don't seem low enough to be a deterrent.

I suspect if the enforcement community would go after phone users and non-signalers like they chase violators of often arbitrary speed limits, they could erase the national debt. I know of local intersections where I swear half the cars are either not using a signal or the driver is holding a phone.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new Odyssey, reminds me of the old one but with the now trendy faux floating C-pillar.

author: fintail
text: Saw another new Odyssey today - reminds me of a stretched Opel Adam. Also an A5 sportback,

author: fintail
text: Saw a Velar today, should be a good seller with the leisure demographic in Bellevue.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: That should punch out at close to $60K with options, don't you think?

author: andres3
text:
Easy solution, make the 1st cell phone/distracted driving offense equal to what they charge for a red-light camera violation ($500+). They love camera fines being high, why not make the important violations equally high? None of this $100-$200 BS for the first offense.

I've heard there might be legislation approved in CA making the right turn on red without a complete stop a reduced fine as compared to actually running the red light. I suppose I should thank the camera industry for this one as no one liked getting fined $550 for a 1-2 MPH (or even less) discrepancy in stopping.

author: Michaell
text:
When was the last time you were at a LR dealership?

I was at one last Saturday - the Velar we looked at was north of $60K

Folks in the leasing thread have quoted sticker prices of $70K and higher, depending on engine, trim level and options.

author: fintail
text: Also extra fines for yappers in cars with bluetooth, and then make the fines progressive. I love seeing a late model Range Rover/Tesla/senior MB-BMW etc where the "driver" has a phone to their ear. If these people are supposed to be smarter and more logical and harder working than most everyone else, they sure have a funny way of showing it. Or maybe they know they are virtually untouchable in what is becoming an oligocracy.

author: fintail
text: Yeah, add 20%, and I think they lease poorly. I suspect a number of these will sell for cash though, to the same people who buy local real estate for cash. Completely on the up and up, nothing to see here.

author: jpp75
text: Saw a Kia Niro yesterday, first one I've seen in the wild.

author: kyfdx
text: New Tiguan. First one that Ive seen. Nice looking, but very generic. Looks better than the pictures.

author: laurasdada
text:
Gray Mazda MX-5 RF. Adorable.
White Lexus LC500. Slick.

author: tlong
text: Plenty of BMW i3's. A new VW Atlas and a new Tiguan. A new Camry.

author: fintail
text: And yet another stretched Opel Adam Odyssey.

author: ab348
text: This was at my tire shop today, newish but not brand new. Snazzy looking little thing, I loved the paint color.

author: kyfdx
text: Nothing sounds better than an Aston Martin

author: fintail
text:
Viewed this new style Aston Martin from my hotel room this afternoon:



And this was parked on the street in front:

author: laurasdada
text: To my eye, the MB S Coupe is a beauty! As is the AM DB11, of course!

author: explorerx4
text: Looks like a neighbor down the street swapped her older XC60 for a white Mustang convertible.

author: texases
text:
Saw a new Atlas or Tiguan today at a distance. Any easy way to tell them apart?

Seems like VW's hopped on the Audi/BMW/MB same-styling club.

author: stickguy
text: the Atlas is the size of a Tahoe with a giant blocky hood. The tiguan is a little smaller.

author: fintail
text:
Saw a GLC plug in hybrid today. Not new, also saw a couple BMW 2 "active tourer", showing how MB and BMW like to copy each other. Also, a surprising amount of GLC and GLE "coupe"s, such a pretty and practical design.

So far in Germany - zero Lexus, one Infiniti.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Don't know as I'd use the word pretty but the AMG version sure can move right along.

author: fintail
text: Pretty is in jest. IMO, the "coupe" SUVs are every bit as awkward as the X4 and X6.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: This is one of those "love it or hate it" designs, I guess, like a Hummer.

author: fintail
text:
I actually saw 3 Lexus in Prague today, a record for Europe. 2 NX and 1 RX, no surprise, they compete in the CUV demographic more than cars.

I was in the tonier part of old town for awhile, saw a Rolls Royce Wraith, a couple Bentaygas, late model Ferraris, S600 Maybach, a new style Aston, etc.

author: tlong
text: Currently driving a Cruze rental. A few years ago I drove one and thought it was decent but the engine was coarse. Happy to report that the new one is much smoother. It has auto-stop/start and that seems to work smoothly. The ride is a little bit wallowy in the front end but suspension and steering are fairly taut. Overall not bad at all, continues to improve and leagues ahead of 10-15 years ago in terms of sedans from GM.

author: stickguy
text: Other day, a VW atlas out in the wild. So they sold at least 1.

author: qbrozen
text:
I spotted one of those Atlases this week, too. Nothing very distinctive about it. Rather boring "me too" vehicle.

Also spotted a Levante yesterday. Same deal. Other than the grille, just nothing special about it. The profile could easily be an Infiniti, and the rear looks like a Kia. Pretty sure I'd rather have an F-pace.

author: Michaell
text:
You should hear the Levante with the 'sport' exhaust mode turned on. You might change your opinion.

Would scare all the soccer moms picking up Buffy and Muffy from the private day school.

author: fintail
text:
In suburban Seattle, that's who the Levante sells to - Stepfords. That and the devilspawn of money launderers who are able to purchase vetting.

I've noticed sunroofs aren't as popular here in Czech as they are in Germany - I have seen numerous near-new MB and BMW, not taxis, not apparent rentals, without sunroof, Can't get them that way in the states.

author: andres3
text: M2 is sunroof-less. M235/240i has to be special ordered with moonroof delete option. All glass roofs seem to be "in" right now with the hip and fashionable crowd.

author: fintail
text:
I'm talking like E-class and 5ers. I don't think either exists even as a special order without sunroof in the US - likely due to a big potential resale hit.

My E has pano, and I like the feature a lot, really brightens up the interior on dreary days.

author: stickguy
text:
I was fine moving from the pano on the Sonata to a normal moonroof on the elantra. Still get my fresh air, and light into the interior. I don't sit in the back, so no worries there. The Pano roofs tend to have more issues. Even ignoring the occasional explosion, they usually creak more and probably better chance might leak.

I think Hyundai learned a lesson, because on the redesigned 2018 Sonata, they moved from a Pano roof on the limited to a normal moonroof.

author: fintail
text:
I notice some cars have roofs painted to simulate a pano roof, which is kind of dorky. I have yet to have a rattle in a MB pano car, but I have read of others - apparently, a simple cure by tightening bolts that come loose over time. Never heard of leaks on MB anyway.

Today in Prague spotted 2x Lexus (sedans! GS and LS) and my first Tesla of this trip. I don't mind not seeing those 4 wheeled Faberge eggs on every corner like I do at home.

author: ab348
text: I posted a link here a few weeks ago about a Transport Canada investigation into exploding pano sunroofs. Hyundai had the worst track record in that regard.

author: fintail
text: Saw another Lexus today, but not new, and out in the country. Saw an AMG GT today in central Prague, cool alternative to a Porsche.

author: iluvmysephia1
text: Seen a Subaru Impreza over there yet, fintail?

author: fintail
text: Subarus are here, but seem to be a minor player - virtually all Outbacks and Foresters.

author: iluvmysephia1
text: Ahh. I knew there was something about Europe that sort of... frightened me.

author: fintail
text: You'd like some things here, I think. There's a very diverse selection of small cars, many of them quite basic.

author: iluvmysephia1
text:
You'd like some things here, I think. There's a very diverse selection of small cars, many of them quite basic.

I'm 3/4 Norwegian, of course I would. The other 4th of me is British! I would love Europe but I'm too close to retirement and all I can think is of retiring. I can't put aside money to fly there now - all I'd be thinking of would be the next Toyota Yaris iA I want or the next little eastern Washington house the Mrs. and I want to buy.

But if I was younger (and even now) I would have a ball there. Of course I'd love to see Norway and the Colisseum in Rome, Italy.

Besides that, I'd love to see all of the interesting rigs over there. For sure! Have fun, man.

What do you think of the VW Jetta, fin? Pfft. See what I mean? There I go again.

author: tlong
text:
Europe is really cheap to fly to in the winter as demand is low. Sometimes less than cross country flights in the US.
We were in Prague in late summer and yes there was a diverse set of cars. I got a picture of myself standing in front of the Rolls dealer.

author: fintail
text:
That's right, I paid less for my nonstop RT flight than a co-worker did for a flight to NC back in the spring. Cheapest I had ever seen, which is why I impulse-booked it. The months in between gave me time to plan the trip and pay for most of it, so I won't have a ton of bills when I return.

Another co-worker flew to Geneva or Paris in June, and it was cheaper yet, something like $560. Seattle has some low cost carriers to Europe now (Icelandair, Norwegian) , so there's competition. I've seen some pretty cheap flights out of Seattle to China, too.

I saw that Rolls-Royce dealer in Prague the other day, in the ritzy Pariszka area. That's where one goes for exotic spotting.

author: fintail
text:
It's always key to spend less than you make, but at the same time, live a little, you have earned it

About 10 years ago, after my dad passed too young, I realized that tomorrow isn't guaranteed. The way I see it now, as long as one has income greater than outflow, and maybe puts a little away for tomorrow, they should also enjoy the fruits of their labor. Being a miser is good for heirs and lawyers, not more. I hope you get a chance to see those places, too.

Jetta, as the Limeys called it. "Golf with a boot". Probably a nice car in the segment with some German engineering behind it, but I think the US spec models were decontented, at least in basic form.
iluvmysephia1 said:
You'd like some things here, I think. There's a very diverse selection of small cars, many of them quite basic.

I'm 3/4 Norwegian, of course I would. The other 4th of me is British! I would love Europe but I'm too close to retirement and all I can think is of retiring. I can't put aside money to fly there now - all I'd be thinking of would be the next Toyota Yaris iA I want or the next little eastern Washington house the Mrs. and I want to buy.

But if I was younger (and even now) I would have a ball there. Of course I'd love to see Norway and the Colisseum in Rome, Italy.

Besides that, I'd love to see all of the interesting rigs over there. For sure! Have fun, man.

What do you think of the VW Jetta, fin? Pfft. See what I mean? There I go again.

author: iluvmysephia1
text:
I guess I still have strong memories of Dad's 1966 VW Fastback. That car was a 4-speed stick and light and tossable around corners. That was the car I took all around Seattle when I turned 16. Seattle was a wild place in the wild 70's. I'm glad I made it home safe (every time!). I drove my parents nuts many a time. But if a modern V-Dub could be anywhere near as fun ta drive as that Fastback I'd be down with giving it a try.

There's several of us living near Seattle. Maybe an Auto Show Meetup would be fun sometime, eh? I'd love to see your nickname car.

author: fintail
text:
I suspect any modern VW would be like a supercar compared to a Fastback/Type 3, especially in terms of acceleration and stability. I have to imagine the rear engine/RWD setup of that car could be quirky in terms of handling. Seattle must have been wild then indeed, an age when normal working class people could afford houses in the city. Unimaginable today.

Speaking of VWs and your love of small cars, the train I am on just passed several train car carriers of assorted VW Up! (not sold in the US) , maybe you'd want these:



I believe they are built in Slovakia, not far from where I am right now. I'd like to be in that old car here, it would get a ton of positive attention - not like it doesn't at home, as it becomes a little more unusual with each passing year.

I always seem to take my vacations around the time of the auto show, but I attended a few years ago. Looks like this year a meetup isn't going to happen either. Maybe next year.
iluvmysephia1 said:
I guess I still have strong memories of Dad's 1966 VW Fastback. That car was a 4-speed stick and light and tossable around corners. That was the car I took all around Seattle when I turned 16. Seattle was a wild place in the wild 70's. I'm glad I made it home safe (every time!). I drove my parents nuts many a time. But if a modern V-Dub could be anywhere near as fun ta drive as that Fastback I'd be down with giving it a try.

There's several of us living near Seattle. Maybe an Auto Show Meetup would be fun sometime, eh? I'd love to see your nickname car.

author: stickguy
text:
My daughter just booked flight to Paris for spring break (better than Cancun or Daytona!). Was in that $500 range, non stop Newark to Paris. And got a super cute air bnb apartment in a great location for really cheap too.

Kid has a more xciting life than I do, that is for sure

author: iluvmysephia1
text:
stick - wow, she's a jet-setter already!

fintail - I do like the VW Up! I just bounce around quite a bit in my research of and excitement for automobiles. Actually, my excitement level stays pretty much level - and by that I mean strong. As I re-open the Toyota Yaris iA file, I notice that Toyota is pricing them at only $15,995 for the 6-speed stick, 2018 model. Nice. And that means the primo Mazda 6-speed transmission installed, too. 

I also noticed at AutoNation in Spokane they're selling a brand new 2017 Toyota Corolla iM for only $16,975. That is also for the 6-speed and the color is white. Sounds weird to add Corolla before the iM but Toyota categorized it that way after Scion folded. I have loved several Scion's, the first one being the small xA.

author: fintail
text: Scion was a funny thing - cynical marketing exercise, the youfs mostly saw right through it, and it ended up appealing most to practical mature folks. IIRC, they didn't even try that trick outside USA and Canada. iA is a lot of mouth for the money

author: iluvmysephia1
text:
iA is a lot of mouth for the money

Oh sure.



The 6-speed stick Yaris iA only weighs 2,395 lbs. Nice! This car would be an absolute ball ta drive, fin.This is a driver enthusiast's car, I have no doubts abouts it.

author: andres3
text:
ab348 said:
I posted a link here a few weeks ago about a Transport Canada investigation into exploding pano sunroofs. Hyundai had the worst track record in that regard.
CR published a chart on exploding glass roofs, and Hyundai and Kia were right at the top of the list. Interesting conundrum. Laminated glass roofs will make the heavy roofs even heavier.

author: explorerx4
text: Probably some supplier cheating on specs due to being financially squeezed by customer.

author: stickguy
text: actually saw a new Camry in the wild today, parked at LL Bean wearing a temp tag. Silver. Looked good from the rear!

author: tlong
text:
stickguy said:
actually saw a new Camry in the wild today, parked at LL Bean wearing a temp tag. Silver. Looked good from the rear!
They seem to be returning to at least decent looking but bland styling. Unlike some of the other Toyotas and especially the Lexi, which look IMHO hideous.

author: fintail
text: Some cars iluv or others might like: spotted while on a train in Slovakia, new VW Up!s and I believe Peugeot 208s:

author: ab348
text: One of these pulled into the space next to me as I was parking at the supermarket. Never saw one before. I thought at first it was some sort of Nissan product but it turns out is is a MV-1, made by AM General. They even have a local dealer as it turns out.

author: texases
text: I saw a couple of those in and around Des Moines last week. Don't see them any more in DFW.

author: stickguy
text: My local Honda dealer sold those. As always odd seeing a few parked outside

author: fushigi
text: There are a number of those in taxi service in Chicago. They're running on CNG.

author: stickguy
text: I think the ones I saw were done up as handicapped transport. I forget how they were rigged, but designed to handle wheel chairs.

author: ab348
text: Funny you mention that. When I saw it my first thought was that of an oversized Element.

author: fintail
text:
Did the Sindlefingen factory tour again, saw E-class body stamping and S-class final assembly, the latter was pretty interesting with the numerous variations on the line in seemingly random order.

Also inside the factory gates (photos forbidden) saw 4 or 5 test mule of prepro updated CLS (I think) in varying camo, a couple of heavily disguised what looked like GLC, and a camo A-class 5 door.

This was the scene at the "Center of Excellence" on a frosty clear morning:



And in front they had a couple of these cladded E-wagons posed on an incline to demonstrate off roading, I guess:

author: qbrozen
text: LOL. Well, in that case, every day I go up and down my driveway, I must be offroading. woohoo!

author: Michaell
text:
Wait, is that an E-class ..... Outback?

And here I thought it was only a US thing...

author: fintail
text: There are some other butched up wagons in Europe, it appears to be a high margin idea, MB is running with it too I guess.

author: tlong
text: Wagons are very popular in Europe, SUVs not nearly as much

author: fintail
text: Yep, full sized ones aren't so common here, a tall wagon is more likely. CUVs are big, but not like in Seattle. Wagons still to appear to outnumber them both.

author: Michaell
text: Do you think this has to do with turning circle and maneuverability?

author: fintail
text: Size certainly has a lot to do with it. Even the height-seeking mommy set here doesn't seem to need more than a small CUV or maybe an AWD wagon. Of course, the Stepford set still buys many of the same things here as in the US, save for Lexus, which exists, but not with huge influence.

author: tifighter
text: Supposedly the All-Terrain is coming to the US. Now that Volvo has gone up in price with the V90 CC, it would be interesting to see how they sell against each other.

author: tlong
text: The streets are narrow in Europe. A car like the VW Golf is a mid-sized car in Europe. They have few of the monstrosities we have in the US like F150 or Escalade or Navigator or Titan.

author: fintail
text:
Streets are narrow, not as many acres of shoddy mcmansions and 3 car garages, etc.

Saw an Audi Q2 today, gotta find a seat for every butt

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Audi's niche marketing is getting a bit ridiculous.

author: explorerx4
text: On the way home from work, a new Volvo S90.

author: fintail
text:
Lots of new models at the massive MB dealership attached to the museum:




This was maybe the newest thing:

author: explorerx4
text: Looks like a Ford Explorer Sport trac.

author: tjc78
text: Ridgeline too.

author: ab348
text: GMC Canyon with a different grille.

author: fintail
text: Saw a couple more Audi Q2 today, a camo'd apparent A-class 5 door prototype in Stuttgart, and a Euro Ford Ranger.

author: fintail
text: Saw one of the big lifted new style G-Wagen on the road, wacky.

author: explorerx4
text: Despite living a couple of miles from a Nissan dealer, the 2nd new gen Titan I've ever seen.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new Accord on the road this afternoon.

author: berri
text: Seems like those are finally starting to trickle out.

author: texases
text: The new Accord Touring got a great review at R&T, said no need to buy a luxury car.

author: ab348
text: That sounds like a bit of a stretch.

author: texases
text:
I agree, but thats what they said:
http://www.roadandtrack.com/new-cars/first-drives/a13818067/2018-honda-accord-review/

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: "Luxury" is really a marketing term, isn't it? I mean, it's hard to quantify exactly. You can spend $80K for a Ford F-250 Platinum edition pickup, but is that "luxury", even thought the seats are leather, and heated and cooled, and give you a massage?

author: fintail
text: I loathe Honda's new trim detail theme at the end of side windows, like the rear quarter window on the Accord. Pointless goofty different for the sake of different design "flair" that I would have to modify if I owned one. A vibrating hood would also bug me to no end. Still, I'd probably choose it over a Camry, based on looks alone.

author: iluvmysephia1
text: fin, care ta enter a vote over in the Cars and Conversations thread?

author: kyfdx
text:
Mercedes AMG C63S sedan.

Seems awfully pedestrian looking, considering the cost and horsepower.

author: fintail
text: In the olden days, AMG was all about being a wolf in sheep's clothing.

author: Michaell
text: Guess that's still the case....

author: fintail
text: Yep, and that's how I like it. I don't want all of the gills and stickers and double decker spoilers etc. Maybe have a slightly different stance, barely-different wheels, subtle exhaust tips, maybe a lip spoiler, and that's it. Save it for under the sheetmetal.

author: fintail
text: Saw 2 new E-class coupes in traffic this evening.

author: stickguy
text: was out walking the dog around the neighborhood, and hard something that sounded unique coming up behind me. Turned out to be a V10 audi R8. Convertible. Interesting looking, but IMO not attractive in white with a black top (cold today, so it was up). But, I would not kick it out of bed.

author: tifighter
text: Yesterday I saw my first Lexus LC500. Dark metallic red. It is pretty striking in person; I can't decide if it will age well or not yet. But it looks like you spent the money, and in the expensive coupe market, that's half the battle. It is distinctive.

author: Michaell
text: I saw a white one some months back, and share the same opinions as you.

author: fintail
text: I've seen a few LC in Bellevue. Striking anyway, yes. They are 100K, so they should be special in some way.

author: explorerx4
text: A orangy/copper color Chevy Bolt. Kind of thought it was a Honda Fit at first glance.

author: fintail
text: Velar, for when an Evoque is too proletarian, and a Sport is too hard to park.

author: Michaell
text: Took a ride in a Velar when @jpp5862 test drove one. Beautiful, but cramped, interior. I think of it as the RR X6

author: fintail
text: Not a bad comparison. A Sport is probably a degree higher, so the Velar fits in. For better or worse, the high riding low headroom ostentatious CUV/SUV is a thing now, and probably here to stay, X6 really got that wonderful ball rolling.

author: qbrozen
text: Saw a Velar today, as a matter of fact. Not very attractive, IMHO. Wife actually said "ew."

author: fintail
text: Saw an E63s wagon at the MB dealer - 123K.

author: Michaell
text: Isn't that the end of the year bonus amount for many of the techies in your neck of the woods?

author: fintail
text: That's about right, it's also probably about the weekly allowance for many in the satellite child devilspawn demographic around here. I've heard amusing stories from a salesman here. A surprising/depressing amount of never-employed under-25s in vehicles in that price range in these parts.

author: fintail
text: New style Panamera in the workplace parking garage.

author: tjc78
text: New Camry.... I can't tell if I like it or not. Front end is a bit "interesting" but what isn't these days.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
I *thought* I saw the 2018 Jeep Wrangler going the opposite way on the freeway but only got a quick glimpse--are they on the road yet?

I've seen video reviews of it, and it looks to be a better Wrangler in every possible way.

author: Michaell
text: I didn't think the new ones had been released yet. We have lease numbers for the 2018's, but I'd guess the new one will be a 2019 model year.

author: stickguy
text: Same as the remodeled Jetta due out soon. Short MY 2018 of the old style.

author: fintail
text: New E300 parked beside me at work - still had window sticker residue (not the best detail?). Then saw a new style E coupe on the road.

author: explorerx4
text: A new Impreza sedan in a nice aqua blue color.

author: qbrozen
text: Saw my first Stelvio today on the open road. White. Sharp car.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Very sharp in the front end. Must be a hell of a blind spot looking rearwards, though.

author: fintail
text: New-ish, saw a Continental today that wasn't a rental or fleet car. Not a bad looking car.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Reminds me a bit of a Tesla Model S. Spokey wheels, big hips.

author: fintail
text:
But it has a grille, not egg shaped, not flocked to by over-monied eco-dorks

I suspect depreciation is fierce, too, might be a good used buy.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Yes, I was thinking that depreciation is going to hit those Alfas pretty hard. It's difficult to rebound from a bad launch in the car mags and vlogs.

author: fintail
text:
Oh, I was thinking about the Lincoln

Alfa depreciation will probably be worse!

author: ab348
text:
Spotted an Alfa Romeo Giulia on a flatbed today (the jokes sort of write themselves....).

The odd thing is that we don't have a dealer locally, with the nearest being in Quebec City, nearly 400 miles away.

author: texases
text:
The Giulia has had one of the worst new car rollouts in quite a while. Seems like every site/magazine/etc. has had problems.

But I'm not reading great things about the Tesla 3, either. Time will tell...

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
The Tesla is critic-proof. It's a cult, really. Short of bursting into flames, every defect on a Model 3 will be artfully apologized for. I'm already seeing this online. It's like the Harley-Davidson or the Apple of EVs.

As critics of the Harley once said: "It's hard to argue against the success of the brand when its customers have the company name tattooed on their foreheads".

author: stickguy
text: I'll consider a Guilia lease in the summer, if they are desperate to unload them. But not a buy. And not if I have to depend on it every day! At least where I am now, there is a dealer close by. Just need to check the areas I may possibly move to.

author: qbrozen
text: Here is where used RWD Ti models are already. If you look closely, you'll see they were around $33k and change in Nov. Now just 1 mo later they are $30k.

author: fintail
text:
It's a cult to an even deeper extent than Apple products - probably because of the high price, and nobody wants to admit spending that much in a questionable decision. I see Jalopnik today had a funny story about a Model 3 owner experiencing constant hiccups - not long ago, they were shilling for Tesla, and would ban people for mentioning it. How things change, I guess even wikipedia-schooled hipster kidults can see the light.

Time for a MSRP cap on tax breaks for such vehicles.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
It's difficult to know what actually goes on at the Tesla factory, and the reporting on the Internet gets more and more bizarre.

In a story I read entitled something like "NEW MODEL 3 NOW LEAVING THE FACTORY", what it actually was, was drone shots of a fly-over showing a few hundred Model 3s (if that) parked in a row, with one truck loaded up with cars just sitting there.

Keep in mind that Musk was promising "5,000 cars a week" by this time.

One would think a normal company would just publish sales figures for the month, instead of the media having to rely on drone fly-overs to speculate where these cars are even going--if anywhere.

It's very odd. Even MORE bizarre was that the story was seriously proposing that this drone shot had effectively silenced all the doubters

Wha?

author: fintail
text:
The "Kool Aid" jokes are kind of trite and cliched, but they kind of apply to this too.

Beta software is often riddled with flaws, cars at launch often have flaws, combine them and have fun.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I've driven a Tesla Model S and the Chevy Bolt (too briefly to really write it up), so I'm looking forward to a spin in the Model 3. One thing about the Model 3 that I did discover, though--if you want one with all the cool features you can add on, this isn't a $35,000 car. This is closer to a $60,000 car. Even just the autonomous feature costs and extra $8K or so.

author: qbrozen
text: The $35k is a bit of a joke, IMHO. Oh, you want a color other than black? Cha-ching. You want full performance instead of the detuned version? Cha-ching. People should just go into it assuming $45k as the starting point.

author: Michaell
text:
I thought it was pushing $50K, minimally equipped.

I would think that less than 1% will be equipped at a price point less than $45K

author: qbrozen
text: $35k base plus $9k high-po version plus $1k for anything other than black paint. Then start adding options from there. Premium pack alone is $5k.

author: bhill2
text: Ah, brings memories of the 60s. Oh sure we have that model for $1995, but wouldnt you like a nice heater?  Power steering makes driving so much easier too.  And the available electric wipers are quite useful in this climate. Oh and a radio to keep you companywe have one for $49.95, of course if you want pushbutton station memory its a little more.... And thats before you consider an optional engine that is capable of actually accelerating the  car.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Musk just sold out of 50,000 baseball caps that said "The Boring Company" on it. $20 bucks a pop, too. I tell you, this guy has magic fingers. He reminds of the patent medicine craze in America in the 1800s----"Dr. Wizard's Vegetable Health Pills--Cures All Diseases!".

author: fintail
text:
Any Simpsons fan will get it:



Musk has a cult around him just like his products.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
What Musk did is make EVs sexy. There's really no "new" technology at all, and his cars are built just like any other modern car. But he did jump start the EV industry.

Remains to be seen if all his "depositers" are going to wait 2 years to get a Model 3 or not, and if they will pay full freight once the tax breaks expire (soon) and the options list grows larger.

And then we have all the EV competition coming down the pike right now.

author: fintail
text: If a 3, S, or X is sexy, I'll be frumpy and proud. I just don't see it. Credit can be given for getting the ball rolling, yeah, although for me personally, until tech makes another quantum leap, I'd want nothing beyond a hybrid - I want range and efficient refueling time.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Well "sexy" in that previously, most EVs made you look like a dork.

author: fintail
text: To some, a Tesla does that too

author: texases
text: Yeah, prior EVs were mostly frumpy or goofy:

author: imidazol97
text:
Remember the days of no 1951:





This huge Hadacol Caravan with 17 plush railroad cars loaded with Americas top movie stars and singers is going to have whistle stops and one-night-stands in 15 states, while traveling 3800 miles. All to increase the sales of Hadacol.

Hadacol, of course, is that cure anything patent medicine that LeBlanc markets as a vitamin supplement and, according to the Senator, marches into battle against the pain and suffering of rheumatism, heart problems, ulcers, diabetes, nervousness, gas, cancer and on and on. You name the medical malady, LeBlanc says, Hadacol cures it. Of course, it doesnt hurt that Hadacol contains 12 % alcohol and has tremendous sales in dry areas of the country where one cannot buy liquor like much of the South. A bottle of wine has about the same alcohol content as this medicinal elixir.

So, alcohol? Yes. Taste? No. Hadacol has been described as smelling like a sewer and tasting like dirt. Consequently, entertainer Groucho Marx asked its creator, What is Hadacol good for? Always the showman, LeBlanc replied, It was good for five and a half million for me, last year.

http://southernmemoriesandupdates.com/stories/hadacol-health-tonic-brings-big-stars-to-small-towns/

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
With EVs and hybrids we get a kind of "feel good marketing", as opposed to power or status.

But that doesn't work all by itself. The car has to perform reasonably well.

The new Porsche Mission E will pack some 670 HP. So you can go that fast and still save the world. Perfect!

author: fintail
text:
Some Hadacol might make those cars seem like a cooler design.

The dry area stuff is amusing too, hard to believe such backwardness existed in relatively recent history (and to an extent, still does).

author: fintail
text:
Although the Tesla powertrain is remarkable and has merit, I think there's some power and status involved too, simply based on the price. This is the new Belle Epoque (remember how the last one ended), and ostentatious displays are in again.

The Porsche will just double down on it too, and probably still get an undeserved tax break.

author: fintail
text:
I spent a few minutes car-looking, This thing caught my eye at the MB dealer - high options, nice colors, and you can see the scrape low on the front driver's side bumper/airdam area. It'll probably buff out as it appears to be transfer from another object, but still.

MB dealer had this cool indoor display for AMG, with simulated tarmac and all. Car is a nicely equipped E63s wagon with a MSRP around 124K, I think:



Also a way to not be hounded too much by a salesperson is to tell them you are 18 months into a 36 month lease

author: ab348
text: Dry areas still exist in pockets here in Nova Scotia. When I was working I had the responsibility for bringing the ancient records up to date - they were recorded on an old highway map with hand-drawn boundaries colored in when I arrived there - and so I pulled together all the records that I could find since Prohibition ended and had it digitized via a GIS. Then I was in charge of initiating the plebiscites required by law whenever a liquor store or manufacturer wanted to set up in these areas. Every year I petitioned the legislators to change the law, to no avail.

author: ab348
text: Unless I'm missing something I don't see a way to look at any photos of that car other than the one on the listing.

author: fintail
text:
That's the funny part, you can see the white scuff in the listing pic. Not the highest attention to detail the day that pic was taken, apparently.

Too bad when you were tasked with updating maps, you couldn't also update minds. More people on the wrong side of history.

author: fintail
text: Saw a Velar today, along with a questionably driven new unplated Jag XE, new E-class at work, and I've noticed a recent proliferation of the illuminated grille star on MB - virtually 100% of the time on a mallcruising CUV/SUV.

author: andres3
text: I saw a model 3 out in the real-world, so someone got one. It was parked though.

author: andres3
text: Just a dork with more money, and/or money to burn.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new unplated G63 AMG in white with black wheels and tinted windows. Russian mafia car or Russian mafia car?

author: fintail
text: Prius people with more money, or sometimes mysteriously monied people who thought the Karma was scary, and can finally move up from their Prius.

author: tifighter
text: Saw a Kia Stinger today. Red. Not amazing, not offensive. Aggressive. Definitely a gutsy move from Kia; the reviews have been positive. The big question- will it sell??? What does it get cross-shopped against?

author: stickguy
text:
Oh yeah. Get to see this at car show too.

I think it competes with itself almost, being unique. But will get cross shopped to an oddball assortment of stuff. BMW and Audi for sure. Probably Infiniti..

author: fintail
text: I've read some Stingers out there are carrying ADMs. Good luck with that!

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Well that's the height of optimism, I must say.

author: tifighter
text: Well, here you go right here. Where's the shaking my head emoji?

author: andres3
text:
Wow, the MSRP is already plenty high. I'd rather get a CPO B8/B8.5 S4 in the 20's these days.

Consumer Reports agreed with me that the Sound System is a weak spot in the Optima. Funny how that works. I wonder if they correct that for the Stinger.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Well what else could you possibly buy for $62,000 other than a Kia, I ask you!

author: qbrozen
text: Truecar says I can get that same car for $205 below MSRP. Just sayin. ;b

author: texases
text: Well, IIRC the PT Cruiser had ADM when it first came out. I never understood the gotta have it first mentality.

author: Michaell
text:
Well, IIRC the PT Cruiser had ADM when it first came out. I never understood the gotta have it first mentality. 

What is it that shifty sez?

Simply an exercise of the dealers First Amendment rights.

author: ab348
text:
Well, IIRC the PT Cruiser had ADM when it first came out. I never understood the gotta have it first mentality. 

Same with the Veloster. When they first came out a guy I worked with absolutely had to have one. The dealer took him to the cleaners.

author: fintail
text: Saw a Stelvio in traffic today, running and driving, so it has that going for it.

author: fintail
text:
Hilarious. Hmmm let's see, I can pay 20% over MSRP or 60+K (which ever seems more ludicrous to you) for a nicely equipped new mild performance Kia from a dealer in Auburn, or get any number of CPO mild or moderate performance cars from prestige brands. Tough decision.

Not knocking the car as an object, but this is very ambitious, and dangerous. Equus and K900 aren't viewed as successful moves.

author: fintail
text:
Yep, percentage wise, it was probably even more. I remember "Limited" models approaching 30K with the ADM. It was so bad local dealers were buying cars in Canada and federalizing the gauges, I kid you not.

I also remember 10K ADMs on the Crossfire and SSR.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: It's a short-lived rush, that's for sure.

author: stickguy
text:
I need to start a list of all the new (or kinda new) cars out I have not had a chance to check out, so I don't miss any at the car show. Off top of the head, there is:

Accord
Alfa Guilia and Stilvio
Ascent (sube)
RDX (not sure if concept or actual production car)
2019 Jetta
Volvo XC60
Stinger

Anything else that should be out, or at least teaser on the turntable, by the end of this month?

author: andres3
text: I wonder what the lease deal on a $60K Kia is.

author: Michaell
text:
In a word - lousy.

Kia has changed their lease programs to have very high money factors but large amounts of lease cash to offset. Adding $10K ADM just makes the lease payments that much higher.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new unplated A5 sportback in the workplace parking garage.

author: kyfdx
text:
2018 Accord Sport.
Looks good from behind.

author: qbrozen
text: LOL. Yet, how many times have we all been fooled?

author: stickguy
text:
a white GLC "coupe". Man is that ungainly looking. what a waste, and so much less practical.

And my first Giulia in the wild. Dark blue. Nice looking. Though at first from behind, I thought it was a TLX!

author: fintail
text:
But those awkward "coupes" seem to be selling. BMW discovered a niche, MB decided to get in on it.

I notice most MB illuminated grille stars seem to be on CUV/SUVs, but lately I have seen an E coupe and cabrio with them. What an age we live in.

author: ab348
text:
This is a nice retro throwback to the '70s Chevy pickup:



http://www.thedrive.com/news/16762/chevrolet-dealer-keeping-the-classic-pickup-look-alive-with-this-cheyenne-super-10-build

author: qbrozen
text: Damn, that's ugly

author: andres3
text: I'd take it over the Aztec.

author: explorerx4
text:
@qbrozen,
I agree, it worked much better on slab sided trucks. The new ones have too many bulging parts.

author: fintail
text: Buick Envision, non-rental.

author: andres3
text: Opposite end of the spectrum, saw a Lambo at that infamous body shop. Looked undamaged and/or already repaired in bright yellow paint.. All Lambo's look too similar to me to tell them apart.

author: fintail
text: Lambos are somewhat like Audi sedans (and now MB and BMW too) - which might make sense with their ownership. One sausage, different lengths.

author: texases
text: Saw a new 911 Turbo S cabrio on the drive in. $203k to start...

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Leave it to Porsche. You can one-up the Turbo S Cabrio guy by buying the Turbo S "Exclusive", a limited-production model staring at $258K. Wait, there's more! At $258K, it *still* has an option list you can check off to go higher.

author: explorerx4
text: A new Accord in red. Not sure what trim level, but front was not as jarring as the pictures and from the side the roof line just seems long. To me, not a huge difference in looks from 2017.

author: stickguy
text: really? I think it looks like a stretched Civic, but not really that much like the prior model.

author: qbrozen
text: Saw a CH-R. Just as ugly in person as expected. My oldest said "my god, why?!?!"

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I'm still traumatized from my first sighting, too.

author: stickguy
text: I saw one today too, parked outside Kohls. so someone must have bought it. Looked even odder in bright teal body with white roof. I pointed it out to the wife and suggested we get one. She just gave me "the look".

author: fintail
text: I am surprised by the lack of CH-R I have seen on the road - I rarely see one. I guess PNW drivers want something that's actually AWD. It's like Toyota was trying to compete with the Juke.

author: ab348
text: I saw one here very shortly after it was introduced but the only others I've seen are on dealer lots. I would guess they aren't selling well.

author: qbrozen
text: They should Not Sell well since the Juke was not and is now discontinued.

author: explorerx4
text: I saw a CH-R once, it reminded of the current Prius, in that it is designed to look like it had body damage right from the factory.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: They seem to be selling roughly 3,500 a month.

author: qbrozen
text: I think (hope) that will drop drastically quickly once initial demand dries up.

author: fintail
text: So 41K units a year? Or was that a three month average or something? The amount I see on the road here anyway doesn't seem to match 40K units a year, but they might not sell here due to no AWD on a silly angry-faced faux-aggressive crossover.

author: stickguy
text:
I saw a few at the dealer. The one this weekend was the first I recall in the wild. Might have seen one that did nor register, but 2 tone teal and white top is hard to miss.

saw a pair of new white camrys today. An LE, with a rear end that was fine looking, pretty bland. Then an SE of some sort, with the black accents/diffuser butt that looks a lot flashier (more like a lexus actually). Something for everybody. Saw the nose on the LE. Not good, but looked worse with all the black plastic against a white car. I think this is a car that really needs to be in a dark color.

author: andres3
text: I've noticed the VW dealership by my work place is full of SUV selection. Probably at least 20 new Tiguans on the lot, maybe 30.

author: texases
text: I'm sure not seeing many of the new Atlas/Tiguans. Kind of surprising.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
No, not a year. December 2017 was their best month:

http://www.goodcarbadcar.net/2016/10/toyota-chr-sales-figures-usa-canada/

author: qbrozen
text: Hell, I was not even aware it had been out since April

author: fintail
text: They must be selling in areas to the south of me. I can't recall exactly when I last saw one on the road.

author: ab348
text: I guess anything will sell if it has a Toyota logo on it.

author: andres3
text: I think Toyota should take your advice and beat Honda at the lawn mower game, and also make snow blowers while there at it. Motorcycles and sport-bikes next!

author: fintail
text:
Yay, the first automatic sportbike with soft suspension and an aggressive face.

Speaking of bikes, I saw an electric motorcycle (kind of a dual sport style) today.

author: explorerx4
text: Saw a Stinger out front at a Kia dealer. Thought I'd be more wow'ed by it. The was another sedan(Cadenza?) near it that didn't look totally dissimilar.

author: fintail
text:
Stinger looks too much like a prior Optima, IMO. Nice spec sheet, but I don't see this one being a blinding success. Might be a good used deal in a few years.

A local dealer is still trying for a 10K ADM on their loaded model - good luck, all I can say is LOL

author: tifighter
text: Grey Tesla Model 3 today. Looks tidy, but the color was pretty bleh on a gray day. But they're getting delivered.

author: Michaell
text: But, at not anything approaching the rate that was originally forecast.

author: fintail
text:
A friend of mine spotted this tasteful classy subtle thing today, and sent a pic:



In a nice part of Manhattan, so it makes sense. FIRE industry go-getter, old money trust funder, or offshore money launderer, take your pick from the list of boostrapping vocations.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Went to the Tesla dealer to play with the Model 3 but didn't drive it. Just got a quick demo of features in the parking lot.

I totally hated the driver interface screen. I would get so annoyed driving this car that I'd probably take an ax to it before I got ten blocks to enjoy the rest of it. Having to use + and - on the screen to adjust fan speed? Really? Directional indicators in the middle of the dashboard? Really?

The dash is completely empty. It's a very spartan environment, to say the least.

You know, sometimes "different' isn't "better".

Perfect car for people who find playing with an iPad more fun than driving.

author: ab348
text:
Interesting article in TTAC on the Tesla battery manufacturing woes and the Model 3:

http://www.thetruthaboutcars.com/2018/01/whistleblowing-tesla-engineers-say-model-3-batteries-made-hand-slowing-production-creating-potential-fire-hazard/#more-1610358

author: explorerx4
ab348
text: The comments on that site usually get a F grade. On that article I give the comments a C- because there are a few that I can agree with.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Did you read /watch the CNET review of the Model 3? It started off with this line:

"the most anticipated vehicle of all time".

Either I need to get out more, or they do.

author: andres3
text:
Shoot, I anticipated the $100,000 dollar Dodge Demon more than the Model 3.

I would never buy one for fear of being out-raced by a reliable Prius as my Demon has some type of disabling malfunction. Of course, a demon might be faster than a Prius in LIMP mode.

My Neon didn't have a LIMP mode, that I know of, perhaps it needed one!

author: andres3
text: I saw one of those Subaru SVX's with the funny glass today. White paint with brassy/goldish rims.

author: stickguy
