text: in a neighbors driveway, a new style Expedition. White. Sharper looking than the old one, but still a real barge.

author: kyfdx
text:
My next door neighbor has a new Suburban.. traded in his Tahoe.

It's yyyuuuuuuggeee!!

author: stickguy
text:
not sure what year, but merging onto the PA turnpike, a snazzy red Nissan GTR. Sounded good going by.

A Kia Niro, also on the highway. Nie looking in person.

And parked at the supermarket, an Alfa Stelvia

author: fintail
text: Saw a Velar today. Haven't seen as many as I once thought, Lexus RX rules that roost here.

author: Michaell
text: Surprisingly, the Velar is way too expensive for what you get. May be out of the budget for the Stepford wife set in the Pacific NW.

author: fintail
text: Budgets can be insane here, I think the Model X is still the ne plus ultra of Stepfordmobiles, along with maybe a top spec Range Rover. Maybe they like the Evoque if they want that kind of thing, although that seems like a spoiled co-ed kind of vehicle. One can't turn around without seeing a new style RX here.

author: Michaell
text: Seen any of the RX-L models yet?

author: fintail
text: I haven't noticed one, but I haven't studied it. I assume it is mostly a rear quarter proportion difference, not sure if they have a badge. When they arrive, I know I will see one. They are seriously everywhere here, and the dealer is just several blocks from where I live.

author: fintail
text: I mention the lack of Velar yesterday, what do I see today - another Velar.

author: fintail
text: Saw a Quadrifoglio on the road today.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Pretty pricey at...what.....$75K ? Very nice vehicle, but don't keep it past the warranty period.

author: Michaell
text: They start in the high 50's, but can go to almost $90K, depending on trim and options

author: fintail
text:
90K, I'd rather get a nice CPO AMG G-Wagen.

There's something off about the rear quarter view of the Velar. I'd rather have the big boy Range Rover.

author: Michaell
text: After test riding in one, I would agree with you. The Velar is pretty tight in the rear seat.

author: fintail
text: Saw a Rolls-Royce Wraith coupe in traffic today - might not be brand new, but uncommon. Also saw that the local Jag/Land Rover dealer has a MB Metris shuttle van.

author: fintail
text:
Saw a Model 3 today. It's a car.

I might have seen two, but I suspect I saw the same car twice (dark blue grey kind of color, dark wheels).

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Tesla lost 771 million bucks last quarter.

author: fintail
text: Less than expected, for me anyway.

author: stickguy
text: and the stock price soared. Because sales and gross revenue went up a bunch.

author: fintail
text: We lose money with every sale, but make up for it with volume.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Ah, I see. Lose money on every individual sale but make it all up in volume! Of course, how stupid of me not to see that.

author: berri
text: I wonder how these EV batteries will hold up over time in extremely cold or hot climates?

author: fintail
text: Was at Costco yesterday, and the "new car" on display was an Infiniti QX50. With the Lexus LS finally updated, is this the oldest new car still in production? I think it dates back to MY 2007.

author: texases
text: Could well be. Just saw one this morning in the parking lot.

author: texases
text: Edit - what about the Lexus GX 470?

author: fintail
text: I think the current GX was a MY 2010 debut, definitely an oldie now.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
A Honda Civic Type R parked right near my house. Naturally I called the police.

I gotta say, in that long row of somewhat anonymous SUVs and sedans, it certainly jumps out at you.

author: ab348
text: Worst thing is, you can't unsee it.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Wait, let me close my eyes for a second here.......you know, you're right. I still see it.

author: fushigi
text: Well the QX50 is basically new. New underpinnings courtesy of MB). New engine with first-ever variable compression ratio.

author: texases
text: That's the 2019 model, not at dealers yet (at least near me, they only have 2017 models). I guess they're skipping 2018.

author: laurasdada
text: Not new, but a shiny, black Caddy ELR. Good looking car, maybe they could revive/re-price it with a performance-oriented engine and call it a CTS Coupe?

author: fushigi
text: The 2019 QX50 has a spring 2018 release planned so yeah, skipping 2018. But coming soon.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: New Chevy Bolt, being driven by what appeared to be an Oompa Loompa.

author: laurasdada
text: Egads, a second ELR, in white!

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: The Electric/Hybrid Cimarron? Man, Cadillac had their nerve putting that price tag on that thing.

author: fintail
text: You can easily find ELRs for under 25K now.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: They were like..what?....$70K when new? All you got was a Volt with nicer upholstery.

author: fintail
text: And brash kind of cool styling, to be fair.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: It was a good looking car, that's very true. But then, what is more of a wasted effort than a car that looks like something it isn't?

author: fintail
text: Isn't that the name of the game these days, with so many overstyled or overcladded cars? Even the once-subtle high end brands are in on it.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Well true to some extent. There are "off-roaders" you wouldn't dare take off-road, but the ELR is like buying a new Corvette with a Volt engine---not that the Volt isn't a great little car, but not for THAT kind of money.

author: berri
text: Several years ago I was passed by an ELR. I recall it had 4 tailpipes and an artificial exhaust noise. I guess you really can't get that old time OHV growl out of an OHC engine, so enter electronics

author: kyfdx
text: That's weird. You sure it wasn't a CTS coupe?

author: berri
text: No it was one of those squarish Cadillac sports cars that resembled a Corvette somewhat. Maybe it had some other designation, but it was definitely wearing Cadillac badges.

author: fintail
text:
XLR:



Think of it as a Corvette in a fitted suit.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: ELR:

author: kyfdx
text: CTS Coupe.. I think they look a lot alike..

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Cadillac sure has some baffling nomenclature.

author: berri
text: XLR it was! Odd little thing.

author: laurasdada
text:
Yup, price the ELR new at ~$50k and Caddy might have sold more than 11 of 'em. Good looking car, and yes, used '14 under $30k around here in Boston. If I wanted a Volt, and practicality wasn't a high priority, perhaps a consideration.

Isn't it great that Caddy learns from it's pricing mistakes on their "halo" cars: Allante, XLR & ELR. All stupidly priced. Among whatever shortfalls each may have had...

author: tifighter
text: Interior of the ELR was a step above other Caddys as well. Pretty nice, actually.

author: fintail
text: Saw 2x AMG GT and a Lexus LC in traffic today.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: True but for DOUBLE the price of a Volt?!!

author: explorerx4
text: A red Alfa Stelvio.

author: fintail
text: Someone in my building just turned up in a new TLX A-spec

author: stickguy
text: the TLX is just a really nice package. Maybe not quite as dynamic driving as some of the Euros, but overall for performance, tech, comfort, and certainly value, hard to beat. Great seats and stereo and really quick, and basically, that is all you really need!

author: fintail
text: Lots of value for sure, I think they even lease well. This one is white with black wheels - the latter making it not what I would choose. I wonder how it rides on some of the roads here.

author: stickguy
text: I did not drive an A Spec like GG and Pens have, but I did try the V6 standard model. Rode and handled just fine, and on 17" wheels, plenty of sidewall. A good compromise I think.

author: fintail
text: Unless the highline models have adjustable suspension with a "comfort" mode, something with smaller wheels might be more agreeable. It's not a track car.

author: fintail
text: New Costco car today was an XC90 - I didn't look at the sticker as don't care.

author: tjc78
text: Proof they actually sold one

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Ford F-150 4X4. I felt like I was parking next to the Lusitania. I could look through my passenger window and read the tire size.

author: fintail
text: I think I've actually seen 2 Cascada.

author: qbrozen
text: Tiny compared to the chromed out F250 dually I saw for sale today by the side of the road.

author: texases
text: Don't get too close, gravity takes over...

author: stickguy
text:
I saw a Cascadia on the highway not long ago. Owner what I expected.

F150? Worst for me was when I had the Miata and got next to a Semi on the highway, and was staring at the lugnuts. The bottom ones. Only saving grace is I could probably drive right underneath the darned trailer.

author: berri
text: I got an F-150 a couple of years ago as a dealer service rental. Didn't want it, but it was the only thing they had available. I was surprised how nicely it rode, but it was awful huge for me. I don't think I was cut out to drive a semi

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Funniest part was when I got back to my car, the owner of the F150 was "loading it up"---with one piece of rolled up window screening. I was hoping he'd doff some heavy work gloves and wipe the sweat from his brow. I don't expect we'll be seeing him hauling a bed full of gravel anytime soon. Maybe after that rig gets a few dings.

author: ab348
text:
Stumbled on this page of exoticar photos from Rodeo Drive/Beverly Hills/SoCal on a buildings forum.

A totally different world...

http://www.skyscrapercity.com/showthread.php?t=1507459&page=8

author: texases
text: One of these things is not like the others...

author: explorerx4
text:
@Mr_Shiftright,
I was leaning toward a Mini, but you keep reporting problems with yours, so I went with another F150.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: If I had explorer's truck, I'd crush that thing---just because I *could*.

author: fintail
text: Nice grille, as most of these were air cooled.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Hand-crafted from the finest recycled beer cans.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I only "spotted" this photo of the new GMC Sierra, but am I being cruel or is this truck rather....ahem....unattractive?

author: stickguy
text: seems that new PUs are intentionally being made overly aggressive like that now. Ram had a few nasty ones too. Toyota, no surprise, went a bit off the deep end too.

author: stickguy
text:
saw quite a few new style odysseys. Side view looks like a slightly cleaned up prior version, but the back end is much different. Looks a lot more "squished" down, and quite a bit like a Pacifica. Making them low and rakish kinda defeats the purpose of a minivan.

and at target, a new Accord parked in the front row. Really noticed this one, in white, because in the spot it just looked enormous.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Reminds me of those old boom-boxes

author: fintail
text: Lots of grille on that thing.

author: berri
text:
I wonder if that GMC has to wear headgear at night in conjunction with all that orthodontia?

Love the boom box, but think it fits latter Pontiac's even better

author: ab348
text: Like the brutalist architecture that often seemed to be used on public buildings in the '60s and '70s.

author: fintail
text: Designs meant to intimidate, whether it be the overconfident truck driver or the omnipotent state employee/judge/politico. I am waiting for a resurgence of fascist neoclassic architecture for public spaces any day now.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
I was going to say--that building could have come right out of Albert Speer's playbook. Unlike today's pickup trucks, though, which are designed to enhance the size and power of the driver, these types of neo-fascist architecture are meant to make the individual feel small and insignificant in relation to the power of the state.

Of course, one could argue that modern pickup trucks are also designed to be intimidating.

author: berri
text: Then you've got the PU with the marker lights on the roof, dual rear tire axle and diesel. No semi driver fantasy there, but they [non-permissible content removed] about fuel mileage

author: ab348
text: Locally I am seeing a lot of newish GMC 4x4 pickups that are equipped the same way: a lift kit, oversized wheels and tires and an aftermarket exhaust. Almost always black paint too. It's strange that it is mostly GMCs I am seeing this way - the occasional Ford or Ram but not many by comparison. Perhaps a local dealer has found a market for them modified that way. They certainly do seem intimidating.

author: fintail
text: Many drivers of those I encounter are Walter Mitty types, doesn't intimidate me much

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
It'll be interesting to see if buying habits change when gas hits $4 a gallon here in CA--which I think is coming sooner rather than later. Gas buddy says the "average" price for premium in San Francisco is $3.45 today.

At 15 mpg, if you're commuting, that's gotta start to hurt.

author: laurasdada
text: $2.70/gal premium at Costco south of Boston (Ironically?, a quarter mile from the Tesla store...). Has been holding steady in the $2.60-2.70 range for a while. .20-.24/gallon cheaper than my "low cost" comparison stations a couple of miles away.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
I usually pick California as a bellwether for shifts in buying habits because it is such a huge market. Automakers can't ignore it. If gas prices spike, you can often find really good deals on gas hogs. I think fear works as decisively in the car market as it does in the stock market.

Might boost EV sales, too, which are rather tepid at best.

author: fintail
text:
I think the only plus of price spikes is seeing drivers of large engined gasoline truck and SUVs moan and groan.

With the current regime, I shudder to think what stupidity could lead to issues.

author: explorerx4
text: I red Model X, not a great color for it Also, a medium metallic blue XC90. Usually I only see black, silver or white.

author: stickguy
text: my neighbor has a white one.

author: explorerx4
text: Another red Tesla, a Model S, New plate. One of the rear trunk lights was filled with condensation and wasn't working.

author: Michaell
text: I saw that color at the Volvo dealer I was visiting yesterday. Very striking, and, with the amber interior, a gorgeous combination.

author: fintail
text: Stopped by the MB dealer for a lookie-loo today, An E43 (not E63) with an 88K MSRP made me wince.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Wince further:

https://www.caranddriver.com/reviews/2018-mercedes-amg-e63-s-wagon-test-review?src=nl&mag=cdb&list=nl_dvr_news&date=030518

author: fintail
text:
I can believe it. The prior generation could easily get into the 120s, and this has a lot more tech. This is the new belle epoque, or at best, welcome to 1928. I'd rather do this than a loaded Model X anyway.

With the no doubt huge margins on these cars, I wonder if the makers could absorb some tariff costs, or just pass them on, should stable genius succeed with his witless bluster.

author: Michaell
text:
Just for grins, I went to the website and built my own E63S wagon. I was judicious with the options, and ended up at just over $117K.

If the lottery numbers were ever to hit, I'd be interested. Keep it a subdued color, skip the "look at me" black rims, and the only thing to give you away would be the quad exhaust. Total sleeper that would give most supercars a run for their money.

Mustang GT's and Camaro SS's? Leave 'em in the dust.

author: fintail
text: Depreciation is fun on those, too. Here's one at 6 years old - this one is quite loaded, and I have no doubt was well past 120K when new.

author: ab348
text:
With apologies to J.P. Morgan, if you have to worry about depreciation, you probably shouldn't buy one.

I wonder how it ended up at a Chevy dealer?

author: fintail
text:
Yep, same thing goes for fuel prices and maintenance in general. The letters "AMG" are key.

No plates, I suspect an auction deal. This seller had a rare W211 E63 AMG sedan a few years ago, someone there must seek these cars.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: You might have to practice first. Mashing a 600 HP gas pedal is tricky.

author: Michaell
text: That I would agree with. Wonder if I could get the Air Force to lend me the use of the runway at Buckley AFB?

author: fintail
text: For as quick as most MBs depreciate, these sure take their sweet time

author: ab348
text: I wish I could understand the attraction of the G-Wagen. For all of its considerable bulk, rear seat legroom does not appear to be its strong suit according to those pics.

author: fintail
text:
I suspect these have but 1-2 occupants 99% of the time. No third row, either.

This thing would have MSRP'd at 155K or so when new, not a huge discount for 3 years.

author: qbrozen
text: And overpriced at that. $46k max, IMHO

author: fintail
text: And with those miles. Now if it had half the mileage, 5K less price, and a different color interior, it would be pushing my buttons, as it appears to be a virtually full option car, and 212s wear white well.

author: kyfdx
text:
I saw my first Tesla Model 3, in the wild (Nashville, in this case).
Not as ugly as the pictures, but not nearly as attractive as the Model S.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: They really messed up the nose on the Model 3. Looks like an old Panhard.

author: fintail
text: Nah, this is actually cooler:

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Panhard makes only armored vehicles now for various militarys around the world.

author: texases
text: I followed a new Volvo S90 in traffic. Can't say the rear end does much for me, kind of blocky:

author: iluvmysephia1
text: That Volvo S90 rear end almost calls to mind some late-model Mopar product packaging.

author: explorerx4
text:
I saw this the other day.
Dodge Charger with black rims, not so unusual.
It was painted a green called 'Tank', which I have only seen on Wranglers.

author: fintail
text: Someone at work has turned up in a new narrow-eyed/Infiniti-eyed SL, unsure of model but not an AMG. Not sure if I am a fan of the new face, as it is really Infiniti-like to me (not knocking Infiniti, but it is just too close).

author: ab348
text: That's sort of Olive Drab, ins't it? Was the Charger given a gloss finish or flat?

author: ab348
text: Was behind an Alfa 4C coupe in traffic today, the first I've seen here since we don't have an Alfa dealer yet. Was white instead of the typical red color. Raucous exhaust note. Rear window that was clear for maybe the area of a small cookie sheet. Didn't look like it would be fun to drive in city traffic. Certainly stood out though.

author: explorerx4
text:
@ad348,
The paint has a gloss to it, not flat. Works better on a Jeep, not so well on a Charger.

author: fintail
text: Newbies on the road - unplated Ferrari FF, yellow G-Wagen 4x4/squared, new style Lexus LS.

author: andres3
text: So in States like CA where you can go a month or two or 3 without a license plate by buying a new car every 3 months, that will be my method to stay off the grid if I win the lottery.

author: fintail
text: If I win a powerball, I won't be doing most of my driving around here

text: Saw a new style E63 wagon on the road tonight, probably the same one I saw in the showroom a couple months ago.

text: Ford Ecosport in Grey. Because people look at the Fiesta and think, it would be better with a lift.

text: I think Ford has some product issues and it is not self driving or electrics. They need to get back to what brings in the cash and start dealing with aging product lines.

author: fintail
text: Saw a recently plated Maserati convertible today, yellow with a black top and kind of beige/tan interior - not my first choices.

author: berri
text: You are a Bellevue man, so it is only time before you're tooling around in an expensive SUV or large crossover that sticks in everyone's face. They do it in the wealthier suburbs throughout America

author: fintail
text:
I'm happy in my relatively anonymous (especially for this area) E-class, it suits me. I'm not one of those Bellevue-ites.

However, if I was to get an SUV, it would be a G-Wagen. The thought has crossed my mind, especially with the high depreciation floor, and our decaying roads.

author: fintail
text: Got behind a Model 3 in traffic while I was in the fintail. Meh - but at least it didn't have an obnoxious personalized plate. Also saw a blacked out Bentayga in a very nice neighborhood, what would Marie Antoinette drive?

author: tjc78
text:
Yeah Ive seen about 5 in the last week.  I liked it in pictures but now in the flesh not so much.   Same deal with its cousin the new Enclave.   Nothing special for the money.  Im sure it drives nice and is competitive but I think they could have done more with the looks. 

Makes me kind of happy I grabbed the last of the prior generation.

author: Michaell
text:
Yeah Ive seen about 5 in the last week.  I liked it in pictures but now in the flesh not so much.   Same deal with its cousin the new Enclave.   Nothing special for the money.  Im sure it drives nice and is competitive but I think they could have done more with the looks. 

Makes me kind of happy I grabbed the last of the prior generation. 

Funny, my ex has the Enclave on her short list for a new SUV in the not-too-distant future.

text: Its a great vehicle and gorgeous inside.  My wife and I just preferred the looks of the outgoing model.  I havent driven one but Id assume it drives similar to ours which is a good thing.

Got behind a black sedan today. Had no clue what it was unless I got closer. A new Accord, that make 2.
Think back of the previous generation looks better.

author: qbrozen
text: 4-hr rental that crashed at 1:30am. I'd expect both the company and the clientelle of such rentals to keep more reasonable hours.

author: andres3
text:
I like how he blames the tires. Would be amazing if we could have sophisticated simulations give him 10 different brands and types of tires, all in random stages of wear.

I have a feeling he'd crash in 99.99% of these simulations.

author: berri
text: The car is cracked and perhaps he was too

author: fintail
text: The LEO seems to blame the driver with maybe just a little well-deserved snark. Good luck blaming the tires. Reminds me of the M4 driver in the viral Youtube video who overcooked it pulling out of a cars and coffee style meet, and blamed tire pressure.

author: kyfdx
text:
I-5 is pretty straight through that tunnel, isn't it?

I'll guess he was going pretty fast and made a twitchy maneuver

author: fintail
text: It's straight at Olive, but coming out of a gentle curve, which could have been the start of the problems at triple digit speeds and wet roads. It'd be interesting to know the insurance situation.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: "A man has got to know his limitations".

author: andres3
text:
If you want to drive fast on wet roads, get an Audi.

If you want to end up on YouTube get a high-powered 2WD car.

I'm sure someone will now link me to some Audi FAIL videos?

author: qbrozen
text: well, as I know you know, no car can defy physics. AWD just means all wheels spinning frantically when you overcome the traction of the tires.

author: andres3
text: As @Mr_Shiftright stated, "know your limits"

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Correct---all AWD does is allow you to accelerate better. It does nothing for "handling" or "braking" per se, unless the dynamics of acceleration are in play. And once tire limits are met, ain't nothin' gonna save you.

author: andres3
text:
So once you point the car in the right direction, you can accelerate out of trouble better.

I remember the Audi S4's vectoring sport rear diff would argue with you though. That feature definitely gave the heavy car more handling capability to power through turns, if you so choosed to do, but man would you burn up those front tires fast. Sort of a simultaneous under and over-steer situation.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Well, maybe, if acceleration is the right thing to do in the situation, and if your tires permit it. Unlike older AWD, modern AWD cars with all the computer controls are nearly impossible to get into awkward situations, but if you do exceed the car's cornering limits, it's going to be all the harder for most drivers to recover an AWD car.

author: fintail
text: Saw a Model 3 on the road, I think this makes #4, or approximately 15% of production so far.

author: texases
text: Saw a Model X, had just been rear ended. Ouch.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Please choose the best excuse you are comfortable with.

1.But....but....this is just a minor production issue...
2. Elon wants to make sure every car is done right, so he's having them made very slowly..
3. There are hundreds of thousands coming any day now...you just wait.

author: fintail

author: stickguy
text: Dude around corner from me seems to have gotten rid of his MB CLA (I assume was a lease). Now has a Range Rover velar. Big imposing beast, especially in black. But good looking.

author: fintail
text:
2 Model 3s today, I think one was the same one from yesterday.

Also saw a C63S coupe which sounded dirty in a good way.

author: fintail
text: Went to the Vancouver Auto Show today - sat in a C wagon, it was as good as expected. Also saw a Lambo Uterus (I know), couple of Koenigseggggggggs, new Corolla hatch, X2, LWB RR Phantom, Cadillac Escala concept, some other new models.

author: iluvmysephia1
text: I do like that new 2019 Toyota Corolla hatchback. It is available with a six-speed manual, keeping it in the game.

author: fintail
text:
Here's a pic from the show for you, iluv:



I have to give credit to Toyota for making something like this in today's market.

author: iluvmysephia1
text: I liked the Toyota Corolla hatchback's predecessor, the Scion iM/Toyota Corolla iM, too. Both cars would make a good replacement for the 2011 Kia Soul, but Kia makes such a durable car our 98,875 current mileage is likely just the beginning of a long relationship.

author: fushigi
text:
It'll be interesting to see it next to the 201HP Elantra hatch, also available with a 6MT (Europe gets a 275HP performance package).

The Corolla has 168, which is pretty good for the size and probably better for economy. But likely won't be nearly as much fun; I think it'll miss getting the hot hatch designation.

author: Michaell
text:
Warm Hatch, perhaps?

I saw where Top Gear tested the Hyundai i30 N - the 270HP version of the Elantra GT. They really liked it.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: A Mini Cooper S has about the same HP as the Corolla, and it's pretty peppy. Of course, it has either a supercharger or turbo depending on year.

author: Michaell
text:
My Jetta only has 150 HP, but because it has a turbo, it too feels pretty good when I exercise my right foot.

If it's naturally aspirated, then all bets are off.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Looks like that Corolla is a 1.8L DOHC with variable valve timing, but yeah, it is a NA engine.

author: iluvmysephia1
text:
2019 Toyota Corolla hatchback


I think Toyota pretty much hit it right out of the park with the new Corolla hatch. The sedan is another story, though I need the info. on that one moreso before I'd even comment on it. One thing odd or even annoying about the '19 Corolla hatch is that Toyota left out Android Auto but includes Apple CarPlay. Humm...Toyota, why did you do that?

If I did get a wild hair one fine day about buying a Toyota Corolla hatchback, I wouldn't let the lack of Android Auto get in the way, however. I notice a whole pallet of other electronic goodies included, including what ought ta be obligatory these days, a USB connection on the dash somewhere.

author: qbrozen
text: Credit for copying the mazda3 14 years late? Why?

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: One small step for a Corolla, one giant leap for Toyota-kind.

author: iluvmysephia1
text: Love that, shifty! I really like the new '19 Toyota Corolla hatchback.

author: fintail
text:
Exactly what Shifty said. Credit is relative to the blandboxes Toyota has been plying us with for 20 years. This probably won't rust like an early Mazda3, too

I still suspect 95% of sales will be trunkback Corolla, and it will still be a magnet for those who don't care much for cars nor driving.

author: texases
text:
Toyota's been selling hatchbacks pretty much everywhere but the US, so no 'copying' involved. US just doesn't like them much, unless it's a CUV.

Saw my first Tesla 3, reminded me of those horror shows where the character has no mouth...

author: fintail
text:
The mouthless facelifted Teslas remind me of "Twilight Zone, The Movie", with the mouthless girl.

My boss just got a new E400 wagon (her husband works for MB on the IT side, and they get it on an insane sweetheart employee lease). Nice car, the ICE requires learning coming from a 2013 Forester.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Never order an E400 wagon in black--the resemblance to a hearse is just too close.

author: fintail
text: Here is dark blue with brown interior, similar (different blue) to my car. Pretty sharp with the contrast with the chrome/silver bits, but not the boring black on black that has been trendy for a long time.

author: stickguy
text: another Elantra sport. Dark gray though. Did not realize it had such a nice growl/snarl sound when stomped on until the guy driving it goosed it in a parking lot to get around someone.

author: tjc78
text: Saw a black one at the diner the other night. Pointed it out to my wife and said it was the hot rod version of my car.... quote looks the same. Ugh.

author: stickguy
text: well, a GTI looks like a Golf. Still not the same.

author: Michaell
text: And a GLI looks like my Jetta. Having tested one, it is not the same.

author: stickguy
text: I drove the Elantra sport and a base one almost back to back. And trust me, other than the body, there is very little in common!

author: stickguy
text:
parked at shop rite, a Stelvio. Nice looking. But that over styled angled rear that likely leads to disappointingly small cargo capacity.

and 2 new Sube Crosstreks. Both bright blue. Not that color, but I really do like this car. Just need to get some more power in the poor thing.

author: fintail
text: Saw another Model 3 today, it's a car.

author: kyfdx
text: Tesla X, yesterday.. No bueno

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Tesla is being rocked lately by some rather unfortunate developments:

1. Based on information from current and former Tesla employees, Kolodny reported that several machine shops in the Fremont CA area are now being tasked with reworking defective parts for the Models S, X, and 3. The article includes photos of large stacks of parts in the yard of one of the machine shops.

2. CoverDrives GAAP forecast is for a loss of $648 million in Q3 and $545 million in Q4 of 2018. (note: GAAP is only one way of calculation, and Musk uses another metric).

3. Last year, several plaintiffs filed a lawsuit called Wochos, et al. v. Tesla, Inc., et al. in California federal court. The thrust of the suit is that the defendants knew mass production of the Model 3 during 2017 was impossible, and also knew Tesla could never achieve the rate of 5,000 per week by year end, but all the same stated repeatedly that Tesla would be able to do so. This amounts, say the plaintiffs, to actionable securities fraud and breach of fiduciary duty. (note: There is a petition to make this a Class Action for all Tesla shareholders, but not yet granted).

Nonetheless, Tesla's stock price, while not near the heady days of yesteryear, isn't that far off the mark of this time last year. It is, however, getting beat up today a bit.

author: kyfdx
text:
GAAP

Generally Accepted Accounting Principles

In other words... real numbers.

author: ab348
text: For most of my working career GAAP was gospel. Then suddenly about 8 or 9 years ago it was replaced with IFRS (International Financial Reporting Standards), and another set of standards called ASPE (Accounting Standard for Private Enterprise) also emerged. So they could either be losing money, losing a lot of money, or losing a whole lot of money.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Yeah, the real numbers thingie.

On April 13, Tesla CEO Elon Musk tweeted an acknowledgement that Tesla had over-automated its production lines and underestimated the value of human workers in auto assembly.

" We had this crazy, complex network of conveyor belts.And it was not working, so we got rid of that whole thing.

!!!!! Wow, did investors read that?

I think 2018 is the turning point for Tesla. If they can scale up and declare a profit for Q4, then the Tesla dream might actually come true---if not, then I think time has run out.

Yeah, I know the theory that Tesla can keep burning investor cash as long as they keep throwing it at him, but he's losing a half-billion a quarter! That's not chump change.

author: kyfdx
text: If they have to turn a profit in the 4th quarter, this year, they should just quit now. No chance of that.. not even on an EBITDA basis.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Tesla is apparently carrying a lot of debt.

Another problem is that his $35,000 Model 3 is actually a $55,000 Model 3 by the time you get it out the door. Tesla isn't building any $35,000 Model 3s at the moment.

author: kyfdx
text:
The biggest problem is: It is an unattractive lump of a car for $50K. Surely, a Tesla could compete in that price range, along with the Kia Stinger?
And, they have the Model S to compare it to, which is a beauty in comparison.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Well I hope it's better in reliability than a Model S. It sure isn't in beauty.

I thought I'd be seeing more Model 3s in the Bay Area here, but I haven't. I've spotted maybe 3 or 4. I see more Ss.

Wall St. says Tesla will need up to $5 billion in new money to continue. A bond issue is out, given the company's existing debt, so it will have to come from a dilutive stock offering.

I'm anxious to see the New Wave of EVs but sometimes I wonder:

Could the entire EV "thing" turn into one big bust?

Perhaps the subject of another topic.

author: stickguy
text: I suspect I represent many people. I would never get a pure EV, but would be just fine with something like a Volt. Heck, I am probably the prototypical buyer for one of those.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I like the Volt--and you can charge it up on 110V overnight, so in theory if you never drive more than 50 miles a day you will never buy gasoline. And yet, it's got a regular engine if/when you need it. And it's not ugly and doesn't cost $55,000.

author: fushigi
text:
The Volt and other PHEVs make the most sense to me today. I wouldn't rule out a pure EV but think that a lot of charging infrastructure & improvements in battery tech would have to come about before I would take the plunge.

Right now I can go to any gas station and in under 15 minutes be set with 350+ miles of fuel. Until an EV can meet or beat that, or at least come really close, I will only be interested in them at an academic level.

author: explorerx4
text:
This is a what?
https://worcester.craigslist.org/cto/d/1970-international-travelette/6552352384.html

author: qbrozen
text: I want a Volt with Tesla performance.

author: texases
text: Saw a new 911 today, been 'sanitized' with no ID on the rear deck (no '911', nothing). Why do that? Now some less-informed folks might assume it's a Cayman...

author: andres3
text: I heard the Tesla didn't do so hot around the "Ring."

author: qbrozen
text: Good thing I don't commute there

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Why? All you're paying double the MSRP for, is batteries and weight, so you can go 0-60 in 3 seconds rather than 6 seconds (about what a Chevy Bolt can do). The range of the Bolt and the base Tesla S or Model 3 is about the same. (240-ish). You could just buy a Volt and a Mustang GT for the price of a loaded up Model S, and have money left over for a cruise around the world.

There comes a point when EVs become pointless. Most Americans never drive 200+ miles in a day, and there are many affordable gasoline cars that can move out very smartly. An EV is best suited as a metro car and a day-tripper. It excels at that.

author: texases
text: EVs have somehow acquired this 'salvation of the environment' label. Folks should read a Scientific American article a few years ago about how that's not true, when compared to regular hybrids, in about half the US. And that's just on a CO2 emissions basis, ignoring the battery costs ($$ and environmental). This is because of the CO2 from coal-powered electricity.

author: stickguy
text: that is a seriously long truck. must have the turning radius of a cruise ship.

author: berri
text: I'm thinking that IH pickup is either some kind of home modified vehicle, or maybe something that used to ride on the railroad tracks. Never saw one like that.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: EVs are like that--the faster they go, the slower they get.

author: fintail
text: Saw another Model 3 today, and a S63 or S65 (hard to tell from a distance in the rain) cabrio.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Spotted a 2018 Prius C at Trader Joe's---I'm not sure I get the point of this vehicle. At least $5K more than the Yaris it is based on, with almost the same MPG (just a few more), and from peeking inside, not nearly as much interior room compared to a full-size Prius. ???

author: qbrozen
text: Oh I dont mean the top spec. I was thinking more like a base Model 3. If they would make the Volt as quick as the Bolt, that would be pretty close.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Yeah, the Bolt is about 2.5 seconds faster than the Volt, 0-60, and about the same as the Model 3 base model.

Really, fast acceleration costs a lot of money in an EV. And given the Volt's short EV range, of only 50 miles, you'd use up your yippies pretty fast I'd imagine.

author: kyfdx
text:
Its an actual option: model delete.

I like it. They put so much crap on the back now. None is better than a lot.
Actually, 911 on the rear is a relatively new phenomenon. That was gone from 84 until recently.

author: Michaell
text:
+1.

Even though most of my driving is around town and less than 50 miles, I'm still leery. I've got a friend who bought a used i3, and I'm listening to him comment on the pros and cons of his ownership experience.

author: Michaell
text:
When I was delivering pizza as a side gig, I test drove a Prius C, figuring the 50 MPG would be good.

I don't think I could have lived with it every day. Very tinny, and only a 10 gallon gas tank.

I still think a Volt would hit the sweet spot.

author: fintail
text:
A friend of mine had a Prius C. He liked it so much he'd park it under trees, hoping a tree would fall on it. I am not joking. The second he was above water, he traded it.

I know someone else with one, too, but they are a cheapskate wanting the most economical (yet reliable) transportation possible, and they drive the doors off it.

author: ab348
text:
On Sunday I swung by the closed-for-the-day Honda dealer just to get a look at the new Accord for the first time. I still have not seen any on the roads here. They had about 10 of them on the back row, a mix of Sport, EXL and Touring trims.

These cars are very large. Very low too. The center console is Taurus-wide. The rear legroom is limo-like. Some had the bright chrome unibrow up front which looked a little garish while others had it in a black chrome finish which was a little better. Flashy wheels on all of them. The Sport models all had black cloth upholstery and their interiors looked rather cave-like. There was a single Touring model there with an ivory leather interior which looked far better than another one with black leather. I believe it was also the only one there with the 2.0T engine. I wonder just how well these will sell compare to the previous models. I think they are just too big. The lot inventory seemed to be about 90% Civics and CRVs.

author: texases
text: Last I heard new Accord sales are down 17% from last year. Some due to the CUV craze, but some must be because of the new car's styling.

author: texases
text: I followed a new Audi TT/S in this morning, first one I've seen in a long while. Not nearly as popular as when the TT first came out.

author: kyfdx
text:
High prices, no incentives, terrible lease program.

I think they forgot that no one buys sedans, any more.
Once the incentives hit, I'd guess sales will normalize. They finally dropped the money factor for April, but I'd guess more incentives on the horizon.

author: stickguy
text: Discovered today that there is an almost complete Tesla showroom going in near me. Hope it isnt short lived! Might have to stop n someday.

author: explorerx4
text:
A new Accord in the parking lot at work.
Gray with darker wheels. Putting a plate on the front changes the look a lot.
It was parked next to a gray Fusion, not mine, and the from the door handles up there is a lot of similarity.
Not a fan of the rear lights design.

author: kyfdx
text:
Genesis G90, in black..

Sort of awkward looking..

author: stickguy
text: I am really interested in seeing the new one. g70?

author: fintail
text: Not new, but unusual - an Evoque cabrio. Top down, people in it, not ducking to avoid being seen.

author: kyfdx
text: No self-awareness. Inveterate nose pickers too, I bet.

author: explorerx4
text: Walked by a Kia Niro. Kind of looked like some kind of Mini, to me.

author: stickguy
text: a Kia Electric soul.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
A new Jaguar XJ-L.

It''s big, black and expensive. Couldn't tell if it was the V-6 or the V8. Is there script on the trunk or something?

author: qbrozen
text: Same sighting here! Except with top up. I even snapped a pic.

author: fintail
text: I bet they've sold at least a dozen of them. Maybe for the CrossCabrio owner who wants a new car.

author: PF_Flyer
text: Not often that Willie Wonka uses the McLaren to go get the groceries, but he did today

author: fintail
text: Saw what looked like a high spec new Lexus LS in traffic today, with BMW-esque turn signal usage.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
A Tesla Model 3 with a flat black wrap---hey, don't shoot the messenger!

Not sure what the hell the owner was thinking--he seems confused on the concept.

"Got my bad EV,
For the world to see..."

Marin county--the birth of Rap.

author: explorerx4
text: In the parking lot at work, a new grey Tuscon(interesting front end) and a white Chevy Equinox.

author: tjc78
text: Saw my first Stinger today. Nice Blue color.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I have to say that even some of the hard-butted reviewers have been heaping praise on the Stinger, at least in terms of its tech, and its bang for the buck.

author: iluvmysephia1
text: Once you open up your eyes to the Kia product, study what you're getting, drive, enjoy and reap the great fruitage of that South Korean carmaker, you will heap praise upon them, too. Only it's not just because of the new Stinger, I have owned three Kia's and have felt very well-treated by each one of them.

author: ab348
text:
Met a friend for lunch today and we rendezvoused at the dealer where I got my ATS since he was there to do some business. On the lot they had a new Cadillac CT6 Twin Turbo Premium Luxury sedan stickered at about $80K Cdn. Man, what an impressive car. Bigger than I realized.

Also looked at the first new Buick Regal I've seen and was less impressed. Looks are kind of awkward and the seats in this one looked cheap with cloth inserts. Disappointed.

author: andres3
text:
And you never paid $40K or $50K for a Kia before either. I think the Stinger will languish. But only the sales will tell the true story.

Have your Kias been cheap to maintain, or do you avoid dealerships?

author: fintail
text:
Stinger could end up being a used bargain, or even a lease bargain if sales are slow. No more 10K ADMS out there, I suspect.

Regarding the Regal, this is more weirdo GM model positioning. The Insignia is not a particularly premium product in the home market, rather just a nice larger car - think of it as a German Impala rather than competing with near-lux. GM has been trying to sell the large Opel as a premium offering here, off and on for more than 20 years now, with marginal success.

author: Michaell
text:
My 2003 Saturn L300 had some European DNA in it, I believe.

And, having sat in the new Regal at the Auto Show, I too was disappointed. I really wanted to like it, but I couldn't.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Yes I agree. The Stinger will be a nice scoop in a used car in 2-3 years. Maybe the 255HP 4 cylinder will sell well---we'll see. But an optioned up GT AWD could push $50K.

author: ab348
text:
New Lexus LS500 gets a mixed review from Cnet Roadshow - the infotainment system gets an F.

https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/auto/2018-lexus-ls-500/review/

author: andres3
text: $50K is what I gave the dealership before fees and taxes for my S4 in late 2013 for a '14 model. I also got a $1K off loyalty rebate that paid for a portion of those taxes and fees. I will forever benchmark a $50K car to that, and if that's the case, there must of been some crazy inflation in the last 4 years if Kia wants the same amount.

author: fintail
text: GT2 is around 52-53K MSRP now. It'll be interesting to see end of year sales and lease offers.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Well you should drive the GT. It may well be a match for the S4 in many respects. I can't say myself but reviewers are quite impressed with it. Doug DeMuro loved it, as did what's his name on "Engineering Explained". These are not easy reviewers either.

author: andres3
text:
I drove a RWD GT, it drove well, but the interior was a let down in my opinion. There were some design ideas I didn't like, such as the tiny rear window with a tiny rear view and rear-view mirror to go with it.

Kia is good at imitating the real thing, but it's still not the real thing. They are not quite "there" yet.

author: qbrozen
text:
Except you'd have to compare to A6 size.
Tough to compare properly performance-wise since the Kia falls in between the a6 3.0T and S6.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Reviewers seem to harp on the "value" aspect of the Stinger--the features and performance you get at that price point. You can certainly "beat" the Stinger's features with a German sedan, but you'll pay another $10K to do it, is the point I think.

It might be analogous to when the first Lexus LS came out. It's true it was "no Mercedes" but it was close enough to sell at the lower price.

author: ab348
text: Well, the Stinger seems to be glued to the pavement on most dealer lots. Something must not be resonating with buyers, either the price tag for the brand name or the perception of quality received for the price. I suspect the large size probably does it no favors either.

author: qbrozen
text:
I'd guess "it's a Kia" for one, and the other being that 95% of buyers have no idea why it is quite a bit more expensive than the virtually same-sized Optima sitting next to it.

I would imagine that is at least part of the reason why other manufacturers chose to split off a separate division. Nissan would probably never have had the success with the G35 they had if it were sitting next to the Maxima.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Yep, it's the "Kia" badge. It's like with the Tesla Model 3 vs. the Chevy Bolt. With that bowtie on the front, the Bolt just isn't attracting the EV cult, even though it is a match for the Model 3 in most respects, at a much lower price point.

I think the Bolt is selling fairly well, but there's certainly no "buzz" about it.

author: stickguy
text:
driving around, a new Accord. Distinctive tail end. Reminds me of some expensive car. just not sure which.

and in the showroom, a Hyundai Kona. Liked it!

author: Michaell
text:
Not just "it's a Kia" but also "It's a Kia dealer". Product may be great in so many ways, but the perception from the majority of the public is that Kia is where the credit challenged go, when all else fails.

Upgrade the facilities (which, has happened to the Kia dealer closest to me), and the buying process, and you might change the perception. Gonna take time, however.

author: stickguy
text: I refuse to step foot in either Kia dealer near me. The hyundai stores are fine.

author: ab348
text: Around here it is just the reverse. One of the Hyundai dealers in particular is about as bad as they get.

author: qbrozen
text: I have never been to a Kia dealer. Tried Hyundai once and would never go back there.

author: tjc78
text: I bought my Genesis and Elantra at Burns.  No complaints with either purchase.   Ive been treated worse at other dealers, thats for sure.

author: stickguy
text: Burns and the places in PA I used (particularly Faulkner) were really nice. Clean, friendly, honest. Everything you want in a car dealer really.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new Navigator this afternoon, definitely has a Range Rover look to it.

author: stickguy
text: I saw a new one too recently. Big imposing beast, but nicely styled for something in that class. Needless to say, the couple driving it looked wealthy!

author: qbrozen
text: I didn't mean all Hyundai dealers. Just the one I went to.

author: explorerx4
text: a black Ford Ecosport - looks like a jacked up Fiesta, which it is or a smaller version of a C Max..

author: tjc78
text:
Gotcha.  

Hell, there are plenty of sleazy dealers for every brand.

author: explorerx4
text:
When I bought my truck, the salesman tried to interest my wife in an Ecosport.
Little did he know she drives an MKC.
We kind of felt it was a bit stereotypical.

author: laurasdada
text: A Bentley Bentayga. Meh.

author: stickguy
text: Quite a few new style odyssey. Minivans not totally dead I guess

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Honda really knows how to do "minivan".

author: fintail
text:
Saw a couple of Model 3 today, meh. Also saw an E300 with distronic - rare option.

I've also noticed more Velar lately - either lease deals are picking up, or more proof I live in Stepfordville.

author: texases
text: Thought I had pulled up next to a collision-damaged car with wavy bodywork...nope, just a Lexus NX300...

author: ab348
text:
Positive review of the upcoming Toyota Corolla hatch. Maybe something for @iluvmysephia1 to consider.

https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/auto/2019-toyota-corolla-hatchback/preview/

author: stickguy
text: something else that sounds nice is the next RAV4. the review I read last night made it sound like a vast improvement. If I had to wade back into the family car market soon, that would now be on the list along with the CRV. The current version RAV would not even warrant a test drive.

author: texases
text: Yeah, current Rav4 is very 'meh'. I'll look at the new one in hybrid form to replace my MKZ hybrid.

author: stickguy
text: the hybrid is interesting. But the standard engine will probably do pretty well on it's own, for less money.

author: explorerx4
text: Drove by a Kia dealer today. They had a yellow Stinger sitting out front. Not my color. Not an unattractive car. Rear overhang seems very long.

author: fintail
text: Spotted a white (pearl maybe) Stinger and another Model 3 today - production must have actually ramped up.

author: Michaell
text: I think I saw my first model 3 today, going the other way on a 6 lane arterial road. I wasn't terribly impressed with the exterior; have to see the inside to render full judgement.

author: qbrozen
text:
Still have not seen a Model 3.
Got another look at a Stinger today. Red GT AWD with a bad driver. In any case, I really like the look of the rear. Probably its best angle.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Incredibly spartan.

author: fintail
text: I think the Model 3 is definitely a case of buying a powertrain and getting the rest for free. Other Teslas have interiors that are far from what is expected in their price class, for this one, you get seats and a steering wheel and feel thankful for that.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: The Model 3's interior reminds me of something like an entry-level luxury Japanese trim at the base level. However, the interior is nicer than a Chevy Bolt. On the other hand, at about $20K more "out the door" than the Bolt, it should be.

author: fintail
text: New car day . In my building's parking garage a new style Jeep 4 door and a new Impreza Sport have appeared in the past 24 hours. On the road I spotted a new X6M, recently plated E63S wagon, matte grey 760Li (not my first color choice), and a co-worker got a new Outback.

author: laurasdada
text: Atomic Silver Lexus LC500. Still sleek.

author: stickguy
text: street parked in a local neighborhood (older, cheesy houses) a white Continental. Might be the first one I saw in the wild. Did not realize how prominent the door handles are. weird how much they protrude. Not bad looking overall though.

author: stickguy
text:
probably one of the first civilians to do so, but got to check out a new 2019 RDX. Had a call from the guy at the dealership (I had done the online "keep me informed"thing). Called a few days ago to say they would be here mid-June. Got another call this afternoon telling me they have a couple on hand until tomorrow afternoon (they are going to an American Honda corporate office, I assume for demo purposes). But if I got there first, they would show it to me. Just no drives.

so stopped after dinner. Sadly, they closed at 6 (I thought they were open to 9). But, I drove around back, and found them. A red standard one, and a white A Spec with snazzy red seats.

overall, I liked it. looks good in person. Stylish. Seems to be bigger in the trunk area than ours. Interior is quite a bit more fancy. Will be interested in getting into it next month.

author: berri
text: So what is this blob of a big Mercedes 4 dr that looks like it is sitting on stilts. Seen several recently and they were all white with black trim... I'm guessing some kind of 4wd sedan/crossover, but with a trunk?

author: fintail
text: Maybe a GLE coupe? Perfect for the X6 driver who lacks the flamboyance required by the modern roundel:

author: tjc78
text: So whats plan Z? Sell the sport to your daughter, lease a new RDX for the wife and take the hand me down RDX for you?

author: stickguy
text:
that plan is on the list someplace. Probably would not happen right away, so would need to be some interim filler plan!

Would just be a lot easier to send her off on her own and keep what we got. Just less fun!

author: tjc78
text:
I know I may be banned for this but saw what appeared to be a fully decked out Camry SE in charcoal grey.  I thouhht it looked pretty sharp except for the front. 

I may have to test drive one to see how it is.

author: berri
text: Yep Fintail, that's it

author: berri
text: If you don't mind the low to the ground profile and somewhat tight headroom, you should. People may mock Camry's, but they are well made, comfortable riding and durable.

author: stickguy
text:
I agree. There is one like that (I think it is actually very dark blue though) I walk past daily with the dog. It is always pulled nose into a driveway. Side and rear profile are nice.

The nose, depending on model and color, is livable. The part I disliked actually was the interior (dashboard mostly, particularly on the passenger side).

No clue how it drives, but the road test reports were positive. Assuming they are blowing out cheap, certainly worth a look.

author: kyfdx
text: I like the new Camry look better than the Accord.

author: andres3
text:
Have they improved the interior?

I was disappointed in Toyota's Camry interior when looking at mid-size cars for my Mother. The Avalon interior is more along the lines of the New Accord Interior quality.

author: explorerx4
text:
Somebody find a good review of Entune.
I find the Camry's shift and electronics frustrating.

author: kyfdx
text:
Our Tacoma has it.. my son hates it.

I don't bother with it.

author: explorerx4
text:
In the parking lot at work, a black Lincoln Continental.
Then I noticed it had out of state Livery plates.
I guess out parking lot security guard fell asleep.

author: fintail
text: I'm noticing a lot more new style Camry on the road lately, including some of the flamboyant 2 tone high models. Looks OK from the side anyway.

author: berri
text: They are dealing and looking at Honda lots I think Accord is going to have to dig deeper soon too.

author: fintail
text: Saw a couple more Model 3 today, don't think I have seen one with front plates yet - I am sure those will be another one where laws don't apply, like other Teslas (but I pity the fool in a dirty old car who drives without a front plate)

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: If you drive without a front plate in Berkeley, CA, they will ticket you right in a parking lot.

author: fintail
text:
Around here I have little doubt there's an inverse relationship between vehicle price and plate enforcement.

Saw an oddity today, a new GLS63, with a European front plate mount (and no plate). I wonder if people do European delivery on a car built in Alabama, or if Euro delivery cars even have that hardware. Weird.

author: kyfdx
text: My first Bentley Bentayga.. and a Lexus LC 500

author: laurasdada
text: My first Tesla Model 3, visiting LA. Red, not overly distinctive. Not nearly as handsome as the S.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: The Model 3 certainly doesn't look like $55,000.

author: texases
text: Just wait - you'll be able to spend $78,000 on a dual motor Model 3, Musk compares it to an M3...

author: Michaell
text: You'll always remember your first....

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
I don't think Tesla buyers realize that the faster an EV goes, and the longer it goes fast, the slower it gets.
There's a reason why Formula E races are only about 50 minutes long.

So this Uber Alles Model 3 might very well outdrag an M3, but it's going to be passed soon enough on the road as speeds climb.

author: berri
text: Plus, as rechargeable batteries age from use they generally tend to hold less charge over time. Don't know if there is enough history on this with tesla though.

author: laurasdada
text: Lotus Evora convertible, Alfa Giulia Qudrafoglio

author: fintail
text: I saw a Model 3 too, white. As these early run cars are all apparently loaded in the 55K range, I don't know if it looks or feels the price. Maybe the best case yet of Tesla being one where you buy the powertrain and the rest is considered a free gift.

author: explorerx4
text: My wife saw a Bentayga today. She described it as an SUV with a big 'B' on it.

author: laurasdada
text: Now I've seen three MOdel 3s, two white. My brother is thinking of an electric, I suggested perhaps a pluging hybrid. He seems intrigued. Living in LA, he believes that there are charging outlets everywhere, and usually in prime parking locations.

author: kyfdx
text: Exactly

author: ab348
text: That will become interesting as sales of EVs grow. Just like now where on-street parking is highly sought-after in some areas, I can foresee a time where all of those charging spots that are now mostly unused become highly prized and people start pulling shenanigans to obtain/keep access to them. Meanwhile other EV owners who get shut out from charging access are subjects of "victim" stories in the media detailing their tales of woes, with calls for govt to do more to help them.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Ford is planning to sell a 300 mile EV crossover in 2020, so the heat is on!

Not sure about Tesla. They are still losing 60 million dollars A DAY!

author: qbrozen
text: I plan on selling a 700-mile EV that does 0-60 in 3.5 secs and seats 7. Who wants to make a deposit?

author: berri
text: Saw my first new Continental on the road. Hard to describe the color, kind of beige light mocha maybe. Liked it from the rear the best. I thought the C pillar had maybe a bit of Mercedes styling hints and the trunk lid and rear maybe a bit of BMW in it with some Lincoln unique. The side and front didn't seem as attractive for me at least. As Lincoln goes, I think the new Navigator (of which I've seen several out there) is pretty sharp and it looks like that will extend down to the upcoming Aviator.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Yeah, but are you going to Mars, too? Bet not!

That's going to be one very expensive EV with that 700 mile range. Tell your engineers to cut that range in half--it's overkill.

author: laurasdada
text: Will you also be selling a bridge in Brooklyn to park said EV under?

author: qbrozen
text: You can only lease the bridge. But it includes insurance and you can upgrade to a bigger bridge after just 12 mos.

author: fintail
text: All we really need is a 400 mile real world (AC use, 75 mph cruising, etc) range, 0-60 in 8 seconds, seats 5, and normal styling. Maybe the ability to charge in a short time too - charging tech is still a huge stumbling block, when I can replenish my 800 mile diesel range in under 10 minutes.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Nobody is going to build that. The # of people who need to go 400 miles in a day is microscopic, and the major expense in building an EV is the batteries. I suppose you could build some $250,000 SUV plush monster that would do that for people in Dubai.

Maybe in 10 years that would be possible at an affordable cost, presuming there is an earth left to drive on, of course.

author: fintail
text:
It's a stumbling block for me. I take some road trips every year, and I don't want to have to stop for half an hour or more every 200 or so miles (range with real world higher speed driving and/or range anxiety).

Battery tech is indeed the issue. That, and I want something with normal styling and build quality. Until then, the diesel hybrid possible in more refined markets is the best answer.

author: tifighter
text: A 30 minute stop every 200 miles is fine with me. For the same reason I get an aisle seat on long flights or have a standing desk at work. Just say no to a DVT.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: That's a very tall order, for 400 miles at 75 mph with AC or Heat on full blast. That would probably mean a "marketing range" of 600 miles--that is, optimum miles under ideal conditions (urban, low speed, no hills, no HVAC, mild temperatures).

author: qbrozen
text: I'm still accepting deposits.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: What about Mars? Are we all going to Mars?

author: qbrozen
text: my lawyers and financial advisors forbid me from talking about that project in the same forum as the electric car project. Go figure.

author: fintail
text: I can't imagine driving to Medford or Missoula or something and stopping for a minimum of an hour (if you can get an open space and charge up immediately, real world would probably be 90 minutes or 2 hours). Normally, I will stop every 250 miles or so for a washroom break and/or fuel, if needed. Unless I am on a secondary road and am enjoying the scenery, the destination is important.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
You could probably buy the EV that fits your particular needs, in 5-10 years, but you'll be paying a hefty price for it. Automakers build the cars that they can make a profit on, not the cars that necessarily suit every type of buyer.

For instance, the public didn't demand FWD, it just got it.

And manual transmissions are going away because it doesn't pay to develop a transmission for those 2-3% of buyers.

author: ab348
text: Do they have better battery tech there?

author: tjc78
text: Faster chargers....

author: fintail
text:
I guess I will have to stick to my liquid fuel vehicle, woe is me, 800 miles on a charge.

I've seen ads from the 70s and 80s with FWD as a selling point, for snowy weather traction.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
FWD has better traction unless you are going uphill--then, not so much.

A Tesla Model S should be regarded as a full-size Lexus with a 9 gallon gas tank and wider panel gaps and one dealer every 100 miles.

author: laurasdada
text: I spotted two Karma Revero's today. Also, Bentayga's, while not common, aren't uncommon here in LA. A couple of DB11s, but don't think I've yet seen an LC500 (or H) here.

author: bhill2
text:
There has been considerable discussion about overcoming the disadvantages of range limitation and recharge time in electric vehicles. In general, the consensus is that significantly longer range and faster charging is years away and likely to be expensive. Consider also that most electricity is generated using fossil fuels anyway.

Please let me present a half-baked idea for potential further baking. It has already been shown that electric cars can be produced at moderate price that have good performance and adequate range for most driving. Would there be any play in adding, or even replacing some of the battery capacity with, an internal-combustion engine optimized to run at constant speed and drive a generator? That is, a parallel hybrid. It should be a fairly simple addition, and I would think that the optimized engine could be made very low in emissions. It would have to be able to maintain battery charge under normal situations, but in most driving not a lot of power is needed. Under high power requirements the battery would be drawn down a bit, but recharging could take place when the power demand goes back to normal. Discuss among yourselves.

author: benjaminh
text: I saw a Honda Clarity plug-in hybrid when I was getting an oil change for my Accord at the dealer. Strange looking, but sort-of cool. Doesn't quite work for me, styling-wise. Slightly reminds me of a Citroen DS....

author: benjaminh
text: Maybe I'm missing something, but I think the Accord Hybrid I'm considering buying sort of does what you are talking about....?

author: qbrozen
text:
That is a Volt, yes?

edit: just looked it up. The original 2011 Volt worked that way for the most part, but the 2016 redesign changed it to be more of a blended power delivery once the battery ran down.

the i3 range extender only charges the battery, right?

author: texases
text: While many folks focus on range and battery costs, getting the charging time down into the 'few minutes' range will be VERY difficult - the current draw to do that is enormous, more than any residential and most small commercial systems can handle.

author: berri
text: Gasoline will be in for a price jolt so to speak when the much higher octane fuel becomes required for new vehicles down the road. Wait and see the oil and gas station industry gouge.

author: texases
text: Gouge? It costs more to make. Basically, the car industry wants us to pay (with higher gas prices) for them to make their mpg targets.

author: andres3
text: and with poor reliability, something Lexus doesn't know the definition of.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Well people are still buying the Model 3, so apparently what Consumer Reports says doesn't blunt the charisma of the Fearless Leader.

Maybe they're using Land Rover as a model for this level of blind faith. Some people want what they want--reliability isn't the highest priority.

author: explorerx4
text:
Saw my first 'without a doubt about it' Model 3 today.
It was moving and didn't see anything fall off, going kind of slow though.
It was black and had a temporary paper plate.
I think that makes sense because I don't think they are for sale in CT.

author: berri
text:
Gouge? It costs more to make. Basically, the car industry wants us to pay (with higher gas prices) for them to make their mpg targets.

You mean to tell me that premium fuel costs 60 cents or more a gallon to produce compared to regular 87 octane??? Now I can't tell you whether it is the industry, wholesalers or gas stations that are exaggerating this price differential.

author: texases
text:
If it didn't cost more, somebody would charge less. Look what happened to gas prices when they plummeted. Demand for premium also is creeping up as more folks buy turbo cars that recommend/require premium.

If gas sellers could set their price where they wanted, why'd they let regular prices drop?

author: stickguy
text: scoped out a new Jetta today. Big upgrade over the prior model IMO. Impressive car. Very roomy too.

author: fushigi
text:
Put a supercapacitor at the charging station and feed it at a sustainable rate. Let it dump the high-current flow into the EV batteries. For commercial chargers the capacitor may need to be oversized or part of a bank of units to handle the demand. For residences or small businesses it would be around the size of Tesla's Powerwall.

But there is still an issue: heat. Dumping that much juice into the EV battery pack quickly creates a lot of waste heat. It has to be managed or you wind up with bulging/exploding battery cells or otherwise shortening the useful life.

author: laurasdada
text:
Shipping up to Boston tomorrow after a nice (and extremely quick!) week long visit with family in LA. To summarize:
Model 3s, not so rare
Bentley's a go go including the Bentayga
A fistfull of Ferraris, including Italias and FFs
Late sightings of Lexus LC500, 3 today
Lexus RX300s
A bunch of Aston Martins, DB9, Vantage and DB11
A dime a dozen 911s
And, of course, the lower middle class folks in their MBs, BMWs and Audis.

You know, the usual.

author: bhill2
text:
That is a Volt, yes?

edit: just looked it up. The original 2011 Volt worked that way for the most part, but the 2016 redesign changed it to be more of a blended power delivery once the battery ran down.

the i3 range extender only charges the battery, right?

I had forgotten the i3 range extender; it may indeed do that. All of the hybrids I am aware of are parallel, so that the engine is often used to propel the car. That requires that the engine be designed to operate at a range of speeds. Since electric propulsion can now provide more than sufficient power on its own, I was hoping that being able to operate the engine at a constant, or limited range of speed for recharging only would allow optimization for low emissions and fuel consumption while still giving greater range and short refueling times.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I'm kind of surprised that BMW was able to sell any i3s. You get very little value for your money.

author: fintail

author: Mr_Shiftright

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Yeah, but it's almost $50,000 dollars!!! For what? Looks? Handling? Performance?

Nope. Ain't got any of those things.

Next to the Cadillac ELR, probably the worst automotive value of the 21st century, IMO.

This may impact new model sightings

author: fushigi
text: It was unclear if that would be a ban on imports or a ban on Mercedes specifically. Banning Mercedes would put at least 4000 Americans out of work based on their US manufacturing.

author: ab348
text:
Things are a bit crazy right now. The US just reimposed tariffs on imports of Canadian aluminum and steel (also ones from Mexico) and the Canadian gov just responded with tariffs on imports of a whole laundry list of US products, from frozen pizza to toilet paper to bourbon.

All of this apparently started because the US gov was unhappy with the time taken to get a NAFTA deal. Up here in Canada both the pols and the citizenry are justifiably P.O.ed at the US gov after all the support we provided after 9/11, in Afghanistan, etc etc.

author: fintail
text:
Funny line I read today is that 45 should repeal the asinine 25 year import rule - as it was bought and paid for by Mercedes (because free markets, limited government, freedom, etc).

ab348, many down here are also less than thrilled with the government.

author: texases
text:
"All of this apparently started because the US gov Trump was unhappy with the time taken to get a NAFTA deal."

There, I fixed it. Two different things.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Saddest of all is that some of the people making these decisions couldn't even tell you in any great detail what's in the NAFTA deal. This is all political theater. If a critic thinks a deal is "bad", that critic should be able to explain why it's bad. That way, we're all in on it.

Perhaps it turned out "bad" but I don't think all parties went in thinking it was bad.

author: thebean
text: From what I see happening at the big white house in DC, apparently the rule is "everything that was enacted prior to 2017 is terrible and everything since is genius".

author: berri
text:
Banning Mercedes would put at least 4000 Americans out of work based on their US manufacturing.
...and a lot of well to do political contributors own one. Sometimes I think he just spurts these things out to appease his base and maybe see what jello-o sticks to the wall.

author: stickguy

author: fintail
text:
I doubt many of the base are in the market for a late model MB, and you can be sure cars made in China won't be touched.

I still have to support repealing the 25 year rule. It'd be hilarious for MB, BMW, and VW to threaten "buh bye", too. Trade wars have produced positive results exactly zero times in history, no surprise the narcissist thinks it will be different this time.

author: stickguy
text: 2019 RDX. scoped out and drove one. Very, very nice. Massive improvement over the old one. I think Acura will sell a bunch of them.

author: texases
text: I may just drop by the Acura dealer, about 2 miles from my home...

text: I hadn't really noticed how the Lacrosse look got taller until I saw those two side by side. I don't think anyone makes a nicer boulevard cruiser better than Buick. Quiet, smooth and comfortable...and the wife looks nice too

author: berri
text: In the latter 00's I rented a Lacrosse pretty much like your wife's previous (blue) model and drove a big chunk of Route 66. I thought the car fit the cruise, and I enjoyed the drive and the car on that trip.

author: stickguy
text: walking the dog today passed a newer Regal parked on the side of the road. I actually liked it quite a bit. I could probably be enticed by one with the 2.0T and right colors/options (if it was cheap enough!)

author: ab348
text: There was one at the dealer a couple of weeks ago and it really did nothing for me, was actually quite disappointing. Styling seemed off and the interior was disappointing. Had zero interest in it. That's something coming from a GM loyalist like me.

author: fintail
text: Welcome back lemko, nice to see you and the new car. Is she going to keep it for 11 years like the old one?

author: kyfdx
text: Lease programs are no good..

author: stickguy
text:
they still make them? I thought they had been discontinued. I was thinking used.

so, what are the hot leases these days? Asking for a friend of course...

author: ab348
text: It's a brand-new design for 2018, available in a large hatchback or a wagon in the USA. Canada only gets the hatchback sedan, called a "Sportback". The 2018 is bigger than the previous model with worse styling and a cheapened-up interior if you do not go for the top-line trims. The one I saw had remarkably ugly cloth-and-vinyl seats. From all reports they drive well but so did the previous model like the one I had, which looked far better IMO. They have virtually no presence in the market here. The one I saw was a special order that the dealer brought in for someone, but they do not carry any inventory of them locally.

author: stickguy
text: thanks. I saw the prior model. I don't remember what the new one looks like.

author: fintail
text:
Yeah, yet another attempt by GM to market a car which is a boring mainstream run of the mill full size entrant in the Euro market as some kind of premium product. Are some variants still made in Germany? Those won't be helped by 45's moronic trade war babble.

Saw 2 new Leafs on the road - now marginally less awkward! At Costco the display car was a Q60.

author: ab348
text: All of them are made in Germany now, under contract to PSA in the Opel Russelsheim plant.

author: fintail
text:
Saw 2x Model 3 now, just about to blend into the background like the S and X.

Also saw 2 late model Ferraris, nowadays I assume exotic rentals or sketchy offshore money (as vetting is only for po folk).

And 2 new style Jeeps, seems to be a few on the road already.

Topped it off with a Google street view car - this one was a 5 door Elantra, maybe the Bluetec and I will be saved for posterity on a street view scene.

author: tjc78
text: I loved my 2012 LaCrosse.  Heck even my wife talks about how much she liked it.

author: andres3
text:
I loved my 2012 LaCrosse.  Heck even my wife talks about how much she liked it.  

The car on the left is definitely more "Lexus" like than the one on the right. I think that's a good thing for the intended market and audience.

author: stickguy
text: stopped at the Audi dealer today. Had a gorgeous A5 sportback, on the showroom floor. Midnight blue over rock gray, all loaded up. Sticker of almost $55K! and that was a 2.0t. But, super nice looking in and out.

author: andres3
text:
Must be those Trump German car tariffs!

Actually, Audi is getting too popular, they are starting to price like BMW and MB.

author: explorerx4
text: Last year I was looking in a multi brand lot. Saw an A4 I liked, 52k.

author: ab348
text: I have 2 problems with Audi, or at least my perception of Audi. First, their dealer locally has cultivated a rather elitist and unapproachable image, acting like their vehicles are made with 24K gold. Secondly, i have a hard time with the perception I have of many of their models being FWD VW-based, and the price premium they try to charge for such a vehicle. But maybe I'm just old and cranky.

author: fintail
text:
Saw 4x Model 3 today, 3 of them white.

Also saw 4x new CRV, which for some reason seemed even more dull than usual, maybe because of the annoying flashing CHMSL and the driving manners of the club, which is a combination of a two handed uptight grip on the wheel combined with dopey lane changes.

Best sighting was a new KTM Duke 1290 in the workplace garage, one of my favorite modern bikes.

author: texases
text: Followed a new Accord, first time. Not a great view:

author: Mr_Shiftright

author: stickguy
