author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
A new owner posted a review here. He seems to like it but has a few criticisms.

https://forums.edmunds.com/discussion/comment/5538415#Comment_5538415

author: explorerx4
text:
Wife confirmed one of the neighbors has a new blue Mustang coupe in the garage.
Probably passed the S60 on to one of the kids.
Black wheels, so could be a GT.

author: texases
text: If you get a look at the back, it'll have 'GT' between the taillights. (but you already know that)

author: explorerx4
text:
@texases,
Yes about the 'GT' and unfortunately it was too far down the street to hear anything either.

author: texases
text: Followed in a newish 911 Turbo S cabrio, about $250k or so...

author: andres3
text:
I saw an attractive brunette in a recent model Porsche 911 Turbo. A slow moving old boxy something or other (like an old Forester maybe) managed to get in front when the street got down to 1-lane, and goes up a hill. The boxy SUV starts going really slow. Predictably, the Turbo Porsche starts to get really close, then tailgates, then honks their horn. This was somewhat justified, as predictably, the guy in the box slow car wanted to escalate the situation all along with their passive-aggressive driving, and slowed down even more (drastically slowing). I"m behind the 911 so now I'm a victim of the slow down caused by Mr. Passive-Aggressive. So I honk too.

At the top of the hill, the road widens a bit, but is still one lane. The Porsche aggressively moves to pass them on the right, and successfully does so. I continue to honk at the car that got passed, but I'm turning right at the next intersection anyway, and they went on their way, straight, going much faster than when the 911 was behind them.

author: kyfdx
text: So... what did all that horn honking accomplish?

author: fintail
text:
Pressure release valve, easier than yelling

I honked this morning, at a dimwit in their XC60 who bumbled down a straight only lane at half the limit, caused everyone to miss the light, then jerked over into the turn lane at last second.

author: kyfdx
text: I've found that most drivers seem even angrier, after honking... I don't think the valve really releases any pressure.

author: berri
text: We just seem to have become an overstressed country anymore. Rudeness way too often seems to prevail these days. Kinda sad really.

author: fintail
text:
Maybe some become more irritated when I honk, to me, it is easier than yelling or doing a pit maneuver. I know in some parts of the country (crapholes, to paraphrase our dear leader, perhaps), a honk might be met with gunfire, but much less likely here. Honking in the fintail is also fun, as the horn is 5x louder than a modern car.

Rudeness could be a chicken and egg, what is ruder - honking, or driving like a decapitated chicken who earns the honk? Oh, if only we had the inconsiderate driver thread

On the new car topic, someone in my building has a new (or at least new to them) 4er GC, debadged, pearl white.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Yep, fintail horns are loud--borderline obnoxious by today's standards--a sharp dual horn with a spinal cord frequency.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Or a Mercedes 600 horn would be a nice addition:

author: fintail
text:
That's the one, I believe the same on all fintails, but somehow mine seems louder. People look when you honk, that's for sure. I've thought of a 600 retrofit, but I bet those are pricey. That video reminds me I want to get my steering wheel refinished.

This ponton horn sounds familiar, too:



Maybe the next time I drive it, I will make a horn video.

On that note, I gave a short toot when out again just an hour ago, to a Rogue that stopped for an invisible stop sign (and once again, I missed a light).

For new cars, there's a Model 3 at the building where I store the fintail. Base wheels, dirty, has plates but still has the temp registration in the window, sounds about like what I expect.

author: andres3
text:
The honking of the horn for me was equivalent to yelling:

1) Your inept driving was noticed, and your control-freak desires are not tolerated on the roadway, and by the way, the 1,000,000 cars behind you don't find it acceptable, and you are not the only 2 people on the planet!

2) Move it! I got places to be!

author: ab348
text:
Fin, I'm surprised that the Ponton in that video doesn't overhead given the number of badges on the grille blocking airflow. I've not seen that bodystyle before, thanks for that.

The M-B horns are loud but have a higher-note "Euro" sound to them that I associate with European city traffic. The GM ones sounded like this (sadly installed on an old CRV):

author: kyfdx
text: Got it.. accomplished nothing.

author: berri
text: We've got an old Camry we use for driving around town. I'm not a slow driver, but people perceive I must be slow because of the vehicle and particularly SUV's ride my [non-permissible content removed] when I'm actually driving over the limit. Doesn't happen with our crossover. My attitude is: you hit it, you bought it because in reality their insurance will probably payout more than a dealer will on trade. I'm not going to be your point man getting the ticket for 15 or more over the limit. I say that because oftentimes when they pass, they end up hitting their brakes and driving about the same speed as I was already doing. Too much!

author: fintail
text:
Ponton coupes and cabrios are relatively rare and expensive, along with wincingly expensive to restore.

That GM horn sounds like a train, nice. Horns on many modern cars are almost embarrassing, like they are yelling and apologizing at the same time. To relate to new cars, maybe there could be a market retrofitting new cars with real horns.

For those triggered by horns, I suspect they or maybe someone they are yoked to get honked at a bit. For people who notice lots of honking, maybe look to personal driving habits

author: andres3
text:
I've heard that from others, similar to your story. I don't get it. When I pass, I pass, and I continue to pass gaining more and more room each second between your car and mine. I wouldn't pass just to slow down unless my radar detector indicated a reason to do so.

Strange your Camry gets tailgated more often than your Crossover. Are you sure you are driving them the same? The meager 4-banger in the Camry is pretty slow. Perhaps your acceleration rate is offending them (it's not always about top cruising speed).

author: lemko
text: She absolutely loves the car! I might get one myself one day. We did very well with our 2005 LaCrosse!

author: lemko
text: Here's a better shot of her ride.

author: fintail
text:
Hey Lemko, nice to see you. That blue Lacrosse must be a rare color.

Someone at work has turned up in a fresh new white Volt.

author: explorerx4
text: In the parking lot at work, 2018 black F150 FX4 supercab.

author: fintail
text:
Not a new release, but new enough and noteworthy for initial hype that hit the ground with a loud "meh"

New NSX, white.

author: texases
text: The dam broke on new Accords, after not seeing them for a while they're everywhere.

author: tjc78
text: Same thing happened here with the new Enclave and Traverse.

author: stickguy
text: Down my street, in houses across from each other, new X1 and a Q5. In a unique medium green. Rare seeing something that color. Nice change.

author: explorerx4
text:
Never see any new Accords other than the 2 or 3 I see on a regular basis.
Definitely see more new Camry's.
I now see that not all Camry's have the same rear bumper styling.

author: tjc78
text: I think the sport model gets different treatment.

author: ab348
text: I don't see either, so far. I guess I should consider myself lucky.

author: thebean
text: Saw a new Subaru Ascent yesterday. Sure is big, and to me it doesn't look that much like a Subie.

author: stickguy
text: but looks really nice to my eye, if you want a large SUV barge like that.

author: berri
text: good AWD system for a crossover as well.

author: fintail
text:
Quite a few new Accords on the road here, but I see 5x as many Camry.

Saw a BMW of Seattle loaner car today, 340i with nav and HUD, so not a stripper.

author: berri
text: Camry's are in the rental fleets, Accords seldom are. Seattle is a business and tourist destination.

author: fintail
text: I see more higher spec non-rental Camry than I expect, too, you know, the ones with 8 exhaust tips, weird rear trim, and strange two tone treatment,

author: kyfdx
text: I think that's the XSE and/or the SE that has the weird rear trim. It's sort of off-putting. I saw an XLE, yesterday, that looked a lot better from the rear.

author: explorerx4
text: One models that have the two outlet pipe on one side, only one outlet is functional.

author: berri
text: I guess there is a difference between sporty, classy or tart it up with some more lipstick

author: fintail
text: Got behind what I think was a recently plated 4er cabrio today, driven by the most stereotypical BMW driver: zero signal use, floors it and goes double the limit, foiled by lights and then dawdles when the light turns green.

author: fintail
text:
Not new but not sure where else to put it. I saw a BWW 550i (I think) GT blowing blue smoke at least as much as when the fintail is hot and in a bad mood, if not a bit more. Do these V8s have the same issue as the x45 badged cars?

Saw two garish model Camry today, to be on topic.

author: thebean
text: Saw a real unicorn today. A new Acura RLX with paper tags. I guess that is the one they sold in 2Q.

author: Michaell
text: Not new, but just as much of a unicorn - Jetta Hybrid.

author: tjc78
text: My cousins wife has one, she loves it.

author: laurasdada
text: On the way home from the Berkshires Sunday, a brand new-looking 911, an Aston Martin DB9 Vantage and a BMW i8. Aston Martin, please.

author: stickguy
text:
neighbor from across the street seems to have traded in (probably lease was up) her Traverse. Came home last night with a new Malibu. Black. Actually quite sharp looking. but surprisingly large. Looks almost as long as her hubbys recently purchased Silverado. also black. I made a crack about cornering the market on black chebbies.

He traded in a Cruze on the PU, so I guess that beast made the large SUV redundant.

author: ab348
text: I never understood GM's thinking in making the Malibu almost as big as an Impala.

author: stickguy
text:
I better check tomorrow. It looked as big as an Impala today, but I think I saw Malibu yesterday. I have to see the nameplate usually to tell the difference (though I guess there is a trim piece on the C pillar too).

they do seem to be very redundant at this point.

author: andres3
text:
This is great news for GM. In the past, the cars were so bad most were one and done, or at most two and out for life. Some fan boys might need to be screwed 3 times even.

It seems the cars are getting good enough and consistent enough in durability that many owners are becoming repeat buyers more routinely.

author: ab348
text: Too bad she couldn't have waited for the 2019 refresh. They finally are shedding the frowny face. Hopefully they are upgrading some aspects of the interior too.

author: kyfdx
text:
Frowny Faces

https://untappd.com/b/streetside-brewery-frowny-faces/2752201

author: fintail
text: Guy who parks near me at home who appears to lease a Tiguan every other year has showed up in a new unplated Jetta - I assume not a loaner as it has no dealer ID. Fancier wheels, didn't notice the trim.

author: texases
text:
I drove a new Mustang GT for a week, vacation in CA, drove San Diego - Carmel - San Jose.

It was a birthday present, I was curious how it compared to my first car, a '65 with the 170. As expected, it was much bigger (what a long front!) and MUCH faster. What I wasn't expecting was how LOUD it was, at all times. Starting, driving in traffic, hitting the gas, LOUD! It kept me from using the gas as much as I might have. I guess I'm not the target market...

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Isn't there some sort of exhaust adjustment? Many cars have that these days.

author: texases
text:
There might be, I didn't take time to figure out the 326 different buttons and their functions...
I also wondered if some of the noise might have been artificially piped in through the stereo, but the open windows showed the car was making plenty of noise the old-fashioned way.

And to think that many GT buyers think the stock exhaust is too tame. I seem to remember Edmunds did a long term test of one a few years back, and considered an aftermarket exhaust.

author: stickguy
text:
Probably most shocking, I bet the GT got way better mileage. Especially highway.

And much faster is probably an understatement.

author: ab348
text: Funny you mention the sound of the GT, @texases . Over the last few days I encountered two new GTs and they both were really obnoxiously loud to me as a passerby. There is an enjoyable exhaust note and then there is just noise. These were the latter.

author: andres3
text: Several Audi owners have reported losses to street light antics with races against the Mustang GT's in a straight line, including a 3.0 supercharged owner. However, there was also a report of a guy with a Stage 1+ 3.0T A6 that walked away from a previous generation (or 2; mid 2000's?) Roushe Mustang; apparently the older ones only had 415 HP or so??? That's beatable with a stage 1 tune Audi with a 3.0.

author: stickguy
text: The driver has a lot to do with that too.

author: andres3
text:
Especially with 2WD

However, if one is trying to engage launch control in a modern fancy car, there is plenty of opportunity to screw it up and get a slow launch in the process. I tell people you need a good 5 second warning before engaging in a stoplight race.

author: qbrozen
text: Is the 2019 A7 out yet? I don't see any listed at dealers around me, but I was behind one today. It had Michigan plates that said "Manufacturer" on the bottom. And the car was debadged. Really good looking in person! Driver was awful, speeding up and slowing down and stepping on the brake randomly for no reason. Oh and the spoiler was stuck in the up position, even when fully stopped. Don't know if it is supposed to be speed sensitive or can be manually overridden.

author: texases
text: The mpgs on the GT were fine, 26 mpg in mostly highway driving, buying premium. I don't remember what the '65 got.

author: fintail
text: I had to run an errand across the street from the MB dealer, good time to pop in and see if there's anything cool. Most noteworthy was 2 late run 18 G63s, both in odd colors. It seems the G color palette has expanded lately, and some old colors have returned. The one in the showroom was "Tectite Grey", the same color as my old E55, and one that previously existed from around 1995-2003 or so. Nice color, cool car, I had to sit in it - but dreary black interior, and 160K MSRP. The other G was "Mauritius Blue", another color with some age, but is a bit bright for me. Same dark interior and MSRP. Other cars on the lot were as-expected, maybe the S63 cabrio being a little unusual. Used section had a few loaner or ex-rental E class and tons of W205 C-class but no E-class with many options. Looking at these and then getting back in my car has me satisfied with my car. Neighboring Porsche dealer had a usual lineup, oddity was a Panamera wagon (as I call it), but no MSRP, and a MB E43 sedan in the used section, 57K asking, no drivers assist option.

author: berri
text: What's with all the black these days - inside and outside. Are we reverting to Henry Ford's Model T approach?

author: fintail
text:
I think it is a few factors. It coordinates with any exterior color, it is probably seen as somewhat fashionable (Germans have been into it for years), and although it shows small dust and hairs etc, it doesn't show built up grime nearly as bad as a light color. Especially if leather or pleather, it is easy to clean.

What happened to blue interiors? I like blue. Blue interiors are effectively gone for mass market cars, and have been gone for some time.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: You can get an orange interior in the new Volvo XC40---yes, orange. Well not the ENTIRE interior, but a healthy portion of it, including the carpets and door panels.

author: ab348
text:
Far too much black used these days.

The shrinkage in color options in interiors is unfortunate. Maybe until around 2000 you could still get some choices like blue, red, maybe even green in addition to tan, gray and black. Not all of those in every model of course, but you had some choice.

One of the underrated interior shades that is seemingly going away is the very light dove gray that used to be popular. I had that in my Lacrosse and really liked it. Going back into the '70s Ford used to offer a knit nylon cloth in the LTD and other top-line models in that shade and it looked wonderful.

@explorerx4 sent me a copy of the book Car! that detailed the development of the '96 Taurus (a very engaging read) and the author spent some time discussing the process around the seat fabric choice, which was apparently one of the first applications of Uglycloth (TM Regd.) via a multicolor printed fabric which was not well-received by dealers and the public. It seemed in that account that the interior color was barely given any thought at all given the much bigger challenges the development team faced.

author: fintail
text:
MB had blue into the mid 90s, maybe late 90s on carryover models. Some, I think Honda especially, have limited it to just greybeige and black on some models.

My Bluetec has brown, which I like even if much of the trim is black. At least it gives some contrast, and at the same time coordinates well with the natural finish wood:



My prior E had light grey, which brightened things up inside and had kind of a posh feeling, but showed dirt easily. Luckily it was tex, and was easy to clean:



I have a 2018 G Wagen brochure, and it lists 21 interior color choices (some are distinctions between solid color and color/black), including a dark blue. The real fun thing is exterior colors - 13 regular colors, 26 designo colors. At that price point, I guess there should be variety.

I remember the 96 Taurus cloth choices, here's a good illustration:



Looks like fungal growth.

author: ab348
text:
Ha, your present E interior is almost exactly the same shades as used in my ATS, and your former E had the same grey that my Lacrosse sported!


fintail said:

I remember the 96 Taurus cloth choices, here's a good illustration:



Looks like fungal growth.

Man, that IS bad. I had no recollection of that. What were they thinking?

Mid-90s to mid-2000s seemed to have an epidemic of Uglycloth (TM Regd.) upholstery, at least in N.A. makes. I remember seeing similarly unappealing fabrics in Chevys, the Pontiac Grand Prix, and some Chrysler products. Hopefully a trend that does not return.

author: fintail
text:
I think brown has made a minor comeback, and I am all for it - something to break the monotony, and it is a rich looking color. Grey can work too in the right shade with the right trim. My ideal MB color combo would be diamond silver on porcelain (or blue, if it exists for the model), but I don't see many like that.

The uglycloth I think is following a 90s trend in Europe, but made boring for NA consumption. Starting in the 90s, many more affordable Euro cars had kind of playful or brash cloth patterns, and it was probably seen as a way to liven up a basic product:







The era around the turn of the century sometimes seems like a mini-malaise era, things got pretty dull for awhile, and some cars had reliability issues.

ab348 said:


Man, that IS bad. I had no recollection of that. What were they thinking?

Mid-90s to mid-2000s seemed to have an epidemic of Uglycloth (TM Regd.) upholstery, at least in N.A. makes. I remember seeing similarly unappealing fabrics in Chevys, the Pontiac Grand Prix, and some Chrysler products. Hopefully a trend that does not return.

author: berri
text: What's with those cloth interiors - did the 60's and 70's come back? Paisley will be next

author: bhill2
text:
fintail said:
I think it is a few factors. It coordinates with any exterior color, it is probably seen as somewhat fashionable (Germans have been into it for years), and although it shows small dust and hairs etc, it doesn't show built up grime nearly as bad as a light color. Especially if leather or pleather, it is easy to clean.

What happened to blue interiors? I like blue. Blue interiors are effectively gone for mass market cars, and have been gone for some time.
I'm kinda with you. Fin. Our '09 BMW is black with a blue interior. It is a nice combination.

author: fintail
text:
That's gotta be rare, too.

I notice MB has blue options for the S-class and G, but I have never seen one in person.
bhill2 said:


I'm kinda with you. Fin. Our '09 BMW is black with a blue interior. It is a nice combination.

author: andres3
text:
Having nightmares of the rainbow speckled gray cloth in the Neon.

That light gray in the MB looks more like white/gray. Most grays are darker then that.

VW is offering up like 30 colors for the new Golf R. You just have to pay $2,500 extra if you want a real color selection.

However, don't ask for any interior other than black

author: tjc78
text:
@andres3
I was just thinking about the Neon cloth. My Stepdad bought a first year Neon, white over grey with the white hubcaps. When he brought home and opened the door I couldn't believe that interior.

author: fintail
text: Welcome to the 90s, I hope you like roundness.

author: tifighter
text: Saw a new NSX in white. It actually looks pretty mean on the street; I think I like it.

author: texases
text: I wonder if they'll ever sell an 'NSX-lite', without all the hybrid equipment and associated electronic wizardry for less $$. My understanding is that it was a BIG job to get actual performance benefits out of a hybrid NSX over a straight gasser.

author: tifighter
text: I doubt it. The NSX is a brand piece, and the hybrid system is in line with their F1 program.

author: qbrozen
text:
texases said:
I wonder if they'll ever sell an 'NSX-lite', without all the hybrid equipment and associated electronic wizardry for less $$. My understanding is that it was a BIG job to get actual performance benefits out of a hybrid NSX over a straight gasser.
It was designed around that drivetrain. Doing a gasser version would be a huge engineering and testing cost.

author: texases
text: Very true. But they could probably sell a lot more at 2/3 the price.

author: fintail
text: I've read the NSX is selling in single digits per month. I'd so rather have an original one.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I've driven the original, and they are surprisingly easy to drive really fast. Compared to an equivalent year Corvette at speed (scary), the NSX makes you feel like a pro, first time out. Of course, you DO have to stare at an Acura steering wheel.

author: tifighter
text:
fintail said:
I've read the NSX is selling in single digits per month. I'd so rather have an original one.
Yeah. But are we sure dealers want to sell them? I imagine the ADM is insane on these. I can just picture an Acura dealer getting allocated one for the year and the principal wanting to keep it around just to show off to buddies.

author: fintail
text:
That could be it. Does anyone really care enough anymore to stop and look at one? The enthusiast marketplace met it with a resounding yawn after it was hyped for eons and finally launched. But no doubt some dummy dealers have 20% ADMs just to troll for suckers, especially if they are in dirty money markets (like this one!).
tifighter said:


Yeah. But are we sure dealers want to sell them? I imagine the ADM is insane on these. I can just picture an Acura dealer getting allocated one for the year and the principal wanting to keep it around just to show off to buddies.

author: texases
text: There are 3 NSX at the Acura dealer near me, listed at MSRP.

author: qbrozen
text: I've seen folks on the other board talking about $30k discounts on them

author: laurasdada
text:
I spoke to an Acura HQ rep at the Greenwich Concours d' Elegance (there were I believe 3 NSX there). She said indeed a $30k discount is doable, I coyly asked about $50k, she said if I was serious, here's my card we can talk when I'm back in CA... Even at $50k discount, not in my league...

She also said the issue was that all of the '17s were ordered by the dealers loaded. And that the clientele, when spending that much $, didn't want to be told all or nothing, they wanted the configuration that they wanted. So, they sat at dealer lots (and I did read on nearly $50k discounts at at least one dealer). Acura Lady noted that all '18s and for the near future, would be by order only. The way the buyer wants it...

author: explorerx4
text: Saw a Buick Avenair(?) wagon, vaguely Volvo'ish looking.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Avenir. Comes in three flavors. Regal, LaCrosse and Enclave.

author: explorerx4
text:
I thought it was a wagon, but could be wrong. There doesn't seem to be a 2018. Could have been a 2019.

Just remembered, I saw a Civic Type R(or what the sportiest version in called). Has to be the most overwrought design in decades.

author: fintail
text: Saw an RLX in traffic today, so they sold another one. Couldn't make out the plate to discern the exact age.

author: fushigi
text: Was behind an i3 for a while on the highway today. It .. isn't a good look.

author: tjc78
text: My cousins wife has one.   When I used that joke they didnt get it

author: texases
text: Followed an RDX in, the new one. Back end was an improved CR-V, but that's not saying a lot. Wish I had seen the front end.

author: fintail
text: At work saw a 5er plug in hybrid, not a common car. On the road saw a yellow Ferrari retractable of some kind, and a Marie Antoinette Bentayga looking gaudier than expected in white with tinted wheels and black wheels.

author: tifighter
text: So here's a weird one. Yesterday I saw a white Nissan Frontier. But not one he have in the US, but the latest one they have overseas, the Navarra 300. Crew cab short bed. Couldn't see the plates. They don't sell this in Canada, but do list it on the Mexico site, so maybe someone is on a road trip.

author: fintail
text: Not the latest thing, but saw a Model 3 with a personalized plate "THREE". At least it wasn't a dorky pro-EV plate, but still cringe-worthy, and probably very appealing to the base.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Like it needs a label? Just stand in front of it, and you won't mistake it for anything else.

author: fintail
text:
I think the Tesla mindset is different from car people.

Drove beside a white on white newer Rolls-Royce convertible today. Not exactly subtle, but this is a place you could get away with that and not worry about safety.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: You'll be pleased to know that Asian real estate speculation is drying up now.

author: fintail
text:
I don't know if I'd go that far - there has been a mild softening, but I suspect offshore money is still a huge factor in many areas. No matter, in many places the damage is done.

R-R driver was a typical looking old guy, rather sketchy newly arrived money.

author: fintail
text: Saw the opposite end of the spectrum today, a new unplated trunkback Mirage, for those who really just want a new car.

author: fushigi
text: re: Mirage. Surprisingly the hatchback lists for a full grand less than the trunkback. Of course dealer incentives may negate the difference. Versa lists for less though Mirage ought to get better economy & has a better warranty.

author: fintail
text:
There's a case where I might pick the Nissan, especially in hatchback version. Small trunkback cars just look off, both the Versa and Mirage sedans look weird.

Shame we don't get the Micra.

author: berri
text: Mitsubishi - suddenly it is 1989

author: iluvmysephia1
text: The Nissan Micra is a cool choice, I agree, fintail.

author: fintail
text:
Micra is kind of a neat little car in a way, really cheap in Canadaland, too.

But I'd rather have the new E63s wagon I saw today

author: jpp75
text: I saw a VW Areton today in a bright gold/yellow color. The color didn't do it any favors but overall it's a good looking vehicle.

author: fintail
text: Are you in Yourup or is the Arteon trickling in now? Haven't seen any here yet but I saw a number in Germany late last year.

author: jpp75
text: This was in Denver, so I think they must be tricking in over here.

author: ab348
text: I saw a new Jetta in the metallic orange they offer with either a factory sport package or dealer add-ons, parked on a podium in front of a local VW dealer. It had black alloys and some blackout trim, and while I am not usually a fan of either of those items, I have to admit this one looked pretty sharp.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new style CLS on the road today, maybe the first I have seen in the wild.

author: texases
text: Driving around Ireland I noticed two things: they're buying LOTS of CUVs (about 1/3 of the passenger vehicles), and they buy all countries' cars - lots of Toyotas, Hyundai/Kias, VWs, Renaults, Peugeots, Fords. Plus lots of work vans, no pickup trucks.

author: stickguy
text: pretty sure I saw a new 2019 Ram today in my neighborhood. I only got a quick glance of the front end but it looked like one.

author: ab348
text: I don't see American vehicles in that list of countries.

author: fintail
text: As contrary to what a certain someone believes, most of the world has no desire for a Taurus or Silverado.

author: berri
text: A lot of US vehicles are too large for many foreign country roads I believe.

author: stickguy
text: Ireland has really small roads. Chevy spark sized in many areas.

author: tifighter
text: Here in Switzerland, I've seen more RAM trucks then you would expect to see. I mean, I'd need a second hand to count them.

author: fintail
text: I've seen RAMs in Germany, too. They are used by actual farmers for utility purposes, weird.

author: kyfdx
text: They are owned by a Euro-based company.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Oh, you mean FRAMS?

author: explorerx4
text:
Saw a new RAM the other day, front reminds me a bit of a Ridgeline.
It may depend on the model, though.

author: berri
text: Anyone know if the Ford Edge is built on the Ford Fusion chassis?

author: texases
text:
It's related. Kind of like how the Highlander and RX350 are related to the Camry.

I'll take a look tonight, I have an MKX and an MKZ...

author: berri
text: The Edge, like the Fusion, get some good write-ups (and you basically have the upscale versions)

author: fintail
text: Saw a white Stinger, along with a Genesis G80 in livery duty.

author: kyfdx
text: The Stinger I saw was white, as well. It's a good color for that model.

author: texases
text:
We're happy with them. Ours are the previous generation, based on the "CD3" platform:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_CD3_platform

Current ones are (surprise) on the CD4 platform:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ford_CD4_platform

I will say, looking underneath there wasn't a lot in common that I could see.

author: berri
text: Thanks

author: stickguy
text: I think the current model edge is really nice looking.

author: stickguy
text: out driving through a neighborhood today, a white RDX with temp tags. Looked nice. And down the blog, a white with black roof Volvo XC40. snazzy looking.

author: explorerx4
text:
A new Acura NSX. I can see why they didn't sell.
The engine sounded very flat, not something you would want in a 'supercar'.

author: fushigi
text: A blue Stinger yesterday. Couldn't see any details but that makes only the second I've seen in the wild (the first was red).

author: fintail
text:
Saw another Clarity on the road, and an X2 - surprised I haven't seen more of those here, given the local penchant for premium branded soft roaders.

Not new, but also saw an M6 GC, maybe my favorite modern BMW, and it was filled with mylar balloons, funny.

author: tifighter
text: Audi Q8. One black and one grey. Like any other Q whatever, but very wide visually. Coming to a suburb near you...

author: fintail
text: There will be a lot of white ones on the eastside, a specific demographic seems to be into that.

author: tifighter
text: Also forgot to mention that Ive seen quite a few copies of the Jag I-Pace on the ground in Switzerland. I dont know when they hit the States but production is definitely underway.

author: fintail
text: Someone in the parking garage at home got a new Prius C yesterday. Has to be one of the oldest designs on sale in this market, dating from MY 2012, with little apparent update.

author: texases
text: Saw my first new-gen Leaf. Driver was slooooowww...

author: stickguy
text: another new temp tagged RDX today. This one was black. From behind, IMO not an attractive color on it. Looked a lot better in lighter/brighter colors IMO.

author: explorerx4
text: A grey Model 3. Lack of an exterior plate drew my attention, otherwise may not have noticed it.

author: tjc78
text:
...putting flame suit on 

Saw a new Camry, White with a pano roof.  It was obviously a top trim model but not a sport.   From the back and side I actually think its quite attractive. The front is another story.

author: kyfdx
text: Our Camry rental was black/black. I thought it was fairly attractive for a sedan. But, I never saw the front of it.

author: fintail
text:
Did it have the weird lines coming down from the tail lights?



I think this car will look better in dark colors. Tons of them on the road here. So much styling.

author: kyfdx
text:
I think those dark lines are only on the SE/XSE model.

And, can't see them on the black ones.

author: ab348
text: I think it will look better IN the dark, as in pitch black nighttime in the wilderness on a night where clouds cover the moon.

author: tjc78
text: Didnt have the black lines.   It must have been the XLE or whatever the top trim is.  It also had wheels that were very fine spokes, not an open design.

author: tjc78
text: These wheels.  Maybe it was a hybrid

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Audi A5 fastback sedan done in a British Racing Green with biscuit interior. Nice looking car, still had temp tags on it, so fresh out of the box. I guess a 2018 model though---the '19s aren't out yet, are they?

author: fintail
text: Saw a 2019 E450 wagon at the dealer. MSRP 79K. I don't recall, but I think it didn't have leather.

author: texases
text: First new Jeep Wrangler Ive seen, pretty different look from the back.

author: Michaell
text: Not yet.

author: texases
text: New RR Phantom, this one was understated, silver, at night, took a while to recognize it (parked, so the Spirit of Ecstacy was hiding).

author: uplanderguy
text: Sheesh, that black line coming down vertically from the lights on that Toyota looks like a piece of black rubber gasket has come unattached there. WTH.

author: ab348
text: That's what I said!!

author: fintail
text: It's interesting to me that some brands are going hog wild with adornment, while others are migrating away from the faux dynamism:

author: uplanderguy
text: I always liked bright metal at the rocker and also at the beltline. If the sides of the car are slab-like (unlike the M-B above), I like a body-colored rub strip there--which almost no car has as even an option anymore.

author: fintail
text:
I like a little chroime - just a little. Especially around the windows. German makers now apparently have returned to the 80s and are offering black trim, with names like "night package" and "shadowline". Not really to my taste, especially on a non-tuned model.

The MBs are a bit curvy, very little of the slashed-about nonsense embraced by some makes.

author: stickguy
text: temp tagged 2019 Santa Fe. Looks good in person. I need to swing by the dealer one day and scope one out.

author: jpp75
text: I saw the other day that VW has delayed the launch of the Aerton here in the US so the car I saw a few weeks ago must have been a CC.

author: fintail
text:
On another fortum I frequent, someone saw an Arteon in Virginia:



Apparently VW HQ is there and they get prepro and testing stuff.

author: stickguy
text: that looks like a toon car. Those wheels look awful.

author: fintail
text: VW has taken the angled/directional wheel thing from Honda and kicked it up a dozen notches. Not a style I like.

author: texases
text: Instant curb rash.

author: stickguy
text: Not just the style. They just seem way too big.

author: jpp75
text: Interesting, that's exactly the same color of the one I saw here in Denver. Maybe that's what I saw because I'm not sure the CC comes in that color.

author: thebean
text: Saw a new Range Rover Evoque convertible today. Why, why why? I can't think of many other vehicles that make less sense.

author: stickguy
text: Its for Murano cross cab owners that come into some money.

author: explorerx4
text:
In the parking lot at work a black Colorado, 1st new midsize pickup in the lot.
Interesting that there is only 1 new Accord and no new Camry's.

author: uplanderguy
text: I like the looks of the current Colorado. I did not like the weird styling of the previous ones at all.

author: stickguy
text: really? The prior one was pretty much a traditional squared off PU design, and the new one is a lot more swoopy and angular. If anything I would have thought the new one would qualify as weird!

author: fintail
text:
The wheelarches of the first Colorado are weird.

IIRC the Evoque cabrio is gone for MY 2019. I think I have seen 2 ever.

author: uplanderguy
text: Agree with fin--the wheel openings were weird, and the parking lights were above the headlights in front. To me, looks like bad '70's Japanese styling, LOL.

author: fintail
text: Saw a poorly driven (hard to believe, I know) Bentayga in traffic today, along with a new style Lexus ES - like the old, but edgier with sharp C-pillar DLO fail.

author: fintail
text: Saw a Nissan Kicks on the road, and quite rare, not one but two Model 3 with front plates.

author: iluvmysephia1
text: Nissan knocked it solidly outta da park with the Kicks. I don't really like SUV's much, but, body-design wise this new design of theirs rocks like Foghat. Live at the Seattle Center Coliseum, May of 1978. I know, because I was there.

author: fintail
text: you should buy one!

author: stickguy
text: I bet you can find one in Denver, or maybe Boise

author: iluvmysephia1
text: Yes-sirree. I like to combine a long drive with a car purchase. It adds to the romance of it all, eh? Up there by Cananada, you guys both needed to hear an "eh" today!

author: ab348
text:
If you buy a Kicks be sure not to turn off the stability control.

https://www.thetruthaboutcars.com/2018/08/be-thankful-the-u-s-market-nissan-kicks-has-standard-stability-control/

author: stickguy
text:
a Nissam Juke Nismo. all black. Did not actually look that bad, for a Juke. Probably about as good as you will get. a redesigned model I guess, much narrower headlights.

and a temp tagged Infiniti QX30. also in black. Based on where it was, might have replaced a prior generation Tuscan.

author: ab348
text: Reminds of a line self-attributed to Alex Karras, the late football star and later actor, in his autobiography, describing his compliment to a girl on the dance floor as a socially inept teenager: "You sweat less than any fat girl I know!".

author: fintail
text: Some cars are best in black. Many Toyolex products fit this.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
My friend did that once, right in front of me. He told his first date: "I really like those spaces between your teeth".

If looks could kill....

Someone has suggested stick-on fake grilles for some cars.

author: fintail
text:
Stopped by the MB dealer to get a keyfob battery (free), and this was in the showroom:







AMG GT "4 door coupe", the Panamera competitor I guess. No Monroney, apparently this is a "training" car, with manufacturer/distributor plates. Appears to be fully loaded. I can't say I am in love with it, in fact, I am a little offended by the fender "vents".

author: Michaell
text:
Is that a hatchback?

Looks sufficiently aggressive, though I imagine that rear seat headroom is only good for kids under the age of 12.

author: tifighter
text: The word "severe' comes to mind...

author: fintail
text:
Yep I believe it is a hatchback, same hatch as on the actual coupe version of the AMG GT.

And the fender vents, unless I overlooked something, completely fake.

author: texases
text: The 4-doors AMG GT is more based on the CLS, right?

author: berri
text: Fin, kind of hard to criticize Toyota and not this MB. But beauty is in the eye of the beholder I suppose or different strokes for different folks.

author: fintail
text:
I criticized it. Those fender vents, ugh. But at least it isn't slashed about on the sides.

Yes, I believe this is related to the CLS, both of which have an E-class basis - so instead of costing twice as much as a basic E, this will cost thrice as much.

author: texases
text: I drove next to its competition on the way home - the new Panamera. Much better proportions than the prior one. First one I've seen.

author: berri
text:
But at least it isn't slashed about on the sides.

Just like NYC and West Side Story - wait, you're probably too young for that

author: ab348
text: What's with all the angry/scary front ends these days? Not a good trend.

author: fintail
text: Seems hard to find a car without leering eyes, not to mention an entire scowling face, these days. Let's make our bland reliable products look aggressive lol.

author: texases
text: Mazda seems to have some of the most balanced styling out there right now.

author: texases
text: First new NSX in the wild today. I like the look. I actually wasn't a big fan of the 1st gen NSX styling. Great car, but the styling never grabbed me.

author: laurasdada
text: I agree about the first gen NSX styling. The back of the car seemed a bit too extended to me. I'd still take one, though!

author: bhill2
text: I am waiting with bated breath for the arrival of the AMG E53 sedan. It may easily induce me to pull a trigger that I only pull every 10 years or so (sedan purchase). The BMW 335i is getting a little elderly, and God I love straight sixes (especially ones with 429 horsepower).

author: texases
text: First time, an "e-Golf", followed it in today. Has a range of about 130 miles, apparently. Not for sale here: "Sorry, the e-Golf will be available only at participating dealers in California, Connecticut, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, New Jersey, New York, Oregon, Rhode Island, Vermont, and Washington, DC."

author: fintail
text: First MB I6 in around 20 years, IIRC. Should be pretty nice, I will be interested to see how they hold their value, as a new one will be too rich for my blood.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Well you know---new AMGs tend to take a beating in depreciation during the first few years and most continue to drop. A C43 AMG can be had for around $7500 median at auction, and they are rare, too.

author: fintail
text: That seems to be around the depreciation floor for old AMGs - you can go cheaper, but I wouldn't recommend it. I wouldn't be shopping for a 20 year old car though. I had a C43 once, the V8 W202, that is. For that model, I think around 400-500 units per year on average were brought over. AMGs from around 2003 onwards were generally sold in significantly higher numbers.

author: fintail
text: Saw not one but two Jeeps with dorky clip on plastic angry faces today - I'd be just a little embarrassed to have this:

author: bhill2
text: Excuse me, but you guys are raining on my parade. You're probably right though. *sigh*.

author: fintail
text:
If you bought a nice car 20 years ago for 50K (approximate price of a new C43 then), drove it, and it is still worth $7500, I think you did fairly well. 20 years is a long time.

A new E53 will never be a real collectible, so if you want one, get one and enjoy it. Or order one in a spec I would choose, baby it, and sell it to me in a few years when the worst depreciation has taken its toll

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
No rain intended. We're just telling you to bring an umbrella, just in case.

RE: Jeep with funky grille. --- they're trying to imitate those Ultra4 desert racers, I think. The bumper decal is hysterical ---"safaripal"-----really? Is that like "Everest Summit Buddy"?

author: fintail
text:
Decked out Jeeps with dopey grilles are the Seattle/Bellevue equivalent to overcompensating brotrucks. Trying to look menacing, lolol.

Saw a new style E coupe pulling out of the building where I live, either someone has a fancy new car or it was a visitor, never seen it before. Gotta look around.

author: bhill2
text: Its a thought, Fin, but I should warn you that the last Mercedes we bought we kept for 26 years, and it would have been longer if the old girl had not been toasted. Oh, and it was used when we bought it.

author: fintail
text:
Oh yeah, your W126

Maybe you should try to find another similar car. Nice ones are out there. It'd be easy to learn, maybe more relaxing to drive, and the best-of-the-best 126s are becoming sought after, and have definitely stopped depreciating.

author: bhill2
text: You know, Fin, I have considered that maybe for our second/pleasure car. We loved that old tank, it had become a trusted family member. If I were to go looking, my impression is that I would be better served by a 420 than a 560 because of less complication. Also, I assume that the later ones (say '89 - '91) would be preferable. Am I on the right track?

author: fintail
text:
I'd support that decision, but you probably already know that.

I don't know if maintenance would be a big deal between a 420 and 560, if a limited use car. These days, I would choose the nicest car possible rather than limiting it by engine. The I6 300SE/SEL is even easier to maintain, but the trimmings are only maybe 90% as fancy (different wood, a couple less gadgets) than a 560, but they will be slower. The 89+ cars are probably the most refined, as that year there was a mild facelift with revised steering wheel and upholstery, and passenger airbags became more common. Budget maybe 15K for a fairly pristine car, or 10K or so for one that gets driven more. These prices are for cars with few to no needs. They can be found much cheaper, but I think you personally really want a minter.

author: Michaell
text: Spotted this today:

author: explorerx4
text:
@micheall,
Did you give it a go to see if it was real or faux?

author: qbrozen
text: My 280hp Alfa has bigger tailpipes than that. Just sayin.

author: Michaell
text:
No.

He turned left, and I made a U-Turn.

Also, I was in the Jetta; most everything can take me.

author: stickguy
text: wife and I saw an X4 at the dealer on Saturday. She asked what the heck it was. Did not find it attractive at all. Yet she loved the X2.

author: explorerx4
text:
@michaell,
I was just having a little fun. Feel the same way driving my Fusion, still like it though.

author: tjc78
text: Im sure your truck could win a few stop light challenges.

author: texases
text: No problem beating one of these, followed a new one in today. It's SMALL!

author: fushigi
text:
Mirage is cheap (starts at $13,395) and reasonably fuel efficient (37/43) but I don't think it represents a good value. I'd recommend a lightly used compact like Elantra or Sentra over it.

My sighting today was a presumably not-new Acura ZDX in front of me. Had to pass it quick to avoid having to look at it for too long & risk my eyes burning.

author: explorerx4
text:
@tjc78,
That's all rumor and speculation.

author: fintail
text: At least the BMW wasn't an X6, maybe the only way it could have more potential to offend.

author: boomchek
text: Some of the Mirages come with front power windows and rear roll ups. Kind of like the Neons or SX 2.0's from years ago. I guess they have to cut costs somewhere. The 3 cylinder engine under the hood looks like a lawnmower engine. I think they started at $9,995 CDN when they were relaunched a few years ago.

author: boomchek
text:
The ZDX kind of grew on me. I think it looks better than the X6 for a "SUV coupe".

Speaking of SUVs, I saw the new Discovery on the road for the first time few weeks ago and it looks very oddly proportioned from the rear. Narrow and tall. Land Rover has a really nice looking lineup imo but the Disco just looks odd. It probably didn't help that suspension was set to off road as it was riding super high and gave it an even more awkward appearance.

author: texases
text: Reminds me of the too-narrow first-gen SRX:

author: boomchek
text: Funny thing I rarely see any first gen SRXs on the road anymore. There used to be quite a few of them out there but from experience in the auto business they weren't the most reliable Caddys.

author: fintail
text: Those are getting rare. I know someone who's mom bought/leased one new. They had more than a couple issues with it. It was replaced by a Crosstour, which was awkward looking but had no issues. Now they have a current model Pilot.

author: boomchek
text: Crosstours are pretty obscure as well.

author: fintail
text: Most days at work I see a Crosstour or ZDX in the parking garage. This area has plenty of issues, but a lack of unusual cars isn't one of them.

author: tjc78
text: My Mom had the Toyota equivalent of those for awhile.   It actually was a fairly versatile vehicle with tons of room inside.  IMO the Venza was the best looking iteration of the tall station wagons.

author: fushigi
text:
One neighbor has - and likes - a Crosstour so I see one daily. He's not really a car guy and is, I think, content with having a little more utility than an Accord without having to go all the way to an SUV or minivan (which his wife drives).

Most of my immediate neighbors are in the minivan + 'other' camp where other might be another minivan, a sedan, or a SUV. As the kids are growing & some are off to college it'll be interesting to see if the car choices change. One did exchange their minivan for a Traverse; I expect that sort of exchange to continue.

author: kyfdx
text: I think the Venza has better packaging for passengers and cargo. Not so sloped.

author: tjc78
text:
My wife has told me she wants an SUV for the foreseeable future.  

I will most likely keep a car for my driving.   We work in the same office so minimum 3/5 days we ride in together and take her car.  

My kids are still small and in car seats (my son is pretty much ready for a booster but still fits) so the three row SUV is nice to have.

author: stickguy
text:
When our youngest was in HS we switched from an odyssey to the RDX. Wife likes the view, and Ill always have some sort of box for hauling bulky stuff. So will stay with a compact to midsize CUV or wagon like a V60.

My car, could be anything, like still a sedan.

author: texases
text: Yeah, the Venza is more equivalent to the Ford Edge. Full on CUV.

author: fushigi
text:
My wife is torn. She's come around to CUVs as I've had one since '09. The ride height, easier entry/exit, AWD for winter, and cargo capacity (and easy loading) are appealing. Neither of us drives a lot of miles; she just rolled 39K after 7 years, so outstanding fuel economy is not a primary feature we need.

She also prefers small cars and to her, her '12 Elantra is almost too big for her to comfortably drive. She's only driven my QX60 a couple of times on the highway. Something the size of the Tucson might work but she'd prob go more for the Kona. Having had good experiences with Hyundai she's likely to stay with them.

author: stickguy
text: I was going to say, if she likes the Elantra, Kona could be perfect.

author: explorerx4
text:
In the parking lot at work...
White Corolla, Burgundy Odyssey, Black Tacoma. Pretty Average stuff.

author: fushigi
text:
Just have to add 2 more Crosstours yesterday .. one black, one white and my neighbor's is silver so not the same one multiple times.

Stickguy, yes on the Kona but Ioniq is also a possibility if she decides to stay on the sedan side of things. She's never been a big fan of hatchbacks but the crappy trunk openings of most cars nowadays is, I think, influencing her. Sure, the groceries and whatnot physically fit in the trunk but the openings and necessary bending over (she bends over a lot for her job & often has a sore back) are detractors.

author: explorerx4
text: I about 20 minutes, spotted 4 Tesla's. 3S's and a gray 3 with really ugly wheels.

author: fintail
text: The base wheels on a 3 are awkward, resembling hubcaps. They scream "cheap [non-permissible content removed]" in a way, good strategy to sell the higher model. Basic S and X wheels are also easy to see, they look small.

author: explorerx4
text: Saw it yesterday and wasn't sure what it was. Saw it again today, a white Honda Clarity.

author: tifighter
text:
The base wheels include the aero covers, which apparently add approx 5% more range to the car:

If you don't like them, they can be taken off and reveal the stock wheels underneath:

I like that they give you the option.

author: explorerx4
text:
@tifighter,
Yes those are the wheels I saw.

author: andres3
text: Do they overheat your brakes 5% faster too?

author: fintail
text:
Kind of like the Prius, has actual wheels under the dorky covers. 5% seems like a strong claim, but given that all the guts are in the lower half, maybe.

Saw an RS3, not common.

author: laurasdada
text: Two Tesla 3s appeared at the same time at work, red and blue. The four charging stations at work are now regularly booked, including a BMW X5 plugin.

author: texases
text: Things might get ugly when #5 shows up...

author: laurasdada
text: Texas, I thought about that. I've read of the electric hierarchy, the disdain full BEV folks have for plugins, who overstay their welcome at the charging stations!

author: tjc78
text: That would be a friendly email Any chance I could have the charger around lunch time?

author: tifighter
text: We have a small office of nine, with four of those driving EVs. There is one charger. It hasn't been an issue at our size; everyone has figured out their time slot. More people would create more obvious complications. We'd just add more chargers, but as the batteries get bigger, I could foresee a time when we wouldn't need to. I'm actually out of the schedule now, but some of the guys are coming from the burbs with 1st gen Leafs. They need to charge.

author: fintail
text: I work in an office campus of 5 buildings, and my building might have close to 1000 people. As far as I know, there are 2 EV spots. If you get there by 6, you might get one, otherwise, good luck. There was a Model S that would monopolize it for eons, haven't seen it around lately, maybe someone read them the riot act. I've seen at least 3 Model 3s in the garage as well.

author: tjc78
text:
We have about 250 parked cars between office and warehouse team members at any given time.  

The only Tesla owner has moved on and we have no charging station.  I dont think we ever will.   Kinda surprising they didnt install one when they did the solar panels on the roof.  It was a pretty big deal being the largest array in the state at the time (maybe still, not sure).  The charging station would have been a nice little value add to the whole thing.

author: laurasdada
text: Yeah, four building office park here, ~1200 folks. Four stations, but not always in use. Two Tesla 3s, a few Prii, couple of Ford C-Max and the BMW X5e, by my count are the consumers. So, hopefully there will be an open spot for the i8 I don't own. Yet? Probably not. Probably. Nah, doesn't make sense. 3 more years of tuition...

author: explorerx4
text:
In the parking lot at work...
2 new Jetta's, a black one and a white one.
Also a new Lexus, IS350? Looked a bit muscular.
After that, a couple of blocks up the street, a new black XC40.

author: explorerx4
text:
A white Volvo V60 wagon.
Also saw a couple of Jaguar XF wagons, was poking around a car dealer lot.
Had no idea they make a wagon. The sticker on the one we looked at was 78k.

author: stickguy
text: I assume the outgoing (2018) V60? Unless the brand new design hit the ground already which would surprise me.

author: explorerx4
text: I'm thinking it was new design although other than being a Volvo, I had no idea what it was until I got close behind it. Of course, I'm not sure the last time I saw a newer V60.

author: fintail
text:
Saw the new baby Caddy CUV on the road in suburban Detroit today.

I've really noticed the higher proportion of later model domestic cars on the road here compared to the west coast, especially outside the cities. I noticed more brand diversity in Cleveland, and even around Detroit, but some other places it seemed to be 95% domestic.

author: berri
text: Did you hit the Rock 'n Roll Hall of fame while in Cleveland? The east side has some good Italian food and the west side good ribs.

author: fintail
text: Nope, didn't really have time, and the Christmas Story house was more relevant to me. Maybe if I return another time.

author: fintail
text: In Detroit, I saw some kind of cladded mule/protoype of a middle CUV kind of vehicle, maybe a Ford as I was in Dearborn. On the highway today I saw a cladded 4 door Jeep Wrangler pickup mule.

author: Michaell
text:
The Jeep is the new Gladiator.

I've seen some disguised cars here in Colorado, for high altitude testing.

author: qbrozen
text: Saw my first Buick Sportbrake thingy in the wild yesterday right here in my home town. Nothing terribly special, but good looking, and it stood out enough that I spotted it coming at me from far away.

author: stickguy
text: Big wagons used to be everywhere. Now they really stand out. Sad.

author: stickguy
text: a new style Altima with temp tags. Nice looking. sharper than the old one, but looks lower, and quite a bit (especially in profile) like an Accord. Interior was nice.

author: Michaell
text: Now also,available with AWD and a turbo instead of the V6

author: tjc78
text:
Saw a brand new Sienna "SE".. all black, clear taillights and black wheels. I never really got the idea of a sporty Minivan.

Not the first time it's been done.... head over to Mystery Car Pix

author: boomchek
text: Dodge has a sporty trim level for their Caravan too with blacked out light housings and black wheels, black grille and trim. I guess when the same design has been out for a decade they need new ideas for trim levels to help sell it.

author: stickguy
text:
out car shopping today, saw a Stinger in an odd flat battleship gray. Not at all attractive. Not sure why, but it was parked at the Honda dealer.

also a Lincoln Nautilus. Dumb name, but pretty sharp looking car. Replacement for the MKX (iow the Lincoln Edge)

author: tjc78
text: Explorer based, right?

author: stickguy
text: could be. Did not look that big, but could be just the styling.

author: texases
text: The Aviator is the 3-row Explorer derivative.

author: tjc78
text:
Yeah, but old truck based Explorer both disc

The Nautilus is still the Edge based model like the MKX was. I just looked it up.

author: stickguy
text: that is what it looked like to me. I mentioned the edge to the salesguy and he didn't correct it!

author: texases
text: Nope, new Aviator is based on new Explorer.

author: tjc78
text:
Ok.... now I feel better.  I knew there was supposed to be an Explorer based new Lincoln SUV.  I just didnt realize the MKX was being renamed to Nautilus.  All makes sense now. 

Thanks!

author: explorerx4
text: I believe the Aviator is supposed is going to get released fist, so technically Explorer is a derivative of the Aviator.

author: berri
text: From what I've read, the next gen Explorer/Aviator will be unibody rear wheel drive or optional AWD, but still RWD favored when AWD not needed. Should be interesting.

author: texases
text: Interesting. Does it have any relationship to the Mustang chassis?  I thought they were going to use that for some new vehicle.

author: berri
text: I don't know. They'd have to extend that quite a bit for a large 3 seat SUV. But I think Ford is planning on some other crossovers in the next couple of years as well. I also think Ford (and Honda) is beginning to use some sort of AWD system that shifts power between all four wheels in some popular priced vehicles. It would be nice to see Ford step into the limelight for awhile after years of nothing much special.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new style Altima on the road, apparent rental. Looks like an improvement, although the faux floating C-pillar can't go away soon enough.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new Avalon this morning. A stunning combination of bland and ghastly.

author: tlong
text: The other day I saw a mint Mercury Grand Marquis. Driven by an old lady. From the appearance and license plate number, I'd guess it was late 80s-early 90's vintage. I'll be it had at least 20K miles on it...

author: fintail
text: Don't know where to put this, but as the Lambo Uterus is now a real thing, this is worth a laugh:

author: berri
text: They lowered the roofline for a new streamlined design

author: texases
text: There was a recent article (on Jalopnik?) about how Pontiac was just ahead of their time, given the current CUV craze.

author: kyfdx
text: I'm in total agreement with that.

author: stickguy
text: same as AMC. The Eagle would have saved the company if it came out 20-30 years later. Look what the outback did for subaru.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Spotted a Lexus LC500. Very impressive car from all angles....except the front. It was parked so I gave it a good lookover for a few minutes, from all angles. Loved the sculpted body panels and tried to adjust to the front grille but I couldn't get myself to accept it as "part of the whole".

author: boomchek
text:
Oh cmon, the Urus is a good design. Probably the best looking out of most of the luxury SUVs. The Bentayga and Levante for example are not elegant designs at all.

Betayga proportions look weird and the Levante could pass off as a generic $30k modern SUV.

author: fintail
text:
I am not sure how one sees out of the Urus, but I also strongly doubt the target demographic cares, or usually looks before reversing or turning to begin with. All of these super-priced new age SUVs are dull in their own way, or maybe I am just jaded against who will end up behind the wheel of them in my neighborhood.

Saw a NSX last night, the RLX of supercars.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: AMC didn't survive long enough to develop the Eagle (which needed a LOT of development). Even the early Subarus were pretty rough pieces of work, but by the 1990s they were functionally a lot better. Then Subaru could finally afford a Styling Department in the early 2000s.

author: texases
text: Given the links to the Cayenne, I'd sure want to compare the two before springing for the extra $$$ Urus.

author: fintail
text:
Stopped by the MB dealer while out and about in the fintail. A couple of interesting things - first, a new S coupe with a white interior and steering wheel. Still a striking design at 5 years old:



And a new style CLS 53 in a matte finish that I thought was a fad that passed. MSRP barely shy of 100K:



Funny thing, I was out looking at the used cars, and a salesman came up to me and chatted, while he was looking for a car in inventory. He remembered what I drove, but I don't recall dealing with him before. Maybe they are waiting for me, yeah, that's right. He also said they can negotiate on lease residuals.

author: qbrozen
text: I'd run away from a salesman who claimed that. Or I'd challenge him to do so. Would depend on how much time I felt like wasting.

author: fintail
text:
He named the car, he had the info in his head somehow, and I didn't drive there in that car, rather, in the fintail.

Another fun thing there, the receptionist who always seems to be there always remembers my name.

author: laurasdada
text: A used S Coupe is on my radar. But, it is so large...

author: bhill2
text: Hmmm, I want that CLS drivetrain in an E-Class sedan. So Im looking at maybe $85K similarly equipped?

author: fintail
text:
I suspect that's about right. It'll base over 70 I think, and you know how options are on these (even my Bluetec has 14K in options, and it isn't a full load). That engine interests me a lot too, maybe it would be fun to have a new I6 to go with my old one.

I have noticed early run S coupes are depreciating almost down to my level. But at that price I start looking at G-wagens too, and that's something maybe better left alone.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Aside from the new G-wagons, which are considerably improved, I have to say, having examined an older one closely, that they are about the most ineptly designed vehicle built in the last 25 years--right up there with the Hummer and the Chevy SSR. I would have expected something more than exposed door hinges and glued-on lights for that kind of money. M-B must still be laughing.

author: fintail
text:
G-wagen (until 2018) is a 1979 design, it was old 25 years ago

It's a utility vehicle with a luxury pretense, rather than the other way around.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Well I'll give it credit for very little pretense then. At least it's for real in the dirt, but my god, what a mess it is for the $$$.

Fortunately M-B really cleaned it up for 2019. Not sure it's still worth the money but at least now you can present yourself as the owner without too much embarrassment at having paid the full MSRP.

author: fintail
text:
The fun thing about the G (especially for MB, as the margins have to be yuuuuge) is that value is exactly 0% of the reason to buy one. The target market doesn't care about it, so MB doesn't have to offer it. I've heard you can't find the new model on lots - all sold. Maybe some discounts to be had on old ones. MBs of all model will generally carry at least a 10% discount from MSRP just by some moderate negotiating.

They don't depreciate insanely fast, either.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Wellll......I dunno about that. I would grant that the power of advertising and image are considerable in keeping the buyer somewhat deluded, but people with that kind of money aren't stupid. I think they know perfectly well that the G has been a primitive, gutless, clumsy, spartan "image". Perhaps it's the exclusivity and the "look".

author: fintail
text:
This is the new Belle Epoque. Plenty of people with that kind of money didn't really do jack for it, and many rich people are stupid, monied via the lucky birth club and the breaks and connections that come with it. Many of the target demographic fall into that category. These things are barely advertised at all - they are a known entity without it.

As it has only officially been offered with a V8 and for some time the base model has been well over 400 hp, I don't know about the gutless - clumsy and spartan are part of that image. It doesn't need to be a roadholder when it will only cruise from a gated mcmansion orchard to a gallery mall or club. It's definitely the look, but I don't think they are exclusive - if you want one, your local dealer will gladly order you one today.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: The older ones were pretty gutless, with 2.4L diesels, or sometimes 2.8L gas. It got better engines in 1990.

author: fintail
text: We never received those through official channels, they were meant for utilitarian work. The first official US model G-Wagen was not until MY 2002, the rest are private imports or Europa cars. Those small engine cars also usually had no power accessories, likely no AC, cloth or vinyl interior, etc. It was not originally designed as a luxury vehicle - that's part of the appeal for some.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: They were incredibly backward all the way up to 2018--for that kind of $$$, you could buy so much more. Benz seemed almost cynical about it, as in "you really want one of these things Americans? OK, here...we'll glue some extra stuff on it, and reverse-engineer some clunky updates...now go away".

author: fintail
text: Like was mentioned, people who buy these aren't seeking value, aren't being rational. It's a show off splurge. 90% image is what sells it, and will continue to sell it.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
I was reading about this prank where a TV production company bought up some cheap shoes from Payless and reboxed them with a phony "upscale brand name" and sold them to people at outrageous prices---the buyers were totally convinced that the shoes were in fact some kind of hand-made imported artisan shoe.

So yeah, they were buying the box the shoes came in. They had no discernment as to the quality of the object of their desire.

author: fintail
text:
Not sure if those shoes are apples to apples with a G-Wagen. The G is not a cheap product pretending to be expensive. It would be pricey even without bling and leather. It is a high quality old fashioned utility vehicle decked out with fancy bits and a price pumped up to a huge margin.

I suspect it would be easier/less painful to run a G to 150K miles than say a Range Rover of the same price point.

author: berri
text: I actually saw one on the road today. Meh

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: The new ones are cleaned up a bit but there are sure a lot better ways to spend your money than on a new car that already looks like an old one.

author: fintail
text:
I still have yet to see a new style G on the road in person. If my local dealer had any, they sold. This will continue to be a cash cow.

Many aspects of value are subjective. Some want that traditional look, it says "I have money to throw away, the amount of taxes I dodge/evade are more than your salary". It is worth it to someone, or MB wouldn't make them

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Doug DeMuro's review on the 2017 AMG version is pretty amusing. He also reviewed the 2019 and he is a bit kinder:

2017 AMG G-Wagon Review

author: fintail

The door handle/latch operation on those is immensely satisfying too, like an old car.

author: tlong
text: I've often wondered what people from the 1800s, when machinery was heavy iron, would think of all of today's mechanical and even non-mechanical items? I suspect they'd be amazed by things like carbon fiber and even plastic. And aluminum. Everything is immensely lighter than in those days.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Jules Verne's space rocket was made out of aluminum, in the story Journey to the Moon (1865), and the engine the Wright Brothers used was made out of aluminum (1903). Aluminum electrical wires were being used in the late 1800s.

author: kyfdx
text:
Aluminum electrical wires were being used in the late 1800s.

Yikes! That didn't work out so well.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Why not? Aluminum gives better conductivity per weight than copper.

author: stickguy
text: But those pesky fires.

author: kyfdx
text:
1 mile from my house:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beverly_Hills_Supper_Club_fire

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: As a metal, it was "discovered" in 1825. At one time, it cost more per weight than gold.

author: tjc78
text:
Aluminum is still widely used as electrical wire.   Most homes large feed from the pole is aluminum. 

Buggest problem with aluminum was electrolysis resulting from splicing it into copper or using the wrong terminations.  

Thinner gauge also also can get brittle over time.

text: Yet, $52 for the Centric brand. Prime example of why I rarely buy OEM.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Are those any good? I have heard pros and cons. I wonder if Wilwood makes rotors for the AMG--they make a very good rotor.

author: qbrozen
text: I bought them for our previous T&C after the stock ones warped and I read that was common. The Centric worked fine and never warped.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
More often than not, brake rotors do not in fact warp. It's the brake pads causing the wobble. Lots of upsell on rotors.

Next time anyone wants to sell you new rotors, have them show you on a dial gauge.

I guess on some cars, it doesn't matter much if you buy new rotors, but at $1,000 a pop it does!

author: qbrozen
text:
curious: how do pads cause a wobble?

I don't fully recall, but I believe it is likely I replaced the pads first, vibration remained, so I went back and replaced the rotors. At least, that's the route I would take now, so I can only assume that's what I did then.

author: andres3
text: Lots of debate on if rotors can be used more than one pad set on "performance" vehicles driven the way they were meant to be driven. Apparently OEM rotors sometimes cut out thickness for weight loss at the expense of being able to be used more than one set of pads.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Here's what Firestone says:

"When you press down on the brake pedal, you kick start a series of rapid events. As you step on the pedal a caliper applies pressure to the brake pad, which in turn clinches down on the rotors. (Similar to how bicycle brakes work.) This brings your car to a stop. If anything is off with said brake pad, you may feel it in your steering wheel. Brake pads that are old, worn, or particularly dirty cannot grip the rotor effectively and can cause your steering wheel to quiver."

author: qbrozen
text:
so, yes, when pressing the brakes. I wouldn't have called it a "wobble" though.
I THINK a warped rotor would be more ...hmmm... "consistent"? rhythmic? Meaning a warped rotor would give you the sensation at the same point(s) in each rotation, while pads would not. Just a total guess.

Also, if warped enough, you could hear/feel it even when not applying the brakes since the rotor could touch the pads on each rotation.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
The true test would be the dial indicator---no guessing on the shop's part, and no upsell for you if they can't prove it.

Of course, on some German cars....cough, cough....rotors are never turned in case of warpage..you are required to throw them away regardless of the "meat" left on them.

I'm half in jest here...I'm sure there are other automakers who require the same thing.

author: qbrozen
text:
What is this "shop" you keep speaking of? ;b

Heck, I can swap my rotors, calipers, and pads and still save money over just paying to get pads done at the dealer.

author: andres3
text: Absolutely true about being "TOO LOYAL." However, until they make unreliable crap cars, they will continue to be loyal, because they are loyal about the legendary trouble-free ownership experience. It is reliability and durability that keeps them coming back for more, not the grounded to the ground driving feel.

author: tlong
text: I saw this on the road and grabbed a quick shot. I have no idea what it is.

author: fintail
text: Looks like a 51 Ford Victoria. New 68 years ago

author: qbrozen
text: THis one is not new either but it is sitting outside my sons dojo right now.

author: tlong
text:
I was recently in Chile for the first time and I saw this truck in Santiago.
Chinese vehicles are definitely happening - this wasn't a rare find.

author: stickguy
text: Id but something called a Wingle. Fun name!

author: qbrozen
text: My question is: with the 3 different names on there, which is the manufacturer, model, and trim? Is it a Denco Great Wall Wingle 5? A Great Wall Wingle 5 in Denco trim? A Wingle 5 Denco Great Wall? ....

author: kyfdx
text:
I'm pretty sure that Great Wall is the make, Wingle 5 is the model.
CRDi is common rail diesel

Not familiar with Derco, unless it's a parent company to Great Wall

author: kyfdx
text:
Yesterday, Lexus IS 250 AWD F-Sport

It had a lot of crap on the back, as well.

author: andres3
text: The fit and finish looks Chinese like... the bumper isn't level.

author: tlong
