author: Mr_Shiftright
text: I don't expect life is easy for a working truck in Chile.

author: tifighter
text: I saw a ton of those Great Wall trucks in Chile. They have to be eating market share in SA. Nissan still seemed pretty popular.

author: explorerx4
text: Those can't be backup sensors on the bumper, right?

author: Michaell
text: Couldn't "Denco" or "Derco" be the dealer name?

author: kyfdx
text:
Derco is a dealer or distributor in Chile.

https://www.dercocenter.cl/busqueda/

author: fintail
text: In Vancouver for a few days, the land of sketchy offshore-based money, where 18 year old "students" in Lambos and McLarens are a common sight. Have only seen one of those so far (bright blue, subtle and classy), also saw a G550 4x4x4x4x4x4x4x4x4x4 with all kinds of signage, apparently used in some kind of rally. Biggest difference from the Seattle zoo is the amount of X2s - they are everywhere here.

author: Michaell
text: Is the X2 available with different engines north of the border?

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: There's a Brit on YouTube ranting about all the troubles with his new McLaren. In 7 months, he's been able to drive the car 21 days.

author: ab348
text: That sounds like Clarkson a few years ago when he bought his GT40.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: The poor guy is so bent out of shape about his McLaren, and he insists he's tried everything to get McLaren to even TALK to him. So he's launching a social media war to get them to phone him. Says this has cost him over 300,000 BP.

author: fintail
text:
If there are any engine variances on the X2, they are minor. No diesel or anything else interesting.

Went to the Vancouver auto show today, kind of a letdown - no MB, no BMW, Kind of weird, but I know MB has skipped out here in the past, and other places recently. The rest of the show had normal stuff as expected. I was impressed with the luxury spec Dodge truck, pretty nice rig. White was not a color I would pick for a display Avalon, but Toyota thought it was a good idea. A purple Mirage was good for a laugh, and the Nissan Micra is fun to see. Some car, I think a lower model Hyunkia or Mitsu CUV, had iffy fit and finish on some exterior trim, not good for a show car. In the exotic section saw the Marie Antoinette Rolls-Royce Cullinan, a couple McLaren Senna, various Lambo and Ferrari etc. Exchange rates make some things decent for Murkan tourists right now, too.

author: texases
text: I may go to the Dallas show this weekend. Also no BMW, which happened before, but MB will be there. No Mini this year, guess BMW's cutting back everything.

author: stickguy
text:
Philly also had no BMW this year. Thats a big show so I was surprised.

MB was there, but they always have a huge display. Ditto Lexus. Those 2 have a hall by themselves. MB had at least 12-15 cars.

Caddy was the other big name brand missing.

author: ab348
text: Porsche rolled out its new Cayenne Coupe on Instagram today. A SUV with less interior room!

author: berri
text: Personally, I think BMW is losing a bit of it's cache. There are plenty of other options out there.

author: fintail
text:
I am waiting for these to not be rare sights:



I suppose it is a 21st century version of this, so it fits with the company ethos:



Thinking of a good plate, maybe "EATCAKE" or "UNDRTXD".

author: berri
text: God Save The Queen

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Is that the new Kelvinator?

author: explorerx4
text: Pretty funny, side by side with separate freezer compartment on the far left.

author: fintail
text: A Ferrari thingy from the show, with a pretty view. At least it is blue, so it has that going for it, which is nice:

author: ab348
text: A Ferarri that color just doesn't seem right.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Much better on a Mustang!

author: fintail
text:
With so many Ferraris being cliche red or born on third base "entrepreneur" who thinks he's edgy black, something different is refreshing.

Another one from the show:

author: stickguy
text: For a Ferrari, I prefer Fly yellow.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: You can actually order a beige Ferrari, or at least you used to a few years ago. I guess they'd paint it checkerboard for you if you paid them enough.

author: texases
text:
Close enough?
https://images.app.goo.gl/G29v82whZxNitMZFA

author: fintail
text: A blue Ferrari can be quite fetching (I have no problem admitting I like these):

author: ab348
text:
The shade of blue immediately above looks fine, as does a dark blue. It is the brilliantly bright Subaru/HyunKia blue that looks wrong.

Colors on Ferraris are interesting. A few years ago on Carini's TV show he did over a Ferrari Daytona that was the traditional red and in doing the body prep discovered it was originally green, Verde Pino. It got repainted in its original color and I thought it would look terrible but it actually was quite attractive.

author: qbrozen
text: I think that is awful. Looks like a Miata Or 80s vette.

author: ab348
text: Wow. Seriously? So do you think "Ferrari" when you see a red Vette or Miata?

author: berri
text: I like the the 1960's Ferrari designs

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Well that's okay---it's not like it's a Ferrari anybody cares about.

author: qbrozen
text: Doesnt seem to work that way for me, no. Although when I would see a black or red C7 when they first came out, my initial reaction was is that... oh, nope... its a vette.

author: fintail
text: And as the rising tide lifts all yachts, they've still done well in the market. I remember when you could get lovely ones for 25K all day long - there was a local one in that same blue I was drooling over.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: They aren't worth much more than that now--maybe $35K. It's the cheapest Ferrari you can buy.

author: explorerx4
text: I don't mind how it looks, but it kind of reminds me of a Fiat.

author: ab348
text: Kind of reminds me of a Mitsubishi or a Nissan.

author: fintail
text:
Cheapest 400i on Hemmings is 55K, same price one brought on BaT in 2017. I think the angular lines are handsome and stylish. I understand the establishment Ferrari cult hated the cars when new.

I'd imagine a Mondial coupe would be the cheapest Ferrari.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Median auction value 2018 is $33K. That's hard data.

author: fintail
text: Sample size? Condition? From what I can see, I wouldn't roll the dice on a 33K example in 2019.

author: Mr_Shiftright
text:
Sample size is all major auctions (global) 2018. The "median" is a good indicator of real world prices because unlike an auction or asking prices, the median eliminates all high and low outliers and weighs the center.

Actually this is interesting but we are off-topic.

author: laurasdada
text: Ah, I thought that was a Bitter SC...

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Well good guess in a way---that's another car nobody wants.

author: laurasdada
text: There were two Bitter's at the Greenwich Concours last year. In fact, the founders of this cool event (The Wennerstroms), in the program every year are profiled with a picture of them and their matching Bitters. I think it may have been the tv show, "The Golberg's," the father bought a Bitter, it died in the driveway and there it sat for years! Sadly funny...

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: Yours for the price of a used Hyundai!

author: fintail
text:
The 80s are becoming cool again. Many of those designs are palate cleansers compared to new cars.

Saw some kind of new style Aston on the road this afternoon.

author: kyfdx
text: The Bitter episode was this past Fall. It's funny, to see the car still sitting in the driveway in episodes since (not running).

author: JustinS
text: We bought a Lexus UX a few weeks ago. I've only seen one other on the road. I'm sure this car isn't for everyone but I'm enjoying it a lot.

author: qbrozen
text: I saw one just a couple of days ago ... except it had a Toyota badge.

author: stickguy
text:
i like most of it! Looks a lot like an Infiniti QX30.

That front end though, looks like Lexus took their game up to the next level!

author: tlong
text: If they could fix their front end style, some of their vehicles look good.

author: berri
text: When I see a latter edition Lexus front end, I can't help thinking about the video clip they used on the old TV show Petticoat Junction showing the train fireman throwing some coal into the engine

author: ab348
text:
Ford rolls out its latest version of the Escape:

https://www.autonews.com/cars-concepts/ford-packs-2020-escape-3-cylinder-engine-hybrid-powertrains

Bringing back the hybrid seems their big news. Looks a lot like the existing one but can't tell if it has more sloped rear. These seem to sell consistently well but I am not their target market I guess since they do not move the needle for me at all.

author: kyfdx
text: Very Mazda-esque

author: tjc78
text: Wow, I literally getting ready to type the same thing...

author: stickguy
text: I like it! Love that color too.

author: Michaell
text:
Given that the Escape is meant to be the replacement for both the Focus and the Fusion, Ford has to really get this one right or it's gonna hurt.

I find the shape attractive and non-offensive (*cough* Nissan/Lexus *cough*), and the variety of engines should appeal to a wide audience, as well.

What is interesting is the inclusion of cylinder deactivation on the base 1.5L 3-cylinder engine. I suppose if you live in Florida or Kansas and never encounter a hill, running on 2 cylinders might be OK. Not sure how I'd feel about it here in Colorado.

author: explorerx4
text:
The Focus plant capacity has already been replaced by the Ranger, so I don't think the Escape has to pick up much of the volume slack from it.
Ford's main goal now is vehicle profit margin, Focus wasn't contributing much to that.

author: fintail
text: Someone in my building has a new Accord, and I've also noticed a new X3 hanging around. And then there's that wagon

author: stickguy
text: cylinder deactivation seems like a silly idea on an engine that small. So much complexity, probably compromised driving dynamics, and probably little to no real world improvement. Better off going with the hybrid.

author: tjc78
text:
Im not a fan of cylinder deactivation.  The Tahoe at work has it and you can absolutely tell when it kicks off to accelerate or climb a hill.  Almost feels like a little hesitation.  

On theinstant economy meter it tells you V8 or V4.

author: ab348
text: Im not sure if the 3.6 V6 in the ATS has it or not. I will have to check.

author: tjc78
text: I dont think so... Ive had three GM 3.6s and none of them had it.

author: ab348
text:
Hmm. Apparently it does. I have never noticed it.

https://media.cadillac.com/media/us/en/cadillac/news.detail.html/content/Pages/news/us/en/2015/dec/1210-award-cadillac.html

author: tjc78
text: Wow, guess its only on the Caddys.

author: sda
text: Our Pilot has cylinder deactivation. It can switch down to 3 cylinders. When it does it often feels like a subtle gear shift, and it sometimes creates a minor rumble and slight vibration in the cabin. It can be a little annoying and depending on the differing grade of the road will go in and out of ECO frequently. I am not convinced it provides an improvement in gas mileage and wish I could manually override it.

author: stickguy
text: I noticed it sometimes on our Oddessy (a 2005, so first year of VCM). Plus it had the Eco light. The RDX, really not noticeable at all. and no Eco light to make you think it is on.

author: stickguy
text: there are a number of people that think it causes problems. There are "muzzlers" available that you can put on the car that trick it into not ever switching the VCM on. The claim it fixes a lot of problems. with little to no MPG penalty.

author: explorerx4
text: I'm happy with stop/start since I sit at some traffic lights that take a while to change.

author: laurasdada
text: I have no issues with the stop/start in my car, I don't find it obtrusive.

author: stickguy
text: for some reason, even though it was an extensive redesign for 2018, the TLX does not have that feature. I don't mind not having it though!

author: qbrozen
text: I often cant tell when mine turns off. I only notice when I lift my foot and it starts back up again. It does not seem to be as quick on the startup as my F150 was and I can get a little jolt from it.

author: fintail
text: I've noticed it is less obtrusive on the wagon than the Bluetec, probably because of engine NVH (the 6 is virtually imperceptible at warm idle). Response is instant anyway.

author: explorerx4
text:
@fintail,
You better not leave that hockey equipment in the car, no trunk to isolate it.

author: fintail
text:
Oh I've already thought about that, I am somewhat of a neat freak about my cars, and smells would put me off. The cargo cover will also be in place whenever the gear is back there.

On the new car front, I saw a brand new X5 today, pretty sure it wasn't an X7.

author: andres3
text:
GLC300, the new popular MB cute-ute in Southern CA.

I saw a Youtube video comparing the usual suspects for decent size (but not big) SUV's, including:
Acura RDX
Volvo XC60
MB GLC300
Audi Q5
BMW X3
Was a pretty good review of the strengths and weaknesses, though a little excessively positive for all of them.

Basically luxury = MB & Audi

Sport = Acura & BMW

Off Road = Volvo

author: stickguy
text: I like all of those. Depending on budget, they would all be on the look at list when it's time to replace my TLX.

author: thebean
text: Will anything not be on the list?

author: stickguy
text: that will be a much shorter list, since it will be the wife's car and she has much "narrower" tastes in automobiles than I do at this point!

author: thebean
text: Makes sense. Wont be as much fun for you, however.

author: fintail
text:
Went in to pick up the rubber mats and cargo box promised to me by the salesman for the new car. He delivered, and I asked him about recent MB sales. He said GLCs are the hot thing here right now - he sold 3 this week, along with an AMG GT 4 door.

He also reminded me the all-important survey should arrive within a week, and I assured him he'll be fine. He has followed through with his promises, and communicated much better than other local dealers I contacted before the purchase.

author: texases
text: I was surprised there were no GLCs at the Dallas car show.  Most other MBs, though.

author: Michaell
text:
MB was a no-show in Denver.

Wife does like the GLC - at least, from the rear. Not that we're in the market for anything; she likes the Outback too much.

author: kyfdx
text: MB was about the only make with no display at the Cincinnati show.

author: stickguy
text: guy across the street from me has a GLC. A year or 2 ago it replaced a GLK. I like the C. Looks good.

author: kyfdx
text: It is in the generic mid-size SUV sweet spot. X3, GLC, RDX, Q5. All incredibly popular. My wife is now on her third one. I like the GLC look, as well.

author: fintail
text: MB was absent at the Vancouver show as well, which is either surprising or not, as the brand is yuuuuge there. At one point maybe 20 years ago, I think it had some weird stat like the most S-class per capita in NA or something.

author: tjc78
text:
Mid size SUV now = Mid size sedan in 90s.  

Easily the most popular segment

author: stickguy
text: makes sense. I consider that to be the most practical, especially for a single car family. We would never give up having some sort of box vehicle in the fleet! The RDX is not the most efficient design style wise (back is a bit rounded, not really square) but it still holds a ton for something the length of a prior generation Jetta or a current Civic.

author: jpp75
text:
Cadillac was also a no show, but I doubt anyone noticed or cared.

@Michaell I can't fault her for liking the Outback, it's one of those vehicles that does everything right and would be hard to replace. The GLC may be nicer in some respects but you all have the better car all around.

author: Michaell
text:
Curbside classic had a nice review of the Denver Auto show; worth a read.

We loaded up the Outback with everything they needed to attend a summer camp fair today. Swallowed it all with room to spare. I need to spend some time cleaning up the interior; the leather could use some attention.

Looks good too.

text: Saw a fairly new (early 2000's) E wagon today parked in front of our house. My best description of the color would be metallic liver. Not a beautiful choice.

author: andres3
text:
Can any of you guess what this unusual SUV is? Going on the 15 South near Ontario area in CA.

Sorry for the dead butterflies, but was coming back from Pahrump, NV, which goes thru Baker, CA (basically almost Vegas). I know what the SUV is, but testing you!

Not as sorry as the butterflies.../jk

ps - looks like an Urus:

author: stickguy

Bentley, lambo or Masserati? One of those beats.

and glad you mentioned the bugs. I was about to try and clean my screen!

author: Michaell
text:
Lamborghini Urus - was featured on the TV Show "Billions" last night.

Baker - home to the worlds tallest thermometer! My dad would do some work up there around the 4th of July, patrolling I-15 with a task force looking for illegal fireworks being brought into CA. This was a good 30+ years ago.

author: texases
text: I wonder if the Urus is "worth" the premium over a maxed-out Cayenne...

author: qbrozen
text: Depends on what you value. To that end, is a maxed out Cayenne worth the premium over a Trackhawk?

author: andres3
text:
URUS seems to be the answer for someone that says a Macan S or SQ5 is too slow. Someone mentioned Macan's were competitive in Autocrosses.

Of course, there is talk of SQ7 or RSQ7 or 8. Q8 seems to be for those that like to say I have a Q8 and Q8> your Q7

author: texases
text: The Urus and Cayenne are near twins under the skin, is why I ask.

author: fintail
text: Not sure if it was a Fisker Karma or the new release, but I saw one today in an unusual pastel kind of lavender blue color, like something I'd expect on the color chart for a 59 Plymouth.

author: stickguy
text: I saw one of them around here not too long ago. Shocking.

author: ab348
text:
My buddy Evan wrote this piece on the new Cadillac CT5 today. Best pictures of it I've seen so far. The C-pillar treatment is very unfortunate since the rest of it seems pretty good.

Oddly enough, mini-vans are considered a prestige ride in China. If you own one, you are deemed somewhat important.

Yeah, I know. Go figure. But it's true.

Looks like Lexus took a last generation Nissan Quest and welded their signature ugly grill on.

the first Lexus minivan

text:

As I work in kind of a tech-adjacent field, some of those who got in back in the day and cashed in are swimming in money, so the new wagon doesn't stick out at all in the parking garage.

author: stickguy
text: My sister lives in N. Virginia, near where AOL HQ is (or was?). Anyway, this was before they hit big and went public. The early employees all had stock options which when they vested, were worth a bundle. She said the next day the parking lot was flooded with fancy new cars.

author: fintail
text: Saw 2x Eclipse today, not the cool 90s DSM legend, but the one of a million tall small CUVs.

author: tjc78
text: I saw one the other day... dont get using that name

author: fintail
text: It might be the most offensive old name revival in a long time. I know some are irked by the new Blazer, but I suspect it is a much more competent vehicle than the 85 S10 Blazer my dad had back in the day.

author: sda
text: I like the new Blazer. What I dont like is GMs ambitious pricing across all product lines. They all seem over priced.

author: qbrozen
text:
I think they figure they'll just work it like a clothing store. Mark it all up 50% so you can have a 50% off sale and folks think they are getting a bargain.

Besides, while I haven't dived too deeply, it seems to be priced in line with the Grand Cherokee

text: Today on the road saw an A-class, big Subaru, BMW 8er.

text:

On the plus side, since I'm an Emerald Club member, I got to skip the 30 person waiting line, and was in my car within 5 minutes. I took the keys, and beat it!

author: tjc78
text: When I traveled and rented frequently, I loved Emerald Aisle. It saved so much time. I think now all the majors have something similar.

author: fintail
text:
Yep, Hertz has it too, also tiered like most of the rest.

Speaking of Nissan, I read somewhere that a full third of their sales are fleet, in the US anyway. For some models like Sentra and Altima, probably more than that.

author: tjc78
text:
What happened to Nissan?  They used to make some interesting stuff.

Now nothing is really bad, but nothing that great either.  The only thing Id consider would be a Maxima or some of the Infiniti models.

author: ab348
text: My sense is that they have taken the penny-pinching to the max, hence the CTV automatics, etc.

author: fintail
text:
Nissan still sells a lot, but I think has some image issues. Whenever I see a new one, I think "rental", and I can't imagine who'd buy a new Sentra in this day and age, unless it was insanely cheap.

Co-worker of mine has a 13 Rogue, bought as a low mileage demo. She beats the hell out of it, even using it for farm duty, and has ~90K on it now. It has had zero issues.

author: Michaell
text: And that's why they are popular. Not flashy, but dependable. They've been offering the CVT for a while, so it's likely dialed in, engineering wise.

author: explorerx4
text:
My son in law had a leased 2013/2014(not sure). Looked great and it didn't really have any problems, but it handled horribly and had tons of rattles by the time he turned it in.
Anyone who drove it, hated it.

author: fintail
text: New style X5, white, CA plates, weaving around in traffic to perfectly match the stereotype.

author: qbrozen
text: Saw my first new s60 in the wild today. Sharp car. The s90 design language carried over well.

author: stickguy

author: Mr_Shiftright
text: S90 looks pretty large in real life, doesn't it?

author: fintail
text:
Saw an X7 today. Reminded me of a local ad, where a spokeswoman exclaims it is the "biggest BMW ever!" or something similar. Is that really something to be proud of?

Also saw a couple of E wagons, new style but not sure of year. One was an E63, other a red sport trim model. I wonder if my car even has an exact twin, I have some doubt.

author: explorerx4
text: I've seem a couple of new Foresters lately. Seems bigger.

author: texases
text: Those Foresters keep growing. The latest Crosstrek is about the size of my son's 2007 Forester, which is just about ideal.

author: kyfdx

author: fintail
text: Not brand new, but saw a late model big Duramax truck today. Noteworthy because it was stuck in the middle of a busy downtown intersection, and had a "DISABLED" sign attached to the back. I noticed it in the same spot an hour later, I overheard guys talking about a fuel problem.

author: texases
text:
New Alfa Giulia, at least it was running:
https://jalopnik.com/car-and-drivers-long-term-alfa-romeo-giulia-quadrifogli-1834511976

author: andres3
text:
There's still a lot of Big 3 apologists online (Facebook for example) where this story was posted, and the usual argument is that the problems on the FCA car are exaggerated, and that if it was a "German/Japanese" car, the problems would have been completely overlooked.

Not really sure why these alternate reality viewpoints get argued online; don't they realize they won't convince former owners? Someone that has avoided a brand based solely on word of mouth, perhaps, but not former owners that know the truth.

author: berri

author: stickguy
text:

did pass a new Kia Telluride on the road today. Nice looking in person. Not as big looking as the pictures make it seem.

text:
the wife was just talking about turning the heat back on tonight. I told her to suck it up. In slightly nicer terms.

Just walked the dog, and grabbed a pair of gloves out of the closet. crazy, considering next week is prime time to start opening pools.

the wife was just talking about turning the heat back on tonight. I told her to suck it up. In slightly nicer terms

author: ab348
text:

A-class:






B-class:

author: stickguy
text: I like that A class. Sharp.

author: ab348
text: The only thing about the A-class I am iffy about is the dash, which looks like several other current MB models. I actually like the "glass cockpit" digital instruments and screens, but the round vents, the shiny black plastic and some other parts look a bit boy-racerish to me and I'm not a fan of the look.

author: fintail
text:
That specific vent design is a coupe thing, I think MB is trying to inject the pretense of sport into the car - the brand has been doing that throughout the range, and I can't say I support it all. That car also has the fancier style steering wheel also seen in coupes and AMG models, and it's a nice unit.

The full digital gauges being standard is a cool thing and a hint at the future. I think the display may be unique to this model, as it seems shorter in height than the screen in the E or S. The screen being very exposed with a thin bezel makes me a little leery.

The B eventually came to the US, but only as an electric, and I think it has been a slow seller.

I suspect it was either a case of a phone not having gone through a $500 registration process as ab348 mentions, or that combination of entitled laziness which might follow certain vehicle models. I have some doubts any LEOs in this area are going to give that citation.

some of it is, I think that people don't want their cars spying on them.
Just another way to monetize your data.

Upon seeing a new Corolla this morning, I was thinking the shape looks familiar:





Especially the greenhouse proportion and detail, wow. Maybe Toyota really is the new GM, with all of its strengths and foibles.

text:

one of my neighbors seems to have gotten a new BMW 440 coupe (2 door). Black. Looks sharp. Also a new temp tag range rover Velar. Though there was already one in the 'Hood (same black color) so either there is a copy cat or he got a replacement for some reason.

text:
Upon seeing a new Corolla this morning, I was thinking the shape looks familiar:

author: explorerx4

author: andres3
text: Some think bland is great for flying under the radar of speed enforcement, literally! I will say, I drove a '95 Camry around for nearly 2 years and I never got pulled over.

author: andres3
text: The new Honda Passport seems to have hit the nail on the head for what the market wants these days.

author: thebean
text: 20 inch wheels/tires make the Passport a no go for me. Im not real smart, so maybe theres a valid reason, but it seems like 18 inchers would have been just fine for it, with, of course, some design tweaks to make the wheel openings a bit smaller.

author: stickguy
text: Bigger sidewalks is all you need.

author: andres3
text: I agree, I noticed the 20's, even on lower trims! I mentioned it to the salesman, how I switched the 20's on my TTS to 19's, and it's crazy that Honda is putting 20's on a Passport even in basic trims. Now the ELITE model, at $54K, I could understand.

author: Michaell
text: I test drove the Passport, and didn't notice a rough ride on the 20's

author: andres3
text: The sidewalls are plenty decent, even with 20" wheels, They are some big tires. Still, I could see an even beefier more off-road type tire used if they went with 18" wheels. My objection to 20" wheels is the cost of 20" tires. Have you looked lately?

author: Michaell
text:
Nope - I worked pretty hard to keep the spend under $1000 when I replaced the 19" tires on our old CX-7.

I'll agree that most folks don't pay much attention to the running costs of something they buy or lease. When we got the CX-7, I knew I was in for a shock when we had to replace the tires.

author: stickguy
text: Our RDX has 18s. They werent too pricey. A spec TLX has 19s. They will cost more. I just hope to not need to re-shoe it before it goes back. Only if I end up buying it out.

author: tjc78
text:
If you think about it... shouldn't the tire with the larger rim opening be cheaper?

If two tires are exactly the same height and width, but one has a 17" opening and the other has a 20" opening, doesn't the 20" tire have less rubber?

Am I missing something?

author: stickguy
text:
Skinnier sidewall, but more linear feet?

Might be more expensive to make. But most likely, its a vestige of when big tires were low production, so had to cost more. People expect it, and will pay it, so they charge it.

author: explorerx4
text:
In the parking lot at work, a few new cars. The only one I can remember is a gray M235i convertible.

My truck has 22's and the tires are a long way from replacement.

author: kyfdx
text:
Most of the higher diameter tires are also wider (though, they wouldn't have to be). Most vehicles that go with 19" wheels standard, also increase the overall size, it seems, as well. (relative to the old model with smaller wheels).

My wife's car has a 19" wheel option (vs. standard 18"), which was one option I could do without.

author: andres3
text:
It's a bit more then that. It takes more high-tech, engineering, and manufacturing exactness to make a skinny sidewall support, say a 96 load rating and meet the speed rating specs, than it does to work with a beefier bigger sidewall tire. Almost all tires these days are XL for extra load because cars are heavier and sidewalls are skinnier. Also, bigger tires tend to weigh more, despite the bigger hole in the middle, a lot of times because a bigger hole in the middle indicates a bigger tire around, and they tend to be wider.

Now if only they could get the ratio of price to be the same as the ratio of wheel size. For instance, get a 20" tire to cost 20/19ths what a 19" tire costs in the same size. That would be preferable to the current pricing scheme.

author: berri
text: Sales volume also comes into play I think. If you sell less of certain sizes, their fixed and semi-fixed costs like molds and transportation are spread over a smaller base incurring individual tire cost increases.

author: tjc78
text:
I think a lot of the points are valid, but Id bet dollars to donuts they are simply more expensive because they are perceived better and the public will pay. 

I bet the auto auto makers added cost is negligible

author: kyfdx
text:
Go to Tirerack.com and check the weight of a 19" tire, vs. an 18" option on the same vehicle.

I think you'll see a substantial difference.

author: fintail
text: Went to the store, saw another new Corolla. Rental.

author: andres3
text: 19" wheels also tend to weight a lot more than 18" wheels.

author: stickguy
text:

I still think it makes business sense to at least have 2 sedans. a small/medium, and a medium/large. Like a Jetta/Passat if you don't want too small, or Elantra/Sonata. Do it right, and will be 2 lengths of the same basic car so cheaper to produce.

author: fintail
text: Fleet sales

author: berri
text: Not my field, but there is a school of thought out there that fracked wells will have a relatively short time span compared to conventional drilling wells. If that turns out to be true, the future may be back to cars or electric/hybrid. Japan isn't dropping minivans right now due to their potential if driver-less becomes a reality. Also, it seems young drivers are often buying cars rather than crossovers, at least initially. Time will tell I guess.

author: stickguy
text: Fusion I think is a platform mate to the Edge. these days, since all the CUVs are just tall station wagons anyway, should be super simple to go the other way and stick a sedan body on the same chassis. Especially the fancy modular ones.

author: berri
text: The Fusion can serve as a band aid in the event the car side perks up while an updated model is set up. Gotta order tooling and the like which has lead times.

author: ab348
text: Fusion strikes me as too narrow to be used as the basis for the Edge. I thought the Fusion was a stretched Focus platform?

author: texases
text: The Fusion and Edge are related like the Camry and Highlander. Not too narrow, it''s wider than the Focus. But, like the Highlander, the Edge is more than a jacked up Fusion. We have the MKX and MKZ, and there are LOTS of differences.

author: berri
text: Have you been happy with those Lincoln's?

author: tjc78
text: I dont think there is a single one of the CUVs that dont have sedan DNA in them.

author: texases
text: Yes, were happy. My wife likes her 2008 MKX, wants to keep it after 11 years. I like my 2011 MKZ hybrid, 35 mpg day in day out.

author: berri
text: Personally, I think that Lincoln's strategy is wiser than Cadillac's. If a buyer wants European, they'll buy European. However, I think there is a market for traditional American luxury. I guess we'll see how it plays out.

author: fintail
text:
Saw another E wagon on the highway this morning. I tried to catch up for maybe some brotherhood recognition, but I had to exit.

I've also seen a ton of the big boy Subaru lately.

author: stickguy
text: a new RAV4. In Cab service in NYC.

author: fintail
text: I've seen a couple Ford Ecosport lately, more than I have seen before. Those small SWB CUVs still don't look right to me, like they are intended for a less developed market. Then again, given some socio-economics, maybe that's good planning.

author: Michaell
text: Weren't they originally for India?

author: fintail
text: I think you may be correct, it has that or a China look to it.

author: thebean
text: Im pretty sure they originated in India.

author: kyfdx
text: The slowest car that C&D tested last year.

author: explorerx4
text:
Ecosport made in India.
Saw a Titan XD.

author: tifighter
text: Toyota Mirai. Burgundy color.

author: tlong
text: I agree that the Camaro is ugly and the Corvette is gorgeous.

author: tlong
text: A BMW 228i. Looked older, like a 5-10 yo 3-series. Was this a 3 series with a smaller engine from overseas? Or a different series?

author: explorerx4
text:
My next door neighbor brought home a new A220 sedan.
sat in the passenger seat to check it out a bit, seems nice.
It's red, but almost exactly the same color as the 10 year old 3 series she sold, kind of amazing.
I told her Mercedes really wanted her to buy one of their cars, so they made one in her color.

author: stickguy
text: I liked that car when we saw it at the car show.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new style G-Wagen on the road today, and yet another new Corolla.

author: thebean
text: A red Civic Type R shined up to beat the band. Man, that wing is big.

author: stickguy
text: Ive seen a couple new corollas. And a few altimas. Was expecting more of them, but might just not notice them.

author: ab348
text:
The other day in a parking lot I walked behind a new Camry - I think it was the top-line model, the XSE. White with a black roof IIRC. But since I went behind it I got to see those black things hanging down from the taillights.



I was surprised to see they are apparently black plastic fake slit vents. They have louvers of a sort molded into them. Once again I am reminded of Nancy Kerrigan: "Whyyyyyyyyyyyyyyyy?"

author: stickguy
text: Sporty!

author: tjc78
text: Over styling at it's finest.

author: explorerx4
text: The new Camry does have a sporty design, but those fake vents and taillight corners that look like the red broke off diminish the look.

author: tifighter
text: I was in Japan again two weeks ago and saw a number of US Camrys being used for taxi service. Mostly hybrids, but still a big car in Japan. I was a little surprised.

author: berri
text: Those aren't plastic slit vents, they are tears of joy

author: fintail
text: Saw a Karma Revero on the road today, appeared to be an almost 50s looking pale blue color.

author: explorerx4
text:
Video of new Explorer being assembled, about 5-6 minutes long.
https://www.blueovalforums.com/forums/index.php?/topic/67366-2020-explorer-production-video/

author: explorerx4
text:
My neighbor who bought the red A220, is now driving a black CLA
After 5 days, SRS and service required popped up.
So now waiting of some part.

author: thebean
text: Have them call @driver100 and he can explain the many advantages to owning a Benz. That should make them feel much better.

author: tjc78
text: .... pass the popcorn. This is gonna be good

author: fintail
text:
First year model might have a quirk here and there, breaking news?

I am surprised at the very few A sedans I have seen on the road. But maybe not, given the CUV craze still in high gear.

author: tjc78
text:
Sedans just dont sell.

I was having a conversation with a guy at work about this the other day. If you want an SUV you have tons of choices, sedans are much more limited.

At least they are discounted well.

author: motoent
text:
Yeah, same problem abroad. In Germany, it's station wagon central. They had to invent the four-door "coupe"--like the Mercedes CLS or BMW gran coupe--to get people to buy a four-door car with a trunk again, just as long as it's not called a sedan.

Of course, you can combine the two concepts and then you end up with the "shooting brake," which brings me to my spot ...

author: fintail
text:
I think trunkback sedans have an old people stigma in some places - I know in Germany, an E sedan is considered a "Rentnertraum" - pensioner's dream. Traditional sedans seem to carry the best lease deals on this side of the pond, anyway.

Wagons have an even worse image in the US, BMW dropped the 5er wagon for NA a decade ago, and E wagons make up a whopping 4% of E sales. I drivee an E wagon, and more than one co-worker gave me a funny look when I told them about it - they all wanted me to get some kind of SUV. No surprise, the ones I even kind of like, I can't afford.

Cool video, makes me want to go back to Germany asap. Lane discipline, such a weird concept.

author: andres3
text: Audi won't even bring the RS4 Avant (wagon) to us in the USA

author: fintail
text: MB won'y give us a C wagon of any flavor - and the killer is they are sold in Canada.

author: bhill2
text: I was an adolescent during a period when the fashion among young men was pants so tight that going downstairs could ultimately substitute for a vasectomy. It's amazing what people will do or not do in the name of looking good.

author: berri
text: A220 is the new Canadian, now Airbus jet Delta just started flying. Even though smaller than a B737, Boeing tried to claim it was unfair competition.

author: fintail
text:
Gotta keep those sweet GLA/GLC profit margins. I am quite surprised we get the A trunkback sedan.

Canada also gets the E53 wagon. I like the I6, but I am not sold on the sport trim and suspension, I prefer the lux trim on my car.

Got behind a C63S coupe in traffic while in the fintail today. Talk about extremes. Also several new Corollas, all rentals. Lots of festivals etc in this region for the week, so we are loaded up with tourists. Tons of Altima rentals, too.

author: fintail
text:
Had a few minutes to pass today, stopped by MB, Porsche, BMW, and Audi lots (they are all within a couple miles here). MB highlights were a white on white S560 cabrio ($156K), white AMG GT 4 door coupe ($162K),
unusually lightly equipped S560 coupe that I think was around $130K (not showing up in inventory) and an assortment of usual cars - no wagons on site. Porsche appeared to have received a full day's production of Macan - every color and variety stacked like firewood around the lot, barely room to move. Audi had a similar volume of Q5 to the point where parking was hard to find. BMW had a couple of new M340 sedans in the $60-65K range, a M3 CS for something like $120K, X7 at $110K.

author: fintail
text: Saw a goodie at the grocery store today. E400 wagon, 17-18 model. Grey, lux trim like mine, 18" wheels (mine are 19"), but apparent full load otherwise, I could see it had distronic and HUD, and the big deal, a Designo interior. Someone paid up for that baby when new, probably around 90K.

author: berri
text: ...and are still paying for it with the dollars in depreciation

author: fintail
text:
Those who actually buy one can afford it

IIRC E wagon buyers have been the wealthiest MB customer demographic for some time. I came along to lower the numbers a little

author: berri
text: Personally, I think MB wagons look better than their SUV/CUV companions. The wagon has a sleekness to it.

author: fintail
text: I won't disagree. Although I like G-Wagens for what they are, I think the best looking normal MB SUV/CUV is the GLC - and it resembles a lifted C wagon. I am still irked that the hardworking MBA braintrust at MBUSA doesn't offer the C wagon here, but I suppose the profit margins are larger on the bloatlings.

author: tifighter
text: Silver MB EQC while in Amsterdam. The new electric one. GLC sized. Not the prettiest face.

author: sda
text: On my drive home from picking up my daughter near Atlanta, a very nice black with black vinyl top, tear drop factory alloys with correct whitewalls, a 93 Cadillac Fleetwood fwd. It had N.C. plates and was keeping up with the 75 mph traffic. It was 90 degrees out, ac must have been working, windows were closed and the driver looked relaxed and enjoying the drive.

author: fintail
text: On the road today new Mazda 3 super blind spot edition, and at the visitor parking area at work, an E450 cabrio in dark blue on white with a white steering wheel.

author: texases
text: I was stunned when I saw pics of that Mazda, and not in a good way.

author: stickguy
text: at Lowe's, a Corolla hatch with temp tags. Actually not too bad looking, but I only saw it from the rear and side!

author: tjc78
text:
Most Toyotas look ok....until you see the front.

They are butta-faces

author: fintail
text: Maybe the Corolla was a west coast launch, seeing numerous sedans on the road now, lots of rentals. Also saw a hatch model today.

author: stickguy
text: another new Passport. I like it. Seems that the missing 8" or whatever makes it better proportioned. On the list to look at for the wife.

author: tjc78
text: I've seen quite a few over here in NJ, but I do have a Toyota dealer walking distance from my house.

author: fintail
text: Saw yet another Corolla today, white, zzz. CEO had both his cars in the workplace garage today - Ferrari 458 and new/facelift (Bentley) Continental. Most of the rest of the suits drive far tamer cars, CFO has an MDX and late 90s SL.

author: tjc78
text:
Our owner drives a Quatroporte (and more commonly an XTS loaner from the dealer group).

President drives a Range Rover

CFO drives an older Audi vert and a mid 2000s (pre beak) Acura TL.

author: tifighter
text: Pic of that EQC I mentioned earlier, now that Edmunds is pic-friendly again:

author: explorerx4
text:
In the parking lot at work a gray GLC AMG 43. If not for the badging, could pass as a more mainstream trim.
A new silver Fusion. Didn't see which model, but had fog lamps, so probably some version of a Titanium.

author: qbrozen
text: Yikes. Toyota grille, Dodge headlights, and massive tristar badge. Its like the worst of the worst meshed together.

author: stickguy
text: At the beach, with the rich people so many nice cars. Street parked was a gorgeous light metallic blue Ferrari. Something new, a front engine one. And enough newer Porsches and range rovers to start a dealership.

author: explorerx4
text: Yikes! A chrome purple Mercedes AMG G convertible. At least the top was black to tone it down a bit.

author: fintail
text:
G cabrio? I think those are all private imports here. They have been made since the start of G production, although examples from the 90s onward were sold for luxury more than utility, and even 90s ones will cost you a pretty penny, you won't get one for under 50K.

I've seen maybe 5 new Corollas in the past day, all but one a rental, one rental had a crooked front plate looking like it could fail at any time - what is it with rental cars and messed up front plates? Maybe aggressive car washes.

author: explorerx4
text: GT. When I added the convertible I dropped the T.

author: fintail
text:
Ah, that makes more sense

Speaking of that, walking back after dropping off the old car last night, I passed by several body shops. In one of the front lots was a new G63 AMG - wonder what happened to it. I saw no obvious damage.

author: stickguy
text: New gladiator. I really liked it. Wife thought I was nuts.

author: Michaell
text: Is it bigger than it looks in pictures? I've not seen one in the wild yet.

author: qbrozen
text: I actually think it is smaller than it looks in pics. Pics (to me) make it look full-size, like F150. Reality is more like Dakota.

author: explorerx4
text:
Have not seen a Gladiator on the road, but the dealer close to me has a few.
I think they look a little off.

author: stickguy
text: It seemed small IRL.

author: tifighter
text: Visually the Gladiator looks really long. Probably since the Wrangler is narrow (and tall) anyhow, but I saw a white one yesterday cross an intersection and thought I was at a rail crossing.

author: fintail
text: Saw another X7 today - not sure how well these will fare when the new GLS hits the road. Also so many new Corollas every day now that they have stopped being new.

author: laurasdada
text: As posted elsewhere, today within a few minutes: Aston Martin DB11, two Ferrari California and a 458 Italia. Nice to be reminded regularly of my epic career and financial mistakes.

author: ab348
text:
New Caddy XT 6 3-row SUV finally dropped, and it's getting decent reviews too aside from being universally deemed too expensive.

https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/reviews/2020-cadillac-xt6-preview/

author: qbrozen
text: I may be missing it ... why is it too expensive? Seems to be right in line with the Q7/XC90/GX460/Aviator

author: stickguy
text: nice looking. tons of content. Too big for me, and quite the porker! But, after reading the review, sounds like the XT5 is getting a serious makeover too so that should be a good option in the ~190" 5 seater class.

author: ab348
text: Thats a standard auto writer line these days for any Cadillac. They seem to perceive them as equivalent to Hondas or something.

author: explorerx4
text:
Just don't park one of those XT6's next to a Telluride.
I have yet to see any other than at best a tepid review of the XT6.

author: fintail
text: I was going to say, I see a dose of Telluride or even a little XC90 there.

author: qbrozen
text: I could be wrong, but I think a review of any 3-row SUV is tepid. Or maybe thats just my personal bias.

author: explorerx4
text:
@qbrozen,
You'll have to try out the new Explorer or Aviator.
They are back to an RWD architecture and have some pretty big power options available.
Don't pick on the wrong model at a stoplight, it might not be like an XT6 which has a Malibu engine.

author: ab348
text:
The 3.6 that's in the XT6 was never available in the Malibu. It didn't offer a V-6 after 2012 and this one is a new engine.

Every Lincoln introduced over the last number of years has elicited similar enthusiastic responses from its fans. Every Lincoln introduced over the last number of years has flopped in the marketplace.

author: explorerx4
text:
@ab348,
My bad, should have written Impala/XTS.
It's not about where product has been, but where it's going.
Read some Explorer/Aviator reviews and see what the XT6 is up against.

author: qbrozen
text: I would be interested in an Explorer Sport. But, then again, one has to eventually ask it to take a corner. ;b

author: ab348
text:
Review today in the local newspaper of the Nautilus. That breathtaking price is in worthless Canadian dollars BTW.

Speaking of "tepid"...

https://www.thechronicleherald.ca/wheels/2019-lincoln-nautilus-quiet-luxury-comes-at-a-price-337035/

author: stickguy
text: Is the nautilus the edge rebrand basically?

author: berri
text: The MKC will be replaced by the upcoming Lincoln Corsair. Nautilus doesn't seem to get reviewers excited, but the upcoming Aviator does. Same for the prototype Corsair . But Lincoln, and the new Ford Explorer may have a pricing problem. I'd hold off until they've been out for awhile, or maybe better yet, buy one used down the road.

author: berri
text: When I look at these crossovers, I'm not sure you need to pay lux prices anymore with some of the new 2020's coming out. HyunKia may be especially hard to beat with the Telluride and Palisade. Seems like strong reviews and an excellent value. I guess the market will tell. Regardless, I think the differences are shrinking between lux and non lux crossovers, especially when you look at features.

author: fintail
text: Saw a Palisade in traffic yesterday (have seen numerous Telluride already), I have to say these look like a pretty good value, upmarket appearance.

author: stickguy
text: VW Aereton (sp?) Nice car. looks sharp, comfy. Not cheap. Probably won't sell many.

author: ab348
text: Arteon. I saw my first ahead of me in traffic just yesterday. Nice-looking design, but knowing the price point I had to ask myself "Why would anyone buy one of those?".

author: stickguy
text: the one in the showroom (R line I think) stickered at $45K. Getting up there.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new style Explorer on the road, looked to be on a test drive.

author: kyfdx
text: For $350K+, you can have one, too

author: explorerx4
text: Is that an early 70's Celica on the right side of the picture?

author: kyfdx
text: It is. Didnt get a picture, as I see it at every car gathering, here. I guess Im used to it.

author: fintail
text: Celica is more interesting to me than the R-R.

author: kyfdx
text: The suicide doors get your attention, though.

author: fintail
text: It has a presence. What it says, however, may not be positive

author: thebean
text: At the gym today, a S-Class wannabe (at least according to @driver100) Genesis G90. I dont believe its a wannabe. I briefly talked to the owner and he has had it for two months and loves it. Its the twin turbo V6 and he said its plenty fast for him. I looked over it and the fit/finish looked superb. Panel gaps consistent and the paint was super deep looking. The only thing he is regretting slightly is getting black on black here in Texas. This week we are due for a string of 100 degree days with humidity.

author: ab348
text: I dont understand the appeal of black on black.

author: texases
text: Me neither, but lots of cars are hard to find with anything besides a black interior. Wish it was otherwise...

author: ab348
text: Tell me about it. Virtually no dealers here will stock anything other than a black interior. Manufacturers like Kia only offer black interiors in the Canadian market despite offering alternatives in other markets.

author: fintail
text: I like how the US vs Canadian market weirdness is still a thing. I think MB does it best, offering numerous models in Canada not seen south of the border, and with significantly different options structures.

author: berri
text: I wonder if all this black inside is about covering up cheap materials? On the outside, my personal experience has been that white is actually easier to keep looking good than black, even in northern winter climates.

author: ab348
text: Yes, my experience is that black may not show accumulated dirt on the seats from the occupants clothing, but shows every speck of dust, lint and hair.

author: tifighter
text: My wife likes coffee. Regularly, she likes to share it with the interior. Black works pretty well for us.

author: sda
text: Black leather seems to hide most soil sins the best. Black cloth can look spotted, faded and dingy. And, yes all lint and everything else shows on the upholstery and carpet. And it is dark and hot. Did I say HOT?

author: berri
text: I also think black hides cheap quality plastic better than beige, or even grey.

author: fintail
text:
Every single rental car I've had in Germany has been equipped with black interior, making me once think it was a German thing. But it is probably just an easy cleaning thing - the dust is easy to wipe off, and the real dirt is harder to see.

On the road today - 2x new GLE, Corolla hatch, Mazda 3 non-blind spot edition, new Panamera, new A8 at work.

author: tjc78
text: My favorite combo is dark floors, but light seats and headliner. Best of both worlds, IMO.

author: thebean
text: Saw my first Gladiator in the wild. This one was a medium gray Rubicon.

author: ab348
text:
Drool-worthy:

https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/reviews/2020-cadillac-ct6-preview

author: fintail
text:
Someone at work has a CT6 completely blacked out. A friend of mine loved the CT6 he test drove, but the local dealer played hardball so bad he walked away and right into the Lincoln dealer, who was more than willing to move some metal.

Saw an i-Pace or whatever the electric Jag CUV is called.

author: berri
text: I'm kind of surprised that either one of those dealers can successfully play hardball in the PNW metro areas. More about German's and Japan in that segment.

author: fintail
text: I don't think they do it successfully. At the time my friend was interested, the CT6 hybrid model he wanted was new and rare, so they played hardball. Check resale on those, my friend is now considering a used one, as he has another car (Fusion, sibling to his MKZ but he doesn't like it) he wants to get out of.

author: sda
text: If I recall he had some initial issues with the MKZ and with this being his second one, I imagine he is getting bored with it and ready for a change. I remember replacing my 96 Mazda Millenia 24 mo lease for a 98 Millenia purchase, and being meh. Though nothing wrong with the car I replaced it within 16 months.

author: fintail
text:
Yep, my friend had a bunch of MKZ teething issues, but the dealer set it right and the car has been flawless since. He actually likes the thing, and I think plans to keep it for awhile, but the Fusion bought as a commuter or something for his other half hasn't warmed his heart. The MKZ is green on green and has virtually all options, probably a pretty rare car.

Spotted a new SL63 yesterday evening.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new style Soul GT today, don't recall having seen one on the road before.

author: andres3
text: I can vouch that the leather in the expensive VW is far better than that in the most expensive Tiguan (SLE Premium).

author: explorerx4
text: Saw a new Honda Passport. Supposed to be more off roady than a Pilot and the body does look like it sits higher, but the rear lower control arms are very low. Kind of reminds me of the 2006-2010 Explorer rear suspension.

author: kyfdx
text: Dammit, son, I told you to leave the Bentley at home!

author: ab348
text:
Once again, Mazda answers the question nobody asked with the intro of the CX-5 Diesel. Only $4100 more than the top of the line 2L Turbo gas model, with less HP and torque, and just 3 mpg more! I'm sure these will be flying off the lots...

https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/reviews/2019-mazda-cx-5-signature-diesel-awd-review/

author: fintail
text: For all intents and purposes, I think diesel is dead in the NA market for passenger cars and CUVs.

author: stickguy
text: Yesterday, 3 telluride and a palisade. I think hyunkia is doing k with these jumbos. Nice looking, and imposing. Really do appear bigger than they actually are.

author: berri
text: Came upon a unusual looking car that I first thought was some kind of sporty Tesla from behind It was a Lexus CL500 I saw as I got closer. Hadn't seen one before. Kind of odd to me, but different strokes for different folks. While its back profile looked Tesla, the side view of the greenhouse almost looked like an old Saturn coupe model.

author: tjc78
text: They aren't really that big. My Enclave is bigger inside.. or at least feels that way.

author: texases
text: I take it you mean the LC500...

author: Davercee
text:
"Came upon a unusual looking car that I first thought was some kind of sporty Tesla from behind It was a Lexus CL500 I saw as I got closer. Hadn't seen one before. Kind of odd to me, but different strokes for different folks. While its back profile looked Tesla, the side view of the greenhouse almost looked like an old Saturn coupe model."

My first time to hear of this. Might want to see it in action.

author: berri
text: Yep texases, I think it did say LC500. Guess I'm getting dyslexic with age

author: laurasdada
text: I would have dad, but you took the 458 Italia! Mom!!! (who probably took the M1...)

author: tifighter
text: Seen a few e-trons on the road over the past few days. All black or grey, so you know its German. Basically looks like a Q8; Im not sure thats a good thing or a bad thing.

author: kyfdx
text: I think the Q8 looks good. Sportier than a Q7.

author: tifighter
text: Agreed. I'm not saying the Q8 is bad. I'm saying they look nearly identical. I bet the sales guy at the dealer walks up to a Q8 with the e-tron key all the time. And vice versa. They are the same size.

author: fintail
text: Saw a Lambo Uterus today, maybe not the vehicle I'd want to be in if the nation ever recovers from TEM syndrome.

author: sda
text: What a horrible name for a vehicle. Lol

author: tjc78
text: Agreed!

author: ab348
text: The name is actually Urus, still an awful name. Must have lost something in the translation.

author: fintail
text: Yes, "uterus" is me making fun of the name. Not exactly a pretty thing, either. Money and class/taste/sense diverge again, makes a Bentayga look downright attractive.

author: texases
text: The seem to like those odd names. The Murcielago always reminded me of

author: texases
text: Saw my first A220, hear it's an improvement.

author: explorerx4
text:
My neighbor has one. Inside looks better than a CLA, but it's had an airbag problem twice.
She has it back again but drove a loaner for about 6 of the first 8 weeks.

author: fintail
text: I've seen fewer A sedans than I expected. I like the style more than the CLA. CLA will have a significant facelift for MY2020.

author: berri
text: When I see A220, I think of the new commercial jet Airbus acquired from Bombardier that was developed in Canada. Noticed Air Canada will start using that aircraft on some routes into Seattle. Maybe a bit of a slap at Boeing and their attempt to harm that aircraft with out of bounds tariff requests?

author: fintail
text:
Saw another X7 on the road today, still quite unpretty to my eyes, and that's relative to its already unpretty class. That grille, ugh.

I don't think Boeing is in its best position ever right now.

author: berri
text: ...but the CEO is still on board hauling in millions in salary and benefits

author: fintail
text: "Talent" must be retained and rewarded lol

author: explorerx4
text:
Driving on Route 17 in NJ today, saw a McLaren dealership.
Also , I think I saw a Urus in CT.

author: tjc78
text: We were very close to each other yesterday... I was on 17 in Hasbrouck Heights.

author: explorerx4
text: I remember see the Hasbrouck Heights sign.

author: fintail
text: The new fad of blinking CHMSLs is driving me nuts, the exact kind of idiotic pensive thing one expects to find on RAV4s, CRVs, Civrollas, etc - which is almost always where they are seen here. I've seen them on a couple new Dodge Journey (still in production?!!) too.

author: Michaell
text: Just another way for the dealer to reach into your wallet. My local VW dealer is charging $500 for that $10 piece of technology

author: fintail
text: Paranoid people will pay good money for the false pretense of "safety". Probably big with new hoverparents too.

author: berri
text: Personally, I think the whole dealership thing needs to be re-evaluated by the manufacturer's. They often more alienate, then inspire buyers. The manufacturers may be better off with small showrooms in retail areas where people can test drive a vehicle and order one directly. The trade in function can really be handled by the Carmax's of the world these days. Manufacturer's can also set up warranty contracts with repair shops they certify. It just doesn't seem essential in today's market to have large, costly dealerships and their often offensive F&I people.

author: bhill2
text: It's worse than that. A potentially costly innovation with dubious value? California will have a law mandating it within a year.

author: fintail
text:
Saw another Uterus today, or probably the same one, garish in white with black wheels and yellow calipers. Makes a AMG G look tasteful.

I could see idiot safety nannies mandating the blinking CHMSL.

author: laurasdada
text: There's a Urus in the showroom of my Jag dealer. Now, what was traded for a Urus??? Maybe it's the owner's, looking to flip.

author: fintail
text: Got behind an RX with a blinking CHMSL today, and not a minute later then got behind a Corolla with a blinking CHMSL. Most aggravating new feature I can recall, loathsome to the core.

author: sda
text: I havent seen many blinking CHMSL here, but Im sure we will. I havent looked at the dimensions but it looks like the new Corolla is bigger, like the current Civic.

author: berri
text: Something tells me that dealer add on blinker will be a problem down the road, especially in damp climates.

author: fintail
text:
Makes me want to get a hammer out and have fun.

New Corolla is an every day sight here now. Inoffensive, invisible, just what the demographic wants. Not as "bold" as other Toyolex design monstrosities.

author: berri
text: I don't know if Toyota is going to continue to get top dollar much longer. HyunKia is putting out very nice new stuff with a lot more value for the buck and Toyota, as well as Honda, don't have that prior big lead in quality and reliability anymore as others are closing the gap. I recently looked at a new Kia Telluride and it seems to really spank the Highlander and Pilot, both as a vehicle and as a value proposition.

author: stickguy
text: I have never seen a blinking 3rd brake light.

author: Michaell

author: imidazol97
text:
I've seen a few of those that blink 3 times and then switch to steady burn. I assumed they were manufacturer OEM on certain models.

The first car that I saw that did something similar was a Mercedes maybe 15 years ago. The taillights blinked once brighter than normal as the brake pedal was depressed. This is long ago, but it seemed I read something about that occurred if the brake was hit harder than average as in an emergency stop mode.

author: laurasdada
text: My first love, I mean, car. Ok, same thing!

author: texases
text: Same here, mine was a '79, black like this, stripe included:

author: sda
text: I always liked those, and they even had a plaid interior like the later GTI. Ive owned multiple VWs from 79-06. I had a good relationship with a VW salesman that I bought or referred to many times. When ever a new model would be introduced he would call or send me a note to come drive it. When the Corrado was introduced and had the supercharged engine I was excited to drive it. It was coarse and not very satisfying to drive and was expecting much more. What a difference the VR6 made!

author: laurasdada
text: My '78 was white over black, with Recaro seats. I was none too pleased that VW took styling in house for the second gen Scirocco, the exterior was a bit too bulbous for me. The most recent iterations look pretty good, though!

author: kyfdx
text: My biggest regret from 1977, is that I didn't steal $1000, so that I could get a Scirocco, instead of a Cobra II

author: texases
text: You can imagine the improvement in driving fun I had, coming from a '72 Duster with a 198 slant 6!

author: laurasdada
text:
But, Mustang 2, boredom 0!
I loved my Scirocco, as did rust. So light and tossable. Purty, too.

author: Michaell
text: I could've used that same $1000 in 1991 to get a Sentra SE-R, rather than the SE I ended up getting

author: ab348
text: I used to know a girl named Aura Lee who had a 2nd-gen Scirocco. Fun car, fun gal.

author: laurasdada
text: Bought the ex a '92 Sentra SE-R. Taught her to drive the stick, which carried over to the '95 Saab 900. Alas, that was the last stick for me/us. To this date...

author: stickguy
text: same here. $1k might have upgraded me from the 1985 Colt GTS (turbo package, sans turbo) to a GTI or Corolla SR5

author: thebean
text: Saw a TSX A-Spec today in Royal Blue with what looked like red interior. I was behind it at a stop light, so the interior color was a bit hard to see with the tint. Looked sharp.

author: Michaell
text:
My other choice in '91 was the Civic Si. However, insurance guy told me it would be more expensive than the Sentra.

In retrospect, I should have convinced the then-wife that we needed to spring for the SE-R

then-wife

Bad choices result in bad consequences

Speaking of new cars, I hate the payment, but 5 months in, I still enjoy driving the wagon. Maybe THIS will be the lease I buy out. We'll see.

text:
In Covington, KY.

McLaren. Not sure which one, but not the smallest one.

author: stickguy
text: getting delivered at the Hyundai dealer, a Kona electric. Probably this one.

author: laurasdada
text:
Where I work, the company owns the building & land (pricey suburb of Boston), four buildings. The times they are a changing; much renovation and shuffling of employees from four buildings to two. Other two are now renovated and being leased to other companies. These include an asset manager, a precious metals firm and Morgan Stanley branch.

This has had a fun effect on the parking lot; this morning, as I exited my car, I watched a very new looking, shiny green Bentley Continental GT convertible (grille looked bigger than me!) pull in to the Morgan Stanley parking lot, followed by a new looking BMW 7, M850 convertible and Audi A8.

Once again, my poor career choices are echoed in the cars that surround me daily!

author: thebean
text: @laurasdada - If you want to feel better about your career choices, go check out the employee parking lot of any retail establishment in the country.

author: andres3
text: Such as Wal-Mart.

author: laurasdada
text: Hey, I'm old. I may be parking in that employee lot!

author: thebean
text: Yesterday on I-40 in New Mexico, a recent vintage Challenger with a Charger Daytona high wing. Could not have been any more strange looking. Also, looked to have trim and wheels blacked out.

author: laurasdada
text: Within a couple of minutes, two Genesis G70, white and blue. Handsome, if derivative, beast.

author: Michaell
text: Isn't everything derivative, at this point?

author: fintail
text: Saw an Edge ST in traffic, along with an Audi Q8 (or maybe SQ) doing rich housewife duty at a Costco.

author: texases
text: On a trip to LA, saw a RR in photo camo wrap. Wonder why it was driving around Glendale in the morning rush hour??

author: fintail
text: Saw either a Ferrari F8 or late 488 today, freshly plated, don't remember the details to differentiate (similar window shape). I was in the fintail, driver gave me a thumbs up.

author: fintail
text: Also saw 3 Ford EcoSports in like an hour - they still seem somehow "off" to me, and I can't imagine who buys them, must be some deals (not apparent rentals).

author: Michaell
text:
I've spotted a couple of them in the past week or so, as well.

Yes, the proportions do seem odd.

author: ab348
text: Examined a Kia Niro up close today. It is nicely styled, better than the Sportage, and seemed to me to be almost the same size as the Caddy XT4 I drove this week, just a bit smaller I think. Interior was OK but certainly a lot more plasticky given the price point. According to reviews its biggest drawback is that it isn't very zippy. Only has something like 139hp/195 torque. If it had more power it might be a more appealing offering.

author: fintail
text: Older woman who parks near me in my building leases a Honda every 2/3 years, she's been around long enough where I've seen 3 or 4 cars. She just got a new one, moderate spec HRV. Apparently this one is a purchase.

author: ab348
text:
First pic I've seen of the upcoming Hyundai Venue, a subcompact crossover the size of the Nissan Kicks and others in that category:



Not sure that one is a great look with those colors.

It seems woefully underpowered with a 1.6NA engine delivering only 121hp/113torque via a CVT.

author: tjc78
text:
1.6NA engine delivering only 121hp/113torque via a CVT.

UGH

author: stickguy
text: My first new car was a 1985 Colt. 68 HP and 82 #/ft torque. Quite the rocket. Got around fine as long as you didnt mind downshifting a lot to pull hills on the Highway!

author: fintail
text:
What did that Colt weigh, like 1900 lbs?

I suspect this new rig weighs like 3700 lbs.

author: stickguy
text: About a ton probably.

author: Michaell
text: Venue - 2250 to 2730 lbs, from what the interwebs state.

i guess that's the Taycan?

text:
I also saw a black G Wagen. Don't see them often around here.
Also, new white BMW M 4, white Ford Explorer Platinum, black Tesla Model 3.

A Model 3 driving up the street, guy in passenger seat giving my truck the stink eye.

author: fintail
text:
Some of the Tesla demographic (around here anyway) would have me tempted to roll coal if I had the ability.

Instead, I can just drive my pre-catalyst and pre-emissions car, which might be the same thing

author: ab348
text:
This looks like tons of fun, but that price? Oy vey!

https://www.hagerty.com/articles-videos/articles/2019/10/29/secrets-of-the-2020-shelby-gt500-revealed

author: qbrozen
text: *choke*

author: fintail
text: Went car looking at the MB dealer while running an errand today. Nothing too unusual, but they did have a couple new GLS, which is a clear evolution from the old one. I sat in one, and didn't find the ICE hard to work with, which surprised me as I have read complaints (but I didn't talk to it). The touchpad made changing nav screen settings quite easy and intuitive, like working on a laptop. Funny thing though, the one in the showroom was an absolute base model, it even had a credit for "standard features not included" (I think maybe some ICE functions and fancier headlights). Never seen that on a MB sticker before. Fleet spec I guess, 73K sticker. But the one outside, filthy looking apparently from being on a car hauler, was quite loaded with an 89K sticker. The fancier one also had an interesting feature - open pore (matte finish) wood with a wood wheel. In the past, wood wheels were only for cars with shiny wood. New thing for 2020 I guess. I also notice on the E, finally, the widescreen digital dash is included with the first tier (virtually mandatory in prior years) premium package, which means the analog gauges, which are awkward to me, are effectively gone from the E.

author: fintail
text: Saw the upper-middle new Caddy SUV/CUV this morning, I've seen a couple in the past few days.

author: stickguy
text: Pointed an XT4 out to the wife (caddy palace shares a lot with BMW palace). Liked the color. Did not like front end at all. Might drive one anyway since they pay $50 too!

author: ab348
text: Geez, the front end is one of its most attractive features. It's hardly a Nissan Juke or an angry RAV4.

author: kyfdx
text:
Parked behind a Volvo XC40, this weekend. Told my wife it was really popular. She doesn't like it. I think it's that reverse kick-up on the C-Pillar, that doesn't look right to her.

I liked it.

author: andres3
text: I saw the large Acura sedan RLX???? , the rarest of sightings on the roadway. They must of sold all of these to people that never drive.

author: fintail
text: I always guessed they sold to people connected to dealerships.

author: PF_Flyer
text: Unusual spy shot from the testing of the new aeroscreen on the Arrow McLaren SP-Chevrolet. Not sure I've ever seen the "hide what it looks like" geometric patterns on an Indy car

author: stickguy
text:
dark red Mazda 3 hatch. Odd proportions in person. too bulky, and rear visibility must be non-existent.

also what I think was a new design Escape. Much different looking. Quick glance as we passed going opposite directions.

author: ab348
text: Have seen a number of those on the roads already, Mazda is inexplicably popular here for some reason. I agree with you, it is a very odd-looking design and visibility must be very poor to the rear.

author: laurasdada
text: Lamborghini Urus. Ok, I didn't spot it, but my brother in LA did, sent me a picture. O'Gara Lamborghini of Beverly Hills; looks like a fun place...

author: kyfdx
text: New BMW Z4 convertible. Great looking!

author: andres3
text: Not in person, but saw plenty of social media posts of photos taken from the Malibu Audi presenting the first 2021 Audi RS6 AVANT on US soil. Looks as good in pictures as did the marketing photos/video.

text: Odd sighting today. A Renault small white commercial van, a bit smaller than the Transit Connect. What it was doing in Texas and how it got here is anyones guess.

author: Michaell
text: Probably up from Mexico...

author: fintail
text: Saw a new G63 (green!) at the gas station (makes sense) driver fit local stereotypes.

text:

Sat in the 2nd row, huge door, which means a large window.
Looked out instead on looking in.

text:
I'm not sure we need yet another CUV, but here's one from Chevy:

https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/news/2021-chevy-trailblazer-la-auto-show

author: ab348
text: Didn't the old-timers way back when have homespun cures for gear whine? Sawdust? Banana peels?

author: fintail
text: New G-wagen in white, and there's a car sharing service (forget the name) using a parking lot near me, a number of new Mazda and Subaru.

author: qbrozen
text:
hopefully the end product looks better.

Gimme one with a twin-turbo 2.7 and it could be interesting.

text:
The shape of the window behind the C-pillar is awkward, to say the least.

But, I could see the Ford faithful adopting this; like @qbrozen noted, the 2.7TT could be a nice engine choice.

author: stickguy
text: I like the concept, being a fan of the OB. Style works for me.

author: stickguy
text: Recent flurry of new rangers near me, many on temp tags. Not sure why. Maybe a nice lease deal? Never driven one, but I love the way they look.

author: explorerx4
text:
Saw a Lambo and a McLaren dicing back and on the highway on the way home.
There was a lane between us when I got along side of them, me on the left, due to traffic.
Funniest part was some old lady in a Legacy nailed the gas, jumped into the lane between us and totally cut them off to get to the exit on the right.

author: explorerx4
text: In the parking lot at work, a black Palisade(not a huge fan o the styling, but looks better than i pictures) and a black Malibu.

author: stickguy
text: Too big for my taste, but both that and the telluride are striking designs for big barge CUVs.

author: tjc78
text: And get great reviews.

author: Michaell
text:
And are still selling for over sticker price - at least, for the top trim levels.

Makes for some really poor lease payments ($700's)

author: stickguy
text: They have gotten great reviews. But man, I realized how big they are when I saw a Santa Fe parked next to a Pallisade. Too big for me. But I can see why people like them. I did a dog placement interview for someone that had a new Telluride and they absolutely raved over it.

author: tjc78
text: Nice vehicle ... but why would you pay $700 for that when you could have an X5 or loaded XC90 for less monthly?

author: stickguy
text:
I would not be leasing one of them, so don't ask me!

I wonder what percentage of them are getting leased now? BMW I assume it is approaching 100% at this point.

author: tjc78
text:
Id bet its 50/50... some people just dont know leasing and shop for the best deal on a particular model.

I have a friend who does some wild things with cars and leased his wife a Ram. Pretty well equipped (high 50s) and when he told me the payment (in the 7s) I almost died. It was the first year of the new model and whatever edition/trim it was didnt have great incentives. I didnt go any further but I hope it was with zero drive off at least.

author: stickguy
text:
at least with the lease, even if it was not a good deal, you just make your payments for 3 years and end up at the same point. If that # fits your budget, just enjoy the car and don't think about it!

I would be shocked if the next one for us is a lease. And only if it is some wild deal where I can make the lease to buy #s actually work out (every time I have tried, it ends up cheaper to buy at the beginning).

author: ab348
text:
You want big? Check out the new Tahoe coming next year. I don't know for sure but it sounds nearly Suburban-sized. One wonders how big is too big in this segment...

https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/news/2021-chevrolet-tahoe-official-reveal/

author: stickguy
text: sounds much nicer. but even worse to me than the extra length, is the way they keep making the front ends so huge, tall and blocky.

author: tjc78
text:
The new Tahoe will be a big hit.... for sure. I like it.

Just think what the new Escalade will be like based off of it. GM is trying to one up the Expedition/Navigator that is apparent.

author: stickguy
text: New sonata. Man that is unique. Long and low. Looks like an Audi and a Citroen mated. Cant wait to see how that sells.

author: stickguy
text:
Also a new venue. Tiny little box, but not bad looking.

Did not get inside the venue or sonata.

author: tjc78
text: I like the new Sonata.... what I dont like is only 180HP. Is a higher output power train coming?

author: laurasdada
text: Was in LA for a few days, spotted a new...everything. Notably McClaren's and Ferraris, a Lambo Urus; 911 are to LA what 3 Series are to Boston. Driving on the 405, side by side with a Ferrari Portofino, a very handsome man eyed enviously my rented Kia Optima; probably mistook it for a Stinger.

author: stickguy
text: Not that has been reported. But always possible. In this class, probably not that important since most buyers go with the base motor anyway.

author: fintail
text: I've seen a number of Audi Q8 on the road in the past few days.

author: Michaell
text: I thought I had read somewhere that the new Kia optima was going to have a TwinTurbo engine with just under 300 hp. I wouldn't be surprised if the same engine found its way into the Sonata.

text: I just see a 2.5 L and 1.6 L turbo in the Sonata offerings.

author: Michaell
text: Could be a late release...

author: qbrozen
text: ...with FWD. a Korean Buick GS.

author: stickguy
text: those are the 2 engines. much different, but pretty close in HP. Different torque characteristics though I think. comparable performance I assume.

author: kyfdx
text:
The lower trims get 191 HP, NA engines, higher trims get 180 HP turbo engines.

Weird.

Guessing they have a supply issue for the turbo? Possible that the higher torque from the turbo translates to better acceleration?

author: kyfdx
text: First time ever, Honda Clarity. Then, an hour later, a 2nd one!

author: kyfdx
text: Also, new Volvo V90 wagon. I like that a lot

author: fintail
text: Funny how cars can still vary by region. Being on the west coast, I have seen countless Clarity. Kind of makes me think of a Japanese Citroen.

author: kyfdx
text: Yeah, not a fan of the aero fender skirts

author: kyfdx
text: Next door neighbors brother showed up with this.

author: tjc78
text: So they did sell more than one!

author: Michaell
text: Looks great from the outside; it's the inside that is disappointing, in my mind.

author: fintail
text: Maybe the only one in red?

author: kyfdx
