author: imidazol97
text: Actually I see a good number. I recall seeing two today.

author: jpp75
text: I still remember the one we sat in the auto show, the interior was so disappointing compared to the exterior. GM really needs to step it up with their interiors all around.

author: fintail
text:
I think I've seen maybe not many more than two total of the Buick wagon ever. Even more uncommon than an MB wagon, which probably costs on average 2.5x more.

GM once again taking a normal Euro market car and marketing it as near-lux, shades of the Catera (hopefully more reliable).

author: Michaell
text: Isn't 2020 the last year for the Regal? I know Opel is part of PSA now, and they are joining up with FCA, likely next year.

author: fintail
text: That's right, and I wouldn't be surprised if the same is true for the Holden/Opel/Vauxhall badged versions. China apparently might keep it, however. The PSA thing is pretty weird, unlikely partners, not sure if I see the "synergy", as drones would say.

author: Michaell
text: It is true. Read somewhere about the demise of the Commodore nameplate down under.

author: kyfdx
text: Spotted another Regal TourX, yesterday. They don't stick out so much in gray..

author: fintail
text: Saw a 6er GT in traffic yesterday, so they sold one!

author: tifighter
text: I found myself driving over one of our mountain passes in the X, along with an Urus and a Cayenne Turbo. It felt like there should have been some magazine comparison going on or something.

author: fintail
text: Sounds like the valet line at Bellevue Square (just need a Bentayga and AMG G)

author: laurasdada
text: Blue Porsche Taycan. On the dealer floor, very sharp. What the Panamera should look like. Locked, no Monroney.

author: explorerx4
text:
Yesterday, someone test driving a black Fiata convertible with the top down.
New record high temp of 68 degrees.

author: laurasdada
text: Two! Jag I-Pace.

author: fintail
text: Saw one of the upper-middle Caddy SUV/CUVs that kind of looks like a Volvo XC90.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new Escape on the road today. Not as offensive in person as in pics, probably because over time we are being numbed to yet another cloned CUV.

author: Michaell
text: I've seen a couple recently, as well. I'll admit it's a nice contrast to the sharp angles of the RAV4.

author: ab348
text: The nearby Ford dealer had a bunch of 2020 Escapes parked next to a bunch of 2019s. You could tell they were different but I cant say the new one looked better. Some aspects were, some werent.

author: stickguy
text: I saw an Escape tonight too. I think I actually prefer the RAV4 this generation. Mainly because I prefer a CUV to be a little boxy, for better space utilization in the cargo area.

author: fintail
text: Faux floating C-pillar on the RAV4 triggers me, and not in a good way. The Toyota corporate face does it no favors, either. Maybe not a surprise, I prefer the first gen, back when cars could be cheeky and fun.

author: tjc78
text: Now that I have to look at a RAV all the time in front of my houses (Moms) its really not that offensive. Its also light years ahead of the previous one in terms of the ride and drive.

author: stickguy
text: And looks. I might take a drive in a hybrid version if the wife likes it at the car show. Too bad they get crazy expensive for a nicely equipped one. Also looking at crv hybrid when they come out. But also pricey.

author: texases
text: Im also considering the RAV4 hybrid. I worry about Hondas bad record with hybrids.

author: fintail
text: CRV aint pretty, but I think I would prefer it. That C-pillar is just so dumb, I wouldn't be able to stop looking at it, and would probably paint it body color myself. Fortunately, I am not a bloggermom with sensible vehicle size tastes/retired 70 year old teacher/dad who has completely lost his freedom, so one isn't on my radar

author: fintail
text: Saw a black Rolls-Royce Cullinan today - what would Marie Antoinette drive? If the guillotines are (finally) ever dusted off, those things will be like a beacon.

author: sda
text: As much as the CRV is not a looker, it has great space management for its size and is comfortable and drives well. They have solid resale as well.

author: ab348
text: The CRVs turbo engine woes would concern me. Many older models up here suffered from premature rust out so badly that Honda had to buy them back. So who knows...

author: stickguy
text:
I was monitoring the gas in oil issue but not seen anything lately. So hopefully resolved, and pretty isolated anyway. I am curious about the differences for the hybrid too. But definitely something to consider. Not an issue really if we lease though!

I think it is pretty good looking, for what it is, and really like the interior. Nice seats, plenty of features, and good cargo room. Just have to see how it drives!

author: qbrozen
text:
I like the sound of guillotine for a car name. LOL.
Introducing the Lincoln Guillotine. Always ahead of its competition.

author: sda
text: I hear you. Rust and turbo woes I think are more of a northern cold climate issue. Rarely do we see rust in this area unless the vehicle is not local. Sun damage to paint and interior is more common. Often a one or two year old CRV isnt much cheaper than buying new.

author: stickguy
text: it has been a long time since worrying about rust was even on my new car consideration checklist. Just doesn't exist any more.

author: ab348
text: Clearly not the case in climates that use road salt, for certain makes.

author: imidazol97
text:
Or "the cutting edge" of auto luxury.
"Slicing to the top of its class."

author: fintail
text: 6er GT in white and a new style G-Wagen in white, I think it was a G63 (from a distance), seems harder than ever to find a non-bling G.

author: fintail
text:
As I am about to mark 10 months in the wagon, it finally happened - a near twin parked near me:



Not identical, as it is an E400 with sport trim, but similar enough. No shock, this was at Whole Foods (where I wanted to buy a $4 container of cheese I can't find elsewhere - and they were out, because of course). I see ab348 was there too.

author: tjc78
text: Ive yet to see an identical white S60 to mine. I did see a burgundy Momentum trim a few days ago.

author: fintail
text: I have yet to see my twin either - the wheels on my car will make that fairly difficult as they were an extra cost option that doesn't seem to be the most popular (but I like the design a lot, suits the car). I recall going through nationwide inventory when I got the car, and didn't find anything completely identical when it comes to interior trim and options.

author: tjc78
text:
When I was shopping there weren't many white on white Inscriptions. Not a high take rate I'm sure.

Love the wheels on your wagon. Similar to my car.

author: fintail
text:
Your car is in a great color combo, I wish the white/porcelain colors on MB were more common - I love the brown in mine, but white on white would have been pretty awesome, too.

Those wheels are also nice, a pretty design without the false pretense of sport. I don't want an aggressive design, I don't need to pretend to be exciting.

author: sda
text:
fintail said:
As I am about to mark 10 months in the wagon, it finally happened - a near twin parked near me:



Not identical, as it is an E400 with sport trim, but similar enough. No shock, this was at Whole Foods (where I wanted to buy a $4 container of cheese I can't find elsewhere - and they were out, because of course). I see ab348 was there too.

If I was a betting man, yours is the clean one at the far left.

author: fintail
text:
Yep. The wheels on my car are only available on "luxury" trim cars, which might be 1:10 of the production mix, if that.
sda said:

If I was a betting man, yours is the clean one at the far left.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new style G-Wagen in white, just after a final run style G also in white with the rare "night package" (black trim on fenders and roof). Both AMG of course, so hard to find a non-AMG model.

author: kyfdx
text:
Bentley Bentayga

Meh..

author: laurasdada
text: Yes, I've seen a few of the Bentayga, totally meh-worthy. I'd go Urus... Or, DBX when available. Of course, Powerball win first.

author: fintail
text: Went to Whole Foods again in search of a $4 piece of cheese never in stock, and saw 2x E wagons - one was the same I posted before, and also a dark blue one with ID plates. I suppose the car fits the store. Not new, but also saw an Eclipse Cross on the road, not a rental! Could have been an ex rental, or someone actually bought a new one.

author: fintail
text: Saw a Caddy XT5 "400", apparently they are badging for torque now.

author: explorerx4
text:
400 is a torque measurement, but not FT/LBS.
Maybe newton meters?

author: fintail
text: I believe it is n/m, yes. First time I have noticed the badge.

author: stickguy
text: A new Supra drove past my house yesterday. Sharp looking in person. And low.

author: qbrozen
text: I saw one yesterday or the day before, as well. Didn't seem too impressive in person. It was a dark gray. I actually, for a split second, thought it was just an FRS.

author: kyfdx
text: Saw one at the car show.. Roof looks tacked on. You can tell they built the car as a convertible (BMW Z4)

author: fintail
text: Not brand new, but I saw a blue G-Wagen 4x4x4x4x4x4x4x4x4x4 in city traffic today.

author: fintail
text: Saw a CX-30 today, it's a CUV. Also 2x Mazda3 super blindspot edition.

author: laurasdada
text:
Went to a Mazda CX-30 intro event at my local Mazda dealer Thursday night. Surprisingly large crowd (small showroom, though) and well catered; enjoyed a fabulous grilled cheese BLT, cheeseburger and crab cake sliders as well as cupcakes... Good swag, nice waterbottles and a few tchothkes.
CX-30 should be a winner, as I posted elsewhere a seemingly roomier and, to me, better looking 3.

author: stickguy
text: Sat in it yesterday. It was very nice and roomy enough to be comfortable. A little too small for us to use it as a primary vehicle.

author: texases
text: I followed a new MB E300 for a bit. Nothing unusual, but I've seen very few new E class. See lots of MB CUVs, of course, and a fair number of C class sedans, but very few E class sedans, which used to be their bread and butter.

author: fintail
text:
Not too surprised. The only data I immediately find, for Q4 2019, combined all car-type E variants (including CLS) with sales down 29.1% YOY. Meanwhile, GLE sales were up 45.9%. C-class car sales were down 12.7%.

It's the segment, apparently. 5er sales were down 34.6%, A6 only 3% (but less than half the volume of others), and Lexus GS sales down 44.1%, with a mere 808 units sold.

author: laurasdada
text: Geez, I'd better buy my new sedan while they still exist...

author: explorerx4
text:
@laurasdada,
I bought my MKZ because they are going to stop making them, but I didn't want an end of the run car.

author: tjc78
text: First one I've seen in the wild.

author: stickguy
text: Ive seen a bunch recently. A couple live near me. Must be selling some!

author: fintail
text: Saw a newish Model S today, pearl white with aftermarket wheels. I didn't hate it, somehow the package worked.

author: andres3
text:
I saw a new looking Mustang GT350 and it looked sharp and menacing. Not fake sporty menacing like a Hyundai, but real deal-like.

Don't see these actually being driven on the freeway like I did today. Rare sighting.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new Supra today, pulling out of a BMW dealer lot, which I found amusing.

author: explorerx4
text: 1985, oh boy.

author: stickguy
text: I love that neat design map light!

author: tjc78
text: I remember that map light as a kid. I cant remember if my Dads 86 Shelby Charger had or the 87 Shadow Turbo. Heck maybe both had it.

author: explorerx4
text: Sorry, I posted in the wrong thread, but glad it was enjoyed, like I did.

author: fintail
text:
My brother's first car was an 85 K-Car (ca. 1995), it or his Sundance Duster may have had that light, it's really familiar to me, as well.

Must have been an era for map lights. I remember my mom's Tempo had a map light on a stalk that was hinged on the roof like behind the rear view mirror/dome light area.

author: ab348
text: I must have missed previous chatter on this. It looks somewhat appealing. https://www.caranddriver.com/ford/fusion-wagon

author: qbrozen
text: Ill take a Sport model with 2.7TT, please.

author: tjc78
text:
So today was F8 Green Dodge day.

Saw the Trifecta.

Dealer tagged Durango
Charger
Challenger

What are the odds of seeing all three in this (rare) exact same color all with my favorite black wheels.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new unplated facelift Q7 today, at Whole Foods of course.

author: ab348
text: First pics of the new Hyundai Elantra:

author: texases
text: Nice, except for the 'keep out' bar between the passenger and driver...

author: explorerx4
text:
Over the weekend, at night, a new Sonata.
Easy to tell by the lighting.
The guy in the left left turn lane, in a few years old Sonata, was staring at it as it went by and didn't realize the light had turned green until he started getting honked at by the other cars in his lane.

author: fintail
text: Had to run an errand, had some cabin fever, stopped by the MB dealer for a lookie-loo. Nothing too exciting in the new section, I did notice a couple GLBs - MSRP in the low 40s, another niche is found, it's just substantial enough that it may sell. Used area was more interesting - brown 15 S63, magno (matte) grey E63 wagon with full carbon fiber package, 14 E63 sedan with wheels I've never seen before (multispoke usually seen in black, these were silver), 17 C43 coupe in rare diamond silver, a couple of G wagens (AMG, unfortunately, but one had a top line designo and carbon fiber interior). Also walked over to the Porsche lot, didn't see anything eletric, did see a pile of Cayenne coupes, a couple of leftover 19 911 turbos with "sale" prices of less than 10% off MSRP, likely rare XC90 Polestar in blue on the used side.

author: kyfdx
text: This..

author: stickguy
text: I could live with one of those. not the payments though.

author: imidazol97
text: Is that a Cincy photo? Under the Columbia Pkwy extension with P&G towers in the background?

author: fintail
text: Saw a white Supra on the road today, the new BMW one.

author: kyfdx
text:
Good eye.. Parking lot off Eggleston. That's one of the domes on the right, and I think the Deloitte building straight ahead (formerly, Chiquita building).

The photo is from my son, who was riding his bicycle over that way.

author: stickguy
text: while out walking earlier, got passed by a nice red Supra. to me, looks better in person than in pictures.

author: fintail
text: My new walking route takes me down what was known as "auto row" here, with 5 dealers still there I think (mostly AutoNation, because legalized monopoly). I noticed every Ford on the lot had its driver's window down an inch or two - dozens of cars. Some kind of Corona thing? Volvo had a bunch of S60s but all beigegrey save for one red (they have what seems like 100 XC cars at an offsite lot). Ford dealer also has a somewhat miled up but very clean and nicely basic spec older G-Wagen in the used car backlot.

author: andres3
text: Some people's RS6 orders might be delayed due to the Virus. 1st world problems.

author: fintail
text: My heart breaks for those poor souls.

author: fintail
text:
At the MB dealer now for the 1 year service on the wagon. I'm the only one waiting. Service adviser told me the techs are here just waiting for work, so it should be quick. No free food

There's a new non-AMG G-wagen sitting on the now-closed showroom floor. I'll probably saunter over and take a look.

author: fintail
text:
And it's locked, damn. Dark grey on dark grey/black designo manufaktur interior, multispoke wheels, non-AMG "plain" G550, 155K MSRP. Not my first color choice, but I like it otherwise.

I'm still the only customer here, which will be something to remember as this is a busy dealer.

author: fintail
text:
One other customer arrived as I was leaving, Service adviser said their daily bookings have gone from 100+ to ~10. He liked my car, too, asked if it was a custom order, complimented the condition.

Showroom was full, had something from almost every model IIRC. That grey non-AMG G would be my pick.

author: fintail
text:
I notice the Ford dealer on my walking route has a ton of Explorer STs in stock, seems like 20 or more, I thought those would be uncommon. Nothing else new seems unusual on my walking route past a few dealerships, other than the Caddy dealer having a crapton of new Escalades, the end of the line before the new model coming up.

I also notice the Ford dealer is shuffling used cars around every couple days, so someone is working somewhere.

author: Michaell
text: About half the requests I get for Explorers are for the ST trim.

author: fintail
text:
I walked by again today and didn't notice a single non-ST Explorer. I guess I assumed they'd be something uncommon.

Nothing else of note on the lot, Expedition supply seems high, but no doubt nothing is selling right now.

author: ab348
text: A lot of early reviews were mixed too.

author: explorerx4
text: Avalon TRD, even weirder than I thought.

author: tjc78
text:
The biggest problem I have with the Avalon is the front grill. I can't get past it and would never own that style because of it.

Having said that... I really don't mind the TRD treatment. It looks pretty sharp along the sides, even with the black wheels.

It is a bit of a sin to do all that work and not massage more power out of the engine. The 2GR is a pretty sweet engine as is, but a sport model should have more power.

To wrap up, this is not the first time Toyota did a sport Avalon. In 2005+ they had a Touring version with charcoal wheels, a spoiler and a stiffer suspension.

author: fintail
text: Hard to believe that Toyota made cars that had no excess styling.

author: laurasdada
text: Current version Ford GT; black with silver stripes. Perhaps a Patriot? (I live just down the road from Gillette Stadium).

author: explorerx4
text:
On a street that connects to my street a freshly washed Challenger Hellcat.
House usually has a parked Raptor in the driveway, not sure if the Challie is an add on.

author: ab348
text:
Was out just now picking up an online grocery order I made a week ago (almost like Christmas since you forget what you're getting!). Since the dealers are closed I stopped by a couple on my way home to look up-close at what I had only seen driving around until now.

There is a massive and posh brand-new VW facility here that just opened a little while ago, relocating from their former little steel building that dated from the 1960s. They have a lot more room to store inventory too. I wanted to look at the new Atlas Cross Sport. The regular Atlas never did much for me but these appeal to me a bit more. They had several in inventory but what caught my eye was one with a V6 in metallic red with a tan-and-black interior, very sharp. Seemed pricey to me though at $55K in worthless Canadian dollars. They also had a couple of new Golf R models on the front row, both black unfortunately.

Just next door was the Kia dealer run by the same group and the Seltos was in abundance. That is a really sharp looking little rig. They had one in a metallic green-gold that was a bit garish but sure caught the eye. There was one next to it in a dark metallic blue that I liked as well. Also saw my first Palisade up close and personal, too big for me but very nice.

My last stop was the Toyota dealer where they had exactly one new Corolla hatch. Nice enough inside but I hope they come in different trims than this one. Lots of Corolla sedans on the lot along with a huge fleet of various SUV/CUV models.

author: fintail
text:
Saw some high zoot newish Charger yesterday - had smoked license plate covers so dark you effectively couldn't see the plate, the worst I've seen. Daddy must be a cop.

Not new, but in my hour of outside time yesterday, I must have seen 10 G-wagens, apparently that group is getting out.

author: fintail
text: Saw my first new C8 on the road, white with roof panel removed. Amused me to see a late 70s model shortly after.

author: fintail
text: Saw a white Lambo Uterus on the road - not as Marie Antoinette as a Bentayga or Cullinan, but trying. Also a new style G-Wagen, AMG of course.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new style Highlander. Puffy, that's a nice way to put it.

author: fintail
text:
Blue seats!

Near twin to my car (but with fancypants upholstery)

author: tjc78
text:
I really dont get the G wagon. I honestly would rather have a Navigator or Escalade.

The wagon is beautiful

author: fintail
text:
The GLS is meant to go against the Slade or Navi. G is in a world of its own, kind of a mixed demographic comprising Kardashian types/Russian mafia/various money laundering or dynastic wealth types.

The wagon appears to be stock/configurator photos so far, but I'll probably stop by and look at it when it arrives, just because it is so similar to mine.

author: stickguy
text: Dont forget wealthy athletes. They buy a lot of them

author: fintail
text:
Those are Kardashian types

It seems AMG to non-AMG for late model examples is about a 95:5 - I'd want the non-AMG.

author: Michaell
text: G-class - for those who believe a Wrangler is too plebeian.

author: Michaell
text: Though, someone one the Wrangler lease thread mentioned an Unlimited with a $75k MSRP

author: tjc78
text: 75K? What?

author: fintail
text:
I'd rather have one G than 2 75K Jeeps.

They both have stupidly high depreciation floors, too. A nice 2002 G with 200K can fetch 25K.

author: Michaell
text: Probably $20K of dealer accessories on it - none of which can be residualized.

author: kyfdx
text: I think you can only hit about $59K on the Wrangler, without dealer installed items.

author: tjc78
text: Gotcha. Forgot about dealer installed stuff.

author: fintail
text: Lift kit, big wheels and tires, LED lighting, bullbar, winch, scotchguard, undercoating, ceramic paint treatment, chip protectant, window tinting, VIN etching, clip on plastic angry eyes to intimidate everyone in your cardboard 'n plywood subdivision or in the office campus parking garage where such things are most at home, it probably adds up.

author: fintail
text: Finally got my C&D with the E450 wagon long term wrap-up. Man, it almost read like a paid advertisement, they loved that thing. Makes me feel a little better about the monkey on my back. I am also suspect of the resale claim - I can't find a year old absolutely loaded one like that for anywhere near the claimed value. Even base ones are a bit pricier.

author: stickguy
text: Can you find one with 40,000 miles on it?

author: fintail
text:
Nope. But the claimed resale is 20K++ from what one could find a similarly equipped car. Those must be some expensive miles.

I suspect the depreciation algorithm is using a higher rate based on the prior gen E-class facing faster depreciation due to being a discontinued model.

author: stickguy
text: I have no idea what they are using for that. KBB trade? WAG?

author: laurasdada
text: During todays run, an orange McLaren. Not sure model of how new. But, surprisingly, it was faster than me. Probably more reliable, too.

author: fintail
text: ALG. Now that I think of it, I suspect maybe the option load isn't taken into account - I could see a more basic car with a value of their claimed 48K at those miles. But at such a young age, things like Designo, air suspension, driver's assist etc still add value.

author: ab348
text: Speaking of McLarens, here is a reminder that they do not mix well with deep standing water:

author: ab348
text: Allegedly, leaked pics of the 2021 M-B S-class via @earlsimxx on Twitter:

author: graphicguy
text: Looks like an Avalon interior!

author: driver100
text:
Where did they take those pictures...in a garbage dump?

That interior had great potential if they made the media system run flat across that flat wide area instead of a pop up screen behind the speedometer and one protruding from the console. Could have been the best interior design ever.

author: carnaught
text: Too much shiny finish and what's that bin behind the driver's side windshield? But, I kind of like it although I have an Avalon .

author: Michaell
text: I think it looks like a Toyota from the rear.

author: fintail
text:
Me no likey that steering wheel. I wonder if the gauge screen will eventually change into something else, looks kind of temporary, like something is being tested or maybe even there to fool spy shot photographers.

Facelift E also has a rear light treatment that seems Asian brand-inspired to my eyes, kind of Infiniti or Hyunkia-ish. It also gets the same headlight style as the A-class. I prefer the pre-facelift.

author: fintail
text:
Here's what they've done to the E:



Not a fan.

This comes to mind first:



And this:

author: stickguy
text: Nose looks like a genesis. Tail looks like an Accord, and genetic Asian design. Interior, just looks bad. Like parts falling off. Too much screen action.

author: explorerx4
text: It looks like the instrument cluster in front of the driver popped out.

author: fintail
text: This makes me think the wagon might be the one I buy, or maybe I'll buy an older model at lease end. Some of these styling elements do not please me, where to me the wagon is pretty much "just right", and I still like W212s as well. W222 S-class has also aged extremely well.

author: ab348
text: Fixed it for you.

author: ab348
text: According to the Twitter post, this was a preproduction test model and could not be sold so they always break them up for parts when they are done with them.

author: imidazol97
text: Does that trunk have a symbol that has a Lexus "L" on it?

author: fintail
text:
Good eye, imid, that appears to be the case. Good way to disguise your prototype/test mule - give it another badge.

Speaking of prototypes, I spotted this on the road in Stuttgart in 2015 - current E-class:

author: ab348
text: Fixed my fix.

author: imidazol97
text:
I know I'm not the target audience, but there's nothing about that rear that says, "Mercedes Benz" to my eye.

The prototype in the decomposition yard said "Kia " to me.

author: fintail
text:
Did my 2021 E rear end pic not work? Guess one needs to save 'n upload to be safe.

I think MB is losing some design identity. What really irks me about the E facelift is that the E loses a unique headlight design, something it retained for decades.

author: ab348
text: The picture you posted seemed to be missing some message board hieroglyphics and just showed the word "Image" on here so I added the missing bits. It let me see it here the first time but this morning it was gone again, apparently the victim of a linking ban from the source. So I downloaded it from your link and uploaded it to a photo storage site to post that version here

author: fintail
text:
Weird, I had no idea, as it loaded in my browser - must have something to do with being cached in.

Thanks for the fix

author: ab348
text:
Toyota announced the return of the Venza yesterday after being out of the market since 2015. Slots between the RAV4 and Highlander but seems to be built on the RAV platform. Not as offensive-looking as many new Toyotas.

https://blog.consumerguide.com/first-look-2021-toyota-venza/

author: qbrozen
text: I always thought the Toyota Edge... I mean Venza... was a good idea. Not sure why it didnt sell better. Was a great used value for a while there.

author: stickguy
text:
I liked those too. a little goofy looking (lifted and chopped at the same time, like a short person on stilts?) I do recall also it looked a bit off since they were an early adopter of oversized wheels (I think 20's) and that was a weird car to pick.

but, I agree that they needed a "momma bear" option. When we were shopping recently, I did look at Toyota. Wanted to like the RAV, but it was just a little bit too small. and the Highlander had some nice touches, but was definitely too big. So if they can slot in a 5 passenger with a bit more space and comfort, should be popular.

It is actually pretty good looking to me. and this factoid was interesting: Venza will differ from every other U.S.-maker crossover in that it will be available only as a hybrid and only with all-wheel drive.

author: tjc78
text:
My Mom had a Venza. Silver over grey. Nicely equipped but 4cyl. It was basically an Avalon station wagon with a mild lift.

She loved it, and her only complaint was poor visibility.

It was as reliable as a Timex never needing a thing.

author: stickguy
text: new one looks like a bit toned down Lexus RX. and 219 HP from the hybrid powertrain with 40 combined MPG. Seems like a winning package to me.

author: kyfdx
text: My neighbor still has the Venza they bought new... Maybe 10 years old?

author: Michaell
text: When we bought the Outback in 2015, we briefly toyed with the idea of getting a Venza. The Toyota and Subaru dealers were next to each other, so on the way to test drive the OB, we swung through the Toyota dealer for a look. Drove past one - the wife took one look at it and said "nope".

author: ab348
text: That might be the first Subaru ever sold on the basis of styling.

author: fintail
text: I always called the Venza a Camry wagon - it wasn't bad looking at all. New one is kind of derpy, as one expects from the brand these days. Gotta have that C-pillar beltline upkick for "character", "dynamism" and to reduce visibility for a driver demographic who needs all the help they can get.

author: Michaell
text:
If it hadn't priced out at $10k more, we both liked the Volvo XC70.

The Outback has aged well, in my eyes. The new iteration isn't all that different looking.

author: fintail
text: I saw a copy of the 2021 E-class dealer ordering guide - the "luxury" trim package (traditional grille, hood star) is being dropped for the facelift. Maybe this car will be the one I buy - I greatly enjoy the hood ornament.

author: andres3
text: I noticed what seemed like a Saab/MB/Audi junk yard car lot in Borrego Springs desert and unforgiving sun. A few of the MB's were thought worthy of a car cover, but the sun beats down on everything, and that hood ornament is usually the first breaking point in a car cover, and most of them were sticking out as it creates a stress/tension point in the car cover, which is where it'll fail first under the hot sun.

author: fintail
text: On that note, I cover my old car, and remove the hood ornament before covering it. Not to preserve the cover (which isn't very tight), but to preserve the hood ornament spring - I've had a floppy hood ornament before, it is irritating, and somehow I remember it being a pain to replace.

author: fintail
text:
Can't wait to see this on the road, what is it, an Edsel-Lexus hybrid?



I guess some stylists defected from Lexus.

author: Michaell
text:
I think we should all remember, with some fondness, the grief Acura got for their "beak"...

If this is the new corporate look for all BMW's going forward, count me out...

author: stickguy
text: That is just godawful. And the rest of the car looks so good!

author: explorerx4
text: New BMW grille, Doubles as a waffle iron!

author: laurasdada
text: Perhaps it will get the Acura beak reaction, and a change will be swifter than Acurs's was. Vote with your wallet!

author: fintail
text:
It keeps getting better:



The canards lol, and look under the grille and try not to see a mouth, it has a face.

author: tjc78
text: Awful grill and black wheels, whats not to love?

author: texases
text: I saw a new NSX yesterday. Maybe the second I've seen. They can't be selling many, I live all of 3 miles from an Acura dealer.

author: ab348
text:
Nissan announced the new Rogue today. Slightly smaller, chunkier/boxy looking.

https://www.thetruthaboutcars.com/2020/06/bread-and-butter-update-2021-nissan-rogue-brings-brawnier-body-and-a-way-to-spend-more/

author: tjc78
text: Wow... that's now a Nissan RAV4. Pure and total knock off, even the interior

author: stickguy
text:
Nice Hyundai nose on it!

But, overall, I actually like it. Vast improvement over the old model.

author: ab348
text: The looks immediately reminded me of a bulked-up Hyundai Venue.

author: fintail
text:
Yeah, the Hyundai is comically apparent. But the prior one was so old, something needed to be done.

It'll be interesting to see how an assumed decrease in fleet sales hurts the brand in the short term.

author: tjc78
text:
I can see some Hyundai in the front for sure, but there is a lot of current gen RAV as well.

Cant blame them, the RAV is selling well

author: andres3
text: However, the RAV 4 is known for being able to withstand anything the world, nature, or mankind can do to it, and still run reliably.

author: fintail
text: Also one of those cars I might give a wide berth in traffic - around here seems to have a knack for either loaf ing along at 5 under or making a random wild unsignalled turn from the far lane.

author: stickguy
text: Could be an interesting lease option a year from now!

author: andres3
text: I wish Actuarial data was made public by Insurance companies. How is it Geico can charge $600+ per 6 months for collision coverage on my TTS with 1,000 dollar deductibles and only 6K miles per year, while another company only upcharges less than $200? Of course, Geico's base price is $600 less so they win; I just self insure on the TTS and get Comprehensive protection only, along with a whopping $3,500 in uninsured property protection. The same $3,500 that existed 20 years ago. You'd think someone in government would have used an inflation calculator by now!!!!!

author: fintail
text:
I swear a Model Y just drove by my window. Kind of like a 3 but more egg/potato-like.

Saw a couple CT5 on a car hauler along with some kind of 2er and leviathan X7.

Not new, also saw an SLS Roadster with commercial plates, which made me think "brave tax-dodging bootstrapper" (such plates are not for rentals here).

author: vunirodo
text: organize a video. it can turn out to capture it!

author: ab348
text:
A walkaround and sit-in (no driving impression) of the 2021 Hyundai Elantra:

https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/videos/the-2021-hyundai-elantra-is-a-bold-move

The reviewer is a bit of an apologist but even at that his comments about the styling themes and resultant trade-offs re headroom and visibility are worth noting. I just dunno about this one...

author: explorerx4
text:
Just a few from my trip to Ohio and back since Thursday.

Merc GLB. Looks better than the pictures. Can't say the same for the driver. Hung on my rear left for too long after I pulled over to let them pass, so I pulled back left and they got to find out how their auto braking worked.
Hopefully they knew it was a feature. Didn't bother me after that.

New Escape, was surprised how much the back looked like the previous gen other than the rear lights.
If you only look at the read lights, it looks like a RAV 4.

A red Stelvio, Red was not Italian enough is all I can say.

My favorite, an SL55 AMG. Poking along behind a 18 wheeler on I-81. Driver had a huge cigar in his mouth.

author: stickguy
text:
In a neighbors driveway, a new MB GLS. Long SUV. At least has clean styling, looks like a suburban. Probably roomy inside, but the rear doors were super long. Looked abnormal, like they were stretched. Could get ugly when kids start shooting them open in a parking lot.

Quite the barge.

author: stickguy
text: 450. In white. Was parked next to an Audi Q5 and made it look like a Dinky toy.

author: kyfdx
text: I always thought those were Tahoe sized, more or less.

author: stickguy
text: Just looked it up. 205 long. So right around Tahoe length, but interestingly on a much longer wheelbase. Still big.

author: explorerx4
text: Those MB SUV's are really that big. There are several in our neighborhood.

author: Sandman6472
text: See them all over South Florida but MB's and BMW's are very popular down here. Audi's, not so much, but starting to see more of them. Or A3 now has around 55K and except for wanting an extra quart of oil very now and then, has been flawless. Sure, it's already had two batteries replaced under warranty and a new set of sneakers, but much more trouble free then my Golf has been. Part of me wants to just take it over once she wants to trade it in but not sure I really would want a sedan to be honest. I want a new hatchback but now that the current oil leak is fixed, holding on a bit even though the axle boots are both in need of repair. But to buy something new when my commute is down to 21 miles/week just doesn't make sense right now. Even though it's a great time to buy if one does have the $!! Love the 0% financing to be honest and the delayed 1st payment period but what to buy is the question.

author: laurasdada
text: Two Maserati QPs (current) within 5 minutes yesterday. Perhaps a 2 for 1 sale at the local dealer?

author: explorerx4
text: A Cadillac XT6. Front looks distinctive, rest is pretty generic.

author: tifighter
text: So here's a funny one, I saw a Dacia Duster truck just outside of Seattle when I was coming back from Mt. Rainier yesterday. I didn't get a chance to see the plates, but I'd like to know what it was doing here.

author: fintail
text:
Dacia Duster exists in Mexico as a Renault Duster, maybe MX plates? Or a diplomat car from one of the few embassies that isn't there to flaunt money, or maybe a testing car?

I've seen several Mexican plated cars in WA before.

author: Michaell
text: I see quite a few in CO, as well.

author: fintail
text:
Saw my first new Defender actually on the road, this one had the 'look at me' sidemounted luggage (pannier for cars?).

I wonder if they are carrying an ADM - the bootstrapping bougie once a year skier occasional hiker (prefers paved trailheads) rough and tumble eastsider outdoorsperson set around here should be lining up right now,

author: laurasdada
text: 97 sunny degrees today. So, naturally my thoughts turned to wandering closed on Sunday new car lots, local MB/Porsche/Acura/Audi. On the Audi lot, two new E-Tron Sportbacks. My initial thought? Looks like a pregnant A7 on stilts. YMMV.

author: stickguy
text:
Down in expensive house land (jersey shore, sadly we can only afford to rent). Car spotting heaven. A few black walk, many newer 6 figure cars. Pretty e450 convertible. Lots of other big MB. pretty M4 convertible. Range rovers dime a dozen.

One house had a new Bentley SUV and a drop dead gorgeous newer Bentley convertible. Dark blue with brown top. I figure the 2 card alone were close to 400k sticker.

author: fintail
text:
Spotted a new style G-Wagen towing a little Airstream trailer today.

Maybe 1:10000 G-Wagen on this continent actually do more than visit a gallery mall/office building/questionably purchased house, so maybe 1:100000 new ones.

author: tjc78
text: See my post if C&C. Was in Margate today. Expensive iron everywhere. Lambo and Ferrari land.

author: stickguy
text: Saw that. Sounds like SH. my son saw something about a house listed cheap. Lowest price single on the island. I think small, needs work. Listed at something like $1.2mill. The cars are no surprise.

author: Michaell
text: Drove past my neighbors house yesterday, and found 2 McLarens parked in the driveway. I guess he alternates between them to keep the miles down.

author: ab348
text:
A rather glowing review of the new Toyota Venza on Roadshow today. I will need to be convinced on the hybrid drivetrain, but I like what I see otherwise, especially the interior.

https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/reviews/2021-toyota-venza-preview/

author: texases
text: If there's any hybrid drivetrain worth getting, it's that one. And I think the Venza is the best looking Toyota, close to the Mazda CX-5.

author: tjc78
text:
Good looking SUV except for the front, but since its a Toyota thats a given. From the rear profile it almost has the shape of the first generation RX300.

I wouldnt be surprised if my Mom gets one of those in two years when her RAV goes back.

author: stickguy
text: back from a week at the shore. car spotting heaven. at least 5 new Excursions (plus a Navigator). Popular beast for the well to do beach house crowd! A pair of GL63 hunchbacks. one in cement. along with a new 911 targa (I think based on the roof style). 2 different cement colored Raptors. temp tag panamera just street parked on a busy road. more Wranglers (mostly customized) than at a Jeep dealer. assortment of big MBs. M3 and M4 BMWs (plus an X7). Couple big Bentleys. An Aviator. Masser convertible.

author: tjc78
text:
What about Tahoes and Yukons! They are pretty popular here in Sea Isle

I think I mentioned it before but the amount of Wranglers is unbelievable. It could be 1 out of 4 cars here at the campground.

author: explorerx4
text:
@stickguy,
You mean Expeditions? Excursions haven't been made for many years.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new 911 cabrio driving down my mom's small town street this morning - car probably cost more than the value of almost any house on the street, things change fast in the PNW when you get a certain distance away from the interstate. Also a couple new Telluride in town, interesting as the nearest Kia dealer is an hour away.

author: Michaell
text:
Saw an article on the Telluride - Kia dealers have, on average, a 15 day supply of them. Still selling for over MSRP.

What's odd is that the Hyundai variant can be had with a discount from sticker.

author: sda
text: I am seeing a lot of both, but more of the Telluride around these parts. New Pilots and Highlanders not so much.

author: fintail
text: The Kia is better looking IMO, that could be part of it.

author: ab348
text: The Telluride is impressive looking while the Hyundai looks just like a bigger Hyundai SUV. I browsed Kia Canada's website yesterday and looked at the Telluride. To get what I would want (a light-colored interior) I needed to select the top-line trim at $54K + taxes/fees. That a lot of money for a Kia even in worthless Canadian dollars.

author: stickguy
text: yeah, sorry. Got my E class barges mixed up! the new design ones. Not bad looking though. but the size of a bus.

author: stickguy
text: a couple of Suburbans were floating around. Really no Tahoes that I recall. Plenty of Audi's though.

author: explorerx4
text:
@stickguy,
Probably thinking of a Hoovies episode.

author: fintail
text: Hey, in the past 6 weeks-2 months or so, as Murka founders under questionable authority and even worse long term planning, the loonie and Euro have made decent gains.

author: fintail
text: Oddball newish car - new style Altima owned by someone across the street from my mom. It was here when I visited a couple months ago, and I paid little attention to it, but walked by it and noticed it is unusual - loaded Platinum AWD model. Surely many don't exist like that, given the fleet nature of the car. Also odd in that the nearest Nissan dealer is at least an hour away.

author: benjaminh
text: A while ago I saw a VW Arteon. The rear quarter window treatment for this car seems unique and very good, providing interesting styling with flush glass, as well as better rear visibility.

author: texases
text: That's the best rear window I've seen in a long time.

author: stickguy
text: overall looks a lot like an Accord.

author: benjaminh
text: But the VW Arteon gives you better rear visibility than the somewhat more thick pillars in the Accord. I assume there are some advantages to the Accord design, since almost all cars use something like this, rather than the very thin dividers found in the Arteon. I assume it adds structural strength.

author: ab348
text: I think the Accord design makes for a shorter (front to back) rear door window which allows it to roll down into the door. The Arteon door glass and structure looks like the glass might just fit when it rolls down or it may have an articulating window regulator. Both are far superior to the very awkward design c/w black plastic triangles in the C-pillar that GM used on the outgoing Buick Regal and the current Cadillac CT5, which should never have been let out of the design studio.

author: sda
text: The Arteon is a hatchback, nicely styled. Too bad they are too expensive. A base model is mid $30s. Depreciation could be significant making it a good used buy.

author: laurasdada
text: I think it was Car and Driver that , in a review, called the Arteon a great car that no one will buy.

author: Michaell
text: Agreed. It is sharp looking, in person, but when you get into the top trim levels that price out in the mid $40's, you begin to seriously think about an A5 Sportback.

author: andres3
text: Or a Golf R.

author: benjaminh
text:
Here's the structure underneath the new TLX. That pillar near the back window looks sturdy.

I know the Honda Accord is built to something like 4 times the federal roof crush standard, and I'm sure Acuras are the same way, if not even stronger. It might be that VW with that cool design was fully meeting the roof crush standard, but maybe not exceeding it by as large a margin?

author: stickguy
text: pretty cool!

author: benjaminh
text:
https://www.iihs.org/ratings/vehicle/volkswagen/arteon-4-door-hatchback/2020

The Arteon does meet all the IIHS standards.

author: explorerx4
text: No pano roof for that design.

author: stickguy
text: a regular moonroof on a sedan is fine by me.

author: fintail
text: Visited the high end car electronics shop to get a new adhesive piece for my dashcam (they gave me some 3M tape for free, then I found I can buy the OEM pieces on Amazon direct from the maker for very little) - in the workshop was a Cullinan, some kind of Lambo with lots of garish paint accents, and different yet more stylish, a 61 Impala.

author: kyfdx
text:
Chevy SUV with temporary tags.. Smaller than an Equinox, but not a Trax.

Trailblazer? Decent looking.

author: stickguy
text:
Blazer? Just a butch body equinox. Might look smaller. Unless it was the smaller trailblazer.

Would be nice if Chevy didnt use confusing names like that. I guess tesilblazer is a lot smaller, so a bulked up trax?

author: Michaell
text:
Yep, Trailblazer.

Comes with an in-line turbo 3-cyl.

author: qbrozen
text: I had no clue that Chevy XC40... I mean Compass.. I mean Venue ... ugh, I mean Trailblazer was even a thing.

author: stickguy
text: I didnt either until I googled it.

author: Michaell
text: And you call yourselves car enthusiasts?

author: andres3
text: Coming soon...a Spark SS

author: qbrozen
text: seriously, take your pic. Can barely tell the difference.

author: fintail
text:
Faux butch, a representation of society. Hyundai and Chevy even have very similar rear door/C-pillar areas.

Faux floating C-pillar, please go away.

author: sda
text: I havent been impressed with what Ive read about the new 3 cylinder turbos from Ford and GM. They seem to be rough runners and coarse sounding, with little or no gas mileage improvement.

author: qbrozen
text: The Ford is far from new, though. I wanted to try one in the Fiesta back in... oh boy... ummm... 2015? 2016? But they were very hard to come by. My thinking was that, eventually, you could tune it and beat the pants off the larger NA engine.

author: stickguy
text: at least the Volvo has really good seats, and is built like a tank.

author: explorerx4
text: Ford had a 1.0 ltoer 3 cyl in the Fiesta. The current 3 cyl is 1.5 liter.

author: explorerx4
text: How good are Chinese tanks?

author: tifighter
text: I hope we never find out.

author: fintail
text: Saw my first Model Y loaded up with PNW outdoorsy cosplay gear - this one a kayak on the roof. 50/50 at best chance it actually sees water.

author: Michaell
text:
Given the popularity of Tesla here in Colorado, I'm surprised I haven't seen a Model Y yet.

Wife's cooking studio has a regular customer who drives a Model X - she thinks the falcon wing concept is a bit dorky.

author: fintail
text:
I've seen maybe 10 of them now, but this area is ground zero for the brand and its demographic, my specific area especially.

I think the doors are cool to look at, but the practical value is limited - it's a show-off/ego trick.

author: fintail
text: Saw a Lambo Uterus on the road today, by the young driver no doubt the product of being the second coming of Horatio Alger or similar.

author: sda
text: What a horrible name for just about anything.

author: ab348
text: The actual name is Urus. Almost as bad but not quite. According to Wiki, the name comes from the Urus, the ancestor of modern domestic cattle, also known as the aurochs. With Lambo's logo being that of a bull, one can make the connection at least.

author: stickguy
text: thats not the actual name

author: fintail
text: I wonder what "fancy Audi" is in Latin

author: qbrozen
text: Except for an actual uterus. I mean, if you have a Lambo uterus, thats gotta be good, right?

author: kyfdx
text: It isn't really a Uterus...

author: stickguy
text: saw a Porsche with a weird rump today. Thought it was maybe a new Cayenne, but after looking online, might have been a Taycan Turismo.

author: explorerx4
text: Pretty sure one of the neighbors bought a 911. It was sitting in the driveway with no plate visible and today his X5 is parked outside the garage.

author: fintail
text: Saw a new Defender with the look at me! rear quarter window pannier. No front plate, we don't want to ruin the look of such a stunner (and it's not like someone buying in that price range is going to get a ticket for it anyway).

author: kyfdx
text: The basic Defenders are a lot less expensive than I thought they would be.

author: fintail
text:
I wonder if they have a stated MSRP vs reality issue. The two I spotted at the local dealer were both in the upper 70s, and no panniers or apparent ADM. But a quick google claims base around 50K.

Still one of the coolest vehicles from the brand I guess, as to me the Disco has weird proportions and the others seem to be magnets for oblivious or entitled drivers.

author: texases
text: I cannot fathom the panniers.

author: tifighter
text: This made me go build a Defender for fun. $60,405 as I'd want it. You can only configure the 110 right now, but I do like the 90.

author: fintail
text: Saw a 2021 GLA on the road, a "little egg" I suppose.

author: ab348
text:
Because nothing succeeds like excess, presenting the new Jeep Grand Wagoneer:





You get a screen! And YOU get a screen! And YOU get a screen...



Expected to exceed $100K apparently.

https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/news/jeep-grand-wagoneer-luxury-plug-in-hybrid/?bhid=25416315718523622077081880631938&cid=534354260&ftag=CAD13782fc&mid=13024553

author: stickguy
text:
looks like a compass on steroids.

hideous in and out.

will probably sell like hotcakes

author: kyfdx
text: Looks like its based on a Durango. (but, probably not)

author: omarman
text: ...and when your screen fails you lose all its functions, and you too, and you three!

author: ab348
text: Apparently it is based on the Ram 1500 pickup truck.

author: texases
text: But modified to have independent rear suspension. Can't compete with the Navigator or Escalade without it!

author: fintail
text:
Excursion for the new age.

Makes me think of this:

author: tjc78
text: This

author: fintail
text: Saw a new 8er GC on the road, have only seen one at the dealer until now. I wonder if the change to "8" was to woo a specific market segment.

author: laurasdada
text: White Porsche Taycan, first I've seen in the wild. Sharp, much more attractive than the Panamera, imo.

author: stickguy
text: passed me at a light today, a nice looking RR coupe (the new version). Imposing car. You see some stuff like this when you live in a town where a number of the local pro athletes live.

author: fintail
text: Saw a C8, light blue that would look at home on a 1958 model.

author: stickguy
text: out driving yesterday, a new RR. The big coupe. .Imposing car, but definitely ostentatious.

author: fintail
text: Saw another new Defender today. Going to be a smash hit around here.

author: explorerx4
text:
Saw this while out for my walk.
There are loaners, then there are loaners.

author: tjc78
text:
Wow that's pretty obnoxious!

I saw three new Trailblazers yesterday. Nothing bad about them, but at the end of the day so similar to the Equinox.

author: ab348
text:
They are really pretty small in comparison. Sure you weren't seeing Blazers?

I looked at a Trailblazer on a dealer lot and the front seat cushions (and overall front seat space) seemed really narrow.

author: imidazol97
text: Ohio just quit requiring a front license plate after decades of having one required. A few people complained so often... and the legislators gave in. What will the inmates do since they only have to make half as many new plates?

author: fintail
text:
Front plates have been a thing in WA since forever, and I doubt it will change. Always amuses me how there isn't a national policy on this, but I guess states rights - unless certain people are offended, of course.

I don't know how stringently it is enforced, at least locally, for people above a certain socio-economic line though. It seems most upmarket sporty/exotic cars and a huge amount of Teslas (not the same thing) lack a front plate, and it doesn't matter.

author: fintail
text:
That's a heck of a loaner. Local dealer uses mostly C and GLA.

Some dealers use big window banners here, some are discreet.

author: imidazol97
text:
The lack of front plate makes it more difficult for law enforcement to find cars on wanted list, if they still have the correct plates on the car. The front plates on cars make it easy for states like Florida to ID that a car approaching slightly over the limit is out-of-state and is fair game for a quick profit.

For a long time here in a lower income community most cars had only one plate. The question I asked was what car is the other plate on: it was sort of a buy one get one free for plates on your car. Okay as long as you don't get stopped for something in the car to which the plate is not registered.

author: fintail
text:
Yep, there's definitely valid reasoning behind it, and front plates are mandatory in all other first world locations (that I know of anyway). I guess I'd just like to see more logical mandates in this part of the world, and consistency in terms of enforcement.

Funny, as I am pretty sure cars with vintage or year of manufacture plates here only need one at rear. I guess if one is going to commit crimes, use an old car

author: kyfdx
text: Indiana and KY don't seem to have any issues with one plate.

author: stickguy
text: Jersey I doubt ever changes. We have 2. But PA next door is only 1.

author: tjc78
text: No they were Trailblazers, in all honesty they didn't look that much different to me. Quick Google action says it's about 10" shorter so not all that much different.

author: andres3
text: I doubt it makes it any more difficult for law enforcement than ticketing a speeder going 86 MPH vs. one going 85 MPH does. Front plates are not justified even for the extra weight, extra gas usage/waste, and extra emissions due to that extra weight they create, and that's very little, but still not justified. Lower taxes, 1/2 the amount of plates we have to pay for! 1/2 the aluminum we have to waste.

author: imidazol97
text: Other than that, how do you really feel about front plates, Andres?
